title: 1 Samuel 1:1–8
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 1:1–8 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 1:1–8 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 1:1–8 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

The book of 1 Samuel tells the true story of Israel during the time when the Israelites changed from judges leading them to kings leading them. The Bible describes the period of time when judges ruled Israel as a time when the people did not all agree on the right way to live. Instead, "everyone did what was right in his own eyes." The first part of the first book of Samuel tells how Samuel was born and how Yahweh called Samuel to serve Yahweh, to judge Israel, and to appoint Israel's first king. At this time, the ark of God, the symbol of Yahweh's presence with his people, was still in a region of Israel that people called Shiloh.

The storyteller says, "There was a certain man." This is the way the Israelites would often begin a true story about a real person who lived in the past. This man was from Ramathaim, or Ramathaim-Zophim, which shows that Ramathaim, sometimes called Ramah, was in Zuph. Zuph was the region of hills where the Ephraimites lived. Ramathaim means "two heights" or "two hills." Some versions say the man was an "Ephrathite." This could mean the man was descended from the tribe of Ephraim or that he was from the city of Bethlehem. Most versions say the man was descended from the tribe of Ephraim, one of the 12 tribes of Israel. In the book of 1 Chronicles, the Bible lists Elkanah as a descendant of Levi. Since the Levite tribe of Israel did not receive any land, the Levites lived in the lands of other tribes. Elkanah might have lived in the area of the Ephraimites even if he was a Levite.

Stop here and share a story about a real person from your community who lived in the past but is no longer living. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a map of Ramathaim and the region of Zuph. Pause this audio here.

The man is a Zuphite, which means he is from the region of Zuph. Some sources say the name Elkanah means "God has created a son," while others say it means "God bought." Because Elkanah was a real person, the author also gives the names of Elkanah's ancestors, Jeroham, Elihu, and Tohu, going back to Elkanah's clan leader, Zuph. Some of these names are a little different in other parts of the Bible. The people called the area Zuph after their clan leader, Zuph.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do people in your community keep a record of the names of their ancestors? How do you name the different areas of your language group? Pause this audio here.

Elkanah had two wives. When God created the first man and woman, God also created the pattern for marriage to be between one man and one woman. Even though the Israelites knew that marriage should be between one man and one woman, sometimes men would marry more than one woman if the man was wealthy. One of Elkanah's wives was called Hannah, which means "grace" or "favor with God," and the other wife was called Peninnah, which might mean "Pearl" or "Coral." Some translations call Peninnah the second wife. Peninnah had children, but Hannah did not. In this part of the world at this time, it was very important for men to have sons, because only sons could inherit the man's property. It was more common for a man to marry a second wife if the first wife could not have children.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Who can marry each other in your community? How many people can be married to each other? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Who can inherit a man's property in your community? Tell a story about a woman who was not able to have children. Pause this audio here.

Now, this man, Elkanah, used to go up every year from his home city, Ramathaim, to Shiloh. When the author says Elkanah went "up," it is because Shiloh was on higher ground than Ramathaim. Elkanah went up to Shiloh each year in order to worship Yahweh. When someone worshipped in that time, the person would usually get down on their knees and touch their forehead to the ground to show honor and respect to Yahweh. The person would also offer sacrifices and eat a feast. Elkanah feasted with his whole family, including Elkanah's wives and children. The Israelites held several feasts each year, but this story does not say which feast Elkanah's family celebrated at this time. The Israelites kept the tabernacle and the ark of Yahweh in Shiloh at this time in their history. Eli's sons, Hophni and Phinehas, were acting as priests for Yahweh in Shiloh. Elkanah worshipped "Yahweh Almighty" or "Yahweh of hosts," which can also mean "Yahweh of Armies." This title might refer to Yahweh's great power or to Yahweh's authority over everything that people can see and also what they cannot see, both on earth and in heaven.

Stop here and share a story about a special feast your community has every year. Pause this audio here.

The author does not say what type of sacrifice Elkanah made to Yahweh. When the Israelites sacrificed a peace offering to Yahweh, Yahweh allowed the Israelites to eat some of the meat. On the day when Elkanah sacrificed to Yahweh, Elkanah would give pieces of the meat to his wife Peninnah and to all her sons and daughters. Elkanah gave Hannah something different. Most translations say Elkanah gave Hannah a double portion. This could mean Elkanah gave Hannah two pieces of meat, or a large, special, or honorable piece of meat. Elkanah did this because he loved Hannah, although Yahweh had closed Hannah's womb. People probably did not expect Elkanah to give Hannah a double or special portion since Hannah did not have children.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How does your community show special honor to some people during a feast? Pause this audio here.

The storyteller says Elkanah gave Hannah a double portion because Elkanah loved Hannah even though Yahweh had closed Hannah's womb, or did not allow her to have children. This is the way the Israelites spoke about a woman who was not able to have children. The Israelites believed it was Yahweh who gave the ability to have children or not. If Yahweh gave that ability, the Israelites said Yahweh "opened the womb," and if he did not, they said Yahweh "closed the womb." Even though Hannah cannot give Elkanah any heirs, Elkanah shows Hannah how much he loves her by giving Hannah a double or special portion of meat.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Why are some women not able to have children? How do women who cannot have children feel about not being able to have children? How do other people treat those women or feel about them? Pause this audio here.

The author says Hannah's rival, Peninnah, used to provoke or bother Hannah. A rival is someone who is competing with another person for the same thing or competing to be better at some type of activity. Peninnah is competing with Hannah to bear Elkanah's children, and Peninnah is winning. Peninnah provoked Hannah to "irritate" Hannah or to make her angry or ashamed, because Yahweh had closed Hannah's womb. Even though everyone believed Yahweh was the one who closed a woman's womb, women still felt ashamed when they could not have children.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do wives of the same husband get along with each other in your culture? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a woman who competes with another woman. Pause this audio here.

Peninnah did not provoke Hannah only one time. Peninnah continued to provoke Hannah every year when they went to Shiloh, up to the house of Yahweh. Each year, when Peninnah would provoke Hannah, Hannah would weep and not eat any food.

Stop here and share a story about someone who teased another person over and over in order to hurt that person and make them feel ashamed. Pause this audio here.

This passage says that Elkanah and his family went to the "house" of Yahweh, but it was probably not a house at this time. The ark of Yahweh was probably in the tabernacle, or tent of meeting, which was a special tent. But people called this tent the "house" of Yahweh.

Stop here and look at a picture of the tabernacle. Pause this audio here.

Elkanah, Hannah's husband, would ask her, "Hannah, why do you weep? And why do you not eat? And why is your heart sad? Am I not more to you than 10 sons?" Elkanah is not really asking questions here. Elkanah knows that Hannah is weeping and not eating because Peninnah is provoking her. Elkanah knows Hannah's heart is sad because Yahweh has not given her any children. For the Israelites, the heart was the most inward part of a person, or the center of the person's thoughts and desires. The question, "Am I not more to you than 10 sons?" probably means, "Am I not more valuable to you than many sons?" Elkanah does not mean 10 as a specific number, but as a large number. Maybe Elkanah thinks he is more valuable than many sons because Elkanah loves Hannah so much, or because Elkanah can do more for Hannah than many sons could do. Elkanah is not asking a question but is trying to comfort Hannah that Elkanah's love for Hannah is more valuable than having many sons.

Stop here and share a story about a family with many children. Pause this audio here.

Stop and discuss this question as a group: What is the most valuable relationship that a woman can have in your culture? Would it be more valuable for a woman in your community to have a husband who loves her very much or to have many children?

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 1:1–8 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has two scenes.

In the first scene: The person telling the story introduces Elkanah with a list of Elkanah's ancestors and the place where Elkanah lived at the time of this true story.

In the second scene: Elkanah takes his family up to Shiloh to worship Yahweh. Elkanah gives his wife Hannah a special portion of the sacrificed meat because Elkanah loves Hannah even though Yahweh has closed her womb. Elkanah's other wife, Peninnah, taunts, or teases Hannah and tries to make her feel ashamed. Hannah becomes so sad that she cannot even eat. Elkanah tries to comfort Hannah by asking her if Elkanah is not better than many sons.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Elkanah

  • Jeroham

  • Elihu

  • Tohu

  • Zuph

  • Hannah

  • Peninnah

  • Hophni

  • Phinehas

  • And Peninnah's children

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

This passage begins with the words, "There was a certain man," which makes it clear that the story that follows is a true story about a real man who lived in the past. Then we hear a list of Elkanah's ancestors and the place where Elkanah lived. These details also show that Elkanah was a real person. It is important to start this story in whatever way your language uses to tell true stories.

Stop here and share a story about a famous or important person in your history. How do you show that the story is a true story about an important person who lived in the past? Pause this audio here.

Even though Zuph is "in the hill country of Ephraim," other parts of the Bible say Elkanah is descended from the tribe of Levi, not Ephraim. Since Yahweh did not give the descendants of Levi their own land, the Levites lived among other tribes. So it is possible that Elkanah is a Levite who lives in the area of the tribe of Ephraim. However, you should translate this as it is.

When the author introduces Elkanah's wives, most translations say that "one wife" was called Hannah and one was called Peninnah, but some translations say that the "first" wife was called Hannah and the second was called Peninnah. It is not certain that Hannah was Elkanah's first wife, but the author also says that Peninnah had children and Hannah did not. So Elkanah probably married Peninnah when he realized Hannah could not have children. The storyteller does not say how many children Peninnah had, except that she had more than one.

Elkanah used to go up to Shiloh every year. The journey from Ramathaim-Zophim to Shiloh would have been uphill. Elkanah went to Shiloh to worship and sacrifice to Yahweh of hosts. Worship for the Israelites included getting down on their knees and touching their foreheads to the ground to show respect and honor to Yahweh. Yahweh was not only the God of the Israelites. Yahweh is the one true God of everything on earth and in heaven.

Stop here and describe how you would travel to another town that is on higher ground than your town. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you describe a journey that people make every year? Pause this audio here.

The author mentions Eli in this passage, but we do not see Eli act in this story. Eli's sons, Hophni and Phinehas, are the priests who serve Yahweh.

The author does not mention what type of sacrifice Elkanah made to Yahweh, but it was probably a peace offering since Yahweh allowed Elkanah's family to eat a portion of the offering. When a worshiper made a peace offering, Yahweh permitted the priest and the worshiper's family to eat a portion of the meat the worshiper offered. Meat was a special food for the people at this time. The storyteller does not say who Elkanah served first, but it says Elkanah gave portions to Peninnah and each of her children. Now the storyteller clearly shows that Elkanah did something different for Hannah than what he did for Peninnah. Elkanah gave a double or special portion to Hannah because Elkanah loved Hannah even though Yahweh had closed her womb, or did not allow her to have children. This is the way the Israelites spoke about a woman who was not able to have children. The Israelites believed it was Yahweh who gave the ability to have children or not. If Yahweh gave that ability, the Israelites said Yahweh "opened the womb," and if he did not, the Israelites said Yahweh "closed the womb." Even though Hannah cannot give Elkanah any heirs, Elkanah shows Hannah how much he loves her by giving her a double or special portion of meat.

Stop here and discuss this as a group: How will you talk about Yahweh closing Hannah's womb? Pause this audio here.

After the storyteller tells how Elkanah divided the meat among his family, the storyteller says that Hannah's rival used to tease Hannah because she could not have children. The person telling the story no longer uses Peninnah's name, but calls her Hannah's rival. Peninnah did not tease Hannah only one time. Peninnah teased Hannah every year when they went to Shiloh for the feast. Peninnah's teasing made Hannah so sad, and bothered Hannah so much, that Hannah would not eat any food.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you name characters in your true stories? When do you stop saying a character's name in a story and instead use a description of the person? Pause this audio here.

Every year, Elkanah tries to comfort Hannah by asking her several questions. Elkanah's questions are not really questions that he expects Hannah to answer. Elkanah is just trying to tell Hannah that he loves her, even though Hannah has not given Elkanah any children. Elkanah thinks his love for Hannah should be a greater comfort to her than having many sons.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What kinds of things do people in your community say or do to encourage others and convince those people that the person loves them? How will you translate Elkanah's encouragement to Hannah? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: When you tell a true story, how do you talk about something that happens over and over, like the journey Elkanah's family takes each year, the yearly sacrifice, and the yearly trouble between Hannah and Peninnah in this story? Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 1:1–8 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has two scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Elkanah

  • Jeroham

  • Elihu

  • Tohu

  • Zuph

  • Hannah

  • Peninnah

  • Hophni

  • Phinehas

  • And Peninnah's children

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

The author introduces Samuel's father, Elkanah, by saying, "There was a certain man," and by telling the names of Elkanah's ancestors.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Elkanah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am proud that I come from a long line of important men from an important tribe; or

  • I feel confident because I have a long history in this place. People know my family; or

  • I feel responsible to keep the good name that I inherited from my ancestors.

Elkanah had two wives. People called one wife Hannah and the other wife Peninnah. Peninnah had children, but Hannah did not.

Elkanah used to go up to Shiloh every year to worship Yahweh and to sacrifice to Yahweh. Eli's sons, Hophni and Phinehas, were priests at Shiloh. Since Elkanah made this journey with his family every year, you might want to act it out in a way that shows the journey happening year after year. You could show this by having the children get older each time, or you could add a new child each time.

On the day when Elkanah sacrificed, he would give portions to Peninnah and her sons and daughters. But to Hannah, Elkanah gave a double portion, because Elkanah loved Hannah even though Yahweh had closed her womb.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Elkanah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I love Hannah very much, even though Yahweh has closed Hannah's womb; or

  • I want to show Hannah that she is special to me, even though Hannah has not given me any sons.

Ask the person playing Peninnah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am jealous that Elkanah gives Hannah a better portion of food than he gives me, even though I have given Elkanah sons and daughters, while Hannah has not; or

  • I am embarrassed that Elkanah is showing everyone how much he loves Hannah by giving Hannah a better portion than he gives me.

Hannah's rival, Peninnah, used to taunt, or tease her because Yahweh stopped Hannah from having children. Peninnah did this every year when they went up to the house of Yahweh. Hannah was so upset by Peninnah's teasing that Hannah wept and would not eat any food.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Hannah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Peninnah is right—Yahweh has closed my womb, and I am so sad about it! or

  • I am thankful that Elkanah gives me a special portion of food, but it is nothing compared to the gift of having a son. I would rather have children like Peninnah.

Elkanah asks Hannah, "Hannah, why do you weep? And why do you not eat? And why is your heart sad? Am I not more to you than 10 sons?"

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Elkanah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I do not know what else to do to show Hannah how much I love her! Yahweh has not allowed me to give Hannah the thing she wants most; or

  • I wish Hannah could see how much I love her and be comforted so she would no longer feel sad about not having sons.

Ask the person playing Hannah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Elkanah cannot understand my sadness about not having any sons.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 1:1–8 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

The passage describes the man as an "Ephrathite." People used this term to describe either a person who was from Bethlehem or someone who descended from Ephraim. In this case, the storyteller probably uses the term to say that Elkanah descended from Ephraim. But in other parts of the Bible, we hear that Elkanah descended from Levi. Even though Elkanah was descended from Levi, Elkanah was living in the land of the tribe of Ephraim, so that is probably why the storyteller uses this term to describe Elkanah as an Ephraimite.

Each year, Elkanah would go up from his city, Ramathaim, to the city of Shiloh to worship Yahweh and sacrifice to Yahweh. Worship means to give Yahweh honor and to be amazed by how powerful, good, and loving Yahweh is. People in the Bible often worshiped Yahweh by bowing down to Yahweh. A sacrifice is a gift to God. There are different kinds of sacrifices, but the one Elkanah gave was a sacrifice of an animal to worship God. It was a sacrifice that Yahweh allowed Elkanah to eat a portion of.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for worship. Look up worship in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for sacrifice. Look up sacrifice in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Elkanah takes his family to Shiloh every year to worship "Yahweh of hosts." The word hosts could refer to the armies of Israel, angelic beings, or heavenly bodies, such as stars. This title emphasizes that Yahweh is the ruler who has all power. Yahweh is not only the ruler over a certain region, but Yahweh is the ruler of everything on earth and in heaven.

Stop here and review the word or phrase you have used for Yahweh. Look up Yahweh of hosts in the Master Glossary for more information. Which word or phrase will you use for "Yahweh of hosts" or Yahweh of heaven's armies? Pause this audio here.

Elkanah and his family went to the "house of Yahweh" to worship. "House of Yahweh" is any place where the Israelites worshipped Yahweh throughout their history, whether the tabernacle or the temple that Solomon later built. In this case, the house of Yahweh refers to the tabernacle, or tent of meeting, where Yahweh met with the Israelites before they built the temple. At this time, the tabernacle, or "house of Yahweh," was located in Shiloh.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for house of Yahweh. Look up house of God in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this phrase in another book of the Bible, use the same phrase that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Hannah's rival, Peninnah, used to "provoke" Hannah. This means that Peninnah caused Hannah to suffer. Some translations say "taunt" or "torment." The storyteller uses this word twice in this passage. Use the same word for provoke in both places. Several translations add a description, such as "provoked her grievously," "bitterly," or "severely." You might want to add a description for the word you choose, too.

Stop here and discuss what word or phrase you will use for provoke. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Each year, when Peninnah provoked Hannah, Hannah would "weep" and would not eat any food. The word weep is like the word cry, but it shows that the person is feeling a lot of sorrow and grief, like the sorrow and grief of losing a child.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for weep. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 1:9–18
content:
Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 1:9–18 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 1:9–18 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 1:9–18 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

This story is about what happened during one special feast that Elkanah's family celebrated in Shiloh. After the family finished eating and drinking the meal, Hannah stood up. The family had finished their meal, but Hannah did not eat anything.

Eli the priest was sitting on the seat or chair by the doorpost of Yahweh's temple or house. A chair was a sign of honor in this culture because most people sat on the floor. It is likely that only the priest used this chair. At this time, Yahweh's temple was the tabernacle, a special tent. The doorpost might have been a post at the entrance to the tent, or the Israelites might have built some kind of structure around the tabernacle at Shiloh.

Stop here and look at a picture of the tabernacle as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, where do you have people sit if you want to honor them? Pause this audio here.

Hannah was deeply distressed. Elkanah had tried to comfort Hannah, but Hannah went to Yahweh for comfort. Hannah prayed and wept bitterly before Yahweh. Hannah vowed, or promised, and said, "O Yahweh of hosts." This is the same title the storyteller used earlier for Yahweh that emphasizes Yahweh's power over everything on earth and in heaven. Hannah says, "If you will look on the affliction of your servant." "Your servant" refers to Hannah. The Israelites would speak about themselves like another person when they wanted to show they were humble. Hannah also shows she is humble before Yahweh by calling herself Yahweh's servant.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do people in your culture show they are humble when they speak to someone that people honor more than them? Share a story of a time when a humble person asked an important leader for help. Pause this audio here.

Hannah asks Yahweh to "look on her affliction," to remember Hannah and not forget her, and to give Hannah a son. Hannah vows that if Yahweh will give her a son, Hannah will give that son back to Yahweh all the days of her son's life. As proof that Hannah has dedicated Hannah's son to Yahweh, Hannah will make sure no razor ever touches her son's head. This means Hannah will make sure no one ever cuts her son's hair. It is unusual that Hannah offers to give her son to Yahweh. It would be more common for a woman who finally received a son to keep that son close to her. Hannah is being like Abraham in this way, because Abraham was also willing to give up Abraham's son, Isaac, to Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How would you ask someone with power and authority over you to think about your suffering and help you? Pause this audio here.

The vow Hannah makes is similar to one called a Nazirite vow. The author does not say that this is a Nazirite vow, but Hannah's story is similar to the story of Samson's mother. Samson was a Nazirite, and that is why no one was supposed to cut Samson's hair. The Nazarite vow also meant that the person would not eat or drink anything from the grapevine, including wine, and would not go near dead bodies. Hannah only mentions not cutting her son's hair, but it is possible that Hannah used one part of the vow to represent the whole vow. People usually made the Nazarite vow for only a period of time, but Hannah makes this vow for "all the days" of her son's life.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What kinds of promises do people in your culture make to God? Share a story about a time someone made a promise to God. Pause this audio here.

Hannah continues praying "before Yahweh," which means that Hannah is praying again and again in Yahweh's presence. Eli is close enough that he can see that Hannah is moving her lips. Hannah prays in her heart and only her lips move. In Israelite culture, the heart is the center of a person's thoughts and desires. So this means Hannah is praying silently or inwardly. The custom at the time was for people to pray aloud. Since Hannah's lips are moving, but she is not making any sound, Eli thinks Hannah is drunk.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you know when someone is drunk? Pause this audio here.

Eli begins the conversation with Hannah because Eli is a man and a priest. Eli asks Hannah, "How long will you go on being drunk?" Eli is not really asking Hannah a question. Eli assumes Hannah is drunk, so this is Eli's way of telling Hannah to stop being drunk. Eli also tells Hannah to put her wine far away from her, which is another way to tell Hannah to stop getting drunk.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do people in your culture think about wine and strong drink? Pause this audio here.

Hannah answers Eli, "No, my lord." Hannah is showing Eli respect by calling him lord, but Hannah is still challenging what Eli said even though he is a priest with spiritual authority over Hannah. Hannah tells Eli that Hannah is a woman troubled in her spirit. Hannah has not been drinking any wine or other strong drink. Hannah says she has been pouring out her soul before Yahweh. In other words, Hannah is telling Yahweh all her sorrows and desires. Hannah is in Yahweh's presence where Hannah knows Yahweh can hear her. Yahweh does not actually need to be near a person to hear that person. Hannah knows this, and this is why Hannah prayed silently, in her heart. But Hannah is emphasizing her closeness to Yahweh as she prays at Yahweh's tent.

Hannah tells Eli not to think of his servant as a worthless woman. Again, Hannah is speaking about herself as if she speaks about another person. Hannah does this to show Eli respect. In this culture, people would have considered a drunk woman to be worthless, harmful, or evil, especially if she was drunk at the tent of Yahweh. But Hannah has not been drunk in Yahweh's presence. Hannah has been begging Yahweh for help because Hannah is so troubled.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: If a man or woman in your culture was drunk in front of the community or in a place of worship, how would your leaders respond? Pause this audio here.

When Eli hears Hannah defend herself, Eli responds and says, "Go in peace, and may the God of Israel give you what you have asked him for." In this culture, peace meant more than just not being troubled. Peace meant to have a full life with Yahweh's blessings. Eli says "the God of Israel" while Hannah says "Yahweh of Hosts." Both of these are titles for Yahweh. The God of Israel means Yahweh, the God whom Israel serves and worships. Eli might just be wishing for something that is not certain. Since Eli is a priest, Eli might be doing more than wishing that Yahweh answers Hannah's prayer. Eli might be saying Yahweh will certainly answer Hannah's prayer.

Hannah replies to Eli, "Let your servant find favor in your eyes." Hannah is again showing respect by speaking of herself as Eli's servant. Hannah wants Eli to favor her, or to treat Hannah kindly.

Then the woman, Hannah, went away and ate food and her face was no longer sad. Earlier, Hannah would not eat any food, but now Hannah eats food. Earlier, Hannah was weeping bitterly and appeared drunk because she was so sad, but now Hannah's face does not look sad. Hannah is not feeling better because she ate food. Hannah is feeling better because Eli's blessing makes Hannah confident that Yahweh has listened to Hannah's prayer.

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 1:9–18 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has three scenes.

In the first scene: Elkanah's family finishes eating their sacrificial feast, and Hannah stands up and leaves.

In the second scene: Hannah stands in Yahweh's presence near the entrance to Yahweh's tent. Eli is sitting in his seat close enough to see Hannah move her lips while Hannah prays silently again and again. Hannah is very upset and does not say her words aloud. Eli can only see Hannah move her lips and cannot hear her words, so Eli thinks Hannah is drunk in Yahweh's presence. Eli scolds Hannah and tells her to stop getting drunk.

Hannah replies that she has not been drinking any wine or strong drink. Instead, Hannah is very sad and miserable and has been silently telling Yahweh all her troubles. Eli tells Hannah to go in peace, and may Yahweh give Hannah what she has asked Yahweh for.

In the third scene: Hannah humbly asks Eli to treat her kindly, and Hannah leaves Yahweh's tent and eats food. Hannah's face does not look sad anymore.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Elkanah's family

  • Hannah

  • Eli

  • And Yahweh, though no one can see Yahweh

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

At the beginning of this story, Hannah gets up at the end of the family meal. People commonly use the phrase "eating and drinking" to refer to having a meal, but this phrase does not mean that Hannah ate. In the previous story, the storyteller says that Hannah would be so upset that Hannah would not eat any food. Hannah has not been eating, but the rest of Elkanah's family, including Peninnah and all her children, did eat the meal. Hannah stands up. That is all the storyteller tells us, but in the next scene, Hannah is in or near Yahweh's tent. So we know that Hannah stood up and left the area where they ate their meal, and Hannah walked over to Yahweh's tent.

At Yahweh's tent, Eli is sitting on the seat beside the doorpost of Yahweh's tent. It is not clear what the doorpost would have been since Yahweh's house was a tent at this time. It is possible that the Israelites built a more solid structure at the entrance of the tent or around the tent.

Eli's seat was special, because most people sat on the ground. The seat showed that Eli had an honored position in his community because Eli was a priest. Hannah is standing and praying silently to Yahweh of hosts. Hannah looks very sad. Hannah moves her lips, but Hannah is not saying any words aloud. Hannah is weeping bitterly as she moves her lips, so she might be making weeping sounds even though she is not saying her words aloud. Hannah is praying over and over again, asking Yahweh to look at Hannah, remember Hannah, and not forget Hannah, but to give Hannah a son. The phrases "look on," "remember," and "not forget" are each different ways of asking God to think about Hannah's sorrow and help her. Hannah makes a vow or promise to Yahweh that if Yahweh will give Hannah a son, Hannah will give her son to Yahweh for all the days of her son's life. Hannah also says she will not let anyone cut her son's hair. Several times in this passage, Hannah talks about herself as "your servant" in order to show humility to Yahweh. Hannah is speaking about herself as if she were speaking about another person.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you beg a deity for help? What kinds of words do you use? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How will you translate this idea of "your servant" so that your audience knows Hannah is speaking about herself? Pause this audio here.

Eli did not hear any of those words. No one else would have heard Hannah's words either, because Hannah prayed in her heart. It is not clear where Hannah is standing, but Hannah is somewhere near Yahweh's tent. We know this because Eli can see Hannah move her lips from where Eli sits beside the entrance to the tent.

The whole time Hannah is praying, Eli is sitting in his seat nearby and watching Hannah. Eli can see Hannah move her lips, but he cannot hear her words, so Eli thinks Hannah is drunk because he thinks she has drunk too much alcohol. Eli scolds Hannah by asking her how long she will continue to be drunk and by telling Hannah to put away her wine.

Stop here and discuss how you will describe that Eli thought Hannah was drunk. Pause this audio here.

Hannah tells Eli not to think of her or treat her as a "worthless woman." Worthless means to have no worth or value. In this case, a worthless woman could also mean someone who is harmful or evil.

Hannah replies to Eli with proper respect by saying "my lord" or "my master." Hannah is showing Eli respect by calling him lord, but Hannah is still challenging what Eli said, even though Eli is a priest with spiritual authority over her. Hannah tells Eli she has not been drinking wine or any other strong drink. Hannah is not drunk, but is very miserable. Hannah has been praying to Yahweh about all her troubles. Hannah tells Eli not to think of Hannah as a wicked woman. Hannah has not been dishonoring Yahweh. Hannah has been praying to Yahweh out of her grief and sorrow. Hannah uses special language about pouring out her soul. Hannah says she has been pouring out her soul before Yahweh. In other words, Hannah is telling Yahweh all her sorrows and desires. Hannah does not mean that she is actually pouring out her soul, because we cannot see, touch, or pour out a soul. Hannah is using special language to say that Hannah is telling Yahweh all her sorrows and longings. Hannah says she is pouring those sorrows and longings out "before" Yahweh, which means Hannah is in Yahweh's presence, where she knows Yahweh can hear Hannah. Yahweh does not actually need to be near a person to hear that person. Hannah knows this, which is why she prayed silently, in her heart. But Hannah is emphasizing her closeness to Yahweh as she prays at Yahweh's tent.

Stop and discuss this question as a group: Think about a time when you shared everything you were thinking and feeling with someone. Now, think about how you talk about the inner part of a person—their thoughts, feelings, and plans. How would you describe how Hannah pours out her soul and shares all her thoughts and feelings with Yahweh? Pause this audio here.

When Eli hears what Hannah has really been doing, Eli tells Hannah to "Go in peace." Eli is doing more than just telling Hannah not to feel so sad anymore. Eli is wishing Hannah a full life of Yahweh's blessings. Eli says, "May the God of Israel grant what you have asked of him." Since Eli is a priest, Eli might be doing more than just wishing and hoping Yahweh will give Hannah the son Hannah has asked for. Eli might be telling Hannah that Yahweh will certainly give Hannah the son she has asked Yahweh for.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do you bless someone or wish them well when you tell them goodbye? Pause this audio here.

Hannah replies, "May your servant find favor in your eyes." This means Hannah is hoping Eli will be kind to Hannah.

After Hannah's conversation with Eli, Hannah returns to the place where Elkanah's family ate the sacrificial meal. Hannah eats food, and Hannah's face is not sad anymore. This is a big change from the last passage, where Hannah was too sad to eat, and everyone could see by looking at Hannah's face that she was very sad.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How would you say that someone is not sad anymore? Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 1:9–18 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has three scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Elkanah's family

  • Hannah

  • Eli

  • And Yahweh, though no one can see Yahweh

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Hannah was deeply distressed. Hannah prayed to Yahweh and wept bitterly. And Hannah vowed to Yahweh.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Hannah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so weary of the way Peninnah torments me! or

  • The only one who can help me is Yahweh, who has closed my womb; or

  • I need Yahweh to have mercy on me. I cannot bear feeling so sad any longer!

As Hannah continued praying before Yahweh, Eli watched Hannah move her mouth.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Eli, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Something is wrong with this woman. This woman's face looks so strange; or

  • I see that woman move her mouth, but why do I not hear any words coming out of it? or

  • That woman is so wicked to come to Yahweh's tent when she has been drinking too much! That woman is dishonoring Yahweh and his place of worship!

And Eli said to Hannah, "How long will you go on being drunk? Put your wine away from you."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Hannah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • This is terrible—the priest thinks I am drunk! or

  • I do not want the priest to think I have been dishonoring Yahweh! or

  • I hope I can make the priest understand that I have really been honoring Yahweh by praying to Yahweh in my distress.

Hannah answered Eli, "No, my lord. I am a woman who is deeply troubled. I have not been drinking wine or other strong drink. I was pouring out my soul to Yahweh."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Eli, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • This woman does not sound drunk. This woman is respectful and speaks well; or

  • I believe this woman. I have mistaken this woman's deep distress for drunkenness, but I was wrong; or

  • This woman is clearly very sad. I do not know what this woman asked Yahweh for, but it must be something very important.

Then Eli answered, "Go in peace, and may the God of Israel grant you what you have asked of him."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Hannah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so relieved that the priest believes me! or

  • What a wonderful blessing! I feel excited that I can have peace and Yahweh's blessings after all these years of shame and sadness! or

  • Eli is the priest, so his words are a great comfort. Surely Yahweh has heard my prayer!

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 1:9–18 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

After Elkanah's family had finished eating and drinking, Hannah stood up. People in the Bible often use the phrase "eat and drink" to refer to having a meal. In this case, Elkanah's family ate the meal, but Hannah did not because Peninnah's teasing made Hannah feel too sad to eat.

Eli sat in the seat near the entrance to Yahweh's temple or tent. Only honored people sat in seats. Most people sat on the ground, so this seat shows that Eli, a priest, was honored above other people.

Stop here and look at a picture of the kind of seat a priest would have sat in. Pause this audio here.

Eli was sitting by Yahweh's temple, or house. Use the same word for Yahweh that you have used in previous passages, and see the Master Glossary for more information about Yahweh. In this passage, the storyteller used the words "big house, or palace," for temple. Remember that this is actually the tabernacle, or tent of meeting. You may use a phrase for "Yahweh's house," or "Yahweh's tabernacle."

Stop here and discuss what phrase you will use for Yahweh's temple, or house. For more information, see tabernacle or house of God in the Master Glossary. Pause this audio here.

Hannah makes a vow to Yahweh that Hannah will give her son to Yahweh and that no razor will touch her son's hair. A vow is a solemn promise, a binding oath, that people make to Yahweh, usually in return for Yahweh's favor or blessing. People made different types of vows to Yahweh. A woman was allowed to keep her vow if her husband did not forbid her. Hannah's vow is probably a Nazirite vow. When Hannah says, "no razor will touch his hair," Hannah means she will not let anyone cut her son's hair. A Nazirite vow also included not eating or drinking anything that people made from grapes, and not going near a dead body. Hannah only mentions not letting anyone cut her son's hair, but she might have used one part of the Nazirite vow to represent the whole Nazirite vow.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for vow. Look up vow in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Hannah speaks to Yahweh and calls him "O Yahweh of hosts." This is a title for Yahweh that emphasizes his great power over everything, both on earth and in heaven. Use the same word or phrase for "Yahweh of hosts" as you used in previous passages. See the Master Glossary for more information about Yahweh of hosts.

Hannah says, "If you will indeed look on the affliction of your servant and remember me and not forget your servant." By calling herself "your servant," Hannah is being humble before Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word you will use for servant. See the Master Glossary for more information about servant, and use the same word that you have used in other parts of the Bible. Pause this audio here.

Hannah was praying in her heart because Hannah was pouring out her soul to Yahweh. The soul is the innermost part of a person's body that continues to live even after a person dies. People referred to the heart as the place where a person's thoughts and desires happen. In this case, it also means that Hannah was praying silently rather than praying aloud. People commonly prayed aloud at this time. For more information, look up soul, pray, and heart in the Master Glossary.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for praying in her heart and pouring out her soul. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Eli took Hannah to be a drunken woman. This means that Eli thought Hannah was drunk. A drunk person was someone who had drunk too much of a fermented or strong drink, so that they acted strangely. It was never good to be drunk, but especially not when praying to Yahweh at his tent.

Hannah says she has not had any wine or strong drink. Wine is a drink that people made by fermenting grapes. In this culture, people made strong drinks by fermenting grains or fruits. Both wine and strong drinks could make a person drunk if they drank too much of them. For more information on wine, refer to the Master Glossary.

Stop here and look at a picture of grapes on a grape vine, and discuss how you will translate wine or strong drink. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Eli wishes for Hannah to "go in peace." Eli is doing more than just telling Hannah not to feel so sad anymore. Eli is wishing Hannah a full life of Yahweh's blessings.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word you will use for peace. See the Master Glossary for more information about peace, and translate peace in the same way you have in previous books of the Bible. Pause this audio here.

Since Eli is a priest, Eli might be doing more than just wishing that the God of Israel will give Hannah what she asked God for. Eli might be saying that the God of Israel will certainly give Hannah what she asked for. "The God of Israel" is a title for Yahweh that means the God whom Israel serves and worships. Use the same term for "the God of Israel" each time you use it. For more information, look up God and Israel in the Master Glossary.

title: 1 Samuel 1:19–28
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 1:19–28 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 1:19–28 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 1:19–28 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

Early the next morning, after Hannah asked Yahweh for a son and Eli blessed Hannah, Elkanah's family got up from their beds and worshiped Yahweh by bowing low before Yahweh. Then, after Elkanah's family worshiped before Yahweh, the family went back from Shiloh to their home in Ramah.

Stop here and look at a map of Shiloh and Ramah as a group. Pause this audio here.

Then Elkanah knew, or had sexual relations with, Hannah, Elkanah's wife. And Yahweh remembered Hannah and treated her kindly. Yahweh kept his promise to Hannah just like Eli said Yahweh would.

Stop here and share a story about a time when God or a powerful person kept his promise. Pause this audio here.

After Elkanah's family returned from Shiloh, and before they took their yearly journey again, Hannah gave birth to a son. Hannah named her son Samuel because Hannah asked Yahweh for this son.

A year passed, and then Elkanah went up with his family to offer the yearly sacrifice to Yahweh and keep his vow. When Yahweh gave the Israelites his law, Yahweh said that a husband could decide whether or not his wife kept a vow she made to Yahweh. Elkanah allowed Hannah to keep her vow to Yahweh. It might be her vow Elkahah is keeping here, or it might be another vow that Elkanah made himself.

But Hannah did not go up to Shiloh this time as she usually did. Hannah told Elkanah that she would wait to take Samuel to Shiloh after she had weaned Samuel. Then Hannah would take Samuel to the tabernacle in Shiloh and present him to Yahweh. And Samuel would live at the tabernacle for the rest of his life until he died. At this time, an Israelite mother would usually wean her baby after three years.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: When does a mother wean her child in your culture? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and share a story about a time when someone in your culture dedicated their child to God. Why did that person dedicate their child? What did it mean for the child when the parent dedicated the child? Pause this audio here.

Elkanah, Hannah's husband, replies to Hannah, "Do what seems best to you." Elkanah's main concern is that Yahweh will confirm Yahweh's word. Elkanah gives Hannah permission to wait, but Elkanah wants Hannah to keep her vow to Yahweh just as Yahweh has kept his word to remember Hannah and give her a son.

After Hannah weans her son, Hannah takes Samuel up to Yahweh's tabernacle in Shiloh with her, even though Samuel is still a young boy. Elkanah goes with Hannah, though the storyteller does not mention Elkanah here. Hannah and Elkanah bring items for a sacrifice with them, too. This sacrifice was typical for someone who was keeping a vow or promise to Yahweh.

Hannah and Elkanah bring a three-year-old bull, an ephah of flour, and a skin of wine. An ephah was a special basket that people used for measuring grain and other items. An ephah could usually hold up to about 13 kilograms. In this culture and time, people usually stored wine in bags that people made from animal skins, but sometimes people stored wine in jars that people made from clay. The most important thing the Israelites would have noticed about the flour and wine offerings Hannah and Elkanah brought is that they were very large amounts. The words for "three-year-old bull" could also mean "three bulls." People would not typically bring three bulls, but the amount of flour and wine is three times as much as people usually brought, so it is possible that Hannah and Elkanah also brought three bulls. However, most translations say a "three-year-old bull."

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a bull, an ephah of flour, and a skin of wine. Pause this audio here.

Stop and discuss this question as a group: What do you use to measure grains? How do you store water or other liquids that you drink? Pause this audio here.

The size of the offerings shows that Elkanah is wealthy. Since Samuel might be as young as three years old, Hannah and Elkanah might have given an extra-large offering because the priests would be caring for Samuel for a long time. Or maybe the offering was so large because this is a very special dedication. Yahweh had closed Hannah's womb for many years before giving her this son. Also, this is Elkanah's first son with his wife, Hannah, whom Elkanah loves very much.

After Hannah and Elkanah bring the offerings to the tabernacle in Shiloh, they slaughter the bull, and they bring the boy to Eli. Hannah greets Eli as her lord, or master, to show him honor. And Hannah says to Eli, "As surely as you live, my lord." Hannah calls Eli "my lord" again to show him respect. The phrase "as surely as you live" was a common oath. Hannah reminds Eli that she is the woman who stood beside him and prayed to Yahweh. Hannah uses an oath to emphasize that she is the same woman, even though that might surprise Eli.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: When someone in your community says something that other people find hard to believe, how does that person emphasize that they are telling the truth? Pause this audio here.

Hannah makes this offering and brings her child to Eli because Yahweh answered Hannah's prayer. Hannah tells Eli she has lent Samuel to Yahweh. Hannah is giving Samuel to God forever. Samuel belongs to Yahweh for Samuel's whole life. Then Elkanah worshiped Yahweh.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 1:19–28 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has four scenes.

In the first scene: The very next morning, Elkanah, Peninnah and their children, and Hannah get out of bed and go to worship Yahweh at his tabernacle in Shiloh. Then the family travels back to their home in Ramah.

In the second scene: Elkanah knows his wife Hannah, and Hannah gives birth to a son. Hannah names this son Samuel because Hannah asked Yahweh for this son.

In the third scene: A year after Hannah prayed to Yahweh for a son, Elkanah and his family prepare to go to Shiloh again to offer sacrifices and to keep Elkanah's vow. Hannah tells Elkanah she wants to wait to go to Shiloh with him until after Hannah has weaned Samuel. Elkanah gives Hannah permission to stay and wait until she has weaned Samuel. Elkanah's main concern is that Yahweh's will is done.

In the fourth scene: Hannah, Samuel, and Elkanah travel to Shiloh with a three-year-old bull, an ephah of flour, and a skin of wine as offerings for keeping their vow. After Hannah and Elkanah slaughter the bull, they bring Samuel to Eli. Hannah reminds Eli that she is the same woman who had stood near Eli and prayed to Yahweh several years before this. Hannah explains that Samuel is the child she asked Yahweh for, so Hannah is giving Samuel to Yahweh to live at the tabernacle for the rest of his life until Samuel dies. Then Elkanah worships Yahweh there.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Elkanah

  • Hannah

  • Peninnah

  • Peninnah's children

  • Samuel

  • And Eli

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

This passage begins where the last passage ended. In the last passage, Hannah asked Yahweh for a son, and then Hannah went back to where Elkanah and the rest of the family had eaten their feast together. This passage begins the next morning after Elkanah's whole family slept through the night. The whole family includes Peninnah and her children. All of the people in Elkanah's family get up from their beds and go to the tabernacle to worship Yahweh. The family members probably bowed low with their foreheads to the ground to worship Yahweh. Then the family traveled back to their home in Ramah.

The next part of the story takes place at the family's home in Ramah. The next action happens in private, so you will want to find a way to show what happened without acting it out. Elkanah knew Hannah, his wife, and Yahweh remembered Hannah. Some translations say Elkanah "lay with" Hannah or "slept with" Hannah. These are all different ways of politely saying that Elkanah had sexual intercourse with Hannah. This phrase was a way people could speak publicly about the private act between a husband and wife. The word "remembered" means that Yahweh treated Hannah kindly and kept his promise to Hannah. This probably means that when Eli said, "May the God of Israel grant you what you have prayed for," Eli was speaking Yahweh's promise to Hannah that Yahweh would give Hannah the son she asked for. You will want to think of a way for your audience to understand what happened without having the actors perform that part or without making your objects do the action.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do people in your community speak politely about the private act that a husband and wife do together in order to make a child? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Remember the story you told in the last step about God or a person keeping a promise. How did you talk about God remembering what God had said and keeping his promise? Pause this audio here.

After that, Hannah conceived and gave birth to a son. The phrase "conceived and gave birth" is the way the Israelites spoke about a woman having a baby. This might also be something you choose not to act out or show with objects in front of the audience. After giving birth, Hannah explains that she named her son Samuel because she asked Yahweh for this son. The passage does not say who Hannah was speaking to when she said this, but perhaps Hannah was speaking to her family.

Stop here and share a story about a woman having a baby. Pay attention to the words you use to say that she had a baby. Pause this audio here.

The name Samuel has several possible meanings: "Name of Yahweh," "Offspring or child of Yahweh," or "Yahweh heard." Samuel was Elkanah's child, not Yahweh's child. So if Samuel's name means "child of Yahweh," it is because Hannah knows Yahweh gave her Samuel, not because Samuel is literally the child of Yahweh. In Hebrew, the name Samuel sounds like the Hebrew word for "to ask." The name Samuel also sounds similar to Saul, whose story the storyteller will tell later in the book of 1 Samuel. Samuel and Saul may sound alike, but they are very different men.

The scene switches to show Elkanah, Peninnah, and their children preparing for their yearly journey to Shiloh again. But Hannah does not go up to Shiloh with the family this time. Hannah tells Elkanah she wants to wait to bring Samuel up to Shiloh after Hannah has weaned Samuel. Then Hannah will bring Samuel to Yahweh's tabernacle in Shiloh, and Samuel will live there for the rest of his life.

Elkanah gives Hannah permission to stay and wait until she has weaned Samuel. Elkanah says, "Only may Yahweh keep his word." Elkanah shows that his main concern is that Yahweh keep his word, or promise. It is not clear if Elkanah is talking about Yahweh keeping his promise or Hannah keeping her promise, so some translations say, "May Yahweh confirm your promise," meaning Hannah's word or vow to Yahweh. People who translate the passage this way think Elkanah is talking about Hannah's promise since Yahweh has already kept his promise. Although the story does not tell this next part, you might want to show Elkanah and the rest of the family leaving while Hannah stays home, and then show the family returning again later. At this point in the story, Samuel is a baby.

Then the storyteller comes back to Hannah after some time has passed. The storyteller says, "After Hannah weaned the boy," so it has probably been about three years since Elkanah went to Shiloh without Hannah. Now, Samuel is a young child. Hannah, Elkanah, and Samuel travel from Ramah up to Shiloh with a three-year-old bull, an ephah of flour, and a skin of wine. An ephah of flour may have been around 13 kilograms. These are the typical sacrifices an Israelite would make to Yahweh when he or she was keeping a vow to Yahweh. Elkanah and Hannah brought much more of each item than people usually brought for such a sacrifice. This shows that Elkanah is wealthy and also that this vow is very special to Elkanah and Hannah.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you speak about the time when a mother stops nursing her child or stops giving the child milk from her breasts? Pause this audio here.

The storyteller says, "They slaughtered the bull," but it is not really clear who sacrificed the bull. This might refer to Elkanah and Hannah or to the priests. Then Elkanah and Hannah bring Samuel to Eli. Hannah reminds Eli that she is the same woman who stood near him and prayed to Yahweh several years ago. Hannah uses an oath to show that she is telling the truth, even though it might surprise Eli to hear that she is the same woman.

Hannah tells Eli, "I prayed for this child, and Yahweh has given me what I asked of him." Hannah's words are almost the exact same words Eli used when he blessed Hannah several years before. Eli had said to Hannah, "May Yahweh give what you have asked of him," so Hannah is emphasizing that her son, this child, is Yahweh's answer to the prayer Hannah prayed that day several years ago.

"So now" shows that Hannah is making this offering and lending her child to Eli because Yahweh answered Hannah's prayer. The word "lent" usually means to give something for just a time and then receive it back, but here Hannah is not expecting to receive Samuel back. Samuel will belong to Yahweh for the rest of Samuel's life until he dies. Most translations then say, "and he worshiped Yahweh there." But it seems likely that Elkanah, Hannah, and Samuel all worshiped there with Eli at this time, so some translations say, "they worshiped Yahweh there." Again, they probably bowed very low with their foreheads to the ground to worship Yahweh.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 1:19–28 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has four scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Elkanah

  • Hannah

  • Peninnah

  • Peninnah's children

  • Samuel

  • And Eli

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Early the next morning, Elkanah's whole family got up from their beds and went to Yahweh's tabernacle to bow low and worship Yahweh. Then the family went back to their home at Ramah.

Elkanah slept with Hannah, and Yahweh remembered Hannah. And in due time, Hannah gave birth to a son. Hannah named her son Samuel because she said, "I asked Yahweh for him."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Hannah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I can hardly believe my great joy! Yahweh answered my prayer for a son! or

  • My many years of deep sadness have ended! Yahweh listened to my prayer and gave me the son I asked for! or

  • Yahweh has removed my shame. Finally, I have given Elkanah a son, and Peninnah cannot tease me.

When it was time for Elkanah to take his family to Shiloh again for their yearly sacrifice to Yahweh, Hannah told Elkanah she wanted to wait to go to Shiloh until after she had weaned Samuel. Then Hannah would take Samuel and present him to Yahweh, and Samuel would live at Yahweh's tabernacle for Samuel's whole life.

"Do what seems best to you," Elkanah, Hannah's husband, told her. "Stay here until you have weaned him; only may Yahweh confirm his word."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Elkanah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Hannah's request makes sense because it would be hard to leave a nursing baby at the tabernacle; or

  • I agree with Hannah, but I want to be sure we keep our vow, because Yahweh kept his promise to give Hannah a son; or

  • The most important thing to me is that we give Samuel to Yahweh.

So Hannah stayed home and nursed Samuel until she had weaned Samuel. After Hannah had weaned him, Hannah took young Samuel, along with a sacrifice, to Yahweh's tabernacle in Shiloh. Hannah and Elkanah brought a three-year-old bull, an ephah of flour, and a skin of wine for their sacrifice. After they sacrificed the bull, Hannah and Elkanah brought Samuel to Eli. Hannah said, "As surely as you live, my lord, I am the woman who stood here beside you praying to Yahweh. For this child I prayed, and Yahweh has given me what I asked him for."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Hannah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Eli must be so amazed to see me here with a child this time! or

  • The last time I was here, I was so sad, but now I am so happy to be here with the child Yahweh gave me! or

  • Yahweh has been so good to me! This child is proof that Yahweh remembered me.

As she had promised, Hannah gave Samuel to Yahweh for the rest of Samuel's life. And Hannah, Elkanah, Samuel, and Eli worshiped Yahweh together at Yahweh's tabernacle.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 1:19–28 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Elkanah and his household got up early the next morning and worshiped Yahweh. You may say that Elkanah and his household bowed down to Yahweh, which was a way of worshipping him, or you may use a word for worship that you have used previously. See the Master Glossary for more information about worship.

"And Yahweh remembered her." When the Israelites spoke of Yahweh remembering someone, people usually meant that Yahweh did something to help that person. This was especially true when the person had struggled for a long period of time, as Hannah had struggled for a long time with not having any children. Use the same word for Yahweh that you used in previous passages. Yahweh is in the Master Glossary.

Elkanah "went up with his house" or household to Yahweh's tabernacle, or house, in Shiloh. Use the same word or phrase for Yahweh's house or tabernacle as you have used in previous passages. See the Master Glossary for more information on house of God or tabernacle. The term "house" or "household" referred to a man's family, because it referred to everyone who lived in that man's house. A household could include more family than just a man's wife and children. A man might also have his parents or his son's families and others living in his house as well.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for household. Look up household in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Elkanah went to offer up his yearly sacrifice to Yahweh and "to keep his vow." A vow is a promise to God. If a married Israelite woman made a vow, her husband could let her keep the vow or not. Use the same words for sacrifice and vow as you used in previous passages. For more information, look up sacrifice and vow in the Master Glossary.

When Hannah and Elkanah brought Samuel to Yahweh's tabernacle in Shiloh, they brought an offering of "a three-year-old bull, an ephah of flour, and a skin of wine." This was the typical offering for someone who was keeping a vow to Yahweh, except that Hannah and Elkanah brought a very large amount of each item. For more information, look up wine and ephah in the Master Glossary.

Stop here and look at a picture of a bull, an ephah of flour, and a skin of wine as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for ephah and skin of wine. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Hannah also calls Eli "my lord," which was how people showed respect when speaking to someone they honored. Use the same word or phrase for "my lord" as you used in previous passages. For more information, look up the word lord in the Master Glossary.

Hannah tells Eli that she is the woman who was praying for a child years ago. When Hannah prayed, she talked with Yahweh. Use the same word for praying as you did in previous passages. For more information about pray, refer to the Master Glossary.

Hannah tells Eli she has "lent" her son to Yahweh. The word "lent" usually means to give something for only a period of time, expecting to receive it back later. In this case, Hannah is not lending Samuel for only a period of time. Hannah says, "for as long as he lives." Hannah is giving Samuel to Yahweh for the rest of Samuel's life until he dies. Some translations say "I give" or "I am dedicating" to show that Hannah does not expect to ever have Samuel back again.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use to say that Hannah lent her son to Yahweh. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
