title: 1 Samuel 2:1–11
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 2:1–11 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 2:1–11 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 2:1–11 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

NOTE: This passage is a song, which is Hebrew poetry. We recommend that your team complete the "Introduction to Poetry Module 1" before continuing with "Step 2: Setting the Stage." Stop here, if needed, and review the translation decisions your team has made regarding the translation of poetry. Pause this audio here.

Hannah and Elkanah have just brought young Samuel to Eli. Elkanah and Hannah worshipped Yahweh in the tabernacle, and then Hannah prayed to Yahweh. People often call this prayer "Hannah's Song" because Hannah uses beautiful, poetic language. This prayer is similar to songs the Israelites used to sing when they celebrated their victory over their enemies. Israelites often made prayers to give thanks after God heard their prayers and helped them. Hannah thanks Yahweh for more than the birth of Hannah's son. Hannah also thanks Yahweh for the way he changes people's circumstances with Yahweh's mighty power. Later, in the New Testament, Jesus's mother Mary sings a similar song-prayer after the angel Gabriel tells Mary she will have a son.

Stop here and tell a story about a time when someone wrote a song to celebrate something very good that happened to them or to your community. Whom did the songwriter address the song to? How is a celebration song different than other songs? Pause this audio here.

Stop and discuss this question as a group: What do prayers sound like in your language? Pause this audio here.

Hannah prays and says that her heart rejoices in Yahweh. In the Bible, the heart is the place where a person's thoughts, feelings, and decisions happen. Hannah says her horn is lifted up to Yahweh. People used horns to symbolize power, strength, and pride. Yahweh has lifted Hannah from the shame of being barren to the dignity of having a son, and Hannah praises Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are some things that your culture uses as symbols of strength and power? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of a horn. Pause this audio here.

Hannah says her mouth boasts, or speaks boldly, over her enemies, because Hannah rejoices that Yahweh rescued her. Then Hannah emphasizes that Yahweh is completely different than anyone else. Three times, in three different ways, Hannah says there is no one like Yahweh. There is no one who is holy like Yahweh. There is no one who is beside Yahweh, or equal to him. And there is no one who is a rock like the Israelites' God. The Israelites often compared God to a rock. The Israelites meant that Yahweh is a strong protector.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are some things that people in your culture compare to God? What are symbols of protection in your culture? Pause this audio here.

Next, Hannah speaks to the rest of her community about how they should behave toward their unique and holy God. The community should not talk proudly or let arrogant words come from their mouths, because Yahweh judges people's actions.

Hannah moves from talking about the Israelites' actions to talking about Yahweh's actions. Hannah gives seven examples to show that Yahweh changes human circumstances. Yahweh can change people's lives in a way that no one understands. Hannah does not say who is doing the action, but Hannah is speaking about Yahweh, and everyone listening knows that. In Hannah's first example, Yahweh breaks the bows of strong men. People often used bows and arrows as weapons in Israel at this time. Yahweh can make strong men weak. Yahweh can cause the weapons that men depend on to fail. On the other hand, Yahweh arms weak men with strength. Even when these men have no weapons to depend on, Yahweh can cause weak men to defeat their enemies.

Stop here and tell a story of a time when God changed human circumstances, either by making a strong person weak or a weak person strong when no one expected it to happen. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of bows and arrows. Pause this audio here.

In her second example, Hannah says that people who used to have plenty of food are now hungry. These people are asking other people to hire them to do work so the hungry people can get enough bread. Bread was a very important food for the Israelites, so they often used bread as a symbol of food in general. But those who were hungry are no longer hungry.

The barren woman who could not have children has given birth to seven children, but the woman who already had many children is childless. Being hungry is similar to being barren, and being full is similar to having children. For the Israelites, the number seven was a symbol of the perfect amount. Yahweh causes the barren woman to have an ideal family, and Yahweh causes the woman who already had children to have no children. This is the situation that most closely matches what Yahweh has done for Hannah, but Hannah is praising Yahweh for more than what he has done for her. Hannah is praising Yahweh for the way he reverses situations for many of his people.

In the next part of her song-prayer, Hannah talks about Yahweh's character. Yahweh kills and brings to life. Yahweh brings people to Sheol, and Yahweh raises people up. Yahweh does not kill people the same way men kill other men, but Yahweh has all power, so Yahweh is the one who causes people to die and who causes people to live. The Israelites considered Sheol as the dark place beneath the earth where both good and evil people from all nations went when they died. The Israelites also considered Sheol the place where Yahweh judged people for the actions people did during their lives. Yahweh has total power over both life and death.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What do you call the place where people go after they die? What is that place like? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh says two similar things in the same way again: Yahweh changes people who are poor or low to people who are rich or high. Again, Yahweh is the one who reverses people's fortunes.

Hannah talks again about how Yahweh can reverse people's fortunes. Hannah says Yahweh raises the poor up from the dust and lifts the needy from the ash heap. Poor and needy are the same thing, because those who are poor have many needs. The dust and the ash heap are both low and dirty places. Because Yahweh chooses who is rich and who is poor, Yahweh can also change who is rich and who is poor. Yahweh makes the poor sit with princes and inherit places of honor. Yahweh owns the whole earth, and Yahweh sets the world in order. Yahweh can also change that order whenever Yahweh wants to, so that those who are poor and needy become rich and honored.

Stop here and share a story about a time when a very poor person became the respected friend of an important leader. Pause this audio here.

Yahweh will guard the lives of those who are faithful to him, but Yahweh will cut off the wicked in darkness. No one will succeed because of their own strength. Yahweh is not only the God of Israel. Yahweh is God of the whole world. Yahweh has power over those who are faithful to him and those who are Yahweh's enemies. The people around Israel worshipped false gods. Those people thought their gods only had power over certain people, places, or things, such as a god of only one people group, a god of rain, or a god of a certain hill. The Israelites knew that their God was the one true God who ruled over all people, places, and things.

Yahweh will completely destroy his enemies. Yahweh will judge everyone on earth. Yahweh will make his king, his anointed one, strong. Israel did not yet have a king when Hannah prayed these words. Hannah's prayer looks forward to King David and David's descendants, which includes Jesus. In the Old Testament, when God set someone aside for a special job like being king, God would instruct someone else to anoint that person, or pour oil over that person's head, as a symbol of the Holy Spirit of God. To anoint that person showed that the person had special authority from God to do their job.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do people in your culture set someone aside to do special work for God? Pause this audio here.

After Hannah's song-prayer, Elkanah and Hannah went home to Ramah, and the boy, Samuel, stayed in Shiloh and served Yahweh under the authority of Eli the priest.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 2:1–11 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has four scenes.

In the first scene: Hannah praises Yahweh for saving Hannah and causing her to boast over her enemies.

In the second scene: Hannah tells the Israelites to be humble because Yahweh knows everything the Israelites do and because Yahweh will judge the Israelites.

In the third scene: Hannah gives examples of how Yahweh reverses people's fortunes as he chooses.

In the fourth scene: Hannah says Yahweh will guard those who are faithful to Yahweh, but Yahweh will destroy his enemies. Yahweh will make his anointed one, the king of Israel, strong.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Hannah

  • Yahweh

  • Elkanah

  • Eli

  • Samuel

  • The Israelites

  • Strong people who are full, rich, powerful, and have children

  • Weak people who are hungry, poor, powerless, and barren

  • Faithful people

  • God's enemies

  • And God's anointed one, the king

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

Stop here and review as a group: We recommend that your team complete the "Introduction to Poetry Modules 2 & 3" before continuing with "Step 3: Defining the Scenes." If your team has completed the introduction to poetry, remind one another of the special ways that poets use language. What are the most common ways that poets use language in Hebrew poems? Pause this audio here.

In this story, Hannah prays immediately after she brings young Samuel to serve Eli at the tabernacle in Shiloh. People often call Hannah's prayer a song because it has rhythm and beautiful language like a song. It is possible that Hannah prayed this prayer at the tabernacle in Shiloh, but Hannah might have prayed it after she went home. Hannah's prayer is similar to other hymns in which people thank Yahweh because Hannah emphasizes that Yahweh has the right to rule over all the earth. Hannah uses a common feature of Hebrew poems where people say the same thing in two or three similar ways. Hannah also repeats important words, one after the other. It is possible that Hannah did not create this prayer herself but was reciting a prayer that the people of Israel all knew. The Israelites used to sing songs like this when they defeated their enemies in battle. Songs like this have a rhythm that is like a drumbeat or a clap-clap-clap sound.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do your victory songs sound? Pause this audio here.

Hannah prays out loud. Hannah focuses on several important truths about Yahweh. Yahweh is holy, so Yahweh has the right to rule all of creation. Yahweh reverses human fortunes, bringing high people low and low people high. Hannah ends by talking about the king, even though Israel does not yet have a king. Hannah begins by speaking about herself, but quickly switches to speaking about people in general. Sometimes Hannah speaks directly to Yahweh in her prayer. Other times, Hannah speaks about Yahweh to the people who hear Hannah's prayer.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, how would you switch from talking to Yahweh and then talking to people in the middle of your prayers? Pause this audio here.

Sometimes in Hebrew poetry, people use one part of something to represent the whole thing. Hannah's heart, horn, and mouth represent Hannah. These things include everything Hannah thinks, does, and says. In the Bible, people use the heart as special language for the place where a person's thoughts, feelings, and decisions happen. Horns were symbols of power and strength. Hannah does not literally lift up a horn with her hands. Hannah is saying Yahweh has changed Hannah from being sad to rejoicing, and from being weak to being strong. Yahweh could do that because Yahweh has power over everything.

Stop here and look at a picture of a horn. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, in which part of the body do people think, feel, and make decisions? Pause this audio here.

Because Yahweh has saved Hannah, Hannah boasts over her enemies. Hannah's mouth does not speak by itself. Hannah uses her mouth to boast. When the Israelites talked about boasting over their enemies, they said their mouths were open wide over their enemies. Hannah was not boasting about herself. Hannah was boasting about what Yahweh did to help her.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Remember when you learned about poetry and you discussed whether you wanted to follow the Hebrew pattern for poetry or your culture's pattern for poetry. If you want to follow the Hebrew pattern, you will want to find two or three similar ways to say that Hannah rejoiced because of what Yahweh had done and that Hannah praised Yahweh. If you want to follow your culture's pattern for poetry, how will you translate these lines? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and share a story about someone who was very strong. How do you speak about that person's strength? What symbols do you have for being strong? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and share a story about a time when your language group had a victory over your enemies. Pay attention to the words you use. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your language, will it be okay to speak about a heart rejoicing or a mouth boasting? Since these parts represent Hannah as a whole person, you could also choose to say that Hannah rejoices in Yahweh and Hannah boasts over her enemies. Pause this audio here.

Hannah emphasizes how different Yahweh is when she says three times that there is no one like Yahweh: no one is holy like Yahweh, no one is beside Yahweh or equal to Yahweh, and no one is a rock like Yahweh, Israel's God. Yahweh is holy, unique, and mighty.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Hebrew poetry repeated an important idea three times in order to emphasize it. How do you emphasize an important idea in your language? Pause this audio here.

Hannah speaks about the rest of the community using parallelism. Parallelism means Hannah says the same thing in two or three similar ways. The people should not talk proudly or let arrogance come from their mouths because Yahweh knows everything, and Yahweh weighs people's actions. "Talk" and "mouth" are similar to each other, and "proudly" and "arrogance" are similar to each other. The Israelites often said that Yahweh weighed people's actions on a scale as a way to talk about Yahweh judging whether the things that someone did were good or bad.

Stop here and look at a picture of a scale. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you speak about God judging whether something that a person did was right or wrong? Pause this audio here.

Hannah goes on to talk about seven ways that Yahweh changes people's fortunes. Hannah compares strong and weak people, full and hungry people, barren and fertile women, dead and living people, sick and well people, poor and rich people, and humble and honored people.

Hannah uses special language to say that Yahweh makes strong men weak. Bows were weapons of war, and strong men relied on bows. Yahweh causes the weapons that strong men rely on to be useless to those men. On the other hand, Yahweh makes weak men strong. Yahweh puts strength on weak men like a piece of clothing for the men to wear.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are some weapons that men in your culture rely upon in battle or when hunting? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh causes people who had stomachs full of food to become so hungry that they offer to work for other people so they can buy a piece of bread. On the other hand, Yahweh gives people who were hungry plenty to eat.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How would you know that someone is extremely hungry? What would that person do? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh causes the barren women who could not have children to have seven children. The Israelites considered seven the perfect number, so Yahweh gives the barren woman the ideal family. On the other hand, Yahweh causes the woman who had many children to lose all of her children and to be lonely and sad. The poet is using different ideas to show the same meaning. To be hungry is similar to being barren, and to be full is similar to having children.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How would you describe a woman who has the perfect number of children? Pause this audio here.

When Hannah says Yahweh kills, Hannah does not mean that Yahweh kills the way men kill other men. Yahweh does not have a body. But Yahweh has control over all of creation, so Yahweh is the one who causes people to die. Yahweh is also the one who causes people to live. This might be talking about Yahweh causing some sick people to die of their sickness while Yahweh heals other people so that those people keep living. Hannah says the same thing in a second way: Yahweh brings people down to Sheol, the place where dead people go, and Yahweh raises people to life.

Hannah says Yahweh makes people poor. Yahweh also makes people rich. Hannah focuses on how Yahweh changes people's circumstances. Yahweh can make people who used to be rich poor and people who used to be poor rich. Yahweh brings people low and humbles those people, and Yahweh lifts people up and honors those people. These are opposite things, and it is Yahweh who does both.

Yahweh raises the poor and needy from the dust and the ash heap. The ash heap was a place where people put garbage or manure. Both the dust and the ash heap represent miserable conditions. "To sit with princes" and "inherit a seat of honor" are special language for Yahweh taking poor people who sat in the dust and giving those people honorable and important positions in the community. A seat of honor was like a throne. A seat of honor was a special seat that people saved for people of high honor or authority, and these seats placed people higher than the other people who sat around them. The Israelites and other people who lived during this time believed that the Earth was flat and that pillars supported the Earth. Hannah says Yahweh is the one who owns the pillars that support the world, and Yahweh is the one who set the world on the pillars. Yahweh makes the world stable.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are the most miserable places in your community? What do you call the places where you put your garbage or pile up the manure of your animals? Where do the poorest people of your community sit? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of a seat of honor together. How will you talk about a throne, or a seat of honor? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What is your culture's traditional belief about what keeps the world stable? Do you want to use traditional special language in this part of Hannah's song-poem, or do you want to change this part to speak about what we understand about the Earth now? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of pillars as a group. Pause this audio here.

Yahweh always guards the feet of his faithful ones, but Yahweh makes wicked people silent in death. Feet here represent the whole bodies of Yahweh's faithful people. The Israelites often used one part of something to represent the whole thing. Yahweh's faithful people are those who obey Yahweh. The wicked are the evil people who disobey Yahweh. Hannah is using the picture of warriors whose feet were slipping, but Yahweh causes these people to walk securely so their enemies cannot defeat them. Yahweh makes Yahweh's enemies silent in death. Yahweh does these things to show that people cannot win victories using their own strength.

Stop and discuss this question as a group: How do you speak about causing someone else to be silent because you have overpowered that person? Pause this audio here.

Hannah makes several statements about what Yahweh will do, but these statements are also Hannah's prayer to Yahweh, asking him to do these things. Hannah uses special language to talk about Yahweh defeating Yahweh's enemies. Yahweh will break Yahweh's enemies to pieces, shatter them, and thunder against them from heaven. For the Israelites, thunder was a symbol of God's powerful judgment. One title the Israelites had for God was "The Most High," because God has the most power and authority, and God dwells in the highest place in heaven. The "ends of the Earth" was a way of speaking about every part of the Earth. Yahweh will judge all the people in the whole world. Yahweh will set apart a man to be the people's king, and Yahweh will make that man strong.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you speak about all the people in the whole world? Pause this audio here.

After Hannah finishes her song-prayer, Hannah and Elkanah go home to Ramah, but Samuel stays in Shiloh and serves Yahweh by helping Eli the priest.

When Hannah talks about Yahweh reversing people's fortunes, Hannah uses several different examples of people: weak people, strong people, poor people, rich people, barren women, women with many children, faithful people, and wicked people. You might want to choose one person who represents all strong people and another person who represents all weak people, and then do this same thing for each type of person Hannah talks about. You will probably want to have some children as well, so you can show that Yahweh gives children to the barren woman and takes children away from the woman who already had children.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 2:1–11 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has four scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Hannah

  • Yahweh

  • Elkanah

  • Eli

  • Samuel

  • The Israelites

  • Strong people who are full, rich, powerful, and have children

  • Weak people who are hungry, poor, powerless, and barren

  • Faithful people

  • God's enemies

  • And God's anointed one, the king

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Hannah prayed and said, "My heart rejoices in Yahweh! Yahweh has made me strong. My mouth speaks boldly over my enemies. I rejoice because you rescued me."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Hannah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so happy! Yahweh has been so good to me! or

  • Peninnah used to speak boldly against me, but Yahweh has changed my fortune, and now I speak boldly against Peninnah; or

  • Yahweh took away my shame by giving me the son I asked for!

"No one is holy like Yahweh! There is no one equal to Yahweh! No one is a rock like our God!"

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Hannah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Our God is the only true God; or

  • God is perfect in a way that no one else is; or

  • No one protects us the way God protects us.

"Stop acting so proud and haughty! Do not speak arrogant words, because Yahweh knows everything and Yahweh judges everything people do."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Israelites, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Hannah is right! We must be humble before God; or

  • It is scary to remember that God knows everything I think, say, and do! or

  • God will judge me for my sin someday. I must humble myself before God so that God will have mercy on me.

"Yahweh breaks the bows of the strong men, but Yahweh gives strength to weak men."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing a strong man, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I must remember that my strength comes from God; or

  • If I am proud, God might take away my strength and make me weak; or

  • It is true that it is not my bow or my muscles that make me strong, but it is God. I should be humble so God will not make me weak.

Ask the person playing the weak man, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Even though it looks like the strong man will certainly defeat me, God is able to make the strong man weak; or

  • I do not need to be afraid of my enemies' strength. God is much stronger than my enemies; or

  • If I stay humble before God, God might make me strong enough to defeat my enemies.

Now repeat those same steps for each kind of reversal of fortunes that Hannah mentioned. Each time, the answers may be a little different, but the strong people should see that God is stronger than they are, and the weak people should be comforted that God can change their circumstances.

"Yahweh will destroy those who fight against Yahweh. Yahweh will shatter those people. Yahweh's wrath will be like thunder against those people from heaven. Yahweh will judge everyone on Earth. Yahweh will set a man apart and make that man a strong king."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Yahweh's enemy, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am terrified! or

  • I do not care. I will keep fighting against Yahweh; or

  • I will surrender. Yahweh is stronger than me.

Ask the person playing an Israelite, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Sometimes it looks like our enemies will defeat us, but God fights for us; or

  • I am so relieved that God will not let our enemies win when they fight us, because we are God's people; or

  • I am excited that God will give us a strong king!

Then Elkanah and Hannah went home to Ramah, but the boy Samuel stayed in Shiloh and served Yahweh by helping Eli the priest.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Hannah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am sad to leave my little boy, but God was so good to me, so I am happy to keep my promise; or

  • I am so thankful that God has removed my shame! or

  • I am thankful to serve God because God is so good and strong and perfect in all that God does.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 2:1–11 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Hannah says that her heart rejoices in Yahweh's deliverance, or salvation. Hannah's heart is where Hannah's feelings and thoughts are. Hannah's heart is the inner part of herself. Use the same word for heart that you have used in previous passages. Heart is in the Master Glossary.

Stop here and discuss what word or phrase you will use for salvation. Look up salvation in the Master Glossary. Some versions say victory here, but in any case, Hannah rejoices because Yahweh has saved her, or rescued Hannah from her circumstances. Pause this audio here.

"There is none holy like Yahweh." Holy means God is completely good, pure, powerful, and majestic. Holy means that God is whole, complete, and unchangeable. God alone is God. Yahweh is the name God gave himself. God is the one who created everything. God is the most powerful spiritual being. Use the same words for God and Yahweh as you used in previous passages. God and Yahweh are in the Master Glossary.

Stop here and discuss what word you will use for holy. Look up holy in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

"The barren woman has given birth to seven children." The Israelites considered seven to be the perfect, complete number.

Stop here and discuss how you describe women who are barren or unable to have children in your language. Pause this audio here.

"Yahweh brings down to Sheol and raises up." Sheol is the word the Israelites used for the place of the dead. The Israelites believed Sheol was under the earth, so the Israelites talked about going down to Sheol.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for Sheol. Look up Sheol in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

"Yahweh will guard the feet of his faithful ones." Faithful ones are those to whom God has pledged his covenant love or those who obey God. Those who love God and have faith in him also obey God.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for faithful ones. Look up faith in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

"Yahweh will thunder against his enemies from heaven." The word heaven sometimes means the visible sky where birds fly and we can see clouds or stars at night. Most of the time, though, "heaven" refers to the place where God lives with his angels.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for heaven. Look up heaven in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

"Yahweh will exalt the horn of his anointed one." To exalt means to lift up. Horns were symbols of strength and dignity. To anoint someone meant to pour sweet-smelling oil over someone. In the Old Testament, before God gave someone a special task, God would instruct someone else to pour oil over that person's head. Usually, a priest would anoint the man God chose to be king.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for anoint, king, and priest. Look up anoint, king, and priest in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 2:12–26
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 2:12–26 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 2:12–26 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 2:12–26 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

The storyteller ended the last story by saying that Samuel served Yahweh in the presence of Eli. In this story, the storyteller compares Samuel's service with Eli's sons' service. The storyteller says Eli's sons were "worthless" or "wicked" men because they did not respect or honor Yahweh as their ruler.

The storyteller gives examples of the ways Eli's sons showed contempt for Yahweh or did not respect Yahweh. When this story talks about the custom or practice of the priests with the Israelite people, the storyteller is probably referring to the custom or practice of Eli's sons. The storyteller goes on to describe two customs of Eli's sons that are different than what Yahweh commanded for the priests.

When Yahweh, through Moses, told the Israelites how to offer sacrifices many years before, Yahweh said to first burn the fat as an offering to Yahweh. After that, the worshiper was to give the priest the breast and the right thigh of the sacrificed animal. Then the worshiper would normally boil the rest of the sacrifice. It seems that during this time in Israel's history, priests took more than their share of the meat. Eli's sons, the priests at this time, also did not obey those commands. When any man offered a sacrifice and then boiled the meat, Eli's sons would send one of their servants to the man with a fork in his hand. The servant would plunge this three-pronged fork into the kettle, cauldron, or big pot of meat while it was still boiling. The servant would take whatever piece of meat the fork brought out of the pot and give it to Eli's sons. Eli's sons treated everyone who sacrificed at Shiloh this way. Yahweh had instructed the Israelites about which parts of the animal the priests could eat, but Eli's sons were choosing their portions for themselves and asking for more! Then, worst of all, Eli's sons wanted meat even before the people burned the fat. This means that Eli's sons were taking part of the sacrifice that was for Yahweh only.

Stop here and look at a picture of a three-pronged fork. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of a kettle or pot as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and share a story about a good religious leader and a bad religious leader. How do you know which leaders are good and bad? What do those leaders say and do? Pause this audio here.

Eli's sons sinned in other ways, too. Yahweh had instructed the priests to remove and burn the fat of the sacrifices as an offering to Yahweh, but Eli's sons were sending their servants to take Yahweh's fat portion for themselves. If the worshiper argued with the servant and said the priests must burn the fat first, the servant would say no. The servant would threaten to fight with the worshiper if the worshiper did not give the servant the meat right away. The Israelites were trying to obey Yahweh, but Eli's sons would not let them.

Yahweh considered the sins of Eli's sons very terrible. Eli's sons were disrespecting the offerings the people made to Yahweh by not obeying Yahweh's commands about the offerings.

Stop here and share a story about a time when someone did not show proper respect for an important leader in your community. Pause this audio here.

The storyteller switches his focus back to Samuel. At this time, Samuel was a boy serving Yahweh while wearing a linen ephod. The linen ephod was the special robe the priests wore, which people made from linen. Linen is a white fabric that people make from a grain. Linen is comfortable to wear in hot places. The ephod was a special robe that priests wore, so it was unusual to see a boy wearing the ephod. The next sentence says that Samuel's mother used to make Samuel a little robe and bring it to him each year when she went up with her husband to offer the annual sacrifice. The word "little" emphasizes that Samuel was young and small to be wearing an ephod. Samuel was like a little priest.

Stop here and look at a picture of a linen ephod as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop and discuss this question as a group: How do young people in your culture learn the roles of religious leaders? Pause this audio here.

Each year, when Hannah and Elkanah came to Shiloh to offer their annual sacrifice and to bring Samuel a little robe, Eli would ask Yahweh to bless Elkanah by giving Elkanah more children with Hannah. And Yahweh caused Hannah to conceive and give birth to three more sons and two daughters. While Hannah continued to have more children over time, Samuel grew while serving Yahweh in Shiloh.

The storyteller changes the focus back to Eli again. Eli was very old, and Eli kept hearing bad reports about his sons from the people of Yahweh. The storyteller also adds another way that Eli's sons sinned: Eli's sons slept with, or lay with, the women who served at the entrance to the tabernacle of Yahweh. This means Eli's sons had sexual relations with the women. Eli asks his sons why they are doing such wicked things, but Eli is not really asking a question. Eli is telling his sons that they should not be doing such things.

Eli tells his sons that if a person sins against another person, Yahweh will mediate for that person, or make peace between the people. But if someone sins against Yahweh, no one will make peace for that person. Eli is warning his sons that they are sinning against Yahweh, and that Eli's sons should be afraid to continue sinning against Yahweh, because no one will mediate for them.

Stop here and share a story about a time when someone helped bring peace between two people or two groups who were arguing or fighting. Pause this audio here.

But Eli's sons would not listen to Eli, because Yahweh's plan was to put Eli's sons to death.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you talk about the things God wants and plans for people? Talk about a time when it seemed like God wanted something bad for someone. Why do you think God wanted that thing? Pause this audio here.

The storyteller changes the story's focus to Samuel again. Even though Samuel is still young, Samuel is different than Eli's sons. Eli's sons would not listen to their father and stop sinning. Samuel continued to grow physically and in favor with Yahweh and also with men. Both Yahweh and the people, including women, were more and more pleased with Samuel as Samuel grew older.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 2:12–26 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has six scenes.

In the first scene: The person telling the story says that Eli's sons, the priests, were worthless or wicked men who did not know Yahweh. The person who tells the story gives an example of one way Eli's sons were wicked. When any man offered a sacrifice, Eli's sons would rob Yahweh by taking meat that Yahweh did not allow the sons to have. While the meat was still boiling, the servant would plunge his fork into the kettle and pull out whatever meat the fork went into. Then the servant would give that meat to the priest.

In the second scene: The person telling the story gives a second example of a way Eli's sons were wicked. When a man would bring his sacrifice to be burned, Eli's sons would order the man to give the sons the fat portion that belonged to Yahweh. If the man argued, the servant would demand, "Give it to me now, or I will take it from you using force."

In the third scene: The person telling the story says that Yahweh considered the sin of Eli's sons to be very great, because the sons treated the people's offerings to Yahweh with contempt.

In the fourth scene: The storyteller switches to focus on Samuel. Samuel was serving Yahweh in the tabernacle, and Samuel was a boy wearing a linen ephod. Samuel's mother used to make him a new little robe and bring it to Samuel each year when she would travel to Shiloh with her husband to offer the yearly sacrifice. Eli would bless Elkanah and Hannah. Yahweh gave Hannah three more sons and two daughters to take the place of the son Hannah gave to Yahweh.

In the fifth scene: Eli hears the bad reports that Yahweh's people are spreading about Eli's sons. Eli warns his sons to stop sinning against Yahweh. But Eli's sons will not listen because Yahweh plans to kill the sons.

In the sixth scene: The storyteller changes focus again by saying, "Now the boy Samuel continued to grow both in stature and in favor with Yahweh and also with men."

The characters in this passage are:

  • Yahweh, though no one can see Yahweh

  • Eli's son Hophni

  • Eli's son Phinehas

  • Eli

  • Samuel

  • Elkanah

  • Hannah

  • The servants of the priests

  • And other Israelites

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

The storyteller switches the story's focus back and forth several times to show the difference between Samuel and Eli's sons. You might want to have one person narrate the story while other people act the story out.

The first scene begins with a word that shows us that the storyteller is changing the story's focus from the previous passage, where the storyteller talked about Samuel. Here, the story shifts to talk about Eli's sons, Hophni and Phinehas, who were worthless or wicked men. Hannah talked about herself in the same way when she previously asked Eli not to think of Hannah as a worthless or wicked woman. Eli's sons did not know Yahweh, which means they did not respect Yahweh. Eli's sons knew Yahweh's commands, but they did not obey those commands. The sons acted as if they did not know that Yahweh was their ruler.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: When you have a story that keeps switching its focus from one person or scene to another in order to compare the two people, how do you show that the focus of the story is changing? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you speak about someone showing proper respect for a deity? How will you translate the idea of Eli's sons not "knowing" Yahweh? Pause this audio here.

The first scene gives one example of how Eli's sons acted wickedly. The storyteller says, "The custom of the priests," and goes on to describe the custom. A custom is a standard way that people do something. Since the storyteller says Eli's sons were wicked and then describes a custom that was not obedient to Yahweh, the storyteller is probably saying this was Hophni and Phinehas' custom only, not the custom of all priests at the time.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you talk about the standard, accepted way that a priest does his duties at a place of worship? Pause this audio here.

The wicked custom was that a priest's servant would come up to the kettle where a man was boiling his sacrifice in a large pot of water. The servant would plunge a three-pronged fork into the boiling water and pull out whatever piece of meat the fork stabbed. Then the servant would give that piece of meat to the priest.

Stop here and look at a picture of a three-pronged fork as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of a kettle or pot. Pause this audio here.

It is not clear from the story where Hophni or Phinehas would be when the servant would go to get the meat. Both Hophni and Phinehas did this wicked thing of sending their servants to take the meat from the pot. Hophni and Phinehas might have been sitting nearby to watch the servant do what they commanded him to do, or Hophni and Phinehas might have been somewhere else. Wherever Eli's sons were, their servant would bring the sons the meat.

The storyteller begins the second scene with a word that shows that it describes another way Eli's sons acted wickedly. The sons would send their servant to demand that the worshiper give the servant meat for the priest right away, before the priest burned the fat as an offering to Yahweh. When the servant says, "I will take it by force," his words are angry, and the servant is threatening to fight with the worshiper if the worshiper does not give him meat right away.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you talk about one person threatening to fight with another person if that other person does not give what the person demands? Pause this audio here.

The third scene begins with a word that shows that the sins of Eli's sons were very great against Yahweh. The sons' actions showed that they treated the offerings to Yahweh with contempt or disrespect. The sons did not obey Yahweh's instructions about which portion of meat they could eat, how the meat should be cooked, or when the sons should take their portion of meat. Some translations think the "men" who disrespected Yahweh's offering were the Israelite men, so Eli's sons were causing the Israelites to disrespect Yahweh's offerings. But most translations say it was Eli's sons who treated the offerings with disrespect.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: The story strongly said that the sons did not respect Yahweh's instructions. How would you say that in your culture? Pause this audio here.

The beginning of the fourth scene uses a word that shows a quick switch to focus on Samuel. The word for boy also means young man. This is the same word the storyteller used to describe Eli's sons. These words show that the storyteller is comparing Samuel to Eli's sons. Samuel is still a boy, but Samuel is wearing a linen ephod, which is the same kind of robe that the priests wore. Samuel is like a little priest, serving before Yahweh. Samuel is different than Eli's sons, because Samuel is showing Yahweh respect.

Stop and discuss this question as a group: What special items do your priests wear to show that they are priests? What would happen if someone who was not a priest wore these special items? Pause this audio here.

The story stays focused on Samuel by talking about Samuel's parents, but the setting switches back and forth between Samuel's parents' home and Shiloh. Every year, while Hannah was at her home, Hannah made a new little robe for Samuel. Every year, Hannah would bring the new robe to Samuel when she traveled to Shiloh with Elkanah to make their yearly sacrifice. Every year, when Hannah and Elkanah came to Shiloh, Eli would bless Hannah and Elkanah by saying, "May Yahweh give you more children to take the place of the one you prayed for and gave to Yahweh."

Stop and discuss this question as a group: Remember when, in previous stories, you discussed how you talk about events that happen over and over again. How did you decide to talk about such events? Pause this audio here.

At home, Yahweh did bless Elkanah and Hannah with more children together. Some translations say that Yahweh visited Hannah to show that it was Yahweh who caused Hannah to conceive and give birth to three more sons and two daughters. The story only uses the phrase conceive and give birth one time, but Hannah probably conceived and gave birth to each child separately over a period of time. Hannah probably gave birth six times, including Samuel's birth. While Hannah and Elkanah continued to have more children at home, Samuel stayed in Shiloh and grew while serving Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you talk about a woman giving birth? How will you show that each child was born at a different time rather than all at the same time? Pause this audio here.

The fifth scene begins with a word that again shows a change in focus. Eli is very old. Eli hears the Israelites talking about the wicked things Eli's sons are doing. Some translations say Eli heard, and others say Eli kept hearing. Eli probably heard bad reports about his sons more than once, over a period of time. It is not clear how long Eli had been hearing the bad reports, but Eli heard the reports from more than one person. It is not clear if anyone told Eli directly what his sons were doing or if people just talked to each other close enough that Eli could hear them. The phrases "slept with" and "lay with" are polite ways of saying Eli's sons were having sexual intercourse with the women who served at the entrance of Yahweh's tabernacle.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Remember when you discussed how your culture talks politely about the private act between a husband and a wife that they do to make a child. What word or phrase did you use? Would you use the same word or phrase to describe that act when it happens between a man and a woman who are not married? Pause this audio here.

Eli asks his sons why they are doing such wicked things. Eli does not expect the sons to answer his question. Eli says, "No, my sons; it is not a good report the people of Yahweh are spreading." Eli is warning his sons that they should stop doing such wicked things.

Stop and discuss this question as a group: How would a father tell his son that the son is doing something wrong when the son already knows he is doing something wrong? Discuss as a group how you will translate Eli's question. Pause this audio here.

Eli says if someone sins against a man, Yahweh will mediate for that person. The word man here refers to a person, either a man or a woman. The idea is that something might or might not happen, but in this case, a person will certainly sin against another person at some time in his life. The words "mediate" and "intercede" mean to come between two people or two groups in order to help the groups make peace with one another.

Eli asks his sons, "If someone sins against Yahweh, who can intercede for him?" Eli does not expect the sons to answer his question. Eli is warning his sons that they are sinning against Yahweh, and the sons should be afraid to continue sinning against Yahweh, because no one will mediate for the sons. But Eli's sons would not listen to him because Yahweh planned to kill the sons. In other words, Eli's sons would not obey Eli and stop sinning. The reason Eli's sons would not listen is that Yahweh planned to kill the sons. Some texts say that Yahweh planned to "put them to death." Yahweh does not have a body, so this does not mean Yahweh planned to physically kill the sons with Yahweh's hands or with weapons. It means that in a mysterious way, Yahweh plans to do something that causes the sons to die.

Stop here and discuss how you will translate the difference between what happens when a man sins against another man compared to what happens when he sins against Yahweh. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Remember the story you shared earlier about someone who helped bring peace between two people or groups who were fighting or arguing. What word do you use to describe a person who brings peace that way? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you talk about the things God desires and plans? Pause this audio here.

In the sixth scene, the storyteller uses a word to again switch the focus to the boy Samuel. The word boy could refer to a young man of any age between birth and just before the young man got married. We do not know Samuel's exact age, but we know Samuel was still young. This is the same phrase that refers to Eli's sons in order to show the difference between Samuel and Eli's sons. Samuel continued to grow in stature and in favor with Yahweh and with men. Stature can refer to physical size, to the way people like you, or to having wealth or power. Samuel was not becoming wealthy or powerful, so stature probably refers to Samuel's size and the way people thought about him. Samuel continued to get older, taller, and heavier. Samuel also grew in favor with Yahweh and with men. Both Yahweh and the people, including women, were more and more pleased with Samuel as Samuel grew older.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: When you tell a true story, how do you show your listeners that you are changing the focus from one event or person to another event or person? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you talk about someone whom others like and treat well? Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 2:12–26 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has 6 scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Yahweh, though no one can see Yahweh

  • Eli's son Hophni

  • Eli's son Phinehas

  • Eli

  • Samuel

  • Elkanah

  • Hannah

  • The servants of the priests

  • And other Israelites

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Eli's sons were worthless men who did not know God. They did things that priests were not supposed to do.

Eli's sons would send their servants with a three-pronged fork to pull meat out of the pot while it was boiling.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing an Israelite, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like

  • I am angry that this servant is taking meat that should not belong to the priest, or

  • I am afraid. This servant is forcing me to disobey Yahweh with my offering, or

  • I feel helpless to obey Yahweh because I do not want to fight with the priest's servant.

The priest's servant would tell the worshiper to give him meat before they burned the fat.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing a priest's servant, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like

  • I like being a servant of the priest, because it gives me power, or

  • I like how scared this man looks when I tell him to give me the meat, or

  • I want this man to be afraid that I will fight him.

The sin of Eli's sons was very great against Yahweh, because they treated the offerings to Yahweh in a way that showed they did not respect Yahweh at all.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Hophni or Phinehas, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like

  • I am the priest, so I should get any piece of meat I want. I think Yahweh's rules are bad, or

  • Yahweh cannot tell me what to do. I have power too, or

  • I am more important than these regular men. They must do as I tell them since I am the priest.

Samuel was serving Yahweh, a boy wearing a linen ephod. Each year his mother would make a new little robe for him and bring it to him when she traveled to Shiloh with Elkanah to offer their yearly sacrifice.

Each year, Eli blessed Elkanah and Hannah and prayed that Yahweh would give them more children to take the place of the child they had given to Yahweh. Yahweh gave Hannah three more sons and two daughters.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Hannah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like

  • I remember when I feared that Yahweh would never give me children, and Peninnah used to taunt me, or

  • I only asked Yahweh for one child, but he has given me three more sons and two daughters, or

  • Yahweh has been so good to me! My shame is removed and I have many children. I am glad I gave Samuel to Yahweh, because Yahweh is so generous to me!

When Eli was very old, he kept hearing Yahweh's people spreading a bad report about his sons.

Eli warned his sons to stop being wicked, but his sons would not listen because Yahweh planned to kill them. But Samuel continued to grow in stature and in favor with Yahweh and with other men.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like

  • I have given Hophni and Phinehas many chances and many years to repent of their sin, but they continue to sin against me, or

  • Hophni and Phinehas are sinning against me and against the people. Since they will not repent, I will not allow them to continue living and serving as priests, or

  • Samuel shows me the proper respect. He serves me well and he treats the people well. I am very pleased with him.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 2:12–26 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Eli's sons were worthless men who did not know Yahweh. Use the same word or phrase for worthless as you used in the previous passage about Hannah. The word "know" here means that Eli's sons did not respect and obey Yahweh as they should have. Use the same word for Yahweh that you have used in previous passages, and remember that Yahweh is in the Master Glossary.

Whenever people made a sacrifice, the priests would take some of the meat. Use the same words or phrases that you used for sacrifice and priests as you used in previous passages, and see the Master Glossary for more information about sacrifice and priest.

The priests would send "one of their young men," or servants, to stab and take a piece of meat from the pot where it was boiling. Although the original language uses the term for young men, we know that these young men served the priests. If you use a word for servant, use the same word or phrase for servant as you have used previously, and see the Master Glossary for more information about servant.

The sin of Eli's sons was very great. When people sin, they disobey Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for sin. If you have already translated sin in another book of the Bible, use the same word here. Look up sin in the Master Glossary for more information. Pause the audio here.

Samuel was a little boy wearing a linen ephod. An ephod was an item of clothing that priests usually wore, so Samuel was like a little priest ministering before Yahweh. Linen is a white fabric that people make from a grain. Linen is comfortable to wear in hot, dry places.

Stop here and look at a picture of a linen ephod as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for linen ephod. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. For more information, look up the word ephod in the Master Glossary. Pause this audio here.

Hannah conceived and gave birth to three sons and two daughters. The word conceived refers to the moment when a new life begins in the mother's womb. Gave birth refers to the way the mother pushes a baby out of her body. Use the same words or phrases for conceived and gave birth as you used in the previous passage when Hannah conceived and gave birth to Samuel.

Eli asks his sons, "Why do you do such things?" Eli's sons were also sleeping with, or lying with, the women who served at the entrance of Yahweh's tent of meeting, or tabernacle. Use the same word for tabernacle that you used in previous passages. For more information, look up tabernacle in the Master Glossary.

Eli said that his sons were doing wicked things. Use the same word or phrase for wicked as you have used in previous stories, and see the Master Glossary for more information about wickedness.

Eli scolded his sons and said, "If a man sins against another man, Yahweh will mediate, or intercede, for him." All people sin against other people at some point in their lives. The words mediate and intercede mean that a person comes between two people or two groups in order to help them have peace with each other.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use to translate this idea that when a person sins against another person, Yahweh will help them make peace with each other. Pause this audio here.

Eli's sons were sinning against Yahweh, but Samuel was growing both in stature and in favor with Yahweh and with the people who knew Samuel. Stature probably refers to Samuel's physical growth in age, height, and weight. Favor refers to the way Yahweh and the people who knew Samuel became more and more pleased with Samuel as he grew older. The Bible uses the same phrase to describe Jesus in the Gospel of Luke. If you have already translated the book of Luke, use the same words or phrases you used for stature and favor in that book.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
