title: 1 Samuel 2:27–36
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 2:27–36 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 2:27–36 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 2:27–36 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous section, Yahweh planned that Hophni and Phinehas would refuse to obey their father, Eli, because Yahweh planned to kill Hophni and Phinehas. This section tells more about what will happen to Eli and his sons. A prophet, or man of God, comes to bring Yahweh's message to Eli.

Yahweh uses questions to remind Eli that Yahweh had made himself known to Eli's ancestors. Yahweh did this while Eli's ancestors were still slaves who belonged to Pharaoh, the king of Egypt. Yahweh chose Eli's ancestor Aaron from all the tribes of Israel to be Yahweh's priest. Aaron was to do all of the priest's work. This included going up to Yahweh's altar to offer sacrifices on the altar. Aaron was also to burn incense, which was a mix of sweet-smelling spices. And Aaron was to wear an ephod. The high priest's ephod was more special than the one little Samuel wore. People made this ephod of colored threads, and the ephod had a part that went over the shoulders and chest, into which people set valuable jewels. The priest had to wear or carry this ephod when the priest served in the most holy part of Yahweh's house. This ephod held the urim and thummim, the holy lots that the priest used to determine Yahweh's will. This was a very important item of clothing for the high priest.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are the duties of a priest or special religious leader in your community? What kinds of clothes do priests wear to show that they are set apart for service to God? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh tells Eli that Yahweh gave Eli's ancestors part of all of Yahweh's meat offerings that the Israelites made with fire. In this way, Yahweh provided food for the priests. Yahweh uses a question to accuse Eli and Eli's sons of disrespecting or hating Yahweh's sacrifices and offerings that Yahweh commanded for the place where Yahweh lives. Eli honored his sons more than Eli honored Yahweh because Eli and his sons made themselves fat by eating the best meat of all the offerings of Yahweh's people. In the previous story, we saw that it was Eli's sons who were doing this, but since Eli is their father and Yahweh's priest, Yahweh blames Eli for his sons' disobedience. When Yahweh gave the Israelites his law, the first command was to worship Yahweh, and after that, the Israelites were to honor each other. Eli disobeyed Yahweh's command by honoring his sons first.

Stop here and share a story about a time when someone punished a father who did not stop that father's children from sinning. Pause this audio here.

The prophet continues speaking Yahweh's words to Eli. Yahweh had promised that Eli's family and the rest of Eli's ancestors' family would serve Yahweh forever. But now Yahweh is changing his promise. Yahweh will not allow all of Aaron's descendants to serve Yahweh as priests, but only those who honor Yahweh. Yahweh will honor those who honor Yahweh, but Yahweh will shame those who do not respect Yahweh. Since Eli has not respected Yahweh, Yahweh will dishonor Eli.

The prophet warns Eli that Yahweh will judge Eli soon. Yahweh says he will cut off, or destroy, the strength of Eli's father's household. The young men of Eli's family will die while they are still young and strong. Eli will weep so much that Eli will not be able to see. Eli will watch with envy as Yahweh does good things for the rest of the Israelites but not for Eli's family. Some translations say Eli will see bad things happen to the place where Yahweh lives, the tabernacle.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What do people consider a terrible curse in your culture? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh says that any of Eli's descendants whom Yahweh allows to serve as priest, Yahweh will also allow to live. Many years after this story, Eli's descendant Abiathar escapes when King Saul kills the other priests of Nob and removes Abiathar from being a priest. Any of Eli's descendants who live will weep and grieve, and men will violently kill the rest of Eli's male descendants before they reach old age. Eli will not live to see all of Eli's descendants die, so Yahweh gives Eli a sign that this curse will happen: men will kill Eli's sons, Hophni and Phinehas, on the same day.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Share a story about a time when an unusual event let you know that something important was going to happen. Pause this audio here.

Yahweh says he will raise up a faithful priest to serve Yahweh, and Yahweh will establish this priest's house, or descendants, to be priests forever. Unlike Hophni and Phineas, the priest Yahweh raises up will act according to what is in Yahweh's heart and mind, or all that Yahweh plans and desires. Yahweh will give this new priest male descendants, so that this priest and his family will serve Yahweh's chosen king as priests forever. Most people think this refers to Zadok, whose family served Yahweh's kings from the time of David until Israel's enemies destroyed the temple. Zadok descended from Aaron through Aaron's son Eleazar. Eli descended from Aaron through his son Ithamar. Yahweh is not talking about Samuel when he talks about this priest. Yahweh made Samuel a prophet, not a priest.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In Israelite culture, a priest would anoint or pour oil on a man to set that man apart for special work, especially the work of a king. How does a religious leader in your culture set someone apart to do special work? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh says that everyone who is left in Eli's house will come to the faithful priest and beg the priest to give them a job among the priests so they can have food to eat. Eli's sons, Hophni and Phinehas, acted as if Yahweh was not generous enough by taking food that belonged to Yahweh and making themselves fat. Hophni and Phinehas' descendants will see that Yahweh is generous to the priests and will wish they could serve as priests, but Yahweh will not let them.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 2:27–36 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has three scenes.

In the first scene: A prophet speaks Yahweh's words to Eli. Yahweh reminds Eli of the promise Yahweh made to Eli's ancestors when the Israelites were slaves to Pharaoh in Egypt. Yahweh gave Eli's ancestors special work to do, and Yahweh fed them from portions of the Israelites' offerings to Yahweh.

In the second scene: Yahweh continues speaking to Eli through the prophet. Yahweh shows his anger and says Yahweh will now change his promise because of Eli's sin. Yahweh will cause people to violently kill Eli's descendants while they are still young men. Yahweh gives Eli a sign that this judgment is coming: both of Eli's sons, Hophni and Phinehas, will be killed on the same day.

In the third scene: Yahweh continues speaking to Eli through the prophet. Yahweh says he will raise up a faithful priest to serve him, and Eli's descendants will beg that priest to give them work to do so they can have food to eat.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Yahweh

  • A man of God

  • Eli

  • Hophni

  • Phinehas

  • Eli's descendants

  • And the faithful priest

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

The storyteller begins this section with a word that shows that the focus is changing from Samuel back to Eli. A man of God comes to Eli to tell him Yahweh's words. Storytellers sometimes use the phrase "man of God" to describe a prophet. A prophet is a man Yahweh sends with Yahweh's message. The storyteller does not tell us where Eli was when the prophet came to Eli. When the prophet says, "Thus says Yahweh," the prophet is using a typical phrase that Israelite prophets used. The things the prophet says after that phrase are the words of Yahweh himself. The prophet speaks the words, but they are not the prophet's words, so the prophet speaks them as if Yahweh himself is speaking, saying things like "I" and "my." Yahweh asks a question, but it is not a question Yahweh wants Eli to answer. Yahweh is reminding Eli that Yahweh revealed himself to Eli's father's house many years ago when they were Pharaoh's slaves in Egypt. Yahweh is not talking about Eli's father, but about Eli's ancestor Aaron. The term "father" could be used for any man who came before Eli in Eli's family line. Pharaoh was the title for the king in Egypt. Pharaoh was not the king's name.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How will you show the change in focus from Samuel to Eli at the beginning of this section? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Although the man who came to Eli was a prophet, the storyteller simply calls this man a "man of God." How will you say that? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How does a prophet show which of his words are his own and which are the words the prophet is speaking for a deity? How will you translate the statement the man of God makes to introduce the words that Yahweh says? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh uses more questions to remind Eli that Yahweh chose Aaron from all the tribes of Israel to be Yahweh's priest. Now Yahweh describes again the important things that a priest does. A priest goes up to his altar and offers sacrifices on it, burns incense, and wears an ephod. The ephod was important because it carried the holy lots, the urim and thummim, that helped the priest to know the will of Yahweh. This shows that part of the priest's work was to find out the will of Yahweh for the people. Yahweh says the priest goes up to his altar, because the altar at that time had steps for the priest to climb. The Israelites would give the animal as an offering, but the priests would burn the offering on the altar. Yahweh gave Eli's ancestors a portion of all the offerings made with fire. In this way, Yahweh provided food for the priests.

The 12 tribes of Israel were the extended families of Israel's sons. The tribes all spoke the same language. Aaron's family was not a whole tribe of Levi, but one family from Levi's tribe.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What do you call a man who is someone's ancestor from many generations ago? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How would you refer to the large, extended families that each descended from one father? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of an altar as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of incense as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of a priest's ephod as a group. Pause this audio here.

Yahweh accuses Eli and Eli's sons of despising, or scorning, Yahweh's animal sacrifices and the other offerings that Yahweh commanded his people to make at Yahweh's tabernacle, where Yahweh lived. Eli and Eli's sons have made themselves fat by eating the first, or best, pieces of meat and by eating the fat that should have belonged to Yahweh. Yahweh blames Eli because it was Eli's sons who were doing this. Because Eli was Yahweh's priest, Eli should have stopped his sons' wicked behavior. Yahweh uses a question to tell Eli he was wrong to honor his sons more than he honored Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you talk about the things people offer to God? Do you have different words for different types of things people offer, such as animals or grains? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when someone treated something that had special honor as if it had no value at all. Pay attention to the words you use. Pause this audio here.

The man of God now shows that Yahweh, the God of Israel, is about to say something very important: Even though Yahweh promised that Eli's house and the rest of Eli's father's house would always serve Yahweh as priests, Yahweh will change his promise because of Eli's sins and Eli's sons' sins. Yahweh says, "Far be it from me!" to show that Yahweh is very angry and he will not continue with that promise. Then Yahweh uses a special word to emphasize that Yahweh is making a change in the promise. Yahweh will not honor all of Aaron's descendants, but only those who honor Yahweh. Yahweh will shame any of Aaron's descendants who do not respect Yahweh. Yahweh uses several different words that all mean not to respect someone. The Israelites often said something two or three different ways to emphasize what they were saying. Yahweh wants to emphasize that Eli has dishonored Yahweh, so Yahweh will dishonor Eli.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: The Israelites used the word house or household to refer to a whole family. How do you refer to a whole family, including parents, children, grandparents, and other family members? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: The phrase "Far be it from me!" appears several times in the book of 1 Samuel. Tell a story about how someone in your culture would express anger and a complete change from something they said or promised in the past. Pay attention to the words you use to show that anger and change of mind. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you emphasize that what you are about to say is an important change from what you said before? Pause this audio here.

The man of God says, "Behold the days are coming," which was a typical way for prophets to announce that Yahweh would send judgment or punishment soon. Yahweh tells Eli that Yahweh will cut off or destroy the strength of Eli's father's household. All the members of Eli's family will die before they reach old age.

Stop and discuss this question as a group: Share a story about a time when a prophet warned someone that God was going to judge that person soon. Pause this audio here.

Stop and discuss this question as a group: How do people in your culture describe their ancestors from long ago and their distant descendants many years from now? Pause this audio here.

Some translations say that Eli will look with envy as Yahweh does good to the rest of Israel but not to Eli's family. Other translations say that Eli will see bad things happen to Yahweh's dwelling, the tabernacle. In any case, Eli will be sad because of the bad things Eli sees happening.

Most translations say it is Eli who will weep, even though Eli will not live to see all of his descendants die. Other translations say it is Eli's descendants who will weep. Yahweh says that any of Eli's descendants whom Yahweh does not "cut off" from serving him as priest, Yahweh will allow to live. The phrase "cut off" that Yahweh used can mean to destroy, separate, or send away from a place. Abiathar was the last descendant of Eli to serve as priest. Solomon did not kill Abiathar, but he did remove Abiathar from serving as priest and sent Abiathar to live in another town.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when a leader sent someone away from a place or killed that person to punish him for something. Pay attention to the words you use to describe the leader sending the person away permanently. Pause this audio here.

When Yahweh says "you will weep your eyes out," or "go blind with weeping," and your heart or soul will grieve, it does not mean that Eli's eyes will actually fall out or that Eli will actually go blind. This is special language to show that Eli will weep so much that Eli will not be able to see, because Eli will be very sad all the time. Eli will weep because all of his other descendants will be "killed by the sword." This is an expression the Israelites used to talk about any violent killing, even if a man used a weapon other than a sword to do that killing. Eli might also weep because he sees bad things happen to the place where Yahweh lives, the tabernacle. While Yahweh punishes Eli's family, Yahweh will still do good to Israel.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you talk about someone who weeps often because they are very sad, such as a person whose child dies from a terrible accident? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when one man violently killed another man. Pay attention to the words you use to describe the killing. Pause this audio here.

Yahweh says he will give Eli a sign. A sign proves that what a prophet said is true. Eli would not live long enough to see all of Eli's descendants die, so Yahweh gives Eli a sign that all of these things would happen. The sign is that someone would kill Eli's sons, Hophni and Phinehas, on the same day. When someone kills Eli's sons on the same day, that will prove to Eli that Yahweh will also stop Eli's descendants from serving at his altar and will not allow those descendants to live until they are old.

Stop here and remember the story you told about a time when an unusual event led you to believe that something important was going to happen. How did you talk about that event? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh says that Yahweh will raise up, or choose, a priest for himself who will be faithful. This priest will do all that is in Yahweh's heart and mind. In Israelite culture, the heart referred to the inner person or a person's will. The mind referred to a person's soul or that person's desires. Yahweh will also make sure the new priest has a long line of descendants who will serve Yahweh as priests. This priest will always serve Yahweh's anointed one. Anointed one usually refers to the king Yahweh chooses to rule over Israel. The priest Zadok is listed as a descendant of Aaron in the book of Chronicles, and he lived to serve Yahweh's anointed king.

The storyteller begins the final section with language that shows the difference between Eli's descendants and the faithful priest whom Yahweh chooses for himself. The prophet speaks for Yahweh, and Yahweh says the words Eli's descendants will say. Eli's descendants will bow down low to show they are humble. Everyone left in Eli's priestly family will be so poor that they will beg the new priest for even the smallest wages and for food. Eli's descendants will say, "Please give us jobs among the priests so that we may have bread to eat." For the Israelites, bread was such an important part of their diet that they often used bread as a symbol for all food. Hophni and Phinehas made themselves fat by taking offerings that belonged to Yahweh. Hophni and Phinehas' descendants will be hungry.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What is the most common and important food in your culture? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are some common things people in your culture beg for? How do they beg? Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 2:27–36 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has three scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Yahweh

  • A man of God

  • Eli

  • Hophni

  • Phinehas

  • Eli's descendants

  • And the faithful priest

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

One of Yahweh's prophets came to Eli and said, "This is what Yahweh says: Did I not reveal myself to your ancestor's family when they were slaves of the Pharaoh in Egypt? I called him out of all the tribes of Israel and chose him to serve me as priest. I also gave his family food from all the Israelites' food offerings. Why have you disrespected my sacrifices and offerings that I commanded at my place of worship? You have honored your sons more than me by making yourselves fat with the best part of my people's offerings."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Eli, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so ashamed! or

  • I regret my sin! Why did I disrespect Yahweh when he was so generous to my family? or

  • Yahweh is right! I have honored my sons more than Yahweh, even though Yahweh deserved my honor. I have no answer for these questions.

Ask the person playing the man of God, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am nervous to speak this message to Yahweh's priest; or

  • I hope Eli will not be angry with me, but I must give him Yahweh's message even though it is a hard message; or

  • If this is Yahweh's message to his priest, I must be very careful to honor Yahweh, too. No one is above Yahweh. No one can dishonor Yahweh and avoid his punishment.

Yahweh, the God of Israel, declared, "I promised that your family would serve before me forever, but not any longer! Those who honor me, I will honor. Those who dishonor me, I will dishonor. Very soon, I will destroy your family's strength so that none of your family will reach old age. You will see bad things happen in my place of worship, even though I will do good to Israel. Any man of your descendants whom I do not remove from serving me as priest will be sad and weep so much that he cannot see. Other men will violently kill all of your descendants. This is the sign that everything I have said will happen: your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, will both be killed on the same day."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Eli, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • This is a terrible punishment! or

  • My family will be so ashamed! Everyone will know that Yahweh is angry with me; or

  • I regret that my descendants will suffer so much because I sinned this way!

Then I will raise up a faithful priest to serve me. This priest will obey all of my plans and desires. I will make sure this priest has a long line of descendants. This priest will serve my anointed one, the king I choose for Israel, forever. Anyone who is left in your family will bow low to the ground and beg this priest for a piece of silver or a loaf of bread. Your descendants will say to this priest, "Please give us work among the priests so we can have food to eat."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Eli, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I wish now that I had honored Yahweh as a faithful priest; or

  • I see now that Yahweh was generous to let us serve as priests and eat from the Israelites' offerings; or

  • I am so humiliated that my descendants will be beggars. Yahweh is shaming my family, and we deserve this shame.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 2:27–36 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

A man of God is a prophet. A prophet is a person who gives messages from God to the people. For more information about the general term for God, look up God in the Master Glossary.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for man of God or prophet. Look up prophet in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The man of God speaks for Yahweh. For more information about God's personal name, look up Yahweh in the Master Glossary. If you have already translated Yahweh, use the same word in all the places where Yahweh is used. Pause this audio here.

Yahweh chose Eli's father's house. Sometimes, father means the man who created a child with the child's mother. Other times, father can refer to any man among a person's ancestors, including that person's grandfather, and so on.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Remember when you discussed what you call a man who is someone's ancestor from many generations ago. What word did you use? Use the same word in all the places where father means someone's ancestor. Pause this audio here.

Yahweh chose Eli's father's house. Sometimes a house refers to a building in which a family lives. In this case, house refers to a family, including the long line of the family's descendants, because often generations of a family would live in the same house. Use the same word or phrase that you used for house in previous passages when it meant family and descendants. For more information, look up household in the Master Glossary.

This passage also uses the word dwelling, which is a place where someone lives. Yahweh said he commanded sacrifices and offerings for his dwelling, the place where Yahweh lived. The people knew Yahweh was referring to the tabernacle. For more information about Yahweh's dwelling, look up tabernacle in the Master Glossary.

Yahweh chose Eli's family from among all the tribes of Israel when they were slaves of the Pharaoh of Egypt. "Tribes" refers to all the extended families descended from one man. The tribes of Israel all spoke the same language. Pharaoh was the word for king in Egypt. Pharaoh was a title, not a name.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Remember when you discussed how you refer to large, extended families who all descend from one man. What word did you use? Use the same word in all the places where the storyteller uses the word for tribes. If you have translated the word tribe in a previous book of the Bible, use the same word here. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How would you like to translate the word Pharaoh? For more information, look up Pharaoh in the Master Glossary. If you have already translated pharaoh in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Eli's ancestors were Yahweh's priests. A priest is someone who works in Yahweh's dwelling or place of worship. This person is between God and the people.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for priest. Look up priest in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The priest would go up to Yahweh's altar. An altar is a place where people make offerings or sacrifices to God.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for altar. Look up altar in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of an altar as a group. Pause this audio here.

The priest would burn incense, a perfume people made with sweet-smelling spices and gums. People usually burned incense for a deity.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for incense. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of incense as a group. Pause this audio here.

A priest would wear an ephod when he served before Yahweh in Yahweh's dwelling. A priest's ephod was a piece of clothing that people made from colored fabric, with a special piece that went over the shoulders and chest with jewels in it. Only high priests wore this.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for ephod. Look up ephod in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of a high priest's ephod as a group. Pause this audio here.

Eli and his sons scorned Yahweh's offerings. Scorn probably means to trample on something. Eli and his sons did not literally trample on Yahweh's offerings. This is special language that compares the men's disrespect for Yahweh's offerings to the way an animal might carelessly walk on top of something it should not step on. For more information, look up sacrifices and offerings in the Master Glossary. The words sacrifices and offerings often appear together in the Old Testament to refer to the whole Israelite sacrificial system. Use the same words or phrases for sacrifices and offerings that you used in previous passages.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Remember the story you told about someone treating something that had special honor as if it had no value. What words did you use? How will you translate the idea of scorn? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh gave Eli a sign that this prophecy would happen. A sign is something unusual that is happening for a special reason.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for sign. Look up sign in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Yahweh would raise up a faithful priest who would do all that was in Yahweh's "heart and mind," or soul. In the Bible, the heart is special language for the place where a person's thoughts, feelings, and decisions happen. Look up heart in the Master Glossary for more information.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for the whole phrase heart and mind. Look up mind in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this phrase in another book of the Bible, use the same phrase that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Yahweh's faithful priest would serve Yahweh's anointed one. To anoint someone means to pour sweet-smelling oil over that person. Before Yahweh gave someone a special task, Yahweh would instruct someone else to pour oil over that person's head. In this case, Yahweh's anointed one is the person Yahweh chose to be Israel's king.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for anointed one. Look up anoint in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 3:1–14
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 3:1–14 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 3:1–14 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 3:1–14 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous passage, Yahweh spoke to Eli through a messenger. In this passage, God speaks directly to Samuel, who is serving Yahweh by assisting Eli. This passage says the word of Yahweh was rare at this time in Israel's history. Also, Yahweh did not often give visions to his prophets at this time. A vision was when a person saw something from God that other people did not see, or heard something from God that other people did not hear. A vision was different than a dream because the person was awake when they had a vision. Both the word of Yahweh and visions were messages from Yahweh. These details let us know how unusual it was that Yahweh spoke to Samuel.

Stop here and tell a story about a time when someone heard God speaking to that person or saw a vision from God. How common is it for God to speak to people in your community or give people visions? Pause this audio here.

One night, the priest Eli is lying down in his own place where Eli usually sleeps at night. Eli can barely see because Eli's sight is becoming very weak. The lamp of God has not yet gone out, so this means that it is still nighttime, before the sun rises. Yahweh had instructed Yahweh's priests to set up a sacred lamp in the tabernacle. One of the priest's jobs was to keep the lamp burning all night long. While the people of Israel sleep at night, Yahweh always stays awake. Eli's bad eyesight might explain why Samuel later comes to Eli when Yahweh calls Samuel. Perhaps Samuel is used to Eli calling to Samuel for help because of Eli's bad eyesight.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of the lamp of God burning in the tabernacle. Pause this audio here.

Samuel is sleeping in Yahweh's tabernacle, near the ark of God. The ark of God was in a special part of the tabernacle, behind a curtain. Only the priest could go into the part of the tabernacle where the priests kept the ark of God. The ark of God was a special box that people made of a wood called acacia and covered inside and outside with gold. The ark of God held special items inside it to remind the Israelites of God's covenant with the Israelites. The Israelites believed God lived in the space above the ark, so the ark was a symbol of God's presence.

Stop here and look at a picture of the ark of God as a group. Pause this audio here.

Then Yahweh calls to Samuel, and Samuel says, "Here I am!" Samuel runs to Eli and says, "Here I am, because you called me." But Eli says, "I did not call you. Lie down on your bed again." So Samuel goes and lies down.

And Yahweh calls again, "Samuel!" Samuel gets up from his bed and goes to Eli and says, "Here I am, because you called me." But Eli says, "I did not call you, my son. Lie down again."

Samuel does not yet know Yahweh because Yahweh has not yet shown Yahweh's word, or will, to Samuel. In other words, Yahweh has never before given Samuel a personal message. This explains why Samuel keeps going to Eli, because Samuel thinks it is Eli who is calling Samuel. It also shows that Yahweh is now going to speak to Samuel.

Yahweh calls Samuel again a third time. Samuel gets up from his bed, goes to Eli, and says, "Here I am, because you called me." After the third time, Eli realizes that Yahweh is the one calling the boy, so Eli says to Samuel, "Go, lie down, and if he calls you, say 'Speak, Yahweh. Your servant is listening to you.'" This was the proper and humble way for a prophet to reply when Yahweh gave a message. So Samuel goes and lies down in his place.

Yahweh comes and stands, calling like he had the other times, "Samuel! Samuel!" In other parts of the Bible, when Yahweh calls people twice, Yahweh has an important and urgent message for that person, and Yahweh has a special job for that person to do. Often, when Yahweh calls a man's name twice, Yahweh also appears to the man in a visible way, like the time Yahweh appeared to Moses in the burning bush. With Samuel, Yahweh calls twice and also comes and stands near Samuel. Samuel does what Eli instructed and says, "Speak, because your servant is listening."

Stop here and share a story about a time when God spoke to someone and revealed himself to that person. Pause this audio here.

Then Yahweh tells Samuel to listen carefully to what Yahweh says next. Yahweh tells Samuel that Yahweh plans to do something shocking soon. This thing will cause everyone who hears about it to be very surprised.

Yahweh prepares Samuel to be Yahweh's messenger, or prophet, by telling Samuel what Yahweh plans to do in Israel. Before this, Samuel did not know Yahweh, because Yahweh had not yet given Samuel a personal message. Now, Yahweh is showing Samuel his word, or Yahweh's will. This is something special Yahweh does for his messengers. Yahweh speaks to Yahweh's messengers directly.

Stop and discuss this question as a group: How do you know when someone is God's messenger? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh tells Samuel that Yahweh plans to do everything he had threatened to do against Eli and Eli's family—every detail of that plan. When people hear what Yahweh does, people will be shocked. Yahweh had told Eli before that Yahweh would soon punish Eli's family line forever because Eli knew about the sins Eli's sons did, and Eli did not stop them. Eli's sons dishonored Yahweh and made Yahweh seem less powerful and important than Yahweh is. Yahweh had already told the Israelites that Yahweh would punish this sin with death.

Yahweh tells Eli that Yahweh is going to keep the oath, or promise, he made to Eli's family. Eli's family will never be able to make a sacrifice or offering that will make it possible for Yahweh to forgive their sins. When Yahweh gave the Israelites his law about how the Israelites should live, Yahweh told the Israelites how priests could make sacrifices and offerings for their own sins. However, Hophni and Phinehas's sins are terrible. Hophni and Phinehas had continually shown such disrespect for Yahweh's sacrifices and offerings that Yahweh would no longer allow Hophni and Phinehas to make sacrifices and offerings in order to cover for or atone for their sins.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How can people in your culture be forgiven when they do something wrong? Share a story about a time when someone did something so bad for so long that no one would forgive that person.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 3:1–14 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has five scenes.

In the first scene: The narrator reminds the audience that Samuel was serving Yahweh as Eli's assistant. At this time in Israel's history, Yahweh rarely spoke to his prophets or gave them visions. One night Eli and Samuel were both sleeping in the tabernacle area and the lamp of God was still burning.

In the second scene: God calls to Samuel. Then Samuel runs to Eli and says, "Here I am, because you called me." But Eli says that Eli did not call Samuel. Eli tells Samuel to go back to bed.

In the third scene: God calls to Samuel again, and Samuel goes to Eli again and says, "Here I am, because you called me." But Eli says he did not call Samuel and tells Samuel to go back to bed again.

In the fourth scene: God calls Samuel a third time. Samuel goes to Eli again, and this time Eli realizes it is God who calls Samuel. Eli tells Samuel that the next time the voice calls to Samuel, Samuel should reply, "Speak, Yahweh, for your servant is listening to you." And Eli tells Samuel to go back to bed.

In the fifth scene: God calls a fourth time and reveals himself to Samuel. God repeats Samuel's name two times, "Samuel! Samuel!" Samuel responds the way Eli told him to. Yahweh tells Samuel about his plans to punish Eli's family because Hophni and Phinehas sinned against Yahweh, and Eli knew about it and did not stop them. Yahweh says everyone who hears about it will be shocked, but there is nothing Eli's family can do now in order to be forgiven.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel

  • Yahweh

  • And Eli

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

This passage shifts focus from Eli back to Samuel. The storyteller reminds us that the boy Samuel was serving Yahweh as Eli's assistant. Samuel was probably about 10 to 15 years old. The word of Yahweh was rare in those days, and people did not often have visions of Yahweh. The word of Yahweh refers to Yahweh's message through Yahweh's prophets. This helps us understand how unusual it is that Yahweh speaks to Samuel and gives Samuel a message.

Stop here and share a story about a very unusual thing that really happened. What words or phrases did you use to let your listener know that your story was unusual and true? Pause this audio here.

Eli was sleeping in his usual place when this story begins. The tabernacle had places like rooms in its courtyard where the priests and Levites would sleep when they served in the tabernacle. Eli's eyes were becoming dim or blind. Eli could barely see anymore. The lamp of God was still burning, so we know that it was still nighttime, before the sun rose.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you speak about someone whose eyes are beginning to see less and less, so that he is almost blind? Pause this audio here.

Samuel was also lying down in Yahweh's tabernacle, which was the tent where Yahweh lived at this time. Samuel was probably in one of the rooms in the courtyard where priests and Levites slept. Samuel was near the ark of God, but not in the same room as the ark of God, because only the high priest could go near the ark of God. One of the priest's jobs was to keep the lamp burning all night, and Samuel would have helped Eli with this job.

Yahweh called Samuel, and Samuel said, "Here I am!" Samuel ran to Eli and said, "Here I am, because you called me." But Eli said, "I did not call you. Go lie down in your bed again." So Samuel went and lay down.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How would someone in your culture respond if they heard an honorable person calling to them? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh called again, "Samuel!" Samuel went to Eli and said, "Here I am, because you called me." Notice that this time, Samuel did not run to Eli but simply went to him. Eli said, "I did not call you, my son. Lie down on your bed again." Samuel was not actually Eli's son, but Eli called Samuel "son" as a way to show tenderness to Samuel.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How would someone in your culture speak to a child whom he loved like his own child but who is not actually that person's child? Pause this audio here.

Here, the person telling the story interrupts the story to give us more information. The storyteller says Samuel did not yet know Yahweh because Yahweh had not revealed himself or his will to Samuel personally. In the original language, this does not mean that Samuel did not know who Yahweh was, but that Yahweh had never given Samuel a personal message before. At the beginning of the story, the storyteller already mentioned that Yahweh did not speak to his prophets often or give them visions often at this time in Israel's history. Now, we hear this added information to show that Yahweh had never before spoken directly to Samuel. This is probably why Samuel did not know it was Yahweh calling to Samuel. It also tells us that Samuel was soon going to know Yahweh, because Yahweh was going to reveal himself to Samuel.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are some reasons why a person might choose to give important information out of order when telling a story? How does giving the information in that order make the story better? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh called Samuel again a third time. This is the third time we see this pattern repeated in the story. This time Eli responds differently from the way he did the first two times. Eli has a new understanding of what is happening. In the Bible, when something happens three times, that shows it is important. Maybe this is why Eli now realizes who is calling Samuel. So Eli tells Samuel that when the voice calls Samuel again, Samuel should reply, "Speak, Yahweh, because your servant is listening to you." Eli is not telling Samuel to command Yahweh to speak, but to make a humble request for Yahweh to speak to Samuel. In the culture at this time, people would sometimes speak about themselves as if they were someone else, such as calling themselves "your servant" in order to show respect.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, what is the proper way for a prophet to reply to a message from God? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do people in your culture refer to themselves when they speak to someone whom people highly honor and respect? Pause this audio here.

The next time Yahweh came, Yahweh stood and called again, "Samuel! Samuel!" This is the first time Yahweh not only called but also stood. Yahweh does not have a body, so Yahweh does not literally stand, but this probably means Yahweh not only spoke words to Samuel but also showed himself to Samuel in a visible way. Yahweh does not have a physical body, so it is not clear how he appeared to Samuel.

Yahweh calls Samuel's name two times, which shows it was a special type of calling. Yahweh also called the names of Abraham, Jacob, and Moses two times in earlier stories in the Bible. Samuel says almost exactly what Eli told him to say, but Samuel does not say Yahweh's name. Instead, Samuel just says, "Speak, for your servant is listening to you." It is not clear why Samuel does not say Yahweh's name as Eli has instructed.

Then Yahweh uses language that shows he wanted Samuel to listen carefully to what Yahweh said next. Yahweh told Samuel he planned to do something shocking soon. Yahweh uses special language about tingling ears to show that the people who hear about what Yahweh does will be very surprised. Yahweh uses this same expression in two other places in the Bible where Yahweh tells the Israelites he is going to punish people, and the ears of those who hear about it will tingle. This means the people will not only be surprised but also very afraid.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do people in your culture tell someone to listen carefully to what they say next? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do people in your culture talk about something they plan to do very soon when they do not want to say exactly what day or time they plan to do it? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and share a story about a time when something very terrible happened to an honored leader, and how people reacted when they heard about that thing. What language did you use to show how surprised the people were when they heard about it? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh says he is going to judge or punish Eli's house or family exactly as Yahweh told Eli he would when he spoke to Eli earlier through the man of God. The language Yahweh uses means Yahweh will do everything he threatened. Yahweh says he told Eli he was going to judge Eli's family forever because Eli knew his sons dishonored Yahweh and made him seem less powerful and important than he is. When the men did that, they brought Yahweh's curse upon themselves. Eli should have done more than just tell his sons they were sinning. Eli should have stopped his sons.

Stop here and share a story about a time when someone dishonored an honorable person and made that person seem less powerful and important than he was. What language did you use to talk about the way that person treated the honorable person badly? Pause this audio here.

Because Eli knew about his sons' sin and did not stop his sons, Yahweh makes an oath or promise to Eli's family that Yahweh will not cover or wipe away their sins against Yahweh. There will never be an offering or sacrifice that Eli's family can make to cause Yahweh to forgive their sins now. Eli's family did not treat Yahweh's sacrifices and offerings with the honor they deserved, and now Eli's family will not be able to make any sacrifices or offerings to atone for, or cover or remove, their own guilt.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 3:1–14 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has five scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel

  • Yahweh

  • And Eli

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Then Yahweh called Samuel, and Samuel said, "Here I am!" And Samuel ran to Eli and said, "Here I am, because you called me."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Eli must need my help because Eli's eyesight is so weak; or

  • I wonder why Eli needs my help in the middle of the night? or

  • I hope Eli is okay. Eli is a very old man now.

Then Yahweh called again, "Samuel!" and Samuel got up and went to Eli and said, "Here I am, because you called me." But Eli said, "I did not call, my son. Lie down in your bed again."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Eli, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Samuel is such a good boy to come quickly when he thinks I have called him; or

  • I wonder why Samuel keeps thinking I am calling him. Samuel must be sleeping badly; or

  • This is the second time tonight that Samuel thought I was calling him. The poor child is acting strangely.

Yahweh called Samuel a third time. And Samuel got up and went to Eli and said, "Here I am, because you called me." Then Eli realized it was Yahweh who was calling the boy, so Eli told Samuel, "Go lie down in your bed again, and if he calls you again, say, 'Speak Yahweh, for your servant is listening to you.'"

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Eli, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • This is the third time someone has called Samuel. This must be a special calling; or

  • Yahweh often does special things three times, so it must be Yahweh calling Samuel; or

  • If Yahweh is speaking to Samuel, I must teach Samuel how to respond like a prophet.

Yahweh came and stood. And Yahweh called like he had the other times, "Samuel! Samuel!" And Samuel said, "Speak, for your servant is listening to you."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I cannot believe Yahweh is speaking to me and appearing to me! or

  • I am so amazed that I cannot even say his name! or

  • I have been serving Yahweh my whole life, but this is the first time Yahweh has spoken to me! What will Yahweh say to me?

Yahweh said to Eli that Yahweh would punish Eli's family forever. Yahweh would do this because Eli knew his sons were dishonoring Yahweh, and Eli did not stop them. Yahweh promises that nothing will cause Yahweh to cover up or wipe away the sins Eli's family has committed.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • It is time to punish Eli's family as I said I would when I spoke to Eli through my messenger; or

  • Eli and his sons might have thought they could keep sinning without being punished, but they were wrong; or

  • Eli and his sons have sinned so terribly that I will not show them any mercy.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 3:1–14 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Now the boy Samuel served Yahweh by assisting Eli. The word the storyteller uses here refers to a boy around 10 to 15 years of age.

Stop here and discuss as a group which word you will use for boy. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

In those days, the word of Yahweh was rare. The word of Yahweh is a message from Yahweh. People did not receive many visions. A vision was when a person saw something from God that other people did not see, or heard something from God that other people did not hear. Use the same word for Yahweh as you have used in previous passages, and remember that Yahweh is in the Master Glossary.

Stop here and discuss as a group how you will translate word of Yahweh and vision. For more information about a vision, refer to the Master Glossary. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The lamp of God had not yet gone out, and Samuel was lying down in the temple of Yahweh near the ark of God. The lamp of God was a sacred lamp, holy and dedicated to God. The priest made sure this lamp had enough oil to keep burning through the night every night. The lamp of God stood inside the tabernacle, before the curtain that separated the holy place from the most holy place, where the priests kept the ark of God.

Stop here and review what phrase you have used for lamp of God in the book of Exodus. If you have already translated this phrase, use the same word that you have used there. Remember that God is in the Master Glossary. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of the lamp of God as a group. Pause this audio here.

The story tells us that Samuel was lying down in the temple of Yahweh, but people had not yet built the temple at the time of this story. The word for temple here also refers to a palace or someone's special house, so sometimes the Israelites called the tabernacle the temple. Some translations say that Samuel was lying in the "house of Yahweh." Samuel was actually lying in the tabernacle or tent where Yahweh lived and where people worshiped Yahweh. Samuel was probably lying in a part of the courtyard of the tabernacle where there were spaces for the priests and Levites to sleep when they served Yahweh in the tabernacle. For more information, refer to tabernacle or temple in the Master Glossary.

Stop here and discuss how you will translate temple, house of Yahweh, or tabernacle of Yahweh. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The ark of God was a chest that people made from the wood of the acacia tree. The chest was covered inside and outside with gold. The chest held the tablets of the law that God gave to Moses; a pot of the manna, or special food, that God gave the Israelites while they wandered in the desert; and Aaron's rod that had budded. The ark of God was meant to remind the Israelites that God had promised to be with them. People sometimes called the ark of God "the ark of the covenant."

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for ark of God. Look up ark of the covenant in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Eli told Samuel to go and lie down, and if the voice called to Samuel again, Samuel should say, "Speak, Yahweh, for your servant is listening." A servant is a man or woman who works for another person. Use the same word or phrase for servant as you used in previous passages. Servant is in the Master Glossary.

Yahweh told Samuel that Yahweh was going to judge Eli's family forever because of the sin Eli knew about. Sin is an act of rebellion against God. Use the same word or phrase for sin as you used in previous passages. Sin is in the Master Glossary.

Yahweh said that Eli's sons were bringing curses on themselves, which means that Yahweh would punish Eli's sons because they were blaspheming or disrespecting God. You may either say that Eli's sons were bringing curses on themselves or that they were blaspheming God.

Stop here and discuss as a group what you will say about what Eli's sons were doing. Refer to the Master Glossary for information about blasphemy and about curse. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Yahweh told Samuel that the guilt of Eli's house would never be atoned for by making sacrifices or giving offerings. Atone means to cover over and reconcile or restore a relationship with God when the relationship has been broken because someone sinned or because someone was impure.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for atone. Look up atonement in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

A sacrifice is a gift to God. Use the same word or phrase for sacrifice as you used in previous passages. Sacrifice is in the Master Glossary. The phrase "sacrifices and offerings" is often used together in the Old Testament to refer to the whole Israelite sacrificial system.

An offering is a gift or sacrifice that people offer in a ritual to God, usually in the temple or on a special altar. Use the same word or phrase for offering as you used in previous passages. Offering is in the Master Glossary.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 3:15–4:1a
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 3:15–4:1a and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 3:15–4:1a three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 3:15–4:1a in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

This passage begins hours after the previous story. Yahweh gave Samuel a vision sometime during the night, and now it is morning. Samuel and Eli are still in Yahweh's house, the tabernacle.

Samuel lies in his bed until morning. The passage does not say whether Samuel goes back to sleep or not. The passage only says that Samuel lies in his bed. When it is morning, Samuel opens the doors of the tabernacle, as Samuel probably did every morning as one of his jobs for Eli. The tabernacle was a tent, but the Israelites might have built doors in front of the entrance to the tabernacle after they settled in Shiloh. This was the first thing Samuel did on that morning. Samuel was afraid to tell Eli about the vision Yahweh had given Samuel.

Stop here and look at a picture of the tabernacle together as a group. Pause this audio here.

Eli really wants to know what Yahweh said to Samuel, even though Samuel is afraid to tell Eli. In the previous story, Eli was the one who finally realized it was Yahweh calling Samuel and who told Samuel how to reply. Now that it is morning, Eli still remembers that Yahweh spoke to Samuel. As soon as Samuel opens the doors, Eli calls Samuel.

Eli asks Samuel what Yahweh told Samuel. Eli seems to already know that Samuel is afraid to tell Eli. But Eli shows how serious Eli is by adding that Samuel should not hide Yahweh's words from Eli. Eli uses an oath, or a curse, by asking God to punish Samuel if Samuel does not tell Eli the whole truth.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are some oaths or curses that people in your culture use to make someone obey that person? Pause this audio here.

So Samuel tells Eli everything. Samuel does not hide anything from Eli. After Samuel tells Eli everything, Eli replies humbly that he accepts Yahweh's plan because Yahweh has the right to do what Yahweh thinks is best.

And Samuel grows, both physically and spiritually. Remember, Samuel is probably between the ages of 10 and 15 years old when Yahweh first speaks to Samuel, so Samuel continues to grow physically, but he also continues to grow spiritually. Yahweh is with Samuel. This shows that Samuel is a true believer. Yahweh does everything he spoke through Samuel. Everyone in the whole country of Israel knows that Samuel is Yahweh's true and faithful prophet, or Yahweh's messenger to the Israelites. Everyone in Israel, from Dan to Beersheba, refers to all the Israelites, because those towns were at the northern and southern boundaries of Israel. The emphasis is on all the people of Israel, not on the land itself.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel together as a group. Pause this audio here.

The expression "Yahweh was with Samuel" is a phrase we commonly see in the Old Testament. This phrase means that Yahweh blessed Samuel. Yahweh protected Samuel, guided him, and caused him to succeed. The storyteller uses special language to say that Yahweh caused Samuel to speak Yahweh's words faithfully to the Israelites. All the Israelites could see that Samuel was Yahweh's trusted prophet because every message Samuel spoke for God was true.

In the previous story, the storyteller began by saying that Yahweh's word was rare in Israel. In this story, the storyteller ends by saying Yahweh spoke to Samuel over and over again.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 3:15–4:1a in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has three scenes.

In the first scene: Samuel gets out of his bed in the morning after Yahweh spoke to him. Samuel opens the doors of the tabernacle, as Samuel probably did every morning. Samuel is afraid to tell Eli what Yahweh said to Samuel in the nighttime.

In the second scene: As soon as Samuel opens the doors, Eli calls Samuel to come to Eli. Samuel comes to Eli and answers respectfully. Eli gently asks Samuel to tell Eli what Yahweh said to Samuel. But Eli also makes an oath where he calls on Yahweh to punish Samuel if Samuel does not tell Eli every word that Yahweh spoke to Samuel. Samuel tells Eli everything Yahweh said to Samuel, and Eli humbly accepts Yahweh's plan.

In the third scene: Samuel continues to grow both physically and spiritually. Yahweh does everything Yahweh says he will do through Samuel. All the Israelites know that Samuel is Yahweh's true prophet. Yahweh continues to appear to Samuel in Shiloh by speaking Yahweh's word to Samuel.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Yahweh

  • Samuel

  • Eli

  • And all the Israelites

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

Samuel lies down in his bed after Yahweh spoke to him. In the morning, Samuel opens the doors of Yahweh's house, the tabernacle. The tabernacle was a tent, but the Israelites might have built wooden doors in front of the entrance after they settled in Shiloh because the Israelites did not move the tent anymore.

In the next part, the storyteller begins with language that shows the difference between Samuel being afraid to speak to Eli about his vision from Yahweh and Eli wanting Samuel to tell Eli. A vision was when a person saw something from God or heard something from God that other people did not see or hear. Even if God only spoke words, people still called it a vision.

But Eli calls Samuel. It is possible Eli is still in his room in the courtyard of the tabernacle when Eli calls Samuel. Eli uses the phrase "my son" even though Samuel is not Eli's son. Eli does this to show affection for Samuel.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Remember in the previous story when you talked about how someone in your culture would refer to a child whom he loved like his own son, but who is not his own son. What word or phrase did you use? Pause this audio here.

Samuel comes to Eli and answers him respectfully. Samuel and Eli probably continue their conversation in Eli's room in the courtyard of the tabernacle. Eli asks Samuel what Yahweh said to Samuel during the night. Eli seems to already know that Samuel is afraid to tell Eli, because Eli uses language that makes his request more gentle. Eli tells Samuel not to hide Yahweh's words from Eli. Eli even makes an oath, or curse, that calls for Yahweh to punish Samuel if Samuel hides any of Yahweh's words from Eli. So Samuel tells Eli everything. Samuel does not hide anything from Eli. The Israelites used this pattern of first saying something in a positive way, like "Samuel told Eli everything," and then repeating the idea in a negative way, like "Samuel did not hide anything." The Israelites did this to emphasize that what they were saying was important.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do people in your culture emphasize something they say in a true story? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss how you will translate Eli's oath that called on God to punish Samuel if Samuel did not tell Eli everything Yahweh had said to Samuel. Pause this audio here.

Eli humbly accepts that Samuel's words are from Yahweh. Eli uses the special language, "good in his own eyes," to say that Yahweh has the right to do what Yahweh thinks is best.

The next passage talks about a much longer period of time, beginning from the time of this conversation and continuing through many years of Samuel's life. Samuel grew to become a man and Yahweh was with Samuel. Samuel was probably between the ages of 10 and 15 years old when Yahweh first spoke to Samuel. It might be good to have a younger person play the part of Samuel at the beginning of the story and then have an adult play the part of Samuel at this point in the story.

Yahweh continued to appear at Shiloh. Yahweh revealed himself to Samuel at Shiloh by his own word. This means that Yahweh himself spoke to Samuel directly. Samuel's words, which were Yahweh's words, went out to all of the Israelites. These are three ways to say that Samuel was a true prophet of Yahweh who spoke Yahweh's true words to the Israelites. The Israelites often repeated important things three times to show that those things were important. The storyteller uses special language when he says, "None of Samuel's words fell to the ground." This means that Yahweh made sure that nothing Samuel spoke on Yahweh's behalf was false.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do people in your culture refer to someone who speaks God's messages to the people? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Share a story about a prophet who said that something would happen, and then that thing did happen just as the prophet said it would. Pay attention to the language you use to talk about the prophet's words. How would you emphasize that none of the prophet's words were false? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh continued to appear to Samuel in Shiloh over and over again. The storyteller does not say exactly how many times Yahweh appeared, but this means Yahweh appeared many times. Yahweh made himself known to Samuel through the things Yahweh said to Samuel when he visited Samuel. It is not clear if Samuel could see Yahweh during these visits or if Yahweh only spoke to Samuel. Through Yahweh's messages to Samuel, Samuel learned to know Yahweh. Samuel spoke Yahweh's messages to all the Israelites, and the Israelites believed the messages.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 3:15–4:1a in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has three scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Yahweh

  • Samuel

  • Eli

  • And all the Israelites

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Samuel lay down until morning and then opened the doors of Yahweh's house. It was probably the entrance doors of the tabernacle that Samuel opened. Eli probably heard Samuel open the doors while Eli was still in Eli's own room. Eli called to Samuel and said, "Samuel, my son."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am afraid to face Eli; or

  • How can I tell Eli what Yahweh said without making Eli angry at me? or

  • Maybe I can avoid telling Eli what Yahweh said last night.

Samuel answered, "Here I am." Eli asked, "What did Yahweh say to you? Do not hide it from me. May God deal with you, be it ever so severely, if you hide from me anything he told you."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Eli, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Did Yahweh talk to Samuel about me? or

  • I am ashamed to think that Yahweh might have told Samuel about my sin; or

  • I hope Yahweh will not add even more to my punishment than Yahweh already told me about.

So Samuel told Eli everything. Samuel did not hide anything from Eli. Then Eli said, "He is Yahweh; let him do what is good in his eyes."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Eli, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I deserve Yahweh's punishment for my sin; or

  • Yahweh has the right to do what he knows is best; or

  • I am no match for Yahweh's wisdom or strength.

Yahweh was with Samuel as he grew up, and Yahweh let none of Samuel's words fall to the ground. All Israel from Dan to Beersheba recognized that Samuel was a prophet of Yahweh.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing an Israelite, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Every time Samuel says he is speaking Yahweh's words, the words turn out to be true; or

  • If Samuel says something will happen, it always does; or

  • Yahweh is clearly speaking through Samuel, because Samuel could not know all those things on his own.

Yahweh continued to appear at Shiloh, and there Yahweh revealed himself to Samuel through his word. And Samuel's word came to all Israel.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 3:15–4:1a in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Samuel opened the doors of the house of Yahweh. During the time when Samuel was judge, Yahweh lived in the tabernacle, so people called this place "the house of Yahweh" or "the house of God," even though it was a tent. Later, the Israelites built the temple as the house of Yahweh. Yahweh is the name God gave himself. Yahweh is God, the creator of all things and the most powerful spiritual being. Use the same words or phrases for Yahweh and God as you used in previous passages. For more information, look up Yahweh and God in the Master Glossary.

For more information, look up house of God and tabernacle in the Master Glossary, and use the same phrase for "house of Yahweh" as you have used in previous passages.

Samuel was afraid to tell Eli the vision. A vision is when God speaks words to a person or shows a person something that other people do not hear or see. Use the same word or phrase for vision as you used in previous passages. For more information on vision, refer to the Master Glossary.

All the people of Israel from Dan to Beersheba knew that Samuel was established as a prophet of Yahweh. Israel is the territory where the Israelites lived. A prophet is a person who gives messages from God to the people. Use the same words or phrases for prophet and Israel as you used in previous passages. For more information on prophet and Israel, refer to the Master Glossary.

Yahweh revealed himself to Samuel through his word, or his message. Use the same word or phrase for "word" as you have used in previous passages, and look up word in the Master Glossary for more information if necessary.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
