title: 1 Samuel 4:1b–11
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 4:1b-11 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 4:1b-11 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 4:1b-11 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous story, Yahweh revealed himself to Samuel at Shiloh and established Samuel as a prophet throughout Israel. Yahweh also told Samuel that Yahweh would judge the house of Eli.

In this story, Yahweh begins to fulfill Yahweh's promise to judge Eli and Eli's family. The storyteller ended the last story by saying that the word of Samuel came to all Israel. This means that all the Israelites knew and accepted that Yahweh would speak to them through Samuel, Yahweh's prophet. It is possible that the beginning of this story is part of the conclusion of the last story, because it shows that the people of Israel have accepted Samuel as a prophet of Yahweh. However, this story also shows that although the people recognized the word of Samuel, the Israelites went out to battle without asking Yahweh's will through his prophet Samuel.

We do not know the reason that the Israelites went to battle or war against the Philistines. To go out to battle is a military phrase that means the army marched out.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Talk about a time when your community went to war. Which members of your community went to fight in the war? Why did your community have this war, and how did the leaders make the decision to fight? Pause this audio here.

The Israelites made their camp at Ebenezer and their enemies, the Philistines, made their camp at Aphek. This is where the two armies settled before they began the battle, but this is not where the armies fought the battle.

Stop here and look at a map of Ebenezer and Aphek as a group. Pause this audio here.

The Philistines were a warrior tribe of people who came many years before by boats and settled in the coast of the land of Canaan. The Philistines were enemies of the Israelites and fought many battles with them. The Philistines arranged themselves in lines to fight against the Israelites.

When the battle began, the Philistines defeated the Israelites and killed about 4,000 men in the field of battle. Four thousand is not the exact number of Israelites. These soldiers did not run away but died in the field while they were fighting.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: When your warriors go to war, how do your leaders organize the warriors to fight? Pause this audio here.

The remaining Israelites who did not die in battle returned to their camp at Ebenezer. The elders or leaders of the Israelites asked why Yahweh had defeated Israel before the Philistines that day. The elders asked that question because the elders believed that it was Yahweh who caused the Philistines to defeat Israel. The elders of Israel were the leaders of the clans of Israel. The elders were generally old men, but it was not necessary to be old to be an elder.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Who in your community do you view as elders or leaders? What types of leaders do you have for different groups of people? For example, who are your leaders for families, clans, and villages? Pause audio here.

The elders made the decision that they should take the ark of Yahweh's covenant from Shiloh and bring it to Ebenezer so that it may save the Israelites from the hand of their enemies, or the control and power of the Philistines. At this time, the Philistines were ruling over the Israelites. This means that the Israelites served the Philistines by following their orders and paying them taxes. It is possible that the elders were thinking that Yahweh would save the Israelites if they brought the ark to the battle because the ark was a visible sign of Yahweh's presence. It is also possible that the elders believed that the ark itself would save them.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group. What does your community do to ask God to give you victory in a battle or war? How do you react when your enemy has defeated you? Pause audio here.

The ark was a rectangular chest that Yahweh had asked Moses to make of acacia wood. The ark contained the tablets that Yahweh wrote his law on and gave to Moses, a pot of manna, and Aaron's rod that had budded. The Israelites believed that Yahweh literally lived in the space directly above the ark, so the ark came to symbolize Yahweh's presence.

Stop here and look at a picture of the ark as a group. Discuss this question as a group: Tell about an object, ritual, or person in your community that is a sign of God's presence. In what ways can people rely on the object, ritual, or person rather than on God? Pause this audio here.

For this reason, the army sent messengers to Shiloh to bring the ark. Shiloh is a town in the hill country of Ephraim. Shiloh is where the Israelites set up the tabernacle before Yahweh divided the land of Canaan among the tribes of Israel. The distance from Ebenezer to Shiloh is approximately 30 kilometers or 20 miles.

Stop here and look at a map of the journey from Ebenezer to Shiloh as a group and a picture of the people carrying the ark. Pause this audio here.

The messengers brought back "the ark of the covenant of Yahweh of hosts, who is enthroned above the cherubim." This is one of Yahweh's full titles. "Yahweh of hosts" means that Yahweh is the leader of heaven's armies. This title refers to the Israelites' belief that Yahweh literally sat between the carved cherubim on the top or lid of the ark like a king sits on a throne. Cherubim were intelligent, powerful winged creatures that protected Yahweh's things. Cherubim often symbolize Yahweh's presence.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What makes the sacred objects in your community sacred? If the deity lives in the sacred object, where does the deity live in the object? How do the object and the deity connect to each other? Pause the audio here.

Hophni and Phineas, Eli the priest's two sons, also came to the army camp with the ark of Yahweh's covenant. It is likely that the reason that Hophni and Phineas came was because they were in charge of guarding and taking care of the ark.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Who are the people responsible for looking after your community's sacred things? Pause audio here.

When the people carried the ark of Yahweh's covenant into the camp, all the warriors of Israel in the camp shouted a great shout of joy. The shout was so great that it shook the ground all around the warriors.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell stories of when something has happened during a war that has caused your warriors to feel very courageous. How did the warriors react to the thing that gave the warriors courage? Pause this audio here.

When the Philistines heard Israel's warriors shouting, the Philistines became confused. The Philistines asked each other what the great shout that they heard from the Hebrews' camp meant. At this time, the name Hebrew probably meant anyone who did not originally live in the land of Canaan. When the Philistines call the Israelites Hebrews, the Philistines are insulting the Israelites. When the Philistines found out that the Israelites had brought the ark of Yahweh's covenant into their camp, the Philistines were afraid. The Philistines spoke among themselves and said that gods have come into the camp of the Israelites. The Philistines worshiped many gods and probably thought that the Israelites also worshiped many gods. The Philistines became scared and distressed and said that they were in big trouble because nothing like this had ever happened to the Philistines before. The Philistines were in anguish and said that they were doomed! This means the Philistines thought that the gods that had come into the camp of the Israelites would completely destroy the Philistines. The Philistines asked who would save them from the power of these mighty gods that had struck the Egyptians with many blows in the wilderness. The Philistines used this question to show how helpless the Philistines felt. This shows that the Philistines were not very clear on the details of how Yahweh had delivered the Israelites from Egypt. The Philistines were wrong when they said that the gods of the Israelites struck the Egyptians with many plagues in the wilderness. It was Yahweh, not other gods, who struck the Egyptians with many plagues. And Yahweh struck the Egyptians in Egypt, not in the wilderness.

Stop here and talk about a time when your community went to war and your community believed that your enemies' gods defeated you. Pause this audio here.

The Philistines encouraged one another and said, "Let us act like men and be brave because if we do not fight, the Hebrews will defeat us and they will make us their servants just like they have been our servants." The Philistines did not want to be brought under the power and control of the Israelites.

For this reason, the Philistines fought bravely and defeated the Israelites. The Israelite warriors who survived fled to their tents. This means that the warriors escaped the battle and returned home because the enemy had defeated the Israelites. There was a great slaughter that day. The Philistines killed 30,000 Israelite warriors. The Philistines also took the ark of God and killed Hophni and Phineas, Eli's two sons.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What would your people think and do if an enemy defeated you and took away your sacred objects?

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 4:1b-11 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has five scenes.

In the first scene: Israel's warriors march out to war against the Philistine warriors, and the Philistines defeat the Israelites.

In the second scene: Israel's remaining warriors return to the camp and tell Israel's elders about the defeat. The elders decide to send messengers to Shiloh to bring the ark of Yahweh's covenant.

In the third scene: The messengers bring the ark from Shiloh to the Israelites' camp at Ebenezer. Eli's sons accompany the ark of the covenant. The people arrive with the ark, and the Israelite warriors who are in the camp shout with very much joy.

In the fourth scene: The Philistines fear much when they hear the Israelites shouting. The Philistines encourage one another to fight courageously so that the Israelites will not defeat the Philistines and make the Philistines slaves.

In the fifth scene: The Philistines fight courageously and defeat the Israelites. The Philistines kill 30,000 Israelite warriors and take the ark of God. The Philistines also kill Hophni and Phinehas, Eli's two sons.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The Israelite warriors

  • The Philistine warriors

  • Israel's elders

  • The messengers, the men that the army sent to bring the ark of the covenant

  • And Hophni and Phinehas

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the story's setting:

In the first scene, Israel's warriors went out to war against the Philistines. This means that Israel's warriors came together from their different homes and traveled to the battlefield in an organized way. The battlefield is the land where people fight battles in a war. It is likely that the Israelites followed the instructions of leader-warriors. The Israelite warriors made their war camp at Ebenezer, and the Philistines made their war camp at Aphek. A war camp is a place to settle near the battlefield. Warriors make the final preparations for battle in the war camp. The Philistines sent out their warriors from their war camp to fight against the Israelites. The Philistine warriors took up their positions in organized battle lines against the Israelites. When the warriors began the battle, the Philistines killed 4,000 Israelite warriors from the battle lines and defeated Israel. It is important to remember that these events took place in a military setting. If your language has a word or phrase for orderly battle lines that people use in war, you should use that here.

Stop here and do this activity as a group. Choose one member of the group to be the leader of the fighting men, and have the rest of the group play the role of fighting men. Imagine that you are about to fight an enemy. The leader should organize the rest of the group in fighting formation and give these people instructions on how to fight. Try to organize your fighting men in lines and have them face each other so you can see how the Israelites and Philistines lined up in battle. The leader should use military words as much as possible. The rest of the group may suggest better or more appropriate military words. Repeat this activity with the most suitable military words. Pause this audio here.

In the second scene, after the Philistines defeated the Israelites, the Israelite warriors who were not killed returned to their war camp at Ebenezer and told their elders what had happened. Israel's elders could not understand why Yahweh had not helped Israel defeat the Philistines. The elders asked why Yahweh himself had defeated Israel that day before the Philistines. The elders did not expect anyone to answer this question. This question means that the elders believed that Yahweh had not been on Israel's side when Israel fought the war against the Philistines. Israel's elders decided to send messengers to Shiloh to bring the ark of Yahweh's covenant to the battle. The elders probably believed that the reason Yahweh had defeated Israel was that Israel had not brought the ark with them to the war. The elders believed that if the warriors of Israel carried the ark with them into the war, Israel would defeat the Philistines. It is unclear whether the elders believed that Yahweh would save Israel from the hand, or power, of their enemies or whether the elders thought that the ark itself would save Israel. If possible, translate this in a way that keeps this uncertain. But if it is not possible, then it is better to translate it in a way that shows that the elders thought that the ark would save Israel. The hand, or power, of Israel's enemies refers to the control that the Philistines had over Israel.

In the third scene, the messengers who went to Shiloh brought back the ark of the covenant of "Yahweh, who is master of armies and has his throne between the two cherubim." This is Yahweh's full name. "Yahweh of armies" refers to Yahweh as the leader of the armies of Israel or of the armies of angels. You could translate this title as Yahweh, the all-powerful. That Yahweh has his throne between the two cherubim refers to the two winged creatures that Yahweh asked Moses to make on the cover of the ark of the covenant. The Israelites thought that the top of the ark represented the throne of Yahweh.

Eli's two sons, Hophni and Phineas, also went from Shiloh to Ebenezer with the ark. This is probably because Hophni and Phineas were responsible for the ark. It is likely that Hophni and Phineas were the ones who carried the ark.

When the men brought the ark into the Israelites' camp, all the Israelite warriors who were there shouted a great shout of joy. The sound of the men's shout was so loud that it shook the ground in the place where they were.

In the fourth scene, the Philistine warriors heard the great shout that the Israelite warriors made. The Philistines were greatly troubled and asked one another what the great shout in the Hebrew camp meant. By calling the Israelites "Hebrews," the Philistines showed that they felt disgust toward the Israelites because, at this time, people used the name Hebrew to mean foreigner. In your translation, you should not change the name Hebrew to Israelites. You should keep it as Hebrew or express it as closely as possible in your own language.

Stop here and tell stories about a time when foreign tribes or people that your community despises came close to your community. How does your community talk about these people? What kinds of words do people in your community use to describe those people to show how they despise them? Pause the audio here.

The Philistines learned that the Israelites had brought the ark into their camp. So the Philistines were very afraid and said that the gods of the Israelites had come into their camp. And the Philistines said that a great disaster had come upon them because something like this had never happened to the Philistines before. This shows that the Philistines were afraid for themselves and felt threatened by the Israelites. The Philistines asked who would rescue the Philistines from the power of these mighty gods who had come into the camp of the Israelites. When the Philistines said that they were in big trouble and that they were doomed, the Philistines used two kinds of expressions that people use when they are terribly afraid of disaster or destruction by their enemy.

Stop here and tell stories of times when great disasters have happened to your people. What phrases do you use to express this kind of fear and feeling of doom? Pause audio here.

The Philistines said that these were the same Israelite gods who had struck the Egyptians with many plagues in the wilderness. When translating what the Philistines said, remember that the Philistines believed in many gods and probably thought that the Israelites also believed in many gods.

The Philistines encouraged one another to be strong and act like men so that the Philistines would not become slaves of the Israelites as the Israelites had been to the Philistines. It is likely that the leaders of the Philistine army are the ones who stood up to encourage the Philistines not to be afraid but to be men and fight. When the Philistines told each other to be men and fight, they meant that men, unlike women or children, are brave and successful in battle.

Stop here and discuss as a group how your community encourages your warriors to fight courageously when the warriors are too afraid to fight their enemy. What phrases do you use to encourage people to be brave? Pause this audio here.

In the fifth scene, the Philistine warriors reacted to this encouragement and fought the Israelites. The Philistines defeated the Israelites, and the Israelites who survived fled, every man to his own tent. This means that the Israelites who survived gave up fighting. The Philistines killed 30,000 Israelite warriors that day. The Philistines also took the ark of God and killed Hophni and Phineas, Eli's two sons.

Stop here and tell stories about a time when your enemies defeated you in a war. How did your community respond when the enemy defeated your warriors? How did the enemy that defeated you treat you after they defeated you? Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 4:1b-11 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has five scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The Israelite warriors

  • The Philistine warriors

  • Israel's elders

  • The messengers, the men that the army sent to bring the ark of the covenant

  • And Hophni and Phinehas

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Israel's warriors went out to war against the Philistines.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the warriors of Israel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are tired of serving the Philistines. We do not want to follow the Philistines' orders anymore. The Philistines charge us taxes and control our lives; or

  • We can defeat the Philistines. Our leaders are sure of it. Our leaders have made a good war plan, and we will surely win.

The Israelites encamped at Ebenezer, and the Philistines encamped at Aphek.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Philistine warriors, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • The Israelites will regret coming out to war against us. The Israelites have forgotten that we are a very strong nation; or

  • These Israelites have forgotten that we rule over them. We must punish the Israelites severely so that they will not think to fight us again.

The Philistines arranged themselves in battle lines against the Israelites.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Philistine warriors, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are a skillful and experienced army. Look at how we arrange ourselves; or

  • These Israelites are no match for us.

When the battle began, the Philistine warriors defeated the Israelite warriors and killed 4,000 of them on the battlefield.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Israelite warriors, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Oh, how terrible these Philistine warriors are. We cannot beat the Philistines. The Philistines have killed many of our brothers who have fought bravely; or

Ask the person playing Philistine warriors, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We feel victorious! We are fighting well and are destroying the Israelites; or

  • The Israelites' bodies are all over the battlefield. The Israelites keep fighting but cannot defeat us; or

  • We are a superior army. Our warriors fight better than the Israelites' warriors.

In the second scene, the Israelite warriors who survived the battle returned to their camp at Ebenezer and told the leaders of the Israelites how the battle had gone. The elders of Israel said, "Why has Yahweh defeated us today before the Philistines?"

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the elders of Israel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • This is terrible. So many of our warriors have been killed. What is the reason? We were sure that we would be victorious, but our enemy has defeated us; or

  • We must have displeased Yahweh in some way. This is why Yahweh has caused us to be defeated; or

  • We must find what has caused Yahweh not to be on our side. We must make Yahweh happy.

The elders of Israel decided that they should bring the ark of the covenant of Yahweh from Shiloh and bring it to the war so that it might save the Israelites from the hand of the enemy.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the elders of Israel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • It is the ark! That is where we went wrong. We did not carry the ark with us as our fathers used to. That is the reason we lost the battle; or

  • The ark always went before the warriors of Israel in every battle, and the Israelite warriors defeated their enemies. We made a big mistake in leaving the ark of the covenant of Yahweh.

In the third scene, the army sent messengers to Shiloh and brought the ark of the covenant of Yahweh of hosts who is enthroned above the cherubim. Eli's two sons, Hophni and Phineas, also came with the ark of Yahweh's covenant.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the messengers, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Desperate! We need the ark or we will all die. Eli will understand that;

Ask the person playing Hophni and Phineas, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We have heard the terrible news regarding the war. This news is very sad; or

  • Our father is too old to go with the ark. We shall go with the ark to guard and look after it. This is our duty.

When the men carried the ark into the camp of the Israelites at Ebenezer, the warriors of Israel shouted and cheered for joy. The warriors made such a great shout that the ground where they stood shook.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the warriors of Israel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are very happy. Our hearts are greatly encouraged. The ark is like a mighty warrior coming into the camp.

In the fourth scene, the Philistine warriors heard the noise of the great shout that the warriors of Israel made. The Philistine warriors were confused and terrified by the shout and asked each other what the sound meant.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Philistine warriors, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We heard a mighty shout coming out of the camp of the Hebrews. It sounded like the shout of a victorious army, but we have just defeated the Israelites. What could it be that would cause the Israelites to make such a great shout; or

  • What makes these dirty Hebrews, who have just suffered a terrible loss, so excited? What kind of people are these foreigners?"

In the fifth scene, the Philistines found out that the Israelites had carried the ark into their camp. The Philistines became very afraid and said that gods had come into the Israelites' camp. The Philistines said that this meant a great disaster had come upon them because the Philistines had never in their history experienced something like this before.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We feel great fear. Our courage has gone. We are in great danger because we have heard that the Israelites have brought gods into their camp. This is terrible news for us. We shall surely be defeated; or

  • We have never had to fight against gods before. The Israelites made a great shout because they know that now they will destroy us. The Israelites have the power of the gods. What can we do? or

  • Our end has come. We shall be destroyed. This is a great sorrow for us. We feel no hope.

The Philistines said that they were doomed because the gods that had come into the camp of the Israelites were the same gods who had struck the Egyptians with plagues in the wilderness. The Philistines asked who would save them from the hand of these gods.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We can fight human armies, but how can we fight these gods? Can our swords fight against plagues? What shall we do? Who will fight for us and save us from these gods? or

  • We are doomed. These gods will destroy us like they destroyed the Egyptians because we have no one on our side to fight against these gods.

The Philistines encouraged each other to be strong and to be men and fight. The Philistines said that if they did not fight, then the Israelites would make the Philistines serve the Israelites, just as the Israelites served the Philistines before.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We must stand strong. We must be brave. We cannot give up now. If we are too afraid to fight because of these gods, then the Israelites will certainly defeat us and rule over us; or

  • Every Philistine warrior must be brave and be a man. We must not lose hope.

In the fifth scene, the Philistine warriors fought courageously and defeated the Israelites. The Philistines killed 30,000 fighting men of Israel. The rest of the warriors of Israel who were not killed fled from the battle, and each man returned to his own tent. The Philistines captured the ark and killed Eli's two sons, Hophni and Phineas.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the warriors of Israel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • The ark did not help us. The elders of Israel were wrong. What hope is there? We cannot continue fighting; or

Ask the person playing the Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are a mighty army. The Philistine warriors have fought with gods and have conquered them.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 4:1b-11 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Israel went out to battle against the Philistines. The Philistines were a nation of people who came by boat and settled in parts of the land of Canaan before the Israelites came to Canaan. The Philistines became the Israelites' enemies and fought many battles with the Israelites.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for Philistines. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

When the battle began, the Philistines defeated the Israelites and killed 4,000 Israelite warriors. The remaining Israelite warriors who were not killed returned to the camp and told the elders what had happened. An elder is a person with authority in the community. An elder was usually the head of a family or a group of families. A group of elders would meet together to make decisions about the affairs in the community. When you are translating this word, be careful that you do not use a word that just means "old people." An elder was not necessarily an old person, though an elder would not be a very young person either.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for elders. Look up elder in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The elders decided that people needed to bring the ark of God from Shiloh to the war. The "ark of God" refers to the oblong chest that God asked Moses to make from acacia wood. The ark was 115x69x69 centimeters and people covered the ark inside and outside with gold. The ark contained the tablets that Yahweh gave to Moses with the law on them, a pot of manna, and Aaron's rod that had budded.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for the general term for God, and for the ark of God. Look up the ark of the covenant in the Master Glossary for more information. In this story, the storyteller calls the ark by three different names: the "ark of God," the "ark of the covenant of Yahweh," and the "ark of Yahweh." Pause this audio here.

So the elders sent messengers to Shiloh to bring the ark of the covenant of Yahweh of hosts, who dwells between the cherubim. "Yahweh of hosts who dwells between the cherubim" is one of Yahweh's full titles, and you should translate this title in one sentence.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for Yahweh of hosts who dwells between the cherubim. Look up Yahweh of hosts in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Cherubim were some sort of intelligent, powerful angelic beings. Cherubim guard sacred places. Cherubim often symbolize Yahweh's presence. Cherubim have the body of a lion, the wings of a bird, and the face of a human.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for cherubim. Look up cherubim in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

When people carried the ark of Yahweh's covenant into the Israelite camp, the Israelite warriors who were there shouted a great shout. When the Philistines heard the shout, the Philistines asked what the noise in the camp of the Hebrews was. "Hebrew" is the name of the people group who are Abraham's descendants, but it is also the name of the language that this people group spoke. The descendants of Abraham often referred to themselves as Hebrews when they were talking with foreigners. When an Israelite wanted to distinguish himself from a person of another ethnic group, he called himself a "Hebrew." Also, when a foreigner wanted to distinguish himself from an Israelite, the foreigner called that Israelite a "Hebrew." When the Philistines called the Israelites Hebrews, the Philistines meant it as an insulting name. Translators should not use the word Israelite where the storyteller uses the word Hebrew.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for Hebrews. Look up Hebrews in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

When the Philistines found out that the Israelites had brought the ark of Yahweh's covenant into their camp, the Philistines said that these were the gods that struck the Egyptians with plagues in the wilderness. Plagues refer to afflictions that Yahweh sent on the people. Yahweh judged Egypt with many different plagues.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for gods and plagues. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Wilderness refers to a lonely, barren place without water. Almost no trees or bushes grow in the wilderness. The ground is dry and rocky, and wild animals roam around in the wilderness. People do not live in the wilderness.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for wilderness. Look up wilderness in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 4:12–22
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 4:12–22 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 4:12–22 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 4:12–22 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the last story, the Philistines killed many Israelite warriors and defeated the Israelites in battle. The Philistines also killed Eli's two sons, Hophni and Phineas, and the Philistines took the ark of Yahweh's covenant.

In this story, a certain man from the tribe of Benjamin escaped from the battle where the two armies fought. On that same day, that man ran to Shiloh. The distance from Ebenezer to Shiloh is about 30 kilometers. It was common for messengers to run great distances to deliver news. The man had torn his clothes and put dirt on his head. This is how the Israelites showed their sorrow.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What kind of things do people in your culture do when they feel deep sorrow? Pause this audio here.

At the time when the man entered Shiloh, Eli the priest was sitting on his seat watching the road. Shiloh is the town where the Israelites set up the tabernacle before the time when Israel's tribes divided into two separate kingdoms. Eli was sitting on his seat by the roadside at the city gate, which refers to a door or opening in the wall that goes around the city. It is likely that Eli was sitting here so that he could listen to hear the warriors of Israel returning because he was worried for the ark.

Stop here and look at a picture of a city gate as a group. Pause this audio here.

Eli was blind and could not see, but Eli was waiting nervously. Eli's heart trembled for the ark. This means that Eli was anxious about the ark because the Israelite warriors had taken it with them to battle. Eli was not watching with his eyes because Eli was blind. Eli was waiting with a worried and trembling heart because Eli was afraid that the ark was not safe.

The man from the tribe of Benjamin entered the city and began to tell the people in the city what had happened to the Israelite army in the war against the Philistines. All the people cried out in horror when the people heard the report.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell about a time when someone told your community very bad news. How did the people react? For example, how would your community react to the death of the most important person in their community? Pause this audio here.

Eli heard the sound of the people in the city crying. Eli called out and asked why the people were making so much noise. Just then, the man hurried and told Eli the news.

The storyteller interrupts the action of the story with more information about Eli. The storyteller tells us that Eli was 98 years old, and Eli's eyes were fixed so that they could not see. This means that Eli was blind. We know that the rest of the people could see how the Benjamite man had torn his clothes and put dust on his head. But because Eli was old and blind, Eli would not understand what was happening. The storyteller may also tell us that Eli is very old to help us understand why Eli dies suddenly.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell stories about old people in your community who died suddenly when no one expected them to die. Pause this audio here.

The Benjamite man told Eli that he was the man who had come from the battle. Because Eli was blind and could not see the man's torn clothes or the dust on the man's head, Eli would not have immediately known that the Israelites had lost the battle. The man repeated that he was the man who had fled from the battle line that same day. This does not mean that the man ran away from the battle. This means that the man ran to Shiloh after the battle was over and the Philistines had defeated the Israelites. Eli asked the man what had happened. Eli called the man Eli's son. This is probably because Eli felt very anxious and afraid of the news Eli was about to hear. It is also possible that the man found it difficult to tell Eli the tragic news, and Eli wanted to encourage the man to speak.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when someone brought terrible news to your community. Who did the person who brought the bad news speak to, and how did that person speak? Pause audio here.

The man told Eli the news in three parts. The man told Eli that Israel's army had run away from the Philistines and had suffered a great defeat. This means that the Philistines had defeated Israel and killed many of their warriors. The man said that the Philistines had also killed Eli's two sons, Hophni and Phineas. The man also told Eli that the Philistines had even taken the ark of God. As soon as the man told Eli that the Philistines had taken the ark, Eli fell backwards from his seat, which was by the side of the city gate.

Because Eli was an old and heavy man, when Eli fell backwards, the bones of Eli's neck broke and Eli died. Eli had judged Israel for 40 years. This means that the period of Eli being Israel's judge had come to an end. Forty years represents a generation. It is possible that the number 40 is not an exact number for the years that Eli judged Israel. Judges were the leaders of the people of Israel. Yahweh gave the people of Israel many judges at different times. The judges guided the people of Israel and sometimes saved the Israelites from their enemies. A judge acted like a chief or great elder of the community.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Who settles disputes between people in your community? What other roles does this person have, and how does your community select this person? What happens when a judge, or someone like a judge, dies? Pause this audio here.

At that same time, Eli's daughter-in-law, the wife of Eli's son Phineas, was pregnant and near her time to give birth. Phineas' wife heard that the Philistines had captured the ark of God's covenant and killed her father-in-law, Eli, and her husband, Phineas. When Phineas' wife heard this news, the pains of giving birth overwhelmed her, and she bowed and gave birth to a baby. Israelite women gave birth by bowing or kneeling down on their knees.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do women in your culture give birth? Who helps the women give birth? What would happen to a woman who gave birth in the middle of the night or in a situation where she could not reach medical professionals? Pause audio here.

Eli's daughter-in-law had a difficult delivery of her baby, but the women who helped her give birth tried to encourage her and comfort her by telling her that she had given birth to a son. The birth of a son usually made the Israelite families greatly rejoice.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What happens when a son is born in your community, rather than a daughter? Who names the newborn child, and when and how do they name the child? Pause this audio here.

The other women wanted this announcement to help Phineas' wife be strong and recover. But Phineas' wife did not answer the other women or pay any attention to their words of comfort. This means that Phineas' wife did not recover her strength but rather that she died in childbirth. As Phineas' wife was dying, she named the boy that she had given birth to Ichabod. It was usual for a mother to name her child as soon as it was born. It was also normal for the mother to give the child a name that reflected the circumstances of the child's birth. Ichabod means "no glory." Phineas' wife called the child Ichabod because she said that the glory had gone from Israel. Phineas' wife's last words show the sorrow that she felt because the Philistines had captured the ark of Yahweh and killed her father-in-law and husband. Phineas' wife said that the glory had gone from Israel because the Philistines had taken the ark of Yahweh's covenant. Phineas' wife probably meant that Yahweh himself, or Yahweh's glory and majesty, had left Israel and gone to live in the Philistines' country with the ark. Phineas' wife probably thought this way because Yahweh's glory lived above the ark.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What is the most sacred object in your community? What would people in your community think if your enemy took this object?

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 4:12–22 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has four scenes.

In the first scene: A certain Benjamite man survives the battle and runs from the place where the Israelites fought the battle to Shiloh to tell the news to Eli the priest and the people of Shiloh.

In the second scene: The man enters Shiloh and begins to tell the news of the battle to the people in the city. When the people hear the news, the people cry loudly.

In the third scene: Eli hears the people crying. Eli calls out and asks why people are making this noise. The man runs and tells Eli that the Philistines defeated Israel, killed Eli's two sons, and even took the ark of Yahweh's covenant. When Eli hears the news about the ark, Eli falls back on his chair and dies.

In the fourth scene: Eli's daughter-in-law is pregnant and about to give birth. When the woman hears the news, her birth pains come to her and overwhelm her. The woman gives birth to a boy, names the boy Ichabod, and then dies.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The Benjamite messenger

  • The people of Shiloh

  • Eli

  • Eli's daughter-in-law, the wife of Phineas

  • The women who helped Phineas' wife give birth

  • The Philistine army

  • The Israelite army

  • Hophni

  • Phinehas

  • And Ichabod

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In the first scene, the same day that the Philistines defeated Israel, a certain Benjamite man escaped and ran from the battle line to Shiloh. Shiloh is a town located within the hill country of Ephraim. This was where the Israelites set up the tabernacle before the time when Israel's tribes divided into two separate kingdoms. That the man ran from the battle line does not mean that he did not fight. This means that after the Philistines had killed the other Israelites in the battle, this man was still alive, so the man ran away from the battlefield. Battle line is a military word that refers to the place where the armies fought the battle.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about a time when someone escaped a war or a dangerous situation and returned to tell the news. Pause the audio here.

The messenger is from the tribe of Benjamin. The storyteller probably tells us that the messenger is a Benjamite because Yahweh will take the leadership of Israel from Eli and then later give it to Saul, who is a Benjamite. The Benjamite man had torn his clothes and put dirt on his head. An Israelite would do this to show their sorrow when a great disaster had happened. If the idea of the man with torn clothes and dirt on his head does not communicate sorrow in your culture, it might be good to add that he did it to show his great sorrow.

When the man arrived, Eli was sitting on his seat by the side of the road at the city gate. Eli was watching the road because his heart trembled for the ark of Yahweh. This does not mean that Eli was watching with his eyes. It means that Eli was waiting anxiously because Eli was afraid that something bad had happened to the ark. When the Israelites talk of feeling strong emotions, they talk as if the people feel the emotions in their heart. Other cultures and people groups may speak of feeling their strong emotion in other parts of their bodies, such as the kidneys.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, which part of the body do people see as the place where people feel strong emotions? Talk about a time when you were very afraid and anxious to hear news about something. Pay attention to the words you use to describe your feelings. Pause this audio here.

Now the storyteller switches the focus of the story from the messenger to Eli. At the same time the man arrived, Eli was sitting by the side of the road at the city gate. However, the man tells the news to the people in the city before he tells it to Eli. This may be because the man entered the city by a different gate from the one Eli was sitting at. Or maybe the man just passed by Eli without talking to Eli.

In the second scene, the man entered the city and began to tell the news to the people the man met. The man did not speak to everyone in the city together but told the news to the people as he went through the city. It is likely that the man shouted the news sorrowfully as he made his way through the city.

Stop here and do this activity as a group: Choose one person to be a messenger with news about the results of a war that your warriors are fighting in. Let the rest of the group play various members of the community, and let them be busy in their daily routine. Spread the group members around an area so that they are not all in one place. This area will be the city. Then make the messenger come into the city hurriedly. Let the messenger show grief and sorrow the way your community shows grief and sorrow. The messenger should announce the bad news to the first person the messenger sees, and that person should react to the news in the way that your community reacts to a great disaster. That person's reaction should draw the attention of the other members of the community, one by one, and each person should respond until the news has spread to the entire city. Pause audio here.

This news caused the whole city to cry out. This means that all of the people in the city shouted in horror, sadness, and fear.

In the third scene, Eli heard the noise the people made and called out and asked what the noise was. Eli was already worried and anxious about the ark. When Eli heard the noise in the city, the noise probably increased the fear and anxiety that the blind man already felt. Just as Eli called out and asked what the noise was, the man hurried and told Eli the news. The man did not come to Eli because Eli called. Instead, the man happened to come to the place where Eli was seated just at the right time.

Stop here and discuss a time when people in your community mourned or felt great sadness. What words or phrases do you use to describe how people behaved and the noise people made? Pause audio here.

The storyteller slows down the action of the story by adding information about Eli's age and eyesight. Eli was 98 years old, and his eyes were fixed so that he could not see. Eli had probably become blind because of his great old age. If it is more natural in your language, you could put this information about Eli at the beginning of this story when the storyteller first introduces Eli sitting on his seat watching the road. The Benjamite man told Eli that the Benjamite was the man who had come from the battle line. The Benjamite man repeated his words to Eli and added that he had fled from the battle line that same day. The Benjamite man probably did this because he realized that the blind Eli could not tell that the messenger had come with bad news. When Eli understood that the man had come from the battle line, where Eli's sons had taken the ark, Eli asked the man what had happened. Eli called the man "son," probably because Eli felt distressed in his heart by the news he expected to hear regarding the ark. It is also likely that Eli felt the man hesitate to tell Eli the bad news, so Eli may have called the man "son" to encourage the man to speak.

Stop here and do this activity as a group: Choose one person to play the role of Eli and another to play the role of the messenger. Let the person playing the messenger hesitate to deliver the news to Eli, and have Eli encourage the man to speak. Pay attention to the word that the person playing Eli uses for "son." The rest of the group may suggest a more appropriate word in your language. Pause audio here.

The messenger delivered the news to Eli in three parts. Each part of the news is more important than the last and adds to the great impact of the last part of the news. The messenger told Eli that Israel had fled before the Philistines and had suffered many losses. This means that the Philistines had defeated Israel and had also killed many of Israel's warriors. The messenger told Eli that the Philistines had killed Hophni and Phineas and even captured the ark of Yahweh's covenant. As soon as Eli heard that the Philistines had captured the ark, Eli fell backward on his chair towards the side of the gate. This shows that Eli was more concerned about the ark of Yahweh than the defeat of Israel or the death of Eli's sons. Because Eli was an old and heavy man, when Eli fell back on his chair, the bones in Eli's neck broke, and Eli died.

Eli had judged Israel for 40 years. Forty years is a general number of years for one generation. It is possible that the exact number of years that Eli led Israel was more or less than 40.

Stop here and do this activity as a group: Have one person be a messenger with this three-part message or a similar three-part message. Let this person deliver the news to another person with the rest of the group watching. The rest of the group should pay attention to the words that this person uses to join the parts of the message. When this person finishes speaking, the rest of the group should suggest phrases the person can use to show that the news goes from bad to worse. At the same time, the person receiving the news should listen intently and show a reaction to the first and second parts of the news. When the messenger tells the last part of the message, the receiver should react by showing great shock or horror and falling backwards as if someone had hit them and caused them to die. Pause this audio here.

In the fourth scene, Eli's daughter-in-law was at the same time pregnant and ready to give birth. This means that Eli's daughter-in-law was close to her day of giving birth, not that she was at that moment in the process of giving birth. Although the storyteller switches the focus of the story from Eli to his daughter-in-law, the storyteller still emphasizes her connection to Eli. Another way of bringing out this connection with Eli would be to call her the wife of Eli's son Phineas.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Discuss the way your community refers to pregnant women. What do you call a woman who is very close to giving birth? Pause the audio here.

Eli's daughter-in-law heard the news that the ark of Yahweh's covenant had been captured and that her father-in-law and her husband were dead. Immediately, when Eli's daughter-in-law heard this news, the pains of labor came to her and overwhelmed her. This means that although Eli's daughter-in-law was close to the day of giving birth, the shock of hearing the news actually caused her labor pains. So Eli's daughter-in-law knelt down and gave birth. This is the way that Israelite women gave birth.

Stop here and tell a story about a woman giving birth. Pay attention to the phrases you use to describe her giving birth. Pause the audio here.

When Eli's daughter-in-law was about to die, the women who helped her tried to comfort her by telling her that she had given birth to a son. But Eli's daughter-in-law did not pay attention to the women or receive their comfort.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What phrases would women in your community use to encourage a woman who is dying in childbirth to strengthen herself? Pause this audio here.

Eli's daughter-in-law called the boy Ichabod, which means "no glory." Eli's daughter-in-law said she called the boy this name because the glory had departed Israel. The Israelites believed that Yahweh's glory, or Yahweh himself, lived above the ark of the covenant. Because the ark had left Israel, the Israelites would feel like Yahweh himself had left them and gone into the land of the Philistines. Eli's daughter-in-law spoke these words because the Philistines had captured the ark and taken it out of Israel, and because both her father-in-law and her husband were dead.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What is a sign in your community that God is with you? Pause audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 4:12–22 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has four scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The Benjamite messenger

  • The people of Shiloh

  • Eli

  • Eli's daughter-in-law, the wife of Phineas

  • The women who helped Phineas' wife give birth

  • The Philistine army

  • The Israelite army

  • Hophni

  • Phinehas

  • And Ichabod

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

In the first scene, a certain Benjamite man escaped and ran from the battle line to Shiloh. The man had torn his clothes and put dirt on his head.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing The Benjamite messenger, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel great sorrow, grief, and anguish. This is a great disaster. Our enemy has defeated us; or

  • This is the worst day for our nation. Our enemies have taken Yahweh's throne. Yahweh's presence is gone with the ark; or

  • What shall be done for us now? I must run to Shiloh and tell Eli the priest. Surely Eli will know what to do.

When the man arrived, right at that moment Eli was seated on his seat beside the road, waiting anxiously. Eli's heart was anxious about the ark of God.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Eli, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • My heart is in great trouble. I have no peace. I am very worried about the ark. I keep listening to hear the army return, but I hear nothing; or

  • The ark is Yahweh's dwelling place. The ark is where I meet Yahweh. Without the ark, how can we worship Yahweh? or

  • What will happen to Yahweh's covenant with the people of Israel if we lose the ark? Why did I let the people take the ark to this war? Why did I not refuse the elders' request?

In the second scene, the man entered the city of Shiloh and began to tell the people there the news about the war.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Benjamite messenger, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel panic, fear, and anguish. I am confused and heartbroken. I do not know what to do.

When the people in the city heard the news, the whole city cried out.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Shiloh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • This is a disaster. A very great disaster has happened to us today; or

  • This is the death of the people of Israel. Without the ark of the covenant of Yahweh, Yahweh will not dwell with us. We are all alone. Our enemy has conquered us now. What hope is there anymore?

In the third scene, Eli heard the sound of the people's cry and called out and asked what the noise meant.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Eli, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel frightened; or

  • What is happening? Is someone attacking us? Has the army returned? Who will tell me what is going on? or

  • I need help! I need someone to explain what is happening. I cannot see. This noise I hear does not sound good.

Just then, the Benjamite man hurried and told Eli the news.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Benjamite messenger, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Here is Eli! What will he do when he hears? Now that I see the priest of Israel, my heart is even more broken for the loss of the ark. What a great evil has happened in Israel today. I pray Eli knows what to do. Maybe Eli can pray to Yahweh and get the ark back.

Eli was 98 years old, and Eli's eyes had set so that he could not see. The Benjamite messenger told Eli that the messenger had just fled from the battle that same day.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Eli, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel very scared. I hear the noise, but I cannot see. I am unable to tell what is happening; or

  • I feel very vulnerable. I cannot move as easily as I used to when I was younger, and I cannot see. I need a young man to lead me by the hand. If I were able, I would have gone to Ebenezer myself.

Ask the person playing the Benjamite, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • These are the most heartbreaking words I have ever spoken in my life; or

  • I am afraid to tell this old man the horrible thing that has happened to our nation today. How do you share such horrible news?

Eli asked the Benjamite what had happened. The Benjamite messenger told Eli that the Philistines had defeated Israel and killed many of their warriors, and that Eli's two sons were dead and that the Philistines had even taken the ark of Yahweh's covenant.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Eli, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • The Philistines have defeated Israel and killed many warriors in battle. My heart is heavy with fear for the ark; or

  • Oh no! The ark! We are doomed! Israel is destroyed! Our end has come. Without the ark, what are we? What am I? I have failed Yahweh by letting the ark go to war without asking Yahweh.

When Eli heard that the Philistines had taken the ark, Eli fell backwards on his chair by the city gate and broke his neck and died because he was an old and heavy man. Eli had judged Israel for 40 years.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Benjamite, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I have killed the priest. The news I have delivered has surely killed the priest; or

  • This day is the worst day that has ever been. The ark is gone, and the priest is dead. Who will help us now?

Ask the person playing the people of Shiloh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Who shall lead us now? Who will tell us what we must do? or

  • Who will take Eli's place? Eli's sons are also dead. And even if Eli's sons had not died, how could they lead us without the ark? Where would they meet with Yahweh?

In the fourth scene, Eli's daughter-in-law was pregnant near her time to give birth.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Eli's daughter-in-law, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am very happy. Any day now, I will have my baby. I pray that my baby is a boy. My husband will be very happy; or

  • I pray for a safe birth and that the baby will be born healthy. I also pray that my husband will return from Ebenezer. My husband will be so happy when the child is born. I pray that the child is a boy.

When Eli's daughter-in-law heard the news that people had captured the ark of Yahweh's covenant and that her father-in-law and her husband were dead, the pains of giving birth came to her, and she gave birth.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Eli's daughter-in-law, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I cannot breathe. The shock I feel is too great. My life is over. Israel is finished; or

  • My heart is broken by this news. How can such terrible things happen in one day?

When Eli's daughter-in-law was at the point of death, the women who helped her tried to comfort her by telling her that she had given birth to a son. But Eli's daughter-in-law did not respond or pay any attention. Eli's daughter-in-law named the boy Ichabod because she said that the glory had departed from Israel.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the women who helped Eli's daughter-in-law give birth, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • This is so sad. Our hearts are broken for her and for her son and for the house of Eli; or

  • Yahweh is no longer with us. Israel is left alone; or

  • Yahweh is now in the land of the Philistines with the ark. We are all alone.

Eli's daughter-in-law spoke these words because the Philistines had captured the ark of God, and because her father-in-law and her husband had died. Eli's daughter-in-law said the glory had departed because the ark of Yahweh's covenant had been captured.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 4:12–22 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

That same day, a Benjamite ran from the battle line and went to Shiloh. A Benjamite refers to someone who is from the tribe of Benjamin, one of the 12 sons of Jacob. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there.

Battle line is a military term that refers to the place where two armies meet for battle. This is where the armies actually do the fighting. If your language uses military terms, it is better to use them.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for battle line. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The Benjamite man had torn his clothes and put dust on his head. The people of Israel tore their clothes when they felt great sorrow. The people of Israel also put dust on their heads to publicly show that they were mourning. If this custom of the people of Israel is difficult to understand in your language, you may want to say the reason in your translation. For example, you could say, "to show his grief, he had torn his clothes and put dirt on his head."

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for torn his clothes and put dust on his head. Pause this audio here.

When the man arrived, Eli was sitting on his seat by the side of the road, watching, because Eli's heart trembled for the ark of Yahweh. "Watching" means that Eli was waiting anxiously. Use a word that is natural in your language to describe a blind person waiting nervously and listening in order to find out whether the thing he is worried about has happened.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for watching. Pause this audio here.

That Eli's "heart trembled" is a phrase that means that Eli was feeling anxious, scared, or worried. If your culture considers another part of the body to be the place of emotion, it is okay to use that part instead of heart.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for Eli's heart trembling. The word heart is in the Master Glossary. Pause this audio here.

Eli was 98 years old, and his "eyes were set" so that he could not see. This means that Eli was blind. The lenses of Eli's eyes were clouded so that Eli could not see through them.

Stop here and discuss the words and phrases you use in your language to say that a person is blind and unable to see. Discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for eyes were set. Pause audio here.

The man told Eli that he had fled from the battle line that same day. The man told Eli the news that the Philistines had defeated Israel, killed both of Eli's sons, and even taken the ark of God. The people do not call Yahweh by his name in this phrase. The people call Yahweh by a name that means that Yahweh is the most powerful spiritual being who created the universe. The Israelites believed that Yahweh literally lived in the space directly above the ark, so the ark came to symbolize Yahweh's presence. Use the same word for God and "ark of God" that you used in previous passages. Both God and ark of God are in the Master Glossary.

As soon as the man mentioned the ark of Yahweh, Eli fell back on his chair by the side of the city gate. Because Eli was old and heavy, when Eli fell, the bones of Eli's neck broke and he died. Eli had judged Israel for 40 years.

Look up judge in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Eli's daughter-in-law, the wife of Eli's son Phineas, was pregnant and about to give birth. When Eli's daughter-in-law heard the news regarding the ark and her father-in-law and husband, her labor pains overcame her, and she gave birth. As she was dying, Eli's daughter-in-law named the boy that she had given birth to Ichabod, which means "no glory." Eli's daughter-in-law said the glory had departed from Israel. Eli's daughter-in-law was referring to the ark of God that the Philistines had taken and the death of her husband and father-in-law. Glory refers to the power and splendor of Yahweh. It can also refer to Yahweh's presence.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for glory. Look up glory in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
