title: 1 Samuel 5:1–12
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 5:1–12 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 5:1–12 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 5:1–12 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous story, the storyteller told us what happened in Israel after the battle. A certain Benjamite man ran from the battle line and went to Shiloh. This man told the people in the city and the priest Eli how the Philistines had defeated Israel in battle, killed Eli's sons, and taken the ark of God. When Eli heard the news about the ark, Eli fell backwards on his chair and died.

In this story, we hear what the Philistines did after the battle. The storyteller uses the general title for God most of the time. The story starts at the end of the battle. After the Philistines captured the ark of God, the Philistines took the ark with them from Ebenezer to Ashdod. The Philistines probably believed that they were taking the God of the Israelites. In wars, the winners usually took the gods of their enemies to show that they had completely defeated the enemy and the enemy's gods.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What things do you do in battle to show that you have been victorious over your enemies and their gods? Pause this audio here.

The land of the Philistines was made up of five cities that had united politically, commercially, and militarily. Each of the five cities had its own ruler. Ashdod was one of these five Philistine cities. Ashdod was about 56 kilometers from Ebenezer, where the armies fought the battle.

Stop here and look at a map of Philistia as a group. Consider the distance from Ebenezer to each of the five cities of the Philistines and discuss why you think they chose to take the ark to Ashdod. How are the people of your tribe, culture, and language spread out throughout the country you live in? Pause this audio here.

When the Philistines arrived in Ashdod, they carried the ark of God into the temple of Dagon, the Philistines' chief god. Dagon's temple was the place where the Philistines worshiped Dagon and placed Dagon's idol or image. Many different nations and people groups worshiped Dagon. The Philistines probably worshiped Dagon as a god of seed, plants, and crops, whereas other nations worshiped Dagon for different reasons. The Philistines worshiped many gods, but Dagon was their main god. In cultures where people worship many gods, people usually honor one of the gods more than the rest.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: If your ancestors worshiped more than one god, tell of the kind of sacrifices that your ancestors gave to these gods. If your ancestors did not worship more than one god, talk about a neighboring community that did. Which of these gods do you think received the greatest honor or worship, and why? Pause this audio here.

The Philistines placed the ark of God beside the statue of Dagon. A statue is an image or figure of solid material like wood, metal, or stone. People make an image of a god and worship that image as if it were that god. Such an image could look like a person, or like an animal, or just have any different shape. Dagon's image probably had a human body, with a head and hands, but the tail of a fish.

Stop here and look at an illustration of the image of Dagon. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Describe the images of the gods that your community or communities around you worship, and where people worship and keep these images. Pause audio here.

It was normal at this time for two nations that were fighting one another to believe that the gods that they each worshiped were also fighting each other. The Philistines took the ark of God and set it beside their god Dagon to show that Dagon had defeated the God of the Israelites. It is also possible that the Philistines put the ark of God next to Dagon as an offering to Dagon because they believed that Dagon had helped them to defeat the Israelites. The Philistines likely believed that Dagon would now control the God of Israel just as the Philistines controlled the people of Israel.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when your community honored God for giving victory in war. What does your community think of the gods of your enemies who have defeated you in battle? And what does your community think of the gods of the enemies that you have defeated? Pause this audio here.

The people of Ashdod woke up early the next morning, went into the temple of Dagon, and found that the idol of Dagon had fallen on its face before the ark of Yahweh. This means that Dagon was in a posture of worship before the ark of Yahweh. So some of the Philistines lifted Dagon up and put him back in his place. Yet when the Philistines came back in again early the next morning, the Philistines found that Dagon had again fallen on his face before the ark of Yahweh and also that his head and his hands had broken off and were lying at the threshold or entrance of the temple. Only the main part of the body or the trunk of Dagon remained unbroken. During war, the winners would sometimes cut off the heads and hands of their enemies to show their victory. Perhaps Yahweh is showing that Yahweh has victory over the Philistine god Dagon.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What gestures do you use to show honor and respect to older or greater people in your culture? Tell stories of times when gods have fought each other. Pause this audio here.

Because of what happened, the Philistines started a new custom. This custom was that none of the Philistine priests or any Philistine who went into the temple of Dagon walked on the threshold. People respected the threshold because it separated the world from the sacred place inside the temple. But now the people showed the threshold even more respect. Because Dagon's head and hands had fallen there, people no longer wanted to step on the threshold.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are some places that people restrict in your culture, and why do they restrict them? Pause this audio here.

The hand of Yahweh was heavy upon the people of the city of Ashdod and its villages. In other words, Yahweh used his power to harm the people of Ashdod by giving them tumors. Tumors are swellings or growths on the skin. This is likely a disease that rats spread widely and quickly among people. This disease causes ugly and painful swellings on the skin and kills many people.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell about a time when a fast-spreading, deadly disease affected your community. Where did your people say it came from, and why did it come? Pause this audio here.

When the people of Ashdod realized what was happening, the people said that the ark of the God had to leave their city because the God of the Israelites was punishing the people and their god Dagon. Although the Philistines did not worship Yahweh or believe that Yahweh was the only true God, the Philistines knew that Yahweh had genuine power because they said Yahweh was punishing them and their god. So the Philistines called together their five rulers and asked the rulers what they should do with the ark of the God of the Israelites. The rulers told the people to bring the ark to another of the five main cities, Gath. Gath was 19 kilometers to the east of Ashdod.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Who governs the people of your tribe, culture, and language in the places they live around the country? What happens when there is an issue that affects all of the people? Pause audio here.

After some of the Philistines had brought the ark to Gath, the hand, or power, of Yahweh was against that city and caused a great panic or chaos and confusion there. Yahweh used his power to punish the people of Gath as he had in Ashdod. Yahweh attacked all the people of Gath, both young people and old people, with an outbreak of tumors.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: When your community was affected by the fast-spreading and deadly disease, how did the people feel and behave? Pause audio here.

So the people of Gath sent the ark of Yahweh to Ekron, another of the five Philistine cities. Ekron was about 19 kilometers to the northeast of Ashdod. Of all the cities of the Philistines, Ekron was the closest to the land of the Israelites. But as the people of Gath were carrying the ark of God into the city of Ekron, the people of Ekron protested. The people of Ekron said that the people of Gath were bringing the ark of the God of the Israelites into their city to kill them. The people of Ekron thought that the ark itself would kill them. The people of Ekron called together the leaders of the cities of the Philistines and told the leaders to tell some men to take the ark of the God of Israel back to its own place. The people said that if they did not return the ark to its own country, the ark would kill them and their people. The people said this because there was a deadly panic throughout the city, because Yahweh was attacking them severely. The people were very afraid of dying because Yahweh had killed many people there. It is likely that Yahweh attacked the city of Ekron more severely than Ashdod and Gath because the Philistines were responding to Yahweh's previous attacks by trying to keep the ark rather than returning to the Israelites. The cry of the city went up to heaven. This means that the people of Ekron prayed desperately for help. It is likely that the people prayed to their own gods.

Stop here and tell a story about a time when you think God punished your community. What did the punishment look like, and what did you do about the punishment?

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 5:1–12 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has six scenes.

In the first scene: The Philistines took the ark that they had captured from the Israelites and brought it with them from Ebenezer to one of their five cities, Ashdod. The Philistines carried the ark into the temple of Dagon and set it up beside the idol of Dagon.

In the second scene: When the people of Ashdod rose up early the next morning, the people found the idol of Dagon had fallen on its face before the ark of Yahweh. So they took Dagon and put him back in his place.

In the third scene: The following morning, the people of Ashdod rose up early and found Dagon fallen on his face before the ark of Yahweh. Dagon's head and hands had been cut off and were lying on the threshold of Dagon's temple.

In the fourth scene: Yahweh attacked the people of Ashdod and its villages by punishing the people with tumors. When the people of Ashdod realized what was happening, the people said that the ark of the God of the Israelites could not remain in Ashdod because the hand of the God of the Israelites was powerful against them and their god Dagon. So the people sent and gathered the rulers of the cities of the Philistines and asked the rulers what they should do.

In the fifth scene: The rulers of the cities of the Philistines decided to send the ark of the God of Israel to Gath, another Philistine city. When the people brought the ark to Gath, the hand of Yahweh was powerful against the people of Gath, and the people of Gath panicked. Yahweh attacked the people of Gath, both young and old, with tumors.

In the sixth scene: The people of Gath sent the ark to Ekron, but the people of Ekron protested against the other people bringing the ark into their city. The people of Ekron were afraid that the ark would kill them. So the people of Ekron called together the rulers of the cities of the Philistines and told them to send the ark away, back to Israel. A great panic had filled the hearts of the people of Ekron because the people were attacked with tumors, and many people had died there. The people wept and prayed for help.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Yahweh

  • Dagon

  • The Philistine warriors

  • The people of Ashdod

  • The people of Gath

  • The people of Ekron

  • The rulers of the cities of the Philistines

  • And the priests of Dagon

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

This story takes place after the battle that the Philistines and the Israelites fought against each other at Ebenezer. The setting of the story is in the land of the Philistines. In the first scene, after the Philistines captured the ark, the Philistines carried the ark of God with them from Ebenezer to Ashdod. The Philistines referred to the ark as the "ark of God" rather than the ark of Yahweh. The Philistines probably said this because they did not know the name Yahweh, the personal name for the Israelites' God. Therefore, the Philistines used a more general name for God. The more general name for God refers to the creator or a powerful spiritual being.

The Philistines carried the ark of God into the temple of Dagon, the Philistines' main god, and set the ark beside the statue of Dagon. Throughout this story, the storyteller talks about the statue of Dagon as if it were a real, living being, even though it is just a statue.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you speak of a non-living object as if it is alive? Pause audio here.

The second scene begins the next morning. The people of Ashdod rose up early in the morning and went into the temple of Dagon. When the people looked inside, there was Dagon fallen on his face before the ark of Yahweh. The phrase "there was Dagon" calls attention to the scene and shows that the Philistines were surprised and alarmed to find Dagon on his face before the ark of Yahweh. Remember that there was no one in the temple overnight and that the Philistines found Dagon in a posture of adoration before Yahweh. Therefore, the Philistines were very surprised by this sight.

Stop here and do this activity as a group: Imagine that you are busy with your daily tasks. One member of the group sees something amazing or terrifying. That person wants to alert the rest of the group. Make that person stand at a small distance and shout out to the rest of the group, calling their attention to the surprising thing. Pay attention to the words or phrases the person uses to call the people's attention to the surprising thing. Pause this audio here.

The storyteller uses the personal name Yahweh to tell us that Dagon has fallen on his face before Yahweh. The storyteller is probably reminding us that the war between the Philistines and the Israelites is really about war between Yahweh, the God of the Israelites, and Dagon, the god of the Philistines.

Stop here and tell a story about a time when your tribe came into contact with another group of people. Tell how your worship customs and God have come into conflict with those people's worship customs and God. Pause this audio here.

Some of the Philistines took Dagon and put him back in his place. This means that the people picked up the statue of Dagon, stood it upright, and placed it back on its platform or stand.

The third scene contrasts what the people of Ashdod did the previous night with what they found the following morning. The previous day, the people had picked up Dagon's statue and placed it back on its platform. But when the people went into Dagon's temple early the following morning, the people found that Dagon had again fallen on his face on the ground before Yahweh. Just like when it first happened, this surprised the Philistines because no human being was in the temple during the night. The Philistines were even more alarmed because they also found that someone had cut off Dagon's head and hands, and the head and hands were lying on the threshold or entrance of the temple. Only the main part of Dagon's body remained unbroken. It was probably Yahweh himself who cut off these parts of Dagon's body. This is why the priests of the Philistines or any other person who enters the temple of Dagon in Ashdod does not step on the threshold. The storyteller then gives us the added information that the Philistines continue to avoid stepping on the threshold even to the time the storyteller writes this book of 1 Samuel.

Stop here and give an example of a taboo or restriction in your culture. How and where did people start that taboo or restriction? Pause this audio here.

In the fourth scene, Yahweh's hand was heavy upon the people of Ashdod and its villages. The "hand of Yahweh" is special language that shows that Yahweh used his hand, or his power, to punish the people who lived in Ashdod and the villages that surrounded it. Yahweh punished the people with unpleasant and painful swellings on the skin.

When the people of Ashdod saw what was happening, the people said that the ark of the God of Israel could not stay with them and must leave their city because his hand was heavy upon them and their god Dagon. This means that the people of Ashdod came to realize that the God of Israel was punishing them for taking the ark. The storyteller does not say how the people came to this realization. When the Philistines spoke of the ark, they called it the ark of the God whom the Israelites worshiped. The Philistines did not believe that the God of the Israelites was the only true God. But the Philistines did recognise that the Israelites' God had power because he was punishing them and their god Dagon. The Philistines did not believe that Dagon was the only god. The Philistines believed that there were different gods in different countries and that each god was powerful in his own country. This is why the Philistines call Yahweh "the God of Israel." The Philistines believe that Yahweh is a god, but not a god of the land of the Philistines.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you refer to the creator of the world when you speak with other communities who do not worship the same God as you do? Pause audio here.

So the people of Ashdod called together all the rulers of the Philistines and asked them to advise the people on what they should do with the ark of the God of Israel. The rulers of the Philistines were probably the kings or governors of the Philistines' five cities.

Stop here and tell a story about a time when your community called together all the rulers or leaders of your people. Pause audio here.

In the fifth scene, the rulers of the Philistines said that they should move the ark from Ashdod to Gath. Gath is another one of the five Philistine cities. The rulers did not say who would move the ark. So some of the men moved the ark of the God of Israel to Gath. But after the men brought the ark to Gath, the hand of Yahweh was hard against that city. This means Yahweh began to punish the people of Gath. This caused great panic, or great confusion and chaos. Yahweh attacked the people of that city—both the old people and the young people—with tumors. This is special language to say that Yahweh punished all the people who lived in Gath by causing tumors to break out or grow suddenly on their bodies.

Stop here and do this activity as a group: Choose one person to play the role of Yahweh and divide the rest into two groups. Make these groups sit apart. One group will represent the people of Ashdod, and the other will represent the people of Gath. Choose an object to represent the ark and give it to the people of Ashdod. When the people of Ashdod have the ark, have the person who plays Yahweh wave his hands over the people of Ashdod as if he is punishing the people. The people should react by crying as if they suffer physically. The people of Ashdod should give the ark to the people of Gath and move away from those people. When this happens, the people of Ashdod should stop suffering and begin to return to their normal lives because the person playing Yahweh has turned from them. Then the person who plays Yahweh should begin to afflict the people of Gath. But the people of Gath should suffer even more than the people of Ashdod. Pause the audio here.

In the sixth scene, the people of Gath sent the ark to Ekron. Ekron is another Philistine city. The storyteller does not tell us how the people of Gath decided to send the ark to Ekron, but we know the people sent the ark there to stop their own suffering. But as the people of Gath were bringing the ark into the city of Ekron, the people of Ekron cried out in protest. This means that the people of Ekron did not want the people of Gath to bring the ark. The people of Ekron said that the people of Gath had brought the ark into Ekron so that the ark or the God of Israel would kill the people of Ekron. The people of Ekron were angry with the people of Gath. The people of Ekron accused the people of Gath of bringing death to their city. The people of Ekron said this because they believed that the ark or the God of Israel would kill them.

Stop here as a group and talk about a time when someone in your community did something that other people thought was wrong or evil. Perhaps people thought this action would make God angry with the whole community. Pay attention to how you talk about the way the community reacted to the person who brought the evil thing into the community. Pause this audio here.

So the people of Ekron called together all the rulers of the Philistines. The people told the rulers to tell some men to return the ark to its own place. This means that the people wanted the ark to be returned to where it belonged, in the land of Israel. The people of Ekron said that the ark must be returned to its own place because the people believed that if the ark remained in their land, it would kill all of the people. A deadly panic had filled the city, and the hand of the God of Israel was heavy upon them. This means the people were afraid they would die because Yahweh was punishing the people severely with the outbreak of tumors. Many people died, and Yahweh punished those who survived with tumors so that the outcry of the city went up to heaven. This means that the Philistines cried out for help from heaven, where they believed their gods lived.

Stop here and discuss what your community did during the time they thought their God was punishing them. How did people ask God to stop punishing them? Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 5:1–12 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has six scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Yahweh

  • Dagon

  • The Philistine warriors

  • The people of Ashdod

  • The people of Gath

  • The people of Ekron

  • The rulers of the cities of the Philistines

  • And the priests of Dagon

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

In the first scene, the Philistine warriors capture the ark and carry it with them from Ebenezer, where the men fought the battle, to Ashdod, one of their five main cities.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Philistine warriors, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are victorious! or

  • We are so happy to celebrate our god Dagon's victory! or

  • The Israelites' God shall serve our god and be his slave just as the Israelites are our slaves.

The people of Ashdod carried the ark into the temple of Dagon and set it up beside Dagon.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Ashdod, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • This is a great day of giving honor and glory to our god Dagon. Dagon has given us victory over the Israelites; or

  • We are very pleased with the results of the war. Our warriors fought bravely and have come out victorious.

In the second scene, the people of Ashdod rose up early the next morning and went into the temple of Dagon. When the people went in and looked inside, the people found that Dagon had fallen face-down on the ground before the ark of Yahweh.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Ashdod, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We feel horrified and alarmed. How could such a terrible thing have happened? Who did this? What does this mean? or

  • We must catch and punish whoever did this; or

  • Let's pick Dagon up and put him back in his place. We must be careful that this does not happen again. What a shameful thing it would be if our enemies heard that this happened.

So the people took Dagon and put him back on his platform.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am Yahweh. There is no God beside me. I do not serve and bow to anyone; or

  • Dagon is not a god. The Philistines make an image of their own imagination and fall down to it to worship it. This is foolish; or

  • Let the Philistines look and see that Yahweh alone is powerful.

In the third scene, when the people of Ashdod woke up early the following morning and came into the temple of Dagon, the people found Dagon fallen on his face before the ark of Yahweh. Dagon's head and hands had been cut off and were lying on the threshold of Dagon's temple.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Ashdod, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • What a horror! This is worse than yesterday. We are very afraid; or

  • What are these signs that the God of Israel is performing? Will Israel's God destroy our god? or

  • How is it possible that the God of Israel can do such things here in our land? What will happen if Israel's God remains here? Will Israel's God not completely destroy Dagon?

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Will the Philistines not learn? Dagon is not a god. Dagon has hands but cannot save himself. Dagon's ears do not hear, and Dagon's mouth cannot speak. Dagon must be carried everywhere by those who worship him; or

  • The Philistines think I only have power in the land of Israel, but I am Yahweh. The whole world is mine.

Dagon's head and hands had been cut off and were lying on the threshold of Dagon's temple. Only the trunk of Dagon was left to him. This is the reason that the priest of Dagon and all who enter the temple of Dagon do not step on the threshold of Dagon in Ashdod to this day.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the priest of Dagon, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • The threshold is holy ground. The threshold was made holy by the head and hands of Dagon. Therefore, we do not walk on the threshold; or

  • To walk on the threshold would be the same as stepping on Dagon himself.

In the fourth scene, Yahweh attacked the people of Ashdod and its villages by afflicting them with tumors.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am not happy with these people. These people have taken my ark. The people are proud and believe that they are stronger than I am; or

  • I have tried to show these people who I am by afflicting their false god, but they will not listen; or

  • I will afflict these people until they hear me and turn.

Ask the person playing the people of Ashdod, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel afraid. There is an outbreak in the city. Painful swellings of the skin have spread throughout the community. Oh, how painful and ugly! or

  • We are in great suffering. There is no one to comfort us. All of us are afflicted by these tumors; or

  • This must be the God of the Israelites. First, he afflicted Dagon, and now he afflicts us.

When the people of Ashdod realized what was happening, the people said that the ark of the God of the Israelites could not remain in Ashdod. The people said this because the hand of the God of the Israelites was hard against the people and their god Dagon. So the people sent and gathered the rulers of the cities of the Philistines and asked the rules what they should do.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Ashdod, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Our life was good before people brought the ark here. Since this ark has come into Ashdod, we have seen many strange things. First, Dagon was attacked and broken, and now we are tormented by these tumors; or

  • This ark cannot stay here! or

  • It is the ark that has caused problems both to us and to Dagon, our god.

In the fifth scene, the rulers of the cities of the Philistines decided to send the ark of the God of Israel to Gath, another Philistine city.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the rulers of the Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • The people of Ashdod are very angry and scared. The people will not allow the ark to stay here any longer. We must do something; or

  • Let's move the ark to another place. Perhaps it would be better if the ark went to Gath. Maybe the God of Israel will have no power there.

When the people brought the ark to Gath, the hand of Yahweh was hard against the people of Gath and caused a great panic. Yahweh attacked the people of Gath, both young and old, with tumors.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • These people refuse to learn that I am powerful in all the earth. I am not a god of stone. I am the living God. No one can control me. Any person who tries to control me will suffer my punishment.

Ask the person playing the people of Gath, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Oh no, what is happening? We are so terrified. A great disaster has come upon us. No one is safe from this disease; or

  • These tumors have come upon us from the day that the ark entered our city. Just like it happened in Ashdod, it has happened to us; or

  • The whole city is in chaos. We are so afraid. Our children are dying from the tumors. We have no one to help us. This ark must leave Gath. It is the only way to end this plague.

In the sixth scene the people of Gath sent the ark to Ekron. As the people of Gath were carrying the Ark into Ekron, the people of Ekron protested against the ark coming into their city. The people of Ekron said that the people of Gath were bringing the ark of the God of Israel so that the ark could kill the people of Ekron.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Ekron, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We heard how Israel's God attacked the people in Ashdod and Gath when they brought the ark into their cities. Now the people of Gath bring the ark to us. No! We shall not have the ark. The people of Gath know that what happened to them will happen to us, and they do not care; or

  • We do not want to die. We want to have nothing to do with this ark. Why would the people of Gath bring the ark here? Surely the people of Gath hate us and mean to bring death to our city; or

  • We must do something immediately.

So the people of Ekron called together the rulers of the cities of the Philistines and told the rulers to send the ark away back to Israel. The people of Ekron were afraid that the ark would kill them. A great panic had filled the heart of the people of Ekron because many people had died there. Those who did not die were attacked with tumors. The people of Ekron wept and prayed for help.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Ekron, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are so afraid. Death is everywhere. Every home mourns; or

  • So many people have died, and the rest have tumors. There are no strong people left. The whole city prays for the end of this plague. Everyone prays to his own god; or

  • I wish people had never brought the ark here. Oh God, help us!

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 5:1–12 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

When the Philistines captured the ark of God, they brought it from Ebenezer to Ashdod. Use the same words or phrases for Philistine, the general word for God, and "ark of God" as you used in previous passages. See the Master Glossary for God and ark of the covenant, if needed.

The Philistines brought the ark into the temple of Dagon and set it up beside Dagon. Temple refers to a place where people worship their god. The Philistines kept a statue of their god Dagon in his temple. You can translate this as the house of Dagon because it is where Dagon lived.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for temple. Look up temple in the Master Glossary for more information. Pause this audio here.

Dagon refers to an image or idol that the Philistines had made to represent Dagon. People would have made this idol out of solid material such as wood, metal, or stone. Dagon is a proper name, so it is best to keep the same name or pronounce it in your language.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for Dagon. Because Dagon is an idol, look up idol in the Master Glossary for more information if you will include the term idol in your translation. Pause this audio here.

The Philistines found Dagon fallen with his face to the ground before Yahweh. The Philistines put Dagon back in his place, but the next morning they found that he had again fallen with his face to the ground before the ark of Yahweh, and his head and hands had been cut off and were lying by the threshold. Yahweh is a name that God gave himself. This name means something like "I am," or "I am who I am." The name Yahweh was a very personal name for God that showed the close relationship that God had with the people of Israel. Look up Yahweh in the Master Glossary for more information, and translate Yahweh in the same way you have in previous passages.

Threshold refers to the bottom of a doorway or entrance to a building. People cross the threshold when they enter a house or room, in this case, the temple of Dagon.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for threshold. Stop here and look at a picture of a threshold as a group. Pause this audio here.

Because of this, the priests of Dagon or anyone entering the temple of Dagon do not walk on the threshold of the temple to this day. Look up priest in the Master Glossary if needed for more information, and translate priest in the same way you have in previous passages.

The hand of Yahweh was heavy against the people of Ashdod, and Yahweh terrified and afflicted the people with tumors. Tumors are swellings or growths on the skin. Rats likely spread these tumors.

Stop here and look at a picture of tumors as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for tumors. Pause this audio here.

The Philistines gathered together all the rulers of the Philistines. Rulers are governors or kings. The Philistines had five main cities, and each city had its own ruler. These rulers made decisions together. You can translate this word as kings, princes, or governors.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for rulers. Pause this audio here.

The Philistines sent up their cry to heaven. The word heaven refers to the place where God lives with his angels. The Philistines probably believed that their gods lived in heaven. Look up heaven in the Master Glossary for more information, and translate heaven in the same way you have in previous passages.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
