title: 1 Samuel 6:1–18
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 6:1–18 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 6:1–18 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 6:1–18 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous story, Yahweh attacked the Philistines and their gods in all the Philistine cities wherever they took the ark. After Yahweh killed many Philistines with painful tumors, the Philistines who lived in Ekron asked their rulers to return the ark of Israel's God back to the land of Israel.

In this story, the Philistines return Yahweh's ark back to the land of Israel. The Philistines had kept the ark in their land for seven months. The Philistines called together the priests and diviners, their religious experts. Diviners are people who communicate with spirits and gods. Diviners use rituals to predict the future, interpret dreams and events, or tell fortunes. It was common for pagan societies to use diviners to make decisions, but Yahweh had told the Israelites never to do it.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when someone predicted the future. Who was that person, and how was the person able to do it? What did the person predict, and did the thing they predicted actually happen? Pause this audio here.

The Philistines asked their priests and diviners what they should do with the ark of Yahweh and how they should send it back to its place in Israel. The Philistines were probably asking about the ritual they should follow when they sent the ark back. For the Philistines to decide to send the ark back to Israel means that the Philistines accepted that Yahweh had defeated the Philistines and their gods.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What does your community do to make peace with God when they think that God is angry with them? Pause audio here.

The Philistines' priests and diviners answered and said that the Philistines should not send the ark of Israel's God empty-handed or without a gift. The priests and diviners told the Philistines to send the ark back to the God of Israel with a payment or offering for their guilt. This is probably because they thought that the Philistines had made the God of Israel angry by taking his ark. The priests and diviners were not completely sure that Yahweh had caused the tumors and deaths. So the priests and diviners said that if the Philistines were healed of their tumors after they had returned the ark with a gift, then the Philistines would know that it was the God of Israel who had been punishing them for taking his ark.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when something unnatural happened in your community. Who did people say caused the thing to happen? Pause this audio here.

The Philistines asked the priests and diviners what kind of payment they should send to the God of Israel. The priests and diviners told the people that they should send five gold models of the tumors and five gold models of rats. The priests and diviners said this because they were five rulers of five Philistine cities, and they had all been punished with the same punishment of tumors. The Philistines also had to send five models of the rats that were destroying all their crops on their farms or in their fields. The Philistines hoped that if they gave glory and honor to the God of Israel, God would lift his heavy hand from them or end the punishment. In that culture, people honored the power of a god that healed by making a model of an illness or the part of the body that was sick. Then people offered that model to the god.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of what the gold tumors and rats might have looked like. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Talk about the different kinds of gifts that people offer to gods in your community when they are in danger or great trouble. How do people know what to offer and the number of offerings to give? Pause this audio here.

The priests and diviners encouraged the Philistines not to harden their hearts or be stubborn like the Egyptians and the Egyptian king, the Pharaoh. The priests and diviners reminded the people of what happened to the Egyptians when Yahweh sent Moses to tell Pharaoh to let the Israelites leave Egypt. When Pharaoh refused to listen, the God of the Israelites humiliated the Egyptians and Pharaoh and punished them harshly until they let the people of Israel leave Egypt. Therefore, the priests and diviners advised the Philistines to prepare a new cart or vehicle and two milk cows, or cows that had recently given birth. The Philistines were to choose cows that had never pulled a cart before. Then the Philistines should take away the cows' baby calves from them and put the calves in the house or pen. After that, the Philistines should yoke or tie the cows to the new cart. People used cows to plow or pull carts by attaching them to a cart with a yoke or wooden bar on their neck. The Philistines probably chose cows that had never pulled a cart because they considered those cows to be suitable to offer to Yahweh, because they were clean and pure. Milk cows would not naturally abandon their calves. By taking away the calves, the people probably thought that the cows would choose to go to their calves when people released them. It is likely that diviners thought that the only reason why these milk cows would abandon their calves would be if Yahweh made them go where Yahweh wanted.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a team of cows that people yoked to a cart. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group. Talk about how your community uses animals for different purposes, like to do work, to eat, to give as gifts, such as a dowry, or to make sacrifices. How do you choose an animal for a sacrifice? Pause this audio here.

The priests and diviners told the Philistines to place the ark of Yahweh on the cart and to place another box or chest that contained the gold tumors and gold rats for the guilt offering beside the ark. The Philistines were to let the milk cows pull the cart whichever direction the cows wanted to go. The Philistines were not to interfere, but they were to keep watching the cart. The priests and diviners said that if the cows carried the ark towards the ark's territory, Beth Shemesh, it would show that Yahweh had been the one who brought the great disaster on the Philistines. But if the cows did not go toward Beth Shemesh, the Philistines would know that an accident or chance had caused the great disaster, not Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when the priests or diviners of your community had to choose between two or more options to determine the cause of a problem in your community. How did the priests and diviners test to see which of the options was the cause of the problem? Pause this audio here.

The Philistines did everything that the priests and diviners had told them. The Philistines tied the two cows to the new cart and shut the cows' calves in the barn. The Philistines placed the ark of Yahweh on the cart along with the other chest that contained the gold tumors and gold rats. When the Philistines let the cows go, the cows went straight towards Beth Shemesh, and kept to the road, not turning left or right, even though the cows were lowing or calling for their calves all the way. The cows were probably lowing because they wanted to go back to their calves, but they did not turn back because Yahweh was leading the cows. The five rulers of the Philistines followed the cows and watched the cows all the way to the border of Beth Shemesh.

The Israelites of Beth Shemesh were busy harvesting their wheat in the valley, or the lowland between two hills.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of people harvesting wheat with a sickle. Pause this audio here.

When the people looked up from their work and saw the ark, the people were very happy to see that the ark had returned to Israel. The cows pulled the cart to the field of a man from Beth Shemesh named Joshua and stopped by a large rock that was there. All this happened without any humans interfering. Some Levites, or men from the tribe of Levi, who were there took the ark of Yahweh and the chest with the gold models off the cart and placed them on the rock.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of Levites carrying the ark. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are some religious activities in your community that only a few select people or groups are allowed to do, and why? Pause this audio here.

A few other Israelites chopped up the cart and made a fire. These people killed the cows and burned them as burnt sacrifices to Yahweh. Burnt sacrifice is a specific type of offering where the priests burned the entire animal on the altar. Usually, the priests used only male cows for burnt sacrifice. The priests probably used the large rock as an altar to sacrifice on. After that, the priests offered other animals as extra burnt sacrifices and made other types of sacrifices to Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are the various sacrifices that you offer in your community? What are the reasons that you make these sacrifices, and what animals do you offer? Pause this audio here.

When the five rulers of the Philistines who had followed the cart to the border of Beth Shemesh saw what had happened, they returned to Ekron the same day. The Philistines had offered five gold tumors to Yahweh for their guilt or wrongdoing. Each gold tumor represented one of their five cities: Ashdod, Gaza, Ashkelon, Gath, and Ekron. The Philistines also offered Yahweh gold rats equal to the number of cities that belonged to the five Philistine rulers. The Philistines offered gold rats for all of their walled cities and open villages.

The great stone in Joshua's field, the man from Beth Shemesh, on which the people placed the ark of Yahweh, is a witness or reminder to this day. The storyteller probably wants to remind us that the great stone was still on Joshua's field when he wrote this story. This stone reminded the people who saw it that Yahweh defeated the Philistines and their gods.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 6:1–18 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has four scenes.

In the first scene: The Philistines called together their priests and diviners and asked them what they should do with the ark of Yahweh. The priests and diviners told the people to send the ark back with a guilt offering on a new cart pulled by two milk cows that had never pulled a cart before. The priests and diviners told the people to leave the cows to pull the cart in whichever direction the cows wanted to go, without interfering, but to follow the cows and watch where they went. The priests and diviners said that if the cows pulled the cart toward Beth Shemesh in Israel, the people would know that it was Yahweh who had been punishing them with tumors.

In the second scene: The Philistines prepared the guilt offerings, the cart, and the cows just as the priests and diviners had advised them. The cows went straight on the road without turning to the right or to the left, even though the cows lowed, or called, for their calves as they went. The five Philistine rulers followed the cows to the border of Beth Shemesh.

In the third scene: The people of Israel who lived in Beth Shemesh were busy harvesting their wheat in the valley. When the people looked up from their work and saw the ark, they rejoiced to see it return to the land of Israel. The cows carried the ark to the field of a man named Joshua and stopped next to a large rock that was there.

In the fourth scene: Some Levites who were there took the ark of Yahweh and the chest that contained the guilt offerings and placed them on the large rock. The people made a fire with the wood of the cart and killed the cows and burned them as a burnt offering to Yahweh. After that, the people offered other sacrifices and rejoiced together. The five Philistine rulers saw what happened and returned home that same day.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Yahweh

  • The Philistines

  • The five rulers of the Philistines

  • The Philistine priests and diviners

  • The Israelites of Beth Shemesh

  • Joshua (the Israelite from Beth Shemesh)

  • And the Levites of Beth Shemesh

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In the first scene, the storyteller tells us that the ark of Yahweh has been in the land of the Philistines for seven months since they captured it in battle. The storyteller probably does this to show us that Yahweh caused the Philistines to suffer enough to make them want to return the ark. At this point in the story, the ark is in Ekron. The Philistines called together their priests and diviners. The Philistines asked the priest and diviners what they should do with the ark of Yahweh and how they should send it back to its place or land. The Philistines already knew that they should send the ark back to Israel, but they wanted the priests and diviners to tell them the way to transport it and the rituals that they should do when they sent it back.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Talk about the person in your community who uses rituals or ceremonies to communicate with spirits. Pay attention to the name you call that person. Pause audio here.

The priests and diviners answered the people and said that if they sent the ark of Yahweh back, they should not send it empty-handed or without an offering for their guilt or wrongdoing. The people believed that it was likely that the God of Israel was angry with them because they had taken the ark, and they needed to pay for their guilt. The priests and diviners told the Philistines that they should send a payment for their guilt to the God of Israel. Then, if the people were healed, they would know that the God of Israel had not lifted his hand from them and had kept punishing them because they had kept his ark. Then the Philistines asked the priests and diviners what kind of guilt offering they should send to the God of Israel. The priests and diviners answered and said that the people should send five gold tumors and five gold rats, the same as the number of their cities and rulers, and because the same punishment or sickness had struck the Philistines and their five rulers. The priests and diviners told the Philistines that they must make the God of Israel gold images or representations of their tumors and gold copies of the rats that were destroying their land. The images would be a payment or gift to honor or acknowledge the God of Israel. They hoped that Israel's God would lighten his hand or stop punishing the people and all their land and gods. It was common in the non-Israelite communities to honor or acknowledge the power of a god who punished or healed you with a gift. It does not mean that the Philistines wanted to worship Yahweh, but that they accepted that Yahweh had used his power to punish them. It is important not to confuse this guilt offering with the guilt offering that the Israelites gave to Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Talk about people in your community who have done something wrong and have had to make a payment to God for the thing they did wrong. Pay attention to the words and phrases that you use when referring to the payment. Pause this audio here.

The priest and diviners asked the Philistines two questions to encourage them to follow their advice. The priests and diviners told the Philistines not to harden their hearts or to be stubborn like the Egyptians and Pharaoh, the Egyptian king, had been when Yahweh said to let the Israelites leave Egypt. When someone hardens their heart, they refuse to listen and they act stubbornly. The Philistine priests reminded the Philistines how the God of Israel had been very harsh with the Egyptians until the Egyptians let the people of Israel go.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Talk about someone who has been very disobedient and has refused to listen even after many warnings. Describe how someone punishes that person very harshly. Use strong words, but do not sound cruel or unjust. Pay attention to the words and phrases that you use to describe the punishment. Pause this audio here.

For this reason, the priests and diviners told the Philistines to get and prepare a new cart that had not been used before, and to choose two milk cows that had recently given birth to calves but that had never been tied to a yoke before. It is likely that the priests were the ones who gave this direction because the priests would be concerned with the purity of the cows and cart that they would send to Yahweh. The priests told the Philistines to take the calves away from the two milk cows and put them in their barn or house, and then tie the two milk cows to the new cart. Then the Philistines should place the ark of Yahweh on the cart and another box next to the ark. The priests told the Philistines to put the gold tumors and rats that they would be sending as their guilt offering in the box that was next to the ark. Then the priests told the people to allow the cows to pull the cart in whichever direction the cows wanted to go, but to keep watching which way the cows went. If the cows went toward Beth Shemesh in the territory of Israel, the ark's home, then it would mean that Yahweh had brought the suffering of tumors on the Philistines. But if the cows did not go toward Beth Shemesh, it would mean that an accident had caused the suffering, and it was not the hand of Yahweh. The priests probably gave this direction because it is a way of deciding whether Yahweh had been the one punishing the people or not.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Describe the various skin diseases that affect people in your community, especially any that cause swelling or that rats spread. Pay attention to the names you give to these diseases. Tell stories of when rats have destroyed crops in the field. Pay attention to what you call these kinds of rats. Pause this audio here.

In the second scene, the Philistines did all that their priests and diviners had told them. The Philistines chose two cows like the ones that the priests and diviners had advised. They tied the cows to a new cart and put their calves in the barn.

Stop here and do this activity as a group: Choose one member of the group to play the role of the priests and diviners. This person should give the instructions that the priests and diviners gave the Philistines to the rest of the group. The group should pay attention to the words and phrases the members of the group use. Focus especially on the words and phrases for the two milk cows and their calves, the action of tying or yoking the cows to the cart, and the golden items that the people put in the box. The group should suggest better words and phrases to the person playing the role of the Philistine priests and diviners. Pause this audio here.

The Philistines placed the ark of Yahweh on the cart together with the chest that contained the gold tumors and gold rats. It is likely that the Philistines had learned not to touch the ark because Yahweh would kill anyone who touched it. Therefore, it is important not to confuse the ark and the box containing the guilt offerings. The cows went by themselves straight toward Beth Shemesh. Even though the cows were mooing, lowing, or calling for their calves all the way as they went, the cows stayed on the road that goes to Beth Shemesh and did not turn off the road to the right or to the left. This is special language that shows that the cows went straight ahead without turning back to look for their calves.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a typical road of the time. Tell a story about a time when someone went from one place to another without stopping or changing their mind. Pay attention to the words and phrases you use to describe how the person traveled. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when you took a calf from its mother. How did the cow react? Talk about the different sounds that a cow makes. Pay attention to the word or phrase you use for a cow calling for its calf. Pause this audio here.

The five Philistine rulers followed the cows to the edge of the fields of the villages that surrounded Beth Shemesh.

In the third scene, the people of Beth Shemesh were busy in their fields harvesting wheat. The people grew their wheat in the fertile valley or the low-lying land between two hills.

When the people looked up from their work and saw the ark, they rejoiced and were happy to see it return to Israel. The people probably felt that Yahweh himself had returned to Israel after spending seven months in the land of the Philistines. The cows pulled the cart into the field of a man named Joshua who was from Beth Shemesh. They stopped the cart next to a large rock in Joshua's field.

In the fourth scene, some Levites took down the ark and the box with the guilt offerings from the cart and placed them on the large rock. The Levites were there because Beth Shemesh was one of the cities of Israel where Levites lived. Although no one was allowed to touch the ark, Yahweh had given the people from the tribe of Levi the work of transporting it. After the Levites had taken down the ark and the chest with the guilt offerings from the cart, the people of Beth Shemesh chopped up the wood of the cart and made a fire with it. The priests killed the cows and burnt them completely as a burnt sacrifice to Yahweh. A burnt offering involves the burning of the whole animal except its hide or skin. The priests probably did this to rededicate or renew their relationship with Yahweh. The priests did this because they probably believed that Yahweh had left them when the Philistines captured the ark, but now Yahweh had returned. That same day, the people of Beth Shemesh also offered other burnt sacrifices in addition to the two cows and made other sacrifices to Yahweh. The people probably offered other kinds of animals, like sheep or goats, as extra burnt sacrifices. The burnt offerings were probably for dedicating themselves back to serving Yahweh, whilst the other sacrifices were to show their joy and restored relationship with Yahweh. The other offerings were also different from the burnt sacrifices because the people did not burn them entirely. The people probably ate some of the meat of the other sacrifices and rejoiced together.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Earlier, you talked about the different kinds of gifts that people offer to gods in your community and their reasons. How do people make sure that they do not offer the wrong sacrifice for a particular need or reason? Pause this audio here.

The five Philistine rulers witnessed all that the people of Beth Shemesh had done, and then they returned home to Ekron that same day.

Now the storyteller gives us a summary of what the Philistines sent to Yahweh. These are the gifts that the Philistines sent to Yahweh. The Philistines sent five gold tumors for their guilt. The Philistines sent one gold tumor for each of their five cities: Ashdod, Gaza, Ashkelon, Gath, and Ekron. The Philistines also offered Yahweh gold rats equal to the number of cities that belonged to the five Philistine rulers. The Philistines offered a gold rat for each of their towns, whether they were walled towns or open villages, because several villages usually surrounded walled towns. It is likely that the total number of towns was more than five, which would mean that they offered more than the five rats that their priests and diviners had advised. This could be because the rats had spread across all the land of the Philistines, whereas the tumors had only affected the people who lived in the cities where people had brought the ark.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Talk about the towns and villages that make up your community. Compare your town with another town to see which has more villages. How do you know which town a village is part of? Pause this audio here.

The large stone in the field of Joshua, the man from Beth Shemesh, on which they placed the ark of Yahweh, remained as a reminder and a witness of what had happened even in the days that this story was written.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are some physical things in your community that your people built so that they can remind everyone of some past events? Pay attention to how you describe these things. Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 6:1–18 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has four scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Yahweh

  • The Philistines

  • The five rulers of the Philistines

  • The Philistine priests and diviners

  • The Israelites of Beth Shemesh

  • Joshua, the Israelite from Beth Shemesh

  • And the Levites of Beth Shemesh

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

In the first scene, the ark of Yahweh has been in the land of the Philistines for seven months.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am angry with the Philistines; or

  • I will continue to punish the Philistines until they return my ark to Israel.

Ask the person playing the Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • No more! We have had enough of this punishment. We will be completely destroyed by these tumors if this does not stop; or

  • So many of our people have died, and more die every day. As long as the ark remains in Ekron, we will keep dying; or

  • The ark must leave! The ark cannot stay here any longer. We must return the ark to its own country; or

  • This is because of the ark of Israel's God. Wherever we take this ark, the people of that city get tumors, and these rats are all over the country. This ark must leave our territory. Seven months of suffering is long enough.

The Philistines called together their priests and diviners and asked them what they should do with the ark of Yahweh and how the Philistines should send the ark back to its place.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We need help. We have called our religious experts to teach us how we must treat the ark. We are very afraid of making mistakes and suffering more than we are already suffering; or

  • Our priests and diviners know how to communicate with the gods and the spirits. Maybe our priests and diviners will be able to tell us what we can do to make Israel's God stop being angry with us; or

  • We just want this suffering to stop. The God of Israel has defeated our gods. Our gods have not been able to save us or themselves from Israel's God.

Ask the person playing the priests and diviners, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Perhaps the people of Ekron and our rulers are right to want to send the ark back. We do not all agree. Some of us think an accident has caused all of this, but some believe Israel's God has done it; or

  • We do not know why this has happened, so we should test and see why this has happened to us.

The priests and diviners told the Philistines that they should send Israel's God a payment for their guilt. If Israel's God healed the Philistines, then the Philistines would know that the God of Israel had not kept punishing them because they kept his ark.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the priest and diviners, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • If the God of Israel has done this to us, then that means that he is angry with us because we have wronged him by taking his ark. Therefore, we must send gifts with the ark; or

  • We must admit our guilt. Maybe then Israel's God will stop punishing us. We must make a payment to Israel's God. We must show this God that we understand that he has done this to us.

The Philistines asked the priests and diviners what kind of guilt offering they should send to the God of Israel.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • What the priests and diviners have said is very wise. Maybe it will work, and then this terrible suffering will stop; or

  • I am worried! What shall we send the God of Israel? We do not know this God. How can we know what to send him? What if the thing we send Israel's God only makes him more angry? or

  • We are so worried and afraid. We want our lives to go back to normal.

The priests and diviners answered the people and said that the Philistines should send five gold tumors and five gold rats, the same number as their cities and rulers.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the priest and diviners, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Maybe when the God of Israel receives these gifts, he will stop being angry with us.

Ask the person playing the rulers of the Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are not sure whether this will work; or

  • It is a very expensive gift that the priests and diviners are suggesting. What if the God of Israel did not do this to us? We will have given the God of Israel a present for nothing. The Israelites will laugh at us and our gods, and they will think that their God defeated our gods; or

  • Why should we pay the God of Israel? If Israel's God was the one doing this to us, why were we able to capture the ark in the war? Our god Dagon defeated Israel's God.

The priests and diviners told the Philistines not to harden their hearts or be stubborn as the Egyptians and Pharaoh who refused to listen to the God of Israel when he told them to let his people go. The priests and diviners reminded the Philistines how the God of Israel had been very harsh with the Egyptians until they let the people of Israel go.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the priests and diviners, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We fear that the suffering will only increase as long as the ark stays in our territory. It is a hard thing to do, but we must do it. We cannot be proud and be stubborn against the God of the Israelites. Otherwise, Israel's God will punish us more severely; or

  • The God of Israel dealt with the Egyptians very severely when they refused to do what he wanted. We are afraid that Israel's God will do the same thing to us; or

  • We are worried that the people and our rulers are not taking us seriously enough. Maybe they think that they can still keep the ark in Philistine territory.

Ask the person playing the five rulers of the Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We do not want to admit that the God of the Israelites had defeated us and our gods, but we are very afraid. If the God of the Israelites has done this to us, then we had better listen to the priests and diviners and return the ark. Otherwise, the God of Israel might do to us a worse thing than he did to the Egyptians; or

  • The God of the Israelites destroyed Pharaoh and Egypt also. We heard the news of what the God of the Israelites did, and we do not want that to happen to us.

Therefore, the priests and diviners told the Philistines to prepare a new cart that no one had used before. The Philistines were also to choose two milk cows that had recently given birth to calves but that had never been tied to a yoke before. The priests and diviners told the people to take the calves away from the two milk cows, to put the calves in their barn, and then to tie the two milk cows to the new cart. Then, the people must place the ark of Yahweh on the cart and another chest that contained the gifts next to the ark.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the priest and diviners, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We must be very careful not to insult the God of the Israelites. We must use a new cart that has not been used for any other purpose before. If we send a cart we have previously used, it may be that this God will consider it unclean and be even more angry with us. The cows also must be cows that no one has ever used to do any of our work—cows that will please this God and be acceptable to him; or

  • We must make a different box to put the guilt offerings in and place it on the cart with the ark. We must be very careful how we deal with the ark. If we try to open it, it might kill us.

The priests and diviners told the Philistines to let the cows pull the cart in whichever direction the cows wanted to go, but to keep watching the cart and see where it went.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the priest and diviners, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We must test and see whether this was an accident or whether the God of Israel has brought this great disaster on us, because we are not sure. We do not want to give the ark back to the Israelites and admit defeat if it was an accident that caused all our suffering.

In the second scene, the Philistines did all that their priests and diviners had told them.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We have done everything exactly as the priests and diviners told us. We feel hopeful that their plan will work, but we will only know once we have let the cows go; or

  • We really want this to work. We want to be healed and for these tumors to go away. We are tired of suffering. We want these rats to go away from our farms; or

  • We are afraid and worried about what will happen if the cows do not go toward Beth Shemesh. How will we be healed?

The Philistines chose two cows like the ones the priests and diviners had asked them to choose and tied these cows to a new cart. Then the Philistines placed the ark on the cart together with the chest that contained the gold tumors and gold rats. Then the cows went by themselves straight toward Beth Shemesh. The cows stayed on the road that goes to Beth Shemesh and did not turn off the road to the right or to the left, even though they were lowing all the way as they went.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am glad that my ark is returning to Israel. I will direct the cows to the place I want them to take it; or

  • I have punished the Philistines for as long as they have kept the ark so that they may know that I am not like their gods of stone.

The five Philistine rulers followed the cows up the border or the fields of the villages that surround Beth Shemesh.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the five rulers of the Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel amazed! We have never seen anything like this. These cows are crying for their calves, and yet the cows do not turn back to go to the calves. The cows saw that we put their calves in the barn, and yet when we let them go, they went away from the calves in the direction of Beth Shemesh; or

  • How is this possible? This must be the hand of the God of Israel. Israel's God must be taking his ark home. This is a powerful God; or

  • The priests and diviners were right. Now we know that we have angered the God of Israel by taking his ark. If only Israel's God will accept our guilt offerings and heal us and our land.

In the third scene, the people of Beth Shemesh, who were busy in their fields harvesting the wheat, looked up from their work and saw the ark coming.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Beth Shemesh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • What a wonderful day! The cows are pulling the ark to us without any man directing them. What a strange and amazing thing; or

  • This must be the hand of Yahweh. Who else could do this? Why would the Philistines give us back the ark? or

  • We must stop our work and sacrifice to our God Yahweh for this great thing he has done. Yahweh has returned to his people.

The cows pulled the cart into the field of a man named Joshua, who was from Beth Shemesh. The cows stopped the cart next to a large rock that was in Joshua's field. Some Levites who were there took down the ark of Yahweh and the chest with the guilt offerings from the cart and placed them on a large rock in Joshua's field. Then the people of Beth Shemesh chopped up the wood of the cart and made a fire with the wood. The people killed the cows and burnt them completely on the wood as a burnt sacrifice to Yahweh. The people of Beth Shemesh also offered other burnt sacrifices in addition to the two cows and made other sacrifices to Yahweh.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Levites, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • This is a great day of rejoicing and praising Yahweh. Yahweh has returned the ark to his people. Yahweh's presence is back in Israel; or

  • We must be careful to follow the instructions that Moses gave regarding the ark. Only adult men from the tribe of Levi can handle the ark; or

  • Let's sacrifice to Yahweh and dedicate ourselves and the people of Israel to serving Yahweh.

Ask the person playing the people of Beth Shemesh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are full of joy. Our God lives with us again. Our God is close to us; or

  • We will sing and shout and send messages to our brothers and sisters all over the land of Israel about this great thing that has happened today.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am happy and pleased to see my people rejoicing in me; or

  • My people's sacrifices are pleasing and acceptable to me; or

  • I will live again with my people! I am very happy!

The five Philistine rulers witnessed all that the people of Beth Shemesh had done, and then the rulers returned home to Ekron that same day.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the five Philistine rulers, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • The people of Israel have celebrated joyfully whilst their God has defeated us. It is a sad day for us and all the Philistines, but we hope that the suffering will end and that we will be healed; or

  • This God of Israel is a terrific God. We do not want to fight him again.

These are the gifts that the Philistines sent to Yahweh. The Philistines sent five gold tumors for their guilt, one for each of their five cities: Ashdod, Gaza, Ashkelon, Gath, and Ekron. The Philistines also offered Yahweh gold rats equal to the number of cities that belonged to the five Philistine rulers. The people sent a gold rat for each town that belonged to the five rulers, whether they were walled towns or open villages.

The large stone that was in the field of Joshua, the man from Beth Shemesh, on which they placed the ark of Yahweh, remained as a reminder and a witness of what had happened even in the days that this story was written.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Joshua from Beth Shemesh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • This is the most amazing thing. Yahweh has done great things and has made my farm a place of memorial; or

  • Praise the name of Yahweh, for he is great and powerful. Yahweh is stronger than all our enemies.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 6:1–18 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

The Philistines had kept the ark of Yahweh in their territory or land for seven months. Use the same words or phrases for ark and Yahweh as you used in previous passages. See the Master Glossary for Yahweh and ark of the covenant, if needed.

The Philistines called together their priests and diviners. Priests are people who are between God and the people. It is important to remember that these Philistine priests are not the same as the priests of Yahweh. Diviners are people who communicate with gods and spirits. Diviners use various rituals to tell the future, interpret dreams, and even to make decisions.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for priests and diviners. Look up priest and divination in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The priests and diviners told the Philistines that if they sent the ark of the God of Israel back, they should send it with a guilt offering. Use the same general word or phrase for God as you used in previous passages. See the Master Glossary for God, if needed. The kind of guilt offering that the Philistines offered was not the same as the guilt offering that an Israelite would offer to Yahweh. The Philistines offered a payment which showed that they acknowledged and accepted that the God of Israel had used his power to punish the Philistines. The Philistines would have offered this kind of gift to any god whom they thought had power over them, but the Israelites would never have offered a guilt offering to anyone except Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for this kind of guilt offering. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The priests and diviners told the Philistines to make images of the tumors that they had on their bodies and the rats that were destroying their land in order to give glory to the God of Israel. To give glory is to honor and recognize God's power. Use the same word or phrase for glory as you used in previous passages. See the Master Glossary for glory, if needed.

The priest and diviners said that if the Philistines gave glory to the God of Israel, perhaps he would lift his hand from the Philistines' gods and their land. Gods of other nations are not the same as the one true God, Yahweh. Sometimes people use wood or metal to make statues or pillars to represent their gods. These were called idols.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for gods. Look up gods in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Israel is the name of the country where the Israelites lived. Sometimes the word Israel refers to all the descendants of Abraham together. It then means the same as the Israelites, or as the people of Israel. When the Philistines say "the God of Israel," they are referring to Yahweh, the God of the Israelites. It is also possible that the Philistines meant the God of the land of Israel. Use the same word that you used for Israel in previous passages. Look up Israel or Israelite in the Master Glossary for more information.

The priests and diviners told the Philistines to prepare a new cart and two milk cows and then to yoke the cows to the cart. A cart is a wooden vehicle that people used to carry things or people, and a milk cow is a cow that has recently given birth and therefore is producing milk for its calf. A yoke is a wooden collar with two openings that people use to tie two animals together. Then the animals can walk together to pull a plow or a cart. The yoke helps the animals to walk in step with each other so that they can pull their load smoothly. For this to work, the animals have to be about the same size.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for yoke. Look up yoke in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The priests and diviners told the people to place the ark of Yahweh on the cart and a box that contained the golden tumors and rats beside it.

The people of Beth Shemesh were in their fields harvesting their wheat. The people rejoiced when they looked up and saw the ark. The people chopped up the wood of the cart and made a fire on which they offered the two cows as a burnt offering to Yahweh. A burnt offering is an offering that is meant to renew a person's relationship with Yahweh. The people kill and chop up the animal, and then burn it completely. The people do not eat any of the animal.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for burnt offering. Look up burnt offering in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Before the people chopped up the wood of the cart, the Levites who were there had already taken down the ark of Yahweh and the box that contained the guilt offerings and placed them on the large rock that was in Joshua's field. Levites are people who belong to the tribe of Levi, one of the 12 tribes of Israel. Those Levites who were descendants of Aaron became priests. Other Levites who were not descendants of Aaron were also important, because they helped the priests in their duties. The Levites had the important job of carrying the ark whenever it needed to be moved. The Levites also helped the priests take care of the tabernacle, and later, the temple.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for Levites. Look up Levites in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The large stone that was in the field of Joshua, the man from Beth Shemesh, on which they placed the ark of Yahweh, remained as a reminder and a witness of what had happened even in the days that this story was written. The word witness here does not mean a person in court. A witness describes a structure that is supposed to remind people of past events. You could translate it as a "stone that helps people remember or testify to certain events."

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for witness. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 6:19–7:2
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 6:19–7:2 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 6:19–7:2 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 6:19–7:2 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the last story, the Philistines listened to the words of their priests and diviners and returned the ark of Yahweh to the land of Israel. The people of Beth Shemesh rejoiced when they saw the cows pulling the ark on the cart into their land. After the Levites took down the ark and the gifts that the Philistines had sent with it, the people made sacrifices to Yahweh.

This story is about what happened to the people of Beth Shemesh after the cows brought the ark into their town. Yahweh struck or killed some of the people of Beth Shemesh because they looked into the ark of Yahweh. Yahweh had commanded that no one was to look into the ark. Yahweh said that he would kill anyone who looked inside the ark, because the ark was holy. It is likely that the people who looked into the ark wanted to see the tablets of the law, the pot of manna, and the rod of Aaron, which the Israelites kept inside the ark. Maybe the people wanted to make sure that the Philistines had not taken these things out or replaced them with other things.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What is the most holy object in your community? What kinds of things can someone do that would be considered disrespectful to this object, and what would God, your gods, spirits, or ancestors do to that person? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh killed 70 men of Beth Shemesh because they had looked into the ark. The people of Beth Shemesh mourned or cried with sorrow because Yahweh had punished them severely or struck them with a heavy blow.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when great joy and celebration suddenly became very sad. What happened to cause the sadness? Pause this audio here.

When the people of Beth Shemesh saw how Yahweh had punished them, the people said that there is no one who is able to stand before Yahweh, because Yahweh is a holy God. The people were afraid of Yahweh and felt that no one was safe in Yahweh's presence. The people did not want the ark to stay in Beth Shemesh because they believed the ark was Yahweh's throne. The people believed that because Yahweh was so holy, Yahweh would kill the people because they were not clean. The people asked each other if there was anyone they could send the ark to. The people asked this question because they realized that no one was holy and probably wondered who could take the ark with them and survive.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Where do you keep the most holy object in your community? What kinds of people are allowed to come near the object? Pause this audio here.

So the people decided to ask the people who lived in Kiriath Jearim to take the ark. The people sent messengers to Kiriath Jearim and told the people there that the Philistines had returned the ark of Yahweh. The people asked the people of Kiriath Jearim to come down to Beth Shemesh and take the ark with them to Kiriath Jearim. Kiriath Jearim was a town of Israel that was 15 kilometers away from Beth Shemesh.

Stop here and look at a map of the journey from Beth Shemesh to Kirjath Jearim as a group. Pause this audio here.

The men of Kiriath Jearim listened to the people's request and came down from their town to Beth Shemesh and took or carried the ark of Yahweh. We do not know how the people transported the ark. The people brought the ark to Kiriath Jearim and put it in the house of a certain man whose name was Abinadab. Abinadab's house was on a nearby hill.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when people in your village or town sent a message to people in another village or town and called them to come help you. Pause this audio here.

The people chose one of Abinadab's sons, whose name was Eleazar. The people dedicated or appointed Eleazar to perform the priestly work of guarding or taking care of the ark of Yahweh. It is likely that Abinadab and his sons were from the tribe of Levi because only the Levites were allowed to perform the work of guarding the ark.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What kinds of things do religious leaders or priests do in your culture? How do you appoint certain leaders to do certain tasks? Pause this audio here.

About 20 years went by from the day the people brought the ark into Kiriath Jearim, and all the people of Israel cried out to Yahweh for help. The people were probably asking Yahweh to save them from the Philistines, who ruled the Israelites. The ark remained in Kiriath Jearim for more than 20 years. The storyteller probably wants to show us that for 20 years the Israelites did not worship Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when your community felt that their God or gods had left them. What made the people feel like that, and how did they behave?

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 6:19–7:2 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has four scenes.

In the first scene: Yahweh punished 70 men of Beth Shemesh with death because the men looked into the ark of Yahweh. The people of Beth Shemesh mourned because Yahweh had caused them great harm. The people said that there was no one who would be able to stand in the presence of Yahweh because of Yahweh's holiness. The people asked each other if there was anyone they could send the ark to in order that Yahweh might leave their town.

In the second scene: The people of Beth Shemesh sent messengers to the people of Kiriath Jearim and told them that the Philistines had returned the ark of Yahweh. The people asked the people of Kiriath Jearim to come down and get the ark and take it with them to Kiriath Jearim.

In the third scene: The people of Kiriath Jearim came down and took the ark of Yahweh and carried it with them to Kiriath Jearim. The people brought the ark to the house of a certain man named Abinadab whose house was on a nearby hill. The people chose one of Abinadab's sons, whose name was Eleazer, and appointed him to look after the ark of Yahweh.

In the fourth scene: The ark remained in Kiriath Jearim for 20 years, and all the people of Israel cried out to Yahweh for help.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Yahweh

  • The 70 men of Beth Shemesh who saw the ark of Yahweh

  • The rest of the people of Beth Shemesh

  • The messengers whom the people of Beth Shemesh sent to Kiriath Jearim

  • The people of Kiriath Jearim

  • The men of Kiriath Jearim whom the people sent to get the ark

  • Abinadab

  • Eleazer

  • And all the people of Israel

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In the first scene, Yahweh struck down some of the men of Beth Shemesh. "Yahweh struck down" was a usual way of saying that Yahweh killed people because he was punishing those people. Yahweh killed 70 men of Beth Shemesh because some of the people looked into the ark of Yahweh. The people probably touched the ark to open it so that they could look inside. It may also be possible that all the people did was stare at the ark with too much curiosity. Yahweh had strictly forbidden anyone from touching the ark. Yahweh had also told Moses to warn the priests who worked in the tabernacle not to go into the holy place to look at the holy things, even for a moment, or they would die. It is not clear whether the men who died were the same people who looked into the ark. It is also possible that more than 70 men looked into the ark. It is also not clear whether Yahweh killed seventy men or fifty thousand and seventy men. The language makes both possible, but it is unlikely that the town of Beth Shemesh would have had fifty thousand and seventy men. Therefore, it is most likely that Yahweh killed 70 men.

Stop here and do this activity as a group: One by one, tell each other about events that you have attended in the past. Choose events that many people attend, such as marriage ceremonies, funerals, or other such gatherings. The person narrating should tell the group how many people they think attended the event and how they know. Pause this audio here.

The people of Beth Shemesh mourned or were sorrowful because Yahweh had caused the people great harm or struck them with a great blow. This is a way of saying that Yahweh punished the people of Beth Shemesh by killing some of the people. It does not mean that Yahweh literally struck the people hard. The people of Beth Shemesh asked whether there was anyone who could bear to be in the presence of Yahweh, because Yahweh is a holy God. The people were not asking a question that they expected anyone to answer. The people were expressing that they did not think anyone could be in Yahweh's presence. It is possible that when the people say, "Yahweh, this holy God," the people are comparing Yahweh to other pagan gods that they may have been worshiping. The people were afraid of the holiness or purity of Yahweh and his power, and the people believed that Yahweh's holiness would kill them all because the people were not pure. Therefore, the people wondered and asked each other whether there was anyone to whom they could send the ark so that Yahweh would leave the people. It is likely that the people discussed this question as a community, with their leaders, like the Philistines had done in the previous story.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Talk about God's qualities or character. Pay attention to how you describe God's purity, or how he is holy, in your language. Pause this audio here.

In the second scene, the people of Beth Shemesh decided to send messengers to the people who lived in Kiriath Jearim. Kiriath Jearim was a town of Israel. In the message, the people of Beth Shemesh informed the people of Kiriath Jearim that the Philistines had returned the ark of Yahweh. The people asked the people of Kiriath Jearim to come down to Beth Shemesh and take the ark with them to Kiriath Jearim. We are not told why the people of Beth Shemesh chose the people of Kiriath Jearim or why they did not send the ark to Shiloh, where it had previously stayed in the tabernacle. The people probably believed that Yahweh had rejected Shiloh. It is also possible that the tabernacle at Shiloh had already been destroyed. The people probably chose Kiriath Jearim because it was the nearest large town on the road from Beth Shemesh to Shiloh.

In the third scene, the people of Kiriath Jearim came down from Kiriath Jearim to Beth Shemesh. Beth Shemesh was a town in a valley, so the people of Kiriath Jearim would have traveled downwards or descended to get to Beth Shemesh. The people of Kiriath Jearim picked up the ark of Yahweh and brought it to Kiriath Jearim. We do not know how the people transported the ark. It is possible that the people brought some Levite men with them from Kiriath Jearim. Yahweh only allowed Levite men to carry the ark. The men brought the ark to Kiriath Jearim and put it in the house of a certain man named Abinadab. Abinadab's house was on a nearby hill, either inside the city of Kiriath Jearim or very near to that city. The people consecrated or dedicated and appointed one of Abinadab's sons, whose name was Eleazer, for the work of guarding the ark. Eleazer would now be able to stand in front of the ark of Yahweh without dying because he was holy or set apart for Yahweh.

In the fourth scene, all the people of Israel were sorrowful and wept for Yahweh all the days that the ark remained in Kiriath Jearim. From the day that the people brought the ark into Kiriath Jearim, many days, about 20 years, passed. The ark continued to remain at Kiriath Jearim until the days of King David, so the storyteller is not saying that people took the ark out of Kiriath Jearim after 20 years. The storyteller is probably explaining to us the spiritual condition of the people of Israel because he tells us that the house or nation of Israel cried out to Yahweh for help. The Philistines still ruled the nation of Israel this whole time, so the Israelites were probably crying out and seeking Yahweh to help them be free from the Philistines.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about someone who needed help, but no one gave that person help. Talk about how this person felt as he begged and continued asking for help and complaining about his situation. Pay attention to the words you use when you describe how the person cries for help. Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 6:19–7:2 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has four scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Yahweh

  • The 70 men of Beth Shemesh who saw the ark of Yahweh

  • The rest of the people of Beth Shemesh

  • The messengers whom the people of Beth Shemesh sent to Kiriath Jearim

  • The people of Kiriath Jearim

  • The men of Kiriath Jearim whom the people sent to get the ark

  • Abinadab

  • Eleazer

  • And all the people of Israel

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

In the first scene, Yahweh killed 70 men of Beth Shemesh because some of the people looked in the ark of Yahweh.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the 70 men of Beth Shemesh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Wow! This ark is amazing. Look how the gold shines. This is the purest gold we have ever seen; or

  • We have heard many stories about the ark from our fathers and our grandfathers. We heard how this ark saved them in war and destroyed their enemies, and now it is here in our town, and our eyes see it; or

  • I wonder what the ark looks like inside. Everyone wants to see it. Everyone has stopped their work and is pushing to look at it.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am angry with the people. The people treat my holy ark like a common object; or

  • These people forget my words to Moses. The people must not touch or foolishly stare at any of my holy things. The ark is not a plaything. The people must make a separation between me and them, because I am holy and the people are sinful. The people must remember that I am holy and powerful. The people must come to me with the highest respect.

Yahweh killed 70 of the people, and the people of Beth Shemesh mourned because Yahweh had struck them with a great blow.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Beth Shemesh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Oh no! What a terrible disaster has happened to us. So many people have died in an instant; or

  • Our joy has turned into sorrow. We have lost our brothers and fathers. Every household mourns. So many deaths.

The people of Beth Shemesh asked if there was anyone who could bear to be in the presence of Yahweh because Yahweh is a holy God.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Beth Shemesh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are too afraid of Yahweh. Yahweh is dangerous. Yahweh will kill us all. Yahweh is not like any other God. We do not want Yahweh to stay here; or

  • Yahweh's holiness is terrifying. Is there any way we can be safe near Yahweh? or

  • Is there anyone who is acceptable to be in Yahweh's presence? Will Yahweh not kill all the people?

The people asked each other whether there was anyone to whom they could send the ark so that Yahweh would leave them.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Beth Shemesh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • The ark cannot stay here. If it remains in Beth Shemesh, all the people will die. But will any town in Israel allow us to bring the ark to them? or

  • Maybe we can send the ark to Shiloh. But how can we send the ark there? Many say that Yahweh rejected Shiloh. Will we not make Yahweh even angrier if we send the ark there? Oh, what shall we do? or

  • Maybe we can send the ark to Kiriath Jearim. The people there will know what to do with the ark. Kiriath Jearim is a big town on the way to Shiloh. Let us ask the people there if they will come and take the ark. It is better there than here with us.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • This is sad. My people would rather get rid of my presence than consider how they might cleanse themselves so that I would not destroy them; or

  • My people's hearts are far from me. The people do not realize that I am able to purify them and bless them and that my presence with them would be good for them if only they would respect me and honor me; or

  • But my people are right in one thing. I am a holy God, and no one can stand before me in their sin.

In the second scene, the people of Beth Shemesh decided to send messengers to the people who lived in Kiriath Jearim. They told the people of Kiriath Jearim that the Philistines had returned the ark of Yahweh and they asked the people to come down to Beth Shemesh and take the ark with them to Kiriath Jearim.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the messengers, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • People have sent us with an urgent message. We must run and deliver it. If we run, we can get there in two hours. Our town depends on us. We do not want anyone else to die; or

  • Maybe we should not tell them about all the people that the ark has killed in our town. We do not want to scare them from coming to take it. We will be very careful about how many details we give them about the things that have happened in Beth Shemesh; or

  • Hopefully, the people of Kiriath Jearim will agree to come back with us and take the ark. If we keep running hard, we can return with them to Beth Shemesh before the end of the day.

Ask the person playing the people of Kiriath Jearim, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We have received messengers from Beth Shemesh today. The people brought an urgent message. The Philistines have returned the ark of Yahweh, and the people of Beth Shemesh have asked us to come and take it from them to Kiriath Jearim; or

  • It is probably best that the ark comes to Kiriath Jearim. Beth Shemesh is close to the country of the Philistines. The Philistines might attack again and capture it. It is probably best if we bring it to us and hide it here; or

  • This is an urgent matter. We have sent some of our men back with the messengers that came from Beth Shemesh to go and bring the ark immediately.

In the third scene, the people of Kiriath Jearim came down from Kiriath Jearim to Beth Shemesh. The people took up the ark of Yahweh and brought it to Kiriath Jearim.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the men of Kiriath Jearim, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • What a wonderful thing has happened. The ark is back in Israel's territory. We are very happy and glad that we are going to get it; or

  • We must make sure that we follow the laws that Moses gave us about transporting the ark, and we must take it back with us at once; or

  • We pray that we will make it back to Kiriath Jearim safely and that we will have no problems on the journey. It would be a great disaster and shame to us if anything happened to the ark.

The people brought the ark to Kiriath Jearim and put it in the house of a certain man named Abinadab.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the men of Kiriath Jearim, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We will bring the ark to the house of Abinadab. It is the safest place in our town. It is on a hill, which means that you can see any enemy approaching. There is also enough room in Abinadab's home; or

  • Abinadab is a Levite, and he has sons who can guard the ark. Yahweh said only Levites are allowed to do the job of guarding the ark; or

Ask the person playing Abinadab, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • What a great honor. I am very happy today; or

  • The ark of Yahweh is the most important thing in all of Israel. How blessed I am that it will be in my house while people make plans for it. It might only be here for a short time, but I am happy that they have chosen my house; or

  • We must be very careful to honor Yahweh and make sure we do not lose the ark again.

The people consecrated or dedicated one of Abinadab's sons, whose name was Eleazer, for the work of guarding the ark.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Kiriath Jearim, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We need someone to guard the ark well, or we will die; or

  • We are also making sacrifices as Moses commanded us so that Yahweh will not be angry.

Ask the person playing Eleazer, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel very emotional and overwhelmed. This is the best day of my life; or

  • This is holy work, and the person doing it must be holy; or

  • Yahweh commanded through Moses this anointing of all who would come into his presence."

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am pleased with the people of Kiriath Jearim. These people are careful to follow my instructions; or

  • These people have treated my ark with respect and have honored my word; or

  • These people have done well to anoint Eleazer. I will bless Eleazer and his father's house.

And all the people in the nation of Israel cried out to Yahweh for help.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the nation of Israel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Our lives are so difficult. We are slaves to the Philistines; or

  • We feel like Yahweh has abandoned us. We cry out to Yahweh for help; or

  • Oh, when will Yahweh come and rescue us?

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • The people need to learn to honor me; or

  • I must teach the people to worship me alone; or

  • I will not help the people until they put away all their false gods and worship me with all their hearts.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 6:19–7:2 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Yahweh struck some of the men of Beth Shemesh. Yahweh struck the men because they looked into the ark of Yahweh. Use the same words or phrases for ark and Yahweh as you used in previous passages. If needed, look up ark of the covenant and Yahweh in the Master Glossary.

Yahweh struck 70 men. Some translations have "seventy and fifty thousand men." This number is difficult because the population of Beth Shemesh was less than 50,070 people. It is probably better to follow what most translations say and use the number 70.

The people of Beth Shemesh asked, "Who is able to stand before Yahweh, this holy God?" Yahweh is holy because Yahweh is completely good, pure, powerful, and majestic. Holy means that God is whole, complete, and unchangeable. But most of all, holy means God is God! Use the same general word or phrase for God as you used in previous passages, and look up God in the Master Glossary, if needed.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for holy. Look up holy in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The people of Beth Shemesh sent messengers to Kiriath Jearim and asked the people to come and take the ark of Yahweh. The men of Kiriath Jearim took the ark of Yahweh and put it in the house of a man named Abinadab.

Stop here and discuss how you will represent these names to make them easy to understand in your language. Pause this audio here.

The people consecrated Abinadab's son Eleazer to guard and keep the ark of Yahweh. To consecrate someone is to dedicate them as holy and set apart for God. We call any person holy whom people dedicate to God. That means that the person is set apart for God's special purposes. That person is no longer common or ordinary.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for consecrate. Look up consecrate in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

From that day, a long time passed, 20 years, and the house of Israel lamented after Yahweh. The house of Israel refers to all the people in the land of Israel.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for the house of Israel. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

When someone laments, they show that they are very sad. Maybe you lament when someone you love dies, but in this case, lament is the kind of sadness that someone feels when they are crying for help. Lament also means that the people were seeking Yahweh earnestly. The people complained to Yahweh about their situation and begged Yahweh to save them.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for lament. Look up lament in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
