title: 1 Samuel 7:3–17
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 7:3–17 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 7:3–17 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 7:3–17 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous story, the men of Kiriath Jearim came to Beth Shemesh and carried the ark of Yahweh from there to their own town. The men brought the ark to Abinadab's house and anointed Abinadab's son Eleazer to guard the ark. The ark remained in Kiriath Jearim for a long time, and for 20 years all the people of Israel were mourning and seeking Yahweh.

This story is about what happened when Samuel heard that the people of Israel were seeking Yahweh. Samuel told the people that if they truly wanted to return to Yahweh, then the people needed to reject or turn away from all of the false gods and be committed to Yahweh and worship Yahweh only. The people of Israel had been worshiping many false gods. It is likely that the people had been going to the temples of the nations that were around them and even bringing the statues of the gods of those nations, like the Ashtoreths, into the Israelites' own homes. The first commandment that Yahweh had commanded the people of Israel in the days of Moses was not to serve or worship any other gods. Samuel said that Yahweh would save the Israelites from the power of the Philistines if the Israelites returned to and obeyed Yahweh only.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when some people in your community stopped doing the worship practices of your ancestors. What caused the people to do so, and what new worship practices did people start doing? Pause this audio here.

The people of Israel listened to Samuel and returned to Yahweh. The people rejected the worship practices of the other nations and got rid of the statutes of the Baals and Ashtoreths. Baal and Ashtoreth were the main male and female gods of the Canaanites. People thought of Baal and Ashtoreth as partners. Many communities worshiped Baal and Ashtoreth in different ways and by different names.

Stop here and look at a picture of the statues of Baal and Ashtoreth as a group. Pause this audio here.

The people of Israel rejected or turned away from all the false gods and returned to Yahweh to worship and serve Yahweh only.

Samuel sent a message to all the people of Israel and told them to gather together at Mizpah so that Samuel could pray to Yahweh for the people. When the people had gathered at Mizpah, they drew water, probably from a well, and poured it before Yahweh. This ritual was probably part of an offering or sacrifice that the people made to Yahweh. The people may also have poured the water as a sign that the people were rejecting Baal, because some people considered Baal the provider of rain. The people also fasted on that day and confessed that they had sinned against Yahweh. Fasting, or going without food for some time, was a religious practice that people did to pray to their god and show that they had turned away from their disobedience.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are some of the rituals your community uses to show God that you are sorry? Imagine the people in your community who had turned away from your way of worship. If those people wanted to return to that worship, how would they do that? Pause this audio here.

It was on this day that Samuel the prophet began to act as a judge or leader of the Israelite people.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Who is the great leader or chief of your people? What are his or her responsibilities? When did this leader begin to be the leader of your people? Pause this audio here.

Someone told the Philistines that the Israelites had gathered together at Mizpah. The Philistine rulers marched out with their army against the Israelites. When the Israelites heard about it, they were afraid that the Philistines would kill the Israelites. The Israelites asked Samuel to pray and beg Yahweh, their God, to rescue them from the power of the Philistines. So Samuel took a young lamb that was still young enough to drink its mother's milk. Samuel cut the lamb up and burned it entirely as a burnt offering to Yahweh. Yahweh had instructed Israel that they could offer a calf, lamb, or baby goat as a burnt offering from the time it was eight days old. Levites offered these burnt offerings to Yahweh on behalf of a person or the nation to say sorry for sin. Samuel may have been a Levite. In any case, Samuel acted like one now.

Stop here and look at a picture of a young lamb as a group. Pause this audio here.

Samuel prayed and begged Yahweh to save the Israelites from the Philistines, and Yahweh heard and accepted Samuel's request.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when your people were in great danger and cried out to God for help. Who spoke to God for the people, and how did he or she do it? Describe any rituals that the person did. Pause this audio here.

This is how Yahweh answered Samuel's prayer: As Samuel was offering the sacrifice, the Philistine army had been approaching the Israelites and had gotten near enough to attack the Israelites. Yahweh sent the sound of a loud thunder against the Philistines and defeated them in the presence of the Israelites. The people of Israel believed that thunder was Yahweh's voice. People believed that Dagon, the Philistines' god, and the Baals controlled the skies. It is likely that Yahweh sent thunder to show that it was Yahweh who controlled the skies. Yahweh's thunder caused the Philistine army to feel great panic. As the Philistines were running away, the men of Israel ran after the Philistines and killed many Philistine men. The Israelites continued chasing and killing the Philistines until they reached a place below Beth Kar.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when your fighters or the fighters of another community lost a battle and ran away in panic. How many fighters died when they ran away in panic, compared to how many fighters died when they drew back all together from the fight? Pause this audio here.

Samuel took a stone and set it up between Mizpa and Shen. People often set up stones where something important happened to remind them of that event. Samuel named the stone Ebenezer, which means "stone of help," because Samuel said that Yahweh had helped Israel up to this point. Samuel likely wanted the people of Israel and their children to remember what Yahweh had done for them so that they would not return to worship false gods.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In what ways does your community keep memory of important events and pass that memory down to later generations? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh defeated the Philistines and made them weaker than the Israelites. The Philistines stopped entering Israel's territory to attack the Israelites.

Stop here as a group and look at a map of the division of the territory of the Israelites and Philistines. Pause this audio here.

For the rest of the time that Samuel was alive, Yahweh was against the Philistines so that they did not enter the land of Israel to take it. The cities between the two large cities of Ekron and Gath that the Philistines had taken from Israel became Israel's territory again. Israel also took back the land that was around those cities from the control of the Philistines. The Amorites, a large and powerful tribe of people who lived in the land of Canaan, also stopped fighting the Israelites at that time and made peace with the Israelites.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when your people took back their own land or property, such as livestock, from your enemies in battle. Or tell about a time when your people took your enemies' land or property because you won a battle. Pause this audio here.

Samuel continued to be the leader of the people of Israel for the rest of his life. Every year, Samuel went to three important Israelite cities to judge the people of Israel. It is likely that Samuel listened to the people's problems and gave them solutions and leadership. It is also likely that Samuel gave justice to people who were in legal disputes after Samuel heard those people's cases.

Samuel traveled to Bethel, Gilgal, and Mizpah. But Samuel always returned to Ramah, his hometown, where Samuel also judged the people.

Stop here and look at a map of Samuel's route as a group. Pause this audio here.

Samuel also built an altar to Yahweh in Ramah. People usually used stone to build altars. People made sacrifices on these altars. The Philistines had probably already destroyed the tabernacle at Shiloh, where the Israelites used to go to sacrifice to Yahweh when Eli was alive. Samuel likely led the people in offering sacrifices, which would mean that Samuel did the job of a priest.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 7:3–17 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has nine scenes.

In the first scene: Samuel told the Israelites that if they truly wanted to return to Yahweh, the people needed to reject and turn away from all of the false gods. The people needed to be committed to Yahweh and worship Yahweh alone. Samuel told the people that Yahweh would save the Israelites from the power of the Philistines if the Israelites did these things.

In the second scene: The people listened to Samuel and returned to Yahweh.

In the third scene: Samuel sent a message to all of Israel and told the people to gather at Mizpah so that Samuel could pray to Yahweh for the people.

In the fourth scene: The people gathered at Mizpah. The people drew water and poured it out before Yahweh. The people fasted that day and confessed their sin.

In the fifth scene: The rulers of the Philistines heard that the Israelites had gathered together at Mizpah, and the Philistines came up to attack the Israelites.

In the sixth scene: The Israelites were afraid when they heard that the Philistines were coming to attack them. The Israelites asked Samuel to cry out to Yahweh to save them. While Samuel was offering a sacrifice to Yahweh, the Philistines came close to attack. But Yahweh sent thunder to scare the Philistines, and Yahweh defeated the Philistines that day.

In the seventh scene: Samuel took a stone and set up a memorial between Mizpah and Shen to remind the people what Yahweh had done for the Israelites.

In the eighth scene: The Philistines stopped entering Israel's territory to fight against Israel because Yahweh had defeated the Philistines. Israel recovered the cities and lands between Ekron and Gath that the Philistines had taken from the Israelites. The Amorites also made peace with Israel.

In the ninth scene: Samuel continued to judge Israel's people all the days of Samuel's life. Every year, Samuel went around in a circle from Bethel to Gilgal to Mizpah, and Samuel judged the people of Israel in each place. Samuel also judged the people in Ramah, Samuel's hometown. Samuel built an altar to Yahweh in Ramah.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Yahweh

  • Samuel

  • The people of Israel

  • The Baals and Ashtoreths—all the false gods that the Israelites had been worshiping

  • The rulers of the Philistines

  • The Philistines

  • And the Amorites

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

The word that opens the first scene shows that Samuel is responding to the previous story. In the previous story, the ark remained in Kiriath Jearim for a long time, and the people of Israel lamented or looked for Yahweh. In the first scene of this story, Samuel responded to the people's lament by telling the house or nation of Israel that if the people were truly returning to Yahweh with all their heart, the people should get rid of their foreign gods. Samuel is telling the Israelites that they need to stop disobeying. The people need to turn back to Yahweh. Samuel says that the Israelites must be sincere and be totally committed to Yahweh. But Samuel uses the special language "with all their heart" because the Israelites believe the heart is the part of the body that shows emotion and commitment.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What special language do you have in your community to speak about someone who does something earnestly and sincerely? In your language, which part of the body do you speak of as being the center of commitment, emotion, or determination? Pause audio here.

Samuel told the people that they should completely put away, get rid of, or turn from worshiping the foreign gods that the nations around them worshiped, including the Ashtaroth. Ashtaroth was a very popular female god of the Canaanites. Samuel told the Israelites that if the Israelites directed or turned their attention to Yahweh and served and worshiped Yahweh only, Yahweh would save the Israelites from the power of the Philistines. The Israelites were supposed to serve Yahweh with sacrifices, rituals, special days, pilgrimages, and temple ceremonies. But the Israelites had stopped doing these things for Yahweh and had instead been doing them for the Baals and Ashtoreths. Samuel is telling the Israelites that they need to stop doing those things and commit themselves completely to Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In what ways do your community and the communities around you serve or worship God? Pay attention to the words you use for worship and serve. Pause this audio here.

In the second scene, the people listened to Samuel. The people put away their many idols or statues and served Yahweh only. The storyteller refers to the Baal and Ashtaroth as being many. This could mean that the people had many idols of the same two gods, or it could also mean that the Israelites had many kinds of male and female gods.

In the third scene, Samuel told all the people of Israel to gather at Mizpah so that Samuel could pray to Yahweh for the people. Samuel wanted to pray for the people so that Yahweh would bring the people back into a peaceful relationship with Yahweh. This would happen if Yahweh forgave the people for worshiping other gods. It is unlikely that every man, woman, and child in Israel came to Mizpah. It is more likely that Samuel meant all adult men. Mizpah means watchtower or lookout. People probably called more than one place in Israel "Mizpah." This Mizpah was in the territory of Benjamin, 13 kilometers north of Jerusalem.

Stop here and look at a map of Mizpah as a group. Pause audio here.

In the fourth scene, the people gathered at Mizpah. When the people had gathered at Mizpah, the people drew water from a well or a pit and poured it out before Yahweh. The people may have poured out water "before Yahweh" as a ritual that was part of a particular sacrifice or offering. It may also be possible that the people were simply denying themselves drinking water. The people may also have wanted to show that they were pouring out, or giving, their sorrow and wrongdoing to Yahweh. The people also fasted or went without food all that day and confessed that they had sinned against Yahweh. The people confessed together for the sin of the whole nation. The people may have also confessed individual sins. Yahweh had promised the people of Israel in the days of Moses that Yahweh would forgive the people whenever they returned to Yahweh and put away their idols and confessed their sin. Yahweh cared about what the people believed and felt about Yahweh. The people needed to sincerely repent. The rituals were outward signs of what was happening in the people's hearts or thoughts. Samuel was the one who was judging or leading the people. A judge in those days led the people to return to Yahweh and to fight their enemies. Samuel also prayed for the nation and set up memorials.

In the fifth scene, as the people of Israel confessed their sin in Mizpah, someone told the Philistines that the Israelites had gathered at Mizpah. The rulers of the Philistines marched out with their men and came to attack the Israelites. People commonly began war with religious rituals, so the rulers of the Philistines probably thought that the Israelites were preparing themselves to attack the Philistines.

In the sixth scene, someone told the Israelites that the Philistines were coming to attack the Israelites. The Israelites were afraid that the Philistines would defeat and kill the Israelites. So the Israelites asked Samuel to keep crying out and urgently beg Yahweh to save the Israelites from the power of the Philistines.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when your people prayed to God to save them from certain death. How did your people sound when they prayed? Pay attention to the words you use for the type of praying that the people did. Pause this audio here.

Samuel responded to the Israelites' request by taking a young or baby lamb and sacrificing it to Yahweh as a burnt offering. The Israelites usually offered a burnt offering to ask Yahweh to forgive the Israelites for their sins. It is likely that Samuel killed and chopped up the animal before he burned the animal completely. Samuel prayed earnestly to Yahweh and asked Yahweh to save the Israelites from the power of the Philistines just as the people of Israel had requested.

Yahweh heard and answered Samuel's prayer in this way. As Samuel had been offering the burnt offering, the Philistines had been approaching the people of Israel to attack the people of Israel. It is likely that at the time that Samuel was sacrificing and praying, the Philistines were close enough to the Israelites to attack them and begin a battle. Yahweh sent a loud thunder against the Philistines and confused the Philistines. It is likely that the sound that the Philistines heard was a loud thunder. The Israelites believed that thunder was Yahweh's voice.

Stop here and discuss how you will talk about the sound of loud thunder in your language. Pause this audio here.

Yahweh defeated the Philistines, and the Israelites saw Yahweh do it. The Philistines believed that their god Dagon was in charge of storms. It is possible that Yahweh sent thunder against the Philistines to show the Philistines and the Israelites that only Yahweh had power in the skies. The Philistines began to run away. When the Israelites saw this, the Israelites chased the Philistines and continued killing many of the Philistines. The Israelites chased the Philistines all the way to the place people called Beth Kar.

In the seventh scene, after the Israelites had chased off the Philistines and killed many of them, Samuel set up a stone between Mizpah and Shen to help the Israelites remember the victory. Samuel called the stone "Ebenezer," or "stone of help," because Samuel said that up to that point, it was Yahweh who had helped the Israelites.

In the eighth scene, the Philistines stopped coming into the land of Israel to make war on Israel, because Yahweh had conquered the Philistines. It is likely that the Philistines would have come into the land of Israel for other reasons, but they did not come again with their army to harass Israel.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell stories about an enemy tribe or community that invaded your lands to fight with you or steal from you. Discuss a time when you were able to defeat that tribe or community. If you have never defeated those people, imagine the day that you will. Tell how those people stopped fighting you. Pay attention to the words you use for how the enemy stopped wanting to fight you. Pause this audio here.

For the rest of the days that Samuel remained alive, the hand or power of Yahweh was against the Philistines to stop the Philistines from defeating Israel. The Israelites use the special language "hand of Yahweh" to talk about Yahweh's power.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What special language do you use in your community to talk about the way someone powerfully defeats that person's enemy? Pause this audio here.

The big cities of Ekron and Gath remained under the Philistines' control, but the Israelites retook all the cities between Ekron and Gath that the Philistines had previously taken from the Israelites. Israel also delivered or saved the lands around those cities from the Philistines' control. The Amorites, who lived in the land of Canaan, also stopped attacking the Israelites.

In the ninth scene, Samuel acted as the leader of the people of Israel for all the days of his life. Samuel would travel around the country in a circle each year. Samuel would go from Bethel to Gilgal and then to Mizpah. In each of these towns, Samuel would listen to the Israelites' problems or disputes, and Samuel would give the people justice by telling them what would be pleasing to Yahweh in each case. Samuel would always return to his house in Samuel's ancestral hometown, Ramah. The people of Israel would also come to Ramah to get justice from Samuel. Samuel also built an altar to sacrifice to Yahweh in Ramah. It is likely that the people of Israel brought their sacrifices to Ramah, where Samuel would also be the religious leader. Samuel was a prophet, but in this story, Samuel also became a judge and did the job of a priest by leading the people in offering sacrifices.

This passage has nine scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel

  • The people of Israel

  • The Baals and Ashtoreths, all the false gods that the Israelites had been worshiping

  • The rulers of the Philistines

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

In the first scene, Samuel told the people of Israel that if they were returning to Yahweh with all their heart, they should get rid of their foreign gods and serve Yahweh alone. Then Yahweh would save the Israelites from the hand of the Philistines.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Israel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am very happy. The people are sincere in their desire to return to Yahweh; or

In the third scene, Samuel sent a message to all of Israel and told the people to gather at Mizpah so that Samuel could pray to Yahweh for the people.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel like it is very important that I must gather the people so that we can confess our sins to Yahweh and ask for Yahweh's forgiveness and help.

Ask the person playing the people of Israel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

In the fourth scene, the people gathered at Mizpah. The people drew water and poured it out before Yahweh. The people fasted that day and confessed their sin.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Israel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • This is a good day. The nation is returning to Yahweh; or

In the fifth scene, as the people of Israel were confessing their sin, someone told the Philistines that the Israelites had gathered at Mizpah. The rulers of the Philistines marched out with their men and came to attack the Israelites.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the rulers of the Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

In the sixth scene, the Israelites heard that the Philistines were coming to attack the Israelites. The Israelites were afraid that the Philistines would kill the Israelites. The Israelites asked Samuel to beg Yahweh to save the Israelites.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Israel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are very afraid. We are not prepared for battle; or

  • Only Yahweh can help us.

So Samuel took a young lamb and sacrificed the lamb as a burnt offering. Samuel cried out to Yahweh to save the Israelites.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • The lamb I sacrifice must be perfect. This is how we make peace with Yahweh; or

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • The Israelites' hearts are sincere. I have forgiven the Israelites' evil ways. I am not angry with the Israelites. I will save my children from disaster.

Ask the person playing the Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so afraid because the gods of the Israelites attack us; or

  • Our military leaders have left us! or

  • So many of our people are dead. The confusion and chaos make us even weaker. We have lost all our strength and confidence.

The Israelites chased the Philistines, who were escaping, and killed many of the Philistines.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Israelites, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Praise Yahweh our God! or

  • Yahweh has given us victory. We are full of courage now that Yahweh has heard our cry and acted for us. Let us all chase our enemy and kill the Philistines.

In the seventh scene, Samuel took a stone and set it up between Mizpah and Shen to remind the people of what Yahweh had done for them.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • The people forget easily, and they turn away from Yahweh and go after foreign gods. If the people do forget, this stone will remind the people about the slavery they suffered under the Philistines and how Yahweh delivered the Israelites.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • If the people remember who I am and what I have done for them, the people will be faithful to me; or

  • I am so happy that my people are free. It does not please me for my people to be in bondage.

Israel recovered the cities between Ekron and Gath that the Philistines had taken from the Israelites. Israel also took back the lands around those cities. The Amorites also made peace with Israel.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Philistine rulers, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We will not attack Israel anymore. The power of Israel's God terrifies us; or

  • The Philistine warriors would not listen to us anyway. None of them wants to fight against Israel anymore.

Ask the person playing the Amorites, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We heard what the God of the Israelites did to the Philistines, and we became very scared. We live very close to the Israelites and do not want to be at war with the Israelites.

In the ninth scene, Samuel continued to judge the Israelites people all the days of his life. Samuel went around in a circle from Bethel to Gilgal to Mizpah. Samuel judged the people of Israel in those places. Samuel also judged the people in Ramah, Samuel's hometown. Samuel also built an altar to Yahweh in Ramah.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am happy that the people do not worship idols anymore; or

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am happy. My people worship only me. I have given my people peace with their enemies, and my people increase in the land. I will keep blessing my people because I love them; or

  • Samuel has been faithful to me. Samuel has followed me with his whole heart and has led my people well; or

  • I will punish my people's enemies who come to attack them because my people are pleasing to me. My people listen to my word that I give to Samuel.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 7:3–17 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Samuel told the house of Israel that if they were returning to Yahweh, the people should put away the foreign gods and Ashtoreth and direct their hearts to Yahweh and serve Yahweh only.

"House of Israel" refers to the nation of Israel, which is all of Jacob's descendants together. House of Israel means the same as Israelites or "people of Israel."

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for the house of Israel. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. For more information, look up Israel in the Master Glossary. Pause this audio here.

Use the same word or phrase for Yahweh as you used in previous passages, and see the Master Glossary for more information about Yahweh. Foreign gods and Ashtoreth are gods of other nations. Gods of other nations are not the same as the one true God, Yahweh. Yahweh told the people of Israel not to worship or follow any other god but Yahweh. Sometimes people used wood or metal to make statues or pillars to represent their gods. People called these things idols. "Foreign gods" is a general phrase that includes any god of another country or community. Ashtoreth was a female fertility goddess of Canaan.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for foreign gods and Ashtoreth. Look up gods in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Serve is another word for worship. When you serve someone, you live and work for that person. Samuel told Israel to serve or worship Yahweh by bowing down, sacrificing, praying, and being obedient to Yahweh only. To do that, the Israelites would have to stop serving the foreign gods.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for serve. If you decide to use the idea of worship in this passage, look up worship in the Master Glossary for more information. Pause this audio here.

The people put away the Baals and Ashtaroth and served Yahweh only. Baal was a male fertility god of the Canaanites. The Canaanites considered Baal to be the husband of Ashtaroth. When the storyteller refers to the Baal and Ashtaroth as many instead of individuals, this could refer to the many idols people made to represent Baal and Ashtaroth or to the many other male and female gods of the surrounding nations.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for Baal and Ashtaroth. Look up Baal in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Samuel gathered all Israel at Mizpah and drew water and poured it out before Yahweh. The people fasted all that day. When someone is fasting, that person is not eating or drinking anything for a certain amount of time. Sometimes people fasted because they wanted to ask Yahweh to forgive their sins. In that case, fasting was a sign of humility. Sometimes people were fasting because they needed Yahweh to help them, or they wanted Yahweh to tell them what to do. Fasting was then a way to show Yahweh how serious the problem was. People in many cultures know the practice of fasting. When you translate the word fasting, be careful that the word in your language does not mean fasting in honor of a particular god or religion, or for one particular purpose. You may need to use a different word or phrase that explains the biblical practice of fasting.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for fasting. Look up fasting in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Samuel judged the people of Israel. Yahweh gave the people of Israel men and sometimes women whom people called judges to lead the people and decide their cases for them. Samuel was a prophet, but Samuel also became a judge. Samuel led the Israelite people in offering sacrifices and prayer. Samuel also led the people in war and set up memorials. Use the same word or phrase for judge as you used in previous passages. For more information on judges, refer to the Master Glossary.

When the Philistines heard that the Israelites had gathered at Mizpah, the Philistine rulers marched their armies out to attack the Israelites. The Israelites were afraid when they heard that the Philistines were coming to attack the Israelites. The Israelites asked Samuel to beg Yahweh to save the Israelites. Samuel took a suckling lamb and offered it to Yahweh as a burnt offering. Samuel cried to Yahweh to save Israel, and Yahweh answered. A suckling lamb is a lamb that is still young enough to drink its mother's milk.

Stop here and look at a picture of a suckling lamb as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for suckling lamb. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

A burnt offering is a form of sacrifice that people bring to God. When a person brings God a burnt offering, that person kills an animal and burns this animal completely on an altar, which is a special place that people make for bringing gifts to God. Samuel was probably telling Yahweh that the Israelite people would be completely devoted to Yahweh, just as they completely burned the animal. Use the same word or phrase for burnt offering as you used in previous passages. For more information on burnt offering, refer to the Master Glossary.

After Yahweh had defeated the Philistines, Samuel set up a stone between Mizpah and Shen. Samuel called the stone Ebenezer, which means "stone of help," to remind the Israelite people that Yahweh had helped them up to that point. It is important to connect the name Ebenezer with its meaning because this is why Samuel used the name. You can use the name Ebenezer and give the meaning, or you can say the name Ebenezer in the closest-sounding way in your language. Use the same word or phrase for Ebenezer as you used in previous passages.

The Philistines stopped entering the land of Israel to fight, and the Israelites recovered the land that the Philistines had taken from the Israelites. The Amorites also made peace with Israel. When nations live in harmony with each other without fighting, those nations are living in peace.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for peace. Look up peace in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Samuel judged Israel for the rest of Samuel's life. Samuel would go around the Israel cities of Bethel, Gilgal, and Mizpeh every year and judge the people there. But Samuel would always return to his home in Ramah, where Samuel built an altar to Yahweh. An altar is a place where people make offerings or sacrifices to God. An altar is like a table or a platform that people make of earth or large stones. People placed gifts for God on this table. Often, this meant that people then burned the gift. The gift could be an animal, food items, or sweet-smelling spices.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for altar. Look up altar in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 8:1–9
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 8:1–9 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 8:1–9 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 8:1–9 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

Samuel has been leading the Israelites for many years and is now growing old. Instead of new judges to replace Samuel, the Israelites want a king like the nations around them. The Israelites are really rejecting Yahweh, because Yahweh chooses the judges. But Yahweh tells Samuel to appoint or choose a king. First, though, Samuel must warn the people about how a king will act. This is an important moment for Israel, when kings begin to lead, instead of judges.

As Samuel grows older, Samuel appoints or chooses his sons to be judges. Judges are people who help solve disagreements and lead the Israelites. Samuel may have wanted his sons to help him lead and maybe continue to lead after Samuel dies. This is the first time a judge chooses the next judge. Normally, God chooses each judge. Samuel's two sons are Joel and Abijah, and these men are judges in the south of Israel in a town people call Beersheba. This is far from where Samuel lives in the town of Ramah.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel as a group and find the towns of Beersheba and Ramah. Pause this audio here.

But Samuel's sons are not good judges. The storyteller uses the special language of walking to describe how Joel and Abijah act. Samuel acts in a fair and just way, which is like walking on good, straight paths. Samuel's sons do not follow Samuel's example or walk on those good, straight paths. Instead, Samuel's sons turn and get off the good paths to do wrong and unfair things. Because Samuel's sons are greedy for money, Joel and Abijah accept bribes or gifts of money from people to make wrong and bad judgments. Joel and Abijah prevent justice or do not treat people fairly according to Yahweh's laws.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: As an activity, describe a leader who acts in a fair and just way. Then describe a leader who does not act in a fair and just way. Discuss what kind of phrases or comparisons you would use to compare those two leaders. Pause this audio here.

Since the Israelites are unhappy with their leaders, the Israelite elders ask Samuel for a new leader for all the Israelites. An elder was the head of a large family or clan. These elders would meet together to make decisions about the community. The elders come to Samuel at Ramah to speak with Samuel. Samuel is getting old, the elders say, which probably means that the elders are worried Samuel will not be able to lead the people for much longer. The elders do not want Samuel's sons to take Samuel's place because the sons do not act fairly like Samuel does. For the Israelites' new leader, the elders ask for a king to lead them. The Israelites want to be like the other nations that have kings.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Discuss the different kinds of leaders in your cultures, such as leaders of family groups, cities, tribes, or nations. What words do you use for these different leaders? Which leaders are more important or have more authority than the other leaders? Who chooses the new leaders? Pause this audio here.

Samuel is not happy that the people asked for a king. The storyteller says that the people's request was evil in Samuel's eyes. This means that Samuel thinks that this is a bad or evil request. Samuel knows that Yahweh has chosen Israel to be Yahweh's people and to be different than the other nations. But now, Israel wants to be like the other nations that have a king. In this time, kings had all of the power and authority, more than the judges who followed Yahweh's guidance. Also, a king would rule for life and then pass on his authority to one of his sons. With a king to lead them, the Israelites will not have to wait for Yahweh to appoint the next judge. Because Samuel is worried about this request, Samuel prays to Yahweh to ask what to do.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when you saw something bad or evil that made you unhappy or upset. Discuss as a group what words or phrases you use to describe how you feel about something that is bad or evil. What words or phrases do you use to show you are unhappy with something? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh speaks to Samuel and tells Samuel to choose a king for the people. Yahweh explains that when the people ask Samuel to give them a new leader to replace Samuel, the people are not just rejecting Samuel as their leader. The people are actually rejecting Yahweh as their king, since Yahweh chooses the judges, including Samuel. With this request, the elders are saying that Yahweh is not a good enough king and that a human king and his sons will do a better job.

Yahweh says that the Israelites have been rejecting Yahweh for a long time. From when Yahweh brought the Israelites out of Egypt up until that day, the Israelites abandoned Yahweh to worship other false gods. And now, the Israelites are treating Samuel in the same way by rejecting Samuel's leadership. Again, Yahweh tells Samuel to do what the elders want, but to first explain what a king will be like. Samuel must solemnly warn the people about what a king will do when he rules over the people. Then the Israelites can see how different a human king is from Yahweh.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 8:1–9 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has three scenes.

In the first scene: Samuel appoints Samuel's sons to be judges. But Samuel's sons are dishonest and accept gifts of money to make wrong judgments.

In the second scene: The Israelite elders come to Samuel and ask Samuel to appoint a king to lead the Israelites so the Israelites will be like the other nations.

In the third scene: Samuel prays to Yahweh about the elders' request. Yahweh tells Samuel to choose a king. Yahweh explains that the people are really rejecting Yahweh as their king and leader, just like the people have been doing since they left Egypt. Yahweh tells Samuel to warn the people how the king will act.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel

  • Samuel's sons, Joel and Abijah

  • The elders of Israel

  • And Yahweh

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

The first scene in this story probably begins many years after the victory in the last passage. Samuel is old, old enough to have two adult sons. Samuel appoints his sons, or gives his sons authority to lead. Samuel may have needed help to lead the Israelites, or maybe Samuel was preparing for when he could not lead anymore. Samuel lives in the town of Ramah in the center of Israel and, according to the last passage, Samuel sometimes travels to nearby towns. Samuel's sons go down to the town of Beersheba, in the south of Israel, and judge there. Because Samuel's sons are greedy for money, Samuel's sons accept money secretly to make wrong judgments. Samuel is not nearby to stop or correct Samuel's sons.

The second scene happens some time after the first. Samuel's sons have been judging long enough for the people to see how bad the sons are. So the elders go to Ramah to speak with Samuel. The elders begin to speak to Samuel with a word that means, "Pay attention! We are about to say something important!"

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, what words or phrases do you use to get someone's attention when you want to talk about something important? Pause this audio here.

The elders mention two problems. First, Samuel is old, so Samuel will not be able to lead the Israelites for much longer. Also, Samuel's sons are not good leaders, so the elders do not want the sons to lead the Israelites after Samuel dies. The elders tell Samuel that the way to solve these problems is to pick a new leader, a king! The Israelites have seen the kings of other nations, and the elders want to have a king too. Samuel is not pleased with this request.

In the third scene, Samuel talks to Yahweh, and Yahweh tells Samuel what to do. Yahweh tells Samuel to listen to the elders' request. This means that Samuel should do what the elders ask. Yahweh says that the Israelites are treating Samuel in the same way that the Israelites have treated Yahweh. The people are rejecting Samuel as their leader while Samuel is still alive. The Israelites are asking for a different kind of leader, which the Israelites think will be better than a judge. In the same way, the Israelites have also been rejecting Yahweh ever since Yahweh brought the Israelites out of Egypt. To this day, the Israelites keep worshiping other gods. The Israelites think these gods will be better than Yahweh.

Yahweh explains that the Israelites are really rejecting Yahweh again, not just Samuel, when they ask for a new leader. Yahweh has been choosing the judges and leaders of Israel. This means that Yahweh was the king, or top leader of Israel. With this request, the elders are saying that Yahweh is not a good enough king and that a human king will do a better job.

Again, Yahweh tells Samuel to listen and do what the people ask. But before Samuel anoints a king, Samuel should warn the people what a king will do. Samuel should speak clearly and seriously. This means that Samuel should speak in a formal way to show how important this information is. The king will declare that he has certain privileges or that certain actions are right for the king to do as king.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Think of times when people speak in a solemn or formal and serious way, such as during a ceremony. Discuss how you would describe that kind of speaking. Pause this audio here.

Now stop and discuss roles or jobs in your culture that come with certain duties and privileges, like a husband or business owner. Discuss how and why people get those roles, and the privileges, too. Discuss what words or phrases you would use to describe how these people take or use these privileges. Pause this audio here.

Yahweh already warned the Israelites about the danger of kings when Yahweh gave the Israelites his law. Yahweh is reminding the Israelites that this is an important choice, and Yahweh is showing the Israelites how a human king will lead them differently than Yahweh does.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 8:1–9 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has three scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel

  • Samuel's sons, Joel and Abijah

  • The elders of Israel

  • And Yahweh

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

When Samuel became an old man, Samuel appointed his sons to be judges in Israel. Samuel's oldest son was Joel, and Samuel's second son was Abijah. Joel and Abijah acted as judges in the town of Beersheba. But Samuel's sons did not follow Samuel's good example. Samuel's sons were only interested in making money, so they accepted bribes to make wrong judgments.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I want to lead the people well, but as I get older, I become more tired and cannot listen to everyone's problems! I need some help! or

  • I trust my sons. As my sons grew up, Joel and Abijah saw how I judged and led the Israelites. Surely Joel and Abijah will lead in the same way; or

  • I am worried for the Israelites. When I die, the Israelites will need a new leader! I will go ahead and choose some new leaders, so that the Israelites will not have trouble after I die.

Ask the person playing Joel and Abijah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I have seen the way my father acts as a judge, but that does not seem like the best way to me. I am sure I know more than my father does. It is a good thing we do not live near our father, so our father cannot correct or catch us; or

  • I do not want to have to work too hard to get money! If I take these bribes that people give me, then I will be able to live well and comfortably! or

  • I am excited to have this new job as a judge! I do not really care about doing what is right or helping other people. I just want to be important and rich!

So all the elders of Israel went together to Ramah to talk with Samuel. The elders said to Samuel, "Look, you are old now, but your sons do not follow your good example. So now choose a king to lead us, so that we will have a king like all the other nations."

But Samuel did not think that the elders' request for a king was good. Samuel prayed to Yahweh and told Yahweh what the people had asked for.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the elders, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Samuel's sons are not good judges! I am tired of having judges. I want a new kind of leader; or

  • I see other nations have strong kings who make the nations wealthy and powerful! I want what those nations have! or

  • I do not like waiting around for Yahweh to pick a new judge. When we do not have a judge, other nations fight against us and win! I would rather have a strong king who can protect us all the time!

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Now I am even more worried about the Israelites! The Israelites want to be like the nations that do not worship Yahweh and do terrible, evil things! or

  • I am offended! These Israelites are saying that they do not want me or my family to lead them! or

  • I know that Yahweh is really our leader, not me, so I will ask Yahweh what to do about this. I know Yahweh will give me the right words to tell the people.

Yahweh said to Samuel, "Do as the people have asked. You think the people are just rejecting you, but really, they are rejecting me as their king. Ever since I rescued the Israelites out of Egypt, these people have rejected me by turning away from me and worshiping other gods. In the same way, the people are rejecting you as their leader. So now do what the people say, but be sure to give them a clear warning and tell the people what their kings will do."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am sad that my people do not want me to lead them. I have protected and saved my people when no human could, but the people still want a human king; or

  • I want my people to choose to follow me, so I will give the people a choice. I want the people to understand how a human king will not be as good a leader as I am; or

  • Even though the Israelites have rejected me again and again, I am patient with them, because I love them. I have taken care of the Israelites even when they chose other gods. However, things will change if the people pick a human king.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 8:1–9 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Samuel appoints his sons to be judges for Israel. To appoint means to assign a job or role to someone and give that person authority to act in a certain way. Use the same word or phrase for appoint as you used in previous passages.

Judges were leaders who helped settle arguments or disputes and sometimes led the Israelites in battle. God chose all the judges except Samuel's sons.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for judge. Look up judge in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Israel is the name of the country where the Israelites lived. Sometimes the word Israel refers to all of Abraham's descendants together. It then means the same as Israelites or "people of Israel." For more information on Israel, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Israel as you used in previous passages.

Samuel's sons accept bribes, or gifts of money, to stop or prevent justice. Justice is when someone treats someone else fairly according to the law. Joel and Abijah make wrong, unjust judgments that do not follow God's laws.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for justice. Look up justice in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Because these new leaders are not just, the Israelite elders go to speak to Samuel. In this time, an elder was usually the head of a large family or a clan who had authority in the community. A group of elders would meet together to make decisions about the work in the community. For more information on elder, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for elder as you used in previous passages.

The elders ask Samuel to appoint a king like the other nations have. A king was someone who ruled over a city or territory. A king normally ruled for his entire life and passed on his authority to one of the king's sons. Kings had more authority and power than judges. For more information on king, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for king as you used in previous passages.

A nation is a group of people who belong together, who live in the same country, and who have the same ruler.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for nation. Look up nation in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Because Samuel is unhappy that the people made this request, Samuel prays to Yahweh. To pray means to communicate with or speak to God. For more information on pray, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for pray as you used in previous passages.

Yahweh is God's proper name. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Yahweh as you used in previous passages.

Yahweh says that the Israelites keep worshiping other gods. These are false gods. For more information on gods, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for gods as you used in previous passages.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
