title: 1 Samuel 8:10–22
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 8:10–22 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 8:10–22 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 8:10–22 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

After Samuel talks with Yahweh about the people's request for a king, Samuel speaks to the elders again. Samuel explains what life with a king would be like. Samuel is trying to warn the elders that their request was not a good one because kings will take many things from the people. However, the Israelites do not listen and insist that they still want a king. When Samuel talks to Yahweh again, Yahweh says to do what the people want and choose a human king.

First, Samuel repeats everything Yahweh has said to the people. Then Samuel explains to the people what a king will have the right to do. Samuel is probably speaking to the elders Samuel talked to in the last section. Samuel says these are the rights of kings, or that kings have the authority to do these things.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture's history, how have kings or top rulers behaved? How did people expect the rulers to behave? Why do people expect these things? Pause this audio here.

A king will take the Israelites' sons and daughters and make them serve the king. The king could pay these people or make them work without payment. Either way, the king forces the people to serve whether they want to or not.

A king will take the Israelites' sons and make the sons work in the king's army. The king will make some of the people's sons drive the king's chariots. Chariots were wagon-like vehicles with two wheels. Horses pulled the chariots, and two men, one driver and one warrior, rode the chariot into battle.

Stop here and look at a picture of a chariot as a group. Pause this audio here.

A king will make some of the Israelites' sons serve with the king's horses, riding the horses into battle. Other sons will have to run in front of the king's chariot as runners. In that time, a group of men ran ahead of the king's chariots to clear the way and protect the king. A king will also make the Israelites' sons serve as commanders or military leaders. These commanders would be in charge of a group of soldiers, from 50 men to 1,000 men. These were standard-sized groups, so sometimes people just called these groups a "thousand" or a "fifty."

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, what are the armies or military groups like? How do the leaders organize the soldiers? Who is in charge of the soldiers? Pause this audio here.

A king will also make the Israelites' sons plow or prepare the king's ground for planting crops, then reap or gather the crops for the king's harvest. Other sons will have to make the soldiers' weapons and the equipment for horses in the king's army.

A king will not only take the people's sons for his work, but the king will also take the Israelites' daughters. The king will make these women serve the king as perfumers, who mix ointments and spices for perfume and maybe medicine. Other daughters will have to cook food and bake bread for the king.

A king will also take the Israelites' land and possessions. A king will take the Israelites' best land: their fertile fields where they grow grains, like wheat. The king will take the people's vineyards, the gardens of vines where the people grow grapes. The king will take the people's olive orchards, which are groups of trees that grow olives. A king will take the most fertile fields, the vineyards that grow the largest grapes, and the olive orchards where the trees grow the most olives. The king will give this land to his own officials and attendants, or trusted servants, probably to keep and reward their loyalty.

Stop here and look at a picture of a vineyard and an olive orchard as a group. Pause this audio here.

A king will then take a tax or portion of the food that the Israelites grow in the fields they have left. The king will take a tenth of their grain and vintage, which are grapes. Out of every ten things the people produce, the king will take one. Then the king will give that food to his important officials and trusted servants. Kings in the nations around Israel normally did this as well.

A king will also take the Israelites' servants, both men and women, so the servants must serve the king instead. A king will also take the Israelites' best donkeys for the king's use. Donkeys were important animals that carried heavy loads and pulled farming equipment.

Stop here and look at a picture of a donkey as a group. Pause this audio here.

Some versions say that the king will take their best young men to serve the king. Other versions say the king will take the people's best cattle. The king is definitely taking both the people's young men and their animals, but the best word to use here is probably cattle. A king will also take a tenth of the flocks of sheep and goats.

Stop here and look at pictures of cattle, goats, and sheep as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Talk about the kinds of things rulers in your history have done compared with the kinds of things Samuel says the kings could do. Talk about what things they took or used. Why do you think they did these things? Pause this audio here.

In the end, the Israelites will become the king's slaves. Soon, the Israelites' enemies will not oppress the Israelites anymore, like in the time of the judges. But instead, the Israelites' own king will oppress them! When that time comes, the Israelites will cry out or protest loudly to Yahweh because of their suffering. The Israelites will ask Yahweh for relief because of their king. However, Yahweh will not answer the Israelites when they ask. The Israelites will have to live with the results of their choice.

When Samuel finishes saying all this, the Israelite elders reject Samuel's advice. The elders say, "No! We do not believe you! This will not actually happen!" Again, the elders say that they want to be like other nations. The elders want a king to lead and judge for them. The elders do not want Yahweh to lead them in Yahweh's battles, like Yahweh has done before. Instead, the people want a king to lead them to fight in their own battles.

After Samuel listens to all the people have to say, Samuel tells Yahweh what the people have decided. Again, Yahweh says to listen to the people and do what they ask. Samuel should appoint a king to rule the Israelites. Because Samuel will now begin to search for a king, Samuel tells the Israelite elders to return to their hometowns.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 8:10–22 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has three scenes.

In the first scene: Samuel describes what kings do. Kings take people's sons and daughters and make those sons and daughters work for the king. Kings take people's best land, produce, animals, and servants. Eventually, the Israelites will become their king's slaves.

In the second scene: The Israelites do not listen to Samuel's warning. Again, the Israelites declare that they want to be like other nations. The Israelites want a king to lead them and fight the Israelites' battles.

In the third scene: Samuel speaks to Yahweh, who tells Samuel to appoint a king. Samuel tells the people to return home.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel

  • Yahweh

  • The Israelite elders

  • The kings who will rule Israel

  • The Israelites' sons

  • The Israelites' daughters

  • The king's officials and attendants

  • And the Israelites' servants

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In the first scene, Samuel repeats Yahweh's words to the Israelite elders, then warns them about what a king will have the right to do. Samuel describes a king's actions because the Israelites have never had a king. The Israelite leaders in the past have not acted like a king. Other nations' kings do these things. And now, since the Israelites want to be like other nations, Israel's kings will do similar things. While one king may do all of these things, Samuel is not necessarily describing a certain king. Samuel is warning the Israelites that these are things kings normally do.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: As an activity, describe the duties or actions of a kind of job or role, such as a farmer or a mother. Pay attention to how you show that you are talking about the normal actions of anyone who has that role or job, and not just one specific person. Pause this audio here.

Samuel then lists everything a king will take. The king would probably send his servants and soldiers to take these things from the Israelites. First, Samuel says a king will take the Israelites' sons and daughters and then make them serve the king. These sons and daughters would probably be at least young men and women. Samuel is probably talking about both these elders' children and their future descendants as well.

Samuel first talks about how a king will take the Israelites' sons for the king's army. The Israelites' sons will drive chariots, ride horses, run ahead of the king's chariot to protect the king, lead groups of soldiers, and make equipment for the soldiers. Other sons will have to prepare the king's land for planting food, then gather the food for the king. A king will also take the Israelites' daughters and have them make perfumes, food, and bread for the king.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when a leader of a group, like a head of a company or a leader in a community, decided what work people should do. Pay attention to the way that you explain that the leader chose what work the people would do. Pause this audio here.

Next, Samuel explains how a king will take the Israelites' possessions and use them as the king wants. A king will take the land that is best for growing food. The king will take fields and vineyards and olive groves. The Israelites would have spent time preparing their fields, and several years growing their grape vines and olive trees. A king will give this land to his officials and attendants as gifts or payment. A king will also take a portion, one tenth, of people's crops, of their grain and grapes. Again, the king will give these to his attendants and officials, who did not spend time growing these foods.

Then Samuel describes how a king will take the people and animals who serve the Israelites. A king will take the Israelites' servants, both men and women, along with their donkeys. Some versions say the king will also take the people's young men, while some say the king will take their cattle. The king is definitely taking the people's sons and male servants, and the king is also taking their animals. The king will take a tenth of the people's flocks, or groups of sheep and goats.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: As an activity, think of a dangerous activity or job. Take some time to think about the reasons that activity is dangerous or bad. Try to come up with a list of why the activity is dangerous or bad, and then share your lists with each other and pretend you are trying to convince the others not to do this activity. Afterwards, discuss the way you all arranged your lists and what methods you used to convince the others. Pause this audio here.

In the end, Samuel says, a king will take so much from the Israelites that the king will own even the Israelites. When that time comes, the Israelites will call out for help, for relief. But when the Israelites call out, Yahweh will not answer their call. The Israelites have chosen these kings who oppress them. The Israelites chose these kings instead of Yahweh to protect them. So the Israelites will have to deal with the results of their choice.

In the second scene, the Israelites respond to Samuel's warning. The Israelites say, "No!" The Israelites do not believe this will happen, so they do not listen to Samuel's warning. Again, the Israelites say that they want a king. The Israelites want a king because they want to be like other nations. Those nations' kings are always ready to fight when the people want to fight, unlike the judges that Yahweh chooses when Yahweh decides the people should fight. The people do not like waiting for Yahweh's guidance and choices.

In the third scene, when Samuel has listened to everything the people have to say, Samuel talks to Yahweh about the people's response. Now that Samuel has warned the people, Yahweh tells Samuel to begin the process of finding and appointing a king. So then Samuel tells the people to go back to their hometowns, and Samuel probably tells the people that Samuel will now go and choose a king.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 8:10–22 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has three scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel

  • Yahweh

  • The Israelite elders

  • The kings who will rule Israel

  • The Israelites' sons

  • The Israelites' daughters

  • The king's officials and attendants

  • And the Israelites' servants

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses. As Samuel tells the people what kings do, the actors can act out what Samuel describes.

Samuel spoke with the people who were asking for a king. Samuel explained to the people exactly what Yahweh had said. Samuel warned the people, "If you have a king, this is how the king will treat you: The king will take your sons and make them serve the king. The king will make some of your sons drive his chariots and others ride his horses in the king's army. Your sons will have to run in front of the king's chariots to honor and protect the king. The king will make some of your sons officers in charge of 50 or 1,000 soldiers. The king will make others prepare his fields and gather his harvests. Also, the king will appoint some of your sons to make weapons for his soldiers to use, and to make equipment for his chariots. The king will take many of your daughters too, and command them to make perfumes, to cook, and to bake for the king."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Israelite sons and daughters, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I do not want to do this job that the king is making me do! I would rather be doing other work, but I cannot leave. The king is powerful and will make us work; or

  • Because the king saw how good I am at my job, the king made me come work for him. I would rather work in my hometown. I am sad because I miss my family and friends; or

  • I am excited to live near the king and work for him, but I am also worried because I am not sure what my life will be like there.

Samuel continued speaking and said, "The king will take your best fields, vineyards, and orchards of olive trees. Then the king will give these things to the king's officials. The king will take a tenth of your grain and grapes and give it to his officers and servants. Also, the king will take some of your servants, both men and women, and make them do the king's work. The king will take your best cattle and donkeys for himself. Not only that, but the king will also take a tenth of your flocks of sheep and goats. So in the end, you yourselves will become slaves to your king. When all this happens, you will call out to Yahweh to free you from your king whom you chose. However, when you do, Yahweh will not do as you ask."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am worried for the people of Israel. The people do not understand how much their lives will change if they have a king. I hope the people will listen to what I am saying; or

  • I am sad that the people are rejecting Yahweh and his judges. The people keep doing this over and over again! or

  • I want the Israelites to understand how the kings will hurt not just these people, but also these people's children and descendants by taking away their belongings, land, and freedom!

But the Israelite people refused to pay attention to Samuel. The people replied, "No, we will not listen to you! We want a king who will rule over us. If we have a king, our nation will be like the other nations. We will have a king who will judge us and lead us into battle and fight for us."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Israel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I do not think Samuel is telling the truth. The other nations have kings, and those nations beat us in battle. So I think that nations with kings become stronger; or

  • We are the leaders of the tribes. We are wise and have experienced many things. I do not think Samuel knows more than all of us. Samuel has not lived with a king! And Samuel's last decision, to appoint his sons as judges, was bad! I trust my own judgment more; or

  • I am tired of waiting for Yahweh to send us a leader when it is time to fight. I want our leaders to always be ready to defend us or to attack if another group is weak! Then we can win new land and wealth, and then keep it!

When Samuel heard everything the people said, Samuel repeated it to Yahweh. Yahweh replied, "Appoint a king over them just as they have asked."

Samuel then told the Israelite people to go back to their hometowns because Samuel had agreed to their request.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I have given the people a choice, and even though they chose poorly, I will let the people have their own way. Like a parent who sees their children making the wrong choice, I feel sad for my people; or

  • Though Israel has rejected me, I will not abandon Israel, but things will change. The Israelites will turn to their human kings for help, but those kings will not be able to help the Israelites like I can.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 8:10–22 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Samuel repeats to the Israelites what Yahweh has said. Yahweh is God's proper name. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Yahweh as you used in previous passages.

Then Samuel warns the Israelites about how kings act. A king was someone who ruled over a city or territory. A king normally ruled for life and passed on his authority to one of the king's sons. For more information on king, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for king as you used in previous passages.

A king will take the Israelites' sons and appoint those sons to many roles. To appoint means to assign a job or role to someone and give that person authority to act in a certain way. Use the same word or phrase for appoint as you used in previous passages.

A king will make the Israelites' sons drive the king's chariots. Chariots were wagon-like vehicles with two wheels. Horses pulled the chariots, and two men, one driver and one warrior, rode the chariot into battle. The warrior would fight the enemy while standing in the chariot.

Stop here and look at a picture of a chariot again as a group, as needed. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for chariot. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

A king will take the people's daughters and make the women serve as perfumers. Perfumers mix spices and oils to make good-smelling scents and healing ointments.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for perfumers. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The king will take the Israelites' best vineyards and olive groves. A vineyard is a garden where people grow fruit called grapes on a tree called a grapevine. Olive groves were gardens where people grew fruit called olives on trees. If you planted these trees and grapevines from a seed, they would need to grow for several years before they grew olives or grapes. Both grapes and olives were important crops for the Israelites.

Stop here and look at a picture of a vineyard and an olive orchard again as a group, as needed. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for vineyard and olive grove. Look up vineyard in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The king will give this land to his officials and attendants. Some versions say "servants" instead of attendants, but these were probably assistants, trusted people who served the king in important jobs. Later, Samuel says that the king will take the Israelites' male and female servants and that eventually, the Israelites will become the king's slaves. A servant, or a slave, is a man or a woman who works for another person. People pay servants for their work, but people do not pay slaves. In the Bible, authors often used the same word for servant or slave. Most servants did not have a choice about serving the master's family, so these people were like slaves. The Israelites probably had servants that they paid, as well as slaves that they did not pay. However, in the end, the Israelites will definitely be their king's unpaid slaves.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for the king's attendants and for the Israelites' servants and slaves. Although these are all the same word in this story, they probably have slightly different meanings. You may want to use different words for the three. Look up servant in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The king will take a portion of the Israelites' flocks. A flock is a group of sheep or goats.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for flock. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Despite Samuel's warning, the people again say they want a king so that the Israelites can be like other nations. A nation is a group of people who belong together, who live in the same country, and who have the same ruler. For more information on nation, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for nation as you used in previous passages.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 9:1–14
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 9:1–14 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 9:1–14 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 9:1–14 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

A new character enters this story. Saul, a strong and tall man from a respected family, goes searching for his father's lost donkeys. When Saul is about to give up, his servant convinces Saul to ask a man of God for help. This man of God is Samuel, who is looking for a new king.

The section begins by introducing Saul's father, Kish. Kish is from the tribe of Benjamin and is a man of good standing, which means that Kish is wealthy or powerful and that other people respect him. Kish is the son of Abiel, Abiel is the son of Zeror, Zeror is the son of Bekorath, and Bekorath is the son of Aphiah. All of these people are also descendants of Benjamin.

Kish's son, Saul, is an impressive man. No other man in Israel is like Saul. Some versions say that Saul is a handsome young man. At that time, Saul had a son old enough to be a soldier. But compared with Kish, Saul is "a young man." Saul is strong, healthy, and is also tall. Saul is head and shoulders taller than anyone else, which means that no other man in Israel is taller than Saul's shoulders.

Stop here and do this activity as a group: Pretend you are introducing an important person, someone you respect, to the group. Explain this person's family line and the person's reputation or place in the community. Then discuss as a group the ways that you normally talk about a person's family and reputation when you are introducing a person. Pause this audio here.

Now Saul's family has a problem. Some of Kish's female donkeys have wandered off, as donkeys often do. Donkeys were important animals because they carried heavy loads and pulled the equipment people used for farming. So Kish asks Saul to go and look for the donkeys and to take a servant with Saul.

Stop here and look at a picture of a donkey as a group. Pause this audio here.

Saul and the servant search for several days as they travel through the tribe of Benjamin's territory and the hill country of Ephraim, which is nearby. It is not clear where Shalishah and Shaalim were, but they were probably regions in Ephraim. However, the donkeys are not in any of those areas.

Stop here and look at a map of the territory of Benjamin and Ephraim as a group. Pause this audio here.

Finally, when Saul and the servant reach the district or region of Zuph, Saul suggests that they stop searching. Saul and the servant have been traveling for about three days, and Saul does not want to worry his father. If Saul and the servant do not come back soon, Kish may worry that Saul is lost or hurt.

The servant suggests a different plan. The servant knows that in a nearby town is a man of God, or a man who serves God. People respected this man because everything this man said would happen did happen. This showed that God was with this man of God. The servant suggests going to the man of God and asking the man where to look for the donkeys.

Saul finds a problem with the servant's plan, though. Saul asks what he and the servant have to give to the man of God. It was normal at that time to give a gift to a man of God, or to anyone with whom you wished to have good relations. But Saul and his servant have eaten all the food in their sacks, and the men have no gift to give. Saul then asks the servant if there is anything they have to give as a gift.

The servant has a solution: he has a quarter of a shekel of silver. A shekel is not a coin, but a certain weight that people used to trade. This quarter shekel is about three grams, and would have been a week's payment for a working man. This is not a big gift, but it is an acceptable gift. The servant offers to give the silver to the man of God so that the man will tell Saul and the servant where to look for the donkeys.

Now the storyteller stops to explain one of the words Saul is about to say. In Saul's time, when people needed to ask for God's guidance, people would often say, "Let us go to the seer." A seer is a person who has a special relationship with God. God gives that person messages about the future to share with the people. The storyteller says that today, in the storyteller's time, people use the word "prophet" instead of "seer." A prophet also shares messages about the future that God gives.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, what are some words or phrases that your grandparents or other older people say that you would say differently? As an activity, discuss how you would explain to your grandparents the new way that people talk. Pause this audio here.

The story continues as Saul responds to the servant. Saul says that this is a good plan and that the men should go to the town where the man of God is. This town may be the man of God's hometown, or the man of God may just be visiting this place. This town was on a hill. Towns were often on hills where it was easier for people to defend the town.

As Saul and his servant are walking up the hill towards the town, the men meet some young women. These women are going down the hill to draw water or lift water up from a well or spring in a jar or bucket. Women would fetch water every day, and normally, the women went in the evening when it was cooler. Saul and his servant ask the women if the seer is here in the town.

The young women answer that the seer is here and that the two men should hurry to find the seer. The seer or man of God has just come to this town today because the people are presenting a sacrifice or offering at a high place. High places were places of worship, often on hills and sometimes with shrines or other buildings. While people did worship false gods at high places, this place is probably an official place to worship Yahweh, since the man of God is there.

Stop here and look at a picture of a high place as a group. Pause this audio here.

The young women say that Saul and his servant will easily be able to find the seer when the men enter the town. The seer is about to go to the high place to eat. When people offered an animal as a sacrifice, the people would sometimes offer some parts to burn and then cook and eat the rest. The people who are already at the high place will not eat until the seer comes. The seer must ask God to bless the sacrifice and the food before the guests at the sacrifice can eat. The women urge Saul and his servant to go now, and the women assure the men that the men will definitely find the seer.

So Saul and his servant continue walking up the hill towards the town. As the men enter the town, they can see Samuel, who is the man of God, walking towards them on his way to the high place.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 9:1–14 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has four scenes.

In the first scene: The storyteller introduces Saul's father, Kish, and his family line. Then the storyteller describes Saul.

In the second scene: Because some of Kish's donkeys wander off, Kish sends Saul and a servant to go and look for the donkeys. Saul and the servant search several regions but do not find the donkeys.

In the third scene: When Saul suggests that the men stop searching, the servant suggests asking a man of God for guidance. Saul says they do not have a gift to bring, but the servant says he has some silver to give as a gift. Saul agrees to go and meet the man of God.

In the fourth scene: As Saul and the servant approach the town, the men ask some young women if the seer is in the town. The young women say that the seer has just arrived for a sacrifice and that the two men should hurry. As Saul and the servant enter the town, Samuel, the man of God, comes towards the men.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Kish

  • Saul

  • The servant

  • The man of God, or seer, who is Samuel

  • The young women

  • And the people at the sacrifice

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

The last section ends when Samuel agrees to search for a king. Now, instead of describing Samuel's search, the story introduces another man, Saul, who is searching for something else. This new character's story is a bit of a surprise, which builds some suspense in the story. Eventually, Saul meets up with Samuel, and we see how the stories and the two men's searches connect.

The first scene introduces Saul and his family. Saul is the son of Kish, a wealthy man from the tribe of Benjamin, whom people respect. Kish is the son of Abiel, who is the son of Zeror, the son of Bekorath, the son of Aphiah. All these men were Benjamites as well. Saul is taller and looks more impressive and handsome than anyone else in Israel.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your language, what words or phrases would you use to describe a powerful man whom people respect? What words or phrases would you use to describe an impressive, tall man? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss how you will translate the list of Saul's ancestors. In your culture, what order do you list ancestors—from the oldest to the present or from the present back to the oldest? Pause this audio here.

The second scene introduces a problem: Kish's donkeys have wandered off. So Kish sends Saul and a servant to look for the donkeys. The two men go northwest into the tribe of Ephraim's territory and search in two areas. The men look in Shalishah, but the donkeys are not there. The men look in Shaalim, but the donkeys are not there. The men search in the territory of the tribe of Benjamin, but the donkeys are not there. For each place the men look, the storyteller repeats that the men cannot find the donkeys.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: As an activity, tell a story about a time when you lost something and searched in many different places for it. Pay attention to the way you show that this was a long and hard search. Pause this audio here.

In the third scene, Saul and the servant come to the region of Zuph. The men are probably back in Benjamite territory and close to a town. Saul suggests that the men stop looking for the donkeys. If the men do not go home soon, Saul says that his father will stop worrying about the donkeys and instead worry about Saul and the servant.

But the servant replies, "Look! We are near a town where a man of God is." People often used the title "man of God" for a prophet. The servant suggests that the men ask the man of God where the donkeys are. The storyteller does not reveal who the man of God is at this point. It is possible that Saul and the servant do not know the man of God's name. The audience, however, would quickly realize that this man of God is Samuel, and they would remember that Samuel is looking for a man to appoint as king. Maybe Saul, this impressive man, will be the king!

Stop here and do this activity as a group: Tell a story about a time when you met someone exciting in an unexpected way. Do not immediately explain who the person is as you tell your story. See if your listeners can guess who the person is before you tell them at the end of your story. Pause this audio here.

However, Saul points out another problem: The men do not have a gift to give the man of God. The servant again says, "Look!" The servant has a quarter shekel of silver that the men can give! Saul agrees that seeing the man of God is a good plan, so the men go towards the nearby town.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Both times when the servant speaks, the servant begins with a word that means, "Pay attention! I have something to say or show to you!" In your culture, what words or phrases do you use to get someone's attention when you want to talk about something or show something to that person? Pause this audio here.

In the third scene, Saul and the servant meet some young women coming out of the town. Towns were often on hills or high ground near a spring or well of water. It was the women's job to fill their jars and buckets with water for their families, and the women often went in the evening when it was cooler. In the original language, "young women" can mean young unmarried girls as well as young married women, so this was probably a group of women of several different ages.

Saul and his servant are walking up the hill of the town, not yet at the top, as some young women are walking down the hill. The men ask the young women if the seer is in the town. The storyteller explains that the word "seer" means the same thing as "prophet," which is the word that people would use in the storyteller's time.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Remember what you discussed about explaining new words in step two, and discuss how you will translate this explanation for the word "seer" in your translation. Discuss where you want to include this explanation. Pause this audio here.

The young women repeat themselves and sound disorganized. Probably several young women all talked at once, each one giving part of the answer. The young women do not say Samuel's name. Instead, the women say that "he," the seer, is ahead of Saul and the servant. The young women probably passed Samuel as they were coming out of town, then reached Saul first because they were moving faster than Samuel. The young women say that the seer arrived today to bless the sacrifice at the high place. The high place was probably on another hill outside of the town. People are already waiting for the seer at the high place. When people offered an animal as a sacrifice, they would sometimes offer some parts for the priest to burn and eat the rest. Once the seer blesses the food, the people can then eat it. The young women tell Saul to hurry because the seer is about to walk outside the town to the high place to bless the sacrifice. Saul and his servant should be able to find Samuel easily when they enter the town.

Stop here and do this activity as a group: Have one person ask the group a question about how to do something. Then have everyone in the group give an answer or part of the answer. Have the first person repeat or explain the answers that the group has said. Pay attention to the ways that this person makes the group's answer more connected, or shows that several people were talking. Pause this audio here.

So Saul and the servant walk to the town at the top of the hill. The town probably had a wall around it with at least one gate. The gateway or entrance to a town was a place where people commonly met. As Saul and the servant enter the town, the men meet Samuel, who is walking out of the town at the same place.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 9:1–14 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has four scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Kish

  • Saul

  • The servant

  • The man of God, or seer, who is Samuel

  • The young women

  • And the people at the sacrifice

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

There was a man whose name was Kish, who was a member of the tribe of Benjamin. Kish was wealthy and important. Kish was the son of Abiel, who was the son of Zeror, who was the son of Bekorath. These men were all descendants of Aphiah, whose ancestor was Benjamin. Kish had a son named Saul. Saul was an impressive young man who looked more handsome than all the other Israelites. No other Israelite was taller than Saul's shoulder.

Saul's father, Kish, had some donkeys, but one day some of the donkeys wandered off. So Kish said to his son, Saul, "Go search for the donkeys. One of our servants can go with you."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Kish, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am upset that some of our donkeys are gone. These are useful animals, and if we do not find the donkeys, it will take time and money to replace them; or

  • I trust my son Saul. I know Saul is capable of searching for these animals. I think Saul will be the best person to send; or

  • I care for my son and want him to have some help. Since I am a wealthy man, I can send a servant with Saul. The servant can help Saul look and help with the journey. The servant can also help lead the donkeys back when the men find the donkeys.

So Saul and the servant left to look for the donkeys. First, Saul and the servant searched through the hilly part of Ephraim. The men searched in the area around Shalishah, but they could not find the donkeys. The men searched in the land of Shaalim, but they did not find the donkeys there either. Then the men traveled through the land of Benjamin, but they did not find the donkeys there.

When the men arrived at the region of Zuph, Saul said to his servant, "We must return home now, or my father will start worrying about us instead of the donkeys."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am tired of searching. We have been responsible and looked in all the places the donkeys might have gone, but we cannot look forever. I need to make a decision about when to go home; or

  • I know my father cares about the donkeys, but I also know he cares about me, his son, and the people who work for him, like this servant. I do not want to cause my father to worry by being gone for so long; or

  • I am surprised that we have not been able to find the donkeys! The donkeys must have run far and fast!

But the servant replied, "Listen. A man of God lives in this nearby town. The people honor this man greatly because when he says something will happen, it happens. It might be good if we went to see the man of God. Perhaps the man can tell us where we can find the donkeys."

Saul said to his servant, "But what can we give this man if we go to see him? We have eaten all our food, so our sacks are empty. We have no suitable present to give to the man of God. Do we have anything at all?"

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I respect this servant, so I will listen to his idea. My father trusts this servant, since he sent the servant with me. The servant has also shown that he is a good servant by searching with me for days; or

  • It would be rude to show up without a gift, and I do not want to dishonor a man of God, especially one who people respect so much; or

  • I do want to go and see the man of God. It would be helpful to get some advice, since we have not found the donkeys! Maybe the servant remembers some item we have that we can give as a gift.

The servant replied to Saul again: "Look, I have here a small piece of silver. I can give that to the man of God. Then the man will tell us where to find the donkeys."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the servant, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I want to honor my master and his son by doing everything I can to help find the donkeys! I will even give up this silver to help! or

  • I am also tired of searching for the donkeys and want to see if there is a better or smarter way for us to take; or

  • I remember hearing about this man of God and how God is with him. Everything this man says will happen actually happens! I am excited to meet this man of God!

In Saul's time, when someone wanted to ask God something, the person used to say, "Let us go and ask the seer." People used to say "seer," but people in our time would use the word "prophet" instead.

Saul said to his servant, "All right then. We will go there now."

So Saul and the servant started on their way to the town where the man of God was. As the men went up the hill towards the town, they met some young women who were just leaving the town. These young women were going to the well to get some water. The men asked the young women, "Is the seer in the town here?"

The young women answered, "Yes, he is. The seer is in the town ahead of you. Hurry up and go into the town. The seer arrived in our town today in order to lead the people as they offer their sacrifice at the high place. When you enter the town, you will see the seer, since he has not yet left the town to go up to the high place to eat the sacrificial meal. The people at the high place are waiting for the seer there, and they will not begin to eat until he comes and first prays over the sacrifice. Then the guests will eat. So if you want to see the seer, you need to go now."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the young women, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are excited to have a man of God in our town. Everyone has been talking about this man, so we know exactly why he is here and what he is doing; or

  • These two men are asking in a polite way, so we will answer. We will let the men know what is happening in town today and assure them they can find the seer.

So Saul and his servant went up to the town. As they entered the town, the men saw Samuel coming toward them on his way to the high place.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 9:1–14 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Kish is a Benjamite, which means he is a member of the tribe of Benjamin. Use the same word for Benjamite as you have used in previous passages.

Saul is so impressive that there is no one like Saul in Israel. Israel is the name of the country where the Israelites lived. For more information on Israel, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Israel as you used in previous passages.

Kish tells Saul to go look for the lost donkeys and to take a servant with Saul. A servant is a man or a woman who works for another person. A servant can work in their master's house or fields. For more information on servant, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for servant as you used in previous passages.

Donkeys were important animals that carried heavy loads and pulled farming equipment. These donkeys were female donkeys. Use the same word for female donkeys as you have used in previous passages.

The servant says he has a quarter shekel of silver to give to the man of God. A shekel is a unit of measurement for weight. One shekel is about 11.4 grams, so a quarter shekel would be about 3 grams. Israelites used weights, or shekels of precious metal, for money before they used coins.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for shekel. Look up shekel in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

"Man of God" is another title for a prophet or seer. A prophet is a person who gives messages from God to the people. This message can be an instruction from God about something that needs to be done or about something that is going to happen in the future. A seer means someone who can see visions or see what other people cannot see. A prophet is a seer because he can see, or understand, God more clearly than other people and knows things that other people cannot know. This happens because God gives the prophet this understanding. People also called a prophet a "man of God" because the prophet serves God. This title uses the general word for God, not God's personal name, Yahweh. In Saul's time, people would use the word "seer," while people in the storyteller's time would use the word "prophet."

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for man of God, prophet, and seer. Look up prophet and God in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The seer, Samuel, is in the town to lead the people as they offer a sacrifice. A sacrifice is a gift to God. People gave sacrifices to thank God for something, worship God, confirm their relationship with God, or ask forgiveness for something they had done wrong. For some sacrifices, a priest would kill an animal and then burn the animal. Sometimes, the priest would burn certain parts of the animal, and then the people would cook and eat the rest of the animal. For more information on sacrifice, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for sacrifice as you used in previous passages.

The people are waiting for Samuel at the high place. A high place was a place of worship, sacrifice, and prayer. People would often make these high places on a hill or higher area of land, sometimes with shrines or other buildings or just an altar outside. Sometimes, these were good or official places to worship God, but usually, people worshiped idols there. This high place was probably an official or good place for worshiping God.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for high place. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The people are waiting for Samuel to bless the sacrifice. When people bless something, like food, this means that the people are thanking God for that thing. For more information on bless, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for bless as you used in previous passages.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
