title: 1 Samuel 9:15–27
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 9:15–27 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 9:15–27 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 9:15–27 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

Yahweh promises to send a man for Samuel to anoint as king. Then Yahweh reveals that this man is Saul. Though the people want to replace Yahweh, Yahweh is still in charge, and Yahweh still chooses the new king. When Samuel and Saul meet, Samuel invites Saul to the sacrifice meal and speaks of how important Saul is to Israel. The next morning, as Saul is about to leave, Samuel says that Samuel has a message from God to share with Saul.

The day before Saul came to the town in the region of Zuph, Yahweh spoke privately and directly to Samuel. Yahweh revealed that he would send a man to Samuel. This man would be from the land or tribe of Benjamin. Yahweh says to anoint this man as ruler over Israel. To anoint means to pour oil over someone's head to show that God has set that person aside for a certain task. Earlier, the people had asked for a king, a word which in the original language meant head ruler. But Yahweh tells Samuel to anoint this man as the leader Yahweh has chosen, perhaps like a military commander.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Discuss the words you have in your language for various leaders or rulers. What words do you use for a leader who leads everyone else? What words or phrases do you use for someone who is the second most important or powerful, who leads almost everyone, but still follows someone's instructions? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh says that this leader will save the Israelites from the hand of the Philistines. People often used the word "hand" to mean "power." This leader will save the Israelites from the Philistines, who have been attacking the Israelites. Yahweh is sending this leader because Yahweh can see the danger the Israelites are in and can hear the Israelites when they pray and call out for help.

So when Saul arrives in town and Samuel sees Saul, Yahweh again speaks to Samuel privately. No one except Samuel hears what Yahweh says. Yahweh says that this is the man Yahweh promised yesterday to send. This man, Saul, will govern the people. While before, the Israelite people each did what they thought was right, Saul will now watch over the people and make them follow God's laws.

Saul walks up to Samuel at the entrance or gateway of the town. Then Saul asks Samuel a question. Saul does not know that Samuel is the man of God Saul is looking for, so Saul asks Samuel where the seer is staying. This town could be the town Samuel lives in, or it could be a town Samuel often visits, with a house Samuel often stays at.

Samuel responds that he is the seer. Samuel invites Saul to a meal and offers to give Saul the help Saul needs. God has revealed to Samuel that Saul has a question or problem with which he needs help. Samuel promises to tell Saul later what is in his heart, which means Samuel will explain the things Saul is thinking or wondering about.

Samuel then shows that he really does hear from God. Samuel does this by talking about the missing donkeys before Saul even mentions them. Samuel reassures Saul that someone has found the donkeys, so Saul does not have to look for the donkeys any longer. Saul has time to eat and talk with Samuel.

Samuel then says that all of Israel hopes for Saul and his family. The people have been wanting and waiting for a king. Samuel is suggesting that Saul will be this king that Israel longs for.

Saul is surprised and says that he does not understand how this can be. Saul responds with questions, but Saul is not expecting Samuel to answer these questions. Instead, Saul asks these questions to emphasize that Saul is not from one of the larger or more important tribes of Israel. Saul also says that he comes from the least important family in the tribe of Benjamin. Though Saul's father is a respected person, Saul's humble answer is polite. Although Saul probably did not fully understand what Samuel had said to him, Saul may have understood that Samuel was predicting great things for Saul. However, Saul does not understand how these great things will happen.

However, Samuel, who knows that Saul is God's choice, does not respond to Saul's questions at the time. Instead, Samuel leads Saul and Saul's servant to the high place and into a hall, or a large room where people eat. About 30 guests are already sitting in this room. Samuel shows how important Saul is by giving Saul and Saul's servant the most honorable seats in the room.

Earlier, Samuel had told the cook to set aside a thigh, or the leg of the animal, and now Samuel asks the cook to bring this thigh out. So the cook brings out the thigh, along with the fat on the thigh. This is a very good piece of meat on the animal! The cook gives the thigh to Saul, and Samuel tells Saul to eat it. Samuel already planned to save this piece of meat for Saul when Samuel was inviting the other guests. Samuel did this even before he invited Saul! So Saul ate with Samuel that evening.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Think about a time when you were hosting or helping at a celebration meal, such as a wedding, where there were guests that you wanted to honor. How did you show that those guests were important? What did you do for those guests? Where did those guests sit? What food did you give those guests? Pause this audio here.

After the feast, everyone comes down from the high place and returns to the town. Then Samuel takes Saul up on the roof of Samuel's house. Since the roofs of the houses in Israel were flat, the roof was a good place to talk privately. People also used roofs as a place for sleeping since it was cooler outside on the roof with the breeze. Some versions say that Samuel talks with Saul on the roof. Some say that Samuel makes a bed for Saul on the roof. Both of these things probably happen.

Stop here and look at a picture of a house with a flat roof as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: When you have guests stay the night at your house, where do you give the guests a space to sleep? Why do you give the guests this space? Pause this audio here.

When the sun comes up the next morning, Samuel says that when Saul is ready to go, Samuel will walk with Saul for a little way on Saul's journey. This was the normal, polite behavior of a host to a guest.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What do you do to say goodbye when a guest leaves your house? Why do you do this? What are some things that many people in your culture do, and which are ones that just you do? Pause this audio here.

So Saul gets ready and starts to walk to the edge of the town, along with his servant and Samuel. While they are still in the town, Samuel tells Saul to instruct Saul's servant to keep walking ahead of them. While the servant continues walking, Samuel stops Saul so that Samuel can privately tell Saul a message from God.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 9:15–27 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has five scenes.

In the first scene: Yahweh promises that tomorrow, Yahweh will send a man for Samuel to anoint as ruler over Israel. Yahweh chooses this man to save the people from the Philistines because Yahweh heard the Israelites' cries for help.

In the second scene: When Samuel sees Saul the next day, Yahweh says that this is the man Yahweh said he would send.

In the third scene: Saul asks Samuel where the seer is staying. Samuel replies that he is the seer and invites Saul to eat with Samuel. Samuel assures Saul about the donkeys and hints at something great for Saul's future. Saul politely responds that he does not understand why Samuel says this to Saul.

In the fourth scene: Samuel and Saul go to the high place, and Samuel gives Saul and Saul's servant the best seats. Samuel also tells the cook to give Saul the best piece of meat. The men eat together, talk together, and then Saul spends the night at Samuel's house.

In the fifth scene: In the morning, Samuel walks with Saul and Saul's servant to the edge of the town. Samuel tells Saul to instruct the servant to keep on going. While the servant continues walking, Samuel stops with Saul to tell Saul a message from God.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Yahweh

  • Samuel

  • Saul

  • The Philistines

  • The servant

  • The guests at the feast

  • And the cook

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

After showing how Samuel and Saul's stories connect, the storyteller now explains something that had happened the day before. The first scene happens the day before Saul enters the town. This scene shows how Yahweh has planned Samuel and Saul's meeting. Yahweh speaks to Samuel privately and says that Yahweh has heard the Israelites when they asked for help. Yahweh has seen the way the Philistines, the Israelites' enemies, are attacking and hurting the Israelites. So Yahweh has chosen a man to rule over Israel and save them from the Philistines. Yahweh will send this man to Samuel at the same time tomorrow. Samuel should anoint this man, or pour oil on this man's head, to show that the man will be Israel's ruler.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when someone told you how something would happen, then later it happened just like the person said it would. Tell the story twice, and each time, pick a different point in the story to explain the time that the other person told you about the event. Discuss what effect the different versions have on the listeners, even though they are still hearing the same story. Pause this audio here.

The second scene starts the next day, as Saul is entering the town with his servant. The town might have had a wall around it with a gate through which people came and went. When Samuel, who is standing in the gate and is about to walk out of the town, sees Saul, Yahweh speaks again. No one except Samuel hears what Yahweh says. Yahweh says that Saul is the man that Yahweh talked about yesterday. This man, Saul, will govern the Israelites.

In the third scene, Saul walks towards Samuel, who is standing "in the gate" or in the entrance part of the town. Saul asks Samuel where the seer's house is. Saul had never met Samuel and did not know Samuel was the seer Saul was looking for. Samuel answers that Samuel is the seer, so Saul does not have to look anywhere else. Samuel tells Saul to go ahead of Samuel to the high place, or the place of worship outside of town. In that time, letting another person walk in front of you could show that you respected or honored that person.

Samuel tells Saul that Saul should eat with Samuel, and then on the morning of the next day, Samuel will tell Saul what is in Saul's heart, or explain anything that is confusing or important to Saul.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your language, how would you describe the things a person is thinking and wondering about—things that are important to the person and that they think about often or over a long time? Pause this audio here.

Samuel says that someone has found the missing donkeys, so Saul does not have to keep searching. Samuel then hints that great things will happen to Saul, saying that all the people of Israel hope for Saul and his family to help or lead the people.

Saul politely replies that he does not understand how this can be. Saul humbly says that he is not important because Saul is not from one of the larger or more important tribes or families of Israel.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, what is the polite way to respond when someone compliments you? How do you respond when someone says that good or important things will happen to you? Pause this audio here.

In the fourth scene, Samuel brings Saul and Saul's servant to the high place, or place of worship. This high place would be on a hill outside the town. When people sacrificed animals, the people sometimes had to eat some of the meat near the place of sacrifice. So these places of worship often had a hall or large room nearby where many people could sit and eat. There were 30 people or guests already sitting in this hall. Samuel gives Saul and Saul's servant the best seats in the room.

It is not clear if the sacrifice happened after Samuel and Saul arrived in the hall or before Saul even arrived in town. But at some point after the sacrifice, the cook started cooking the meat, and Samuel asked the cook to save one particular piece of meat for a special guest.

Now, the cook and anyone who helped the cook were probably bringing out the food to the guests. Samuel tells the cook to bring out the special piece of meat. We are not sure what kind of animal this meat was from. This was the thigh of an animal, which was a very good piece of meat. This is probably a cooked piece of meat, since Samuel then tells Saul to eat this meat that they have saved for Saul. Samuel says that he planned to save this piece for Saul before the sacrifice, when Samuel was inviting the other guests. So Saul eats with Samuel and the other guests.

Stop here and do this activity as a group: Pretend you are having the other people in the group over for a meal, and you made some very good food for each person. Describe how you planned for and prepared this food for the people before they arrived. Pause this audio here.

Saul also stays the night at a house with Samuel. This could be Samuel's house, or the house Samuel stays at when he is in this town. Samuel may have prepared a bed of soft things, like a wool mattress and blankets, on a mat or light wooden frame for Saul on the flat roof of the house. Samuel and Saul probably talk some before Saul goes to sleep.

Scene five begins the next morning, when the sun comes up and everyone is waking up. Samuel, who is on the ground or in the house, calls up to Saul, who is on the roof. Saul should get ready, and Samuel will then walk with Saul for a little while to send Saul on his way. So Saul gets ready to travel again and comes down from the roof. Saul and his servant then walk towards the edge of town with Samuel. Before the men reach the edge of town or the town walls, Samuel tells Saul to instruct his servant to keep walking. Saul does, and the servant keeps walking while Samuel and Saul stop. Samuel will now give Saul a message from God.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 9:15–27 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has five scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Yahweh

  • Samuel

  • Saul

  • The Philistines

  • The servant

  • The guests at the feast

  • And the cook

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

The day before Saul arrived, Yahweh had spoken to Samuel and said, "Tomorrow, about the time that it is now, I will send a man to you from the territory of Benjamin. Pour oil on this man's head to show that I have chosen him to be the leader of my people, Israel. This man will rescue my people from the power of the Philistines. I have seen how my people are suffering, and I have heard how they are crying out for help."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • My people want to replace me with another ruler, but I know that a human king will not be as good or powerful as me. While this makes me sad, I am patient with my people, and I will help them find a human ruler. This ruler will not be more powerful than me, though; or

  • I care about my people, and it makes me sad to see other nations attacking them. I can see that my people need help, and I will help them, even though they have not served me like they should; or

  • It is an important task to choose a new king for the people. I will help Samuel and bring a man to him, so that Samuel does not have to travel and search for a long time.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am always amazed when Yahweh, my God, speaks directly to me. What an honor it is to hear his voice and serve him! or

  • I am so thankful that Yahweh is helping me choose a new king. I know all the people will have different opinions on who would be the best king, so I am glad that Yahweh is guiding me to the right person; or

  • I wonder what this man will be like. I wonder if this man will be a soldier, since he will make the Philistines stop attacking us. I really do hope this man will lead the Israelites well.

When Samuel saw Saul, Yahweh said to Samuel, "This is the man I told you about. This man will rule over my people."

There at the gateway, Saul approached Samuel and asked, "Can you tell me where the seer lives?"

Samuel replied, "I am the seer. Go ahead of me to the hill where the sacrifices are made, for today you will both eat with me. Tomorrow morning, I will answer all your questions and then send you home. Do not be concerned about your donkeys that wandered off three days ago. Your father has got the donkeys back. The people of Israel look to you and your father's family, Saul, hoping that you will lead them."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Every time Yahweh says he will do something, he does it! And every time I am amazed by the way Yahweh works and allows me to be a part of his work; or

  • Yahweh has also shown me that this man is worried about several things, like the missing donkeys. I know Yahweh will give me the words to speak to comfort and give good advice to this man; or

  • I am glad I get the chance to talk to this man who will be our new ruler. I can see what this man is like and maybe give him some advice from the time I have spent leading Israel.

Saul answered Samuel, "But I am only a member of the tribe of Benjamin. Our tribe is the smallest of all the tribes in Israel. And my family is the least important of all the families in the tribe of Benjamin. I am surprised that you are saying this to me."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am surprised that the first man I talked to was the seer! I am also surprised that the seer already knew about the missing donkeys! This man must really serve God, since he knows this! or

  • I am also surprised and confused by what the seer has said to me. Why would the Israelites want me to lead them? People respect my father and his family, but just the people who know us, not all of the Israelites! or

  • I am responding in a humble way because I want to be polite, but I am honored that the seer has said this to me. I also feel a little excited. Maybe the seer means that I will do important things for my people!

When the men had climbed the hill to the place of worship, Samuel took Saul and Saul's servant into a large room where about 30 guests were sitting. Samuel gave Saul and Saul's servant the most honorable seats of all.

Samuel said to the cook, "Bring here the piece of meat I told you to set aside."

So the cook brought the thigh covered with fat and put it in front of Saul. Samuel said, "Here, we put this aside for you. Go ahead and eat it. I was saving it for you even before I invited these others."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the guests, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We all respect Samuel and know how important he is, because Samuel serves God. If Samuel is giving this other man the most honorable seat, this man must be very important! or

  • It looks like Samuel might have set up this sacrifice and meal in order to celebrate and thank God for this man. I wonder who this man is and what he will do!

So Saul and Samuel feasted together that evening. After the feast, everyone came down from the hill and returned to the town. Then Samuel took Saul up on the roof of Samuel's house, and they talked together there. The men got up as the sun was rising, and Samuel called up to Saul, who was on the roof, "Come on, let us go. I will send you on your way."

Saul got ready, and he and Samuel went out of the house together. As they were approaching the edge of the town, Samuel said to Saul, "Tell your servant to go on in front of us." Saul did so, and the servant went on ahead.

Then Samuel said to Saul, "Stay here for a while so that I can tell you the message that God has told me to tell you."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the servant, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Many amazing things have happened to me and my master, Saul. The seer, whom everyone respects, has honored us, eaten with us, and even let us stay with him! or

  • I wonder what Samuel and Saul are talking about while I walk ahead. It must be something very important; or

  • I am glad that Samuel has told us that someone else has found the donkeys. Now we can stop searching and return home!

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 9:15–27 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Before Saul arrives in town, Yahweh speaks to Samuel. Yahweh is God's proper name. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Yahweh as you used in previous passages.

Yahweh tells Samuel to anoint the man Yahweh is sending. To anoint someone means to pour sweet-smelling oil over someone. Before Yahweh gave someone a special task, Yahweh would instruct someone else to pour oil over that person's head to show that Yahweh had set this person apart for a special purpose. For more information on anoint, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for anoint as you used in previous passages.

Yahweh says this man will be a ruler, or chosen leader. In the original language, this is not the same word as king, which is what the Israelites asked for. This means that Yahweh will still be the highest ruler, and this man will be second to Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for ruler. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

This chosen leader will rule over Yahweh's people, Israel. Sometimes the word Israel refers to all the descendants of Jacob together. It then means the same as Israelites or "people of Israel." For more information on Israel, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Israel as you used in previous passages.

Saul asks Samuel where the seer lives. A seer is someone who can see visions or see what other people cannot see. People also call these people prophets. For more information on seer, refer to prophet in the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for seer as you used in previous passages.

Saul tells Samuel that Saul is from the least important clan, or family group, in the tribe of Benjamin. A clan is a large group of people made up of many families. A clan is smaller than an entire tribe, but larger than one household.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for clan. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Samuel tells Saul to go up to the high place. A high place was a place of worship, sacrifice, and prayer. People would often make these high places on a hill or higher area of land, sometimes with shrines or other buildings, like a big room where people would eat. This high place was probably an official or good place for worshiping God. Use the same word or phrase for high place as you used in previous passages.

Samuel gives Saul and Saul's servant the best or most honorable seats. A servant is a man or a woman who works for another person. A servant can work in their master's house or fields. For more information on servant, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for servant as you used in previous passages.

When Saul is leaving town, Samuel says he has a word or message from God to give to Saul. This is the more general word for God, not God's personal name, Yahweh. For more information on word and God, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same words or phrases for word and God as you used in previous passages.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 10:1–16
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 10:1–16 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 10:1–16 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 10:1–16 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

Samuel anoints Saul because Yahweh has chosen Saul to rule over Israel. Samuel describes three events that will happen to Saul. These events are signs that God is with Saul. Samuel tells Saul that when they meet up again, Samuel will give more instructions. Saul travels home and everything happens as Samuel said it would, but Saul does not tell anyone what Samuel has told Saul about being Israel's ruler.

After Saul's servant walks on ahead of Samuel and Saul, Samuel tells Saul Yahweh's message: Yahweh has chosen Saul to rule over Israel. To show this, Samuel anoints Saul by pouring a little oil out of a flask, or small clay jar, over Saul's head.

Stop here and look at a picture of a clay jar as a group. Pause this audio here.

Samuel kisses Saul, probably on the cheek, as a sign of affection or respect. Samuel says that Yahweh is anointing or choosing Saul as ruler over Yahweh's inheritance. An inheritance is something that belongs to someone by right. Both the land and the people of Israel belong to Yahweh, who has chosen Saul to rule over them. Samuel phrases his statement like a question to emphasize that it is definitely Yahweh who chooses.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, what are some actions that you do to show respect to someone, like an elder or a leader? Discuss kissing in your culture. When is it acceptable or polite to kiss? Which people do it and with whom? Pause this audio here.

Some versions say a few more things after Samuel says that Yahweh has chosen Saul. In these extra statements, Samuel says that Saul will rule over Yahweh's people and save the people from the hand or power of their enemies. Then Samuel says, "Here are the things that will show that Yahweh has chosen you to be the ruler of his people." These statements repeat or emphasize information that we already know. If the translation you are listening to includes these extra sentences, you may keep them.

Samuel then describes three events that will happen. First, when Saul continues to travel, Saul will meet two men by Rachel's tomb or burial place, which is at Zelzah, on the border of the tribe of Benjamin's land. Rachel was the wife of Jacob, whose name is also Israel. Jacob and Rachel were the Israelites' ancestors. These two men near the tomb will tell Saul that someone has found the missing donkeys and returned them to Kish. Since Saul has not returned home yet, Kish is now worried about Saul. Kish is wondering what Kish should do to find his son.

When Saul travels on to the big tree at Tabor, the second event will happen. This big tree may be a terebinth tree. Trees were often landmarks, meeting places, and sacred places.

Stop here and look at a picture of a terebinth tree as a group. Pause this audio here.

Saul will see three men who are going to the town of Bethel to worship God. Bethel was an important holy place and for many years had an altar for sacrifice. These men will be carrying three young goats, three loaves of bread, and an animal skin or leather pouch full of wine, all of which may have been gifts for God. These men will greet Saul and offer to give Saul two loaves of bread. Saul should accept the bread from these men.

The third event will happen when Saul is approaching the town or hill that people call Gibeah of God. This town or hill was near a Philistine outpost, which is a camp of soldiers. As Saul is walking towards Gibeah, a group of prophets and musicians will be coming from the high place, or place of worship. The musicians will be playing lyres, which are string instruments, and timbrels, which are small hand drums that people made out of animal skins. The musicians will also be playing flutes, also called pipes, and harps, another string instrument with thicker strings and a louder sound than the lyre.

Stop here and look at pictures of a lyre, timbrel, pipes, and harp as a group. Discuss what instruments you have in your culture that are similar to these. What are some times when musicians play instruments in a procession, or as they walk in front of people? Why do the musicians do this? Pause this audio here.

The prophets will be prophesying. These prophets were a little different than Samuel, who told people instructions and messages from God. These prophets would follow a certain ritual, like listening to someone play a musical instrument while the prophets began to praise and worship Yahweh and to speak words that Yahweh's Spirit gave to the prophets.

When Saul meets these prophets, the Spirit of Yahweh will suddenly take control of Saul, and Saul will also prophesy. Yahweh's Spirit will change Saul into a different person, or a different sort of man, and give Saul new abilities for his new role as Israel's leader.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, how would you describe what prophets or seers do? What are the different kinds of prophets in your culture? How do other people react to prophets? Pause this audio here.

Once all these events or signs happen, Saul should do whatever his hand finds to do. Samuel is urging Saul to act confidently and do what Saul thinks is right because God will be with Saul. This means that God protects Saul and gives Saul success.

Samuel then instructs Saul to eventually meet Samuel at the town of Gilgal. Samuel promises to come there to sacrifice burnt offerings and fellowship offerings. Burnt offerings were gifts of animals that people burned on an altar to give to God. Fellowship or peace offerings were gifts people gave to maintain a good relationship with God. However, when Saul arrives at Gilgal, he will have to wait seven days for Samuel to arrive. When Samuel comes, Samuel will sacrifice the offerings and tell Saul what to do.

When Samuel finishes speaking and Saul turns to leave, God changes Saul's heart. In the original language, people used the word "heart" to describe the deepest part of a person, where people thought, felt, and understood things. God changes the way Saul thinks, giving Saul a new understanding.

Then, as Saul travels, all the signs happen just as Samuel said they would. The third sign makes some people at Gibeah, Saul's home, surprised. When Saul meets the prophets and God's Spirit takes control of Saul, people who know Saul see him prophesying and are amazed. The people ask each other what has happened to Saul, the son of Kish. The people ask, "Is Saul also among the prophets?" and wonder if Saul is also a prophet now. One man asks who the prophets' father is. Father was another name for a leader, and groups of prophets often had a leader. This man could be asking who the head prophet is who allows Saul to prophesy with this group.

The saying, "Is Saul also among the prophets?" became a proverb or a famous saying. Many people used this proverb in the time of the storyteller, so the storyteller did not need to explain the proverb. However, the proverb is not as clear to us. People probably said this proverb to express surprise when a person did something they had never done before that people did not expect.

When Saul stops prophesying, Saul goes to the high place or place of worship, where he speaks with his uncle. Saul's uncle asks where Saul and Saul's servant have been. Saul answers that they were looking for the donkeys, and that when the men could not find the animals, they went to ask Samuel for help. Saul's uncle wants to know what Samuel said, but Saul does not tell his uncle everything. Saul replies that Samuel told them that someone had found the donkeys, but Saul does not mention anything about how Yahweh has chosen Saul to be the ruler or king of Israel.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 10:1–16 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has three scenes.

In the first scene: Samuel anoints Saul and describes three events or signs that Saul will see. Saul will meet men who will tell Saul about the missing donkeys. Saul will meet men who will give him two loaves of bread. Finally, Saul will meet a group of prophets, and Yahweh's Spirit will cause Saul to join the prophets as they prophesy. Samuel finishes by instructing Saul to eventually meet Samuel at Gilgal.

In the second scene: When Saul leaves Samuel, God changes Saul's heart. All three signs happen. When Saul joins the prophets, the people who know Saul are surprised and ask if he is one of the prophets now.

In the third scene: When Saul stops prophesying, Saul goes up to a high place where he meets his uncle. Saul's uncle asks where Saul and the servant have been. Saul tells his uncle that they went to Samuel and that Samuel told the men what happened to the donkeys.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel

  • Saul

  • Yahweh

  • The two men, who know what happened to the donkeys

  • Kish, Saul's father

  • The three men with the goats, bread, and wine

  • The group of prophets and musicians

  • The people who know Saul

  • The servant

  • And Saul's uncle

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In the last section, Saul, Saul's servant, and Samuel were walking towards the edge of the town. Saul sent the servant ahead so that Samuel could tell Saul a message from God in private. God has spoken to Samuel and told him to anoint Saul. God has also revealed certain events to Samuel that will show that God will help and protect Saul. This section has the general title for God more often than Yahweh, so pay attention to when the storyteller uses each word.

Now, in this first scene, Samuel and Saul are standing in the town, probably away from other people, so that no one will hear the message or see Samuel anoint Saul. Samuel brings out a flask or small jar from a bag he was carrying or from a pocket in his clothes. This was probably a clay jar, and the oil was probably olive oil. Samuel pours a little of the oil on Saul's head to anoint Saul. Then Samuel kisses Saul, probably on the cheek, as a sign of affection and honor. Samuel then speaks the message from God. Samuel explains that Yahweh has chosen Saul to be the ruler of Israel. When Samuel anoints Saul, Samuel is doing it as Yahweh's representative, so Yahweh is anointing Saul to be the ruler. Remember, Samuel uses the word for leader instead of king when he describes what Saul will be.

Then Samuel describes three things that God has said will happen to Saul. These events will be signs or proof that God is with Saul. First, after Saul leaves Samuel and begins to travel, Saul will come to the place where people buried Rachel. Samuel says that this place is at Zelzah near the border of the land of Benjamin. It is not clear where Zelzah or Rachel's burial place is, though there is a traditional location for Rachel's tomb. This and the other locations Samuel mentions were probably on the main or normal route between Saul's home and the town Saul is in now.

Stop here and look at a map of central Israel as a group. Find the border of Benjamin on the map. Pause this audio here.

When Saul is near the burial place, Saul will see two men. These two men probably knew Saul and Saul's father and might have been looking for Saul. These two men will tell Saul what happened to the donkeys. The men will also say that Saul's father is worried about Saul, since Saul has not returned home yet.

Saul will continue to travel, and when he reaches the big tree at Tabor, Saul will see another sign. Saul will see and talk to three men who are going to Bethel to worship God. It is not clear where the big tree at Tabor is, but it is on the way to Bethel.

Stop here and look at a map of central Israel as a group. Find Bethel on the map. Pause this audio here.

One of the men will be carrying three young goats. The second man will be carrying three round loaves of bread. The third man will be carrying a skin, or a leather pouch full of wine. The three men will greet Saul and ask if Saul wants some bread to eat. The men will offer to give Saul two loaves, probably one loaf each for Saul and Saul's servant. Samuel tells Saul to accept the bread.

The third sign will happen as Saul approaches Gibeah of God. This could be referring to the high place around Gibeah, where people worship God, or to the town of Gibeah, which is probably the same Gibeah as Saul's hometown. Nearby the town is the Philistine outpost. The Philistines were Israel's enemies and had built a camp, maybe with some buildings, probably to threaten the Israelites or control the roads.

Stop here and look at a map of central Israel as a group. Find the town of Gibeah on the map. Pause this audio here.

Also, near the town is a hill with a high place or place of worship at the top. A group of prophets and musicians will be walking down the hill, probably towards Saul. The prophets will be prophesying, or loudly and joyfully speaking the words Yahweh's Spirit gives the prophets, while the musicians are playing their instruments. All of the instruments will be small enough that the musicians can carry and play the instruments at the same time. We do not know exactly what the prophets will be saying.

Yahweh's Spirit will come to Saul and cause Saul to also start prophesying. Samuel says that Yahweh's spirit will change Saul so that Saul will be like a new person, ready to serve Yahweh.

When all this happens, Samuel says, Saul will know that God is with Saul to help him. Because God will be with Saul, Saul will be successful in whatever he does, so Saul should then act confidently. God will give Saul opportunities to prove himself as God's chosen ruler.

Samuel's final instruction is for a meeting at Gilgal. Gilgal is a town in central Israel and one of the towns Samuel visits every year. We do not know how soon Saul should go to Gilgal. Samuel may have been about to start his annual visit, so Saul's visit to Gilgal may be within a few weeks or months. When Saul arrives in Gilgal, he should wait for seven days for Samuel. When Samuel arrives, Samuel will then lead or help with the sacrifices, as well as tell Saul what to do next.

Stop here and look at a map of central Israel as a group. Find the town of Gilgal on the map. Pause this audio here.

The second scene begins when Samuel finishes speaking and Saul travels home. When Saul turns to leave Samuel, God changes Saul's heart or changes Saul to be a different sort of man. God prepares Saul to be Israel's ruler.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Think about a time someone went away to learn something new, like at school or for a job, then came back with new skills or abilities. How would you describe how the person had changed when they came back? Pause this audio here.

God also causes all three signs to happen just as Samuel described. However, the storyteller only describes the third sign, since other people saw that sign and talked about it.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when someone explained how something would happen, like a wedding or a ceremony, before you went and saw it happen. Describe what the person said, then how the event happened. Pay attention to the times that you choose to explain exactly how the event happened, and times that you just give a brief explanation or summary, since you have already described what the person has said. Pause this audio here.

When Saul is prophesying with the group of prophets near the high place by Gibeah, other people are nearby and can see Saul and the prophets. People who know Saul are amazed to see him with the prophets. The people ask each other if anyone knows what has happened to Saul to make him act like this. A man who lived there in Gibeah also wonders who the father or the leader of the prophets is. The storyteller mentions that people's question, "Is Saul also one of the prophets?" is now a famous saying in the storyteller's time.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Think of proverbs or famous sayings in your culture and discuss how those things became famous or why people say them. Pay attention to the way you chose to explain certain phrases and which phrases you chose not to explain because other people would know them. Pause this audio here.

The third scene begins when Saul finishes prophesying. Saul and his servant walk up the hill to the high place, or the place of worship, that is just outside of Gibeah. Saul most likely meets his uncle at the high place. This was probably Saul's father's brother, and he may have been waiting for Saul there or came there to find Saul. Saul's uncle asks Saul and the servant where they have been. Saul answers that he and the servant were looking for the donkeys, and when they could not find the animals, they went to Samuel for help. Saul's uncle politely asks what Samuel said. Saul only repeats what Samuel said about the donkeys and does not mention anything about being Israel's new king.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 10:1–16 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has three scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel

  • Saul

  • Yahweh

  • The two men, who know what happened to the donkeys

  • Kish, Saul's father

  • The three men with the goats, bread, and wine

  • The group of prophets and musicians

  • The people who know Saul

  • The servant

  • And Saul's uncle

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Then Samuel took a bottle and poured some oil from the bottle onto Saul's head. Samuel then kissed Saul and said, "Yahweh has certainly chosen you to be the leader over Israel. After you leave me today, you will travel on to Zelzah at the edge of the land that belongs to the tribe of Benjamin, near Rachel's burial place. There you will meet two men. The men will tell you that someone has found the donkeys you were looking for. So now, your father is no longer concerned about the donkeys. Instead, your father is worried about you and is wondering what he should do to find you."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Kish, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am glad that I have the donkeys back, but my son is more important to me than these donkeys, so now I am hoping that he will return safely; or

  • My son does not know that the donkeys are no longer missing. I do not want my son to keep searching forever! I know Saul has been looking all over for the donkeys, so I do not know where he is, and I do not know how I will find him.

Samuel then said, "As you go on your way, after a while you will reach the large tree at Tabor. There you will meet three men who will be on their way to Bethel to worship God. The first man will be carrying three young goats. The second man will be carrying three round loaves of bread, and the last will have a leather pouch filled with wine. The men will greet you politely and offer you two loaves of the bread. You should accept the bread from the men.

"Then go on to Gibeah of God. There is a Philistine camp nearby. When you come near the town, you will meet a group of prophets returning from the high place of worship. Musicians will walk in front of these prophets, playing various kinds of stringed instruments, drums, and pipes. The prophets will be speaking words that Yahweh's Spirit gives them. Then the Spirit of Yahweh will suddenly take control of you, too. You will join the prophets in what they are doing and will become a new person. When these things happen, be confident, because God is with you to help you."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I know that ruling Israel will be a hard task. I have seen how the Israelites do not listen! I will prepare Saul for this new role, and I will be there to help Saul; or

  • I like to fill people with my Spirit, so that they are full of joy and praise. I want Saul to feel that joy and reassurance from me; or

  • I am sure Saul is amazed and wondering if he can really be king. I will give Saul signs to show him that I am in control and that I have really spoken to Samuel about this.

Finally, Samuel said, "Go ahead of me down to Gilgal. I will come down later and meet you there in order to offer burnt sacrifices to God as well as peace offerings. But do not do anything until seven days have passed and I have come to tell you what you should do."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I know Yahweh cares for us, and I can see how Yahweh is reassuring Saul with these signs. When Saul sees these things happen, just as Yahweh said they would, Saul can know that Yahweh is powerful and is helping Saul, giving Saul reassurance, food, and God's own Spirit; or

  • I am thankful that Yahweh has chosen the new king for the Israelites. When I chose new leaders for Israel, I did not make a good choice. I would not want to choose poorly again! or

  • I hope Saul will listen to my instructions and believe my words, because they are from Yahweh and Yahweh's way is best.

As Saul turned aside to leave Samuel, God changed Saul's nature for a new, better one. Then, after Saul went on his way, everything that Samuel had told Saul happened that day just as Samuel had said it would. When Saul and his servant arrived at Gibeah, some prophets met Saul. Then the Spirit of God suddenly took control of Saul, and Saul joined the prophets' activities.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I can see clearly how God's Spirit is with me, and I am amazed! I have to tell people about how amazing Yahweh is, and praise Yahweh! or

  • I feel a little overwhelmed by these signs I have seen and the new role Yahweh has given me. I am glad Yahweh is with me to help me! or

  • I feel and think differently now. After I left Samuel, I felt something change in me. Before, I would have never thought I could lead Israel, but now I can feel Yahweh leading me to be Yahweh's ruler.

When all the people who knew Saul saw him prophesying along with the prophets, the people exclaimed to each other, "What has happened to Saul, the son of Kish? It is hard to believe Saul is one of the prophets!"

But one of the local people said, "Who is the father of those other prophets?" So people's exclamation about Saul became a famous saying. People often said, "Has Saul really become a prophet?"

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people who know Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We have known Saul since he was a boy, and we have never seen Saul do anything like this! Something must have happened to Saul while he was away; or

  • I do not understand how people prophesy, and it is a little strange to me. I wonder if anyone can become a prophet; or

  • I cannot believe that Saul is prophesying. Maybe Saul is just caught up in the excitement and music and does not know what he is saying. I wonder who is leading these prophets and is allowing Saul to join them.

After Saul finished prophesying, Saul went to the high place. Saul's uncle asked Saul and the servant, "Where have you both been?"

Saul answered his uncle, "We were searching for the donkeys. But when we realized we could not find them, we went to ask Samuel for advice."

Saul's uncle asked, "What did Samuel say to you?"

Saul answered, "Samuel told us not to worry, because someone had found the donkeys." But Saul did not tell his uncle what Samuel had said about Saul becoming king.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul's uncle, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • People were saying strange things about Saul. People said Saul was prophesying, but Saul seems normal now. I wonder what happened earlier; or

  • I am glad Saul is home. I was worried about Saul, too. I wonder where Saul was looking for the donkeys; or

  • I am impressed that Saul got to speak with Samuel, our leader. Maybe Samuel told Saul some wise advice or a message from God!

Ask the person playing the servant, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Many strange and surprising things have happened to us today. I wonder if those things have something to do with what Samuel said to Saul when I could not hear them; or

  • Saul seems different now. When we left Samuel, something about Saul changed. Maybe Samuel told Saul something about Saul's future. I hope it is good! or

  • I am glad our journey is over. I am a little frustrated that we searched in the wrong places, but at least we got to meet the man of God on our trip.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 10:1–16 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Samuel says that Yahweh is the one who chose Saul, so Samuel is anointing Saul on Yahweh's behalf. Yahweh is God's personal name. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Yahweh as you used in previous passages.

To anoint someone means to pour sweet-smelling oil over someone. This shows that God had set this person apart for a special purpose. For more information on anoint, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for anoint as you used in previous passages.

Yahweh has chosen Saul as ruler over Yahweh's inheritance. In the original language, this word for ruler or chosen leader is not the same word as king, which is what the Israelites asked for. Use the same word or phrase for ruler as you used in previous passages.

An inheritance is something that belongs to someone by right. Inheritance generally refers to something that a person has the right to receive when his father dies. But in this context, inheritance refers to the land and people of Israel, which belonged to Yahweh, who had the right to rule and lead Israel.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for inheritance. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Samuel says that Saul will meet two men near Rachel's grave, or tomb. A grave is the general name for a place where people bury a dead person. A tomb is the name for a specific type of place where people bury a dead person. In the Bible, a tomb could be a natural cave in a rock, or it could be a hole that people cut out of rock. Although the storyteller uses the general word for grave in this story, you can use the word for tomb, because tombs were the normal way to bury people during Old Testament times in Israel.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for grave or tomb. Look up grave and tomb in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

These men will tell Saul that someone has found the missing donkeys. Donkeys were important animals that carried heavy loads and pulled farming equipment. These donkeys were female donkeys. Use the same word or phrase for donkey as you used in previous passages.

Samuel says that Saul will meet three men who are going to God at Bethel. This is the more general word for God, not God's personal name, Yahweh. Pay attention to where the storyteller uses the word God or Yahweh. For more information on God, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for God as you used in previous passages.

One of those three men will have a skin or leather bag full of wine. Wine is a drink that people make from fermented grape juice. For more information on wine, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for wine as you used in previous passages.

Saul goes near a Philistine outpost or army camp.

Stop here and discuss as a group what you will call a group of soldiers who camp all together in order to protect an area or prepare for battle. Pause this audio here.

Samuel says that Saul will also meet a group of prophets who will be prophesying. A prophet is someone who speaks the words that God gives to that person. Some prophets, like Samuel, tell people instructions and messages from God. Some prophets, like this group of prophets, speak the words God's Spirit gives them to worship and praise God.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for prophet and prophesying here. Look up prophet and prophecy in the Master Glossary for more information. Look at how you have already translated the word prophet. Pause this audio here.

These prophets would be coming down from the high place. A high place was a place of worship, sacrifice, and prayer. People would make these high places on a hill or elevated area. This high place was probably an official or good place for worshiping God. Use the same word or phrase for high place as you used in previous passages.

A group of people playing instruments will be walking in front of the prophets. These people will be playing on lyres, timbrels, flutes, and harps. Lyres are instruments with strings stretched across a frame. People plucked or stroked the strings to play them. Timbrels, or tambourines, are small hand drums that people made out of animal skins. Flutes, or pipes, are instruments that people made of wood, ivory, or bone. These instruments made a soft, nasal sound when the player blew on them. Harps are another kind of string instrument with thicker strings and a louder sound than the lyre.

Stop here and look at the pictures of a lyre, timbrel, pipe, and harp again as a group, as needed. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for lyres, timbrels, pipes, and harps. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The Spirit of Yahweh will come to Saul and Saul will start prophesying. The Spirit of Yahweh is the Holy Spirit. The Spirit of Yahweh is the power that comes from Yahweh. This power creates, gives life, performs miracles, and changes people. When the Spirit of Yahweh comes over a person, that person receives a special power or ability. This can mean physical strength, special wisdom, or a clear understanding of what God wants.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for the Spirit of Yahweh. Though not in the Old Testament, this is another term for the Holy Spirit, so look up Holy Spirit in the Master Glossary for more information. Do not translate this as the Holy Spirit, but translate "Spirit of Yahweh" in the same way that you have translated it in previous passages in the Old Testament. Pause this audio here.

Samuel tells Saul to go to Gilgal, and Samuel will join Saul there to sacrifice burnt offerings and fellowship offerings. To sacrifice means to give a gift to God. For more information on sacrifice, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for sacrifice as you used in previous passages.

A burnt offering is a kind of sacrifice that people bring to God. When a person brings God a burnt offering, he kills an animal and burns this animal completely on an altar, which is a special place meant for bringing gifts to God. For more information on burnt offering, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for burnt offering as you used in previous passages.

A fellowship offering, also called a peace offering, is an offering that people brought to God to restore peace with someone else. For more information on peace or fellowship offerings, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for peace or fellowship offering as you used in previous passages.

Saul and his servant travel home together after Samuel finishes speaking. A servant is a man or a woman who works for another person. For more information on servant, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for servant as you used in previous passages.

God changes Saul's heart. In Saul's culture, people used the heart to talk about the place where their emotions, feelings, and decisions happen. God changed the way that Saul thought and acted. Use the same word for heart that you have used previously, and see the Master Glossary for more information about heart, if needed.

God made all the signs happen that God said would happen. Signs are unusual things that God makes happen in order to warn people or to prove to them that something God said would happen will happen. Use the same word or phrase for sign as you have used in previous passages, and see sign in the Master Glossary for more information.

The people say, "Is Saul also one of the prophets?" and people repeat their exclamation until it becomes a proverb in the storyteller's time. A proverb is a short saying that is easy to remember and that people pass on to other people. These sayings give advice about right behavior, describe what usually happens in a situation, or express a common feeling.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for proverb. Look up proverb in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Saul does not tell anyone, including his uncle, how Samuel has anointed Saul to rule Israel, or about the kingship. The kingship is the role or position of a king.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for kingship. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
