title: 1 Samuel 10:17–27
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 10:17–27 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 10:17–27 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 10:17–27 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

Yahweh has already given signs to Saul to prove that Yahweh has chosen Saul to rule Israel. Now Yahweh will show the Israelites that Yahweh has chosen Saul. When the Israelites gather together, in front of all the people, Yahweh chooses Saul's tribe, clan, and family, and then Saul himself. Some people accept and follow Saul, but some do not believe Saul is the right person to rule.

At the beginning of this story, Samuel sends out messages to tell all the people of Israel to come to Mizpah and gather before Yahweh. The town of Mizpah was a location where the Israelites gathered for sacred or special gatherings. There was an altar at Mizpah. To gather before Yahweh means to come together or meet together in a place where Yahweh's Spirit is. The Israelites could gather before Yahweh at the tabernacle, or in front of an altar, like at Mizpah.

Samuel begins by announcing that Yahweh, the God of Israel, has said these things. Then Samuel tells the Israelites what Yahweh has said. Yahweh says that Yahweh is the one who rescued the Israelites from the Egyptians and brought the Israelites out of Egypt. Ever since that time, Yahweh has also saved the Israelites from the kings and other nations who have attacked the Israelites. Yahweh is reminding the Israelites of what the Israelites already know.

Now Samuel starts speaking Samuel's own words. Samuel says that even though God has saved the people from difficult and dangerous situations, the people have rejected or refused to honor God. The people have said to Yahweh, "No, we do not want you as our king." The people have demanded that Samuel appoint or choose a king for the people.

Since Yahweh has agreed to give the people a ruler, Samuel tells the Israelites to present themselves, or come forward in the presence of Yahweh, so that Yahweh can show the Israelites whom he has chosen to be the king. Each person should stand with their family. All the families should stand in a clan or a group of families. All the clans should stand together with the other clans in their tribe. Each tribe should stand apart from the other tribes. Saul belonged to Kish's family, in Matri's clan, in the tribe of Benjamin.

Yahweh will choose the new ruler by lot. Casting lots was a way people used to discover God's will. There were several ways to do this, so it is not clear exactly what happened in this story. People sometimes shook stones in a small container in such a way as to cast or shake out a stone. Each stone could have a symbol on the stone with either the word "Yes" or "No" to answer the person's question. Yahweh would cause the stone with Yahweh's answer to come out.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of the stones for casting lots. Pause this audio here.

First, each of the tribes came forward. Yahweh chose the tribe of Benjamin. Then the clans in the tribe of Benjamin came forward, and Yahweh chose the clan of Matri. Then the families in the clan of Matri came forward. Finally, Yahweh showed that Yahweh chose Saul from the family of Kish. Kish was Saul's father.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your people's history, what have been some of the ways that a person becomes king or leader? Who chooses the leader? What ceremonies do you have to show this? Pause this audio here.

However, Saul is not standing with his family. When some people look for Saul, the people cannot find Saul. So the people ask Yahweh if Saul was even at Mizpah. Yahweh answers that Saul is here and that Saul is hiding in the baggage or stacks of supplies. Some people run over to the supplies, where they find Saul and bring him out to the people. Then everyone could see how tall Saul was. No one was taller than Saul's shoulder!

Then Samuel declares to all the people that this is the man that Yahweh has chosen. Samuel phrases this statement like a question, asking if the people can see Saul, but Samuel knows they can see Saul. Samuel is telling the people to look at Saul and understand that Yahweh has chosen Saul. Samuel says that there is no one in Israel who is like Saul. The people respond by shouting, "May the king live for a long time!" to show that they understand and are excited. The people are wishing God's blessing on the king so that the king will live a very long time.

So Samuel then explains the king's duties and rights, or the things that a king has authority to do. These may be the same things that Samuel has already told the people about kings earlier. Samuel may also be repeating what Yahweh has said about kings in Yahweh's law. Samuel writes down these things to record or officially show that Saul and the people have heard and agree to these things. Samuel writes these things on a scroll, which is a long strip of papyrus or parchment. After Samuel finishes writing it on the scroll, Samuel puts the scroll before Yahweh. This means that Samuel puts the scroll in a holy place in the presence of Yahweh. This could be there at Mizpah or with the ark of the covenant in Kiriath Jearim.

Stop here and look at a picture of a scroll as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: When you begin a new job or project with other people, how do you discuss everyone's roles or duties? When do you do this? How do you make sure everyone agrees and will do what each person says they will do? Pause this audio here.

Then Samuel tells all the people, including Saul, to go back to their homes. When Saul goes back to Gibeah, some men go with Saul. God touches or changes the hearts of valiant or brave men. In the original language, people used the word heart to describe the deepest part of a person, where people thought, felt, and understood things. So God inspired these men to follow Saul and to want to protect and serve Saul.

However, not everyone was happy about Yahweh's choice. Some men, who are troublemakers or disrespectful people, said that Saul would not be able to save the Israelites from their enemies. These men did not honor Saul, and they did not give Saul any gifts. People often brought gifts to kings to show respect, especially when a new king began to rule. When Saul hears what the troublemakers are saying about him, Saul does not defend himself, say bad things about the men, or punish them. Saul waits patiently and does not try to take revenge.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 10:17–27 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has five scenes.

In the first scene: Samuel tells the Israelites to come to Mizpah so Samuel can tell them what Yahweh has said. Samuel says that Israel has rejected their God by asking for a king. But, since Yahweh has agreed to give the Israelites a ruler, Samuel tells them to come forward in orderly groups so that Yahweh can show the people who Yahweh has chosen.

In the second scene: The tribes, clans, and families come forward, and Yahweh chooses the tribe of Benjamin, Matri's clan, and Kish's family. However, when Yahweh shows that he has chosen Saul, Saul is not standing with Saul's family.

In the third scene: People look for Saul, and when they cannot find Saul, they ask Yahweh if Saul is here. Yahweh says that Saul is hiding in the baggage. The people find Saul and bring him out to the people, where everyone can see how tall Saul is.

In the fourth scene: Samuel says that no one is like Saul, the man Yahweh has chosen. The people shout, "May the king live for a long time!" Samuel then explains the duties of a king and writes the duties all down on a scroll, which Samuel puts in a holy place.

In the fifth scene: Samuel tells all the people, including Saul, to return home. Everybody goes home. Some brave men follow Saul. Some men do not respect or honor Saul. Saul does not say anything about the disrespectful men.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel

  • The people of Israel

  • Yahweh, the God of Israel

  • The tribe of Benjamin

  • The clan of Matri, which is a clan within the tribe of Benjamin

  • The family of Kish, which is a family within the clan of Matri

  • Saul

  • The men who accept and follow Saul

  • And the disrespectful people who do not accept Saul

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In the first scene, Samuel tells the people of Israel to gather at Mizpah. Samuel probably sends out messages to all the people. This probably took several days or even weeks for everyone to gather. Mizpah was a town in the center of Israel, so Mizpah was a good gathering place.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel as a group. Find Mizpah on the map. Pause this audio here.

There was also an altar there at Mizpah, where Yahweh would meet with the people when they brought Yahweh gifts and asked for guidance. So when the people gathered there, near the altar, the people were before Yahweh, or at the place where Yahweh would come to meet with the people. The people are probably outside of the town of Mizpah, and there are probably people in the crowd who will repeat what Samuel is going to say so everyone can hear Samuel.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, when people are going to make a big decision for their people group, where do they gather together to talk? What makes this place a good or important place to gather? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh spoke to Samuel before the gathering and told Samuel what to say to the Israelites. Samuel begins by saying, "This is what Yahweh, the God of Israel, says." In this time, messengers were supposed to repeat the message exactly as the original speaker said it, so they would start their messages like this: "Yahweh says, 'I am the one who rescued you and brought you out of Egypt.'"

When Yahweh says "you," Yahweh means "your people" or "your ancestors." Yahweh saved the Israelites' ancestors from the hand or the power of the Egyptians. Yahweh has also saved the Israelites and their ancestors from all the kings and other nations who have attacked and mistreated the Israelites.

Stop here and as an activity, tell a brief overview of your people's history up until now. Pretend you are telling this history to other members of your people. Pay attention to when you say "you," "your people," or "your ancestors." Pause this audio here.

Now Samuel begins speaking his own words. Samuel says that this day, or in this present time, the Israelites are rejecting their God. Though God has saved the Israelites from their troubles and difficult situations, the Israelites have said that Yahweh is not a good enough king. The Israelites think a human king will be better, so they have asked Samuel to appoint a king. Since Yahweh has agreed to do what they ask, Samuel will now show them the man that Yahweh has chosen. Samuel tells the people to organize themselves and come forward in the presence of Yahweh.

In the second scene, the people stand in groups. All the people stand with their families. All the families stand in clans or family groups. Then all the clans stand with the other clans in their tribes. All the tribes stand separate from each other.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Discuss what words you use in your language for various family groups, such as family, clan, or tribe. As an activity, introduce yourselves to each other and share what family groups you come from using the words you have discussed. Pause this audio here.

Each of the tribes comes forward as Samuel casts lots and asks Yahweh if this was the group Yahweh had chosen. Since Yahweh was choosing a man for their new leader, it may have been just the men in each group. It is possible that each group actually came and stood in front of Samuel, or that Samuel wrote down the names of each group and presented them to Yahweh in some way. Yahweh would then reply with a "Yes" if this was the group Yahweh chose and a "No" if it was not. Either way, this still probably took some time to do.

Yahweh chooses the tribe of Benjamin. Then, when the clans step forward, Yahweh chooses Matri's clan. When the families and then the men in the families come forward, Yahweh chooses Kish's family. Then Yahweh shows that Saul is Yahweh's choice. However, Saul is not standing with Saul's family.

In the third scene, the people start looking for Saul. When the people cannot find Saul, the people ask Yahweh if Saul has come to Mizpah yet. The people think Saul may still be traveling or at home. To ask Yahweh this question, the people may have asked Samuel to ask Yahweh. Yahweh responds with a word that means "Look! There he is!" Yahweh says Saul is hiding amongst the piles of supplies, which may be the food and traveling gear that the people brought with them.

Some of the people run over to the supplies and find Saul. The people bring Saul out to stand amongst the other people. Now the people can see how tall Saul is. No one is taller than Saul's shoulder!

In the fourth scene, Samuel tells the people that this is the man Yahweh has chosen and that no one in Israel is like Saul. Remember in the last section, Yahweh prepared and changed Saul to be ready to rule Israel. Saul impresses the people when the people see Saul. The people are excited and shout, "May the king live for a long time!" This is probably not all of the people, since later we learn that some people do not approve of Saul.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your people's history, how would people show that they were excited to pick or see a new ruler? What kind of respectful or excited phrases would the people say? Pause this audio here.

Because the people have responded like this, Samuel explains the rights and authority of the king, so that everyone will know how to act. To show that everyone has officially heard and agreed to these things, Samuel writes the things down in a scroll. Samuel puts this scroll before Yahweh, which means at a holy place where Yahweh's presence is. This could be at the altar at Mizpah or with the ark of the covenant at the town of Kiriath Jearim. If Samuel puts the scroll with the ark, Samuel will probably travel to put the scroll there when Samuel and everyone else leave Mizpah.

In the fifth scene, Samuel tells everyone to return home, and the people show how they feel about Saul. God inspires some brave men, probably fighting men, to go to Gibeah with Saul when he returns home. These men are showing that they are loyal to Saul and ready to serve Saul. However, some other people are not happy with Yahweh's choice of ruler. These people are disrespectful to Saul. These people ask, "How can this man save us?" These people are not expecting anyone to answer this question. These people are saying that they do not believe that Saul is able to save or lead Israel. These people do not give Saul the traditional gifts for a king like other people probably do. However, Saul does not say anything about these people's disrespectful actions.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 10:17–27 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has five scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel

  • The people of Israel

  • Yahweh, the God of Israel

  • The tribe of Benjamin

  • The clan of Matri, which is a clan within the tribe of Benjamin

  • The family of Kish, which is a family within the clan of Matri

  • Saul

  • The men who accept and follow Saul

  • And the disrespectful people who do not accept Saul

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Some time later, Samuel sent messages to the people of Israel and told them to come to Mizpah to hear what Yahweh had to say to the people. When the people arrived, Samuel said to them, "This is what Yahweh, the God of Israel, says to you: 'Long ago I led your people, Israel, out of Egypt and freed you from Egyptian authority. I have rescued your people from all the other enemy kings that were mistreating you.' But in these recent days, you have refused to follow your God, the one who rescues you from all your troubles and sufferings. You have demanded a man to be your king. So gather before Yahweh and stand in groups according to your tribes and clans."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am still not happy that the Israelites have disrespected Yahweh like this, but I trust Yahweh and will do what he tells me to; or

  • I am glad that Yahweh is giving me the words to say and showing me how to choose Israel's ruler. I wouldn't know the best way to do these things by myself! or

  • I hope the people will understand that they still need to obey Yahweh, even though they have a human king. Maybe this ceremony, where the people see Yahweh choose the ruler, will help them remember that Yahweh is still their God.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Even though the Israelites have rejected me, I still care for the people and want to make their lives better. So I will choose the new ruler in a peaceful way, so that the different tribes do not fight over who will rule; or

  • I know my people are quick to forget that they can trust me, so I will remind them of how reliable I am and how I always rescue my people from their enemies.

Samuel told each tribe of Israel to approach Yahweh, and Yahweh chose the tribe of Benjamin. Then Samuel instructed each clan from the tribe of Benjamin to come before Yahweh. The clans came before Yahweh, and Yahweh showed that Matri's clan was the one Yahweh had chosen. Finally, Yahweh showed that he had chosen Kish's son Saul. But when some of the people looked for Saul, they could not find Saul anywhere.

So the people asked Yahweh another question: "Has this man, Saul, come here yet?"

And Yahweh replied, "Yes, Saul has come and is hiding among the baggage."

The people hurried to get Saul. When Saul came out and stood among the people, everyone could see that Saul was taller than any of them. No one was taller than Saul's shoulders.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I do not want to look too proud, like I expected that Yahweh would choose me. So I will hide back here for a while; or

  • I have felt how God's Spirit has prepared me to be king, but I am still a little nervous about ruling all these people, especially now that I see them all! or

  • God has already shown me that I will rule the people, but I am glad that he is showing everyone else, so that no one will try to fight over who will rule. Surely everyone will listen to Yahweh!

Then Samuel said to all the people, "Here is the man Yahweh has chosen to be your king. No other person is like this man."

Then the people exclaimed, "May the king live a long life!"

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Israel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • This man, Saul, is so tall and impressive! Saul looks like a king! Yahweh has chosen a good man to be our king! or

  • This is such an exciting day! Now that we have a king, all the other nations will see that we are just as important as they are! or

  • I am from the tribe of Benjamin, and I am proud that Yahweh chose a man from my tribe!

So Samuel explained to the people the rights and duties of a king. Samuel wrote these things down in a scroll and placed the scroll in a special place before Yahweh. After that, Samuel told the people that they could all go home. Saul also went to his home in Gibeah. God led some brave men to go with Saul, and they went.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the brave men, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Now that I have seen Saul, I think that he is a good leader. I think that it would be worth leaving my home to go serve and protect Saul; or

  • I feel different from how I felt earlier today. I feel loyalty and love for this king. I want to do what this king tells me to do; or

  • I wonder what serving a king will be like. I am excited to have adventures and do good things for our people.

But there were some others, troublemakers, who said, "This man Saul could never save us from our enemies." These people did not honor or respect Saul and refused to bring him a gift. But Saul did not say anything about these people.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the disrespectful people, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I think that a different man would be a better king—someone from my tribe or maybe even me! Why does Saul get to rule everyone? or

  • I have never heard of this man, Saul! Saul has never led us into battle, and I have never seen him settle disputes. I do not think Saul has the skills to be king; or

  • I do not trust Yahweh or his way of picking a king. I think I know better what a good king looks like.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 10:17–27 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Samuel tells the people of Israel to gather before Yahweh. Yahweh is God's proper name. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Yahweh as you used in previous passages.

Samuel repeats the words that Yahweh, Israel's God, has said. This is the more general word for God. For more information on God, refer to the Master Glossary. This word for God appears several times in the passage, so pay attention to how you translate the names or words for God. Use the same word or phrase for God as you used in previous passages.

Yahweh says that he rescued Israel from the Egyptians and from the other kingdoms that wanted to oppress the Israelites. Sometimes the word Israel refers to all the descendants of Abraham together. It then means the same as Israelites or "people of Israel." For more information on Israel, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Israel as you used in previous passages.

Kingdoms are areas of land that a king rules over.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for kingdom. See the Master Glossary for more information about kingdom, and translate this in the same way that you have in previous passages in the Bible. Pause this audio here.

The Israelites have rejected God and demanded a man to be their king. A king was someone who ruled over a city or territory. For more information on king, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for king as you used in previous passages.

The people presented themselves as tribes and clans. Use the same words for tribes and clans as you have used in previous passages.

Samuel writes down the rights and duties of a king on a scroll, which is a long strip of papyrus or parchment. Papyrus is a thin sheet that people make from the fibers of a certain plant, and people make parchment from the skin of an animal. On both ends of the scroll, people attached a narrow wooden handle, like a round stick. When people were reading from a scroll, they would unroll one side of the scroll and roll up the other end around the stick.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for scroll. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 11:1–15
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 11:1–15 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 11:1–15 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 11:1–15 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

While the people know that Yahweh has chosen Saul to be their king, Saul does not start leading until the Israelites are in danger. Another people group, the Ammonites, is threatening the Israelite town of Jabesh Gilead. When Saul hears about these threats, Saul gathers the Israelite men together and attacks the Ammonites. Saul shows that God is with Saul as he leads the Israelites to win the battle. The people see this and celebrate. The people confirm again that Saul is their king.

This story begins some time after Yahweh chose Saul as king. King Nahash leads the Ammonite army to attack Jabesh Gilead, or the Israelite town called Jabesh, which was in the region of Gilead. Jabesh is located on the east side of the Jordan River in the land where the half-tribe of Manasseh lived. The Ammonites lived in the same area, to the east of the Jordan River. The Ammonites often fought with the Israelites. The Ammonite army besieged the town or set up camps around the Israelite town so that none of the people could get out, and no one could bring food in.

The people of the town send a message out to the Ammonite king Nahash. The people ask Nahash for a treaty or an agreement. The people will agree to serve the Ammonites, or accept Nahash as their king, if the Ammonites stop attacking. In Israel at that time, it was probably normal for towns to be independent enough to make their own treaty, as Saul was not yet governing and making decisions as king.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, how do your people or leaders make agreements with other people groups and nations? Who has the authority to suggest or confirm these agreements? Pause this audio here.

Nahash says his army will stop attacking the town if they first gouge or cut out everyone's right eye. This would shame or dishonor all of the people of Israel because they could not save the Israelite people of Jabesh from the Ammonites.

The elders or leaders of Jabesh ask the Ammonites to wait one week so the people can send out messengers for help. If no Israelites come to help, then the people of the town will surrender and walk away from the town. The people will leave the town empty and unguarded so the Ammonite soldiers can enter it. Then Nahash can treat the people however he wants.

Nahash agrees to this plan, probably because Nahash does not think anyone will rescue the people of the town. The other nations probably still think that the Israelites are divided and do not have a king.

The people of the town send out messengers who travel to Gibeah, where Saul lives. The messengers describe the attack and treaty to the people of Gibeah, who begin to weep loudly. The people of Gibeah are worried and scared for the people of Jabesh. As the people are weeping loudly, Saul comes back from working in the fields. Saul is walking behind his oxen. Oxen are cattle that can pull a plow.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of an ox. Pause this audio here.

When Saul sees the people weeping, Saul asks the people what is causing them to weep. The people of Gibeah tell Saul what they have heard. Then God's Spirit comes to Saul in power. This means that God's Spirit comes to Saul and controls Saul. Now, Saul will have God's power for what Saul will do. Saul becomes angry at the Ammonites. Saul's anger is so strong that it is like a burning fire.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about someone who was so angry that it seemed like someone else was controlling that person. What words or phrases do you use to describe this person in your story? Pause this audio here.

Saul sends out a message to the Israelites in a shocking way. Saul kills two oxen, cuts them up, and sends pieces of the oxen with messengers throughout Israel. Saul tells the messengers to say, "If you do not follow Saul and Samuel to battle, then your oxen will be like this one, cut into pieces." Saul mentions Samuel because Samuel still has authority in Israel. Yahweh causes the people to fear Saul, so the people quickly come together as one army and act in a united way. Saul gathers all the fighting men at the town of Bezek. Bezek is on the west side of the Jordan River. Bezek is opposite the town of Jabesh, which is on the east side of the Jordan River. Saul counts the fighting men. Saul has 300,000 men from "Israel," which is what people called northern Israel. Saul also has 30,000 men from Judah, or southern Israel.

Saul and the army tell the messengers to take a message to the Israelite people of Jabesh. The messengers should say that the Israelite army will rescue Jabesh tomorrow by the time the sun is hot, which means midday. When the messengers repeat this to the people of Jabesh, the people are very happy and relieved. The people of Jabesh tell Nahash and his troops that tomorrow, the people will come out of the town to the Ammonites, and the Ammonites can do what they want to the people. The people of Jabesh were purposely vague when they said that they would come out. The people were probably trying to deceive the Ammonites so that the army would not expect an attack.

The next day, Saul prepares to attack. For the Israelites, a day was from sundown to sundown, so it is evening when Saul divides his men into three groups. This would give Saul's troops more options and safety when they attack. The army travels overnight from Bezek to Jabesh Gilead, and the army arrives at the last watch of the night. A watch was a measurement of time. The night had three watches, and the last watch was early morning before dawn. Saul and his army surprise the Ammonite army by attacking at this time. The Israelites slaughter, or kill, their enemies until the heat of the day, or midday, just like the messengers said. The Ammonites lose so badly that there are not many Ammonite soldiers still alive at the end of the battle. The Ammonite soldiers who are still alive run away. Each of the soldiers is on his own. No one is leading the soldiers in orderly groups.

Saul leads the fighting men so well, and the people are so enthusiastic about their new leader, that the people ask Samuel about the Israelite men who had disrespected Saul earlier. We heard about those men in the previous story. The people insist that those men come forward so that the people can kill the men. However, Saul says that the people will not kill any other Israelites today. Yahweh has just rescued the Israelites, so the Israelites should be celebrating, not punishing people.

Samuel suggests a better way to show that the people approve of Saul. The Israelites should all go to Gilgal and there renew or confirm the kingship, to show that the Israelites all accept Saul as their king. So all the people go to Gilgal and the people confirm Saul as king in Yahweh's presence. Yahweh's presence is a sacred or holy place, where Yahweh is present and listening in a special way. This is the final step or ceremony to make Saul king. Before, Yahweh had shown that Yahweh chose Saul by telling Samuel and by choosing Saul by lot in front of all of Israel. Now that Saul has shown that he will be a good king, the people have a celebration to emphasize that all of Israel has now agreed that Saul is the king of Israel. The people also offer peace or fellowship offerings to God. People often gave these offerings at celebrations to thank or praise God for what he has done. The people eat a portion of those offerings and celebrate joyfully together.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, what is the process people use to pick or appoint a new leader? What steps or ceremonies do you have? How long does the process take? Where do these ceremonies happen?

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 11:1–15 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has seven scenes.

In the first scene: Nahash and his army camp around the Israelite town of Jabesh in the region of Gilead. When the people of the town ask for a treaty, Nahash says he will only make a treaty if Nahash can cut out the people's right eyes. The elders of the town ask for time to see if anyone will help. Nahash agrees.

In the second scene: The messengers leave Jabesh and arrive in Gibeah. When the messengers explain what is happening at Jabesh, the people of Gibeah weep loudly. Saul returns to town and asks what is wrong. The people tell Saul the news. God's Spirit comes to Saul. Saul cuts up his oxen and sends out messengers with pieces of the oxen to tell the Israelites to gather together to fight.

In the third scene: When the people of Israel hear the message, God causes the people to gather quickly to form an army at Bezek. Saul and the army send the messengers from Jabesh Gilead back to their town to tell the people there that the army will rescue the people.

In the fourth scene: The messengers repeat their message to the people of Jabesh Gilead. The people rejoice and send a message to Nahash and his army.

In the fifth scene: Saul and his army travel overnight to attack the Ammonites in the morning. Saul's army wins when they kill and scatter the Ammonite army.

In the sixth scene: The people are so impressed by Saul that they want to kill anyone who does not approve of Saul. Saul, however, stops the people from killing anyone. Samuel tells everyone to gather at Gilgal to renew the kingship.

In the seventh scene: At Gilgal, the people declare that Saul is king in a holy place where Yahweh meets the people. The people offer fellowship offerings and celebrate together.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Nahash

  • Ammonite army

  • People of Jabesh Gilead

  • Messengers from Jabesh Gilead to Israel

  • People of Gibeah

  • Saul

  • Messengers from Saul to Israel

  • People of Israel, including the men who can fight

  • And Samuel

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In the first scene, Nahash and his Ammonite army come to attack the Israelite town of Jabesh, which is in the area called Gilead. Jabesh is on the east side of the Jordan River. This was near the territory that belonged to the Ammonites. We know from later passages that Nahash is the king of the Ammonites. Nahash may have led his army through the Israelite land and fought anyone in his way, or Nahash may have just avoided other towns to attack Jabesh specifically.

Stop here and look at a map of central Israel as a group. Find the region of Gilead, as well as the Ammonites' land. Pause this audio here.

The people of Jabesh see the Ammonite army surrounding their town. The Ammonite army is probably much larger than the number of fighting men in Jabesh. The people of Jabesh ask for an agreement to stop fighting. The people probably send messengers to Nahash, who then sends back a message for his answer. Nahash says he will only agree to a treaty if the people let Nahash's army cut out everyone's right eye. Nahash could mean just the men, or maybe everyone in the town. Nahash wants to shame Israel and show that the Israelites are not strong enough to stop Nahash.

The Israelite elders, respected men who lead the town, ask for time to make their decision. The elders want to send out messengers throughout Israel to ask for help. If no one comes to rescue Jabesh, then the people will agree to a treaty where they lose their right eyes. Though the storyteller does not mention it in the passage, Nahash must have agreed, because the messengers would have to walk through Nahash's camp to leave. The people of Jabesh may have sent out several messengers to quickly spread the news of this attack.

In the second scene, the messengers arrive in Gibeah, Saul's hometown. The messengers may have come straight to Gibeah because Saul lived there, and the messengers were looking for their new leader. When the messengers arrive, Saul is not in the town. The messengers probably go to a meeting place in the town, like the market or at the entrance gates. Then the messengers start to tell everyone what is happening in Jabesh. Everyone who hears the news is worried and sad, and the people start to weep loudly.

Stop here as a group and look at a map of central Israel. Find the town of Gibeah on the map. Pause this audio here.

Saul is returning with his oxen from the fields where Saul has been working. Saul sees the people who are weeping. Saul asks why the people are weeping, and the people answer and again tell the news about Jabesh.

When Saul hears what the people are saying, God's Spirit comes to Saul and fills Saul with power. Saul becomes angry at the Ammonites. Saul is angry that the Ammonites would attack Saul's fellow Israelites. Saul's anger is so strong that the storyteller compares it to a burning fire, which is hard to put out or stop.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Why do you think the storyteller compares Saul's anger to a burning fire? What words or phrases do you use to describe when someone is very angry? Pause this audio here.

Saul kills and cuts up two oxen in order to send pieces with messengers around Israel. The messengers will show the pieces of the cut-up oxen and repeat Saul's message to the Israelites. The messengers will say that if anyone does not follow Saul and Samuel into battle, then those people's oxen will be like these cut-up oxen.

In the third scene, when the people of Israel hear the messages, God causes people to fear Saul so that they will obey immediately. The men of Israel quickly travel to Bezek, which is probably a town on the west side of the Jordan River, near a good river crossing. Three hundred thousand men come from the north, and 30,000 men come from the south. Samuel probably comes to Bezek too, to travel with the army.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: God causes the people to fear Saul, or to have a deep respect for and awe of Saul. Talk about someone you respect so much that you are almost afraid of that person. What kind of things does that person do? What kinds of descriptions do you use? Discuss what words or phrases you will use to show this deep respect. Pause this audio here.

Now that the army has gathered and is ready to go help Jabesh, Saul and his men send the messengers back to Jabesh. The messengers should tell the people of Jabesh that the army will come to rescue them before noon tomorrow.

In the fourth scene, the messengers arrive back in Jabesh and repeat this message to the people there. The people are very happy and very relieved that someone is coming to help them. The people send a message to the Ammonites, but the people do not tell the Ammonites about Saul's army. Instead, the people say they will come out of their town tomorrow, and then the Ammonites can do what they want. The Ammonites will probably assume that this means the people are surrendering.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Discuss situations in your language and culture where you pick certain words or phrases carefully so that the words have several meanings, like for poetry. For example, if you want to send someone a message to tell them you are coming, but you do not want to tell the person when you are coming or why you are coming, what words or phrases would you use in your message? Pause this audio here.

In the fifth scene, Saul and his men prepare for battle. Day began at sundown and ended at the next sundown for the Israelites, so the messengers return to Jabesh in the daylight on one day, and then that evening the army prepares to leave. Saul divides his men into three groups, and then the men travel to Jabesh. The men arrive during the last watch of the night, which means early the next day, before the sun has risen. Saul and the Israelite fighting men will be able to surprise the Ammonites by attacking at this time.

When the Israelites attack the Ammonites' camp, the Ammonites are not ready to fight, but are probably still sleeping. The people of Jabesh may have come out of their city, like they said they would. However, the people would not have come out to surrender, but to help fight the Ammonites. The Israelite army wins this battle. The Israelites kill the Ammonite soldiers until the sun is high, or until midday. Only a few Ammonites are left. These Ammonites are afraid and have no leaders to organize them, so each Ammonite runs away alone.

The sixth scene happens the same day as the battle. The Israelites ask Samuel for the names of the people who had earlier questioned whether Saul could really save the people. Although the people say this like a question, the people are really reminding Samuel and each other about these men in a disapproving way. The people insist that those men come forward so that the people can kill those men.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Think of an annoying or bad problem that several people in the group know about or have encountered, like bad weather or rough roads. Remind each other of these things, and pay attention to the way you bring these things up, how you phrase your reminders to each other. Pause this audio here.

Saul, however, stops the people. Saul says that the people will not kill anyone today because today, Yahweh has rescued Israel. Because Yahweh has led Saul to rescue Israel, Samuel suggests that the people celebrate. The people can all go to Gilgal, where the Israelites often gathered, to be in the place where Yahweh comes to meet with the Israelites. Then the people can once more proclaim that Saul is their king.

Stop here and look at a map of central Israel as a group. Find the town of Gilgal on the map. Pause this audio here.

So in the seventh scene, the people gather at Gilgal. It may have taken a day or two for everyone to gather together, as families may have joined the fighting men there. In the place where Yahweh meets with the Israelites, the people officially made Saul their king. It is not clear exactly what the people do, but they may give Saul special items to show that Saul is king. Then the people declare together that they all accept Saul as their king.

The people also sacrifice peace or fellowship offerings to Yahweh. When people sacrifice these offerings, they give a portion to Yahweh and then eat the rest together. So Saul and all the Israelites celebrate, eat, and thank Yahweh for their victory and their new king.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 11:1–15 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has seven scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Nahash

  • Ammonite army

  • People of Jabesh Gilead

  • Messengers from Jabesh Gilead to Israel

  • People of Gibeah

  • Saul

  • Messengers from Saul to Israel

  • People of Israel, including the men who can fight

  • And Samuel

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Nahash the Ammonite led his soldiers to the town of Jabesh in Gilead and surrounded the town. So the people of Jabesh sent Nahash a message that said, "If you promise not to kill us, we will become your subjects and allow you to rule over us."

But Nahash sent back this reply: "I will not make this agreement with you unless you agree to let us blind all of you in the right eye. In this way, I will humiliate all the people of Israel."

The elders of Jabesh sent this answer to Nahash: "First, wait seven days. We will send messengers to all of Israel for help. If nobody comes to help us, then we will surrender to you."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Nahash, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I want to expand my land and take the good things in Jabesh. Then my people will see what a powerful king I am; or

  • I do not like the Israelites. I want to shame the Israelites by taking one of their towns. I do not care if I have to fight and kill everyone, or just cut out their eyes. Either way, I win and show how weak the Israelites are; or

  • I have heard how Israel does not have a king. There is no one to gather the Israelites into an army to fight me. I am not worried about these messengers.

Ask the person playing the people of Jabesh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • When I looked outside our town and saw the army surrounding us, I was terrified! These soldiers are ready to kill all of us! or

  • I hope the other Israelites will come quickly to help us! Maybe our new king, Saul, can gather men fast enough to come rescue us; or

  • We have taken care of ourselves for so many years that we even make our own treaties and agreements. While the other Israelites are our people, we are not very united. I worry that no one will come, because they are scared of the Ammonites or do not want to help us.

When the messengers from Jabesh reached Saul's town of Gibeah and told the people there what the Ammonites had demanded, all the people of Gibeah started to cry loudly.

Right at that time, Saul was driving his two oxen home from the fields. When Saul heard the people crying, Saul asked some of the people there, "What is the problem? Why are the people crying?"

So the people told Saul the news that the men from Jabesh had brought. When Saul heard the news, the Spirit of God entered Saul with power, and Saul became very angry.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Gibeah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • The people of Jabesh are our people! I am scared for Jabesh and sad that the people are in this danger! If the Ammonites defeat the people of Jabesh, the Ammonites may come attack us next! or

  • I do not know what I can do to help the people of Jabesh. The Ammonites will probably defeat Jabesh and then attack other towns in Israel. I do not know who will stop them! or

  • The Ammonites are humiliating all of us Israelites, because we do not have an army ready to fight against the Ammonites. I feel shame and sorrow because other nations think we are weak and divided.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Just a few minutes before this, I was thinking about my farm work. Now I feel completely different. I feel God's Spirit with me, and I know what I need to do; or

  • The Ammonites have threatened my people, the people I am supposed to protect as king! I am angry that my people are afraid! I am also angry that the Ammonites think that we will not be able to stop them! or

  • I was surprised when I saw all the people crying. I knew something terrible must have happened, but I did not expect this news. It is good that the messengers came here, since I am the leader of Israel and can help gather the people together.

So Saul took two oxen and cut them into pieces. Saul gave the pieces to messengers, who traveled around the whole land of Israel. The messengers showed the pieces to the people and said, "This is what will happen to the oxen of anyone who refuses to follow Saul and Samuel into battle!"

When the people heard these words, Yahweh caused the people to be terrified when they saw Yahweh's power in Saul. All of the people came together to join Saul's army.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Israel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I was just doing my work as usual when suddenly these messengers came with the pieces of meat and this message about Ammonites attacking and war and everything! I was so shocked! How quickly my day has changed! or

  • All of us men must leave right now! It is very urgent that we do not waste any time. I almost feel afraid to stop and do anything else but prepare for battle; or

  • I am amazed at the power of God in our new king. I was impressed when I saw Saul at the last gathering because Saul is so tall. But now there is something different about Saul. I want to follow Saul and do whatever Saul says.

Then Saul gathered the army together at Bezek. There were 300,000 men of Israel and 30,000 men of Judah. Saul and his men gave this message to the messengers from Jabesh Gilead: "Tell the other people in your town that we will rescue them before noon tomorrow."

The messengers from Jabesh returned home and gave the message to the people of the town. Then the people rejoiced at this news. The people of Jabesh said to the Ammonites, "Tomorrow we will come out of the city to you. Then you can do whatever you like to us."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Jabesh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I have not been able to eat or sleep because I have been so worried about the army that is right outside our town. I can hear the army no matter what I do! But now, the messengers have told us this news, and I feel so relieved. I have hope that this will end soon! or

  • I am amazed that the other Israelites have gathered to help us so quickly! The messengers told us about what Saul was like and how everyone obeys Saul immediately. I am so glad we have a good leader! or

  • We must be careful not to let the Ammonites know that we are expecting an army to help us. We should send a message to trick the Ammonites. That way, we can help the other Israelites who are helping us!

That night, Saul divided his soldiers into three groups. In the early morning, the men attacked the Ammonite camp and began killing the Ammonites there. The men continued to fight till noon. The Ammonite soldiers who survived ran away in all different directions so that not even two of the Ammonites remained together.

After the battle, the Israelite people said to Samuel, "We remember that certain men did not want Saul to reign over Israel. Bring those men to us and we will kill them!"

But Saul said to the people, "No! You will not kill any Israelites today because this is the day that Yahweh rescued us."

Then Samuel said to the people, "Come, let us go to Gilgal and once more proclaim that Saul is our king."

So all the people went to Gilgal. There before Yahweh, the people confirmed that Saul was king. There, the people gave fellowship offerings to Yahweh. And so Saul and all the Israelites had a very joyful celebration.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • These people keep making the wrong decisions. Even when the people are excited and celebrating a victory, they want to hurt others! It is hard to lead these people sometimes! or

  • I am glad that Saul led the people so well and then calmed the people down after the battle. I hope that Saul leads the people well his whole life, even when I am not there to help Saul; or

  • I know that Yahweh is really the one who gives us victory when we fight, so I want to celebrate and honor Yahweh at Gilgal. I want to finish the ceremonies to make Saul king, which we should also do in Gilgal, in Yahweh's presence. This way, we can show that Yahweh is our God and that we respect him.

Ask the person playing the Israelite people, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I remember those people who said that Saul could not save us. I am angry that those people were rude and disrespectful to the man who has just saved our people! We should punish those people for what they said! or

  • I am so excited about our new king! Look at what a good leader he is! Everyone should be just as excited as I am! or

  • I am excited about our future. Now the other nations will know that we have a king who is mighty in battle. Those other nations will not bother us anymore!

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 11:1–15 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Nahash is an Ammonite. Nahash comes and attacks Jabesh Gilead with his army. The Ammonites were a people group who lived to the east of Israel.

The people of Jabesh ask Nahash to make a treaty or covenant with them. When people make a covenant, they make a solemn promise to each other that they cannot break. A king or ruler could also make a covenant with another ruler or kingdom that was weaker than he was. The king could say to these other people, "I will protect you, but you will have to pay me," or "You have to work for me." These other people had to promise to do what the king wanted.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for treaty or covenant. Look up covenant in the Master Glossary for more information. Look at how you have already translated this word before. Pause this audio here.

The elders of Jabesh ask for time to send out messengers to ask for help. In this time, an elder was usually the head of a family or clan who had authority in the community. For more information on elder, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for elder as you used in previous passages.

When the messengers arrive in Gibeah, Saul is in the fields with his oxen. An ox is a large animal that people used to pull plows and help with farming. Saul is working with two oxen, which people sometimes call a yoke of oxen. A yoke is a wooden collar with two openings that people used to tie two oxen or two other animals together so that the animals walk together to pull a plow or vehicle. You can just say "two oxen" instead of yoke.

Stop here and look at a picture of an ox again as a group as needed. Pause this audio here.

When Saul hears about the Ammonite army, the Spirit of God comes to Saul again. The Spirit of God, or the Spirit of Yahweh, is the power that comes from God. When the Spirit of God comes over a person, that person receives a special power or ability. This can mean physical strength, special wisdom, or a clear understanding of what God wants. For more information on Spirit of God, refer to Holy Spirit in the Master Glossary. Though these are the same power, you should not translate "Spirit of God" as Holy Spirit. Use the same word or phrase for Spirit of God as you used in previous passages.

Here, the storyteller uses the more general word for God, not God's personal name, Yahweh. For more information on God, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for God as you used in previous passages.

Then the storyteller says that Yahweh causes the people to fear Saul and gather together quickly. Yahweh is God's proper name. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Yahweh as you used in previous passages.

When the men gather together as an army, 300,000 men come from Israel and 30,000 men come from Judah. Sometimes the word Israel means only the northern part of the country of Israel, while Judah means the southern part of the country. For more information on Israel, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same words or phrases for Israel and Judah as you used in previous passages.

Saul and his army attack the Ammonites during the morning watch or the last watch. A watch is a period of time during which someone looks out for danger or trouble, usually during the night. In this time, the night had three watches, and the last watch was from about 2 a.m. to 6 a.m., right before sunrise.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for watch. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Samuel tells the people that they should go to Gilgal to declare or reaffirm that Saul is their king. A king was someone who ruled over a city or territory. For more information on king, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for king as you used in previous passages.

While at Gilgal, the people give peace or fellowship offerings to Yahweh. A fellowship offering, which people also called a peace offering, is an offering that people brought to God to restore peace with someone and to celebrate fellowship with God and people. For more information on offerings, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for peace or fellowship offering as you used in previous passages.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
