title: 1 Samuel 12:1–17
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 12:1–17 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 12:1–17 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 12:1–17 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

Samuel speaks to the people at the end of his role as their leader, since Saul is now king. Samuel reminds the people of how Samuel has led them. Then Samuel reminds the people of their history and how they failed to follow Yahweh as they should. Samuel urges the people to act differently now, to follow Yahweh. Then Samuel asks Yahweh to give a sign of Yahweh's power, to show that Yahweh is listening and confirming Samuel's words.

In this passage, Samuel begins his speech by reminding the people of how Samuel acted during his long time as leader. Samuel listened to the people's request for a king and did what the people asked. Samuel points out the people's king, Saul, who will now lead Israel. Samuel next points out Samuel's age. Samuel is old, his hair is gray, and people can see Samuel's adult sons, who are among the people and have also served the people or led them. Samuel started leading when he was young and has led up until this day, or this time. Samuel emphasizes his age to show how long Samuel has been leading Israel.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, how would you show or describe that someone has lived a long time? What things would you point out about how the person looks or what they have done? Pause this audio here.

Now Samuel asks the people to look at his actions as their leader and agree that Samuel has not mistreated the people in any way. "Here I am," Samuel says. Samuel will not hide from the results of his actions. Samuel tells the people to testify or judge Samuel and bring any complaints against him while Yahweh and Yahweh's anointed one, the chosen king, are listening.

Samuel asks five questions. First, Samuel asks the people if they know of anyone's ox or donkey that Samuel has taken or stolen. An ox is a farm animal similar to a cow, and a donkey is like a small horse. Samuel asks if he has cheated or tricked someone so that Samuel could take something from that person. Samuel asks if he has mistreated anyone. Samuel asks if he has taken any bribes or gifts to make an unfair judgment. Samuel says that if the Israelites can point out anyone whom Samuel has mistreated, Samuel will give back what he has taken and make things fair.

Stop here and look at the pictures of the donkey and ox as a group. Pause this audio here.

Samuel is not expecting the people to name someone whose ox or donkey Samuel had taken. Rather, Samuel is pointing out that the people cannot name anyone. Samuel does this to emphasize that he has never acted unjustly toward anybody in any way. And the people agree. The people say that Samuel has acted fairly as their leader.

Samuel then says that Yahweh and Yahweh's chosen king are witnesses to what the people have agreed to. A witness is a person who sees or hears what happens and is able to testify to the fact that the thing happened. Again, the people agree. Samuel reminds the people of how reliable and trustworthy Yahweh is, since it was Yahweh who appointed Moses and Aaron to be the leaders of their ancestors. It was Yahweh who brought the people's ancestors out of Egypt.

Samuel is speaking like they are in front of a judge in a trial to decide a legal problem. Samuel tells the Israelites to "stand here," referring to the way an accused person stands in front of a judge. First, Samuel is going to remind the people of all of Yahweh's righteous acts or the good things that Yahweh has done for the people in the past. Then Samuel will show how the people were wrong to ask for a king, because the people were acting like Yahweh and Yahweh's righteous acts were not good enough.

Samuel begins by reminding the people how Yahweh brought the Israelites out of Egypt. When Samuel says Jacob went to Egypt, Samuel means Jacob and Jacob's family, whose descendants became the people of Israel. When the Israelites were slaves and cried out to Yahweh for help, Yahweh sent Moses and Aaron to lead the Israelites out of Egypt and into the land where the people live now.

Again and again, the Israelites forgot Yahweh their God. This means the Israelites ignored Yahweh or stopped worshiping Yahweh alone. So Yahweh allowed Israel's enemies to conquer or oppress the Israelites. One of these enemies was Sisera, the commander of the soldiers from the town of Hazor. Other people groups, like the Philistines and the people of Moab, with their king, also defeated the Israelites' ancestors. Each time, the Israelites admitted that they had sinned by worshiping idols of false gods like Baal and Ashtoreth instead of Yahweh. When the people asked Yahweh for help, Yahweh sent the people leaders like Jerub-Baal, whose name is also Gideon. Yahweh also sent Barak, Jephthah, and Samuel. Some versions say "Bedan" instead of Barak, but Samuel is probably referring to Barak. Each time, Yahweh saved the people so they could live in safety.

But when the people heard that Nahash, king of the Ammonites, was preparing to attack, the Israelites did not trust Yahweh to help. The Israelites asked for a human king, even though Yahweh was their king. But Yahweh still listened to the Israelites' request and gave them a king, who is now here in front of the people. Samuel emphasizes that Yahweh was the one who chose the Israelites' king.

The Israelites' future will depend on how the Israelites act from now on. The people can fear Yahweh, and honor and respect Yahweh by serving him, obeying him, and not rejecting his authority. If both the people and the king follow Yahweh and allow Yahweh to lead them, then the people's future will be good. However, if the people do not obey Yahweh and instead rebel against his commands, Yahweh will treat the people like he treated their ancestors who rebelled. Yahweh will allow the Israelites' enemies to defeat the Israelites.

Again, Samuel tells the Israelites to stand still and pay attention, this time to see Yahweh do something amazing. Samuel points out that this is the time for harvesting wheat, which is during the dry season when it does not rain. Samuel will pray and ask Yahweh to send rain and thunder. When Yahweh does, it would show the people that Yahweh agreed with what Samuel had told them: that the people had done something evil or wrong when they asked for a king.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when a leader scolded his people, or told them how they had done something wrong. How did the leader show that it was important for the people to understand what they had done?

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 12:1–17 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has four scenes.

In the first scene: Samuel speaks to the people and says that his time as their leader is over. Samuel asks the people to tell Samuel if he has ever acted unjustly. The people declare that Samuel has not mistreated them in any way. Samuel says that Yahweh and Yahweh's anointed one are witnesses to all that Samuel is saying. The people agree.

In the second scene: Samuel reminds the people of all the good things that Yahweh has done for them in the past. Samuel says that the people rejected Yahweh when they asked for a king, which was wrong.

In the third scene: Samuel explains how the Israelites' future depends on whether they follow Yahweh from that time forward, or whether the Israelites rebel against Yahweh again.

In the fourth scene: Samuel declares that he will pray to Yahweh to send rain to show the people that Yahweh agrees with what Samuel has told the people.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel

  • The people of Israel

  • Yahweh

  • Yahweh's anointed king, Saul

  • Samuel's sons

  • Moses

  • Aaron

  • The Israelites' enemies: Sisera, the Philistines, the king of Moab and his people

  • Leaders of Israel: Gideon, Barak, and Jephthah

  • And Nahash, king of the Ammonites

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

Samuel speaks to the Israelite people who are gathered together. This may be at Gilgal, right after the last passage when the people affirmed Saul as king, or this may be at another gathering. Samuel speaks like he and the people are in a trial in front of a judge. Samuel first invites the people to bring any accusations or complaints against Samuel if he has done anything wrong. The people do not, which shows that Samuel is a trustworthy person whose words are reliable. Next, Samuel points out the witnesses, Yahweh and Saul. Then Samuel accuses the Israelites of acting in a wrong way. Samuel presents two options for the people to do, then asks Yahweh to confirm everything Samuel has said.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, when you have a complaint or problem with another person, and must go in front of a judge, what are the steps for that process? What kind of people must be there? What evidence or proof must you give? Pause this audio here.

In the first scene, Samuel begins his speech by mentioning the length and end of Samuel's time as a leader. While Samuel led, he listened to the people's request for a new king, then followed Yahweh's instructions to appoint a king. Samuel points out this king, who is here listening. Samuel has led the Israelites for many years, starting from when Samuel was young until this day, or this time. Samuel is now old, with gray hair and grown sons, who are also listening here.

Samuel then asks the people to judge Samuel's actions and character. Samuel says that he is here in front of the people, ready to listen. Samuel invites the people to testify, or bring evidence against Samuel, while Yahweh and Yahweh's chosen king are listening. Samuel asks if he has done various wrong actions, like stealing, cheating, mistreating, or accepting bribes to make unfair judgments. If the people accuse Samuel of doing any of these things, then Samuel will repay what he has taken and make things right. Although Samuel asks the people if he has done these things in the form of a question, Samuel is not expecting the people to name someone whom Samuel has mistreated. Rather, Samuel is pointing out that the people cannot name anyone because Samuel has been a reliable and trustworthy leader.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Discuss how you will show that Samuel is pointing these things out. Discuss if you want to keep the questions or phrase them differently. Pause this audio here.

The people agree and declare that Samuel has not done any of those things. Samuel points out that Yahweh and Yahweh's anointed one are witnesses. They have heard and can repeat that the people have declared Samuel to be a good leader. Yahweh and Saul can also confirm that what Samuel says is true, both about Samuel's good character and about what Samuel will next say about the people. The people agree that Yahweh is a witness.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: When you are in front of a judge, what kind of witnesses or people to support your story do you need? How do you show that these people are good witnesses? Why do you need these people? Pause this audio here.

In the second scene, Samuel accuses the Israelites. Since Yahweh has saved the Israelites many times, the Israelites have done wrong by rejecting Yahweh for a human king. Samuel tells the people to stand still here as Samuel confronts the people with evidence. Samuel does not mean that the people were moving around. Rather, Samuel means that the people should stand like a person stands in front of a judge while another person accuses that person. Samuel reminds the people of the righteous or good acts that Yahweh has done for the people. These acts are Samuel's evidence or proof that the people had sinned.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: When you go to a judge, where do the different groups of people stand or sit? Why do the people stand in different locations? What does this show, or how does this help the process? Pause this audio here.

Samuel quickly summarizes how Yahweh saved the Israelites from Egypt, since the people would already know the story. Samuel mentions how Jacob and Jacob's family moved to Egypt, and how, later, when the Egyptians made the Israelites serve as slaves, the Israelites cried out to Yahweh for help. Yahweh sent Moses and Aaron to lead the Israelites out of Egypt into the land they are in now.

Then Samuel summarizes the next several hundred years of Israel's history to point out a pattern. The Israelites stopped serving Yahweh, so Yahweh allowed the Israelites' enemies to defeat the Israelites. Then, when the Israelites admitted they had sinned by serving other gods, and they asked Yahweh to help, Yahweh sent leaders to save the Israelites, so they could again live safely. Samuel lists some of the Israelites' enemies during those times, like Sisera from the town of Hazor, the Philistine people group, and the king of Moab and his people.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel as a group. Find the town of Hazor, the Philistines' land, and Moab's land. Pause this audio here.

Then Samuel lists some of the leaders Yahweh has sent: Jerub-Baal or Gideon, Barak, Jephthah, and finally himself, Samuel, whom the people have declared to be a good leader. Yahweh chose military leaders to show that Yahweh was the one who was the king who gave the people a victory.

Even when they heard about Nahash, who was preparing to attack, both Yahweh and Samuel led the Israelites. Samuel was a good leader, and Yahweh was an even better leader, so the people had no reason to ask for a king. But the people rejected Samuel and Yahweh and asked for a king.

Yahweh, however, gave the people what they wanted. Samuel again points out Saul, the king that the people asked for. Samuel also points out that Yahweh is the one who chose the king to emphasize that Yahweh is still the top ruler.

In the third scene, Samuel describes two sets of actions. The first action will bring a good relationship between the people and Yahweh. The people must fear Yahweh by honoring him. The people must serve and obey Yahweh, and not rebel against his commands. Both the people and the king must follow Yahweh, their God.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Samuel tells the people to fear Yahweh, or to have a deep respect for and awe of Yahweh. Talk about someone you respect so much that you are almost afraid of that person. What kind of descriptions do you use? Discuss what words or phrases you will use to show this deep respect. Pause this audio here.

However, if the people disobey Yahweh and rebel against his commands, then there will be consequences. Yahweh will treat the Israelites like he treated their ancestors, and Yahweh will allow the Israelites' enemies to defeat them.

In the fourth scene, Samuel declares that he will ask Yahweh to do an amazing thing. Samuel tells the people to pay attention. Samuel reminds the people that it is the dry season, when it does not rain. The people's crops of grain are fully grown in the fields and are ready for people to harvest.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a ripe wheat field. Pause this audio here.

Samuel will ask Yahweh to make thunder and rain to show that Yahweh is listening and to confirm that what Samuel has said is true. Samuel does this so that the people will realize and understand that the way the people have been acting is evil. This rain will damage the grain, so this rain could also be a punishment for the people's wrong actions.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 12:1–17 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has four scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel

  • The people of Israel

  • Yahweh

  • Yahweh's anointed king, Saul

  • Samuel's sons

  • Moses

  • Aaron

  • The Israelites' enemies: Sisera, the Philistines, the king of Moab and his people

  • Leaders of Israel: Gideon, Barak, and Jephthah

  • And Nahash, king of the Ammonites

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Samuel said to all the Israelites, "I have agreed to all you were asking and have appointed a king over you. Here he is, ready to lead. As for me, I have been your leader from my youth until today. Now I am old and have gray hair. You also know my sons; they are here with you.

"Here I am in front of you. You know my character. Yahweh and his anointed king are listening, so speak up if you have seen me doing anything wrong. I have never taken anyone's ox. I have never taken anyone's donkey. I have never cheated anyone. I have never mistreated anyone. I have never accepted a bribe from anyone in order to judge unfairly. If I have, I will repay it."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I have been careful to lead in the way that Yahweh has told me. I am not worried about any accusations or complaints; or

  • I know that one way to be a good leader is to let the people bring any complaints or issues. The people can trust the leader and help the leader do what is right. I hope Saul sees and understands this; or

  • I am growing old and tired now. It is getting harder to lead the people into battle and make so many decisions for the people. I hope Saul will be able to do these things well.

The people who stood there listening responded, "You did not cheat any of us, and you did not mistreat us. You did not take anything that belonged to any of us."

Then Samuel said to the people, "Yahweh and his chosen king are witnesses today. They have heard and can testify against you that you have just said that I have not taken anything from you."

"Yes," the people said, "Yahweh is witness."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Israel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Of course, Samuel has been a good leader! I wonder why Samuel is saying all of this; or

  • Samuel is speaking in such a formal way. Samuel must be about to tell us something important; or

  • Yahweh, the king, and Samuel are all here speaking and listening to everything we say! This is an important gathering, and I am impressed that I get to be here too!

Then Samuel said to the people, "It was Yahweh who appointed Moses and Aaron to be the leaders of your ancestors. It was Yahweh who brought our ancestors out of Egypt. Now pay attention. While Yahweh is listening, I will accuse you. Since Yahweh has saved you and your ancestors many times, I accuse you of doing wrong to reject Yahweh as king.

"After Jacob and his family went to live in Egypt, Jacob's descendants cried out to Yahweh for help. Yahweh answered by sending Moses and Aaron, who led our ancestors out of Egypt and to this land where they could live. But your ancestors ignored Yahweh their God, so Yahweh allowed your ancestors' enemies to defeat them. One of these enemies was Sisera, the commander of the soldiers from the town of Hazor. Other enemies who defeated your ancestors were the Philistines, as well as the king of Moab and his soldiers.

"Each time, the people of Israel prayed to Yahweh to save them, and they confessed that they had sinned. The people admitted that they had stopped worshiping Yahweh and had started worshiping Baal and Ashtoreth idols. The people asked Yahweh to rescue them from the power of their enemies and promised to worship only Yahweh. Each time Yahweh sent someone to rescue the people. Yahweh sent Gideon, Barak, Jephthah, and me, Samuel. Yahweh saved the people of Israel from all their enemies, who were attacking from every direction, and then you lived in safety."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Even though my people do not listen to me, I still care for my people and want to save them; or

  • It makes me sad when my people worship other gods. When the Israelites' enemies attack, those false gods cannot save the people. When the Israelites ask for help, I will show them that only I can save them; or

  • I warned the Israelites that their enemies would defeat them if the Israelites did not follow my instructions, as they had promised.

Samuel then said, "But when you heard that Nahash the Ammonite king and his soldiers were preparing to attack, you demanded a human king to rule over you, even though Yahweh your God was your king. See now, here is the king you demanded and chose. Here he is, the one Yahweh has appointed as king over you."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Since it was wrong for the people to ask for a king, I wonder if it is bad that I am the king. Maybe I should stop being king; or

  • I am worried about our future now. Will other nations defeat us, just like they defeated our ancestors when they disobeyed Yahweh? or

  • Since Yahweh chose me to be his king, maybe there is a way for me to lead the people in the way Yahweh wants me to lead.

Samuel said, "If you honor Yahweh, serve and obey him, and do not disobey Yahweh's command but follow Yahweh your God, you and your king, then things will go well for you. But if you refuse to obey Yahweh and refuse to do what he commands, then Yahweh will punish you like he punished your ancestors."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Israel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Wow, I did not realize we were rejecting Yahweh like that! I am ashamed that I did not think through my actions; or

  • I had forgotten how many good things Yahweh had done for us, and how many times we sinned against Yahweh. I am thankful that Yahweh is giving us another chance to obey; or

  • I do not want our enemies to defeat us again! We must remind each other, and our king, to follow Yahweh's commands!

Then Samuel said, "So pay attention and see the amazing thing Yahweh is going to do. You know that this is the time when we harvest wheat. Although this is the dry season, I will ask Yahweh to make it thunder and rain. Then you will realize how great an evil thing you have done against Yahweh by asking him to appoint a king for you."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I need the people to understand how bad and dangerous it is to rebel against Yahweh's instructions. This sign will surprise and scare the people, but Yahweh will be able to show this to the people even better than I can; or

  • I know Yahweh is here listening to what we are saying, and I want the people to be aware of Yahweh's presence. I am thankful that Yahweh shows us that he is near; or

  • I trust that Yahweh hears me when I ask for things. We have a good relationship as I serve Yahweh and Yahweh teaches me.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 12:1–17 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Samuel points out that the Israelites' king is here with them. A king was someone who ruled over a city or territory. Saul is the king of Israel. For more information on king, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for king as you used in previous passages.

Samuel tells the people to testify against Samuel while Yahweh and Yahweh's anointed one listen. To testify means to declare the truth about something from one's own experience.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for testify. Look up testimony in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Yahweh is God's proper name. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Yahweh as you used in previous passages.

Anointed or anointed one means a person whom God has chosen for a special task. God had Samuel anoint or pour oil over Saul's head to show that God had anointed Saul. For more information on anointed one, refer to anoint in the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for anointed or anointed one as you used in previous passages.

Samuel says that Yahweh and Yahweh's anointed one are witnesses. A witness is someone who declares the truth about something that person has seen.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for witness. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Yahweh appointed Moses and Aaron to bring the Israelites out of Egypt. To appoint means to assign a job or role to someone and give them authority to act in a certain way. Use the same word or phrase for appoint as you used in previous passages.

Samuel reminds the people of Yahweh's righteous acts. Someone who is righteous is behaving in the right way. Yahweh is righteous because everything that God does is right and good. Here, "righteous acts" refers to how Yahweh acted to save the people of Israel from their enemies.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for righteous. Look up righteous in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Samuel says that Jacob moved to Egypt and then "they" cried out to Yahweh. Jacob is the Israelites' ancestor. Jacob's name is also "Israel," which is why people call Jacob's descendants "Israelites." The names "Jacob" and "Israel" sometimes refer to the person and sometimes to the people group. Jacob and his family moved to Egypt and became the people group of Israel, so Samuel probably uses this name to refer to Jacob and his family, while "they" refers to the Israelite people group.

When the Israelites' enemies defeat them, the Israelites admit that they have sinned. Sin is an act of rebellion against God. Anytime that a person disobeys God's laws, that person sins. For more information on sin, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for sin as you used in previous passages.

The people admit that they were wrong to worship the Baals and Ashtoreths. Baal and Ashtoreth were false gods that the nations around Israel worshiped. People made idols or statues of these gods in order to worship them. People then called these idols "Baals and Ashtoreths." For more information on Baal, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Baals and Ashtoreths as you used in previous passages.

Samuel says if the people fear Yahweh, it will go well for the people. Here, fear means to have reverence, honor, and respect for Yahweh. People show this fear by obeying Yahweh because of the respect they have for Yahweh, not because the people are afraid that Yahweh will treat the people cruelly.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for fear. Look up fear of God in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

When Yahweh sends rain to confirm Samuel's words, then the people will see how they have done an evil thing by asking for a king. Evil is the opposite of good. When people do evil things, they do things God has told the people not to do.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for evil. Look up evil in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 12:18–25
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 12:18–25 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 12:18–25 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 12:18–25 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the last story, Samuel pointed out how the Israelites had sinned against Yahweh. Samuel declared that he would ask Yahweh to send thunder and rain to show that Yahweh agreed with what Samuel had said. This story begins when Samuel prays to Yahweh. Yahweh sends thunder and rain, and the people of Israel are afraid because they realize they have sinned against a very powerful God. The people are afraid that God might kill the people to punish them. Samuel agrees that the people have sinned, but also reassures them that God will not punish the people by killing them. Samuel urges the people to follow Yahweh and promises that Samuel will continue to teach the people and pray for them.

Just like Samuel said he would, Samuel calls out to Yahweh and asks Yahweh to send rain and thunder to prove to the Israelites that they had sinned against Yahweh. Yahweh listens and sends thunder and rain that same day. Everyone is frightened of both Samuel and Yahweh. The people are afraid because Yahweh has so quickly responded to Samuel.

The people of Israel say to Samuel, "Pray to Yahweh your God for your servants." The people are afraid that God might kill them to punish the people for asking for a king. The people call themselves "your servants," which is a humble way to talk about yourself. The people ask Samuel to "pray to Yahweh your God," because the people realize that they do not have the same standing with God that Samuel does because of their sin. Now the people understand that they have sinned in the past and have sinned again with this evil or bad request for a king.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when someone had to apologize to someone important. How did that person show that they were sorry for what they had done? Pause this audio here.

Samuel is honest but compassionate when he responds to the people. Samuel tells the people not to be afraid, and he reassures the people that God is not going to punish the people with death. Samuel agrees that the people have sinned, but says they should not continue to sin by turning away from Yahweh or leaving Yahweh in order to follow other things. Instead, the people should acknowledge that their true king is Yahweh. Samuel urges the people to serve Yahweh with all their heart. In the original language, people used the word "heart" to describe the deepest part of a person, where people thought, felt, and understood things. To do something with all your heart means to do it sincerely and completely, not halfway or distractedly.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when someone did something with "all their heart." Tell how the person focused all of their attention on something or someone they cared for. For example, tell about an athlete who practiced their sport or a person who loved another person. How did that person show that they were determined to show their care for this thing or person? Pause this audio here.

Samuel tells the people not to turn to worthless or empty things. In this story, these worthless things are idols or statues of false gods. These idols cannot do anything to help or save the people. The gods these idols represent are not true gods at all. These gods have no power to do anything for the people who worship them. These gods and their idols are useless.

The people should not reject Yahweh because Yahweh will not reject the people. Yahweh will not reject the people because of his great name or reputation. Yahweh chose to make Israel his people because Yahweh loved the people. Yahweh will continue to care for his people because Yahweh does what he says he will do. Yahweh will not dishonor his name or reputation by giving up on the Israelites. Yahweh wants people to see that he is a great God who is true to his promises, so that the people will honor Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, how do people show their loyalty to their gods? Why are the people loyal to their gods? How do the gods show loyalty to the people? Why are the gods loyal to the people? Pause this audio here.

Samuel then promises to continue to help the Israelites, even though they have a king now. Samuel says, "Far be it from me to stop praying for you!" Samuel was saying here in a very strong way that he would always pray for the people so that the people would follow Yahweh. If Samuel did not pray for the people, Samuel would be sinning against Yahweh. Samuel also says that he will show the Israelites what is right and good for them to do.

Again, Samuel tells the people what they should do. The people should fear Yahweh and treat Yahweh with deep awe and respect. The people should serve Yahweh faithfully with all their hearts. The people should remember all the great things Yahweh has done, to remind themselves that Yahweh is a good God that the people can trust.

However, if the people continue to do evil or wrong things, then Yahweh will punish both the people and their king. Samuel says Yahweh will sweep the people away, like a broom sweeps dirt from a floor. We know from the rest of the Israelites' history that Samuel is saying that if the people continue to do evil things, Yahweh will send the people out of the land that Yahweh had given to the people. Although the people do not know it yet, Yahweh will cause their enemies to take the Israelites away as captives.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 12:18–25 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has two scenes.

In the first scene: Samuel asks Yahweh to send rain and thunder, and Yahweh does. The people are terrified and ask Samuel to pray to Yahweh for them so that Yahweh does not kill the people.

In the second scene: Samuel reassures the Israelites that Yahweh is their God. Samuel also reassures the Israelites that Samuel will continue to pray for the people and teach them. Samuel urges the people to serve Yahweh, then warns them what will happen if they do not.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel

  • Yahweh

  • The Israelite people

  • And the Israelite king, Saul

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

The first scene begins right after the end of the last story. While Samuel is in front of all the people, Samuel asks Yahweh to send rain and thunder. Samuel probably speaks loudly so that the people can hear Samuel talking to Yahweh. That same day, Yahweh sends rain and thunder. When the people see how quickly the rain and thunder came in the dry season, the people are terrified of both Yahweh, who sent the rain, and Samuel, who has such a good relationship with Yahweh that Yahweh would listen to Samuel like this.

The people ask Samuel to pray for them because the people have sinned and because they have seen that Yahweh listens to Samuel. Perhaps the people are not sure they can call Yahweh their God anymore since they have sinned again and again. So the people call Yahweh Samuel's God, and the people humbly call themselves Samuel's servants. The people were afraid because they realized they had sinned against a very powerful God, who might kill the people to punish them. The people admit that they have sinned before and have sinned again by asking for a king.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, what is a humble way to refer to yourself? Think of the story you told earlier about when someone apologized to an important person. What words or phrases did the person use when they apologized? Discuss why people choose these words or phrases. Pause this audio here.

In the second scene, Samuel reassures the people, but also reminds them of what they need to do in response. Samuel tells the people not to be afraid, because Yahweh is not going to punish them with death. Samuel agrees that the people have sinned, but urges them not to give up or stop serving Yahweh. The Israelites should serve Yahweh with all their heart! Yahweh is still the people's God, too!

Stop here and discuss as a group: Remember the story you told in the previous step about when someone did something with all their heart. Pay attention to the way you described how that person was enthusiastic and sincere when they did that action. Discuss how you want to translate the way Samuel says the Israelites should serve Yahweh with all their heart. Pause this audio here.

The Israelites should not serve other idols because they think that Yahweh will not help them anymore. Those idols cannot help the Israelites, but Yahweh can and will! It was Yahweh who decided to make the Israelites his people, not because of what the people did, but because Yahweh wanted to. And Yahweh continues to be the people's God because he keeps his promises, so that Yahweh does not dishonor his name or reputation. That way, everyone can see that Yahweh is a great God and can honor Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your language, discuss how you refer to someone's reputation. As an activity, pretend you are picking people to work on a project together, such as building a house or preparing a party. You can pick anyone you know or know of. As you list each person, describe why you picked that person. Pay attention to the way you describe that person's reputation, or how you know that person will act. Pause this audio here.

Samuel also reassures the people that they do not need to worry that Samuel will give up and stop praying for them. Samuel says it would be a sin if Samuel stopped praying, so of course, Samuel will keep praying! Samuel will also teach the people about the right and good way to act. Then the people can learn how not to sin against Yahweh again.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: As an activity, suggest impossible or crazy actions to each other, things that you would never do. Think of both serious and funny things, such as doing something that scares you or cheering for a rival sports team. Pay attention to how you respond to these suggestions and what words and phrases you use to show that you would never do this thing. Pause this audio here.

To show how important this instruction is, Samuel repeats it and gives a warning. The Israelites must fear Yahweh and serve him completely and sincerely. If the people need a reminder of why they should serve Yahweh, the people should just think about all the good things Yahweh has done for them! If the people do not serve Yahweh, but instead continue to sin and do evil, then Yahweh will punish the people. Yahweh will sweep the people away.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Discuss how you will translate the phrase "sweep away" to show that Yahweh will banish or cause the Israelites to leave their land. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: When the people are very afraid in the beginning, Samuel tells the people not to be afraid that God will be cruel to them. Later, Samuel tells the people to fear God or have deep respect for and awe of Yahweh. Discuss what words you will use to describe these different kinds of fear. As an activity, think of great leaders who were so good, powerful, and impressive that you were almost a little afraid of them. Then think of powerful leaders who were bad and hurt people. Discuss the difference between how you fear or respect the good leaders and the bad ones. Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 12:18–25 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has two scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel

  • Yahweh

  • The Israelite people

  • And Saul, the Israelite king

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Then Samuel asked Yahweh to send thunder and rain, and on that day Yahweh did cause thunder and rain. Then all the people were very frightened of Yahweh and of Samuel. The people pleaded with Samuel and said, "Ask Yahweh your God to forgive us, your servants. Ask Yahweh not to kill us, for we sinned many times before, and now we have sinned again by asking for a king."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of Israel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I have never seen a storm like this at this time of the year! It must really be Yahweh who has sent it. Yahweh really is here, listening to what we say! or

  • Look at the heavy rain and the loud thunder! It is so loud and windy! Yahweh must really be powerful to control the rain and thunder! I am afraid because I have sinned against Yahweh. Yahweh may be angry and kill me with this storm! or

  • Yahweh listened to Samuel's request for rain! Samuel must have a close relationship with Yahweh, who is a powerful God! I am now afraid of both of them.

But Samuel replied, "Do not be afraid. It is true that you did all these evil things, but you must not turn away from Yahweh. Instead, serve Yahweh sincerely. Do not abandon Yahweh to serve useless idols. These idols cannot help you, and they cannot rescue you, for these idols are completely useless. Yahweh will not stop helping his people because Yahweh is very happy to make you his own people and because everyone will honor Yahweh as the great God."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I love the people of Israel so much that I chose them to be my people, even before they started serving me. I also will continue to help the people, even when they sin or turn away from me; or

  • I am sad when my people ask false gods for help instead of me. Those gods cannot help them! The people are wasting their time. Instead, the people should ask me for help and rejoice as they worship me; or

  • I want all people to see how I treat the Israelites so they can understand that I am a good God. I care about other people groups as well, and want them to honor me.

Then Samuel said, "As for me, I will certainly always pray for you. If I did not, I would be sinning against Yahweh. I will also teach you how to live in a way that is good and right. But you must fear Yahweh and be sincere as you serve him wholeheartedly. Remember all the wonderful things Yahweh has done for you. However, if you still continue to do evil, Yahweh will allow your enemies to defeat all of you, including your king, and your enemies will take you away from this land as captives."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I care for these people that I lead, and I want to reassure them that Yahweh is not a cruel God. I want the people to have a good relationship with Yahweh, as they learn to fear and respect Yahweh in the right way; or

  • I worry about the Israelites. If the Israelites do not serve Yahweh, there will be consequences. I do not want the Israelites to keep making the same mistakes, so I will remind them what to do; or

  • I want the Israelites to see how good it is to serve Yahweh! Yahweh is a good God who cares for us, even though we do not deserve it!

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 12:18–25 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Samuel asks Yahweh to send rain and thunder. Yahweh is God's proper name. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Yahweh as you used in previous passages.

The people ask Samuel to pray to Yahweh for the people. To pray means to speak to God. For more information on pray, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for pray as you used in previous passages.

The people call Yahweh "Samuel's God." This is the more general word for God, not God's personal name, Yahweh. For more information on God, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for God as you used in previous passages.

The people also call themselves Samuel's servants. A servant is a man or a woman who works for another person. Here, servant is a humble way to refer to yourself. The people do not actually work for Samuel. For more information on servant, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for servant as you used in previous passages.

The people admit that they have sinned. Any time that a person disobeys God's laws, they sin. For more information on sin, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for sin as you used in previous passages.

The people also admit that their request for a king was evil. Evil is the opposite of good. When people do evil things, they do things God has told the people not to do. For more information on evil, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for evil as you used in previous passages.

A king was someone who ruled over a city or territory. Saul is the king of the Israelites. For more information on king, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for king as you used in previous passages.

Samuel urges the people to serve Yahweh, not worthless things. Here, Samuel is probably talking about idols or false gods. An idol is an object that people make in order to worship a god. The object reminds the people of some characteristics of the god.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for worthless things, idols, or false gods. If you decide to use idol or god for worthless things, look up idol and gods in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Samuel tells the people to fear Yahweh. Here, fear means to have reverence, honor and respect for Yahweh. People show this fear by obeying Yahweh because of the respect they have for Yahweh, not because they are afraid that Yahweh will treat the people cruelly. For more information on fear of Yahweh, refer to fear of God in the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for fear of Yahweh as you used in previous passages.

The people should serve Yahweh faithfully and wholeheartedly. To do something faithfully means to do something sincerely and loyally. Use the same word or phrase for faithfully as you used in previous passages.

When a person does something wholeheartedly, or with their whole heart, it means that they are sincere and committed. The person really wants to do that thing. Use the same word or phrase for wholeheartedly or "with all your heart" as you used in previous passages.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
