title: 1 Samuel 13:1–14
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 13:1–14 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 13:1–14 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 13:1–14 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

This section gives a short summary of Saul's time as king and tells a story that happens during this time. In the story, Saul prepares his army to fight against the Philistines, Israel's enemies. Saul's army is afraid of the huge Philistine army. To keep his soldiers from running away, Saul offers sacrifices to Yahweh without waiting for Samuel. When Samuel arrives, Samuel tells Saul that Saul has disobeyed Yahweh, so Yahweh will not let Saul's sons be king after Saul.

This section begins with a statement that introduces kings of Israel. This special statement usually includes how old a king is when the king begins to rule and how many years the king ruled. Here, in the original language, the numbers for Saul's age and the length of his rule are perhaps incomplete or confusing. Some translations use information from other reliable sources and say that Saul was 30 when he became king and ruled for 42 years.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: As an activity, tell a story about a leader or king who ruled a long time ago. Begin by introducing the leader, so everyone will know who you are talking about. Then tell the story of something that happened while that person ruled. Pay attention to the phrases or information you use to introduce the leader. Pause this audio here.

The story begins when Saul chooses 3,000 men for his active army. This army will always be ready to defend Israel and the king. Saul keeps 2,000 men with him at Mikmash, which is a town in the hill country of Bethel. Then Saul sends 1,000 men with his son, Jonathan, to the town of Gibeah. Gibeah is in the territory of the tribe of Benjamin. Saul sends the men he did not choose to their homes. If Saul needs more men to fight in the army, Saul can gather those men together later.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel as a group. Find the town of Gibeah in Benjamin's territory. Pause this audio here.

While at Gibeah, Jonathan and his men attack and defeat the Philistine outpost or army camp nearby. An outpost is a place where soldiers stay to guard or watch over an area. The Philistines are the Israelites' enemies. The outpost is at Geba, which may be another name for the town of Gibeah.

Stop here and discuss these questions as a group: When people in your culture go to battle, how do they decide when they need to attack the enemy or when to just wait until the enemy attacks and then defend themselves? What makes these actions different? When might you attack as a way to defend? Pause this audio here.

Someone tells the other Philistines that Jonathan and Jonathan's men have defeated the Philistines at the outpost. Saul knows the Philistines will be angry, so Saul sends messengers around Israel to tell the Israelites what has happened. To get everyone's attention, messengers blow on instruments called trumpets, which people made out of ram's horns. People would often use trumpets to gather the people for war.

Stop here and look at a picture of a trumpet as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, how do people pass messages or tell others about news of big events? How do people know how or when to gather together for war? Pause this audio here.

The messengers also say, "You Hebrews, listen to us!" Hebrews is another word for the people group of Israel, including Israelites who lived in other lands. Usually, other people groups, like the Philistines, used this title. The messengers may have said "Hebrews" to include the Israelites who did not live in Israel.

Then the messengers say that Saul has attacked the Philistines. Even though Jonathan led the attack, the messengers probably said Saul did this, since Saul is the king and is responsible for what his army did.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: List some things that your leaders or nearby leaders have done or decisions that they have made. Discuss whether the leader was able to do those things by themselves or if they had other people help the leader. Pause this audio here.

The messengers also say that the Philistines hate the people of Israel, just like they hate a bad smell! The Israelites understand that the Philistines will attack, so the men travel to Gilgal to join Saul's army. Saul has moved from Mikmash to the town of Gilgal, which is a normal gathering place for the Israelites.

Meanwhile, the Philistines prepare to fight as well. The Philistines have 3,000 chariots, which are wagon-like vehicles with two wheels that horses pull. Soldiers would ride on chariots into battle. It was very difficult to defeat a chariot, but the soldiers on a chariot could often kill a lot of men. The Philistines have 6,000 men to ride the chariots and horses. The Philistines also have so many soldiers that no one can count the men, just like no one can count how many grains of sand are on the seashore!

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a chariot and of a seashore. Pause this audio here.

The Philistines go to Mikmash and set up their camp to the east of Beth Aven. The Israelites see the Philistine army and are afraid! The Israelites realize that they are hard pressed, or in great danger. There are so many Philistine soldiers that they could easily defeat and kill the Israelites. So the Israelites run away and hide. The Israelites hide in caves or holes in the sides of mountains and hills, and in thickets or thorn bushes. The Israelites hide in areas of rocky ground and in pits or holes in the ground. The Israelites hide in cisterns or holes that people had dug out of rock for storing water. Some even cross the Jordan River and go to the territory of the tribe of Gad and the region of Gilead.

Stop here and look at a picture of a cistern and of the Jordan River as a group. Pause this audio here.

Saul is still at Gilgal, and the soldiers who have not run away are so afraid that they are shaking or trembling. Samuel has told Saul to wait seven days at Gilgal. This may be the time of year when Samuel normally comes to Gilgal. Saul could also be waiting as a way to prepare himself spiritually for the sacrifices. In Israel and in other countries at that time, the king and his army would sacrifice to their god to ask for help before starting a battle or war. On the seventh day, Samuel has not arrived yet, and Saul's men are running away in fear, so Saul decides to begin offering sacrifices without Samuel.

Saul asks his men to bring to Saul the animals and supplies for the burnt offerings and the fellowship or peace offerings. People would often offer burnt offerings to Yahweh when they had a request. People offer peace offerings to celebrate that God is with them. Just as Saul finishes giving the burnt offering, Samuel arrives. Saul goes to Samuel to welcome him, but Samuel asks Saul what Saul has done. Samuel can see that Saul has offered the burnt offering already, so Samuel is not asking what has happened. Samuel is accusing Saul of doing wrong and asking why Saul has done it.

Saul says that he was running out of time because his men were scattering, Samuel was late, and the Philistines were already gathered and ready to fight. Saul thinks that the Philistines will come to attack the Israelites at Gilgal, and Saul does not want to fight without asking Yahweh's favor or help. It was Samuel's job to offer the sacrifice and speak to Yahweh to ask for favor and direction in battle, but since Samuel was not there, Saul decided to do Samuel's job himself.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, how do people ask for help from their gods before a battle? Who asks for help or speaks to the gods? Pause this audio here.

Samuel replies that Saul has done a foolish thing. Saul has not kept the command that Yahweh, Saul's God, has given him. Yahweh is Samuel's God, too, but Samuel is emphasizing that because Yahweh is Saul's God, Saul should have obeyed Yahweh. Samuel does not say which command Saul did not follow, but Saul would know which command it was. Because Saul has disobeyed, Yahweh will not establish Saul's kingdom or let Saul's kingdom continue. This means that even though Saul is still king, Saul's descendants will not be kings after Saul.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Think of a king or leader whose children and grandchildren became king after that king died. Pretend you are a teacher who is telling your class about this family of kings. How would you describe the way this king or leader's descendants also ruled as a king or leader? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh has decided to find someone else to appoint or choose as Yahweh's ruler. It is so certain that Yahweh will do this that Samuel says it is already done. Yahweh has found a man after Yahweh's heart. In the original language, people used the word "heart" to describe the deepest part of a person, where people thought, felt, and made decisions. This means that this man is loyal to Yahweh and wants to serve Yahweh. Yahweh has decided to appoint or choose this man to rule Yahweh's people instead of Saul's descendants, because Saul did not keep or follow Yahweh's command.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 13:1–14 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has five scenes.

In the first scene: The writer formally introduces Saul as king and then begins a story that happened while Saul was king. In the story, Saul chooses some of the men for his army and sends the rest home.

In the second scene: Jonathan and his soldiers defeat the soldiers at the Philistine outpost. Because the Philistines are angry at the Israelites for defeating their men at the outpost, Saul sends messengers to gather the Israelite men at Gilgal to fight.

In the third scene: The Philistines gather their army and camp at Mikmash. The Israelites are afraid and many run away.

In the fourth scene: Saul waits seven days at Gilgal for Samuel. When Saul sees how his men are afraid and how Samuel has not yet arrived, Saul decides to offer the burnt offering.

In the fifth scene: Samuel arrives and asks Saul why Saul has done this. Saul says he was afraid to wait any longer for Samuel. Samuel replies that Saul has disobeyed Yahweh, so Yahweh will not let Saul's family continue to rule Israel.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Saul

  • The men of Israel, or the Hebrews

  • Jonathan, Saul's son

  • The Philistine army

  • Samuel

  • And Yahweh

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

The first scene begins with a common statement about the age of the king when he began to rule, and how long the king ruled. In this time, this was a normal way to begin a history or story about a king. This statement gives the setting for the story that the writer will tell next. While the numbers of Saul's age and the length of Saul's rule are not clear here, Saul was a grown man when he became king and probably ruled for about 40 years. You can use the numbers of the translation you are listening to.

Stop here and discuss which numbers you will use here. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Remember the story you told in step two about introducing a leader. How will you introduce Saul in this story? Pause this audio here.

The story begins when Saul chooses men for his army. It is not clear if this happened at the beginning of Saul's time as king or at a later time. All the fighting men of Israel are together, ready for Saul to pick from. Saul chooses 3,000 men to be his active army. These men's job will be to protect the king and the people from any attack. Saul keeps 2,000 men with Saul at, or "in," a camp just outside the town of Mikmash. Mikmash was a town in the hilly country around the town of Bethel.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel as a group. Find the towns of Mikmash and Bethel. Pause this audio here.

Saul puts his son Jonathan in charge of 1,000 men and sends Jonathan and Jonathan's men to the town of Gibeah. Gibeah is in the tribe of Benjamin's territory. Gibeah is across from Mikmash on the south side of a valley. These two towns are good places to defend the area. Saul sends the rest of the men to their tents, which is another way of saying Saul sends them home. If Saul needs a big army for a battle, Saul can gather these men together again.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel as a group. Find the town of Gibeah in Benjamin's territory. Pause this audio here.

In the second scene, Jonathan decides to attack the Philistines. The Philistines had an outpost or camp of soldiers outside the town of Giba, which is probably another name for Gibeah. The Philistine soldiers there would be a threat or danger to the town. It is not clear how long Jonathan has been at Gibeah before he attacks the outpost with his soldiers and defeats the Philistines there.

Someone tells the other Philistines about the attack, and the Philistines are angry. Saul knows that the Philistines will probably try to attack the Israelites, so Saul sends messengers around Israel to gather all the fighting men. These messengers would go to towns and blow trumpets that people had made from rams' horns. The Israelite men would understand that this was a signal that they should gather together for war.

As an activity, have everyone in the group talk to each other. Have one person call out to the others to listen to what the person has to say. Pay attention to the words or phrases you use to get everyone's attention. Pause this audio here.

The messengers also explain why they must gather. Because of the attack on the outpost, the Philistines hate the Israelites like people hate a bad smell.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your language, what words or phrases do you use for things that you hate? What do you compare these things to? Pause this audio here.

When the Israelite men hear this, the men understand that the Philistines will attack soon. Any Israelite man who can fight goes to Saul to join the army. Saul has left Mikmash and gone to Gilgal, probably because this was where the Israelites often gathered.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel as a group. Find the town of Gilgal. Pause this audio here.

In the third scene, the Philistines also gather their army. Some versions say the Philistines have 30,000 chariots, but others say 3,000, which is the more likely number. Two men can ride each chariot, and the Philistines have 6,000 men to ride the chariots and horses. The Philistine soldiers who walk are too many to count. The storyteller says the Philistines are like the grains of sand on the shore of a river or the sea, which no one can count!

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Describe a large group of things, too many to count, like stars in the sky, wheat or rice grains in a field, or a big crowd of people. Pay attention to what words or phrases you use to describe how there are lots of items or people. Pause this audio here.

The Philistines camp outside the town of Mikmash, just east of the town of Beth Aven. The Israelites see how many soldiers the Philistines have and realize that they are in great danger. The Israelites believe that the Philistines will defeat the Israelites and kill them, so many of the Israelite soldiers run away and hide. The Israelites hide in caves, in any kind of hole or pit, among rocks and bushes, and in places to store water. The Israelites even cross the Jordan River to the east and go to the land of the tribe of Gad, and the region of Gilead, just to be further away from the Philistines.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel as a group. Find the Jordan River and the regions of Gad and Gilead. Pause this audio here.

The fourth scene takes place in Gilgal, where Saul is, along with the soldiers who have not run away. These soldiers are still afraid. The soldiers are so afraid that they are shaking with fear. Saul waits for seven days for Samuel to arrive at the appointed time, or the time Samuel said he would. On the seventh day, Samuel has not yet arrived, so Saul decides he cannot wait any longer. Saul's men are scattering or running away, and Saul thinks that he has to do something to stop the men from leaving.

Saul tells people to bring Saul supplies for the burnt offerings and the peace or fellowship offerings. For a burnt offering, a priest would kill an animal and burn the whole animal on an altar. For a fellowship offering, a priest would kill an animal and burn part of it on the altar, and then the people would cook and eat the rest of the animal. Saul offers the burnt offering. Saul may do this by himself, or someone may help Saul, but either way, Saul does not wait for Samuel.

In the fifth scene, Samuel arrives, just after Saul finishes the burnt offering. Samuel has come on the day Samuel said he would come, probably later in the day than Saul expected. Samuel sees the burnt offering and asks Saul why Saul has done this wrong thing.

Saul replies with reasons or excuses for what Saul did. Saul's men were leaving him, so Saul wanted to do something that would cause the men to stay. If Saul's men left, Saul thought he would lose to the Philistines, who may attack at any time. Saul wanted to make sure that the Israelites asked Yahweh for help before they started fighting. Samuel was not there to ask Yahweh for help or instructions, so Saul says he forced himself to offer the burnt offering to ask Yahweh for help, even though that was not Saul's job.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Saul says he forced himself or took the risk of offering the burnt offering, because Saul knew he was not supposed to do that thing. In your language, what words or phrases would you use to describe when someone does something dangerous or something they know they should not do? Pause this audio here.

However, Samuel tells Saul that what Saul did was a very foolish thing to do! This was not what Yahweh told Saul to do. If Saul had done what Yahweh said, then Yahweh would have allowed Saul and his descendants to rule Israel forever. Now this will not happen. Yahweh has already decided to replace Saul with a man whom Yahweh has chosen himself. Samuel says this man will be the ruler over Israel. Again, Samuel uses a different word than king, because Yahweh is really Israel's true king or top ruler. This man is loyal to Yahweh and wants to serve Yahweh. This will happen because Saul did not obey what Yahweh commanded Saul to do.

Stop here and discuss as a group how you will talk about the new ruler as a "man after Yahweh's own heart." Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 13:1–14 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has five scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Saul

  • The men of Israel, or the Hebrews

  • Jonathan, Saul's son

  • The Philistine army

  • Samuel

  • And Yahweh

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

When Saul became king, Saul was 30 years old, and he ruled over Israel for 42 years. Saul chose 3,000 Israelite men to be in Saul's army. Saul ordered 2,000 of these men to stay with Saul at Mikmash, which is in the hills around Bethel. The other 1,000 went with Jonathan to Gibeah in the territory of Benjamin. Saul sent the rest of the men back to their homes.

One day, Jonathan and Jonathan's men defeated the Philistine soldiers at the outpost at Geba. Someone told the rest of the Philistine soldiers what had happened. So Saul ordered some of Saul's soldiers to blow trumpets throughout the land of Israel to signal the Hebrews to gather for war. Throughout all Israel, the people heard that Saul's army had attacked the Philistine garrison and that the Philistine people hated the Israelites now. The Israelite men joined Saul at Gilgal as the messengers told the men to do.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Israelites, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am glad we are finally going to fight back against the Philistines. Maybe, now that we have a king, we can completely defeat the Philistines, so the Philistines will stop bothering us! or

  • One moment I am working in my fields, then I hear the messengers blowing trumpets, and now I am going to go join the army! This is all happening very fast. I hope my family will be safe while I am gone; or

  • I am a little scared to fight the Philistines! I want to defend my people, but I have not trained to be a warrior.

At the same time, the Philistines gathered together to fight against the Israelites. The Philistines had 3,000 chariots, 6,000 horsemen, and many other Philistine soldiers on foot. There were so many Philistines that no one could count them. Then the entire Philistine army went up to Mikmash and camped there, east of the town of Beth Aven.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • The Israelites are too proud and think that they are better than us! We will defeat the Israelites and show them that we are stronger than them; or

  • I am so angry that the Israelites killed some of our people! I want to hurt the Israelites back! or

  • I am excited to go fight. I think we definitely will defeat these people and take their land and all their possessions.

The Israelite soldiers realized that they were in great danger because the Philistine army was much stronger than their army. So the Israelites hid in caves or in thick brush. Others hid behind rocks or in pits and wells. Some of the Hebrews even fled across the Jordan River to the regions of Gad and Gilead.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Israelites, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I saw how many Philistines there are! There is no way we will be able to win! I do not want to die! or

  • If I die, my family will not have anyone to provide for them! Maybe if I hide, I can return home after the Philistines win; or

  • No one can defeat the Philistines. I am upset that Saul started a war that we cannot win! I am not going to stay and follow Saul.

Saul stayed at Gilgal, and all the soldiers who had not already run away were shaking with fear. Saul waited for a week, as Samuel had told Saul to do. However, Samuel did not come to Gilgal during that time. Then Saul's soldiers began to leave Saul. So Saul said, "Bring me the animals for a burnt offering and fellowship offerings." Then Saul offered the burnt offerings himself.

As soon as Saul had sacrificed the burnt offering, Samuel came. Saul went out to welcome Samuel. But Samuel asked Saul, "Why have you done this wrong thing?"

Saul answered, "I had to do it! I saw my soldiers leaving me, and you did not come when you told me you would. Not only that, but the Philistine army was gathering at Mikmash. I realized that the Philistines were coming to attack me here in Gilgal and that I had not done anything to ask Yahweh to help me. So I thought that I had to offer the burnt offering myself."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I did wait for Samuel, but Samuel did not come! Samuel is not Israel's only leader. Since I am the king, I am the next best person to offer the sacrifices; or

  • I do not want to fight the Philistines without Yahweh's help. I will do anything to get Yahweh's help, even if it is in a different way than he told me to; or

  • My army is scared because they have had nothing to do but wait for seven days. I know we have to sacrifice before battle, so I want to go ahead and offer the sacrifices so we can start fighting. Then my men will not have time to think about how scared they are.

Samuel said, "That was a very foolish thing you have done! You did not do what Yahweh your God told you to do. If you had, Yahweh would have allowed you and your descendants to rule over Israel forever. But now that will not happen. You and your offspring will not continue to rule as Israel's kings. Yahweh has decided that he will replace you with a man whom Yahweh has chosen himself. Yahweh has appointed this other man to be the leader of Yahweh's people, because you did not obey what Yahweh commanded you to do."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • These sacrifices are not payment for my help. I help the Israelites because I care about them, and they honor me by doing what I tell them to do. Saul did not do what I told him to, but instead did the job that I gave to Samuel; or

  • I will not refuse to help the Israelites because of Saul's mistake, because I have chosen to make them my people. However, there will be consequences because of what Saul did; or

  • I want to give my people good things and good leaders. I am already prepared to choose another leader, one who will do what is best for the people by following my commands.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am disappointed that Saul did not trust me or Yahweh and did not wait for me. I did what I said I was going to do and came on the day I said I would! or

  • I am pointing out what Saul did wrong so that Saul can learn and not do it again. It is important that a leader makes wise decisions, or that leader could hurt his people! or

  • I am sad that Saul did not do what Yahweh asked Saul to. Yahweh only asks us to do what is best for us!

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 13:1–14 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

This story begins by describing how old Saul was when he became king of Israel. A king was someone who ruled over a city or territory. For more information on king, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for king as you used in previous passages.

Israel is the name of the country where the Israelites lived. For more information on Israel, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Israel as you used in previous passages.

Jonathan attacks the Philistine outpost at Geba. Use the same word or phrase for outpost or army camp that you have used in previous passages.

After Jonathan attacks the Philistines, Saul sends messengers with trumpets around Israel. People made trumpets out of a ram's horn, with a hole at the narrow tip. When someone blew through the hole, the trumpet would make two or three notes. People used trumpets to signal messages, especially messages for gathering the people for war.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a trumpet again, as needed. Pause this audio here.

Stop here as a group and discuss what word or phrase you will use for trumpet. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The messengers say, "You Hebrews! Listen to what we have to say!" The word Hebrew can refer to the descendants of Abraham. People call the descendants of Abraham Israelites, Jews, and sometimes Hebrews. For more information on Hebrew, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Hebrew as you used in previous passages.

The Philistine army has chariots. Chariots were wagon-like vehicles with two wheels. Horses pulled a chariot, and two men, one driver and one warrior, rode the chariot into battle. The warrior would fight the enemy while standing in the chariot. Use the same word or phrase for chariot as you used in previous passages.

Stop here and look at a picture of a chariot again as a group as needed. Pause this audio here.

When the Israelites see the Philistines, the Israelites are afraid and hide in all sorts of holes, such as cisterns. Cisterns are holes that people dig out of rock to store water.

Stop here and look at a picture of a cistern again as a group, as needed. Pause this audio here.

Stop here as a group and discuss what word or phrase you will use for cistern. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Some Israelites cross the Jordan River to hide from the Philistines. The Jordan River is a long river that runs through Israel from north to south. At some times of the year, the river is smaller, and a person can get across the river by wading or swimming through the water.

Stop here and look at a picture of the Jordan River again as a group as needed. Pause this audio here.

Stop here as a group and discuss what word or phrase you will use for Jordan River. Look up Jordan River in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Saul waits seven days, which is the length of time Samuel appointed. Later, Samuel says that Yahweh has already decided to appoint someone else as ruler of Israel. To appoint means to choose something. An appointed time is a time that someone chose. To appoint someone means to assign a job or role to that person. Use the same word or phrase for appoint as you used in previous passages.

When Samuel does not arrive when Saul thinks Samuel should, Saul tells people to bring him the supplies for the burnt offerings and fellowship offerings. A burnt offering is a kind of sacrifice that people bring to God. When a person brings God a burnt offering, he kills an animal and burns this animal completely on an altar, which is a special table or platform that people put gifts to God on. For more information on burnt offering, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for burnt offering as you used in previous passages.

A fellowship offering, also called a peace offering, is an offering that people brought to God to restore peace with someone and to celebrate fellowship with God and people. For more information on peace or fellowship offerings, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for peace or fellowship offering as you used in previous passages.

Samuel says that Saul did not obey the commandment that Yahweh gave to Saul. A commandment refers to the rules that God gave his people. This can be the general rules of God or a rule that God gave to Saul specifically. Samuel does not specifically say which commandment Saul did not obey.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for commandment. Look up commandment in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Yahweh is God's personal name. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Yahweh as you used in previous passages.

Samuel says, "your God," or the God Saul worships. Here, Samuel uses the more general word for God. This is still Yahweh, the God that both Samuel and Saul worship. For more information on God, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for God as you used in previous passages.

Because Saul disobeyed Yahweh, Yahweh will not let Saul's kingdom continue. Here, kingdom means the role or position of a king. Yahweh is saying that Saul's family would not continue to have the role of king after Saul died.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for kingdom when it refers to someone's descendants having the role of king. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Yahweh has decided to choose someone else to be the ruler of Israel. In the original language, this word for ruler or chosen leader is not the same word as king. Use the same word or phrase for ruler as you used in previous passages.

This new ruler will be "a man after God's own heart." In the original language, people used the word "heart" to describe the deepest part of a person, where people thought, felt, and made decisions. This means that this man is loyal to Yahweh and wants to serve Yahweh. See the Master Glossary for more information about heart. If you use the word for heart in your translation, use the same word that you have used in previous passages.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 13:15–23
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 13:15–23 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 13:15–23 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 13:15–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

This story explains why the Philistine army was such a danger to the Israelites. Samuel leaves the Israelite army, and the Philistines send out groups of soldiers to attack the Israelite people. The Philistines have stopped the Israelite craftsmen from making weapons. When it is time to fight, only Saul and Jonathan have swords and spears. This shows how great Yahweh's victory will be in the later stories, since the Israelites had no swords or spears with which to save themselves.

This story begins when Samuel leaves Saul and the army. Some translations say that Samuel left Gilgal and went to the town of Geba, which is probably another name for Gibeah. Other translations say that Samuel went on his way while Saul and Saul's army went to Gibeah. This second option better matches information from later in the story.

Gibeah is in the territory of the tribe of Benjamin. When Saul arrives there, Saul counts all his soldiers, but there are only about 600 who did not run away in the last story. While the Israelites camp at Gibeah, the Philistines are still at the town of Mikmash, which is not far away. The Philistines send out raiding parties, or groups of soldiers who attack any Israelites they meet. These Philistine soldiers steal or destroy the Israelites' belongings and food supplies.

There are three groups of these Philistine soldiers. The first group goes north, toward the town of Ophrah in the region of Shual. The next group goes west toward the town of Beth Horon. The third group goes east to a range of hills near the valley of Zeboyim. These hills are on the edge of a wilderness, or a place where no one lives.

The storyteller gives us the extra information that it is hard for the Israelites to defend themselves because the Philistines have stopped any blacksmith from working in Israel. Blacksmiths are people who can make tools and weapons from iron. Iron swords and spears were the strongest weapons at that time, and only a blacksmith could make them. The Philistines said they did not want the Hebrews making swords and spears. Hebrew is another word for Israelite. Other nations used the word Hebrew to insult the Israelites.

Stop here and look at a picture of swords and spears as a group. Pause the audio here.

Stop here and discuss these questions as a group: In your culture, what materials do people make weapons out of? What are the best or strongest materials for these weapons? What do you call the people who make these weapons? Pause this audio here.

So if any Israelite needed to have their iron farm tools sharpened or repaired, that person had to pay a Philistine blacksmith to do it. The Israelites had iron plowshares to break up the dirt to prepare to plant seeds. The Israelites also had mattocks or hoes, which are metal tools for digging in the dirt. The Israelites had axes, which people used to cut down trees, and sickles, which people used for harvesting grain.

Stop here and look at a picture of plowshares, mattocks or hoes, axes, and sickles as a group. What tools do you have in your culture that look similar to these? Who usually repairs these tools? Pause this audio here.

The Philistines made the Israelites pay very high prices. The Israelites had to pay two-thirds of a shekel or piece of silver to sharpen or repair a plow, a mattock or hoe, a pitchfork, an ax, or a goad. A pitchfork was a three-pronged metal tool that people used to lift grass or hay. A goad is a long stick with a sharp metal point. If a farmer wanted an animal to move or go forward, the farmer would jab the animal with the goad. Some translations say the Israelites paid one-third of a shekel for the last three tools. Either way, these were high prices.

Stop here and look at a picture of pitchforks and goads as a group. Pause this audio here.

Tell a story about a time when something important broke and there was no one nearby who could repair that thing. What did you do? Pause this audio here.

So whenever there was a battle, none of the Israelite soldiers who were with Saul and Jonathan had a sword or spear to fight with. Only Saul and Jonathan had swords and spears. The Israelites are in danger, since they have only a small army, with no swords or spears, and the Philistine army is not far away.

And the Philistines move even closer. The Philistines send the main group of their army to the pass of Mikmash. Remember from the last story that the two armies are on opposite sides of the valley. The valley is hard to cross, except at the pass. Now the Philistines are at the pass, ready to defend themselves or attack Saul's army.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 13:15–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has three scenes.

In the first scene: Samuel leaves Gilgal and goes away. Saul and the army also leave Gilgal and go to Gibeah, where Saul counts his men. The Philistines send groups of soldiers north, west, and east to attack the Israelites.

In the second scene: The Israelites have no swords and spears to defend against these attacks because the Philistines had stopped any blacksmiths from working in Israel. When the Israelites needed someone to repair their tools for farming, the Israelites had to take the tools to Philistine blacksmiths.

In the third scene: A large group of Philistines move from their main camp to the pass at Mikmash.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel

  • Saul

  • Jonathan, Saul's son

  • The Israelite army

  • The Philistine army, including their raiding parties

  • The Israelite farmers

  • And the Philistine blacksmiths

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

At the end of the last passage, Saul and Samuel were at Gilgal with the Israelite soldiers who had not run away. This story begins by describing where everyone goes next. In the first scene, Samuel leaves the Israelite army. Saul and the army also leave Gilgal and travel to Gibeah, which is in the territory of Benjamin.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel as a group. Find the towns of Gilgal and Gibeah. Pause this audio here.

Jonathan and his group of soldiers have probably been at Geba, or Gibeah, this whole time. When Saul arrives there too, Saul counts the men he brought with him and those who are already at Gibeah. There are about 600 men. All the other men who had gathered together in the last story have run away.

Meanwhile, the Philistines are still camped at the town of Mikmash, which is north of Gibeah. The towns of Mikmash and Gibeah are only a few miles away from each other, separated by a deep valley. The valley was hard to cross except at the pass, or safe crossing, of Mikmash.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel as a group. Find the towns of Mikmash and Gibeah. Pause this audio here.

The Philistines send out three raiding groups of soldiers north, west, and east to attack the Israelites. One group of Philistines goes north towards the town of Ophrah, which is in the region of Shual. Ophrah is about eight kilometers north of Mikmash. One group goes west toward the town of Beth Horon, which is about 16 kilometers from Mikmash. The last group goes east towards the ridge of hills and the Valley of Zeboyim. A wilderness is just beyond these hills. The Israelite army cannot stop these raiding groups because the Philistine army is blocking the way north. It would be too difficult to pass by or through the Philistines' main army camped at Mikmash and the soldiers the Philistines sent to guard the pass.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel as a group. Find the towns of Ophrah and Beth Horon, as well as the Valley of Zeboyim. Pause this audio here.

The second scene explains why the Israelites could not protect themselves well from these attacks. The storyteller pauses the story to explain something that had been happening in the past. The Philistines wanted to keep the Israelites from making iron swords and spears, so the Philistines stopped any blacksmiths from working in the land of Israel. The Philistines may have sent other raiding parties in the past to kill, capture, or attack any blacksmith in Israel. When Israelite farmers' tools broke, the farmers had to travel to the Philistines' land and pay Philistine blacksmiths for a repair. And the Philistines probably would not make or repair any weapons for the Israelites.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: As an activity, tell a story about something that happened during a dangerous time in your people's history. At some point in the story, explain why it was a dangerous time. Pay attention to how and when you choose to explain this. Pause this audio here.

So now, when the Israelites are gathered together with Saul at Gibeah, none of the Israelites have swords or spears except for Saul and his son Jonathan. The army may have had other weapons which they made out of wood, stone, and other metals, but nothing as strong as the iron weapons that the Philistines had.

In the third scene, a garrison, or large group of the Philistine army, moves from the Philistines' main camp by the town to the pass in order to defend it.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 13:15–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has three scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel

  • Saul

  • Jonathan, Saul's son

  • The Israelite army

  • The Philistine army, including their raiding parties

  • The Israelite farmers

  • And the Philistine blacksmiths

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Then Samuel left Gilgal and went on his way. The rest of the men followed Saul as Saul went to join his other soldiers. The men went from Gilgal to Gibeah in the territory of Benjamin. There Saul counted the soldiers who were still with Saul. There were only about 600 men.

Saul and his son Jonathan and their soldiers were camping at Gibeah in Benjamin. As for the Philistine army, they were camped at Mikmash. The Philistine soldiers went out from their camp in three groups to go on raids. The first group went north toward the town of Ophrah in the region of Shual. The next group went west toward the town of Beth Horon. The third group went east to the bordering hills that overlook the Valley of Zeboyim toward the wilderness.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • It will be easy to take anything we want from the Israelites. The Israelites' army would have to fight our army to stop our raiding groups, but they are not strong enough to do so; or

  • We hate the Israelites because they attacked our outpost. We want to steal from the Israelites to punish and humiliate them; or

  • Since there are so many soldiers in our army, we need lots of food and supplies. We can just take these supplies from the Israelites around us!

Before this story happened, the Philistines wanted to keep the Israelites from making iron swords and spears, so they prevented blacksmiths from working in any part of the land of Israel. When the Israelites needed to have their plows, hoes, axes, and sickles sharpened, the Israelites had to take them to Philistine blacksmiths. The Israelites had to pay a lot of money for the repairs: two-thirds of a shekel to sharpen plows, hoes, pitchforks, axes, and to repair cow goads.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Israelite people, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I do not feel safe, since no one in our army has iron weapons. The Philistines could attack any time, and I do not think we could stop them! or

  • I am angry that the Philistines have stopped the blacksmiths from working here. The Philistines do what they want in our land, and we cannot stop them! or

  • I cannot afford the time and money to travel to a Philistine blacksmith. If my tools break, I am worried that I will not be able to repair them. Then I cannot work on my farm and grow food for my family!

So when the Israelites went into battle against the Philistines, only Saul and his son Jonathan had swords and spears. A large group of Philistine soldiers had gone to the pass at Mikmash.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Israelite soldiers, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am scared to fight the Philistine soldiers! The Philistines have more soldiers, and when we fight, their weapons are so strong that they can break our weapons! We are going to die! or

  • I am determined to stay with Saul and the army to defend my people, even though the Philistines are stronger than we are. I hope our God saves us! or

  • I feel ashamed that we do not have the strongest weapons and that we cannot stop the Philistines from attacking our people.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I do not know what to do. Samuel has just scolded me and left. I am not sure if Yahweh will help us, since I disobeyed Yahweh's command. My army does not even have enough weapons! or

  • I am sad that I cannot defend my people from the Philistine raiding groups. Maybe I am not a good king or leader! or

  • I wish Jonathan and I could use our swords and spears to defend my people, but I know it will not be enough. I feel useless!

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 13:15–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

One group of Philistine soldiers goes south towards the wilderness. A wilderness is an empty place without water. There are almost no trees or bushes growing in a wilderness. The ground is dry and rocky, and there are wild animals roaming around. For more information on wilderness, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for wilderness as you used in previous passages.

The Philistines have stopped any blacksmiths or craftsmen from working in the land of Israel. A blacksmith is a person who can make and repair tools and weapons from iron.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for blacksmith. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The Philistines say that they do not want the Hebrews to make swords or spears. Foreigners often referred to the Israelites as Hebrews. For more information on Hebrew, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Hebrew as you used in previous passages. Use the same word or phrase for swords and spears as you used in previous passages.

The Israelites had to pay Philistine blacksmiths to repair their plows, hoes, axes, sickles, pitchforks, and goads. Most of these tools had a wooden handle and a metal blade or sharp end. A plow is a farm tool with a metal blade called a plowshare. People used plows to break up the dirt for planting seeds. Animals often pulled the plow. People also used hoes or mattocks for digging in the dirt. An ax had a shorter handle. People used axes to cut down bushes or trees. A sickle had a curved blade. People used sickles for harvesting grain. A pitchfork or a three-pronged fork had a long handle and three sharp metal prongs. People used pitchforks to lift hay or grass. A goad is a long stick with a sharp metal point. If a farmer wanted an animal to move or go forward, the farmer would jab the animal with the goad.

Stop here and look at the pictures of a plow, mattock or hoe, ax, sickle, pitchfork, and goad as a group again as needed. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for plow, mattock or hoe, ax, sickle, pitchfork, and goad. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The Israelites had to pay two-thirds of a shekel for these repairs. A shekel is a unit of weight. One shekel is 11.4 grams, so two-thirds of a shekel is about 9 grams of silver. For more information on shekel, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for shekel or piece of silver as you used in previous passages.

The Philistines moved the main group of their army to the pass. A pass is a safe route through rough or dangerous ground.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for pass. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
