title: 1 Samuel 14:1–15
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 14:1–15 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:1–15 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:1–15 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

At the end of the last section, the Philistines sent a group of their soldiers to the pass, or the valley's safe crossing. In this story, Saul's son Jonathan goes to look at the Philistine camp with another soldier. Jonathan trusts that God will show Jonathan whether he should attack the Philistines. When God does give Jonathan a sign, Jonathan and the other soldier attack. The Philistines are terrified because God is helping the Israelites.

This section begins by introducing the main characters in the story and what those characters will do. Jonathan, Saul's son, speaks to the young man who is Jonathan's armor-bearer. In that time, a soldier would often go into battle with another man who carried the soldier's shield and sometimes his other weapons, such as a sword, spear, bow, and arrows. The two men would fight together as a team, with the armor-bearer giving the soldier weapons as the soldier needed them. The armor-bearer would also protect the soldier from attacks from behind.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, how do soldiers work together when they fight? What role or responsibility does each person have? Pause this audio here.

Jonathan suggests that he and his armor-bearer go towards the Philistine outpost or army camp on the other side of the valley, probably to see what the Philistines are doing. Jonathan does not tell Saul, perhaps because Jonathan does not want to worry Saul or because Jonathan thinks that Saul will tell Jonathan not to go.

Then the storyteller gives some background information about Saul and the rest of the army. Saul is staying, or temporarily living, outside of the town of Gibeah. Saul is staying near a tree that grows fruit called pomegranates. Pomegranate trees can grow up to 10 meters tall, and leaders often sat and made decisions by trees. This tree was near a place called Migron, which may have been a threshing floor, a large flat space where people would prepare grain.

Stop here and look at a picture of a pomegranate tree and a threshing floor as a group. Pause this audio here.

The 600 soldiers in the Israelite army are near Saul, as is the priest, Ahijah. Yahweh's priests all come from the same family, so the writer lists Ahijah's family line or ancestry to show that Ahijah is really a priest. Ahijah's grandfather, Eli, served Yahweh as a priest at Shiloh, where Yahweh's place of worship was. Ahijah has the ephod. In the original language, this word can mean a sacred garment which only the high priest wore, and which possibly looked like a vest with a pocket. It can also mean the objects that priests used to determine God's will, which priests probably kept in or near the sacred garment. We are not sure which object Ahijah has here.

Stop here and look at a picture of the high priest's ephod as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, when would you announce or remind people of someone's family line? Why is it important to know a person's family line? Pause this audio here.

None of these people knows that Jonathan leaves the camp with his armor-bearer. Jonathan plans to cross at a pass or safe place to cross the valley. This valley separates the Israelite army at Gibeah from the Philistines at the town of Mikmash. There are cliffs or rocks on the north and south sides of the pass. People named the cliff on one side Bozez, which means shining or slippery, and they called the cliff on the other side Seneh, which means thorny. It would be hard to cross the valley by going over these cliffs instead of the pass!

Stop here and look at the drawing of the pass as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Where are some areas of land that are rough or dangerous near you? What makes these places dangerous? What do you call these places? Pause this audio here.

Now that the storyteller has described the area and people around Jonathan, he then returns to Jonathan's suggestion to look at the Philistine camp. Jonathan insults the Philistines by calling them uncircumcised. The Israelites were all circumcised as a sign of God's promise with the Israelites. The Israelites considered uncircumcised men to be very bad since those men were not part of God's promise.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, what do you call people who are not a part of your people group? What are some nice names? What are some names that can be insults? Pause this audio here.

Jonathan says that perhaps Yahweh will help them. Jonathan does not doubt Yahweh, but understands that Yahweh does not have to act. Perhaps Yahweh will help Jonathan and his armor-bearer now, or maybe Yahweh will help the Israelites later. Jonathan is confident that Yahweh will fight for Israel and that nothing can stop Yahweh from saving Yahweh's people. Jonathan knows that with Yahweh on their side, even a small number of men can win a victory.

Jonathan's armor-bearer shows how loyal he is in his response. Jonathan's armor-bearer agrees with whatever plan Jonathan has and is willing to do anything to help Jonathan succeed. Jonathan's armor-bearer says that his heart and soul, or all of him, is completely loyal to Jonathan.

Jonathan then explains Jonathan's plan. Jonathan says that he and his armor-bearer should come out of hiding so that the Philistines can see them. If the Philistines tell them to wait, then Jonathan and his armor-bearer will not go near the Philistines. But if the Philistines tell the two men to come to the outpost, then this will be a sign from Yahweh. Jonathan says this sign will show that Yahweh has given the Philistines into their hands, or that Yahweh is going to help them defeat the Philistines. Jonathan trusts that Yahweh will cause the Philistines to speak these words in order to show Jonathan what to do.

Jonathan and his armor-bearer come out of hiding so the Philistine soldiers at the outpost can see them. The Philistines say, "Look! The Hebrews are crawling out of the holes they have been hiding in!" Other people groups used the word Hebrews for the Israelites. The Philistines are insulting the two Israelites by comparing them to animals crawling out of the holes they live in.

The Philistines urge Jonathan and his armor-bearer to come up to the outpost so the Philistines can teach the men a lesson. This was a way of challenging the men to fight. The Philistines want to show that they know more about fighting than the Israelites.

Since the Philistines say to come up, Jonathan knows that God will cause Jonathan to be victorious, so he and his armor-bearer go up the hill towards the outpost. The hillside is steep and difficult to climb, so Jonathan has to use his hands as well as his feet. When the two men reach the Philistines, Jonathan starts to knock down the Philistine soldiers. Then Jonathan's armor-bearer comes along behind to where the Philistines have fallen and kills these men. The Philistines start to run away, but the two Israelites follow their enemies and kill 20 Philistines over an area of about one-quarter of a hectare. This storyteller compares this area to a field small enough to be plowed by a pair of oxen in half a day to show how small this area is.

Then the entire Philistine army begins to panic, including those who are at their camp and in the countryside. The soldiers in the outpost and raiding parties shake because they are so afraid. There is also an earthquake. In that time, people understood that an earthquake showed that God was involved in whatever was happening. This panic was from God. In the original language, people said that something was from God to mean either that God caused something to happen, or to show how big and bad something is.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:1–15 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has five scenes.

In the first scene: Jonathan plans to go and look at the Philistine camp with his armor-bearer. Jonathan does not tell his plans to Saul, Ahijah, or the 600 Israelite soldiers who are outside Gibeah.

In the second scene: The storyteller describes the pass that Jonathan plans to cross.

In the third scene: Jonathan speaks to his armor-bearer and suggests crossing the valley. The armor-bearer agrees to do what Jonathan says. Jonathan then explains how Jonathan will know if Yahweh will help them or not.

In the fourth scene: Jonathan and his armor-bearer go towards the Philistine soldiers, who see them. The Philistines tell Jonathan and his armor-bearer to come to the outpost. Jonathan tells his armor-bearer that Yahweh will help the men defeat the Philistines.

In the fifth scene: Jonathan and his armor-bearer climb up to the outpost and kill 20 Philistines. The whole Philistine army begins to panic.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Jonathan

  • Jonathan's armor-bearer

  • The Philistine soldiers in the outpost, main army, and raiding groups

  • Saul

  • Six hundred Israelite soldiers

  • Ahijah

  • Ahijah's family: Ichabod, Ahitub, Phinehas, and Eli

  • And Yahweh

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

This story begins in the same place as the last story. The Israelite army is camped near the town of Gibeah. To the north, across a steep valley with cliffs on either side, the Philistine army is camped near the town of Mikmash. There is a safe crossing place across this valley called the Mikmash pass, and the Philistines have sent a group of soldiers to block the pass. Mikmash and Gibeah are about six kilometers apart. Jonathan and his armor-bearer are with Saul's army at Gibeah.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel as a group. Find the towns of Mikmash and Gibeah. Pause this audio here.

In the first scene, the storyteller introduces what the story will be about. Then the storyteller gives the context and setting for the story. The storyteller says, "This story will be about the time when Jonathan shared his plan to spy on the Philistine outpost with his armor-bearer, but did not tell anyone else."

The people Jonathan did not tell his plans to are nearby. Saul, Jonathan's father, is staying or temporarily living near a pomegranate tree. This tree is near a place called Migron. It is not clear what this place is, but it may be a threshing floor, which was a flat, open space that was a good place to gather.

The 600 soldiers in the Israelite army are staying near Saul. These soldiers are near enough to protect their king, but also probably spread out so that everyone can have room. Ahijah, the priest, is near Saul as well. Though Ahijah does not do much in this story, the storyteller introduces Ahijah here so Ahijah will not be a surprise when he does act in the later stories.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story with several characters that you have to introduce to your listeners. Pay attention to when you introduce these characters. After you finish the story, discuss why you chose to introduce each character when and how you did. Pause this audio here.

Ahijah's grandfather, Eli, served as Yahweh's priest in the town of Shiloh. Ahijah is either carrying or wearing an ephod, the special clothing for the high priest. Jonathan is probably staying near Saul, too, but none of these people sees Jonathan leave the Israelite camp with his armor-bearer.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel as a group. Find the town of Shiloh. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In what order do you list a person's family line in your language? Listen again to how your translation lists Ahijah's family line. Discuss how you will list Ahijah's family line. Pause this audio here.

In the second scene, the writer describes the pass that Jonathan and his armor-bearer must cross to get to the outpost. There are two cliffs or sharp rocks, one on either side of the pass. One cliff is located on the north, near Mikmash, and the other on the south, near Geba, which is probably another name for the town of Gibeah. People call the first cliff Bozez, which means slippery, and the second cliff Senah, which means thorny. This valley is rough and hard to cross, so people have to cross at the pass.

In the third scene, the storyteller has finished explaining the people and the land around Jonathan, so the storyteller now returns to Jonathan's conversation with Jonathan's armor-bearer. The storyteller repeats Jonathan's words from the beginning of the section, but now he shows the rest of the conversation.

Stop here and discuss as a group: As an activity, tell a story about something funny or interesting that happened recently. To begin, announce what the story is about, like the storyteller does here. Then explain the setting, such as the date or where you were when it happened. Next, you can explain what happened. Discuss how this is similar or different from ways that you normally tell stories. Pause this audio here.

Jonathan is speaking to his armor-bearer, and the men are somewhere where no one else can hear them. Jonathan suggests that they go over to the Philistine outpost. The two men may just see what the Philistine soldiers are doing, but if Yahweh helps the men, they may be able to do more. Jonathan knows that nothing is more powerful than Yahweh and that Yahweh will help the Israelites. Yahweh can act through a large group of soldiers, or just a few, like Jonathan and Jonathan's armor-bearer.

Jonathan has not yet finished explaining his plan, but Jonathan's armor-bearer is so loyal that the man does not even need to hear the plan before he agrees. The armor-bearer says that Jonathan should go ahead and do what Jonathan thinks is best. The armor-bearer declares that he is ready to follow and support Jonathan.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: The armor-bearer says that his heart and his soul are with Jonathan. This means that the armor-bearer is completely loyal and ready to follow Jonathan. Describe a person who is completely loyal to someone else. Pay attention to the words or phrases in your language that mean someone is completely devoted or loyal to someone else. Pause this audio here.

Jonathan then explains how the men can learn if Yahweh will help them defeat the Philistines. Jonathan and his armor-bearer should go towards the Philistine outpost until the Philistine soldiers can see the two men. If the Philistines say "Wait," Jonathan and his armor-bearer will not continue climbing up to the outpost. But if Yahweh causes the Philistines to say, "Come to the outpost," then the two men will climb up. This will be how Yahweh will show that Yahweh has given the Philistines "into Jonathan's hands," or into Jonathan's power. Then Jonathan will know what to do.

In the fourth scene, Jonathan and his armor-bearer cross the pass and walk towards the outpost until the Philistines see the two men. The Philistine outpost was on the edge of the pass or on a hill nearby. The Philistines would be higher than the pass and probably could see if anyone was trying to cross it.

The Philistines point out Jonathan and his armor-bearer and speak to one another. The Philistines make fun of the Israelites and then yell out to Jonathan and his companion to come up. The Philistines are challenging Jonathan and his armor-bearer to fight, because the Philistines think they can easily beat two men. Jonathan, however, knows that this means Yahweh will help them, so Jonathan tells his armor-bearer to follow him up to the outpost.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your language, what words or phrases do people use to challenge someone else to fight? Pause this audio here.

In the fifth scene, Jonathan and his armor-bearer climb up to the outpost. Even though this is the safe crossing, it is still steep, and the two men have to use both their hands and feet to climb safely. When they reach the soldiers at the top of the hill, Jonathan begins to knock down the Philistine soldiers, probably using his sword. The armor-bearer follows behind Jonathan and kills the Philistines who had fallen. The armor-bearer may have his own weapon, or he may be using Jonathan's iron spear. The two men kill 20 Philistine men in the space of a quarter of a hectare. To help people understand the size of this area, the storyteller compares it to a field that a person and their ox can plow or prepare for planting in one day.

After Jonathan and the armor-bearer kill 20 men, the ground shakes in an earthquake, and the whole Philistine army begins to panic. The soldiers in the outpost nearby, as well as in the camp or out in the fields, are terrified. Even the soldiers who are far away in the raiding groups and cannot see Jonathan begin to panic and shake with fear. God has made the Philistines all afraid.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:1–15 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has five scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Jonathan

  • Jonathan's armor-bearer

  • The Philistine soldiers in the outpost, main army, and raiding groups

  • Saul

  • Six hundred Israelite soldiers

  • Ahijah

  • Ahijah's family: Ichabod, Ahitub, Phinehas, and Eli

  • And Yahweh

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

One day, Saul's son Jonathan said to the soldier who carried Jonathan's weapons, "Let us cross over the pass to the Philistine camp to observe our enemy there." But Jonathan did not tell his father, Saul, what Jonathan planned to do.

At this time, Saul was camping under the pomegranate tree at Migron on the edge of Gibeah. There were about 600 men with Saul. Ahijah the priest, who was wearing the ephod, was also there. Ahijah was the son of Ichabod's brother Ahitub. Ahitub was the son of Phinehas, who was the son of Eli, who had been Yahweh's priest in the city of Shiloh. No one was aware that Jonathan and Jonathan's armor-bearer had left the Israelite camp.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am thankful that 600 of my soldiers are still with me, but I do not know how we will be able to defeat the Philistines. The Philistines have many more soldiers than we do! or

  • I am not sure what to do now. Maybe God will speak to Ahijah and give me a message about how to defeat the Philistines; or

  • There are so many things that I have to pay attention to. I have to make sure my soldiers can eat, make sure that more do not run away, and plan what we are going to do! I do not have time to pay attention to everything, not even where my son is right now!

Jonathan and his armor-bearer planned to go through the pass at Mikmash in order to reach the Philistine outpost. On each side of the pass was a steep cliff. People called one cliff Bozez and the other cliff Seneh. The first cliff was on the north side of the pass facing Mikmash, and the other cliff was on the south side of the pass facing Geba.

Jonathan said to the young man carrying Jonathan's weapons, "Come with me across to the camp of those Philistines who do not know God. Perhaps Yahweh will help us to defeat them. Nothing can stop Yahweh from saving his people. It does not matter whether there are many soldiers fighting on our side or only a few."

Jonathan's helper replied, "Do whatever you think best. Lead the way. I will certainly support you."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the armor-bearer, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I know that Jonathan is a smart man, so I trust that Jonathan will have a good plan; or

  • Jonathan's trust in Yahweh encourages me to trust in Yahweh too! Yahweh will certainly help us Israelites, and Yahweh surely will protect Jonathan and me too; or

  • It is my responsibility to protect and support Jonathan, and I am determined to do so, whatever Jonathan decides to do.

Jonathan said to the armor-bearer, "All right, here is my plan. We will cross the valley and go toward the Philistines so that they can see us. If the Philistines tell us to stop and wait until they come to us, then we will stay right there and not continue climbing up to them. But if the Philistines tell us to go on up to where they are, then we will climb up to them. That will be how Yahweh tells us that he will help us defeat the Philistines."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Jonathan, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I trust that Yahweh will help the Israelites. I also trust that Yahweh will guide me to do what he wants me to do. I know that Yahweh's plans are the best plans! or

  • My armor-bearer's loyalty and trust encourage me. I feel braver and safer since my armor-bearer is with me; or

  • I am glad that we serve such a powerful God. By ourselves, our 600 soldiers would certainly lose against the thousands of Philistines! But Yahweh can give us victory even if it is just me and my armor-bearer.

The two men walked towards the outpost so that the Philistine soldiers at the outpost could see the men. The Philistines said, "Look! The Hebrews are crawling out of the holes they have been hiding in!"

Then the outpost soldiers shouted to Jonathan and his helper, "Climb up here and we will teach you a lesson!"

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I have seen how the Hebrews run away when they see the size of our army. I am not worried about these two men coming towards us. We will easily beat these men! or

  • I am bored of sitting and guarding this pass. An easy fight will make the day more interesting; or

  • Perhaps these Hebrews are giving up and will give us information about what the other Hebrews are doing. If they do, maybe we can defeat the Hebrew army faster.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I see how Jonathan is trusting in my strength to save him, instead of Jonathan's own strength. Because Jonathan trusts me, I will listen to Jonathan's request to show him what to do and help him defeat the Philistines; or

  • I want to save and protect my chosen people, even if many of them are running away or their king, Saul, does not do what I tell him to; or

  • I rule over everyone on earth, even the people like the Philistines who do not serve me. I will cause the Philistines to speak in a certain way.

So Jonathan said to his companion, "Follow me up the hill. Yahweh is going to enable us, the Israelites, to defeat the Philistines."

Jonathan climbed up on his hands and feet, and Jonathan's companion climbed up after him. Jonathan started to knock down the Philistine soldiers. Then Jonathan's companion came along behind to where the Philistines had fallen and killed each man. In this first attack, Jonathan and his companion killed about 20 Philistine soldiers. This happened over an area of about one-quarter of a hectare.

Then the entire Philistine army began to panic, including those at the camp and those in the countryside. The soldiers in the outpost and raiding parties trembled with fear. There was an earthquake. It was God who caused all the Philistines to be terrified.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I do not understand how two Hebrews have killed so many of our men! If two of their soldiers fight this well, the Hebrews will not need many soldiers to defeat us! or

  • Two Hebrews are defeating our larger group of soldiers, and the ground is shaking. This is not normal. A god must be helping the Hebrews! We cannot defeat a god! or

  • I am more afraid than I have ever been in my life! I am so afraid that I am shaking, and I cannot think of what I should do!

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:1–15 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Jonathan explains his plan to the young man who is Jonathan's armor-bearer. An armor-bearer carries the large shield of his commanding officer and sometimes that man's other weapons, such as a sword, spear, bow, and arrows. An armor-bearer is responsible for protecting the commanding officer during a battle, and the two men fight together as a team.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for armor-bearer. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Jonathan wants to go towards the Philistine outpost. An outpost is an army camp where soldiers stay so they can guard or watch over an area. Use the same word or phrase for outpost as you used in previous passages.

Saul is staying by a pomegranate tree. These plants are large shrubs, and some may grow as tall as 10 meters. Pomegranate trees have bright green leaves and bright scarlet blossoms that grow into round red fruits people call pomegranates.

Stop here as a group and look again at a picture of a pomegranate tree as needed. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for pomegranate. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Ahijah has the ephod. The ephod is a piece of clothing for priests. The ephod has lots of beautiful decorations and designs. For more information on ephod, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for ephod as you used in previous passages.

Ahijah is Eli's grandson. Eli had been Yahweh's priest. Yahweh is God's personal name. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Yahweh as you used in previous passages.

A priest is a person who serves God, presenting offerings and prayers on behalf of the people. For more information on priest, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for priest as you used in previous passages.

The Mikmash pass has sharp cliffs on either side. A pass is a safe route through rough or dangerous ground. Use the same word or phrase for pass as you used in previous passages.

Jonathan refers to the Philistines as uncircumcised men, or men who are not circumcised. Circumcision is the Jewish custom where people cut off the loose skin at the end of a boy's penis. The circumcision was a sign that the person was included in the covenant that God had made with Abraham. Jonathan is insulting the Philistines by saying that the Philistines are not included in this special covenant.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for uncircumcised. Look up circumcision in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Jonathan trusts that Yahweh will give him a sign. A sign is something unusual that happens for a special reason. God can give a sign to tell people that something God tells them is true. For more information on sign, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for sign as you used in previous passages.

The Philistines say, "Look at the Hebrews!" The word Hebrew can refer to the Israelites. People from other groups or nations often used this word. For more information on Hebrew, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Hebrew as you used in previous passages.

Jonathan says that Yahweh has let Israel defeat the Philistines. Israel can refer to the Israelite people as well as the country where the Israelites lived. For more information on Israel, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Israel as you used in previous passages.

The panic the Philistines feel is of God. This is the general word for God, or Yahweh, and can mean that God sent the panic or that it is very large and bad. For more information on God, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for God as you used in previous passages.

There is also an earthquake. An earthquake is when huge groups of rocks under the ground shift and cause the ground to shake.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for earthquake. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 14:16–23
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 14:16–23 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:16–23 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:16–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the last story, King Saul's son, Jonathan, attacked the Philistine soldiers, who began to panic. In this story, the Israelite army sees the confusion in the Philistine camp. Saul begins the process to ask Yahweh for guidance, but then decides to lead the army to fight the Philistines, who had started to kill each other in their panic. Yahweh causes the Israelites to defeat the much larger group of Philistines.

This story begins when Saul's lookouts see the Philistine soldiers who are panicking. Lookouts are soldiers who guard a place by watching out for the enemy. These lookouts are at Gibeah or Geba, which may be different names for the same town in the territory of Benjamin. The lookouts can see the Philistines scattering in all directions. The storyteller compares the way the army scatters with the way ice or wax melts and spreads in the heat.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, when soldiers camp somewhere, how do the soldiers keep the camp safe? Who has the role of looking out for danger? Where do these people watch from? Pause this audio here.

When Saul hears that the Philistine soldiers are scattering, Saul realizes that someone from the Israelite army must have left their camp to attack the Philistines. So Saul commands his men to gather the soldiers in order to find out who is missing. The men discover that Jonathan and the man who carries Jonathan's armor are missing.

Then Saul instructs Ahijah the priest to bring the ark of God to Saul. Saul probably wants to ask God about what is happening. The ark of God, or the ark of the covenant, is a box that people covered in gold. This box symbolizes God's presence. Some translations say that Saul instructs Ahijah to bring the ephod, or the priest's vest. However, since Ahijah is already wearing or carrying the ephod, Saul probably asks for the ark. While the ark is normally at the town of Kiriath Jearim, the ark is probably with the army during this time. The Israelites believed that if they took the ark with them into battle, then Yahweh would also go with the Israelites and give them victory.

Stop here and look at a picture of the ark of God as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, when soldiers go out to fight, what kind of religious items or symbols do the soldiers bring with them? Why do the soldiers bring these items? Pause this audio here.

At the same time that Saul is speaking to Ahijah, the noisy chaos among the Philistine soldiers is getting louder. Saul then tells Ahijah to withdraw his hand. Here, "withdraw your hand" probably means something like "Stop! There is no time to do that now." It is not clear exactly what the priest is about to do. The priest may be about to use the ark and maybe the ephod to find out God's will or ask for God's favor. But the confusion has become so great that Saul believes there is no time to do this.

Saul calls all of his soldiers together and attacks the Philistine army. By this time, the Philistines are so confused that they are killing each other with their swords. In the Philistine camp, there are Hebrews who joined the Philistines before this battle, perhaps as hired soldiers. But when the Hebrews see the Philistine army scattering, the Hebrews join their fellow Israelites. The storyteller calls them "Hebrews" instead of Israelites, perhaps to show that they are different than the Israelites who normally live in the land of Israel. We also know from previous stories that there are other Israelite soldiers who had run away earlier from the Israelite army and hidden. These soldiers hear that the Philistines are scattering, so these soldiers also join the battle.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, how would you describe people from your people group who no longer live in your native land? How would you describe people from your people group who live with another people group that is your enemy? Pause this audio here.

The storyteller finishes the story by saying that this is how Yahweh saves the Israelites. Yahweh enables Jonathan to defeat the soldiers at the outpost, causes the Philistines to panic, and brings more soldiers to fight for the Israelites. The Philistines run away, and the Israelites continue to attack their enemies all the way to the town of Beth Aven.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:16–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has three scenes.

In the first scene: The soldiers on guard see the chaos in the Philistine camp and they tell Saul about it. Saul gathers the soldiers to see who is missing. The men find that Jonathan and his armor-bearer are missing.

In the second scene: Saul instructs Ahijah to bring the ark of God to Saul. However, noise in the Philistine camp is getting worse, so Saul tells Ahijah to stop.

In the third scene: Saul and his soldiers go to attack the Philistines. The Hebrews who are living with the Philistines help Saul's army. The Israelites who had run away earlier also help Saul and his army. The Israelite soldiers continue to attack while the Philistine soldiers run away.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The lookouts, or Israelite soldiers on guard

  • The Philistine soldiers

  • Saul

  • Jonathan

  • Jonathan's armor-bearer

  • Ahijah

  • The Israelite army with Saul

  • The Hebrews in the Philistine camp

  • The Israelite soldiers who had run away

  • And Yahweh

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In the first scene, Saul is still camping near the town of Gibeah in Benjamin's territory with Saul's army of 600 soldiers. Saul has ordered some soldiers to stand some distance away from the camp to guard the camp and watch for any attacks.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel as a group. Find the town of Gibeah, as well as the town of Mikmash, where the Philistines are. Pause this audio here.

These Israelite soldiers, or lookouts, are close enough to the Philistine camp to see when the Philistine soldiers start running away in terror. The Philistine soldiers look like something that is melting in warm sunlight.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when you saw a large group of people or animals run away in different directions. Pay attention to the words or phrases you use to describe how the people or animals move. Pause this audio here.

The lookouts return to the Israelite camp and tell Saul what they have seen. Saul tells his soldiers to gather together so the men can check and see who has left to go and fight the enemy. The soldiers may line up in fighting groups while their leaders check to make sure everyone in the group is present. The men discover that Jonathan and Jonathan's armor-bearer are missing.

In the second scene, Saul instructs Ahijah the priest to bring the ark of God to Saul. The ark was a rectangular wooden box that people had covered in gold. The ark was normally in the town of Kiriath Jearim, but the Israelites sometimes brought the ark with them when they went out to fight. The ark was probably nearby in a safe and honorable spot in the Israelite camp.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel as a group. Find the town of Kiriath Jearim. Pause this audio here.

However, while Saul is still talking to Ahijah, the noise and chaos of the Philistines is becoming worse and worse. The Israelites may have been able to hear the noise from their camp. Saul tells Ahijah to stop. Ahijah may have still been bringing the ark to Saul, or Ahijah may have been using the ark to ask Yahweh for guidance.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are some phrases you use to tell someone to stop what they are doing because it is no longer useful or needed? Pause this audio here.

In the third scene, Saul and his soldiers gather together, probably in their fighting groups, and march off to fight the Philistines. When the men arrive, the Israelites see how the Philistines are so confused that they are killing other Philistines with their swords. Saul joins with Jonathan and Jonathan's armor-bearer, who are already attacking the Philistines, and they all fight the Philistines together.

There are some Hebrews who had joined the Philistines and lived in the Philistine camp. These Hebrews now join Saul and Saul's army to fight against the Philistines. There were also some Israelites who were hiding nearby in the hills of Ephraim. These Israelites are the men who had earlier run away from Saul's army. These men may have heard the noise and chaos from the camp, or someone may have told the men about the battle. These Israelites also join Saul to chase and fight the Philistines. Though the Philistine soldiers are quickly running away, the Israelite soldiers are close behind and are killing the Philistines as the Philistines run.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when you chased and caught an animal or a person, such as for a game or while you were hunting. What words or phrases do you use to describe when you were close behind whatever you were chasing? Pause this audio here.

It was Yahweh who caused the Israelites to win, even though the Israelites had fewer soldiers and weapons than the Philistines. The Israelites are able to chase and kill the Philistines all the way to the town of Beth Aven, and the Israelites continue fighting throughout the hill country beyond Beth Aven. It is not clear where Beth Aven was, but it may have been a few kilometers north of Mikmash.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:16–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has three scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The lookouts, or the Israelite soldiers on guard

  • The Philistine soldiers

  • Saul

  • Jonathan

  • Jonathan's armor-bearer

  • Ahijah

  • The Israelite army with Saul

  • The Hebrews in the Philistine camp

  • The Israelite soldiers who had run away

  • And Yahweh

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Back at Gibeah, in Benjamin's territory, where Saul and Saul's soldiers were camping, the soldiers on guard saw the Philistine soldiers running back and forth, or scattering in confusion.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing lookouts, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I do not understand what is happening in the Philistine camp, so I am a little nervous. I should hurry and tell my king about what I see. Then the king can decide what to do; or

  • It looks like the Philistines are running away! Maybe this is how Yahweh will save our people! or

  • I know that my job as a lookout is serious because I protect my fellow soldiers in the camp. If I see anything strange or unusual, I will quickly tell the others.

Then Saul said to his soldiers, "Gather our soldiers and check to see who has left us to go and fight the enemy." The soldiers obeyed and found out that Jonathan and his armor-bearer were missing.

Then Saul instructed Ahijah the priest to bring the ark of God to Saul so that Saul could inquire of God about what was happening. The ark of God was with the Israelite army at that time.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • After Samuel left and so many of my soldiers ran away, I felt unsure what I should do. I have been waiting for some sort of sign or opportunity that will help us; or

  • Maybe this is Yahweh giving us a sign. I will have Ahijah ask Yahweh, just to make sure; or

  • There may be something dangerous happening in the Philistine camp, such as another people group joining the battle. I do not want to lead my soldiers into more danger.

As Saul was talking to Ahijah the priest, the noise and chaos in the Philistine camp were becoming worse and worse. So Saul said to Ahijah, "Stop, there is no time to do that now."

Saul and all his soldiers gathered for battle and marched off to fight the Philistines. The men were amazed to see that the Philistines were completely confused. The Philistine soldiers were even killing each other.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Israelite soldiers with Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am surprised that the Philistines are killing each other like this! This is not normal! This must be our God helping us! or

  • Look at how the Philistines are no longer a threat! I have been afraid of the Philistines' big army for so long, but now I am relieved because I think we can win! or

  • I am ready to attack the Philistines and get them off our land so that I can go home to my family!

Earlier, some Hebrews had joined the Philistines and lived among the Philistines in their camp. Now, however, these Hebrews returned to the side of their fellow Israelites and joined Saul and Jonathan. The Israelites who had been hiding in the hills of Ephraim heard that the Philistines were running from their fellow Israelites, and they too all joined in the battle. In this way, Yahweh rescued the Israelites on that day. The Israelites continued to attack the Philistines even after they had traveled farther than Beth Aven.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Hebrews in the Philistine camp, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • When the Philistines came to our land, they were so strong and had so many soldiers! I was afraid the Philistines would kill me, so I offered to serve the Philistines if they let me live; or

  • I am relieved that my fellow Israelites are here to fight the Philistines! I do not want to work for the Philistines anymore! or

  • I am ashamed that the other Israelites can see that I was working for the Philistines. Maybe if I fight the Philistines, the other Israelites will forgive me.

Ask the person playing the Israelite soldiers hiding in the hills of Ephraim, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • When we first saw the Philistine army, I was so afraid that I ran away and hid. There was no reason for me to fight and die if we were going to lose anyway! or

  • When I heard how the Israelite army was defeating the Philistine soldiers, I was ashamed of how I ran away. I must go back and fight to make up for how I ran away; or

  • I want to be a part of the battle now that we are winning! I want to be a part of the winning army, since they get honor and treasures after they win.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:16–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

The Israelite lookouts see the confusion in the Philistine camp. The lookouts were soldiers in Saul's army who had the task of watching the enemy.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for lookouts. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Saul and his soldiers discover that Saul's son Jonathan and Jonathan's armor-bearer are missing. An armor-bearer carries his commanding officer's shield and weapons. An armor-bearer protects and fights alongside his commanding officer. Use the same word or phrase for armor-bearer as you used in previous passages.

Saul asks Ahijah to bring the ark of God, or the ark of the covenant, to Saul. This is the wooden box covered in gold that God asked the Israelites to make when they were in the desert. The box symbolized God's presence, and the Israelites sometimes carried the ark with them when they went to fight. For more information on the ark of the covenant, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for "ark of the covenant" or "ark of God" as you used in previous passages.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of the ark of God as needed. Pause this audio here.

The word God in "the ark of God" is the general word for God. For more information on God, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for God as you used in previous passages.

Ahijah is a priest. A priest is a person who serves God, presenting offerings and prayers on behalf of the people. For more information on priest, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for priest as you used in previous passages.

The Philistines are killing each other with their swords. Use the same word or phrase for swords as you used in previous passages.

There were some Hebrews in the Philistine camp. The word Hebrew can refer to the descendants of Abraham. Sometimes, people used this word for Israelites who did not live in the land of Israel. For more information on Hebrew, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Hebrew as you used in previous passages. Be sure to use different terms for Hebrews and Israelites throughout this passage. For more information about Israelites, see the Master Glossary.

Yahweh caused the Israelites to defeat the Philistines. Yahweh is God's personal name. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Yahweh as you used in previous passages.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 14:24–35
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 14:24–35 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:24–35 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:24–35 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

This story takes place during the battle from the last story. At the beginning of the battle, Saul makes all his soldiers promise not to eat anything until the end of the day, when the soldiers have defeated the Philistines. Jonathan does not know about the promise and eats some honey. At the end of the day, the Israelite soldiers are so hungry that they begin to eat meat in a way that Yahweh had told them not to. Saul stops the soldiers who are disobeying Yahweh and builds an altar.

In this story, the storyteller explains why the Israelite soldiers were hard-pressed or exhausted during the battle. Before the battle, Saul made his soldiers swear an oath or a very solemn promise that they would not eat any food. Saul wanted to get revenge on the Philistines by sunset. Saul cursed, or wished bad things to happen, to any soldier who ate before sunset.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time someone cursed someone else. How do people curse each other? What are the effects of these curses? Pause this audio here.

The storyteller does not include why Saul cursed the soldiers. Probably Saul hoped to get God's help to make sure the Israelites defeated the Philistines. In this time, people often fasted, or did not eat, in order to prepare themselves before they asked God for something. People often did this before a battle, but not often during the battle.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, when are some times when people choose to stop doing normal actions, like eating, before doing something important or special? Why do people do this? Pause this audio here.

So during the day of the battle, none of the Israelite soldiers ate any food. Some time during the battle, the Israelite army is in a forest, or an area with trees. There, the soldiers find some honey on the ground. Bees make honey, a sweet liquid, and store it in honeycombs, which are the nests the bees make out of wax. Bees usually make their nests in a high place, like on a tree branch. Apparently, there was so much honey in this bee's nest that it was dropping out of the honeycomb onto the ground.

Stop here and look at a picture of honey, a honeycomb, or a bee's nest, as a group. Pause this audio here.

Because the Israelite soldiers fear the curse of Saul's oath, the soldiers do not eat any of the honey. However, Jonathan has not heard about the oath. Jonathan dips his staff, or wooden stick, into the honey and eats some of the honey. The storyteller says Jonathan's eyes brightened, which means that Jonathan feels stronger and more alert.

Then one of the Israelite soldiers tells Jonathan about the strict oath. The soldier says that because of the oath, none of the soldiers has eaten, so the soldiers feel weak. Jonathan says that his father, Saul, has made trouble for their country. Jonathan means that Saul has made it more difficult for the Israelite army to defeat the Philistines. Jonathan says it would have been better if the soldiers had eaten some of the spoils or plunder. Spoil is anything that people take from an enemy they defeat, and in this case, Jonathan means food. Jonathan asks if eating some food would have caused the Israelites to kill more Philistines. This is not a question that Jonathan expects anyone to answer. Jonathan is emphasizing that Israelite soldiers would have been able to kill more Philistines if the soldiers had eaten something, which would have made the Israelites feel stronger.

The Israelites chase the Philistines from the town of Mikmash to the town of Aijalon, and strike down or kill many of the Philistines by the end of the day. The Israelites take sheep, cattle, and calves as spoil from the Philistines. These are all farm animals that are good for eating. Because the men have not eaten all day, the Israelites are exhausted. Now that it is evening time and they have defeated the Philistines, the Israelite soldiers are in a hurry to eat quickly, and the soldiers do not prepare the meat properly. The Israelite soldiers kill the animals immediately at the spot where they took the animals. However, the soldiers do not drain the blood out of the meat like Yahweh told them to. The soldiers eat the meat together with the blood.

Stop here and look at a picture of a sheep, cow, and calf as a group. Pause this audio here.

Someone tells Saul that the soldiers are sinning against Yahweh, or disobeying Yahweh's law by eating meat with the blood still in it. So Saul calls the soldiers unfaithful, or traitors against Yahweh. Saul orders some soldiers to roll a big stone over to Saul immediately. Saul tells his officers to order their soldiers to kill the animals on the stone. Then the blood will drain from the animals and flow onto the stone and down to the ground. The men can then eat their meat. Saul says that the men must not sin against Yahweh by eating meat with blood still in the meat.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, what do people think or believe about eating meat with blood in it? What are some foods or ways of eating foods that are wrong or not acceptable in your culture? Why should people not eat those foods in that way? Pause this audio here.

So everyone does as Saul instructs and brings the animals to the stone. Though the storyteller just mentions the cattle, the storyteller means both the cattle and the sheep. The men kill their animals on the stone. In this way, Saul makes an altar to Yahweh, or to honor Yahweh. The animals that the people kill there might be like a sacrifice to Yahweh. In any case, this altar is a place where people honor Yahweh by following Yahweh's laws. This is the first time Saul has made an altar.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, what do altars look like? Who usually makes the altars? What are some special or important times when people would make an altar? Why do people make altars at those times?

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:24–35 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has five scenes.

In the first scene: Before the battle, Saul commands the Israelite soldiers to swear that they will eat nothing during the daytime until Saul gets his revenge on the Philistines. So throughout the day, the Israelite soldiers are very weak and exhausted because no one eats anything.

In the second scene: During the battle, the Israelite army enters a forest. When the men find honey on the ground, the men do not eat the honey. Jonathan does not know about the promise Saul made the soldiers swear, so Jonathan eats some honey and feels stronger. When the soldiers tell Jonathan about the serious oath, Jonathan says that Saul has caused trouble for the Israelite soldiers.

In the third scene: All day, the Israelite soldiers continue to chase the Philistines, from the town of Mikmash to the town of Aijalon.

In the fourth scene: The Israelites have defeated the Philistines by the end of the day. The soldiers are so hungry that they begin to kill and eat the animals without preparing the animals in the way Yahweh said to do.

In the fifth scene: Someone tells Saul what the soldiers are doing. Saul instructs the soldiers to set up a stone where they can properly kill and prepare the meat. This way, the men do not sin against Yahweh.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The Israelite soldiers

  • Saul

  • The Philistine soldiers

  • Jonathan

  • And Yahweh

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In the last story, the storyteller said that Yahweh caused the Israelites to defeat the Philistines. Now, in this story, the storyteller will describe some events that happened during the day of the battle.

Scene one probably begins before the Israelite soldiers attack the Philistine soldiers. The Israelite army may still be at their camp, or the soldiers may be outside the Philistine camp. Jonathan is probably not with the main group of soldiers. Saul orders the Israelite soldiers to swear an oath that they will not eat any food before the evening. No one is allowed to eat any food until Saul has taken revenge on his enemies. If anyone does eat, then those people will be under a curse. This is why the soldiers are weak from hunger during the day of the battle.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, how do people swear oaths? What do people say or do to show that this is a very serious promise? Pause this audio here.

Scene two happens during the battle. While the Israelites are chasing and killing the Philistines, the Israelites enter a forest, or an area with many trees. The Israelites see honey on the ground. There is probably a bees' nest in a nearby tree, and there is so much honey inside that the honey is dripping out. Though the soldiers see the honey, no Israelite soldier eats any of the honey, because of the oath that the men swore.

However, Jonathan has not heard about the oath, so he dips the end of his staff or walking stick into the honey. Jonathan then scoops the honey off the end and eats it. Because Jonathan eats some sweet honey, Jonathan's eyes brighten, and Jonathan feels stronger and more alert.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when you had not eaten for a long time, then had some good food. Think about how each part of your body felt after you ate. What are some words or phrases you would use in your language to describe how the food made your body feel stronger or better? Discuss what phrase you want to use in your translation to describe how Jonathan felt stronger and more alert. Pause this audio here.

One of the soldiers says to Jonathan, "Your father made us swear a very solemn oath not to eat, which is why we are all weak with hunger." Jonathan replies that his father has made it more difficult for the Israelite army to defeat the Philistine army.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Discuss how in your culture a soldier would refer to the king when speaking to the king's son. Discuss how the son of a king would speak of his father when talking with one of the king's soldiers. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Imagine a situation where you have not eaten for a long time, and you are very hungry. How do you talk about being weak from hunger? How will you translate that the Israelite soldiers were weak from hunger? Pause this audio here.

Jonathan wishes that the soldiers had eaten the food left behind by the Philistines. The Israelites had probably already chased the Philistines out of their camp, so everything in the Philistine camp now belonged to the Israelites. This included food supplies, and Jonathan wishes that the Israelites had stopped and eaten some of the food. Jonathan says that if the Israelite soldiers had done that, then the soldiers would have been able to kill many more of the Philistines.

In the third scene, the Israelites continue to chase and kill the Philistines all the way from Mikmash to the town of Aijalon, which is 25 kilometers away. Since no one has eaten any food, the soldiers are very exhausted and weary.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel as a group. Find the towns of Mikmash and Aijalon. Pause this audio here.

The fourth scene begins at the end of the day. Now it is evening, and the Israelites have defeated the Philistines. The oath is completed, so the Israelites can eat again. The Israelites probably have returned to the Philistine camp to gather the spoil or plunder. The men are so hungry that they rush towards the sheep, cattle, and calves, and the men immediately kill the animals. However, the men do not drain the blood out of the meat. The men probably cook the meat and begin to eat it.

The fifth scene begins when someone, probably one of the soldiers, tells Saul to look at the soldiers. Saul is probably not near the soldiers who are eating, so Saul cannot see what the men are doing. This person says that because the men are eating the meat with blood, the soldiers are sinning against Yahweh. Saul agrees and calls out to those soldiers who are eating. Saul says, "You are unfaithful to Yahweh!" Saul is telling the men that their actions are wrong because the men have not faithfully followed Yahweh's laws.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: As an activity, pretend you are talking to someone you work with who has not followed your boss or leader's instructions. What words or phrases would you use to tell that person that they are doing something wrong or against the rules? Pause this audio here.

Saul orders some of his soldiers to roll a large stone over towards Saul. Once the men do this, Saul speaks to his officers, or the leaders of the smaller groups of men. Saul instructs these officers to go among their soldiers and order their soldiers to kill their animals on the large stone. When the men do, the blood will drain off the meat onto the stone. Then the soldiers can eat the meat because there will be no more blood in the animals. Saul commands the soldiers not to sin against Yahweh by eating the meat with blood in it.

So, that night, all the soldiers bring their animals over to the stone and kill the animals there. This stone is an altar. Because Saul instructed his soldiers to set up the stone, the storyteller says that Saul built this altar. This is the first time that Saul has done this.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:24–35 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has five scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The Israelite soldiers

  • Saul

  • The Philistine soldiers

  • Jonathan

  • And Yahweh

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

During the battle, the Israelite soldiers were weak from hunger because Saul had made the men swear an oath. Saul said, "May God curse any of you who eats anything at all before evening. No one is allowed to eat any food until I have taken revenge on my enemies." So none of the soldiers ate anything that day.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so determined to get revenge on the Philistines. I want my soldiers to be just as determined. I do not want the soldiers to think about anything else, even food! or

  • I am worried that my soldiers will see the food and other supplies in the Philistine camp and become distracted. The soldiers may leave the battle to go and eat. I will order the men to swear this oath so that they will not stop fighting; or

  • I have heard that people sometimes do not eat to honor Yahweh, and then Yahweh helps them. I will make sure no one in my army eats, then Yahweh will definitely help us.

Ask the person playing the Israelite soldiers, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am worried. I know that when I fight, I will become exhausted. If the battle lasts all day, I do not know if I will be strong enough to keep fighting if I do not eat! Someone may kill me if I am not strong enough! or

  • I do not like this oath, but I must obey my king, so I will swear just like the others are doing; or

  • I do not understand how this oath will help us win the battle. Why would our king want us not to eat?

All the Israelite soldiers went into an area with trees where there was honey lying on the ground. As the soldiers went by the trees, the men saw the honey dripping down from the honeycomb. However, none of the men ate any of the honey because they were all afraid of Saul's curse.

But Jonathan was not there when his father made the soldiers swear an oath not to eat, so Jonathan did not know about it. So when Jonathan saw the honey, Jonathan reached out the end of the staff that he was carrying and dipped it into the honeycomb. Jonathan ate some honey, and he felt stronger and more alert.

Then one of the men in the army said, "Your father, Saul, made us swear a severe oath not to eat anything. Saul cursed anyone who ate anything today, so we have not eaten anything today, which is why we are weak."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Israelite soldier who speaks to Jonathan, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am scared for Jonathan! I do not want Saul's curse to come to Jonathan! or

  • Oh no! Jonathan was not with us when we swore the oath, so Jonathan does not know about the curse! I wonder if the curse will affect Jonathan, since he did not swear with us; or

  • I can see how Jonathan looks stronger after eating. I wish we could eat too. I am so hungry and tired!

Jonathan replied, "My father has caused trouble for the people of Israel. You can easily see how I regained strength when I ate just a little honey. It would have been much better if you had eaten some of the food we took from our enemies, the Philistines! Then you would have had the strength to kill even more of the Philistines."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Jonathan, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I do not understand why my father would make the people swear this oath. Everyone knows that people need food to stay strong! or

  • I am angry that my father would order the people to swear this oath so that he can get revenge. If our soldiers are weak, the men may die in battle. Saul's oath is harming our soldiers! or

  • I feel so much stronger and more alert after eating. I feel ready to chase the Philistines all day. I wish everyone in the army could feel this way!

That day, the Israelites defeated the Philistines and pursued them from Mikmash all the way to Aijalon. Afterwards, the Israelites were weak from hunger since they had not eaten that day. So the men rushed to the animals they had taken away from the Philistines, and killed the animals right there on the ground. The men began to eat the meat with the blood still in it.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Israelite soldiers, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so hungry and exhausted that I cannot think about anything but eating food right now! I do not want to move much or do much work before I eat; or

  • Look at all the good things the Philistines left in their camp! Here are all the animals and possessions that the Philistines stole from the Israelites, as well as all the supplies they brought with them. I will have many good things to take back to my family!

Then one of Saul's men said to Saul, "Look! The men are sinning against Yahweh because they are eating meat that still has blood in it."

Saul cried out to his soldiers, "You have been unfaithful to Yahweh! Roll a large stone over here at once."

Then Saul said to his officers, "Go and tell the men to bring their cattle and sheep here to kill them properly. Then the men can eat the meat. The men must not sin against Yahweh by eating the meat that still has blood in it."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am worried that my men were not following Yahweh's law. I do not understand why the men forgot to drain the blood, since they would normally do that at home; or

  • I do not want Yahweh to be angry with us. I already disobeyed Yahweh earlier, so I cannot allow anyone to do anything that would cause Yahweh to stop helping us; or

  • There are so many things that I must focus on as a king, so I did not even notice what my soldiers were doing!

So the men all did as Saul instructed them to do. In this way, Saul made an altar to honor Yahweh. This was the first time that Saul did this.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:24–35 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Saul makes his soldiers swear an oath. When people make a promise to each other, they can swear an oath to make the promise more serious. When someone swears an oath, the person says, "I will absolutely keep my promise. If I do not, God may punish me."

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for oath. Look up oath in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Saul curses anyone who does not keep the oath. When you curse someone, you wish that something bad will happen to that person. People believed that a curse would come true. For more information on curse, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for curse as you used in previous passages.

Saul says that no one may eat until Saul avenges himself or takes revenge on his enemy. To avenge yourself means to harm someone because of the way that person first harmed you. Saul wants the Israelite soldiers to harm the Philistines because the Philistines harmed the Israelites as their enemies.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for avenge. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The Israelites are very weak from hunger. Use the same word or phrase for Israelites as you have used previously. See the Master Glossary for more information about Israelites.

The soldiers find honey in a forest. Honey is a sweet liquid that small, flying insects called bees make. Bees make a nest called a honeycomb out of wax, where the bees make and store honey. Honey was a precious and valuable food to the Israelites.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for honey and honeycomb. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Jonathan wishes the soldiers had eaten some of the spoil or plunder. Spoil is anything that a winning army takes from its defeated enemy after the battle. Here, Jonathan is specifically referring to the food that the Israelites took from the Philistines.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for spoil or plunder. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Someone tells Saul that the soldiers are sinning against Yahweh. Sin is an act of rebellion against Yahweh. Anytime that a person disobeys Yahweh's laws, that person sins. Here, the Israelite soldiers are disobeying Yahweh's command not to eat meat with blood in it. For more information on sin, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for sin as you used in previous passages.

Yahweh is God's personal name. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Yahweh as you used in previous passages.

Saul tells his men to set up a stone as an altar. An altar is a place where people make offerings or sacrifices to God. An altar is like a table or a platform that people make of earth or large stones. This altar seems to be a place where people can drain blood from meat so they can honor Yahweh by following Yahweh's law. For more information on altar, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for altar as you used in previous passages.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
