title: 1 Samuel 14:36–46
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 14:36–46 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:36–46 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:36–46 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the last story, Saul made his soldiers promise not to eat anything during the day while they fought the Philistines. In this story, it is now evening, and Saul wants to keep chasing the Philistines. However, when God does not respond to Saul's questions about whether he should chase the Philistines, Saul thinks this must be because one of the Israelites has sinned. Saul discovers that Jonathan broke the promise by eating, but the other Israelite soldiers rescue Jonathan from Saul's punishment.

This story probably begins right after the last story finishes. Now that the Israelites have eaten, Saul wants to continue to chase after the Philistine soldiers. Saul says that the Israelites should all plunder the Philistines. Normally, this means that the men should take the Philistines' belongings, but here, Saul also means to keep fighting the Philistines. Saul wants to chase the Philistines all night until sunrise and kill everyone in the Philistine army. This way, the Philistines will not be able to attack the Israelites again for a very long time.

The soldiers agree to Saul's instructions, but the priest, probably Ahijah, insists that the men should ask God before doing anything. So Saul asks God if the Israelites should chase after the Philistines. Saul asks if God will give the Philistines into the Israelites' hands. In the original language, people used the word "hand" to mean power or control. Saul is asking if the Israelites will continue to win against the Philistines. Saul is probably not praying directly to God, but asking through another method, such as using the Urim and Thummim in the priest's ephod.

Stop here and look at a photo of the ephod with its pouch as a group. Pause this audio here.

When God does not respond, Saul assumes that this is because someone has sinned. The Israelites knew that their sin always separated them from God. So when God was silent, the Israelites knew it was probably because someone had sinned. However, Saul does not know who that person is or what the person has done. Saul tells all the leaders in his army to gather together so they can find out who sinned or disobeyed God. Saul says that the men must kill whoever has sinned. Saul gives a strong promise to do this. Certainly, Yahweh, who rescues Israel, lives, and just as certainly, Saul will do what Saul promises.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about a time when someone knew they had upset or offended someone else, not because the other person said so, but because the other person was silent. Talk about what the first person did to try to fix the situation so that the other person would talk to the first person again. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Saul promises very strongly that he will do what he says. In your culture, how do people show that they will absolutely do what they say they will? Pause this audio here.

Some of Saul's soldiers know that Jonathan has broken the solemn oath from the last story by eating the honey, but none of the soldiers wants to tell Saul. Saul tells his soldiers to stand in one group while Saul and his son, Jonathan, stand separate from them. Saul's soldiers agree and do so. Then Saul prays to Yahweh and respectfully asks Yahweh why he has not answered Saul. Since Saul believes Yahweh has not answered because someone has sinned, Saul asks Yahweh to show the men who has sinned.

Saul asks Yahweh to show the men through casting lots, which was a way people asked what Yahweh wanted. There were several ways to do this, so it is not clear exactly what the men did here. People often shook stones with symbols in a small container in such a way as to cast or shake out a stone. This stone could have either the word "Yes" or "No" on it as an answer to their question. Yahweh would cause the stone with Yahweh's answer to come out.

The priests of Israel had two stones, one they called Urim and one called Thummim. These two stones may have been different in color, one white and one black. A priest may have pulled these stones out of the ephod pouch in order to determine by lot Yahweh's choice between two different options.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, how do people ask a god for guidance? Who can speak to the god? Pause this audio here.

Saul asks Yahweh to choose the Urim stone if Saul or Jonathan is guilty or has sinned. If the other Israelites have sinned, then Saul asks Yahweh to choose the Thummim stone. Yahweh chooses the Urim, showing that Jonathan or Saul is guilty of doing this sin and that the other Israelites are not guilty. Saul then asks Yahweh to show the men if it was Jonathan or Saul who was guilty. Saul probably assigns one stone to Jonathan and one to himself. Yahweh chooses the stone that shows that Jonathan has sinned.

When Saul asks Jonathan what Jonathan has done, Jonathan explains that he ate some honey off his staff. Though eating honey was not a sin, Jonathan sinned because he ate food even though Saul had ordered the men to swear an oath not to eat. Breaking a solemn oath with Yahweh's name is a sin, even if Jonathan did not know about the oath. Jonathan accepts Saul's punishment of death. Since Saul promised earlier that Saul would order his men to kill whoever sinned, Saul swears another oath, or strong promise, that Jonathan will die. Saul calls on God to punish Saul with death or worse if Saul does not keep his oath.

The soldiers do not think that this is a fair punishment. The soldiers ask if Jonathan, the man who saved Israel, should die. The soldiers are not expecting Saul to reply to their question. The soldiers are saying that it does not make sense to kill the man who saved them. The soldiers say, "This must never happen!" which means that the soldiers will not agree to kill Jonathan. The soldiers also swear an oath and say that Yahweh certainly lives and, just as certainly, the soldiers will not let a hair fall off Jonathan. The soldiers mean that the soldiers will not let Saul punish Jonathan in any way, because God helped Jonathan save the Israelites.

So the Israelite soldiers ransom Jonathan, and no one kills Jonathan. To ransom someone means to make a substitute payment for someone or something. The people offered something else to Yahweh in place of Jonathan. Perhaps the men gave money, or perhaps the men provided an animal to die instead.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: The soldiers save Jonathan, but the soldiers must pay the price or punishment for the sin. Tell a story about a time when someone did something wrong. Tell how another person gave that person a punishment, such as to pay back the money or do extra work. Then tell how someone else helped the person who did wrong by paying the money or doing the work instead. Pause this audio here.

Saul stops chasing after the rest of the Philistine soldiers, who are able to escape back to their own land. Because of his oath, Saul had to stop chasing the Philistine soldiers to see who broke the oath. Then Saul could not chase the Philistines and kill as many of them, just like Jonathan said in the last section. The human King Saul, even though he spoke a curse, could not keep the curse because Saul's own soldiers would not allow it. This shows how Saul sometimes acted unwisely as a leader when Saul made strong promises to God. Saul made these promises to try to make God like Saul more. But Saul could not keep these promises.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:36–46 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has five scenes.

In the first scene: Saul says that the Israelites should continue to chase after the Philistines. The soldiers agree, but the priest says that the men should ask God first.

In the second scene: Saul asks God if the men should chase the Philistines, but God does not answer Saul.

In the third scene: Saul gathers his officers and says that whoever has sinned must die. Saul orders his soldiers to stand apart from Saul and Jonathan. Saul asks Yahweh to show the men who has sinned. Yahweh shows through the lot that Jonathan has sinned.

In the fourth scene: Saul asks Jonathan what Jonathan did, and Jonathan explains that Jonathan ate some honey. Saul declares that Jonathan must die. The Israelite soldiers say that they will not let anyone hurt Jonathan, and so the soldiers rescue Jonathan.

In the fifth scene: Saul does not continue to chase the Philistine soldiers, who return to their homes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Saul

  • The Philistine soldiers

  • The Israelite soldiers

  • The priest, probably Ahijah

  • God, whose personal name is Yahweh

  • The Israelite officers

  • And Jonathan

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

The first scene probably begins right after the end of the last story. It is evening time, and the Israelites have stopped chasing the Philistine soldiers to eat. Now that the Israelites have finished eating, Saul speaks to his soldiers. Saul orders his soldiers to go with Saul to attack the Philistines all night long and kill all of the Philistine soldiers. Saul's soldiers agree to do what Saul says. But the priest insists that the men should ask God before the men do anything. This priest is probably Ahijah, since the storyteller said earlier that Ahijah was with the Israelite army.

So in the second scene, Saul asks God what to do. The storyteller does not describe how Saul does this, but Saul may have asked the priest to use the ephod or the Urim and Thummim in the ephod pouch to speak to God. Saul asks if Saul, along with Saul's soldiers, should chase the Philistines. Saul wants to know if God will cause the Israelites to win. Saul may wait some time for a reply, but God does not respond to Saul that day. This shows that someone has sinned against God.

In the third scene, Saul tells his officers to come together and that together the men all must discover who has sinned. Saul swears an oath that whoever has sinned will definitely die. This means that Saul will order someone to kill that person. Saul will do this even if the person is Saul's son, Jonathan. At least some of the men know that Jonathan has sinned because Jonathan ate that day, even though Saul had threatened that anyone who ate that day should die. However, none of the men tells Saul what Jonathan did.

Then Saul tells his soldiers to stand in a group together, while Saul and Jonathan stand apart as a second group. The soldiers agree, and the men all do what Saul said. Then Saul prays to Yahweh respectfully. Saul says God's name and emphasizes that Yahweh is the God of Israel. Saul asks Yahweh why Yahweh has not answered Saul's question. Saul asks Yahweh to show the men who is guilty by choosing a stone when the men cast the lots. If Saul and Jonathan are guilty, Saul asks Yahweh to show this by choosing the Urim stone. If the other soldiers are guilty, Saul asks Yahweh to show this by choosing the Thummim stone.

The priest probably casts the lots by reaching into a pouch for a stone or by shaking the pouch in such a way that only one stone falls out. Yahweh causes the priest to get the Urim stone, which shows that the guilty person is in Saul and Jonathan's group. Then Saul says to choose the lot again between Saul and Jonathan, so the priest casts the lots. The storyteller shortens this part and does not explain which stone represented which man, since the listeners would know how this process works. The priest casts the lots again and gets the stone that shows it was Jonathan who sinned.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story where you do the same action with several steps many times. Pay attention to when you describe all the steps of the action and when you choose to shorten your description and leave out steps of the action. Pause this audio here.

In the fourth scene, Saul asks Jonathan what happened, and Jonathan explains how he ate the honey. Jonathan then says that Jonathan must die, but we are not sure how Jonathan says this. It is possible that Jonathan protests the punishment or asks a question. Most likely, Jonathan accepts Saul's punishment of death for what Jonathan did. Saul then swears another oath, this time that Saul will kill Jonathan. Saul calls on God to punish Saul with death if Saul does not keep the oath.

However, Saul's soldiers strongly say that Jonathan must not die for Jonathan's sin. Jonathan rescued the Israelites from their enemies because God helped Jonathan do so. The Israelites could see that God was with Jonathan that day. So the soldiers also swear by Yahweh that they will not let anyone punish or harm Jonathan in the smallest way. No one will even cut or cause a piece of hair on Jonathan's head to fall to the ground.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about someone who completely protects someone else, such as the way a parent protects a child. Pay attention to the words or phrases you use to describe the way that this person is completely safe. How will you talk about the way the people say that not even a piece of Jonathan's hair will fall to the ground? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Both the soldiers and Saul say that Yahweh surely lives, and just as surely, the men will do something too. What are some words or phrases in your language that people say to promise or show that they will definitely do a certain thing? Pause this audio here.

So the men ransom or redeem Jonathan. The men may pay some money or give an animal to die instead of Jonathan.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Think about the story you told in the last step, where someone gave something like money to save someone else from punishment. What words or phrases would you use to describe how that person helped? Pause this audio here.

In the fifth scene, Saul does not order the Israelites to continue chasing like Saul had planned. The Philistine soldiers who are still alive return to their home country.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:36–46 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has five scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Saul

  • The Philistine soldiers

  • The Israelite soldiers

  • The priest, probably Ahijah

  • God, whose personal name is Yahweh

  • The Israelite officers

  • And Jonathan

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Then Saul said, "Let us chase the Philistines tonight, take their belongings all night long, and kill every one of the Philistines!"

"Yes," the Israelite soldiers replied, "that is a great plan!"

But the priest said, "First, we must ask God and see if this is what God wants us to do."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the priest, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Even though we have a king, God is still our top leader. I must remind the people of that; or

  • I am worried because Saul does not remember to ask God before he makes his plans. The last time that Saul did not do what God wanted, Samuel left our army; or

  • I want the Israelites to be safe. If God does not want us to continue to chase the Philistines, the Philistines may defeat and kill our soldiers. We should ask God before we do this.

So Saul asked God, "Shall I lead my army to chase the Philistines? Will you allow us to destroy the Philistines?"

But God did not answer Saul's question that day.

So Saul said to Saul's army officers, "Someone must have sinned, and that is why God is not answering. Come here. We need to discover how one of us has sinned today. As surely as Yahweh who delivers Israel lives, so surely do I promise that the person who has committed this sin must die, even if that person is my son Jonathan!"

But no one at all told Saul what Jonathan had done.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I thought that we killed so many Philistines because God wants us to and is helping us. I do not understand why God would not answer my question; or

  • I am angry that someone has sinned. Now we have to stop and discover who has sinned, while the Philistines are escaping; or

  • I want to be a fair king, so I will punish whoever sinned, even if it is my son Jonathan.

Ask the person playing Saul's officers, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I know that Jonathan broke the oath, but I did not say anything, because I am worried the king will be angry with me for not telling him earlier; or

  • I do not want Jonathan to die. Perhaps Jonathan did not really break the oath, because Jonathan did not know about the oath. Maybe someone else has sinned; or

  • I wish Saul had not sworn all these oaths, because I do not think that was wise. First, we were hungry during the battle, and now Saul's son is in danger of death. I am not sure what the right thing to do is now, so I will not say anything.

Then Saul gave this command to the Israelite soldiers: "You all stand over there, and Jonathan and I will stand here."

And the men replied, "We will do whatever you say."

Then Saul prayed, "Yahweh, God of our people Israel, why have you not answered me today? Yahweh, God whom we worship, if Jonathan or I are guilty, then answer by the Urim stone, but if your people Israel have sinned, then answer by the Thummim stone."

The priest chose the Urim, showing that Jonathan or Saul was guilty and the soldiers were innocent.

Then Saul said, "Now decide by drawing lots whether my son Jonathan is the guilty one or if I am."

The priest did so, and it was Jonathan who was at fault.

Then Saul said to Jonathan, "What have you done?"

So Jonathan said to Saul, "Indeed, I did taste a little honey which I dipped with the end of my staff. I stand before you willing to die."

Saul answered, "If I do not have you put to death, Jonathan, then may God strike me dead!"

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Jonathan, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I think my father's oath was not a good one, but I understand that I disobeyed it. I will not try to make excuses; or

  • I wish that my father had not made his soldiers promise this oath. I am frustrated that our soldiers were weak yesterday, and now we have to stop chasing the Philistines; or

  • I am surprised that my father swore another oath that I must die. My father looks like he is not even sad that I am going to die!

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am embarrassed that it is my own son who has caused us to stop chasing the Philistines. I do not even know what my son is doing most of the time! or

  • I am very sad that it is my son who has sinned! I do not want to order my soldiers to kill my son, but I cannot break my promise; or

  • I must show that I am a fair king, or the people will not trust me. I will swear another oath to show that I will not break the rules for some people, even people I care about.

But the soldiers said to Saul, "No one shall kill Jonathan. Jonathan is the one who has rescued us, the Israelites, from our enemies. We swear by the living Yahweh that we will not allow anyone to punish Jonathan in the slightest way, for Jonathan was able to save Israel from the Philistines today because God helped Jonathan."

So no one killed Jonathan because the men redeemed Jonathan's life.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Israelite soldiers, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Jonathan just saved our people! It is not fair if Jonathan must die now! or

  • I understand that we cannot break promises, but our God has shown us ways to ransom or pay a substitute in some situations. Maybe we can do the same here to save Jonathan; or

  • God helped Jonathan but did not speak to Saul. Maybe Saul should not have commanded us to promise the oath that Jonathan accidentally broke.

After that, Saul and Saul's soldiers stopped chasing the Philistines, and the Philistine soldiers returned to their own country.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:36–46 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Saul says that the Israelites should chase after and plunder the Philistines. To plunder means to take belongings like food and weapons from a defeated enemy. Here, Saul probably means to kill the Philistines and take the Philistines' belongings.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for plunder, the action people do when they take the belongings of the enemies they conquer. If you have already translated this idea in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The priest instructs Saul to ask God for guidance first. A priest is a person who serves God and presents offerings and prayers on behalf of the people. For more information on priest, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for priest as you used in previous passages.

The priest says to ask God first. This is the general word for God, or Yahweh. For more information on God, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for God as you used in previous passages.

Saul asks if God will cause Israel to continue to win the battle with the Philistines. Israel can refer to the Israelite people as well as the country where the Israelites lived. For more information on Israel, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Israel as you used in previous passages.

Because God does not answer Saul, Saul tries to figure out who has sinned against God. Sin is an act of rebellion against Yahweh. Anytime a person disobeys Yahweh's laws, that person sins. For more information on sin, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for sin as you used in previous passages.

Saul swears a solemn oath with Yahweh's name. Yahweh is God's personal name. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Yahweh as you used in previous passages. Although the word "oath" does not appear in the original language in this story, you may use oath if needed for clarity in your translation. If needed, look up oath in the Master Glossary and use the same word or phrase that you used in the previous passages.

Saul prays to Yahweh and asks Yahweh to show who has sinned. When someone prays, that person is communicating with God. For more information on pray, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for pray as you used in previous passages.

Saul calls himself Yahweh's servant. A servant is a man or a woman who works for another person. Here, servant is a humble way to refer to yourself. For more information on servant, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for servant as you used in previous passages.

Saul asks God to choose the Urim if the Israelites have sinned and the Thummim if Saul or Jonathan has sinned. We are not exactly sure what these looked like, but the Urim and Thummim were probably two special stones. The Urim and Thummim may have been different colors, one white and one black. Priests may have picked one out of the ephod by lot to determine God's choice of two different options.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for Urim and Thummim and for casting lots. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Jonathan says that he ate a little honey off his staff. Honey is a sweet liquid that small flying insects, called bees, make. Use the same word or phrase for honey as you used in previous passages.

The soldiers ransom Jonathan. When someone is a prisoner, another person can buy that person free or ransom the person. The soldiers may have paid money or given animals to kill instead of Jonathan.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for ransom. Look up ransom in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 14:47–52
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 14:47–52 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:47–52 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:47–52 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

This story is a summary of Saul's time as king. While Saul is king, Saul fights bravely and defeats many of the Israelites' enemies. The storyteller gives the names and relationships of some important members of Saul's family. Because the Israelites and the Philistines often fought during Saul's life, Saul often added more soldiers to his army.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, what are some important things that a king or leader does? What do people choose to remember or talk about when a leader dies or finishes ruling? Pause this audio here.

This story begins after the battle with the Philistines. Even though the people had earlier declared Saul to be king, it was through the battle with the Philistines that Saul secured his authority as king. People were not challenging Saul or saying that Saul should not be king.

Then Saul leads the Israelite soldiers to fight against the Israelites' enemies, who live in the lands around Israel. Saul and his army fight against the people of Moab, Ammon, and Edom. The Israelites also fight the kings of Zobah and their people, as well as the Philistines. Saul leads the Israelites to win these battles against these nations.

Saul fights valiantly or bravely and leads the Israelite army to defeat the Amalekites as well. Before this, the Amalekite people, as well as others, had plundered the Israelites, which means they attacked the Israelites to take the Israelites' possessions. But now Saul saves the Israelites from the hand of their enemies. In the original language, people used the word hand to mean power or control, so Saul saves the Israelites from the power of the enemies.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time in your people's history when an enemy invaded and stole your people's belongings. How did your people eventually stop or defeat that enemy? Who led the people to defeat the enemy? Pause this audio here.

Next, the storyteller lists some of Saul's family members. Jonathan, Ishvi, and Malki-Shua are Saul's sons. Ishvi is probably another name for Ishbosheth, who shows up in a later story. Merab and Michal are Saul's daughters. Merab is older than Michal. Saul's wife's name is Ahinoam, and Ahinoam's father's name is Ahimaaz. The commander or leader of Saul's army is Saul's cousin, Abner. Saul's father, Kish and Abner's father, Ner, are brothers. Kish and Ner are Abiel's sons.

Even though Saul helps the Israelites defeat many of their enemies, Saul cannot fully defeat the Philistines. As long as Saul lives, the Israelites and the Philistines fight bitterly or fiercely. Since these two groups are often fighting, Saul is always ready to find more men to add to Saul's army. Whenever Saul sees an Israelite man who is strong and brave, Saul takes that man into Saul's service, or commands that man to join his army.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, how do leaders or rulers convince or order people to join their army? What kind of men do those leaders look for? How often do those leaders add more soldiers?

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:47–52 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has three scenes.

In the first scene: During his time as king, Saul leads his soldiers to fight the people who live in the land around the Israelites. Saul defeats the Israelites' enemies, who had plundered the Israelites.

In the second scene: Saul's wife's name is Ahinoam. Saul has sons named Jonathan, Ishvi, and Malki-Shua as well as daughters named Merab and Michal. Saul's cousin Abner is the commander of the Israelite army.

In the third scene: Because the Israelites are often fighting the Philistines, Saul adds any brave men he sees to Saul's army.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Saul

  • The Israelites, including the strong and brave men

  • The Israelites' enemies, who include the Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, the kings and people of Zobah, the Philistines, and the Amalekites

  • Saul's sons, Jonathan, Ishvi, and Malki-Shua

  • Saul's daughters, Merab and Michal

  • Ahinoam, Saul's wife, who is Ahimaaz's daughter

  • Abner, Saul's cousin, who is Ner's son

  • Kish, Saul's father

  • Ner, Abner's father

  • And Abiel, Kish and Ner's father

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In this story, the storyteller gives a short overview of Saul's time as king after the victory in the last section. The storyteller describes Saul's military victories, Saul's family, and the ongoing fight with the Philistines.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: As an activity, pretend you are a teacher and you are about to tell your students about a king or leader in your history. Quickly give a little overview or summary of what that leader did during their lifetime. Pay attention to which information you include and how you choose to organize that information. Pause this audio here.

Scene one begins after the last story and covers all of Saul's time as king. Because Saul defeated the Philistines, the Israelites trusted Saul as their king because Saul could protect the Israelites. At different times during Saul's reign, Saul led the Israelites to fight their enemies, who lived in the lands all around the Israelites.

The people groups of Moab, Ammon, and Edom live to the east and south of Israel. The Philistines and Amalekites are in the southwest, while Zobah is a city or a kingdom of cities located north of Israel. Some of these people groups had been attacking the Israelites and taking the Israelites' possessions. However, Saul is a brave warrior and leads the Israelites to win battles against these nations. Saul stops these other people groups from plundering or attacking the Israelites. Saul and his army probably fight several battles against each nation, like the Philistines, whom the Israelites often fight during Saul's time as king.

Stop here as a group and look at a map of Israel and the surrounding lands. Find the territory of the Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, Zobah, the Philistines, and the Amalekites. Pause this audio here.

In the second scene, the storyteller lists the names of some of Saul's family members. Saul's wife's name is Ahinoam, and Ahinoam's father is Ahimaaz. Saul has sons named Jonathan, Ishvi, and Malki-Shua. The storyteller probably listed these sons in age order, like their sisters Merab and Michal. Saul's cousin Abner is the commander of Saul's army. Abner's father is Ner, who was Saul's uncle. Saul's father, Kish, and Abner's father, Ner, are both Abiel's sons. Saul does have more family members, but the storyteller does not list those family members here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you describe your father's brother and your father's brother's son? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your language, how do you list or describe someone's family members? Why do you do it in this order? Discuss how you will list Saul's family members. Pause this audio here.

In the third scene, the storyteller explains that because the Israelites and the Philistines often fought during Saul's time as king, Saul often needed more soldiers. So whenever Saul saw any Israelite man who was strong and brave, Saul either asked or commanded that man to join the army. In the original language, the storyteller says that Saul attached these men to himself, which means these men came into Saul's army.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In the original language, the storyteller says that the Israelites and Philistines fought all the days of Saul. This means the Israelites and Philistines fought throughout Saul's lifetime. Discuss how you would talk about something that happens throughout or during someone's entire life. Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:47–52 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has three scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Saul

  • The Israelites, including the strong and brave men

  • The Israelites' enemies, who include the Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, the kings and people of Zobah, the Philistines, and the Amalekites

  • Saul's sons, Jonathan, Ishvi, and Malki-Shua

  • Saul's daughters, Merab and Michal

  • Ahinoam, Saul's wife, who is Ahimaaz's daughter

  • Abner, Saul's cousin, who is Ner's son

  • Kish, Saul's father

  • Ner, Abner's father

  • And Abiel, Kish and Ner's father

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

After Saul had secured his position as king, Saul led his army to fight against the Israelites' enemies all around them. The Israelites fought against the people of Moab, of Ammon, and of Edom; the kings of Zobah and their people; and the Philistines. Saul defeated all the nations he fought. Saul was a very brave fighter and led his army to defeat the Amalekites. In this way, Saul rescued the people of Israel from all who had been attacking them and taking the Israelites' possessions.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Israelites, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so proud of our king, who is a strong warrior. Now we can defeat anyone who attacks us, and the other nations will respect us! or

  • I have been afraid for a long time, since the other nations attacked and stole from us. I am relieved that Saul has defeated our enemies. Now we can live in peace; or

  • I am glad we have such a good king. I want to support the king and follow his commands because I know the king will protect us.

Saul had sons named Jonathan, Ishvi, and Malki-Shua. Saul's daughters were Merab and Michal. Merab was older than Michal. Saul's wife was Ahinoam, the daughter of Ahimaaz. The commander of Saul's army was Abner, Saul's cousin. Abner's father was Ner, who was Saul's uncle. Saul's father, Kish, and Abner's father, Ner, were both sons of Abiel.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am thankful that God has given me both sons and daughters; or

  • I want someone I can trust to lead my army, so I will put my cousin in command. I know my cousin, and I know he will be loyal to me.

As long as Saul lived, the Israelites were always fighting their enemy, the Philistines. So whenever Saul saw a strong and brave Israelite, Saul took that man into his army.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the strong and brave men of Israel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am glad to fight for Saul, since Saul keeps leading our people to defeat our enemies; or

  • While I would rather do another job, I do want to protect my people, so I will obey my king's orders; or

  • I wish we were not fighting the Philistines all the time, but I am thankful that Saul often brings more soldiers to help us fight.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 14:47–52 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Saul secures his kingship over Israel. A kingship is the role or position of a king. For more information, refer to king in the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for kingship as you used in previous passages.

Israel can refer to the Israelite people as well as the country where the Israelites lived. For more information on Israel, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Israel as you used in previous passages.

Saul defeats the people groups who had plundered Israel. To plunder means to take belongings like food and weapons from a defeated enemy. Use the same word or phrase for plunder as you used in previous passages.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 15:1–9
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 15:1–9 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 15:1–9 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 15:1–9 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In a previous story, Saul had failed to obey Yahweh's command. Samuel, the prophet, told Saul that because of what Saul had done, Yahweh would not allow Saul's children to continue to be kings after Saul. In the meantime, Saul continued to make Saul's army stronger and bigger. In this passage, Samuel gives Saul Yahweh's instructions to attack and kill all of the Amalekite people and all of their animals and to destroy the Amalekites' belongings. Many years before, when the Israelites left Egypt to go to the Promised Land, the Amalekites had attacked the Israelites. Now it was time for Yahweh to punish the Amalekites for this.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Talk about people groups that your people have been enemies with for many years. How did those people become your enemies? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What do your people expect of warriors when those warriors go to war? What are the warriors supposed to carry or not carry back home, and what are the warriors supposed to completely destroy? What is the reason for this? Pause this audio here.

Samuel has been silent since Samuel accused Saul of disobeying Yahweh's commands. Now Samuel appears again in the story to give Yahweh's message to Saul. When Samuel says that Samuel is the one who Yahweh sent to anoint Saul as king, Samuel is remembering how Samuel anointed Saul in the past. Yahweh appointed Samuel as Yahweh's prophet and as the one who anointed Saul as king. Therefore, the king must obey Samuel's instructions.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: If someone in your culture gives a message from a deity, how should the people respond? How do people in your culture know whether or not to trust the person who brings the message? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh, who is the commander of the angel armies, or heavenly beings, says that Yahweh will punish the Amalekites, who are the descendants of Amalek. The Amalekites attacked Israel when Yahweh brought the Israelites out of Egypt many years ago. So now Yahweh commands Saul to completely destroy the Amalekites and all that belongs to the Amalekites. Yahweh wants the Israelites to totally destroy everything the Israelites capture in war, including men, women, children, babies, and livestock or different animals that belong to the Amalekites.

Stop here and look at pictures of what people considered livestock: camels, donkeys, sheep, cows, and oxen, if needed. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do people in your culture show their loyalty to their deity or deities? Pause this audio here.

Saul listens to Yahweh's order to totally destroy the Amalekites and their belongings, and Saul does what Yahweh says to do. Saul calls, inspects, and counts the soldiers at Telaim. Telaim was a city in the territory of Judah. The 200,000 men on foot, or foot soldiers, are from the northern tribes of Israel and not Judah, since Judah is listed separately. There are 10,000 men from Judah. We are not sure if the men from Judah are also foot soldiers, or men who ride in chariots or on horses.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when your leaders gathered and assigned people from your community to go to war. How did the leaders do this? Pause this audio here.

Saul and Saul's soldiers waited in the valley, or dry riverbed, outside of the city of Amalek. A wall may have surrounded this city to protect the people in the city. While the army was waiting in the valley, Saul sent a message to the Kenites who lived with the Amalekites. The Kenites were kind to the Israelites when the Israelites came out of Egypt because the Kenites guided the Israelites in the desert. Saul chose to warn the Kenites to leave before the battle began so the Kenites would be safe from fighting. The Kenites listened to the warning and left the Amalekites.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Saul showed loyalty to the Kenites because of what the Kenites had done many years ago for the Israelites. When is it important to show loyalty to a person or group of people in your culture? How does your culture show loyalty to people in your culture as well as people outside of your culture? Pause this audio here.

Saul and his army then defeated the Amalekites from the city of Havilah to the city of Shur. We do not know the location of Havilah, but it is perhaps in the territory of the Ishmaelites, descendants of Abraham's first son. We think Shur is east of Egypt, in the wilderness region in the Sinai Peninsula.

Though Saul and his army won the battle against the Amalekites, Saul did not obey Yahweh's command to destroy everyone and everything that belonged to the Amalekites. Saul took Agag, the king, captive as a prisoner of war. Saul also spared the best of the livestock and did not completely destroy the animals. But, everything that was not good, Saul and his army destroyed.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Share stories where the Israelites or people in your communities failed to obey instructions from a deity. Why do you think Saul may have chosen to disobey?

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 15:1–9 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has four scenes.

In the first scene: Samuel tells Saul to listen to Yahweh's words. Yahweh tells Saul that Yahweh knows that the Amalekites fought against Israel when the Israelites came out of Egypt. Yahweh instructs Saul and Saul's army to completely destroy the Amalekites and everything that belongs to the Amalekites. Yahweh tells Saul to kill everyone, including men, women, children, and infants, plus all of the livestock animals.

In the second scene: Saul prepares Saul's army to fight against the Amalekites. Saul calls Saul's army to meet Saul in Telaim, and then Saul inspects and numbers the soldiers. There are 200,000 foot soldiers from Israel, plus 10,000 men from the tribe of Judah.

In the third scene: Saul and Saul's army come to the valley outside of the city of Amalek and wait there. Saul sends a warning to the Kenites who live with the Amalekites to leave the area. Saul says that the Kenites showed kindness to the Israelites when the Israelites left Egypt, so Yahweh will not harm the Kenites. So the Kenites leave the Amalekites.

In the fourth scene: Saul and Saul's army defeat the Amalekites from Havilah as far as Shur, which is next to Egypt. Saul takes Agag, Amalek's king, alive. But Saul destroys all of the people by the sword of Saul's armies. However, Saul spares, or keeps alive, Agag and all of the best sheep, oxen, the fattest calves, and the lambs. Saul does not destroy these animals. But everything that Saul thinks is worthless, the Israelites destroy.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Saul

  • Samuel

  • Yahweh

  • The Israelite foot soldiers

  • The soldiers from Judah

  • The Kenites

  • The Amalekites

  • And Agag

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

We do not know how long after the previous passage this passage happens. It seems as if Saul has had time to build up his army, so it may have been quite a bit of time. We are also not sure exactly where the conversation between Samuel and Saul takes place.

When Samuel talks to Saul, Samuel identifies himself as the person Yahweh had previously sent to anoint Saul as king of the Israelites, Yahweh's chosen people. Saul has to obey Samuel since Samuel is a prophet of Yahweh. Samuel tells Saul to listen to the words of Yahweh as Samuel tells the words to Saul.

Samuel identifies Yahweh as "Yahweh of hosts." This title shows that Yahweh is the leader of both the armies of the Israelite people and the armies of spiritual beings in heaven.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How will you talk about Yahweh as "Yahweh of hosts"? Pause this audio here.

Amalek was a grandson of Esau, Jacob's older twin brother. Amalek's descendants, the Amalekites, had attacked the Israelites at Rephidim in the Sinai wilderness. Yahweh tells Saul, through Samuel, to go and utterly, or completely, destroy the Amalekites and all of the Amalekites' belongings and animals.

In the second scene, Saul calls his men to the area of Telaim, and then Saul counts and inspects the men.

Stop here and do this activity as a group: Count as many of one specific object as you can see. For example, count all of the rocks in the area. Discuss how you would count large numbers in the thousands and tens of thousands. Pause this audio here.

In the third scene, the story talks about both Saul and Saul's army by only saying Saul's name. In your translation, you could say that Saul and Saul's soldiers go to the city of Amalek and wait in the valley. It is not only Saul who goes, but Saul and all of Saul's men. The valley is a dry riverbed, or lower part of land, where water only flows in the rainy season. Saul and his army wait in the valley so that they can attack the Amalekites in the city at the right time.

Stop here and have one person in the group give instructions directly to a leader about what the leader should do, together with the leader's people. Pay attention to how you talk about the leader and all of the leader's people. Do you only use the leader's name, or do you say the leader and all of the leader's people? Pause this audio here.

The story then says that Saul told the Kenites to leave the Amalekites. More than likely, Saul did not say this directly to the Kenites. Saul probably sent a message to the Kenite leaders to tell their people to leave the area so the Kenites would not be destroyed. The Kenites had acted as a guide to the Israelites when the Israelites had left Egypt. Because the Kenites were kind, Saul spared the Kenites. Saul told the Kenites that the Kenites were kind to, or steadfastly loved, the Israelites. Saul meant that the Kenites were loyal and faithful to the Israelites by doing something to help the Israelites.

Stop here and discuss as a group stories about people or groups of people who are very kind and very loyal. What kinds of words do you use to describe this type of person? When someone is kind like this, others trust that person and think that person is very loyal. Pause this audio here.

In scene four, Saul destroyed the Amalekites but did not obey Yahweh's command. Saul took Agag, the Amalekites' king, prisoner and kept Agag alive. Saul did destroy the rest of the Amalekites. However, Saul kept the best of the livestock alive and was not willing to destroy these animals. Saul's army did destroy everything that no one wanted or that was weak or unworthy.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 15:1–9 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has four scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Saul

  • Samuel

  • Yahweh

  • The Israelite foot soldiers

  • The soldiers from Judah

  • The Kenites

  • The Amalekites

  • And Agag

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Samuel tells Saul to listen to Yahweh's words. Yahweh tells Saul that Yahweh knows that the Amalekites fought against Israel when the Israelites came out of Egypt. Yahweh instructs Saul and Saul's army to completely destroy the Amalekites and everything that belongs to the Amalekites. Yahweh tells Saul to kill everyone, including men, women, children, and infants, plus all of the livestock animals.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Killing women, children, and babies seems so cruel! or

  • I had better do this just right because Yahweh is already upset that I did not obey last time; or

  • I can kill everything, maybe. But what if the Amalekites have some good animals?

Saul prepared his army to fight against the Amalekites. Saul called his army to meet Saul in Telaim, and then Saul inspected and numbered the men. There were 200,000 foot soldiers from Israel, plus 10,000 men from Judah's tribe.

Saul and his army came to the valley outside the city of Amalek and waited there. Saul sent a warning to the Kenites who lived with the Amalekites to leave the area. Saul said that the Kenites showed kindness to the Israelites when the Israelites left Egypt, so the Kenites would be spared. So the Kenites left the Amalekites.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Kenites, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Thank the god of the Israelites that our ancestors were kind to the Israelites! Now the Israelites are kind to us! or

  • Praise be to Yahweh, that Yahweh is letting us live! or

  • I never liked those Amalekites!

Saul and his army defeated the Amalekites from the city of Havilah as far as the city of Shur, which is next to Egypt. Saul took Agag, the Amalek king, but destroyed all of the people by the sword of Saul's armies. However, Saul spared or kept alive Agag and all of the best sheep, oxen, the fattest calves, and the lambs, and did not destroy them. But everything that Saul thought was worthless, the Israelites destroyed.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Yahweh could not have really meant all of the sheep. Look, these sheep are perfect for sacrificing to Yahweh! or

  • I am sure it will not hurt for us to keep the animals. The animals are not worshiping foreign gods, and the animals are in good condition.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Why will Saul not just listen to me? Does Saul not know that what I tell Saul to do is best for Saul? or

  • I am so angry at Saul, but I still love my people. I will bring another person to rule over Israel who loves me.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 15:1–9 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Samuel told Saul that Samuel was the one whom Yahweh had sent to anoint Saul as king over the Israelites. So Samuel told Saul to listen to the word or voice of Yahweh, or the message that Yahweh had given for Saul. Yahweh is God's personal and proper name. To anoint is to set someone or something apart for special service by pouring a sweet-smelling oil over that person. A king is someone who rules over a region or country. The people of Israel were God's chosen people who were Jacob's descendants. Use the same words for Yahweh, anoint, king, and Israelites that you have used in previous passages. For more information on Yahweh, anoint, king, and Israelite, refer to the Master Glossary.

Yahweh of hosts tells Saul to attack the Amalekites as punishment for the way they treated the Israelites when the Israelites left Egypt. Saul is to attack the Amalekites and destroy all of the people and all that belongs to the Amalekites. Saul should completely destroy, not spare, or not keep alive the Amalekites. Saul must put to death all of the men, women, children, and babies, as well as the cattle and sheep, camels, and donkeys. Remember that cattle can be cows or oxen. "Yahweh of hosts" means that God is in charge of Israel's armies and the armies of the spiritual beings in heaven. Camels are large, strong animals that can walk for a long time in the desert. Donkeys are animals that are big enough to carry a heavy load or a person. Use the same words or phrases for Yahweh of hosts, cattle and sheep, camels, and donkeys that you have used in previous passages. For more information on Yahweh of hosts, camels, and donkeys, refer to the Master Glossary.

Stop here and discuss as a group how you will talk about someone completely destroying something. If you have already translated this idea in another book of the Bible, translate it in a similar way here. Pause this audio here.

Saul called all of Saul's army together from Israel and Judah. Saul and Saul's army waited in the valley, or dry riverbed, outside of the city of Amalek. A valley, sometimes called a wadi, is a dry riverbed that only flows with water during the rainy season. A city is a large area where people live, and it has a wall around it to protect it. Use the same words for valley or dry riverbed and city that you have used in previous passages.

Saul warned the Kenites who were living with the Amalekites to leave the city so Yahweh would not destroy them. Saul did this because the Kenites had shown kindness, or steadfast love, to the Israelites. So the Kenites left.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for kindness or steadfast love. Look up steadfast love in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this idea in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Saul's army destroyed the Amalekites with swords. In other words, Saul's army used swords to kill the Amalekites in battle. Talk about killing people with swords in battle in the same way as you have in previous passages.

Then Saul attacked the Amalekites and took Agag, the king, and all of the best animals and kept them alive. But everyone else and all of the unworthy animals Saul and Saul's army completely destroyed.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
