title: 1 Samuel 15:10–23
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 15:10–23 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 15:10–23 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 15:10–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous passage, Yahweh gave a command to Saul through the prophet Samuel. Samuel told Saul that Yahweh was going to punish the Amalekites for their sins against the Israelites. Yahweh told Saul to totally destroy the Amalekites and everything that belonged to the Amalekites. Saul went to battle with Saul's army and destroyed all of the Amalekites except for the king, Agag. Then the soldiers in Saul's army kept the best of the sheep and cattle in order to sacrifice those animals to Yahweh.

In this passage, the scene shifts from Saul's actions to Yahweh's response. Yahweh speaks to Samuel and tells Samuel that Yahweh is sad because he made Saul king, since Saul has not followed Yahweh. Therefore, Yahweh will remove Saul from the position that Yahweh gave Saul as king. Samuel is angry and cries out to Yahweh all night. More than likely, Samuel is feeling the sadness of Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss as a group a story about a time when your culture's god felt an emotion such as sadness or anger. What happened to make your god feel that way, and what did that god do? Pause this audio here.

At Carmel, Saul put up a monument, probably to celebrate Saul's victory over Amalek. Kings often did this in the ancient Near East. Gilgal was in the Jordan Valley and was the main town where people made sacrifices to Yahweh. Gilgal was also the place where Samuel had anointed Saul as king.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What places in your culture are religiously or politically significant to the people in your culture? Why are those places significant? Pause this audio here.

Stop here as a group and look at a map of Carmel and Gilgal. Pause this audio here.

The prophet arrived, probably when King Saul was getting ready to offer burnt offerings from the best animals that Saul took from Amalek. Saul greeted Samuel enthusiastically, and Saul blessed Samuel and assured Samuel that Saul had carried out Yahweh's command successfully. Saul told Samuel that Saul had kept the best sheep and cattle for sacrifice to Yahweh. Saul had directly disobeyed Yahweh! Samuel shows that Samuel does not believe Saul's claim to have obeyed Yahweh's commandment and to have killed all of the people and animals of the Amalekites.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell stories of people who have rebelled against deities in your culture. What are the consequences for people in your culture who rebel against their deities? Pause this audio here.

Samuel asks Saul about the cries or sounds of the sheep and oxen.

Saul blames Saul's soldiers for failing to completely destroy everything. Then Saul says the soldiers spared the animals for a good reason: to make sacrifices to Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are some of the reasons that people might give for disobeying their deities? Why do you think people might disobey deities? Pause this audio here.

When Yahweh commanded Saul to totally destroy the Amalekites and their belongings, Yahweh placed the Amalekites and their possessions under a ban. In other words, these people and their property were completely off limits to the Israelites and were inappropriate or unclean to sacrifice to Yahweh. When Saul decided to sacrifice these animals to Yahweh, Saul showed that Saul was making an idol of himself and Saul rejected Yahweh's message.

Samuel says that Yahweh is more pleased when people obey Yahweh than when people make sacrifices to Yahweh. Then Samuel says that to rebel against God and to be stubborn are as sinful as witchcraft and worshiping idols. Samuel ends his statement by telling Saul that because Saul has rejected Yahweh's command, Yahweh now rejects Saul as king. Samuel is not saying that people are doing the wrong thing when they give sacrifices, but Samuel is saying that to obey God is always the most important thing that people should do.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 15:10–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has five scenes.

In the first scene: Yahweh speaks to Samuel and tells Samuel that Yahweh regrets making Saul king of Israel. Samuel is distressed and angry and cries out to Yahweh through the night.

In the second scene: Someone tells Samuel where to find Saul. They say that Saul has built a monument of himself in Carmel and then gone down to Gilgal.

In the third scene: Samuel finds Saul. Saul says that Yahweh has blessed Samuel, and Saul tells Samuel that Saul has carried out Yahweh's commands. Samuel confronts Saul and says that Saul has disobeyed Yahweh. Saul makes excuses that the soldiers brought the best sheep and oxen from the Amalekites in order to sacrifice to Yahweh. Saul says that Saul and his men totally destroyed the rest of the Amalekites.

In the fourth scene: Samuel tells Saul that Yahweh said that Saul was once small in his own sight, but that Yahweh had anointed Saul as king and sent Saul to destroy the Amalekites completely. Samuel again confronts Saul for disobeying and calls what Saul did evil in Yahweh's sight.

In the fifth scene: Saul again makes excuses that he did obey Yahweh. Yet Saul brought back King Agag, and the soldiers took some of the sheep and oxen from the Amalekites to sacrifice to Yahweh. Samuel tells Saul that Yahweh is not as happy when people make sacrifices as much as Yahweh is happy when people obey Yahweh. Samuel says that rebellion is like the sin of divination, or calling upon other spirits. Samuel also says that when someone is arrogant or thinks that they are better than everyone else, it is the same as idolatry. Now, because Saul has rejected Yahweh's commands, Yahweh has rejected Saul as king.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Yahweh

  • Samuel

  • Saul

  • Agag

  • Amalekites

  • And soldiers

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

It is likely that the action starts outside of the battle in which Samuel had told Saul to destroy the Amalekites. This scene shifts from the battle to the conversation between Yahweh and Samuel. Then Samuel goes to find Saul in Gilgal.

In the first scene, when the word of Yahweh comes to Samuel, this means that Yahweh speaks to Samuel. This is the normal way that Yahweh spoke to a prophet. Yahweh says that Yahweh regrets that Yahweh made Saul king. Yahweh is not saying that Yahweh made a mistake. Yahweh is explaining that Yahweh is sad that Saul rebelled against Yahweh. Samuel is so distressed and angry that Samuel cries out to Yahweh all night long.

Stop here as a group and talk about different ways that God speaks. What words do you use when God speaks to you or to others? Notice the way you describe God speaking. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and talk about a time when you were both sad and angry at the same time. How will you talk about how Samuel felt when he cried out to Yahweh? Pause this audio here.

The second scene starts early in the morning when Samuel goes to meet Saul. Someone tells Samuel that Saul has set up a monument, or some sort of structure, to himself in Carmel, a town in Judah. Then Samuel goes to Gilgal.

In the third scene, when Saul sees Samuel in Gilgal, Saul says that Yahweh has blessed Samuel. Saul then boasts that Saul obeyed Yahweh. However, Samuel asks Saul why Samuel hears the sounds of the sheep and oxen in the distance. Samuel is not asking Saul a question that Samuel expects Saul to answer. Samuel is reminding Saul that Samuel knows Saul did not obey Yahweh. You may want to use the words here for the specific sounds these animals make, or you can use a general word for the cries of the animals. Samuel uses the phrases "in my ears" and "I hear," both of which mean that Samuel hears the noises the animals make.

Saul says that it was the people, or the soldiers, who brought the sheep and oxen from the Amalekites to sacrifice to Yahweh, Samuel's God. The original language simply says that someone brought the sheep and oxen to Saul, but we know that it was the soldiers. It is also important to notice that Saul calls Yahweh "Samuel's God," not Saul's own God.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you describe the sounds that animals make? What sounds do you use for sheep and cows, or oxen? Make those sounds. How will you talk about the way the animals in this story make these sounds? Pause this audio here.

In the fourth scene, Samuel starts with the exclamation, "Enough!" Samuel is telling Saul to stop talking. Samuel tells Saul what Yahweh had said to Samuel the previous evening. Samuel says that Saul might have thought of himself as small in his own eyes, which means that Saul thought of himself as unimportant.

Stop here and discuss as a group: If you feel like you are not important, how do you describe yourself? How will you talk about how Saul used to feel like Saul was not important? Pause this audio here.

Then Samuel asks Saul again why Saul did not obey Yahweh. Note that Samuel is saying that Saul is the one who disobeyed by taking the spoils of the war. Samuel asks Saul directly why Saul did not obey Yahweh to help Saul understand that Saul did not obey. Samuel asks Saul why Saul did something that was evil in the eyes of Yahweh, which means that Yahweh thinks what Saul did was evil.

In the fifth scene, Saul still says that Saul obeyed the voice of Yahweh, or Yahweh's instructions to Saul. Saul admits that Saul brought back Agag, the Amalekites' king. Then Saul tries to say that it was the people, not Saul, who were the ones who took the spoils of war to sacrifice to Yahweh, but that the people destroyed everything else. Samuel passes Yahweh's judgment on Saul and declares that it is better to obey Yahweh than to sacrifice to Yahweh. Samuel says that when someone rebels or disobeys against Yahweh, it is like that person sins by asking other spirits to help them. Samuel says that when someone thinks they know better than Yahweh, that person is making themself an idol. That person is really worshipping something other than Yahweh. Samuel ends by telling Saul that Yahweh has rejected Saul as king of Israel.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 15:10–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has five scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Yahweh

  • Samuel

  • Saul

  • Agag

  • Amalekites

  • And soldiers

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Yahweh speaks to Samuel and tells Samuel that Yahweh regrets making Saul king of Israel. Samuel is distressed and angry and cries out to Yahweh through the night.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so angry at Saul for his disobedience! Now Yahweh will reject Saul as king! or

  • Why did Yahweh make Saul king in the first place? or

  • Yahweh, please give Saul another chance!

Someone tells Samuel that Saul built a monument of himself in Carmel and then went to Gilgal. Samuel finds Saul in Gilgal. Saul calls Samuel "blessed of Yahweh" and tells Samuel that Saul has carried out Yahweh's commands.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so awesome! I built a monument to myself. This was a great victory! or

  • I feel panic. I need to justify why I did not keep all of Yahweh's commands; or

  • Samuel is here, so we can go make these sacrifices to Yahweh!

Samuel confronts Saul for not obeying Yahweh. Saul makes excuses that the sheep and oxen were the best that the soldiers brought back from the Amalekites in order to sacrifice to Yahweh. Saul says that the soldiers totally destroyed the rest of the animals.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I destroyed everyone but Agag! Is that not good enough? I was obedient! or

  • I do not understand why Samuel is so upset. I was not the one who brought the sheep and oxen back. That was my army, not me. or

  • I do not understand! We kept these so we could sacrifice them to Yahweh. Is that not what Yahweh would want from us?

Samuel tells Saul that Yahweh said Saul was once small in Saul's own sight, but that Yahweh had anointed Saul as king and sent him to destroy the Amalekites completely. Samuel again confronts Saul about Saul's disobedience and calls that disobedience evil in the sight of Yahweh.

Saul again makes excuses that Saul did obey Yahweh. Yet Saul had brought back Agag, and the soldiers had taken some of the sheep and oxen from the Amalekites to sacrifice to Yahweh.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am getting more and more angry as I talk to Saul. Saul just does not understand; or

  • I cannot believe how prideful Saul is. Saul does not actually realize that it was Saul who was disobedient to Yahweh. Yahweh gave Saul clear instructions, and Saul did not follow the commands or make his soldiers follow them!

Samuel tells Saul that Yahweh does not delight in sacrifices as much as Yahweh does obedience. Samuel says that rebellion is like the sin of divination, or calling upon other spirits, and that being proud is the same as worshipping other gods.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 15:10–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

The word of Yahweh came to Samuel. In other words, Yahweh gave Samuel a message. Yahweh said that Yahweh regretted making Saul the king of Israel. Saul had disobeyed Yahweh. Saul did not fulfill the commands that Yahweh had given Saul. Samuel was angry or distressed and cried out all night to Yahweh. Yahweh is God's personal and proper name. Use the same word for Yahweh that you have used in previous passages. For more information on word and Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary.

Samuel got up early in the morning to meet Saul. Someone told Samuel that Saul had gone to Carmel to set up a monument to himself because of Saul's victory over the Amalekites. Then Saul had gone down to Gilgal. When Samuel found Saul, Saul said that Yahweh had blessed, or done good to, Samuel. Saul declared that Saul had obeyed the word or command of Yahweh. Use the same word for blessed as you have used in previous passages. For more information on blessed, refer to the Master Glossary.

But Samuel asked Saul, "What then is the bleating of the sheep and lowing of oxen that I hear?" Bleating and lowing are the sounds that sheep and oxen make. Use the same words for sheep and oxen that you have used in previous passages.

Stop here and discuss together as a group what you will call these sounds that the animals make. Pause this audio here.

Saul confesses that the army brought the best sheep and oxen from the Amalekites to sacrifice to Yahweh, whom Saul calls "Samuel's God." But Saul says that his army destroyed everything else. A sacrifice is a gift that people give to Yahweh. God is the one true creator God. Use the same words for sacrifice and God that you have used in previous passages. For more information on sacrifice and God, refer to the Master Glossary.

Samuel tells Saul to stop talking so that Samuel can tell Saul what Yahweh has said. Samuel talks about when Saul still felt unimportant, but Yahweh anointed Saul as king over Israel. When someone anoints someone or something else, they set that person or thing apart by pouring a sweet-smelling oil over the person or thing. A king is a ruler over a territory or region, like a nation or country. Use the same words for anoint and king that you have used in previous passages. For more information on anoint and king, refer to the Master Glossary.

Samuel confronts Saul because Saul disobeyed Yahweh. Saul kept some of the spoil, or good things, from the Amalekites. Yahweh saw this as evil. Evil is the opposite of good. In this case, evil is disobedience to Yahweh. Use the same word for evil that you have used in previous passages. For more information on evil, refer to the Master Glossary.

Saul then defends himself and says that Saul did what Yahweh told Saul to do. But Saul says that it was the people, or the soldiers, who disobeyed and took the spoil, the sheep and oxen, to sacrifice to Yahweh.

Then Samuel corrects Saul by telling Saul that Yahweh is happy when people obey more than when people make sacrifices. Samuel says that when people rebel, it is like the people are looking to other things than Yahweh for their answers, much like a person who sins when they use divination. Divination is when someone calls on spirits that are not Yahweh. Samuel also says that disobedience is the same as wickedness and idolatry, or worshiping other gods. Therefore, since Saul rejected the word or command of Yahweh, Yahweh has rejected Saul from being the king. Use the same words for sin, divination, and idolatry that you have used in previous passages. For more information on sin, divination, and idols, refer to the Master Glossary.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 15:24–35
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 15:24–35 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 15:24–35 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 15:24–35 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous passages, Samuel gave Saul instructions from Yahweh to totally destroy the Amalekites. Saul won the battle against the Amalakites, but allowed King Agag and the best sheep and cows to live. When Saul saw Samuel, Saul greeted Samuel and said that Saul had obeyed Yahweh's commandments. Samuel told Saul that because Saul had rejected the word or instructions of Yahweh, Yahweh had rejected Saul as king of Israel.

In this passage, Saul admits that Saul did sin by listening to the desires of Saul's soldiers, instead of listening to the word of Yahweh. Saul confesses his sin and provides a weak excuse. Saul says he was "afraid of the men," so Saul "listened to their voice." Samuel had commanded Saul to listen to the voice of Yahweh, but Saul disobeyed by listening to other voices instead.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Who are some of the people that you are tempted to listen to instead of God? Who do people in your culture listen to for advice? Why do they listen to those people? Pause this audio here.

The conversation between Samuel and Saul has apparently been in secret, away from people. Now Saul asks Samuel to return with Saul to worship Yahweh because Saul wants the Israelites to feel like Samuel still honors Saul as king. Samuel refuses to go with Saul because Yahweh no longer blesses Saul as king, and Yahweh has rejected Saul.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do the actions of one person give honor to another person in your culture? Who do people in your community want to be friends with because it makes them famous? Pause this audio here.

When Samuel turns to leave the area, Saul grabs the hem or end of Samuel's long robe, and it tears. Usually, when someone tears their own clothing in this culture, that person is sad about bad news or about a sin that the person has done. In this case, Saul means something very different. Regardless of what Saul may have intended, Samuel explains the real meaning. Just as Saul separated a piece of cloth from Samuel, so Yahweh has taken the kingdom of Israel from Saul.

Stop here and look at a picture of a robe. Pause this audio here.

Samuel says that Yahweh will give Saul's kingdom to another person, or a neighbor, who is better than Saul. This does not necessarily mean that Yahweh will give the kingdom to someone who lives in the same town, but perhaps to a friend, or to someone Saul knows.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Talk about a time when a good leader came in place of a bad leader. How did this change happen? What did people know about the leadership change before it happened? Pause this audio here.

Samuel goes on to say that Yahweh, whom Samuel calls the "Glory of Israel," will not lie or change his mind. Samuel calls Yahweh the "Glory of Israel" to show that Yahweh lasts forever, and therefore Yahweh does not change. Samuel wants to show Saul what Yahweh is like, and Samuel wants to remind Saul that Yahweh has made a decision that is final.

Saul confesses his sin again to Samuel. However, instead of honoring Yahweh, Saul is concerned with honoring himself. Saul is unwilling to be ashamed in front of the Israelites, and especially the elders or older leaders of Israel.

Although Samuel had said that he would not return with Saul, Samuel changes his mind and turns back after all to go with Saul.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Talk about a time when you or someone else wanted to cover up a shameful action. What did you do? Who did you ask to help you? Pause this audio here.

You will remember that Saul had not killed the king of the Amalekites. Now, Samuel asks his guards to bring King Agag into Samuel's presence. King Agag goes calmly because Agag thinks that no one wants to kill Agag anymore. Instead, Samuel speaks to Agag. Samuel tells Agag that Agag has killed people with swords, and many mothers no longer have children because of Agag. Therefore, Samuel will make Agag's mother childless. Then Samuel kills and cuts Agag to pieces in front of Yahweh, much like a priest cuts up an animal to sacrifice to Yahweh. In this way, Samuel completes the work that Saul did not do. Samuel makes sure that the Israelites destroy everything they took from the Amalekites.

In summary, both Samuel and Saul go back to their own hometowns. The distance between their towns is about 16 kilometers. Samuel does not see Saul ever again, though Samuel feels sad because Saul disobeyed Yahweh. Yahweh also regrets, or is sorry, that Yahweh had made Saul king over Israel. This does not mean that Yahweh himself has changed. This simply means that when Saul disobeyed Yahweh, Yahweh was sad that Saul had made that choice to disobey Yahweh.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 15:24–35 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has four scenes.

In the first scene: Saul confesses to disobeying Yahweh's word and Samuel's instruction because Saul was afraid of his men, or soldiers. Saul asks for forgiveness from Samuel and asks Samuel to go back to Gilgal with Saul. Samuel refuses to go back to Gilgal with Saul. Samuel tells Saul that since Saul has rejected Yahweh's command, Yahweh has rejected Saul as Israel's king. Samuel tells Saul that Yahweh will not lie or change his mind because Yahweh is not like a human who changes his mind.

In the second scene: Saul begs Samuel again to honor Saul by going back to Gilgal with Saul so that Saul may worship Yahweh, Samuel's God. So Samuel goes back to Gilgal with Saul, and Saul worships Yahweh.

In the third scene: Samuel asks for someone to bring Agag, the Amalekites' king, to Samuel. Agag goes to Samuel gladly because Agag thinks that the time for Agag to die has passed. Samuel tells Agag that the same way Agag made many women childless, so will Agag's mother be childless. Samuel cuts Agag to pieces with a sword in front of Yahweh.

In the fourth scene: Samuel returns to Samuel's home in Ramah, and Saul returns to Saul's house at Gibeah. Samuel never meets with Saul again, but Samuel mourns for Saul. Yahweh is sorry that Yahweh made Saul king of Israel.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Saul

  • Samuel

  • Yahweh

  • King Agag

  • Saul's soldiers

  • And the Israelite elders

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In the first and second scenes, Saul and Samuel's conversation takes place somewhere in or near Gilgal. However, Saul and Samuel are not at the place where they sacrifice the offerings to Yahweh. Saul says that he has sinned against Yahweh's command and against Samuel's instructions. In this case, Saul actually says that Saul has sinned against the "mouth of Yahweh," which means that Saul has disobeyed what Yahweh told Saul to do.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How will you talk about how Saul describes what Saul did? Saul says that Saul did not do what Yahweh told Saul to do. Pause this audio here.

But Saul gives an excuse. Saul says that Saul was afraid of his men, Saul's soldiers. Saul begs Samuel to forgive Saul and to come back with Saul to worship Yahweh, or so that Saul can sacrifice the animals that Saul brought back to worship Yahweh. Samuel refuses to go with Saul. Samuel says that Saul has rejected "the word of Yahweh," which means that Saul has not obeyed what Yahweh told Saul to do. Because Saul rejected Yahweh's commands, Yahweh rejected Saul himself as king over Yahweh's people, Israel.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How will you say that Yahweh rejects Saul because Saul did not obey Yahweh? Pause this audio here.

Samuel turns around to leave. As Samuel turns, Saul reaches down and pulls on the bottom of Samuel's long robe. Some of the cloth tears off. Saul is begging Samuel to stay with Saul. But Samuel uses this action to tell Saul what Yahweh will do. Samuel says that Yahweh will tear away, or take away, Saul's kingdom and give it to another person who is better than Saul. Some Bible translations say that Yahweh will give the kingdom to a neighbor. This does not necessarily mean that Yahweh will give the kingdom to someone who lives in the same town, but that Yahweh might give the kingdom to a friend, or to someone Saul knows.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Samuel uses Saul's action of tearing Samuel's robe as a way to show Saul what will happen to Saul's kingdom. How will you talk about this in your translation? Pause this audio here.

Samuel says that "The Glory of Israel does not lie or change his mind." The Glory of Israel refers to Yahweh. The word glory is not the normal word for glory. It is a word that usually means "something that continues forever." Some Bible translations translate this title for Yahweh as something like "the eternal God of Israel." The fact that Yahweh will not lie or change Yahweh's mind is something that is always true about Yahweh. Samuel wants Saul to know that Yahweh has decided to reject Saul as king, and there is nothing Saul can do to change Yahweh's mind.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How will you translate the title "The Glory of Israel" so that it refers to Yahweh as a God who is always the same? Pause this audio here.

In the second scene, Saul confesses his sin again. However, Saul immediately changes from talking about Saul's own sin to begging Samuel again to come with Saul so that Saul will not be ashamed in front of the elders of Israel. Saul needs Samuel, as Israel's religious leader, to be with Saul when Saul sacrifices the animals. It is important to remember that Saul again calls Yahweh Samuel's God. Saul says that Saul will worship "Yahweh, your God." Samuel finally agrees and goes back to Gilgal with Saul. Saul worships Yahweh there, probably by sacrificing the animals Saul has brought back from the Amalekites.

In the third scene, Samuel asks for someone to bring King Agag to Samuel. King Agag comes. Although we do not fully understand the language here, it is possible that King Agag was hopeful or cheerful because he thought "the bitterness of death was past." In other words, King Agag thought that it was too late for the Israelites to kill him and that Agag would not experience the horrible shame and pain of death. However, Samuel reminds King Agag of what Agag has done to others. Samuel says that King Agag has made many women no longer have children because Agag has killed those women's children with swords. Because of this, Samuel will make King Agag's mother no longer have children by killing King Agag with a sword.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Samuel uses special language to talk about how King Agag killed many people with swords, and that is why Samuel will kill King Agag with a sword. How will you talk about this in your translation? Pause this audio here.

Samuel cuts Agag into many pieces with a sword, probably in the same way he would cut up an animal before Samuel sacrifices it to Yahweh. This is why the story tells us that Samuel kills Agag "in front of Yahweh."

In the fourth scene, Samuel returns to Samuel's hometown of Ramah, and Saul returns to Gibeah. Samuel never again sees Saul, but Samuel is very sad that Saul has disobeyed Yahweh. Yahweh is sorry that Yahweh made Saul king of Israel.

Stop here and look together at the map of Gilgal, Ramah, and Gibeah. Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 15:24–35 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has four scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Saul

  • Samuel

  • Yahweh

  • King Agag

  • Saul's soldiers

  • And the Israelite elders

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Saul confesses to disobeying Yahweh's word and Samuel's instruction because Saul was afraid of his men, the soldiers. Saul did what the people wanted, not what Yahweh told Saul to do. Saul asks for forgiveness from Samuel and asks Samuel to go back to Gilgal with Saul.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I was really hoping it would be okay to bring sheep back to sacrifice; or

  • I should have known better than to be disobedient again! or

  • Maybe Yahweh will change his mind.

Samuel refuses to go back to Gilgal with Saul. Samuel tells Saul that since Saul has rejected Yahweh's command, Yahweh has rejected Saul as Israel's king.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • How could Saul do this? or

  • Does Saul not understand that he had to obey what Yahweh said? Now, who will rule over the Israelites? or

  • My heart is so sad at Saul's disobedience.

Samuel turns to leave, and Saul grabs Samuel's robe. Saul tears Samuel's robe. Samuel tells Saul that Yahweh has torn the kingdom of Israel from Saul and has given it to Saul's neighbor, who is better than Saul. Samuel tells Saul that Yahweh, who is the Glory of Israel, will not lie or change his mind because Yahweh is not like a human who changes his mind.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • My anger against Saul is great! Saul has not obeyed me, so Saul will not be king; or

  • My heart delights in Samuel, and I know Samuel will deliver my word; or

  • I have already chosen another person to be king. I am done with Saul!

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you thinking or feeling?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am devastated that Yahweh will not change his mind; or

  • I want to do anything to make Yahweh allow me to keep the kingdom; or

  • I do not believe Samuel! I will keep the kingdom, because I will look good to the Israelites! I will convince Samuel to come back with me and honor me!

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you thinking or feeling?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am devastated that Saul would do this; or

  • I am angry now. Saul is showing that he does not repent.

Saul begs Samuel again to honor Saul by going back to Gilgal with Saul so that Saul may worship Yahweh, Samuel's God. So Samuel goes back to Gilgal with Saul, and Saul worships Yahweh.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • At least Samuel will come back with me to show the elders that I am still honored!

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I will go back with Saul in order to kill Agag and finish the job; or

  • I still love Saul. I want to help Saul as much as I can.

Samuel asks people to bring Agag, the Amalekites' king, to Samuel. Agag goes to Samuel gladly because Agag thinks that the time for Agag to die has passed. Samuel tells Agag that the same way Agag made many women childless, so will Agag's mother be childless. Samuel cuts Agag to pieces with a sword in front of Yahweh.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Agag, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel panic. I really thought I was safe!

Samuel returns to Samuel's home in Ramah, and Saul returns to Saul's house at Gibeah. Samuel never meets with Saul again, but Samuel mourns for Saul. Yahweh is sorry that Yahweh made Saul king of Israel.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 15:24–35 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

In this passage, Saul confesses that he disobeyed Yahweh's command and Samuel's instruction. Saul confesses that Saul was afraid of his soldiers, so Saul gave in to the soldiers' wishes instead of obeying Yahweh. Saul begs for Samuel to forgive Saul's sin and asks Samuel to go back with Saul so that Saul may worship Yahweh. Yahweh is God's personal, proper name. To worship is to give honor to God. Use the same words that you have used for Yahweh, sin, and worship in previous passages. For more information on Yahweh, sin, and worship, refer to the Master Glossary.

Stop here and discuss what word or phrase you will use for forgive. Use the same word you have used in other books of the Bible, and see the Master Glossary for more information on forgiveness. Pause this audio here.

Samuel tells Saul that Samuel will not go with Saul to worship Yahweh. Samuel says that Saul has rejected the word of Yahweh and so Yahweh has rejected Saul as Israel's king. The "word of Yahweh" is the command or instruction that Yahweh gave. To reject someone or something is to dismiss that person or thing. A king is a ruler over a region or country. Israel is the country of people who belong to Yahweh, who people call the Israelites. Use the same words or phrases for the "word of Yahweh," reject, king, and Israel as you have used in previous passages. For more information on word, king, and Israel, refer to the Master Glossary.

Samuel turns to leave, and Saul tries to grab Samuel's robe to stop Samuel from leaving. Saul tears Samuel's robe. Samuel tells Saul that Yahweh has torn or taken the kingdom of Israel from Saul and given it to someone else—one of Saul's neighbors who is better than Saul. A robe is a piece of clothing that people would usually wear as an outer garment. A kingdom is a territory or a people that a king rules. A neighbor is someone who lives in the same area or near the same region as another person. Use the same words for robe, kingdom, and neighbor that you have used in previous passages. For more information on robe, kingdom, and neighbor, refer to the Master Glossary.

Samuel tells Saul that Yahweh, who is the glory of Israel, does not lie or change Yahweh's mind because Yahweh is not a human. Glory is usually the fame that people receive for doing something wonderful. In this case, this word reminds the people that Yahweh's fame and Yahweh's character never change.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for glory in this setting. Pause this audio here.

Saul confesses his sin again to Samuel. Saul also requests that Samuel honor Saul before the elders of Saul's people and Israel by going back with Saul to worship Yahweh, Samuel's God. So Samuel goes back with Saul, and Saul worships Yahweh. Use the same words for God and for elders that you have used in previous passages. For more information on God and elders, refer to the Master Glossary.

Then Samuel asks for Agag, the Amalekites' king. Agag comes to Samuel gladly because Agag thinks the possibility of Agag's death has passed. But Samuel tells Agag that since Agag's sword has made many women childless, Agag's mother will also be childless. Then Samuel cuts Agag to pieces with a sword before Yahweh, at Gilgal.

Samuel then returns to Samuel's home in Ramah, and Saul returns to Saul's home in Gibeah. Samuel never meets with Saul again. Samuel mourns a lot for Saul. Yahweh is sorry that Yahweh made Saul king of Israel.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 16:1–13
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 16:1–13 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 16:1–13 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 16:1–13 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

This passage takes place some time after Yahweh has rejected Saul as king. Samuel and Saul have both returned to their hometowns. Samuel is grieving over Saul's rebellion. Yahweh asks Samuel why Samuel is still grieving.

Yahweh tells Samuel to fill Samuel's horn with oil and leave. These horns were from rams, and leaders often filled these horns with olive oil to anoint people for special tasks. A leader would anoint a person by pouring the olive oil over the person's head. Samuel would have used this oil to anoint the new king.

Stop here and look at a picture of a ram's horn. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you choose leaders in your culture? What kinds of rituals do people do to show that someone is the new leader? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh tells Samuel to go to Jesse's household in the town of Bethlehem because Yahweh has chosen one of Jesse's sons to be king. Jesse was from the tribe of Judah. Jesse lived in Bethlehem just south of Ramah.

Stop here and look at a map of Bethlehem in relation to Ramah. Pause this audio here.

Samuel is afraid. Samuel knows that Saul will be angry if Saul hears that Samuel is anointing a new king in Saul's place. So Samuel asks Yahweh why Yahweh thinks this is a good idea. Yahweh tells Samuel to take a heifer, which is a female cow. People used heifers specifically for peace offerings, which are offerings to show good relationships between people and God, and between people and other people. Samuel does all that Yahweh has told Samuel to do, which means that Samuel fills his horn with olive oil, takes a heifer, and goes to Bethlehem.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do people in your culture communicate their peaceful intentions to one another? Pause this audio here.

The elders of Bethlehem tremble in fear when they see Samuel enter their town. We do not know why the elders tremble in fear. Samuel tells the elders that Samuel has come in peace. Samuel invites the elders to consecrate themselves, or clean themselves and make themselves holy, and come to the sacrifice. Then Samuel consecrates Jesse and Jesse's sons and invites them to the sacrifice. Yahweh required that people prepare themselves for all kinds of sacrifices by performing certain kinds of washing to symbolize that the people were ready to worship Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What kinds of things do you do to prepare yourselves for special religious ceremonies in your culture? Why are these rituals important to your people? Pause this audio here.

Jesse's sons come before Samuel one at a time. Samuel thinks to himself that the oldest, Eliab, must be the one Yahweh will choose to be king because in that culture, the oldest son was usually the most important son. However, Yahweh tells Samuel not to look at outward appearances because Yahweh knows people's hearts. In other words, Yahweh knows if someone is really good or bad.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What kinds of outward appearances do people use to help them decide if someone will be a good leader? What kinds of status in the community or family are important to consider when you choose new leaders? Pause this audio here.

Samuel probably asks Jesse to call each of Jesse's sons to walk in front of Samuel, although Jesse probably does not know why Samuel wants to look at Jesse's sons. As each passes by, Yahweh tells Samuel that Yahweh has rejected each son. Samuel asks if there are any more sons, and Jesse calls Jesse's youngest son to come. This son is out in the fields watching the family's sheep. Because this son is the youngest member of the family, Jesse had probably not considered David important enough for Samuel to look at. Jesse sends a messenger to get David. But when David comes in, Yahweh tells Samuel to stand up and anoint David. David has beautiful eyes, which means David is really handsome. So Samuel takes the horn of oil and anoints David in front of all of David's brothers. Yahweh's Spirit is with David from that time forward, and Samuel goes back to Samuel's home in Ramah.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 16:1–13 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has four scenes.

In the first scene: Samuel is sad that Saul disobeyed Yahweh. Yahweh tells Samuel to stop grieving because Yahweh has rejected Saul. Yahweh tells Samuel to go to Bethlehem and anoint one of Jesse's sons as the one Yahweh had chosen to be king over the people of Israel.

In the second scene: Samuel goes to Bethlehem with a heifer and tells the elders, as well as Jesse, to consecrate themselves and come to a sacrifice.

In the third scene: Jesse and Jesse's sons arrive at the sacrifice. When they enter, Samuel assumes that he is going to anoint Eliab, Jesse's oldest son. However, Yahweh tells Samuel not to look at Eliab's outward appearance because Yahweh looks at the heart of people to understand who those people really are. Eliab, Abinadab, and Shammah all pass before Samuel. However, Samuel tells Jesse that Yahweh has not chosen these. Four more of Jesse's sons pass before Samuel, but they are not the ones Yahweh has chosen. Samuel asks Jesse if Jesse has any other sons. Jesse tells Samuel that the youngest is out in the fields watching sheep. So Samuel tells Jesse to bring the youngest son in.

In the fourth scene: Jesse brought in his youngest son, David. David was handsome with beautiful eyes. Yahweh told Samuel to get up and anoint David. Samuel took the horn of oil and anointed David where all of David's brothers could see. Then Yahweh's Spirit came on David powerfully from that day forward. Samuel got up, left, and went back to Ramah.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Yahweh

  • Samuel

  • Jesse

  • The elders

  • Eliab

  • Abinadab

  • Shammah

  • The rest of Jesse's sons

  • A messenger who calls David from the fields

  • David

  • And the Spirit of Yahweh

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

This story happens sometime after Yahweh rejects Saul as king, but we do not know how long after.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How will you start this passage to show that this happened some time after Yahweh rejected Saul? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh's conversation with Samuel probably happens while Samuel is in Ramah, where Samuel lives. Yahweh asks Samuel a question that Yahweh does not expect Samuel to answer: "How long will you grieve over Saul?" This question could also be worded as a gentle command like, "Do not keep grieving for Saul," or "You have grieved long enough for Saul."

Stop here and discuss as a group: How will you talk about how Yahweh gives Samuel the gentle command to stop grieving for Saul? Pause this audio here.

Samuel answers with another question that Samuel does not expect Yahweh to answer. Samuel asks, "How can I go? Saul will kill me if he finds out that I am anointing someone else as king." Samuel is saying that Samuel thinks it is a bad idea to go. Perhaps Samuel is afraid that Saul will kill Samuel. Yahweh tells Samuel that it will be fine, and Yahweh asks Samuel to take a heifer, or female cow, with Samuel to Bethlehem. Samuel will tell the people in Bethlehem that Samuel is sacrificing this heifer as a way to worship Yahweh and to cover any sins that the people in the area have done. In this way, the people will perhaps not know the other reason that Samuel is coming to Bethlehem.

Samuel gathers the things Samuel needs, and the setting changes to Bethlehem, a town about seven kilometers south of Jerusalem. When Samuel arrives in Bethlehem, the elders, who are the older men of the community, tremble in fear when they see Samuel. We do not know why the elders are afraid, but perhaps the men understand that Samuel is visiting Bethlehem for a serious reason. The elders ask Samuel if Samuel is coming in peace.

Samuel has the elders consecrate themselves, or make themselves "holy" or ritually pure, so that the elders can participate in the sacrifice to Yahweh. Samuel also consecrates Jesse and Jesse's sons. Although the storyteller does not include this information, the elders and Jesse probably have to wash themselves in a special way in order to become holy and able to participate.

Each one of Jesse's sons stands before Samuel. Yahweh has not yet told Samuel which son Yahweh has chosen as king. When Samuel sees the eldest son Eliab, Samuel assumes that Eliab is the one that Yahweh has chosen to be king. Yahweh tells Samuel not to look at the outward appearance, or the way a man looks, because Yahweh sees all that is in a man's heart. The Israelites would talk about their emotions and decisions coming from their heart. This conversation between Samuel and Yahweh is likely taking place in Samuel's thoughts, and not out loud for others to hear.

Stop here and discuss as a group how you will talk about Yahweh seeing what is in a person's heart. In other words, how will you talk about the fact that Yahweh does not just look at what a person looks like on the outside? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh has not chosen any of Jesse's seven sons whom Jesse brought before Samuel. Samuel asks Jesse if Jesse has any other sons. David, Jesse's youngest son, is in the fields taking care of the sheep. Samuel tells Jesse to call for David and that they will not sit down until David arrives. Samuel does not mean that the men will remain standing, but that the men will not do anything else important until David arrives.

Stop here and discuss as a group: In your culture, how do you talk about someone waiting for an event to happen before that person continues doing something important? Pause this audio here.

Jesse sends a messenger to call David back from the fields to the town of Bethlehem, where everyone has gathered. When David arrives, Samuel sees that David is very handsome. In the original language, the story says that David is red and that David has beautiful eyes. When someone says that a person is red, this means that the person looks healthy. When someone says that a man has beautiful eyes, this means that the man is handsome.

Stop here and discuss as a group: In your language, how do you talk about a man who looks healthy and handsome? How will you talk about how David looks in this story? Pause this audio here.

Yahweh tells Samuel to rise and anoint David, for David is the one Yahweh has chosen. This does not mean that Samuel has been sitting down, but that Yahweh wants Samuel to act. Samuel anoints David with Samuel's horn of oil, which means that Samuel pours the oil on David's head from Samuel's ram's horn. Yahweh's Spirit comes on David. This means that Yahweh gives David everything David needs to do the things Yahweh asks him to do.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How will you talk about Yahweh's Spirit giving David everything he needs from that time onwards? Pause this audio here.

Samuel then goes back to Ramah.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 16:1–13 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has four scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Yahweh

  • Samuel

  • Jesse

  • The elders

  • Eliab

  • Abinadab

  • Shammah

  • The rest of Jesse's sons

  • A messenger who calls David from the fields

  • David

  • And the Spirit of Yahweh

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Samuel is sad because Saul disobeyed Yahweh. Yahweh tells Samuel to stop grieving because Yahweh has rejected Saul. Yahweh tells Samuel to take Samuel's horn of oil and go to Bethlehem to Jesse, and to anoint one of Jesse's sons. Yahweh had chosen one of Jesse's sons as Yahweh's king.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I will do what Yahweh says, but I am still sad about Saul; or

  • I hope this next king is better than Saul; or

  • How do I know this problem will not happen again?

Samuel asks Yahweh how Samuel can go to Bethlehem because Saul will try to kill Samuel. Yahweh tells Samuel to take a heifer, or a female cow, with Samuel in order to sacrifice the heifer. Yahweh tells Samuel to invite Jesse and Jesse's sons to the sacrifice and to anoint the son that Yahweh tells Samuel to anoint.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I trust Yahweh, so I am sure this will work and Saul will not try to kill me; or

  • Jesse has a lot of sons. I wonder which one Yahweh has chosen.

Samuel goes to Bethlehem with a heifer and tells the elders, as well as Jesse, to consecrate themselves and come to the sacrifice. Jesse and Jesse's sons arrive at the sacrifice. When Jesse and Jesse's son enter, Samuel assumes that Samuel is going to anoint Eliab, Jesse's oldest son. However, Yahweh tells Samuel not to look at the outward appearance because Yahweh looks at the heart. Eliab, Abinadab, and Shammah all walk in front of Samuel. However, Samuel tells Jesse that Yahweh has not chosen these sons. Seven of Jesse's sons pass before Samuel, but none of these is the son Yahweh has chosen.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the elders, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so afraid! Why is Samuel coming to our town? What have we done wrong?

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Yahweh, what is wrong with these boys? Surely they are good enough; or

  • I have looked at each of Jesse's sons. Maybe I heard Yahweh wrong; or

  • I wonder what kind of person Yahweh is looking for in a new king.

Ask the person playing Eliab, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • What is it that Yahweh is choosing? I do not understand, but this must be an important task!

  • I know Yahweh is going to pick me since I am the oldest; or

  • Surely I am good enough! or

  • There is no way that Samuel will pick one of my younger brothers!

Samuel asks Jesse if Jesse has any other sons. Jesse tells Samuel that the youngest son is out taking care of sheep. So Samuel tells Jesse to bring the youngest son in.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Jesse, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Why would Samuel want to see my youngest? David is just a shepherd, not a warrior; or

  • David's a great kid, but he is not very strong. What was wrong with Eliab or the others? or

  • I wonder what Yahweh is looking for.

So Jesse brings in his youngest son, David. David is handsome and healthy. Yahweh tells Samuel to get up and anoint David. So Samuel takes the horn of oil and anoints David where all of David's brothers can see.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • What just happened? How did I get to be anointed and not my brothers? or

  • What an honor that Yahweh chose me. Yahweh, help me serve you well; or

  • I wonder what Yahweh wants me to do for Yahweh? or

  • I feel Yahweh's power! How wonderful! or

  • I feel Yahweh's power! I am afraid of what Yahweh will ask me to do!

Ask the person playing Eliab, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • How did Yahweh choose David, the youngest son? I am so angry! or

  • What is wrong with me? I am the strongest, the oldest, and the best fighter; or

  • This is so unfair. I cannot follow my youngest brother!

Then the Spirit of Yahweh came upon David powerfully from that day forward. Samuel got up, left, and went to Ramah.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 16:1–13 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Samuel is sad that Saul disobeyed Yahweh. Yahweh tells Samuel to stop grieving because Yahweh has rejected Saul as king over Israel. Yahweh is God's personal and proper name. A king is a ruler over a region. Israel is the land that Yahweh gave to Jacob's descendants and the people who live in that land. Use the same words for Yahweh, king, and Israel that you have used in previous passages. For more information on Yahweh, king, and Israel, refer to the Master Glossary.

Yahweh tells Samuel to take Samuel's horn of oil, go to Bethlehem to Jesse, and anoint one of Jesse's sons. Yahweh had chosen one of Jesse's sons as Yahweh's king. Samuel asks Yahweh how Samuel can go to Bethlehem because Saul will try to put Samuel to death. Yahweh tells Samuel to take a heifer, or a female cow, with Samuel in order to sacrifice the heifer. Yahweh tells Samuel to invite Jesse and Jesse's sons to the sacrifice and to anoint the son that Yahweh tells Samuel to anoint. A horn of oil was a ram's horn that held oil that people used to anoint a person. Bethlehem is the birthplace of David, a town not far from Jerusalem. A sacrifice is a gift, usually an animal, that people offered to Yahweh. To anoint is to pour a sweet-smelling oil over someone or something, usually to appoint that person or thing for a special task. Use the same words for horn, oil, Bethlehem, sacrifice, and anoint that you have used in previous passages. For more information on horn, Bethlehem, sacrifice, and anoint, refer to the Master Glossary.

Samuel goes to Bethlehem with a heifer and tells the elders, as well as Jesse, to consecrate themselves and come to the sacrifice. Elders are older men who have authority in a community. To consecrate is to set something or someone apart for God and to make the person or thing clean. Use the same words for elders and consecrate that you have used in previous passages. For more information on elders and consecrate, refer to the Master Glossary.

The elders ask Samuel if Samuel has come in peace. Use the same word or phrase for peace that you have used previously, and see the Master Glossary for more information about peace.

Jesse and Jesse's sons arrive at the sacrifice. When they enter, Samuel assumes that Samuel is going to anoint Eliab, Jesse's oldest son. However, Yahweh tells Samuel not to look at the outward appearance because Yahweh looks at the heart. The Israelites spoke about the heart as the place where a person's emotions and decisions came from. Use the same word for heart that you have used in previous passages where heart means the same thing. For more information on heart, refer to the Master Glossary.

Samuel asks Jesse if Jesse has any other sons. So Jesse has someone bring in Jesse's youngest son, David. Samuel takes the horn of oil and anoints David. Then the Spirit of Yahweh comes upon David powerfully from that day forward. Use the same word or phrase for "Spirit of Yahweh" that you have used in previous passages. Although this story talks specifically about the Spirit of Yahweh, you can listen to more information about God's Spirit by referring to Holy Spirit in the Master Glossary.

Stop here and discuss as a group what name you will use for David. Look up David in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this name in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
