title: 1 Samuel 16:14–23
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 16:14–23 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 16:14–23 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 16:14–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

This story follows when Samuel anointed David to become the new king in place of Saul. We see in the previous story that Yahweh's spirit has come with power to David. In this story, we hear that Yahweh's Spirit departed from Saul, and Yahweh sent a spirit that does evil to terrify and torment Saul. We see that Yahweh's favor, or Yahweh's Spirit, had left Saul and had come to David.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do people in your culture know that God, or their deity, is present with their leaders? Pause this audio here.

In ancient cultures, people often played music to help relieve people's sadness. Some cultures believed that the lyre instrument could chase away demons. Saul's servants told Saul that God had sent a spirit that does evil to torment Saul. The servants called Saul their master, and the servants asked Saul to command the servants to search for someone who plays the lyre. That person could play when the spirit of evil bothered Saul, and then Saul could feel better.

Stop here and look as a group at a picture of a lyre. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How does your culture use music? When do you use music, and what kinds of musical instruments do you use for different types of events? Pause this audio here.

Saul told his servants to find someone who plays the lyre well and to bring that person to Saul. One of the servants told Saul that a son of Jesse from the town of Bethlehem knows how to play the lyre. Jesse was an important man in Bethlehem, and the servant says that David plays the lyre skillfully. The servant also says that David is a man of valor, or a courageous man. David is a warrior. This is the first time we hear of David being a courageous warrior, but it is possible that David fought wild animals as a shepherd when David was protecting his sheep. Most importantly, the servant tells Saul that Yahweh is with David. This means that Yahweh helps David.

Stop here and discuss as a group: In your culture, what kinds of servants or helpers do your rulers have? What kinds of things do those servants do to help the ruler? When a leader is looking for a helper, what qualities does the leader look for in a helper? Pause this audio here.

So Saul sent messengers to Jesse to send Jesse's son David, who was a shepherd, to Saul. Jesse sent David to Saul along with a young goat, a donkey loaded with bread, and a wineskin full of wine. Wine and bread were traditional food and drink, and in this case Jesse was giving these things as a gift to king Saul. People often carried wine in an animal's skin.

Stop here and look at a photo of a donkey, a young goat, and a wineskin. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What kind of food, drink, crops, or livestock would you give as a gift to a ruler in your culture? Pause this audio here.

David served Saul, and Saul loved David very much. Sometimes, a king and a servant would be loyal to each other like friends. David was so special to Saul that David even became one of the men who carried Saul's armor and weapons during a battle. Saul sent a messenger to ask Jesse to let David stay in Saul's service because Saul liked David so much. And whenever the spirit from God tormented Saul, David would play the lyre. Then Saul would feel better, and the spirit would go away.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 16:14–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has four scenes.

In the first scene: Yahweh's Spirit had left Saul, and Yahweh sent a spirit that did evil to torment Saul.

In the second scene: Saul's servants told Saul that an evil spirit from God was tormenting Saul. Saul told his officers to find someone who plays the lyre well and to bring that person to Saul. One of the servants told Saul that one of Jesse's sons from Bethlehem knows how to play. So Saul sent messengers to Jesse to send Jesse's son David, who was a shepherd, to Saul.

In the third scene: Jesse sent David to Saul along with a young goat, a donkey loaded with bread, and a wineskin full of wine.

In the fourth scene: David served Saul, and Saul loved David very much. David became Saul's armor bearer. Saul asked Jesse to let David stay in Saul's service because Saul liked David so much. And whenever the spirit from God tormented Saul, David would play the lyre. Then Saul would feel better, and the spirit would go away.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Spirit of Yahweh, or Spirit of God

  • King Saul

  • Spirit that does evil things

  • Saul's servants

  • Yahweh

  • Messengers who take messages to Saul and Jesse

  • Jesse

  • And David, Jesse's son

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

This story happens sometime after Samuel anoints David as the next king. Saul is likely still at Saul's home in Gibeah when this story happens.

Yahweh's spirit had left Saul, and instead, Yahweh sent a spirit that did evil things and tormented Saul. This spirit probably made Saul very afraid. It seems as though this spirit torments Saul often and is not a one-time event.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How will you talk about Yahweh's spirit leaving Saul and then Yahweh sending another spirit that does evil things to Saul? In your culture, what kinds of things do evil spirits do to people? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How will you talk about this evil spirit from Yahweh? We know that Yahweh sent this spirit and that this spirit did evil things to Saul. Pause this audio here.

Saul's servants want Saul to pay attention to what they say to Saul. The servants tell Saul that it is an evil spirit that is causing Saul this trouble. When the servants come to Saul, the servants refer to Saul as "our lord" or "our master," even though the servants are talking to Saul. The servants refer to themselves as "your servants," or "his servants," even though they are talking about themselves.

Stop here and discuss as a group: In your culture, how do servants respectfully come to talk to a leader? How do the servants get the leader's attention? How do the servants address the leader, and how do the servants talk about themselves to the leader? Pause this audio here.

The servants politely ask Saul to tell the servants to find someone who plays the lyre, or small harp, well. Then, whenever the evil spirit torments Saul, the person can play the lyre and Saul will feel better.

Saul tells the servants to find someone who plays the lyre well. One of the servants suggests Jesse's son because this son is brave and a good fighter. The servant describes Jesse's son as someone who speaks well or wisely. The son is also handsome, and Yahweh is with the son.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How will you say that Yahweh is with Jesse's son? Remember that this means that everyone can see that Yahweh favors and does good things for David. Pause this audio here.

Saul sends messengers to Jesse to bring David from watching the sheep to serve Saul. So Jesse sends David with a donkey, a lot of bread, a wineskin of wine, and a young goat.

David comes to serve Saul. Saul likes David. David becomes one of Saul's armor-bearers, or a person who carries the armor and the weapons into battle. After this, Saul sends a message to Jesse to allow David to remain in Saul's service. Notice that messengers are going back and forth between Saul and Jesse. Saul and Jesse are speaking directly with each other. Saul asks Jesse for David to continue to "stand before" Saul. This means that Saul wants David to continue to serve Saul. Saul says that David has found favor in "his sight." This means that Saul likes David very much.

Whenever the evil spirit from Yahweh comes on Saul, David plays the lyre. Then the evil spirit leaves Saul, and Saul feels relieved.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 16:14–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has four scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Spirit of Yahweh, or Spirit of God

  • King Saul

  • Spirit that does evil things

  • Saul's servants

  • Yahweh

  • Messengers who take messages to Saul and Jesse

  • Jesse

  • And David, Jesse's son

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Yahweh's Spirit had left Saul, and Yahweh sent an evil spirit to torment Saul.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel tormented; or

  • I feel scared; or

  • I am terrified!

Saul's servants told Saul that an evil spirit from God was tormenting Saul. The servants said to Saul, "Let our master command us to search for someone who plays the lyre. He will play when the evil spirit from God comes upon you, and you will feel better."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the servants, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I have heard that music will help with evil spirits, so I hope this works; or

  • I hope we can find someone quickly. I feel bad for Saul; or

  • I am very afraid of Saul when the evil spirit torments Saul; or

  • I never want this to happen to me!

Saul told his officers to find someone who plays the lyre well and to bring that person to Saul. One of the servants told Saul that a son of Jesse of Bethlehem knows how to play. This servant describes the son as brave and a warrior. The son speaks well and is fine-looking. Yahweh is with the son.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I hope this works! or

  • I should have listened to Yahweh and Samuel! or

  • Why would Yahweh allow this to happen?

So Saul sent messengers to Jesse to send Jesse's son David, who was a shepherd, to Saul. Jesse sent David to Saul along with a young goat, a donkey loaded with bread, and a wineskin full of wine.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Jesse, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am very afraid for my son David! or

  • I am happy to help Yahweh's king.

David served Saul, and Saul loved David very much. David became Saul's armor-bearer. Saul asked Jesse to let David continue to serve Saul because Saul liked David so much. And whenever the spirit from God tormented Saul, David would play the lyre. Then Saul would feel better, and the spirit would go away.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • What an honor to serve the king; or

  • I am glad I can help the king feel better when the king is unwell; or

  • Samuel just anointed me. What if King Saul gets jealous of me? Does King Saul know that Samuel anointed me?

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 16:14–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Yahweh's Spirit had left Saul, and Yahweh sent an evil spirit to torment or make Saul afraid. Yahweh is God's personal and proper name. Yahweh's Spirit is the power of God. Use the same word for Yahweh and Yahweh's Spirit that you have used in previous passages. For more information on Yahweh and Yahweh's Spirit, refer to the Master Glossary.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for torment. When someone torments someone else, that person does evil things to the other person to make the other person afraid. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss how you will translate an evil spirit from Yahweh. This is a spirit that Yahweh has sent to torment Saul. Because Yahweh created all spirits, Yahweh can tell any spirit what to do. Although we do not fully understand what this evil spirit does, you may refer to the Master Glossary for evil spirit, and use the same words or phrases for evil spirit that you have used in other books of the Bible. Pause this audio here.

Saul's servants told Saul that an evil spirit from God was tormenting Saul. These servants were probably officials in Saul's government. You may translate servant as "official" if you would like. See servant and God in the Master Glossary for more information.

The servants said to Saul, "Let our lord command us to search for someone who plays the lyre." A lord is someone who is a master over another person. A lyre is a stringed musical instrument similar to a small harp. Use the same words for lord and lyre that you have used in previous passages. For more information on lord, refer to the Master Glossary.

Stop here and look at a picture of a lyre as a group again if necessary. What word will you use for this musical instrument? Pause this audio here.

Saul told his officers to find someone who plays the lyre well and to bring that person to Saul. One of the servants told Saul that a son of Jesse of Bethlehem knows how to play. Bethlehem is in the Master Glossary.

So Saul sent messengers to Jesse to send Jesse's son David, who was a shepherd, to Saul. Jesse sent David to Saul along with a young goat, a donkey loaded with bread, and a wineskin full of wine. David was Jesse's youngest son and became the second king of Israel. A shepherd is a person who takes care of sheep and goats. Use the same words for David, shepherd, donkey, and wine that you have used in previous passages. For more information on David, shepherd, donkey, and wine, refer to the Master Glossary.

So David served Saul, and Saul loved David very much. David became Saul's armor-bearer. Use the same word for armor-bearer that you have used in previous passages.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 17:1–11
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 17:1–11 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:1–11 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:1–11 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous passage, the prophet Samuel anointed David as the next king of Israel. Then, David served King Saul in Saul's court by playing soothing music when Saul felt upset because the evil spirit came on Saul.

In this passage, the Philistines attack the Israelites again. You will remember from previous passages that the Philistines were enemies of Israel who worshiped idols. The Philistines gather their armies for war against Israel. This means that the whole Philistine army gets ready to fight against the Israelite army.

The Philistine army gathers at the town of Sokoh, which is in Judah, to the west of Bethlehem, in the direction of the Philistine territory. The Philistines camp at the town of Ephes Dammim, which is between Sokoh and Azekah. The people in this city allow travelers to use the main road through the Valley of Elah. We do not know exactly where Ephes Dammim is located, but it was probably on the southern slope of the Valley of Elah. The Valley of Elah runs from Bethlehem west towards the Philistine cities of Gath and Ekron.

Stop here as a group and look at a map that includes Sokoh, Ephes Dammim, Azekah, Elah, Gath, and Ekron. Pause this audio here.

Saul and the Israelite army gather together and probably camp on the northern slope of the Valley of Elah. The Philistines may attack Israel at this place because it is the easiest place for the Philistines to get into Israelite territory.

The Philistine army and the Israelite army draw up their battle lines. This means that each army stands in a line to prepare for battle. The armies face each other on opposite hills, and the Valley of Elah is between the armies. A valley is a narrow gorge or ravine that water has created as it flows through the land between two hills.

Stop here and look at a picture of a valley in between two hills as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: In your culture, how do you prepare soldiers for battle? What kinds of formations do your soldiers use when they fight? How do soldiers choose where to do battle with an enemy? Pause this audio here.

From the battle line of the Philistine army, a champion comes out. A champion is someone who steps out to fight between two battle lines of opposing armies. This champion's name is Goliath. Goliath is from Gath, which is an important Philistine city on the southern border.

Goliath is extremely tall. Goliath is six cubits and a span tall. A cubit measures the space between the tip of a man's middle finger and that man's elbow. A span measures the space between a man's thumb and the tip of the man's little finger when the man stretches them as far apart as he can. A cubit is about 45 centimeters, and a span is about 22 centimeters. This means that Goliath is nearly three meters tall.

Goliath wears armor. Armor is a metal covering that soldiers wear to protect their bodies. The armor covers almost all of Goliath's body except for his face. The armor Goliath wears is made of bronze and weighs 5,000 shekels, which is about 57 kilograms. Goliath wears a bronze helmet and scale armor covering his chest, back, and stomach. People made the scale armor from scales that overlapped one another. Goliath has bronze greaves or coverings that fit over his shins to protect Goliath's legs. Goliath carries a javelin made of bronze on his back. A javelin could have been a light, short spear that warriors could throw at an enemy, or it could have been more like a scimitar, which is a short sword with a curved blade that is sharp on the outside of the blade. The shaft or long wooden handle of Goliath's weapon is very big, like the crossbar of a weaver's beam in that culture. The tip or metal point of the spear or scimitar, which people made from iron, weighs 600 shekels or about 7 kilograms. Goliath also has a large shield that covers his entire body. A man walks in front of Goliath to carry the large shield.

Stop here and look at a picture of a man wearing armor, including a helmet, scale armor over his chest, and greaves over his shins. Look at a picture of a javelin, a picture of a scimitar, and a picture of a weaver's beam to see how big the shaft of Goliath's weapon was. Look at a picture of a man carrying a large shield. Pause this audio here.

Goliath comes out of the battle line of the Philistines and begins to shout insults to the Israelite army. Goliath begins to ask the Israelite army questions. Goliath does not want answers to these questions. Goliath uses his questions to insult the Israelite army. Goliath asks why the Israelites have lined up for battle because Goliath is a champion of the Philistines, but the Israelite army are only servants. Goliath wants to make a point that the Israelites are servants of Saul. Goliath demands that Israel send one man down into the valley to fight Goliath to decide the ending of the entire war. In ancient times, it was common for two armies to each send a champion to fight one another. This fight between two individuals would determine which army won the battle. If the Israelite champion won, then the Philistine soldiers would be slaves to the Israelites. But if Goliath won, then the Israelite soldiers would be slaves to the Philistines.

Goliath challenges the Israelite army and demands again that Israel send one man to fight Goliath. Goliath taunts the Israelite army and shows that he hates the Israelites and does not respect them. When Saul and all the Israelite army hear Goliath's shout, the men do not see any way to defeat Goliath and become dismayed and terrified.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:1–11 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has three scenes.

In the first scene: The Philistine and Israelite armies gather on opposite sides of the Valley of Elah. The armies stand in their battle lines and face one another.

In the second scene: The Philistine champion Goliath steps into the valley between the two armies. Goliath is very tall and wears heavy armor that protects his entire body except his face. Goliath also carries a large sword and follows behind a man who carries a shield that protects Goliath.

In the third scene: Goliath shouts at the Israelite army. Goliath makes fun of the Israelites for even trying to fight the Philistines and demands that the Israelites send a champion to fight Goliath. This fight will decide who wins the battle between the Philistines and Israelites. If the Israelites win, then the Philistines will be the Israelites' servants, but if the Philistines win, then the Israelites will have to serve the Philistines. Saul and the Israelite soldiers are dismayed and afraid.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Philistine army

  • Israelite army

  • King Saul

  • And Goliath

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In scene one, the Philistine army approaches Israel's territory to fight the Israelite army. The Philistines gather their armies for war. To gather armies for war means to gather soldiers together and prepare to fight. The Philistines draw up battle lines. This means the Philistines line up in battle formation on one side of the Valley of Elah. Saul and the Israelite army line up on the opposite side of the Valley of Elah. The armies face one another.

Stop here and look at a picture of a valley between two hills. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How will you describe the valley between the hills and the two armies that have gathered for war? Why do you think the Philistine army may have chosen this spot to prepare to fight the Israelites? Pause this audio here.

In scene two, Goliath moves from the Philistine battle line into the valley between the armies. Goliath is almost three meters tall and wears bronze armor that covers his entire body. Goliath has a helmet, scale armor covering his stomach and back, and greaves that cover Goliath's legs from his knees to his feet. The only part of Goliath without armor is Goliath's face. Goliath's armor is very heavy. Altogether, the armor weighs about 57 kilograms.

Goliath also carries a huge javelin or scimitar on Goliath's back. The shaft of the javelin is so thick that it looks like a weaver's beam. A weaver's beam was a strong, long, rounded wooden pole that people used at the top of a loom to hold all the threads. A weaver's beam would have been very thick and sturdy. This comparison helps us to understand just how big Goliath's weapon is. The iron point of the javelin weighs close to 7 kilograms. Along with all of Goliath's protective armor, Goliath has a man in front of Goliath whose job is to carry a shield that protects Goliath's entire body.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do you describe the size of things in your culture? If you do not have weaver's beams, what kinds of objects do you have that would be a good comparison here? How will you describe how tall Goliath was and how heavy his armor and weapons were? Pause this audio here.

Look at a picture of a man wearing armor like Goliath. Look at a picture of a javelin, a picture of a scimitar, and a picture of a large shield. Tell a story about a soldier who is so large that it looks like no one could defeat that soldier. What language do you use to describe this very strong soldier? Pause this audio here.

In scene three, Goliath begins to shout at Saul and the Israelite soldiers. Goliath says, "Why have you bothered to line up for battle?" Goliath is saying, "I am a soldier and a champion, but all of you are only servants. I am a Philistine, and I am ready to fight you, servants of Saul. So choose a soldier to represent you and send that soldier to fight me. If that soldier wins and kills me, then my people will be your slaves. But if I win and kill your soldier, then you will become our slaves and serve us."

Goliath continues to shout at the Israelites, "Today I challenge you, Israelite soldiers! Choose one of your soldiers and send him to fight me!" When the Israelites hear Goliath's taunts, Saul and the Israelite soldiers are greatly afraid and do not believe they can defeat Goliath.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about a time when someone made fun of an enemy. How do you describe one person taunting another? Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:1–11 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has three scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Philistine army

  • Israelite army

  • King Saul

  • And Goliath

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

The Philistines gather their army for battle and camp at Ephes Dammim between Sokoh and Azekah. King Saul and the Israelite army gather and camp in the Valley of Elah. The Philistine and Israelite armies face each other on opposite hills with the Valley of Elah in the middle.

Pause the drama.

Ask the people playing the Philistine army, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The people might answer things like:

  • We are confident that our army is greater and we can attack Israel and win; or

  • We take pride in knowing our champion is bigger and stronger than the men in Israel.

The Philistine champion Goliath of Gath steps forward from the Philistine soldiers' battle line. Goliath is close to three meters tall and wears bronze armor from the helmet on Goliath's head to the chain mail around Goliath's stomach and back to the greaves that cover Goliath's legs from his knees to his feet. Goliath's armor weighs almost 57 kilograms. Goliath also has a huge javelin on Goliath's back. The javelin's shaft is so thick it looks like a weaver's beam, and the javelin's point is made of iron and weighs about seven kilograms. Goliath has a man in front of him who carries a large shield that protects Goliath almost completely. The only part of Goliath that is not covered by armor is Goliath's face.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Goliath, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am confident that my armor will protect me from any weapon the Israelites might have; or

  • I take pride in knowing I am a great champion and am not afraid to fight the Israelites.

Ask the people playing the Israelite army, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The people might answer things like:

  • Goliath is so intimidating in his big, heavy armor and with his huge shield! We could never defeat Goliath! or

  • We do not know how to respond to a great champion like Goliath and just want to stay silent; or

  • We are not sure Yahweh can protect us from this great champion; or

  • We are angry and disappointed that Yahweh has not yet saved us!

Goliath begins to shout at the Israelite army. Goliath taunts the Israelites and asks, "Why did you bother to line up for battle? I am a Philistine, but you only serve Saul. Send me a soldier who can fight me! If that soldier wins and kills me, my people will be your slaves. But if I win and kill that soldier, then you will be our slaves and serve us." Goliath continues to taunt the Israelites and shout, "I challenge the armies of Israel today! Send me a man to fight me!" When Saul and the Israelites hear Goliath, they are dismayed and terrified.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing King Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I would like to send someone to fight Goliath, but I have no soldiers who can do that. We would become slaves to the Philistines! or

  • I am afraid that we will never be able to defeat the Philistines as long as the Philistines have champions like Goliath.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:1–11 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

The Philistines gathered their armies for war and camped at Ephes Dammim. The Philistines were a group of people who were enemies of Israel and worshiped idols. Use the same word for Philistines as you used in previous passages.

The Philistines camped on one hill of the Valley of Elah, and the Israelites camped on the opposite hill. A hill is a naturally raised area of land that is not as tall as a mountain. A valley is a narrow ravine that water created as the water flowed through the land between two hills. Use the same words or phrases for hill and valley as you used in previous passages.

Stop here and again look at a picture of a valley between two hills as a group, if needed. Pause this audio here.

A champion named Goliath stepped out from the Philistine army. A champion was someone who stepped out to fight between two battle lines of opposing armies. A champion represented an entire army. Champions would often fight to determine the outcome of battles instead of having entire armies fight each other.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for champion. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Goliath tells the Israelites that whoever wins in battle against Goliath will become the servant of the other army. If the Israelites won, the Philistines would be the Israelites' servants, but if the Philistines won, then the Israelites would have to be servants to the Philistines. A servant is a man or woman who works for another man or woman. A servant usually has a low position in the community. Use the same word for servant as you used in previous passages. For more information on servant, refer to the Master Glossary.

Goliath was six cubits and a span tall. A cubit was a measure of the distance between the tip of a man's middle finger and that man's elbow. A span was a measure of the distance between a man's thumb and the tip of that man's little finger when the man stretched them as far apart as he could. A cubit measured about 45 centimeters, and a span measured about 22 centimeters.

Stop here and discuss what words or phrases you will use for cubit and span. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words you have used there. For more information on cubit and span, refer to the Master Glossary. Pause this audio here.

Goliath wore armor. Armor was a metal covering to protect a soldier in battle. Goliath wore a helmet, scale armor, and greaves that people had made of bronze. A man also carried a shield in front of Goliath. A helmet was a covering that protected a soldier's head. Scale armor was metal plates that people tied together with leather straps. Scale armor covered a soldier's chest and back. Greaves were metal coverings over a soldier's calf that may have been lined inside with leather for comfort. A shield was a large plate of metal that the soldier or another person carried in front of the soldier to protect almost all of the soldier's body.

Stop here and look at a picture of armor, including a helmet, scale armor, and greaves. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for helmet, scale armor, greaves, and shield. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Goliath's armor was very heavy. The armor weighed 5,000 shekels, or 57 kilograms. The tip of Goliath's weapon weighed 600 shekels, or about 7 kilograms. A shekel is a unit of measurement. One shekel is about 11.4 grams. Use the same word for shekel as you used in previous passages. For more information on shekel, refer to the Master Glossary.

Goliath carried a javelin on Goliath's back. A javelin may have been a light, short spear that someone could throw at an enemy, or it could have been more like a scimitar, which is a short sword with a curved blade that is sharp on the outside of the blade.

Stop here and look at a picture of a javelin and a picture of a scimitar as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss what word or phrase you will use for javelin. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Goliath walked behind Goliath's shield-bearer. A person who was a shield-bearer carried a large shield in front of another soldier.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for shield-bearer. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

When King Saul and the Israelite army heard Goliath's taunts, the Israelites shook and were very afraid.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 17:12–19
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 17:12–19 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:12–19 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:12–19 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous passage, the Israelite army and the Philistine army lined up to face each other to prepare for battle in the Valley of Elah. A champion named Goliath stepped out from the Philistine army to challenge the Israelite army to send their own champion to fight Goliath. Goliath was tall and wore heavy armor to protect Goliath. Saul and the Israelite army were terrified.

In this passage, the storyteller begins by interrupting the story about Goliath to talk about David. Even though we learned about David in a previous passage, here the storyteller talks about David again and gives more information. You will remember David from previous passages. Earlier in 1 Samuel, the prophet Samuel anointed David to be the next king after Saul. David then served King Saul by playing the harp to calm Saul.

David's father was Jesse, who was an Ephrathite. This means that Jesse was from Bethlehem in Judah. People sometimes called Bethlehem, and the area around Bethlehem, Ephrathah, and people living in that area Ephrathites. This also means that Jesse was from the ancestral tribe of Judah. Jesse was already an old man when Saul was king, and Jesse had eight sons. Jesse's oldest three sons were Eliab, the oldest, Abinadab, the second-born, and Shammah, the third-born. These three sons followed King Saul into war against the Philistine army.

David, however, was Jesse's youngest son. David also served King Saul, but instead of remaining with King Saul and Saul's army at their camp, David traveled back and forth between Saul's army and Bethlehem, where David took care of David's father's sheep.

Stop here and look at a map that shows both Bethlehem and the Valley of Elah as a group. Look at a picture of sheep as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What do younger brothers usually do in families in your culture? What are those younger brothers' responsibilities? Pause this audio here.

Now, the author very briefly goes back to the story about Goliath. At the same time that David was traveling back and forth between the battle lines and Bethlehem, Goliath continued to challenge the Israelites. For about 40 days, the Philistine champion Goliath stepped in front of the Philistine army in the morning and in the evening, and Goliath challenged and laughed at the Israelite soldiers. Goliath may not have done this for exactly 40 days, but at least for many days.

The author then goes back to telling about David. One day, while the Israelite and Philistine armies still faced one another, Jesse told David to hurry and take an ephah of roasted grain and 10 loaves of bread to David's brothers in the army camp. An ephah was a way to measure dry substances like grain. An ephah was between 13 and 23 kilograms. This roasted grain was probably wheat or barley. Roasted grain and loaves of bread were common foods for the Israelite people to eat at that time. Jesse also told David to take 10 pieces of cheese to the commanders of David's brothers' unit. Cheese is a solid food that people make from milk. The commander of the unit was probably the brothers' commanding officer, the person in charge of their group of soldiers.

Stop here and look at a picture of roasted grain, a picture of a loaf of bread, and a picture of a piece of cheese as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop and discuss as a group: Why do you think it was important for David to bring this type of food to the commanding officer? What kinds of food do people in your culture eat during a battle or when they are in the army? Pause this audio here.

Jesse told David to hurry and see how David's brothers were doing, and to bring back news about the brothers. Jesse wanted to know that Jesse's sons were well. Jesse either wanted David to bring back good news about David's brothers, or Jesse may have wanted David to bring Jesse a token or physical sign that the brothers had received the food and were safe and well. David's brothers were in the Valley of Elah with King Saul and Saul's soldiers fighting against the Philistine army.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do people in your culture receive news about their families during a battle or war?

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:12–19 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has three scenes.

In the first scene: Jesse, an Ephrathite man from Bethlehem, had eight sons. Jesse's three oldest sons, Eliab, Abinadab, and Shammah, followed King Saul to war with the Philistines. Jesse's youngest son was David. While Jesse's oldest sons stayed with King Saul, David traveled back and forth from the battle lines to Bethlehem to take care of David's father's sheep.

In the second scene: Meanwhile, the Philistine champion Goliath comes out from the battle line every morning and evening for about 40 days. When Goliath steps forward, Goliath challenges the Israelite army to send a man to fight against Goliath.

In the third scene: One day, Jesse tells David to quickly take an ephah of roasted grain along with 10 loaves of bread to David's brothers. Jesse also sends 10 pieces of cheese for David to give to the commander of David's brothers' unit. Jesse wants David to deliver the food, find out if David's brothers are well, and bring back a confirmation or token to prove that the brothers are well. David's brothers are with King Saul and Saul's army in the Valley of Elah, fighting against the Philistines.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Jesse

  • Eliab, Abinadab, and Shammah

  • David

  • Goliath

  • The Israelite army

  • And the commander of the brothers' unit

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In scene one, the storyteller interrupts the story about Goliath that began in a previous passage. Now the storyteller will tell more about Jesse and David. Jesse is an Ephrathite from Bethlehem. Jesse is already an old man when Saul is king, and Jesse has eight sons. Jesse's oldest three sons, Eliab, Abinadab, and Shammah, fight in King Saul's army. These three sons have followed King Saul into battle against the Philistines. Jesse's youngest son is David. Although David serves King Saul, David travels back and forth between the battle lines and Bethlehem, where David takes care of Jesse's sheep.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story where the action moves between different characters but happens all at the same time. How do you make sure your audience understands that, even though each character is acting in a different place, everything is happening at the same time and is all part of the same story? Pause this audio here.

In scene two, at the same time that David travels back and forth from the battle lines to Bethlehem, the Philistine champion Goliath continues to challenge the Israelite army on a regular basis. Goliath steps out from the battle line and challenges the Israelites to send someone to fight against Goliath every morning and evening for about 40 days.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story in which there seems to be no solution to a problem. How do you show how it feels not to know the solution to the problem? Pause this audio here.

In scene three, Jesse gives David an ephah, or between 13 and 23 kilograms, of roasted or parched grain. If you would like, you can just say that Jesse gave David a bag of roasted grain. Jesse also gave David 10 loaves of bread and 10 pieces of cheese to take to the commander of David's brothers' unit. Jesse tells David, "Go quickly and take this food to your brothers. Find out if your brothers are well and bring back a token to prove to me that they received the food and are alright." Jesse may want David just to bring back good news, or Jesse may want a physical sign that David's brothers are well. The brothers are with King Saul and Saul's army in the Valley of Elah, fighting against the Philistines. We do not know if Jesse actually tells David where David's brothers are, or if this is a summary the storyteller gives to let the audience know where the brothers are located.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do people who are far apart communicate with one another in your culture? How do you carry messages and bring back news? Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:12–19 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has three scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Jesse

  • Eliab, Abinadab, and Shammah

  • David

  • Goliath

  • The Israelite army

  • And the commander of the brothers' unit

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Jesse is an Ephrathite from Bethlehem. Jesse is already an old man when King Saul begins to rule. Jesse has eight sons. Jesse's three oldest sons, Eliab, Abinadab, and Shammah, fight in King Saul's army. These sons followed King Saul to the Valley of Elah to fight against the Philistines. Jesse's youngest son is David. While Jesse's oldest sons stay with King Saul to fight, David travels back and forth from the battle lines to Bethlehem, where David takes care of Jesse's sheep.

Pause the drama.

Ask the people playing Eliab, Abinadab, and Shammah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The people might answer things like:

  • We are proud to fight for King Saul! or

  • We know being a soldier is an important job; or

  • We are more important than our little brother, who just takes care of sheep.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I know I am too young to fight, but I will keep serving King Saul; or

  • I get tired of going back and forth, but I know that both serving King Saul and taking care of my father's sheep are important jobs.

While David travels back and forth, the Philistine champion Goliath continues to taunt the Israelite army. Every morning and evening for about 40 days, Goliath steps in front of the Philistine battle line and demands that the Israelite army send someone to fight Goliath.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Goliath, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I know the Israelites are terrified of me and will never fight me; or

  • I believe defeating the Israelites will be easy because the Philistine army and I are so strong and mighty.

Ask the people playing the Israelite army, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The people might answer things like:

  • We are losing hope that Yahweh will intervene and defeat this champion; or

  • We are terrified of Goliath and do not know what to do.

One day, Jesse gives David an ephah of roasted grain and 10 loaves of bread. Jesse wants David to hurry to the battle line and give the food to David's brothers. Jesse also gives David 10 pieces of cheese for David to deliver to the commander of David's brothers' unit. Jesse tells David, "Take these to your brothers and bring back news about them. Bring me a token so I know your brothers received the food and are well." David's brothers were with King Saul and Saul's army in the Valley of Elah, fighting against the Philistines.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Jesse, "What are you feeling and thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am concerned about my sons and want to make sure their needs are met; or

  • I want to make sure the commander of my sons' unit takes good care of my sons.

Ask the person playing the commander of the unit, "What are you feeling and thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am terrified of Goliath and glad to get some food; or

  • I will take special care of these men because I know David will visit again.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:12–19 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Jesse had eight sons, and David was Jesse's youngest son. David would become the second king of Israel. For more information on David, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word for David as you used in previous passages.

David's father, Jesse, was an Ephrathite. An Ephrathite was a person from Bethlehem or the towns right around Bethlehem. Ephrathites came from the tribe of Judah in Israel.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for Ephrathite. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Jesse was from Bethlehem, a small village in Judah. For more information on Bethlehem, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word for Bethlehem as you used in previous passages.

Jesse's three oldest sons fought with King Saul against the Philistines, but Jesse's youngest son, David, traveled back and forth between the battle line and the place where David cared for his father's sheep in Bethlehem.

The Philistine Goliath stepped out every morning and evening to challenge and laugh at the Israelites and to demand that the Israelites send someone to fight against Goliath. The Philistines are a people group who were constantly at war against the Israelites. The Philistines lived in the southwest part of Israel by the Mediterranean Sea. Use the same word for Philistine as you used in previous passages.

Jesse told David to take an ephah of roasted grain and 10 loaves of bread to David's brothers. An ephah is a dry measure equal to approximately 13 to 23 kilograms. Use the same word or phrase for ephah as you used in previous passages. For more information on ephah, refer to the Master Glossary.

Jesse also sent 10 pieces of cheese with David to give to the commander of David's brothers' unit. The commander of a unit was a military officer in charge of a particular group of soldiers. Use the same word for commander as you used in previous passages.

Cheese is a food that people make from milk.

Stop here and look at a picture of pieces of cheese. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for cheese. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Jesse told David to take the food to David's brothers and to bring back news or a token from the brothers. A token was a physical sign that the brothers were well. A token would give Jesse assurance or confirmation that Jesse's sons were alive and well.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for token or assurance. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
