title: 1 Samuel 17:20–30
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 17:20–30 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:20–30 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:20–30 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous passage, David traveled back and forth between the Israelite army camp and the town of Bethlehem to take care of his father Jesse's sheep. One day, Jesse told David to quickly go to the camp and take some food to David's brothers. Jesse wanted David to find out if David's brothers were doing well.

Early the next morning, David left another shepherd in charge of the sheep and hurried toward the camp with the food, just as Jesse had instructed David. David arrived at the camp as the soldiers were leaving to line up in their battle positions. The Israelite army shouted the war cry to show that the battle was about to begin as they lined up in battle formation. The Israelite and Philistine armies lined up to face each other in preparation for battle.

Stop here and look at a map that includes Bethlehem and the army camp at the Valley of Elah. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do people in your culture know when a battle is about to begin? Pause this audio here.

David left the food David had brought with the man who took care of the supplies for the army. Then David ran to greet his brothers in the battle line. While David spoke with his brothers, suddenly the Philistine champion Goliath from Gath stepped out in front of the Philistine battle line. Goliath made fun of the Israelites and made his usual challenge as he had been doing day after day. This time, David heard what Goliath said. When all the other Israelite soldiers heard Goliath, they ran from Goliath because the soldiers were so afraid.

The Israelite soldiers talked among themselves about how Goliath kept coming up the hill towards the Israelite army to challenge them. The Israelites discussed how King Saul had promised to give any man who killed Goliath great riches as a reward. The king had also promised to give the king's daughter as a wife to any Israelite who killed Goliath. The family of the man who killed Goliath would be free in Israel. This means that man's descendants and servants would not have to pay taxes or fulfill any other obligations to serve the king.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What kinds of rewards do people receive for defeating enemies in your culture? Pause this audio here.

David turned to the men who were next to David and asked what would be done for the man who killed Goliath and removed the disgrace from Israel. Goliath brought disgrace, or shame, to Israel because Goliath dared to go against God and God's people. David asked, "Who does this uncircumcised Philistine think he is to mock or defy the army of the living God?" Circumcision was a sign that a man was included in the covenant God made with Abraham. Goliath was uncircumcised because Goliath was not one of God's people.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story where someone brings shame on a person or group of people. Pause this audio here.

The soldiers around David repeated the information about what the king had promised to the man who would kill Goliath. When Eliab, David's oldest brother, overheard David talking with the soldiers, Eliab's anger burned against David. This means that Eliab was very angry with David. Eliab asked David why David came to the camp and who was taking care of the few sheep that were David's responsibility. Eliab called David proud and devious and accused David of coming to the camp only so David could watch the battle.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about a time when someone was very angry with someone else because they thought that person was irresponsible or proud. Pause this audio here.

But David replied to Eliab, "I have not done anything wrong. Can I not even speak?" David turned away from Eliab and continued to ask other soldiers what people might do for the man who was brave enough to kill Goliath. Every soldier David asked confirmed the information David had already heard.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:20–30 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has five scenes.

In the first scene: Early in the morning, David leaves another shepherd in charge of David's sheep and hurries to the army camp with the food. David arrives just as the Israelite and Philistine armies are lining up to face each other for battle. David leaves the food with the man who keeps supplies and runs to greet David's brothers in the battle line.

In the second scene: Suddenly, Goliath, the Philistine champion from Gath, steps out of the line of the Philistine army. Goliath taunts the Israelite army as he has been doing day after day. This time, David hears Goliath's challenge. The Israelite soldiers are so afraid of Goliath that the soldiers flee in terror.

In the third scene: The Israelite soldiers talk amongst themselves about Goliath and what King Saul has promised to give the man who kills Goliath. The king has promised to give great wealth, a daughter in marriage, and freedom to the man's family.

In the fourth scene: David turns to the soldiers next to David and asks what people will do for the man who kills Goliath and removes Goliath's disgrace from Israel. David asks how Goliath, a man who is not one of God's people, could dare to defy the armies of the living God. The soldiers tell David what King Saul has promised.

In the fifth scene: David's oldest brother Eliab overhears David asking about rewards for killing Goliath, and Eliab's anger burns against David. Eliab calls David proud and devious and accuses David of coming to the camp only to watch the battle. David replies, "I have done nothing wrong. Can I not even ask a question?" David turns away from Eliab to ask again about rewards for killing Goliath. The soldiers confirm what David has already heard.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • The other shepherd who cares for David's sheep

  • The Israelite soldiers

  • The Philistine soldiers

  • Goliath

  • Eliab

  • And David's other brothers

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In the first scene, early in the morning, David leaves his sheep with another shepherd and travels to the army camp with the food, as Jesse instructed David. David arrives at the camp right at the time when the Israelite army is taking their battle positions and shouting their war cry. David gives the food from Jesse to the man in charge of supplies for the Israelite army. Then David hurries to the battle line to find out if David's brothers are well.

In the second scene, at the same time that David reaches his brothers in the battle line, the Philistine champion Goliath of Gath steps away from the Philistine army and moves up towards the Israelite army. The Philistine army has lined up on one side of the valley, and the Israelite army has lined up on the other side of the valley. Goliath probably walks down from the Philistine army into the valley and then up towards the Israelite army on the other side. Goliath challenges the Israelite army to find a champion to defeat Goliath as he has done day after day. This time, David hears Goliath's shouting towards the Israelite army. The Israelite soldiers flee from Goliath in fear when they hear Goliath's insults.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story where the order of events is clear even though the setting of the story changes. In this story, two things happen at almost the same time when David greets his brothers and hears Goliath speak. How will you make this clear to your audience? Pause this audio here.

In scene three, the Israelite soldiers have been talking among themselves. The soldiers talk about Goliath and how Goliath constantly challenges and makes fun of the Israelite army. The soldiers also discuss what King Saul has promised to give to the champion who would defeat Goliath. The king promised to give great riches, to give the king's daughter to the man in marriage, and to give freedom for the man's whole family in Israel. To marry a king's daughter was a great reward for faithful service in Israel. A free family in Israel did not have to pay taxes or fulfill other obligations to the king.

In scene four, David turns to the Israelite soldiers next to David and asks what reward the man who kills Goliath would receive. Even though the soldiers have been discussing the rewards among themselves, we are not sure if David has heard what King Saul has promised to give the man who kills Goliath. David asks, "What will be done for the man who kills this Philistine and takes away the disgrace of Goliath from Israel? Who is this uncircumcised man who dares to challenge the army of the living God?" David may have asked this question because he did not know what King Saul promised, or David may have wanted to make sure that what David had heard was true. David may also have asked the question to show David's disrespect for Goliath. By challenging the Israelite army, Goliath spoke wrongly about Israel's God. Goliath is a disgrace because Goliath has dared to challenge the army of the living God. The term "living God" reminds the Israelites that God is active and working on behalf of the Israelites. This contrasts with the gods from other cultures, who are not alive and do not act. When David questions the soldiers, the soldiers repeat what they have been discussing among themselves.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do people describe gods in your culture? How will you describe the living God in this passage? Pause this audio here.

In scene five, David's oldest brother Eliab overhears David's questions, and Eliab's anger burns against David.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How will you show how angry Eliab is at David? Remember the story you told in the previous step about someone being angry. Pay attention to what words you used to describe that person's anger. Pause this audio here.

Eliab demands to know why David has come to the battle line and what David did with the few sheep that were David's responsibility. Because David's family only has a few sheep, it would have been a great loss if they had lost even one sheep. Eliab believes David has been irresponsible in leaving the sheep. Eliab declares that David is full of pride and has an evil heart. Eliab accuses David of coming to the camp only so David could witness the battle.

But David knows David has obeyed his father Jesse. David asks Eliab, "What have I done wrong? I only asked a question." David turns away from Eliab to another soldier and asks again about the reward for the man who kills Goliath. Again, the soldiers repeat the same information David has already heard.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:20–30 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has five scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • The other shepherd who cares for David's sheep

  • The Israelite soldiers

  • The Philistine soldiers

  • Goliath

  • Eliab

  • And David's other brothers

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Early in the morning, David leaves his sheep with another shepherd and travels to the Israelite army camp at the Valley of Elah with the gifts of food as Jesse had instructed. David arrives at the battlefield just as the armies are lining up for battle and shouting war cries. The armies stand facing each other. David leaves the food with the keeper of supplies and runs to greet David's brothers in the battle line.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am excited to travel to the army camp to see my brothers; or

  • I am happy to obey my father so that we can make sure my brothers are doing well.

Ask the people playing Eliab and David's other brothers, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The people may answer things like:

  • We are glad to see our brother and to know he brought food; or

  • We do not know why David is here. We are not happy to see David.

Just as David begins to speak with his brothers, Goliath, the Philistine champion from Gath, comes out from the Philistine army and walks up the hill towards the Israelite army. David hears Goliath shout the challenge Goliath has made towards the Israelite army day after day. The other Israelite soldiers are so afraid of Goliath that they flee from Goliath in terror.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Goliath, "What are you feeling and thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I know I am more powerful than these Israelite soldiers. The Israelite soldiers are still terrified of me, even after almost 40 days! or

  • I am proud of my might and wish these Israelites would just let us defeat them already.

Ask the people playing the Israelite soldiers, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The people may answer things like:

  • We are still terrified of Goliath! God has not done anything for us in the time Goliath has been insulting us, and we do not know if God will ever help us; or

  • We are not sure God can defeat Goliath.

The Israelite soldiers talk amongst themselves about Goliath. "Have you seen that giant?" the soldiers ask each other. "Goliath comes out every day to challenge Israel. But King Saul has promised great rewards for the man who kills Goliath." The king had promised to give the man who defeated Goliath great riches and the king's daughter in marriage, and to allow the man's family to be free from taxes in Israel.

David turned to the soldiers next to David and asked what reward people might give to the man who defeated Goliath. "What reward will the man receive who defeats Goliath and ends his disgrace against Israel? Who is this uncircumcised Philistine who dares to defy the army of the living God of Israel?" The soldiers confirm the rewards that King Saul has promised to give to the man who defeats Goliath.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I know the living God of Israel will not accept this Philistine who is not one of God's people and who does not respect the God of Israel; or

  • I know the living God of Israel can defeat any giant; or

  • I know God could use me to fight this giant even though I am small and young.

When David's oldest brother, Eliab, hears David asking about the rewards for killing Goliath, Eliab is very angry with David. Eliab accuses David of being irresponsible for leaving the sheep that are David's responsibility. Eliab says, "I know you are prideful and deceitful! You probably came here only to watch the battle!" David replies to Eliab, "I have done nothing wrong. I was only asking a question!" David then turns to another soldier and again asks what people might do for the man who defeats Goliath. The soldier confirms what other soldiers had told David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Eliab, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I think my little brother is just here to cause trouble. David cannot possibly be useful here on the battlefield; or

  • I do not think David could defeat Goliath. David is just being nosy.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:20–30 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Early in the morning, David left his sheep with another shepherd. David was Jesse's youngest son, and David took care of his father's sheep. A shepherd is someone who takes care of sheep or goats. Sheep are gentle animals that people keep to use the animals' milk, to eat the animals' meat, and to use the animals' hair for clothing. Use the same words or phrases for shepherd and for sheep as you used in previous passages. For more information on David and shepherd, refer to the Master Glossary.

Stop here and look at a picture of a sheep as a group, if it is helpful. Pause this audio here.

David reached the army camp right as the Israelite and Philistine soldiers lined up for battle and began to shout war cries. A camp is a place where a group of people stop for a limited period. In this case, it was a place where the Israelite army stopped and stayed to fight the Philistines. Use the same word or phrase for camp as you used in previous passages.

Israelites refer to the people who are descended from Jacob. The Israelites lived in Israel. Use the same words or phrases for Israelite and Israel as you used in previous passages. For more information on Israelite and Israel, refer to the Master Glossary.

A war cry or battle cry is when an army shouts a word or phrase, or makes a noise, right before the soldiers fight in a battle.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for war cry. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

David left his things with the keeper of supplies and ran to greet David's brothers. The keeper of supplies took care of the baggage and provisions that the Israelite army needed.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for keeper of supplies. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Just as David greeted his brothers, Goliath, the Philistine champion from Gath, came up from the Philistine army. A champion was someone who was willing to fight against someone else on behalf of that champion's country. Use the same word or phrase for champion as you used in previous passages.

The Israelite soldiers ran from Goliath in terror. The soldiers talked amongst themselves about the rewards King Saul had promised to give the man who defeated Goliath. The king would give that man great riches and the king's daughter in marriage. The king would also make that man and the man's family free in Israel. To be free in Israel meant that a man and his family would no longer have to pay taxes in Israel.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for free in Israel. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word as you used there. Pause this audio here.

David asked the soldiers around David what reward a man would receive if that man defeated Goliath and took the disgrace away from Israel. To bring disgrace on someone or something means to bring shame or make that person ashamed. Goliath brought disgrace on Israel because Goliath defied the army of the living God.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for disgrace. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word as you used there. Pause this audio here.

David asked, "Who is this uncircumcised Philistine who dares to defy the armies of the living God?" Circumcision is the Jewish practice of cutting off the loose skin at the end of a boy's penis. Circumcision was a sign that the person was included in the covenant God made with Abraham. Goliath was uncircumcised, or not circumcised, which means that Goliath was not part of the covenant and was not one of God's people.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for uncircumcised. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word as you used there. For more information on circumcision, refer to the Master Glossary. Pause this audio here.

David called God "the living God." God refers to the God who created everything. God is the most powerful spiritual being. This is the God who made a covenant, or special promise, to Abraham and Abraham's descendants, the Israelites. Use the same word for God as you used in previous passages. For more information on God, refer to the Master Glossary.

When David's brother Eliab heard David's questions, Eliab was very angry and accused David of being irresponsible, prideful, and deceitful. Eliab asked David who was watching the sheep in the wilderness. Eliab said that David had a wicked heart. Use the same words or phrases for wilderness, wicked, and heart as you have used before, and see the Master Glossary for more information about wilderness, wicked, and heart.

David said to Eliab, "I have done nothing wrong. All I did was ask a question." David then turned to some other soldiers and asked more about the man who would kill Goliath. Those soldiers repeated the same information to David that David had already heard.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 17:31–40
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 17:31–40 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:31–40 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:31–40 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous passage, David took some food from his father Jesse to David's brothers at the army camp at Elah. When Goliath came out from the Philistine army and challenged the Israelite army, David asked the men around David what the king would do for the man who could defeat Goliath and remove the disgrace from Israel. David asked why Goliath continued to go against the armies of the living God.

In this passage, we learn how some men heard David asking those questions, and the men repeated David's questions to Saul, Israel's king. Now, Saul asks the men to bring David to Saul. When David arrives, David tells Saul that no man should lose heart because of that Philistine. To lose heart means to be afraid, so David is telling Saul that no one should be afraid of the Philistine. David says David will fight the Philistine Goliath.

King Saul says that David cannot fight against the Philistine because David is just a young boy. David is probably between 15 and 20 years old, and men would not think of David as an adult. Saul also might mean that David does not have any military training or experience. Saul goes on to tell David that the Philistine Goliath has been a warrior and expert in war since Goliath was a young man.

Stop here and discuss as a group: When do you consider young men adults in your culture? How do you know when a young man is ready to fight in battle? Pause this audio here.

David calls himself King Saul's servant and responds to Saul in a polite and respectful way, even though David does not agree with King Saul. David says that David has been taking care of David's father's sheep. David has experience with fighting because David has protected the sheep from dangerous animals. David tells Saul that when a lion or bear tried to steal a sheep from the flock, David chased the lion or bear, hit it with David's staff, and rescued the sheep from the animal's mouth. A shepherd like David would use a staff to help defend themselves and their animals from dangerous animals. When the lion or bear turned to attack David, David grabbed the lion or bear by the fur on its throat and hit that animal until it died. We can see from David's experiences that David was strong and brave.

Stop here and look at a picture of a sheep, a lion, and a bear as a group. Look at a picture of a shepherd's staff. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What kinds of tools do you use when you take care of animals in your culture? Pause this audio here.

David continues to tell Saul that David has killed a lion and a bear, and David will kill the uncircumcised Philistine just like David killed the lion and bear. David is insulting the Philistine Goliath by calling Goliath uncircumcised. The Israelites were proud that their circumcision was a sign of their special covenant with Yahweh. The Philistine did not respect the armies of the living God. "The living God" is another name for Yahweh. Yahweh rescued David from the paw of the lion and the bear, and Yahweh will also rescue David from the hand of the Philistine. To rescue someone from the paw or hand of something means to rescue that person from the power of something. God will rescue David from the Philistine, even though Goliath is more powerful than David.

King Saul replies, "Go, and may Yahweh be with you." This was a common way to say goodbye, but King Saul is also asking Yahweh to be with David on David's mission to fight against the Philistine. King Saul gives his armor to David. This armor includes a tunic, or shirt that people wore under armor, and a bronze helmet. People made this kind of armor from small metal rings, which they tied together with leather straps. People wore this kind of armor over their chest for protection. A helmet is a metal covering for a person's head. Saul's helmet was bronze, which is a type of metal. David put on King Saul's sword over the armor and tried to walk around. David had never worn armor before and could not move freely because the armor was very heavy.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of armor, including a tunic, a helmet, and a sword. Pause this audio here.

David told King Saul that David could not wear the armor because David had not worn it before. So, David took off King Saul's armor.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What kind of clothing or armor do people in your culture wear in battle in order to protect themselves? Pause this audio here.

David picked up his shepherd's staff or stick and started to walk down the hill and into the valley towards Goliath. At the streambed in the valley, David stopped and picked up five small smooth stones. A streambed is where water sometimes flows in a valley between hills. Sometimes streambeds are dry when there has not been much rain. The stones would have been smooth because water had flowed over the stones. David put the stones in the pocket of David's shepherd's bag. With David's sling in his hand and David's staff in his hand, David came closer to Goliath the Philistine. A sling was a weapon that people made of leather that could hold a small stone. A person would swing the leather of the sling around his head and then release the stone to hit that person's enemy. Because David carried his sling in his hand, we know David was ready for the action of battle.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a valley with a streambed in the valley. Look at a picture of a smooth stone and a shepherd's bag. Look at a picture of a sling. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What do you think about David going to fight a warrior like Goliath with only a sling?

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:31–40 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has four scenes.

In the first scene: Some men from the army overhear David when David asks questions about what the king would do for the man who would defeat Goliath. These army men tell King Saul, and King Saul asks the men to bring David to Saul.

In the second scene: David tells King Saul that no one should be afraid of that Philistine Goliath, and David will fight Goliath. King Saul responds to David and says that David is too young and inexperienced to fight a warrior like Goliath.

In the third scene: David responds to King Saul and says that David has experience because David protected his sheep from dangerous animals. David chased and killed lions and bears that attacked David's sheep and rescued the sheep from those animals. David killed the lion and the bear, and David will kill the uncircumcised Philistine Goliath like David killed the lion and bear. Yahweh rescued David from the animals, and Yahweh will rescue David from Goliath.

In the fourth scene: King Saul tells David to go, and may Yahweh go with David. King Saul tries to give David some armor, but after David tries the armor on, David decides not to wear it because David is not used to the armor. David picks up five small smooth stones from the streambed and walks closer to Goliath. David carries his shepherd's staff in one hand, and David carries his sling in his other hand.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Men from the Israelite army

  • King Saul

  • David

  • Lion and bear

  • Sheep

  • And the Philistine, Goliath

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In scene one, David had spoken to some men in King Saul's army. David had asked those men what people would do for the Israelite man who defeated the Philistine Goliath. Now, some of the men from the Israelite army tell King Saul about David's questions. King Saul sends someone to bring David to Saul. The Israelite army is in a battle line on one side of the valley, and the Philistine army is in a battle line on the other side of the valley. The Philistine Goliath stands in front of the Philistine army battle line and continues to challenge the Israelite army while David speaks to King Saul.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story where the focus is on action in one place, and then the focus switches to action in another place, even though the first action is still happening. How will you help your audience understand that several things are happening all at the same time? Pause this audio here.

In scene two, David comes to King Saul and tells Saul that no man should lose heart because of Goliath. To lose heart means to be afraid. No one should be afraid of the Philistine. David is talking about the Philistine Goliath, but David does not say Goliath's name because David did not like or respect Goliath. David says David will fight against the Philistine. King Saul replies, "You cannot fight against this Philistine and win! You are only a young boy, but that man has been a warrior for his entire life."

Stop here and discuss as a group how you will talk about people who lose heart, or who become very afraid and discouraged. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about an enemy that you really do not respect. Notice that what you call your enemy shows how you feel about that person. Pause this audio here.

In scene three, David disagrees with King Saul. Even though David does not agree with King Saul, David speaks respectfully and calls himself King Saul's servant. David says David has experience in battle because, while David took care of his father's sheep, David protected the sheep. When a lion or bear came and stole a sheep from the flock, David chased after the animal, hit it, and took the sheep out of the animal's mouth. When the lion or bear tried to attack David, David grabbed the animal by the fur on its throat, beat the animal, and killed it. "I have killed any lion or any bear who tried to steal my sheep," David tells King Saul, "and I will kill this uncircumcised Philistine too because he challenged the armies of the living God. Yahweh rescued me from the lion and the bear, and Yahweh will rescue me from this Philistine."

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story where someone disagrees with someone else in a polite and respectful way. How will your audience understand that David respected King Saul even though David disagreed with King Saul? Pause this audio here.

In scene four, King Saul tells David, "Go, and may Yahweh go with you." King Saul wants David to defeat the Philistine. King Saul gives David King Saul's armor to protect David in the battle. King Saul gives David a tunic to go under the armor. King Saul also gives David a helmet that people made of bronze and King Saul's own sword. David puts on the armor and the sword and tries to walk around. However, David has never worn armor before, and David cannot move easily because the armor is so heavy.

"I cannot fight in this armor because I have never worn it before," David says. David takes the armor off and, with his staff in his hand, David stops and picks up five small smooth stones from the streambed. David puts the stones in the pocket of David's shepherd's bag. David has a sling in his other hand. David walks towards the Philistine.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do people in your culture prepare for a battle? How will you describe David's preparation for battle? Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:31–40 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has four scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Men from the Israelite army

  • King Saul

  • David

  • Lion and bear

  • Sheep

  • And the Philistine, Goliath

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

David has been talking to some men from the Israelite army. David asks the men about what the king might do for the Israelite who defeats the Philistine Goliath. Some men go to King Saul and tell Saul about David's questions. King Saul sends someone to bring David to Saul.

Pause the drama.

Ask the people playing the men from the Israelite army, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The people might answer things like:

  • We think this boy, David, wants to fight against Goliath; or

  • We are tired of David's questions and hope King Saul tells David to go home; or

  • We hope David is the answer to the problem of Goliath! or

  • We are angry with David because David is bragging about defeating Goliath.

David comes to King Saul and says, "No one should be afraid of this Philistine. I will fight him!" King Saul replies, "There is no way you could ever defeat this Philistine! You are only a young boy, and you have no experience with fighting. But this Philistine has been a warrior from the time he was young!"

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing King Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I like David's courage, but I see no way David could win against Goliath; or

  • I am afraid that David has too much confidence in himself; or

  • I think this young man is too prideful and will cause even more trouble for us with the Philistines.

David does not agree with what King Saul says. David tells King Saul, "I have plenty of fighting experience! I have been watching my father's sheep, and whenever a lion or a bear came to steal a sheep, I chased after it, hit it, and took the sheep out of its mouth. When that lion or bear turned and tried to attack me, I grabbed it by the fur on its throat and hit it until it was dead. I have killed lions and bears, and just like I killed them, I will kill this Philistine because he has challenged the armies of the living God. Yahweh rescued me from the lion and the bear, and Yahweh will rescue me from the Philistine Goliath."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Even though no one seems to believe me, I know Yahweh will fight for me; or

  • I know King Saul does not have confidence in me, but I have confidence in Yahweh. I hope King Saul allows me to fight!

King Saul tells David to go, and may Yahweh go with David to fight. Then King Saul offers David Saul's tunic and armor. Saul also gives David a helmet that people made of bronze and King Saul's own sword. David tries on the armor and tries to walk around, but David has never worn armor before. The armor is heavy and makes it hard for David to move easily. "I cannot wear this," David tells King Saul. "I cannot move easily." David takes off King Saul's armor and picks up five small smooth stones. David puts the stones in the pocket of David's shepherd's bag and walks towards Goliath. David has his shepherd's staff in one hand and David's sling in the other hand.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel a little afraid, but I know Yahweh is with me, like King Saul said; or

  • I am confident Yahweh will use what I have to defeat Goliath.

Ask the person playing the Philistine Goliath, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I see a young boy walking towards me and wonder what the Israelites are thinking; or

  • I can kill this boy easily, and then we can finally defeat all these Israelites! or

  • Israel must have a very weak God to send a young boy to fight against me!

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:31–40 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Someone brings David to Saul because David has been asking questions about the man who would defeat Goliath. David was Jesse's son who took care of Jesse's sheep and served King Saul. Use the same word for David as you used in previous passages. For more information on David, refer to the Master Glossary.

David continues talking to Saul and says, "Your servant will fight Goliath." A servant is a man or woman who works for another person. David was Saul's servant. David showed respect for Saul when David called himself Saul's servant. Use the same word or phrase for servant as you used in previous passages. For more information on servant, refer to the Master Glossary.

Saul tells David that David cannot defeat Goliath because David is only a youth or a boy. A youth could be an infant or a growing boy, or a youth could just mean that David was a young soldier whom people did not yet accept as an adult soldier. Use the same word for youth as you used in previous passages.

Saul tells David that Goliath has been a warrior since Goliath was a youth. A warrior is a brave or experienced soldier. Use the same word for warrior as you used in previous passages.

David tells Saul that David fought a lion and a bear when those animals came to attack David's father's sheep. A lion is a large brownish-yellow cat. Male lions have a large mane, or a lot of fur, around their heads. Lions are excellent hunters. A bear is a large, hairy animal with thick hair and a short tail. Both lions and bears have sharp claws that they use to grab and hurt other animals or people. Lions and bears will eat other animals like sheep.

Stop here and look at pictures of a lion, a bear, and a sheep. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for lion, bear, and sheep. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

David tells Saul that David killed the lion and the bear, and David will kill the uncircumcised Philistine Goliath. Circumcision is the practice of cutting off the loose skin at the end of a boy's penis. Circumcision was a sign that a person was included in the covenant God made with Abraham. Goliath was uncircumcised, so Goliath was not one of God's people. Use the same word for uncircumcised as you used in previous passages. For more information on circumcised and uncircumcised, refer to circumcision in the Master Glossary.

David tells Saul he will defeat Goliath because Goliath challenged the armies of the living God. God is the one who created everything. God is the most powerful spiritual being. Use the same word for God as you used in previous passages. For more information on God, refer to the Master Glossary.

David says that Yahweh rescued David from the lion and the bear, and Yahweh will rescue David from Goliath. Yahweh is God's personal name. This name showed the close relationship between God and the people of Israel. David also uses the name "living God" when David talks about Yahweh. Use the same word for Yahweh as you used in previous passages. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary.

Saul agrees to let David go with Yahweh to fight Goliath. Then Saul gives David Saul's tunic, breastplate of scale armor, bronze helmet, and sword. A tunic is an item of clothing that reaches to the knees or the ankles. People made tunics from wool or linen, and sometimes a man would put his sword in the waist of his tunic. People wore armor over the chest and back. People made armor out of many small metal rings that they tied together with leather straps. Because all the rings were connected, the armor would be flexible like fabric, but the metal would make the armor difficult for weapons to pierce. The helmet Saul gave was made of bronze. Bronze is a metal that people make by combining copper and tin. Use the same words for tunic, armor, bronze helmet, and sword as you used in previous passages. For more information on tunic and bronze, refer to the Master Glossary.

Stop here and look at pictures of a tunic, armor, helmet, and sword, if needed. Pause this audio here.

David tries on Saul's armor, but the armor is too heavy and does not allow David to move easily. David takes off the armor and picks up five small smooth stones in the streambed. A streambed is where water sometimes flows in a valley between hills. In dry seasons, when there is not much rain, streambeds do not have much water. But during rainy seasons, streambeds can be full of flowing water. The stones would have been smooth because water had flowed over the stones for a long time.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for streambed. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you used there. Pause this audio here.

David puts the stones in the pocket of David's shepherd's bag. A shepherd would use a shepherd's bag to carry belongings as the shepherd walked alongside their sheep each day. David also carried a shepherd's staff. This was a stick shepherds could use to help them walk and to help defend the sheep against other animals. David carried a sling in David's other hand. A sling is a simple weapon that people made of a strap in a loop that people could spin over their head to fling small stones.

Stop here and look at a picture of a shepherd's bag, a shepherd's staff, and a sling. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for shepherd's bag, shepherd's staff, and sling. See the Master Glossary for more information about shepherds, if needed. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 17:41–54
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 17:41–54 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:41–54 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:41–54 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous passage, David told King Saul that David would fight Goliath. King Saul disagreed, but David insisted that Yahweh would rescue David from Goliath. David walked towards Goliath carrying a shepherd's staff and a sling with five small rocks in David's bag.

Now, Goliath begins to walk towards David. The man who carries Goliath's shield walks in front of Goliath. The shield is big enough to protect most of Goliath's body. The two men walk closer and closer to David. Goliath looks at David and realizes that David is a youth. David's face is ruddy, or healthy with reddish cheeks, and David is handsome. David carries his shepherd's staff or stick and a sling, which is a weapon people use to throw rocks. Goliath is not impressed with David's appearance or with the staff David carries. Goliath probably thinks that Goliath is much stronger and better equipped to fight than David, so Goliath despises David. Goliath does not believe it is worth the effort to fight against David.

Stop here and look at a picture of a shield-bearer with a shield, a picture of a staff, and a picture of a sling. Pause this audio here.

Goliath asks David if David thinks Goliath is like a dog that David can chase away with a stick. A dog is a four-legged animal that the Israelite people considered unclean. To call someone a dog was an insult. Goliath thinks David does not respect Goliath. Because David only carries a staff and a sling, David looks like he is about to fight a dog instead of a warrior like Goliath. Goliath curses David in the name of Goliath's gods. Goliath probably worships the gods of the Philistines. To curse someone means to wish something bad would happen to that person. Goliath hopes that the Philistine gods Goliath worships will use their power to destroy David.

Stop here and look at a picture of a dog as a group. Pause this audio here.

Goliath shouts for David to come closer so Goliath can kill David and give David's body to the birds of the air and the beasts of the field, or the wild animals. For the Israelite people, the idea of leaving bodies out for the birds and wild animals to eat was worse than death because people highly valued giving dead bodies a proper burial. Goliath threatens and challenges David.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What do people in your culture usually do to show respect to dead bodies? Pause this audio here.

David replies that Goliath attacks with a sword, spear, and javelin, but David comes in the power of Yahweh Almighty, who is the God of Israel's armies. Because Goliath has defied or challenged the God of Israel, David says Yahweh will give David victory over Goliath. David will hit Goliath and cut off Goliath's head. David says that today the Israelites will slaughter or kill the entire Philistine army, and the Israelites will give the dead bodies of the Philistine army to the birds and the beasts. Then the entire world will know that Israel has a God who really does things for God's people. David says that everyone who is gathered to fight will know that Yahweh does not use weapons or spears to save Yahweh's people. Yahweh always decides who wins battles, and Yahweh will give the Philistines into the Israelite army's hands. This means Yahweh will help the Israelites defeat the Philistines.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about the gods in your culture. What kind of power do those gods have, and how do those gods use that power to help people in battle against their enemies? Pause this audio here.

Goliath moves closer to David as Goliath gets ready to attack David. Goliath probably cannot move quickly because Goliath has so much armor on his body and so many weapons to carry. But David quickly runs forward to the battle line to meet Goliath. David reaches into David's shepherd's bag and takes out a stone. David puts the stone in David's sling, swings the sling around David's head, and slings the rock straight into Goliath's forehead. This is one of the few places on Goliath's body that armor does not protect. The stone goes deep into Goliath's forehead, and Goliath falls facedown on the ground.

So with only a sling and a stone, David defeats Goliath the Philistine. David does not have a sword when David strikes the Philistine and kills him.

As soon as Goliath falls, David runs to Goliath and stands over him as Goliath lies on the ground. David grabs Goliath's sword from its sheath or holder. People had probably made this sheath from leather. Even though the earlier description of Goliath and Goliath's armor did not include Goliath's sword, this is probably the javelin or scimitar Goliath wore on his back. David uses the sword to kill Goliath by cutting off Goliath's head, just like David had promised to do earlier.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a javelin next to its sheath and a scimitar next to its sheath. Pause this audio here.

When the Philistine army sees that their champion Goliath is dead, the Philistines turn away from the Israelite army and run away. The Israelite men, who are from Israel and Judah, run forward and shout a battle cry as they chase the Philistine army. The army chases the Philistine soldiers all the way to the entrance of the city of Gath and to the gates of the city of Ekron. All along the road that leads from Shaaraim to Gath and Ekron, the dead and wounded bodies of the Philistine soldiers lay.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about an important military victory in your culture. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a map that contains the Valley of Elah and the cities of Gath, Ekron, and Shaaraim. Pause this audio here.

When the Israelites finished chasing the Philistines, the Israelites returned and plundered the Philistine army camp. This means the Israelites took all the equipment and supplies out of the camp. David kept Goliath's head and took it to Jerusalem. We are not certain if David left Goliath's head outside Jerusalem right away, or if David took the head to Jerusalem much later. Because Jerusalem belonged to the Philistines at this time, David may have placed Goliath's head outside Jerusalem as a warning to the people who lived there, or David may have placed the head in Jerusalem much later when the city belonged to Israel. David kept Goliath's armor and weapons in David's tent or dwelling-place. The army may have given David his own tent at the army camp right away because David had won a big victory. Or, David might have put Goliath's weapons in the tent of meeting or the tent of Yahweh. This was the place where Yahweh's presence lived, and later on, David found Goliath's sword in the tent of meeting.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:41–54 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has four scenes.

In the first scene: Goliath walks behind his shield-bearer towards David and sees that David is a young boy who is ruddy and handsome. Goliath despises David and accuses David of thinking Goliath is only as intimidating as a dog. Goliath curses David by Goliath's gods and shouts for David to come closer so Goliath can give David's body to the birds and wild animals to eat.

In the second scene: David replies to Goliath that Goliath comes with weapons, but David comes in the name of Yahweh Almighty. Because Goliath defied the army of Israel, Yahweh will give David victory over Goliath so that the whole world will know that Israel has a God who really does things for his people. Yahweh always wins Yahweh's battles, and Yahweh will give victory over the Philistines to Israel.

In the third scene: Goliath slowly moves closer to David, and David runs quickly towards Goliath as David pulls a stone out of David's bag. David puts the stone into David's sling and throws the rock into the middle of Goliath's forehead, where the stone sinks in. Goliath falls facedown on the ground. David takes Goliath's sword out of its sheath and uses the sword to kill Goliath and to cut off Goliath's head.

In the fourth scene: When the Philistines see that Goliath is dead, the Philistines run away. The men in the Israelite army shout a battle cry and quickly chase the Philistine army all the way to Gath and Ekron. Dead bodies of Philistines lie on the road. When the Israelites finish chasing the Philistines, the Israelites return to plunder the Philistine camp. David takes Goliath's head to Jerusalem, but keeps Goliath's weapons in David's tent.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The Philistine Goliath

  • Goliath's shield-bearer

  • David

  • The Philistine army

  • And the Israelite army

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In the first scene, David had already walked toward Goliath, and now, Goliath begins to follow Goliath's shield-bearer towards David. Goliath watches David walk towards Goliath, and Goliath sees that David is young, healthy, and handsome. But Goliath is not impressed with David. Goliath sees that David carries only a staff, and Goliath believes David insults Goliath by only carrying such inferior weapons. Goliath accuses David of treating Goliath like a dog because David comes towards Goliath holding a staff or stick in David's hand while Goliath walks behind a shield that almost covers Goliath's entire body. Goliath makes fun of David and begins to curse David by the Philistine gods. Goliath wants his gods to destroy David. Goliath yells, "Come closer so I can kill you and feed your body to the birds and wild animals!"

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story in which one person insults another. What kinds of insults do people use in your culture? What actions do people use to show that they are cursing or making fun of someone else? Pause this audio here.

In the second scene, David shouts back to the Philistine. In this passage, David is talking to the Philistine Goliath, but David does not say Goliath's name because David hates and does not respect Goliath.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about someone you really do not respect. Notice that what you call that person shows how you feel about that person. Pause this audio here.

David yells, "You are coming towards me with a sword, a spear, and a javelin. But you have challenged the God of the army of Israel. So I am coming to you in the name of our God, Yahweh the Almighty." To come "in the name of" Yahweh means that David comes to Goliath with the power and strength of Yahweh the Almighty. To say that Yahweh is almighty means that Yahweh is all-powerful because Yahweh is the God of heaven's armies or hosts. You may translate this as "Yahweh, the God who is all-powerful" if you believe that works better in your language. David also says, "Today, Yahweh will defeat you, and I will cut off your head. Then I will give the dead bodies of your Philistine army to the birds of the air and beasts of the field to eat!"

Stop here and discuss as a group: Goliath and David both threaten to give the dead bodies of their enemy to the birds of the air and the beasts of the field. Goliath and David would not really give the dead bodies to the birds and the animals, but this was a way to show that they were cursing their enemy. How will you say this so that people understand that this was a way to show disrespect to a person's enemy? Pause this audio here.

David says, "Then the whole world will know that Israel has a God who really does things for his people. And everyone here will know that Yahweh always wins his battles, and he does not have to use weapons. This battle belongs to Yahweh, and Yahweh will give us victory over you!"

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story where someone has great confidence over an enemy even though that person looks weaker than their enemy. How will you help your audience understand David's confidence and trust in Yahweh? Pause this audio here.

In the third scene, as Goliath walks even closer to David, David runs towards Goliath. David grabs a stone out of David's bag and puts the stone into David's sling. David swings the sling over David's head and throws the rock at Goliath. The rock hits Goliath right in the forehead and sinks in. Goliath stumbles and falls facedown on the ground. So David defeats the Philistine warrior Goliath with only a sling and a stone. David does not have a sword when David strikes and kills the Philistine Goliath. The storyteller repeats this information to show that what David said would happen comes true. David runs over and pulls Goliath's sword out of its sheath. David uses Goliath's sword to kill Goliath by cutting off Goliath's head.

Stop here and discuss as a group: In this scene, David throws the rock and hits Goliath, and Goliath falls down. Then the storyteller summarizes what David did by saying that David defeated Goliath with only a sling and a stone. After the storyteller summarizes what happened, the action continues, and David kills Goliath. Tell a story where people do a lot of things, then the storyteller gives a brief summary of what happened, and then the action continues. Pause this audio here.

In the fourth scene, when the Philistine army sees that Goliath is dead, the Philistines turn away from Goliath and run. The Israelite army, which is made up of men from Israel and Judah, shouts a battle cry and quickly runs after the Philistine army. The Israelites chase the Philistines all the way down the Shaaraim road that also led towards the cities of Gath and Ekron. Bodies of dead and wounded Philistine soldiers lay along the entire road. When the Israelite army finishes chasing the Philistines, the Israelite army goes back to their camp and plunders the Philistine army camp. The Israelites take anything that is valuable. David eventually takes Goliath's head to Jerusalem, but David keeps Goliath's weapons in David's own tent.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:41–54 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has four scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The Philistine Goliath

  • Goliath's shield-bearer

  • David

  • The Philistine army

  • And the Israelite army

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Goliath walked towards David. Goliath walked behind a man who carried a shield that was big enough to protect almost all of Goliath's body. Goliath's forehead was the only part of his body that was not covered by the shield or armor. As Goliath walked, Goliath looked at David and saw that David was young, healthy-looking, and handsome. Goliath also saw that David carried only a staff and a sling. Goliath hated David and asked him, "Do you think I am no more than a dog that you can chase away with a stick?" Then Goliath called out to his gods and asked the gods to harm David. Goliath yelled to David, "Come closer, so I can kill you and leave your body for the birds and wild animals to eat!"

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Goliath, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am insulted that the Israelite army would send a young boy with only a stick and a sling to fight someone as important and powerful as me! or

  • This battle should be easy because this youth cannot possibly defeat me.

David responded to Goliath by shouting, "You come to fight me with a sword, spear, and javelin, but I come to you depending on Yahweh Almighty, the God of the armies of Israel. You have defied Yahweh, but today Yahweh will give me the strength to defeat you. I will kill you and cut off your head! And today we will kill all the Philistine soldiers and leave their bodies for the birds and wild animals to eat! Then people everywhere will know that Israel has a God who really does things for his people. Everyone here will know that Yahweh does not rescue his people with a sword or a spear because Yahweh decides who wins every battle. Yahweh will give us victory over you!"

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person may answer things like:

  • I have no doubt that Yahweh will defeat Goliath and the Philistines! or

  • I am offended by Goliath because he challenged Yahweh. I am excited to see Yahweh defeat this army of Philistines, who do not respect Yahweh.

Goliath comes closer and closer to David, and David runs to meet Goliath at the battle line. David quickly grabs a stone out of David's bag and places it in his sling. David slings the stone directly at Goliath and strikes Goliath in the forehead. The stone sinks deeply into Goliath's head, and Goliath stumbles and falls on his face on the ground. So with a sling and a stone, David defeated Goliath. David did not have a sword when he defeated Goliath. David ran to Goliath and grabbed Goliath's sword out of its sheath as David stood over Goliath. David used Goliath's sword to kill Goliath by cutting off Goliath's head, just as David had promised he would do.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Goliath's shield-bearer, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am very surprised that this young boy has killed Goliath! or

  • I am terrified that this young boy will now kill the rest of us just as he said he would!

When the Philistine army realizes that their champion is dead, the Philistines all turn and run away from the Israelite army. The Israelite army, men from Israel and Judah, shout their battle cry and chase the Philistine army. The Israelites chase the Philistines along the road that goes from Shaaraim all the way to Gath and Ekron. The Israelites kill the Philistines as they run, so the bodies of dead and dying Philistine soldiers lie all along the road. When the Israelites finish chasing the Philistines, the Israelites return to the Philistine camp to plunder it. David takes Goliath's head to Jerusalem, and David keeps Goliath's weapons in David's tent.

Pause the drama.

Ask the people playing the Philistine soldiers, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The people might answer things like:

  • We are terrified of the Israelites and their God! or

  • We do not care about the promise we made to serve the Israelites if they defeated our champion. We are going to run away as fast as we can so we might live!

Ask the people playing the Israelite soldiers, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The people might answer things like:

  • We are so happy that Yahweh defeated Goliath! We celebrate Yahweh's power and our victory! or

  • We are determined to kill the Philistines who disrespected and made fun of us and our God; or

  • We are shocked that God used a shepherd boy to defeat Goliath instead of having King Saul defeat the Philistine!

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:41–54 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Goliath walked behind Goliath's shield-bearer. A person who was a shield-bearer carried a large shield in front of another soldier.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a man carrying a shield. Translate this word in the same way you have in previous passages. Pause this audio here.

Goliath walked towards David. David was Jesse's youngest son, and David kept his father's sheep in Bethlehem. David also served King Saul. For more information on David, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for David as you used in previous passages.

Goliath looked at David and saw that David was ruddy and handsome. To be ruddy means that someone is healthy and has rosy or reddish cheeks. Use the same word or phrase for ruddy or healthy as you used in previous passages.

Goliath accused David of coming towards Goliath as if David were trying to scare a dog away. A dog is a four-legged animal that people in Israel considered unclean. It was a common insult to call someone a dog.

Stop here and look at a picture of a dog as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for dog. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The Philistine cursed David by the Philistine's gods. Use the same word or phrase for gods as you used in previous passages. See the Master Glossary for more information.

To curse someone is to wish that something bad would happen to that person.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for curse. Look up curse in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

David said Goliath came against David with a sword, spear, and javelin or scimitar. These were all weapons people used in war. Remember from the last passage that Goliath also wore heavy armor that covered almost all of Goliath's body, and a man walked in front of Goliath carrying a large shield. David had no armor, and David did not carry any weapons. Use the same words or phrases for sword, spear, and javelin or scimitar as you used in previous passages.

Stop here and look at a picture of a sword, a spear, and a javelin or scimitar as a group. Pause this audio here.

David came against Goliath in the power of Yahweh Almighty, or Yahweh of hosts. Yahweh of hosts is the God of Israel. Yahweh is God's personal name that shows the close relationship that God had with Israel. To describe Yahweh as "almighty" or "Yahweh of hosts" means that Yahweh is in charge of all of the armies, or hosts, of Israel. This name reminds us that Yahweh has power over all things in the universe. For more information on Yahweh, Yahweh of hosts, God, and Israel, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same words or phrases for these ideas as you used in previous passages.

David knew that Yahweh would defeat Goliath. David ran towards Goliath, put a stone in David's sling, and slung the stone into Goliath's forehead. A sling is a weapon people make by connecting leather straps to a pouch. Use the same word for sling as you used in previous passages.

Stop here and look at a picture of a sling as a group. Pause this audio here.

David knocked Goliath down with a sling and a stone. Then David ran to Goliath, took Goliath's sword out of its sheath, and used the sword to kill Goliath. A sheath is a cover for a knife or sword. People had probably made Goliath's sheath out of leather.

Stop here and look at a picture of a sheath as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for sheath. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

David used Goliath's sword to kill Goliath, and then the Israelite soldiers chased the Philistine soldiers. The Israelites shouted their battle cry as they chased the Philistines. A battle cry is a word or noise that an army shouts as they begin a battle. Use the same word or phrase for "battle cry" as you used in previous passages.

When the Israelite soldiers finished chasing and killing the Philistine soldiers, the Israelites returned to plunder the Philistine camp. To plunder means to steal goods. Use the same word or phrase for plunder as you used in previous passages.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
