title: 1 Samuel 17:55–18:5
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 17:55–18:5 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:55–18:5 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:55–18:5 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous passage, David fought against Goliath the Philistine. Yahweh gave David victory over Goliath, and the Israelite soldiers chased and killed the Philistine soldiers and plundered their camp.

As this passage begins, we learn about something else that happened in the last story while David was walking toward Goliath. This event has already happened, but the storyteller is giving us more information about what else happened at the same time. As David went out to meet Goliath, King Saul watched. Saul asked Abner, the commander of Saul's army, who David's father was. Saul knew who David was because David served King Saul, but Saul may not have known much about David's family or background. Saul wanted to know more about David's family and the family's reputation in Israel. Saul may have wanted to know who David's father was so Saul could have David serve Saul permanently. You will remember that David had been going back and forth between Bethlehem, where David cared for his father's sheep, and the army camp, where David served King Saul.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Talk about what happens when you introduce new people to each other, especially someone you want to work with. In your culture, what kind of information is important to know about each other? What kind of information do you want to know about someone's family or ancestors? Pause this audio here.

Abner, however, did not know anything about David's family or status within Israel. Abner told the king, "As surely as you live, O king, I do not know." With this phrase, Abner wanted King Saul to know that Abner was telling the truth about Abner's lack of knowledge about David. Saul told Abner to go and learn more about David's family.

As soon as David finished killing Goliath by cutting off Goliath's head, Abner brought David to Saul. Abner brought David so quickly that David still held Goliath's head in David's hand. Saul asked David who David's father was, and David replied that David was the son of Saul's servant Jesse from Bethlehem.

David and Saul finished talking. Afterwards, the soul of Jonathan became bound to the soul of David, and Jonathan loved David as much as Jonathan loved himself. Jonathan was King Saul's oldest son. For one soul to be bound to another means that these men had great affection for one another and were best friends. From that day forward, King Saul had David stay with Saul to live at Saul's court so David could serve Saul. Saul did not send David back to David's father's house.

Jonathan made a covenant with David because Jonathan loved David deeply. When people make a covenant, they make a solemn promise to one another that they cannot break. The people say they want to have a good relationship with each other. Jonathan and David promised to always be loyal friends to one another.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about two people who have a relationship as close as David and Jonathan. How do people show promises of friendship and love in your culture? Pause this audio here.

To show Jonathan's friendship, Jonathan took off his robe or tunic and gave it to David. Jonathan's robe or tunic was an outer garment that would have covered Jonathan's other clothing. Jonathan also gave his own armor to David, along with Jonathan's sword, bow, and belt. People wore armor to protect themselves in battle. People used swords and bows as weapons in battle. Jonathan's belt may have been where Jonathan held his dagger, or a short sword. By giving David his robe, armor, and weapons, Jonathan showed his covenant friendship with David. Jonathan also showed how unselfish Jonathan was. We do not know if Jonathan already knew that David would be the next king, but we see that Jonathan did not feel threatened by David like Saul did.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a robe, armor, sword, bow, and belt. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: In your culture, how might someone show that they are very close friends with someone else? Pause this audio here.

Whatever military tasks Saul commanded David to do, David did them well. Therefore, Saul made David a high-ranking officer in Saul's army. David was probably in charge of a large group of soldiers. All the soldiers and officers in Saul's army were happy about this.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:55–18:5 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has three scenes.

In the first scene: Earlier, when David was walking towards Goliath to fight against Goliath, King Saul watched. Saul asked his army commander, Abner, who David's father was. Abner did not know, so Saul asked Abner to find out. As soon as David killed Goliath, Abner brought David to Saul, and David told Saul that David's father was Jesse from Bethlehem.

In the second scene: After David and Saul finished talking, David and Jonathan became best friends. Jonathan was King Saul's oldest son. King Saul had David stay and serve Saul at Saul's court. Jonathan and David made a covenant to always be loyal friends, and as a sign of friendship, Jonathan gave David Jonathan's robe, armor, sword, bow, and belt.

In the third scene: Whatever King Saul asked David to do, David did it well. So, Saul made David a high-ranking officer in Saul's army. All the soldiers and officers in Saul's army approved of David's position.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • King Saul

  • Abner

  • Jonathan

  • And soldiers and officers in Saul's army

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In scene one, the storyteller helps us understand something that already happened in our last story. While David walked towards the Philistine Goliath, King Saul watched. Saul turned to his army commander, Abner, and asked, "Who is the father of that young man?" Abner responded to the king, "As surely as you live, my king, I do not know." Abner used an expression in which Abner swore on the king's life. This expression was part of an oath or a promise that Abner used to make sure Saul knew Abner was telling the truth. By swearing on the king's life, Abner was saying that the king could kill Abner if Abner was not telling the truth.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What phrases or expressions do you use in your culture to make sure people know you are telling the truth? Pause this audio here.

Saul told Abner to find out who David's father was. As soon as David finished killing Goliath by cutting off Goliath's head, Abner brought David to King Saul. David had not even set down Goliath's head. David was still holding Goliath's head in David's hand. Saul asked David who his father was, and David replied that his father was Saul's servant Jesse from Bethlehem. By calling Jesse "Saul's servant," David did not mean that his father served King Saul. David meant that Jesse was loyal to Saul as Israel's king.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story where the action goes from something that is happening right now to something that has already happened. How do you help your audience understand when the action is happening? Pause this audio here.

In scene two, David and King Saul finished talking. Afterwards, David and Saul's oldest son, Jonathan, became best friends. Jonathan's soul was bound to David's soul, and Jonathan loved David as much as Jonathan loved himself. God created humans with souls, which are a person's thoughts, feelings, and desires. We cannot see a person's soul, but we know it is there. In the original language, the word used for "bound" means to bind or to tie something to something else. David's soul was bound to or tied to Jonathan's soul, and Jonathan and David cared deeply for one another. From that day on, King Saul had David live at Saul's court so David could serve Saul. Saul did not send David back to David's father in Bethlehem. Because Jonathan loved David so much, Jonathan and David made a covenant together. Jonathan and David promised to always be loyal friends to each other. To show Jonathan's friendship, Jonathan took off his robe and gave it to David. Jonathan also gave David Jonathan's armor, sword, bow, and belt. By giving David all these things, Jonathan showed that Jonathan deeply respected and loved David. Jonathan also showed his unselfish covenant friendship with David.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Remember the story you told about two friends in the previous script. Pay attention to the words you use to describe this kind of friendship and loyalty. Discuss how you might translate this. Pause this audio here.

In scene three, whatever military tasks Saul gave to David, David did well. So, Saul promoted David to be a high-ranking officer in Saul's army. All of the soldiers and other officers in Saul's army were happy about David's position.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about a leader that everyone likes. How do you describe that leader? Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:55–18:5 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has three scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • King Saul

  • Abner

  • Jonathan

  • And soldiers and officers in Saul's army

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Even though the action has moved forward from the last story, the author helps us to understand something that has already happened. Earlier, while David walked towards the Philistine Goliath, King Saul watched David. Saul asked his army commander, Abner, "Whose son is that young man?" Abner replied, "I swear, my king, I do not know." Saul ordered Abner to find out who David's father was. As soon as David had killed Goliath by cutting off Goliath's head, Abner brought David to King Saul. David had not even had a chance to set down Goliath's head, and still held the head in David's hand. Saul asked David about David's father, and David told Saul, "My father is your servant Jesse from Bethlehem."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing King Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am impressed with this young man and want to know more about him; or

  • I see that God uses David, and I want David's help to fight other battles.

Ask the person playing Abner, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I see that this young man has impressed the king, and I want to please the king by getting the king what he wants; or

  • I am curious about this young man's family, too, because this young man serves in my army.

David and Saul finished talking. Later, David and Saul's son, Jonathan, became best friends. David and Jonathan's souls were bound together, and they loved each other very much. Jonathan loved David as much as Jonathan loved himself. From that time on, King Saul kept David in Saul's court so David could serve Saul. Saul did not send David back to David's father's home in Bethlehem. Because Jonathan loved David so much, Jonathan and David made a covenant together. Jonathan and David promised to always be faithful and loyal friends. As a sign of Jonathan's friendship, Jonathan took off his robe and gave it to David. Jonathan also gave David Jonathan's armor, sword, bow, and belt. By doing this, Jonathan showed his deep respect and love for David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Jonathan, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am grateful to be David's close friend and want David to know that; or

  • David is more famous than I am because of what David did to Goliath, but I do not feel threatened by David. I trust God and support David.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I love Jonathan and am so grateful for Jonathan's friendship; or

  • I am humbled that my friend supports me and gave me his armor and weapons.

Whatever tasks King Saul gave David to do, David did them successfully. Because David did everything so well, Saul promoted David to be a high-ranking officer in Saul's army. All the other soldiers and officers in Saul's army were happy about David's position.

Pause the drama.

Ask the people playing the soldiers and officers in Saul's army, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The people might answer things like:

  • We approve of David because we see that David trusts God; or

  • We know David is a good leader and are happy to follow David.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 17:55–18:5 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

As Saul watches David walk towards Goliath, Saul asks Abner, his army commander, about David's father. The commander of an army leads a large group of soldiers into battles. Use the same word or phrase for commander as you used in previous passages.

Saul asks Abner whose son David is. A son is the male child of his parents. Use the same word or phrase for son as you used in previous passages. For more information on son, refer to the Master Glossary.

David tells Saul that David's father is Jesse, Saul's servant. A servant is a man or woman who works for another person. A servant may live in the same house as his master. Jesse did not live in King Saul's house, but Jesse was loyal to Saul as a king. Use the same word for servant as you used in previous passages. For more information on servant, refer to the Master Glossary.

Saul wants to know more about David. David was the youngest son of a man named Jesse. David took care of his father's sheep, but later, David became a commander in King Saul's army. For more information on David, refer to the Master Glossary.

Some time after Saul and David finished talking, Saul's son Jonathan and David became best friends. Jonathan and David's souls were bound together. God created people with thoughts, feelings, and desires. We cannot see this part of a person, but we know it is there. In the Bible, people usually call this invisible part of a person a soul.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for soul. Look up soul in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

From this time forward, Saul kept David at Saul's court and did not send David to David's father's home in Bethlehem. Jonathan made a covenant with David because Jonathan loved David as much as Jonathan loved himself. A covenant is a solemn promise people make to each other that they cannot break. When people make a covenant together, they say they want to have a good relationship with each other. Use the same word or phrase for covenant as you used in previous passages. For more information on covenant, refer to the Master Glossary.

As a sign of their deep friendship, Jonathan gave David Jonathan's robe, armor, sword, bow, and belt. A robe was an outer garment that people wore over other clothing. Armor was a metal covering people wore to protect themselves in battle. A sword had a long, pointed metal end that people used as a weapon in battle. People made bows out of a curved piece of wood held tight by a string. People used bows to shoot arrows. Jonathan's belt probably tied his robe over Jonathan's armor and may have held a dagger or a short sword. Use the same words or phrases for robe, armor, sword, bow, and belt as you used in previous passages and see the Master Glossary for more information about robe, if needed.

Stop here and look at a picture of a man wearing a robe, armor, and a belt. Look at a picture of a sword and a bow. Pause this audio here.

Whatever Saul gave David to do, David did it well. Saul promoted David to a high rank or position of authority within Saul's army, and all of Saul's soldiers and officers were pleased.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 18:6–16
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 18:6–16 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 18:6–16 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 18:6–16 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous passage, Saul asked David who David's father was. Later, David and Saul's son Jonathan became best friends and swore a covenant with one another. Saul promoted David to be a high-ranking official in Saul's army, and all the other soldiers and officers approved.

This passage begins with another look back at something that already happened. This is what happened after David had killed the Philistine Goliath. David and the other soldiers, including King Saul, were returning home. When the men passed through each town in Israel, women came out to greet King Saul. The women wanted to honor King Saul for his victory over the Philistines. The women celebrated with joyful songs and danced. The women played music on their tambourines and stringed instruments. People often used a tambourine, which is a small, round drum, in celebrations. We are not sure what kind of stringed instrument this was, but it was probably a lute or sistrum. It may have been an instrument with three strings or an instrument like a triangle with three sides that would make a jingling sound when someone shook it.

Stop here and look at a picture of a tambourine and a picture of a lute or sistrum. Pause this audio here.

The women celebrated Saul's victory and sang a song which said, "Saul has killed thousands of the enemy, and David has killed tens of thousands of them." This does not mean that Saul and David killed this exact number of people. The women wanted to celebrate that their leaders had been victorious over a great number of enemies. The women probably were not trying to say that David was better than King Saul because David had killed more men. The women were celebrating the victory of both men.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do people in your culture celebrate a military victory? Pause this audio here.

King Saul did not like the words of the song the women sang, so Saul became very angry. Saul thought, "The people say that David has killed tens of thousands of the enemy, and I have killed only thousands. If the people keep honoring David this way, soon the people will want to make David king instead of me!" So from that time on, Saul watched David suspiciously because Saul was jealous of David.

The next day, an evil spirit from God came forcefully on Saul. We do not know if God himself sent the evil spirit or allowed the evil spirit to control Saul, but we know that the spirit of God had left Saul. The evil spirit overwhelmed, harmed, and distressed Saul. Saul was acting wildly, or was not in Saul's right mind. Saul did not act like Saul was in control of his behavior or speech. As Saul acted wildly, David played the lyre. A lyre is a musical instrument with strings like a harp. We know from a previous passage that David regularly played the lyre to comfort King Saul when Saul was upset.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story where someone acts like they are not in control of their behavior. How does the person look and act? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of a lyre as a group. Pause this audio here.

Saul had Saul's spear in Saul's hand. This spear was probably a special spear that was a sign of Saul's authority as king. Suddenly, Saul threw Saul's spear at David. Saul thought Saul would kill David by pinning David to the wall with Saul's spear. To pin someone to a wall means to throw a spear so hard that the spear goes through the person and sticks into the wall, so the person cannot move. Saul tried this twice, but each time David jumped away.

Stop here and look at a picture of a spear as a group. Pause this audio here.

Yahweh was with David, but Yahweh had left Saul. Therefore, Saul began to be afraid of David. So Saul sent David away from Saul and made David the commander over 1,000 soldiers. David led the soldiers into their battles and returned victoriously to his people. David was successful and won every battle because Yahweh was with David. When Saul saw how successful David was, Saul was even more afraid of David. But everyone else in Israel and Judah loved David because David led their soldiers into battle so well.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 18:6–16 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has three scenes.

In the first scene: When the Israelite army was returning home after David defeated Goliath, the Israelite women came out from every town to honor King Saul and rejoiced with singing, dancing, and musical instruments. The women's song said, "Saul has killed his thousands, and David has killed his tens of thousands." Saul did not like the words of this song, so Saul was angry. Saul thought the people might try to make David king instead of Saul, so Saul watched David suspiciously from then on.

In the second scene: The next day, God sent an evil spirit that came forcefully on Saul. Saul was acting wildly in Saul's house while David tried to comfort Saul by playing the lyre, as David often did. Saul tried twice to kill David by throwing his spear at David to pin David to the wall, but David jumped away both times.

In the third scene: Because Yahweh was with David but had left Saul, Saul was afraid of David. So Saul sent David away and made David a commander of 1,000 soldiers. David led the soldiers and won every battle because Yahweh was with David. When Saul saw all of David's success, Saul became even more afraid of David, but all of Israel and Judah loved David because he led the soldiers victoriously.

The characters in this passage are:

  • King Saul

  • David

  • The Israelite army

  • The Israelite women

  • The evil spirit from God

  • David's unit of 1,000 soldiers

  • And the people of Israel and Judah

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In scene one, we have a flashback to an earlier passage. When David had defeated Goliath and all the Israelite soldiers were returning to their homes, the women came out of every town the men passed through to greet King Saul. The women wanted to honor Saul for Saul's victory over the Philistines. When the women came out, the women celebrated with joyful songs and dancing and played tambourines and stringed instruments. The women sang a song that said, "Saul has killed thousands of enemies, but David has killed tens of thousands." People used phrases like these as a kind of special way to talk about how both men killed many enemies. The women probably did not want to compare David and Saul, but we can understand how Saul might have thought the women were saying David was more successful at killing enemies than Saul.

The women were happy that the Israelite army had defeated the Philistines and that their soldiers were returning home. The women celebrated both Saul's and David's victory. But King Saul did not like the words to the song, so Saul became very angry. "The people believe David has killed tens of thousands of enemies, and I have only killed thousands," Saul thought. "Soon the people will want David to be king instead of me!" From then on, Saul did not trust David and watched David closely.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story where someone says something good about someone else, but the other person thinks that the first person is saying something bad even though they use the same words. How can you explain how people can hear the same words but understand those words differently? Pause this audio here.

In scene two, the next day, an evil spirit came upon Saul forcefully. This means that the spirit overwhelmed Saul and distressed Saul greatly. Saul was raving, or acting wildly, in Saul's house. Saul's words and actions were so wild that Saul did not look or sound like Saul was in control of himself. David was with Saul and was playing the lyre. You will remember from an earlier passage that David often played the lyre to comfort King Saul when Saul was distressed.

Saul had his spear in his hand, and suddenly, Saul threw this spear at David. Saul wanted to kill David by pinning David to the wall, which means to throw a spear so hard that it goes through a person and sticks the person to the wall. Saul threw his spear at David two times, but each time David jumped away.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about someone who lost control of himself or behaved in a wild way. Act out your story and think about what words you use to describe that person's actions. Pause this audio here.

In scene three, Saul became afraid of David because Yahweh was with David, but Yahweh had left Saul. So, Saul sent David away and made David the commander of 1,000 soldiers. David led the soldiers in their battles. David won every battle because Yahweh was with David. When Saul saw all of David's victories, Saul was even more afraid of David. But all of Israel and Judah loved David because David went out and came in before the soldiers. This is a way to say that David led the soldiers victoriously.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story where someone is successful in everything that person does. What words do you use to describe someone who always seems to succeed? Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 18:6–16 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has three scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • King Saul

  • David

  • The Israelite army

  • The Israelite women

  • The evil spirit from God

  • David's unit of 1,000 soldiers

  • And the people of Israel and Judah

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

When David had killed Goliath, the Israelite soldiers were returning to their homes. When the soldiers passed through the towns in Israel, the women came out to honor King Saul. The women sang joyful songs, danced, and played musical instruments. The women sang a song that said, "Saul has killed thousands of enemies, and David has killed tens of thousands of enemies!" King Saul did not like the words to this song, so Saul became very angry. Saul thought to himself, "The people believe David has killed ten times the number of enemies that I have killed. Soon, the people will want David to be king instead of me!" So from then on, Saul watched David closely because Saul did not trust David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I deserve more honor than David because I am king and David is not! or

  • I had better be watching in case David or the people decide they do not want me to be king anymore. I cannot trust David.

Ask the people playing the Israelite women, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The people may answer things like:

  • We celebrate both Saul and David because they both led our soldiers to be victorious in the battle; or

  • We are impressed with David's bravery. We trust in Yahweh, and we notice that David is a good leader.

The next day, God sent an evil spirit to King Saul, and this spirit came on Saul forcefully. Saul was in Saul's house. Saul was acting wildly and did not seem to have control over his own thoughts or actions. David was with Saul, and David was playing the lyre to comfort Saul, as David often did. Saul had his spear in his hand, and suddenly, Saul threw the spear at David. Saul wanted to kill David by pinning David against the wall with Saul's spear. Saul threw his spear at David twice, but both times David jumped away and was safe.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the evil spirit from God, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I want Saul to be angry and afraid because God is no longer with Saul; or

  • I am determined to make Saul try to kill the next king Yahweh has chosen.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I do not understand why Saul is so angry with me when I have obeyed and served Saul well; or

  • I am afraid that the king of Israel will kill me; or

  • I am afraid, but I will trust Yahweh no matter what Saul does because I know Yahweh is with me.

Yahweh was with David, but Yahweh was not with Saul anymore, so Saul was afraid of David. Therefore, Saul sent David away and made David commander over 1,000 soldiers. David led the soldiers in their military campaigns and won every battle. David was victorious because Yahweh was with David. When Saul saw all of David's victories, Saul was even more afraid of David. But all the people of Israel and Judah loved David, because David faithfully led the soldiers into battle and won every time.

Pause the drama.

Ask the people playing David's 1,000 soldiers, "What are you feeling and thinking?" The people might answer things like:

  • We trust David with our lives because we can tell Yahweh is with David; or

  • We love David because David is with us and leads us well.

Ask the people playing the people of Israel and Judah, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The people might answer things like:

  • We are beginning to trust David more and more because David is a great leader; or

  • We believe David would make a good king.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 18:6–16 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

When the soldiers were returning home after David defeated Goliath, the women of Israel came out to greet King Saul. Use the same word for Israel that you have used in previous passages, and remember that Israel is in the Master Glossary.

The women sang with joy, danced, and played the tambourine and stringed instruments. A tambourine is a small, round drum that people often used in celebrations. Use the same word for tambourine as you used in previous passages.

Stop here and look at a picture of a tambourine as a group. Pause this audio here.

We are not sure exactly what the stringed instrument was, but it was probably a lute or sistrum. These had three strings or a triangle with three sides that made a jingling sound when people moved it.

Stop here and look at a picture of a lute or sistrum as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for these stringed instruments. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

The women of Israel sang a song about Saul and David and how those men had killed their enemies. Saul did not like the song, so Saul was angry. Saul believed the people might want to make David king instead of Saul. David was Jesse's son, and Samuel anointed David to be king after Saul. David became a commander in King Saul's army. Use the same word for David as you used in previous passages. For more information on David, refer to the Master Glossary.

Saul is afraid that David will become king or take over the kingdom. A king is someone who rules over a city or territory. A kingdom is the territory or people that a king rules. You may want to translate this so that people understand that Saul is afraid that the people will make David their king. Use the same words for king and kingdom as you used in previous passages. For more information on king and kingdom, refer to the Master Glossary.

The next day, an evil spirit from God overwhelmed Saul. Evil spirits are spirits that God created, but that chose to rebel against God. Because God created the spirit, God can still use the spirit to do what God wants. Evil spirits can take control of people and make those people act in strange ways. Use the same word or phrase for evil spirit as you used in previous passages. For more information on evil spirit, refer to the Master Glossary.

Saul was raving in Saul's house. To rave means to act wildly or ecstatically. Saul did not appear to be in control of Saul's thoughts or actions. Saul was speaking messages, but those messages were not coherent or true. The word the storyteller uses means "to prophesy," but this does not mean that Saul was speaking the words of God.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for rave. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

While Saul raved, David played the lyre as David often did to comfort King Saul. A lyre was a musical instrument like a harp with strings. Use the same word or phrase for lyre as you used in previous passages.

Stop here and look at a picture of a lyre as a group, if needed. Pause this audio here.

Saul held a spear in his hand that Saul used to try and pin David to the wall. A spear is a weapon with a pointed tip and a long shaft. Saul's spear may have been a symbol of his authority as king. Use the same word for spear as you used in previous passages.

Stop here and look at a picture of a spear as a group, if needed. Pause this audio here.

Saul was afraid of David because Yahweh was with David, but Yahweh was not with Saul anymore. Yahweh is the name God gives himself. This name reminds people of the close relationship God had with the people of Israel. Use the same word for Yahweh as you used in previous passages. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary.

Saul made David commander over 1,000 men. A commander was an officer in the army who led a group of soldiers. Use the same word for commander as you used in previous passages.

Because Yahweh was with David, David never lost a battle. When Saul saw David's success, Saul was even more afraid of David, but the people of Israel and Judah loved David because David led the soldiers well.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 18:17–30
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 18:17–30 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 18:17–30 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 18:17–30 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous passage, Saul was angry with David and watched David carefully because Saul was jealous. When an evil spirit came upon Saul, Saul tried to kill David. Saul feared David and sent David away to be a commander in the army. But all of Israel and Judah loved David because David led the soldiers well and won many battles.

One day, Saul says to David, "You know my older daughter Merab. I will give you permission to marry Merab if you will serve me by being brave and fighting Yahweh's battles." The people in Israel believed the battles they fought against other nations were Yahweh's wars against nations that did not worship Yahweh. You will remember from a previous passage that, before David fought against Goliath, Saul had promised to give Saul's daughter to be the wife of the man who defeated Goliath. But Saul has not yet kept that promise to David.

Saul is still jealous and afraid of David, so Saul is secretly thinking that the Philistines will kill David, and Saul will not have to do it himself. David answers Saul, "How am I worthy of such an honor? Who am I, and who is my father's clan?" A clan is a group of families from the same ancestor. David does not expect Saul to answer David's questions. David is telling Saul that it is a great honor to have a chance to marry Saul's daughter, but David is not from an important family. David does not believe he is worthy or important enough to marry Saul's daughter.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about a time in your culture where an important person treated an unimportant person in a surprising and honorable way. How did the unimportant person respond? How did other people in the community respond to what happened? Pause this audio here.

When the time comes for David to marry Merab, however, Saul allows another man to marry Merab. This man's name is Adriel, and Adriel is from the town of Meholah. We do not know exactly how much time passes between the time Saul tells David that David can marry Merab and the time when David and Merab are supposed to be married. We also do not know exactly why Saul chooses to allow Adriel to marry Merab instead of David. Saul may have thought the Philistines would kill David before the time when Saul had to allow David to marry Merab.

Stop here and discuss as a group: In your culture, what happens when someone changes their mind after they make a promise? Pause this audio here.

However, Saul's other daughter, Michal, had fallen in love with David. When someone tells Saul, Saul is happy to hear the news. Saul wants David to desire to marry Michal so much that David will be willing to fight the Philistines. In this way, Saul will use Michal as a snare, or a trap, to try to get David killed in battle with the Philistines.

Stop here and look at a picture of a snare as a group. Pause this audio here.

So Saul says to David a second time, "I will give you permission to marry my daughter, and you will become my son-in-law." A son-in-law is the husband of a father's daughter. Then Saul orders his servants to speak privately with David and say to David, "Listen, the king is very pleased with you, and all of us and the officials are loyal to you. So accept the king's offer, and marry the king's daughter."

Saul's servants obey Saul. We do not know if the servants speak directly to David or just speak so that David can hear what the servants say. When David hears the servants' words, David says, "How could I ever hope to get such an honor to marry the king's daughter? It seems impossible for someone who is poor and unknown like me." David knows that, to marry a woman, a man has to pay a bride price. A bride price is a sum of money that the groom has to pay the bride's father. David knows that the price to marry a king's daughter would be very high, and David cannot pay the king much money. David says he is not rich or famous enough to be a part of Saul's royal family.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about a time a man wanted to marry a woman. What did the man or woman have to do in order for the woman's family to allow the man to marry the woman? Pause this audio here.

Saul's servants tell Saul what David said. Saul understands that David wants to marry Michal, but David does not believe David will be able to pay the bride price. Saul commands Saul's servants to go back to David and to tell David that Saul does not want money for the bride price. Instead, Saul wants the foreskins of 100 Philistine men. Saul wants David to kill 100 Philistine soldiers and bring the soldiers' foreskins to Saul to prove that David killed the soldiers. When someone circumcised a man, that person removed the foreskin from the man's penis. The Israelite men were all circumcised, but the Philistine men were not. Saul knows this will be good proof that David has killed that many Philistines. Saul is actually plotting to have the Philistines kill David. Saul does not believe David can kill and circumcise that many Philistines.

Saul's servants tell David what Saul said, and David is happy that he can marry Saul's daughter, Michal. So David and David's men quickly go to fight the Philistines. Together, David and his men kill more Philistine soldiers than Saul had required. David may kill as many as 200 Philistines, or David may just kill more Philistines than necessary. David cuts off the Philistine men's foreskins and brings the foreskins to King Saul even sooner than Saul had asked. David shows the king that David brings the full number of foreskins that Saul required so that David can marry Saul's daughter. Then Saul allows David to marry Michal.

When Saul realizes that Yahweh is with David and that Saul's daughter Michal loves David, Saul grows even more afraid of David. Saul hates David and remains David's enemy for the rest of Saul's life.

The commanders of the Philistine army continue to lead the Philistines into battle against the Israelites. Whenever the Philistines do this, David defeats the Philistines more completely than any of Saul's other officers. Therefore, David becomes very well known. Everyone knows who David is and honors David.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about a young man in your culture who becomes famous because he did something good.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 18:17–30 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has five scenes.

In the first scene: Saul tells David that Saul will allow David to marry Saul's older daughter, Merab, if David will be brave and fight in all of Yahweh's battles. Saul secretly wants the Philistines to kill David. David tells Saul that David is not important or worthy enough to marry Saul's daughter. Saul eventually allows another man, Adriel, from the town of Meholah, to marry Merab.

In the second scene: Saul's other daughter, Michal, had already fallen in love with David. Saul is pleased and thinks that this time, Saul might be able to use Michal as a snare for David so that the Philistines might kill David. A second time, Saul tells David that Saul will allow David to marry one of Saul's daughters.

In the third scene: Saul tells his servants to go to David privately and say that Saul is pleased with David, that all the servants and officials are loyal to David, and that David should marry Saul's daughter. Saul's servants obey. When David hears what the servants say, David says he would feel honored to marry Saul's daughter, but David is poor and unimportant in Israel. David really means that David would be unable to pay the bride price to marry Saul's daughter.

In the fourth scene: Saul's servants report David's words back to Saul, and Saul says the only bride price Saul wants David to pay is 100 Philistine foreskins. Saul secretly hopes David will not be able to kill that many Philistines, and the Philistines will kill David. However, David kills more Philistines than Saul requested and brings Saul the full number of foreskins that Saul wanted. Saul allows David to marry Michal.

In the fifth scene: Saul realizes Yahweh is with David, and even Saul's daughter loves David. Saul feels even more fear and hatred towards David. Saul continues to feel this way for the rest of Saul's life. David continues to defeat the Philistines each time the Philistines attack, and David becomes famous and honored throughout Israel.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Saul

  • David

  • Merab

  • Adriel

  • Michal

  • Philistines

  • And Saul's servants

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In the first scene, one day, Saul comes to David and says, "You know my older daughter Merab. If you serve me as a courageous and faithful soldier and fight Yahweh's battles, I will allow you to marry her." However, Saul does not speak truthfully to David. Saul is thinking that if David fights in battles and if the Philistines kill David in those battles, Saul will not have to kill David himself. Saul does not want to raise a hand against David, which means that Saul does not want to harm David himself. David answers, "How am I worthy of such an honor? How could you think my family and clan are so important?" David answers Saul politely, but David does not believe that his family is worthy of the honor of marrying into the king's family. David's clan includes David's extended family, which is a group of families descended from the same ancestor.

Stop here and discuss as a group: In the previous step, you told a story about an important person and an unimportant person in your culture. What words do you use to describe someone who is important and someone who is unimportant? Pause this audio here.

Instead of giving Saul's daughter to David as David's wife, Saul had caused Saul's daughter to marry a man named Adriel, who was from the town of Meholah. We do not know why Saul changed his decision. However, we know Saul hated David, and Saul may have thought the Philistines would kill David before David could marry Merab.

In the second scene, Saul's other daughter, Michal, had fallen in love with David. To fall in love means that someone develops romantic feelings for someone else. Michal felt great affection for David. When someone tells Saul, Saul is pleased. Saul thinks to himself, "I will allow David to marry Michal. Maybe I can use Michal as a snare for David so the Philistines will kill David." Saul thinks that David might be so happy to marry Michal that David will be willing to fight the Philistines more, and the Philistines will kill David. Saul promises David for the second time that David can marry one of Saul's daughters.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story in which someone says he wants something good to happen, but this person really wants something bad to happen. What words communicate that the person's intention is not what the person says? Pause this audio here.

In the third scene, Saul tells his servants to go to David privately and say, "Listen, the king is pleased with you, and all of us and the officials are loyal to you. You should marry the king's daughter." The servants obey Saul and either speak to David or speak so that David can hear them. But David responds, "How could I ever receive the honor of marrying a king's daughter? It seems impossible that someone as poor and unimportant as I could receive such an honor." David knows that to marry a king's daughter will require a high bride price. David is concerned that David will be unable to pay the bride price.

In the fourth scene, Saul's servants report back to Saul what David said. Saul tells the servants to go back to David and tell David, "The king is not asking for money. The only bride price King Saul wants is the foreskins of 100 Philistines. This is how the king will have revenge on his enemies." The Israelites were circumcised, but the Philistines were not circumcised. Saul wants David to circumcise the dead Philistines and bring the foreskins to Saul to prove the Philistines are dead. But Saul actually has a secret plan. Saul hopes that David will not be successful and that the Philistines will kill David.

Saul's servants take the message to David, and David accepts the bride price because David is happy to marry Saul's daughter, Michal. So, earlier than the time Saul set for David to bring the bride price, David and David's men go and fight with the Philistines and kill more men than Saul had asked for. David brings the Philistines' foreskins to Saul and counts the foreskins out completely in front of Saul. So Saul agrees to let David marry his daughter, Michal.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about someone who completes a task that seems impossible, and that person does the task much better than anyone expected. Pause this audio here.

In the fifth scene, when Saul sees and knows that Yahweh is with David, and that even Saul's daughter Michal loves David, Saul fears David even more. As long as Saul lives, Saul hates David.

The Philistine commanders often lead the Philistines into battle against the Israelites. Each time they fight, David defeats the Philistines more completely than any of the other officers in the Israelite army. So David becomes famous, and everyone knows David's name.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 18:17–30 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has five scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Saul

  • David

  • Merab

  • Adriel

  • Michal

  • Philistines

  • And Saul's servants

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

One day, Saul said to David, "You know my older daughter Merab. If you will serve me by being a brave and faithful soldier and fight in all of Yahweh's battles, I will allow you to marry my daughter." Saul secretly thought that the Philistines would kill David, so Saul would not have to kill David. David responded politely, "How am I worthy of the honor of marrying the king's daughter? How could you consider my family and my clan to be so important in Israel that you would invite me to marry the daughter of the king?" But when the time came for David to marry Merab, Saul did not keep his promise. Instead, Saul allowed a man named Adriel from Meholah to marry Merab.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking? The person might answer things like:

  • I feel honored that King Saul wants me to marry Saul's daughter, but I feel so unworthy; or

  • I am suspicious that King Saul might have plans that Saul is not telling me; or

  • Sometimes I feel unworthy to marry a king's daughter. Other times, I feel upset that King Saul promised to let me marry Saul's daughter, but then allowed someone else to marry her.

Ask the person playing Merab, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel happy that I could marry a man as famous and great as David; or

  • I feel confused that my father allowed another man to marry me and did not keep his promise to David.

However, Saul's other daughter, Michal, had fallen in love with David. When someone tells Saul, Saul is pleased and thinks to himself, "I will allow David to marry Michal. I hope I can use Michal as a snare for David, and the Philistines will kill David." A second time, Saul tells David that David can marry one of Saul's daughters.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am glad that I have another chance to get the Philistines to kill David; or

  • I want David to believe I am pleased with him, but I really want David to die because I am afraid of David and how much the people love David."

Saul tells his servants to go to David privately and tell David, "Listen, the king is pleased with you, and all of us are loyal to you. You should marry the king's daughter." David responds and says, "How could I ever receive the honor of marrying the king's daughter? I am poor and unimportant in Israel. This seems impossible." Although David did not say it, David knew that he would probably be unable to pay the bride price to marry Saul's daughter.

Pause the drama.

Ask the people playing Saul's servants, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The people might answer things like:

  • We trust David and want to follow David; or

  • We want to obey Saul, but we also want David to marry Saul's daughter because we love David.

Saul's servants report back to Saul what David said. When the servants tell Saul that David does not believe David can pay the bride price to marry Saul's daughter, Saul tells the servants to return to David. The servants should tell David, "The king does not want money for the bride price. All the king wants are the foreskins of 100 Philistines, and you will be able to marry his daughter." When the servants tell David what Saul said, David is happy to agree to pay that price. David is happy to marry Saul's daughter Michal.

So, earlier than the time Saul set for David to pay the bride price, David and David's men quickly go to the Philistines and kill more men than King Saul had requested. David brings the full number of foreskins to Saul to prove that David has killed more men than Saul had asked. So Saul allows David to marry Michal.

Pause the drama.

Ask the people playing the Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The people might answer things like:

  • We keep fighting against David, but we keep losing the battles! or

  • We cannot believe that this one man has so much power to keep defeating us.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel joyful that I was able to give Saul what he wanted and to marry Michal; or

  • I celebrate that I defeated the Philistines and proved I am worthy to marry the king's daughter.

When Saul realized that Yahweh was with David and that even Saul's daughter Michal loved David, Saul was even more afraid of David. Saul hated David for the rest of Saul's life.

The Philistines continued to attack the Israelites in battle. Every time they did, David defeated the Philistines more completely than any of Saul's other officers, so David became very famous in Israel.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 18:17–30 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Saul tells David that Saul will allow David to marry Saul's older daughter, Merab, if David serves Saul bravely and fights Yahweh's battles. David was a commander in Saul's army, and Yahweh helped David to win many battles. Yahweh is God's personal name. This name showed the close relationship that God had with the people of Israel. Use the same words or phrases for David and Yahweh as you used in previous passages. For more information on David and Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary.

Saul offers to let David marry Saul's daughter. David says that David's family and clan are not important in Israel. A clan is a group of families descended from the same ancestor. Use the same words or phrases for clan and Israel as you used in previous passages. See the Master Glossary for more information about Israel.

David says he is not important enough to marry Saul's daughter and to become Saul's son-in-law. A son-in-law is the husband of a man's daughter.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for son-in-law. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word you have used there. Pause this audio here.

When the time comes for David to marry Merab, Saul allows another man to marry Merab. However, Saul's other daughter, Michal, had fallen in love with David. Saul is pleased and wants David to marry Michal. Saul hopes that Michal will be a snare for David so that David will fight the Philistines more, and that the Philistines will kill David. A snare is a trap that people use to catch animals. Saul wants David's marriage to Michal to trap David into fighting the Philistines.

Stop here and look at a picture of a snare as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for snare. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Saul sends Saul's servants to speak to David privately and to encourage David to marry Michal. A servant is a man or woman who works for another person. Use the same word or phrase for servant as you used in previous passages. For more information on servant, refer to the Master Glossary.

David says to the servants that David would be honored to marry the king's daughter, but David is poor and unknown in Israel. David does not believe David can pay the bride price to marry Michal. A bride price is a sum of money or goods that the man who wants to marry the bride gives to the bride's family.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for bride price. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Saul tells his servants to let David know that the only bride price Saul wants is 100 Philistine foreskins. The foreskin is the skin at the tip of a penis that someone removes to circumcise the man. The Israelite men were circumcised, but the Philistine men were not circumcised. Saul wanted David to show that David had killed the number of Philistine men that Saul requested by circumcising those men and bringing the foreskins to Saul.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for foreskin. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

David is happy to agree to do what Saul asks so that David can marry Michal. David and his men kill more Philistines than Saul requested and bring the full number of foreskins to Saul. Saul allows David to marry Michal.

When Saul realizes that Yahweh is with David and Michal loves David, Saul is even more afraid of David and remains David's enemy for the rest of Saul's life. The Philistines continue to attack the Israelites, but David defeats the Philistines more completely than any other of Saul's officers. So David becomes very famous in Israel. Everyone knows who David is.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
