title: 1 Samuel 19:1–10
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 19:1–10 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 19:1–10 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 19:1–10 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous passages, King Saul realized that his son-in-law, David, had become more famous and that the people of Israel respected David. At the beginning of this story, King Saul orders his son, Jonathan, and Saul's household servants to kill David. Some translations refer to King Saul's household as servants, but most people believe that the people King Saul spoke to were not servants who cooked or cleaned, but were instead Saul's close advisors and companions in the royal court. This was an important command because a king may punish people if those people do not obey the king's commands.

Stop here as a group and look at a map that includes Israel and the land of the Philistines. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Who in your culture has the most power to order people to do a task? What happens if a person refuses or fails to do the task? How does a leader punish a person if the person does not obey the leader's command? Pause this audio here.

It is likely that Jonathan found this order difficult because Jonathan was King Saul's son and heir, but Jonathan was also David's close friend. The storyteller says that Jonathan "delighted much in David" or "was greatly fond of David." Jonathan does not want to harm David, so Jonathan tells David that King Saul wants to kill David. Jonathan gives David directions on the same day that King Saul gives the command. Jonathan knows that Jonathan needs to warn David quickly.

Jonathan urges David to be "on guard" or to be aware, because King Saul could attack David at any time. Jonathan seems to be the only person who warns David of the plan.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Think of a time you helped a friend in a difficult situation. How did you help that friend get out of trouble? Has a friend ever given you help when you were in trouble? If so, share your experience with the group. Pause this audio here.

Jonathan tells David to go out into a field and hide. While this could be a field for planting and growing crops, it is more likely that this is an open field in the countryside where David can hide. The location is not as important as the reason. Jonathan tells David to hide because Jonathan will bring his father, King Saul, to the field to convince Saul not to kill David or have anyone else kill David. This may seem like an odd or risky decision. However, Jonathan might have done this so that David could trust that Jonathan was doing what Jonathan said he would do. Jonathan vowed to "speak well" of David. This means that Jonathan would help King Saul see why King Saul should not have his servants kill David. Jonathan also promised to tell David if Jonathan learned anything new about King Saul's plans or intentions.

Stop here and look at a photo of an open field in the countryside. Pause this audio here.

The next morning, David does what Jonathan told him to do. David hides and listens for Jonathan and King Saul. Jonathan and Saul come into the field, and Jonathan acts as a mediator, or someone who tries to bring peace and understanding between two or more people. Jonathan honors his father's role as king by addressing Saul as king first before speaking to Saul as Jonathan's father. Jonathan asks the king not to kill the king's servant, David. Jonathan calls David a servant because David honors the king by serving Saul. Jonathan gives King Saul reasons why Saul should not kill David when Jonathan says that David has not sinned against the king and that everything David has done has actually brought good things to King Saul. David is a strong fighter. David's fame also gives King Saul a good reputation as someone who is strong and powerful.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you show honor in your culture? How do a hero's actions make the leaders of your community look good or become famous? Pause this audio here.

Jonathan also reminds Saul that, as a king, Saul should avoid killing an innocent person. Saul agrees and makes a promise not to kill David. Again, Yahweh uses Jonathan to bring peace between King Saul and David.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Why do people make promises or vows in your culture? Think of a time you made an important promise and kept it. Share this story with the group. Pause this audio here.

After King Saul makes his oath not to kill David, Jonathan calls out for David to come to Jonathan. It is likely that some time passed between Saul's vow and Jonathan calling for David. It is also likely that Saul was not present when Jonathan and David spoke. Jonathan does not assume that David heard the conversation, even though David was in the same field as Jonathan and Saul. Instead, Jonathan tells David what happened during the conversation. Again, this shows David that David can trust Jonathan to keep Jonathan's promises and that Jonathan is a close friend and protector. Because of King Saul's vow, Jonathan brings David back to serve King Saul. David seems to trust King Saul enough to return to serve Saul.

After Jonathan speaks to David, people begin to go to war again, but we do not know how long after the conversation this happens. We find out who David, and likely the army, fights against when we learn that David defeats the Philistine army. The Philistine army flees, so it seems that the defeat is so great that the Philistines have no choice but to run away from the war. Once again, Israel and their enemies, the Philistines, recognize David's victory. It is likely that King Saul feels jealous of David, which may explain why King Saul becomes angry. David receives Yahweh's favor, and Yahweh's spirit rests on David. But an evil spirit from Yahweh comes and torments Saul.

Stop here and discuss as a group: When you are angry or proud, how do you act towards other people or situations? How have you seen other people act when they are angry or proud? Pause this audio here.

As the evil spirit comes to King Saul, David is near Saul playing a stringed instrument called a lyre. At the same time, King Saul is holding a weapon called a spear. King Saul forgets the vow that Saul made not to kill David, and King Saul either lunges with or throws the spear at David. However, because Yahweh is protecting David, David is able to see and know what King Saul is doing. David avoids the spear, and that night, David runs away again to escape King Saul.

Stop here and look at a photo of a spear. Also, look at a photo of a lyre.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 19:1–10 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has eight scenes.

In the first scene: King Saul speaks to his son, Jonathan, as well as Saul's close advisors and officials. King Saul orders the men to kill David.

In the second scene: Jonathan tells David that King Saul is trying to kill David. Jonathan tells David to hide in a secret place for protection from King Saul.

In the third scene: David hides in an open field and waits for Jonathan and King Saul to speak.

In the fourth scene: Jonathan meets with King Saul in the open field where David is hiding. Jonathan asks King Saul to spare David's life, and Jonathan reminds King Saul of all the good David has done. King Saul agrees with Jonathan and vows not to kill David.

In the fifth scene: Jonathan calls out for David and tells David about the conversation with King Saul.

In the sixth scene: Jonathan takes David back to serve King Saul.

In the seventh scene: David goes to war with the Philistines, conquers the Philistine army, and causes the Philistines to run away.

In the eighth scene: After David returns from war, David is back in the royal court and plays the lyre for King Saul. An evil spirit comes upon King Saul, and Saul lunges with or throws his spear at David to try to kill David. David escapes and does not return.

The characters in this passage are:

  • King Saul

  • Jonathan

  • David

  • King Saul's officials and advisors

  • The Philistine army

  • And the evil spirit from Yahweh

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

As the story begins, King Saul speaks to Jonathan and Saul's officials and advisors and orders them to kill David. It is likely that this conversation takes place in the place where King Saul rules. This means that King Saul may be seated on his throne with Jonathan and the officials and advisors standing or kneeling in front of the throne to show respect to King Saul. It is possible that Jonathan feels confused between obeying his father, King Saul, and saving the life of Jonathan's closest friend, David.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How would you feel if you were in charge of something and people praised someone else for the success? Pause this audio here.

Jonathan finds David in another place and tells David what King Saul is planning to do. Jonathan tells David to stay in a secret place and to hide near the field where Jonathan says he will talk to King Saul the next morning.

Jonathan tells David to be on his guard in the morning. Jonathan will speak to King Saul the morning after King Saul orders David's death, because Jonathan feels it is urgent to protect David.

As Jonathan speaks to King Saul in the open field, Jonathan reminds King Saul of all the good David has done for the people of Israel. It is possible that David hears and sees part of this conversation, since David is hiding in the same field. It is important to remember that David's good deeds have strengthened King Saul's reputation with other nations. In other words, when David is successful, it makes King Saul successful. Jonathan gives King Saul examples of how David has helped King Saul, including how David killed the Philistine Goliath. Jonathan tells King Saul that David "took his life in his own hands," or risked being killed, when David fought the Philistine. King Saul remembers these actions and seems to lose the desire to kill David. King Saul then makes an oath not to kill David and says, "As Yahweh lives, David will not be put to death." By saying "as Yahweh lives," King Saul makes a strong oath that King Saul must keep as long as Yahweh lives.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, what special words or phrases do you use to make a vow? How would you translate King Saul's vow? Pause this audio here.

When Jonathan shares with David that David is now safe, it is likely that David trusts Jonathan completely. That is probably why David agrees to go back to the royal court and be with King Saul.

The scene changes as David then goes to fight in a war. We do not know how long David had been back serving Saul before David left for war again. David successfully fights the Philistine army and returns more famous than before. David and the army fought so hard and so well that the Philistine army was frightened and ran away to save their lives.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, how would you translate the fact that David struck the Philistine army with such force that the army ran away? Pause this audio here.

Once again, King Saul is jealous to hear how famous David is and how successful David has been. Yahweh showed that Yahweh gave David "favor" or approval by giving David success in battle. King Saul seems to fear that Yahweh has taken Yahweh's approval from Saul and has given Yahweh's approval to David. An evil spirit from Yahweh comes and torments Saul. Yahweh has a bigger plan, and Yahweh knows that this must happen to Saul. King Saul then likely lunges with or throws his spear at David while David is playing the lyre in the royal court. Yahweh protects David, and David manages to move away quickly enough that Saul does not hurt David. The spear remains stuck in the wall. That night, David runs away. David may have thought that King Saul would not give up trying to kill David until Saul succeeded.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 19:1–10 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has eight scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • King Saul

  • Jonathan

  • David

  • King Saul's officials and advisors

  • The Philistine army

  • And the evil spirit from Yahweh

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

This is a story about how King Saul tried to kill David. King Saul was frustrated and angry because David was very successful fighting in the war, and people praised David for all David did. King Saul decided to kill David. King Saul ordered Jonathan and Saul's advisors and officials to find and kill David. Jonathan was King Saul's son and David's close friend.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing King Saul, "What are you thinking or feeling?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am angry that people are not honoring me! or

  • I am jealous of David's successes; or

  • How dare the people praise David more than me!

Jonathan found David and told David that King Saul wanted Jonathan and the king's officials and advisors to find David and kill David. Jonathan told David to be on guard in the morning and to find a secret place and hide. Jonathan told David to hide in an open field because Jonathan planned to take King Saul to the same field to tell King Saul why Saul should not kill David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you thinking or feeling?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am scared! or

  • Can I trust what Jonathan is saying? or

  • Why does Saul want to kill me?

The next morning, David secretly hid in the field and waited for Jonathan and King Saul to come to the field to talk.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you thinking or feeling?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am afraid that King Saul will see me; or

  • I feel lonely. I have no more friends; or

  • Will Jonathan be able to convince King Saul not to kill me?

When David was hiding in the morning, King Saul and Jonathan came to the field to talk. Jonathan shared all of the good things David did for King Saul and the people of Israel, and Jonathan reminded King Saul why Saul should not kill David. Jonathan also helped King Saul remember what King Saul had seen with his own eyes. King Saul remembered watching David kill Goliath, and King Saul remembered rejoicing at all David had done. King Saul listened to Jonathan and agreed that David should not be killed. King Saul made an oath not to kill David for as long as Yahweh lived.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing King Saul, "What are you thinking or feeling?" The person might answer things like:

  • David has been good to me; or

  • How could I forget those things that David did?

Ask the person playing Jonathan, "What are you thinking or feeling?" The person might answer things like:

  • I hope this works! or

  • What should I say to convince my father not to kill David?

After King Saul left, Jonathan called out for David, and Jonathan told David about the conversation with King Saul. David listened to what Jonathan said to King Saul about David's good deeds. Jonathan also told David that King Saul promised not to kill David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you thinking or feeling?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so relieved! or

  • I still have a friend! or

  • I am so grateful for Jonathan's help!

David trusted Jonathan, so David went with Jonathan back to the royal court and stayed with King Saul again.

After some time, David went to war to fight against the Philistine army. David did very well. David did so well that the Philistine army fled in order to save their lives. This made David even more famous, and people praised David for all David had done.

When David returned from war, David returned to the royal court and played the lyre for King Saul. God showed favor to David, and King Saul could see this. An evil spirit came upon King Saul, and King Saul forgot his vow not to kill David. King Saul likely lunged with or threw his spear at David and missed. David was able to escape from King Saul's attempt to kill David. David fled that night.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you thinking or feeling?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so jealous of David! or

  • I will feel better once I kill David!

Also, ask the person playing David, "What are you thinking or feeling?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am scared that Saul will kill me! or

  • I do not know who to trust!

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 19:1–10 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

At the beginning of this story, King Saul speaks to his son, Jonathan, and to Saul's servants or officials and advisors. Saul orders the men to kill David. King Saul was the first king of Israel. Saul had a son named Jonathan who was a soldier and a close friend of David. David was also married to King Saul's daughter. The king told the king's servants and Jonathan to kill David. In this passage, the servants are probably really officials and advisors who served in the royal court near the king and helped the king make decisions by providing information and advice. You may translate this either as the king's officials or the king's servants. For more information about the word servant, see the Master Glossary. If you choose to use the word for servant, use the same word you have used in previous passages for servant.

If you choose to use the words officials and advisors, stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use. If you have already translated these words or phrases in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Jonathan meets with David and tells David that King Saul wants to kill David. Jonathan tells David to find a secret place to hide from King Saul. Jonathan tells David to hide in a field, and Jonathan says that Jonathan will bring King Saul to the field so Jonathan can speak with King Saul. Remember, an open field is not the same as a field where people grow crops. This type of field usually has high grass or overgrown plants.

Stop here and look at a picture of an open field as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss the best word to use for an open field, and use this word in future passages. Pause this audio here.

The next morning, Jonathan talks to King Saul in the open field where David is hiding. Jonathan reminds King Saul of all the good things David has done. Jonathan helps King Saul remember how David killed the Philistine and how David saved Israel from the Philistines. Look up Israel in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there.

Jonathan asks King Saul not to kill David, and Jonathan helps King Saul remember the moments that King Saul saw with his own eyes. King Saul remembers and is happy about all the things David has done. King Saul swears an oath not to kill David for as long as Yahweh lives. An oath is a promise that a person makes to another person. When a person makes an oath, Yahweh expects that person to keep the oath. Jonathan speaks to David about what King Saul promised to do, and David returns to be with King Saul. Use the same words or phrases for Yahweh and oath as you used in previous passages. Look up oath and Yahweh in the Master Glossary for more information.

As people tell stories of David's victory, King Saul seems to become jealous and afraid of David's popularity and success. An evil spirit from Yahweh comes on King Saul, and Saul forgets the vow he made not to kill David.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Based on what you have learned about Yahweh, how will you translate this part of the story? Look up evil spirit in the Master Glossary for more information. Discuss how you will translate "evil spirit." You may say something like "spirit from Yahweh that torments Saul," or "evil spirit from Yahweh." Pause this audio here.

As David is playing a stringed instrument, likely a lyre, King Saul lunges with or throws a spear at David and tries to kill David. A lyre was a small instrument with strings that a person could play with their hands. A spear was a weapon a person could use in battle. A spear had a sharp blade that people attached to the end of a stick. A person could use a spear to kill someone near them, or a person could throw the spear in order to kill someone farther away. David moves quickly out of the way of the spear. That night, David runs away. Use the same words for lyre and spear as you have used before.

Stop here and look at a picture of a lyre as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of a spear as a group.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 19:11–24
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 19:11–24 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 19:11–24 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 19:11–24 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous passage, King Saul attempted to kill David with a spear, but David escaped. Then David ran away and returned to his home. King Saul now sends messengers to watch or spy on David and make sure that David does not escape, so that they can kill David the next morning. However, David's wife, who is King Saul's daughter, Michal, warns David that King Saul wants to kill David. Michal urges David to leave immediately and not to wait until the morning. Remember, Michal and Jonathan are both working against King Saul's plan and are helping David escape.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Why do you think that both Jonathan and Michal were willing to help save David, even though their father, King Saul, wanted to kill David? Pause this audio here.

Michal creates a plan to help David escape, and Michal lowers David from the window. It is possible that David's house was part of the city wall, and David may have been able to leave the city by climbing out the window. Michal also places a household idol in David's bed with goat hair on it to try to trick King Saul's men into thinking David is asleep. Although Michal has an idol, there is no indication that David himself worshipped idols. People often made household idols in different sizes, and it is likely that this idol was a larger idol in the home, because Michal thought the size would trick people into thinking it was David himself.

Stop here and look at examples of household gods or idols. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at goat hair. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, is it acceptable for a person to go against their parents' wishes in order to protect or defend their husband or wife? What happens to someone if that person lies to their parents? Pause this audio here.

When King Saul's messengers arrive at David's house, the messengers demand to see David. Michal tells the men that David is sick. King Saul's men tell King Saul that David is sick, and King Saul orders his men to go back to the house, get David, and carry David on David's bed back to Saul so that King Saul can kill David. David's bed likely has a wooden frame and a wool mattress with blankets and pillows. However, when the men try to bring David to King Saul, the men realize that Michal has lied and that David has escaped. King Saul asks Michal why Michal lied to King Saul. Michal lies to King Saul and says that David forced Michal to help or that David said David would kill Michal. It is likely that Michal lied to King Saul in order to save Michal's own life and to hide her involvement in helping David escape.

Stop here and look at a picture of a bed from ancient times. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Think of a time when you told a lie to avoid getting into trouble. Share the details and the reason you lied. Tell how you felt when you lied. Pause this audio here.

After David escapes, David goes to a place called Ramah to see the prophet Samuel. David tells Samuel everything that King Saul did to David. It is important to remember that Samuel knows David well and is the prophet who anointed David as the future king of Israel. Samuel takes David with Samuel to live in Naioth. King Saul receives information that David is in Naioth, and King Saul sends men to capture David. However, when King Saul's men find Samuel in Naioth, the men see Samuel with other prophets who are prophesying. King Saul's men begin to prophesy also! In this case, the men were probably in a trance-like state and receiving messages from God. The men were probably not able to harm David.

Stop here and look at a map of David's route from David's home to Ramah and then David's route from Ramah to Naioth with Samuel. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: David runs to Samuel because David trusts Samuel. Think of a person you trust the most. If you were in trouble, who would you ask for help? Share with the group about your trusted person and why you would ask for that person's help. Pause this audio here.

When King Saul hears that Saul's men are prophesying, King Saul sends more men to capture David. But when the second group of men finds Samuel in Naioth, the Spirit of God comes on these men, and these men also start to prophesy. The Spirit of God takes control of the men and causes the men not to find and harm David. King Saul then sends a third group of men to capture David, but these men also begin to prophesy when they find Samuel. It is likely that King Saul feels very frustrated at this point, and Saul decides to go to Naoith himself to find Samuel and David.

Stop here and look again at a map of the route that David took and that King Saul and his men took. Pause this audio here.

When King Saul arrives at the great well in Seku, King Saul demands to see Samuel and David. Someone tells King Saul that Samuel and David are in Naoith in Ramah. King Saul journeys to find Samuel and David, but the Spirit of God falls on King Saul in the middle of the journey. When King Saul arrives where Samuel is, King Saul begins to prophesy in front of Samuel like Saul's men did before. King Saul takes his clothes off and lies on the ground continuously during the day and night as Saul prophesies. The people around King Saul are surprised and ask if even King Saul is a prophet! In previous stories, King Saul prophesied to help show God's presence. But this time, it seems that King Saul is prophesying because the Spirit of God is protecting David and preventing King Saul from killing an innocent man.

Stop here and look at a photo of a well or cistern that people used to store water. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Think about the highest position in your culture. You may be thinking of a king, president, or leader. Picture that leader behaving like King Saul did when Saul prophesied. How would you react if you saw your leader behave like Saul?

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 19:11–24 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has 12 scenes.

In the first scene: King Saul sends messengers or spies to watch David and to make sure David does not leave David's home.

In the second scene: Michal tells David that King Saul is trying to kill David. Michal urges David to leave immediately. Michal helps to lower David out of the house's window, and David escapes. Michal then places a household idol in David's bed to trick King Saul's men into believing that David is ill.

In the third scene: King Saul sends messengers or spies to take David to King Saul. Michal then says to the messengers that David is ill.

In the fourth scene: Messengers likely report to King Saul that David is ill. King Saul sends messengers once again, and King Saul tells the messengers to bring David on his bed to King Saul so that King Saul can kill David.

In the fifth scene: The messengers enter David and Michal's house to take David, and the messengers realize that David is not there. The men find the household idol that Michal has used as a disguise for David. The men then report back to King Saul.

In the sixth scene: King Saul likely calls for Michal, because King Saul and Michal talk about where David has gone. King Saul asks Michal why Michal lied to Saul and why Michal let Saul's enemy, David, go. Michal responds with a lie and says that David forced Michal to let David go or that David said he would kill Michal.

In the seventh scene: David has escaped and decides to travel to Ramah to find Samuel. David finds Samuel and tells Samuel all that King Saul has done to David. Samuel takes David to stay with Samuel in Naioth.

In the eighth scene: King Saul finds out where David is hiding, and King Saul sends men to find David and bring David back. When the men find Samuel, the Spirit of Yahweh falls on the men, and the men begin to prophesy and are unable to harm David.

In the ninth scene: King Saul hears about the men and decides to send more men to find and bring David back. Again, the men see Samuel and immediately begin to prophesy. These men are also unable to harm David.

In the tenth scene: A third time, King Saul sends men to find David. These men also begin to prophesy as soon as the men see Samuel and the other prophets.

In the eleventh scene: After sending three groups of men, King Saul is likely frustrated and decides to go himself to find David. King Saul stops at the great well of Seku to ask where David and Samuel are, and people tell Saul that David and Samuel are in Naioth. As King Saul continues on his journey, the Spirit of Yahweh falls on King Saul, and King Saul begins to prophesy like the other men did!

In the twelfth scene: King Saul arrives at Naoith. King Saul continues to prophesy when Saul sees Samuel and the other prophets. King Saul strips off his clothing and lies naked through the day and night as Saul continues to prophesy. All of the people watching are amazed and ask if King Saul is also a prophet.

The characters in this passage are:

  • King Saul

  • David

  • Michal

  • Messengers or spies

  • Household idol

  • Samuel

  • Prophets

  • Spirit of Yahweh

  • Three separate groups of King Saul's men

  • People near the great well of Seku

  • And people who watch Samuel, King Saul, and the prophets

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

After King Saul tries to kill David with a spear, David runs home to David's wife, Michal. King Saul sends messengers to spy on David at David's house and to make sure David does not leave so that they can kill David in the morning.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What phrases do you use in your language for "spies" or people who secretly observe and report information back to a person in charge? Pause this audio here.

Michal warns David that Michal's father, King Saul, is going to kill David. Michal urges David to leave immediately, and Michal helps to lower David out the window so that David can escape in the night. Michal knows that King Saul will want proof that David is in the house, so Michal decides to put a household idol in David's bed. Michal covers the idol with clothes and goat hair to make the idol look like David. This idol is big enough that people could think the idol is a person when the idol is in a bed and blankets are on top of it.

Stop here and look at examples of household gods or idols. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at goat hair. Remember that a goat is a small animal like a sheep. Look at a photo of a goat. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What words or phrases will you use to describe the household idol that Michal used? Pause the audio here.

When King Saul sends messengers to get David, Michal tells the messengers that David is ill. The messengers must then go back to give King Saul the news that Michal said David was ill. King Saul then demands that the messengers bring David on David's bed so that King Saul can kill David. The messengers then go back to David's house. When the messengers realize that Michal has tricked them, the messengers report back to King Saul. King Saul calls Michal and asks Michal why she has lied to Saul and why Michal has let Saul's enemy, David, escape. Michal lies to King Saul and says that David forced Michal to let David go, or that David said David would kill Michal.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How will you talk about the lie that Michal tells King Saul in order to protect herself? Pause this audio here.

After David escapes, David decides to go to Ramah and finds Samuel because David trusts Samuel. David tells Samuel everything that King Saul has done, and Samuel takes David to live with Samuel in Naioth. We are not sure where Naioth is, but it is possibly a camp where prophets lived together close to Ramah.

Stop here and look at a map of David's route from David's home to Ramah and then David's route from Ramah to Naioth with Samuel. Pause this audio here.

When someone tells King Saul where David is hiding, King Saul sends men to bring David back. However, when the men see Samuel and the group of prophets with Samuel prophesying and playing music, the Spirit of God falls on or controls King Saul's men. The men begin to prophesy and are unable to harm David. These men probably do not prophesy in the same way as other prophets. The Spirit of God controls the men, and the men are almost in a trance. The Spirit of God prevents the men from harming David. When Saul finds out, Saul sends more men. Once again, the men see Samuel, the Spirit of God falls on the men, and the men begin to prophesy. A third time, King Saul finds out and sends more men to bring David back. Again, the Spirit of God falls on the men, and the men prophesy when they see Samuel.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How will you describe the "Spirit of God" and how the Spirit falls on, or controls, King Saul's men? Pause this audio here.

Finally, King Saul decides to go himself to bring David back. King Saul travels to Ramah and stops at the great well of Seku to ask the people where David is. King Saul likely stops at the well because many people would often travel to wells to get water for their homes and to speak to other people. Wells were good places for people to stop and get information. When the people tell King Saul that David is in Naoith, King Saul continues on to find David. While King Saul is traveling, the Spirit of God falls on Saul, and Saul begins to prophesy like the men before him as Saul continues to travel along the road to find Samuel.

Stop here and look at a map that shows the route King Saul's men and King Saul would have taken to get to Naioth. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a photo of a well or cistern used for storing water. Pause this audio here.

When King Saul arrives in Naoith, Saul sees Samuel with a group of prophets that Samuel is teaching and training, and Saul continues to prophesy like before. King Saul strips his royal clothes off and lies on the ground during the day and night, while Saul continues to prophesy. It is possible that the other prophets were also naked. In this case, each man may have taken off his outer clothes but still worn his inner tunic. The Spirit of God controls both King Saul and Saul's men by causing the men to be in a trance-like state and naked. The people who are watching are amazed, and the people ask if King Saul is also a prophet!

Stop here and discuss as a group: In your culture, how would you describe a king removing his clothing like King Saul did? Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 19:11–24 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has 12 scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • King Saul

  • David

  • Michal

  • Messengers or spies

  • Household idol

  • Samuel

  • Prophets

  • Spirit of Yahweh

  • Three separate groups of King Saul's men

  • People near the Great Well of Secu

  • And people who watch Samuel, King Saul, and the prophets

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

After King Saul tries to kill David with a spear, David escapes and runs home. King Saul sends messengers to David's house to spy on David and to make sure that David does not leave the house.

Pause the drama.

Ask the people playing the messengers or spies, "What are you thinking or feeling?" The person might answer things like:

  • I do not want to disappoint King Saul! or

  • We had better find David, or King Saul might kill us instead!

Michal, David's wife, warns David that King Saul is still trying to kill David. Michal urges David to leave the house immediately. Michal helps lower David from the window, and David escapes into the night. Meanwhile, Michal knows that she needs to make it look like David is asleep in the bed. So, Michal places a household god in the bed and covers it with clothing and goat hair to look like David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Michal, "What are you thinking or feeling?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so scared that my father is going to kill my husband! or

  • I know I should not lie, but I am protecting my husband.

King Saul sends messengers to get David and bring David to King Saul. Michal tells the men that David is ill and asleep in bed.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing King Saul, "What are you thinking or feeling?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am finally going to get David! or

  • Surely, my daughter, Michal, will understand and help me.

After the men tell King Saul, King Saul tells the men to go and get David on David's bed and bring David to King Saul so that Saul can kill David.

However, when the men go to see David, the men realize that Michal has lied and tricked the men into believing that David is ill.

Pause the drama.

Ask the people playing the messengers, "What are you thinking or feeling?" The person might answer things like:

  • Surely King Saul will be furious and kill us! or

  • We should blame Michal for lying to us so that we do not get into trouble!

When King Saul finds out, Saul calls his daughter, Michal, to come and see Saul. Saul asks Michal why she lied to Saul and why Michal let Saul's enemy, David, escape. Michal lies again and says that David forced Michal to let David go, otherwise David would kill Michal.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Michal, "What are you thinking or feeling?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am frightened for my life! or

  • How can I convince my father that I am not to blame?

After David escapes, David decides to go to Ramah to find Samuel. David trusts Samuel as a friend and as the person who anointed David as the future king. David finds Samuel and tells Samuel everything that King Saul has done. Samuel takes David to stay with Samuel in Naioth.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you thinking or feeling?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so tired and just need someone I can trust! or

  • I am so thankful that Samuel is here to help and protect me! or

  • I really miss my wife!

When King Saul finds out where David is hiding, King Saul sends men to find David in Naoith and to bring David back to King Saul. However, when the men arrive and see Samuel, the Spirit of Yahweh falls on the men, and the men begin to prophesy. The men are unable to harm David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you thinking or feeling?" The person might answer things like:

  • I did not expect this to happen! or

  • I am so grateful for how Yahweh is protecting David and all of us!

When King Saul hears what has happened to Saul's men, Saul sends another group of men to Naioth to get David. When the men arrive and see Samuel, the same thing happens again! The men begin to prophesy and are unable to harm David.

King Saul then sends another group of men to Naoith to get David. However, the same thing happens again! The men see Samuel, and the Spirit of Yahweh falls on them. The men are unable to harm David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Spirit of Yahweh, "What are you thinking or feeling?" The person might answer things like:

  • I will not let these men hurt David! or

  • Everyone will experience my spirit!

Finally, King Saul decides to go to Ramah and find David. King Saul stops at the great well of Seku and asks people if they know where David is. The people tell King Saul that David is in Naioth, and King Saul continues on Saul's journey. As King Saul is on his way to Naioth, the Spirit of Yahweh falls on King Saul, and King Saul begins to prophesy!

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing King Saul, "What are you thinking or feeling?" The person might answer things like:

  • Nothing will stop me from finding David! or

  • I am so frustrated that David keeps getting away from me!

As King Saul arrives in Naioth, King Saul sees Samuel and the prophets with Samuel. King Saul continues to prophesy, and King Saul strips his clothes off and lies on the ground during the day and night as Saul continues to prophesy. The people watching the prophets are amazed and ask if even King Saul is a prophet too!

Pause the drama.

Ask the people observing King Saul, "What are you thinking or feeling?" They might answer things like:

  • What is the king doing?! or

  • Should I be looking at King Saul when he is not clothed?

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 19:11–24 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

When David ran away from King Saul, David went home. King Saul sent messengers to make sure that David did not leave his home. These messengers are spies that Saul sent to watch and to report back to King Saul. Use the same word or phrase for king as you used in previous passages. For more information on king and David, refer to the Master Glossary.

Stop here and discuss what word you will use for messengers or spies. If you have used "spies" before, use the same word or phrase for spies as you used in previous passages. Pause this audio here.

Michal warned David that King Saul wanted to kill David, and Michal urged David to leave immediately. After Michal lowered David from the house window, Michal knew she needed to make it look like David was asleep in bed. Michal took a large household idol, also known as a teraphim, and placed it in the bed with clothing and goat hair to make it look like David. Use the same word or phrase for idol as you used in previous passages. For more information on idol, refer to the Master Glossary.

When King Saul sent men to bring David back, Michal told the men that David was ill. King Saul then demanded that the men carry David on his bed to King Saul so that King Saul could kill David. This means King Saul literally wanted the men to carry David on David's bed to Saul.

Stop here and discuss the word or phrase you will use for carry David on his bed. If you have already translated this phrase in another book of the Bible, use the same phrase that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

When King Saul realized David was gone, Saul called Michal, and King Saul asked Michal to explain why she let Saul's enemy, David, go. Use the same word for "enemy" as you have used in previous 1 Samuel passages.

David escapes and finds Samuel. When Saul sends men to find David, the men find Samuel with a group of prophets. Saul's men begin to prophesy, or give messages from God. In this case, the men were probably in a trance-like state. The men may have been dancing and shouting as they gave these messages. You may use the same words or phrases to describe these actions as you used in previous passages when Saul began to prophesy. If you use the words for prophesy or prophets, see the Master Glossary for more information on prophesy or prophets.

After King Saul sends men three different times, King Saul decides to go and find David. When King Saul finds Samuel, Saul begins to prophesy and strips his clothes off. King Saul and his men prophesied because the Spirit of God fell on them and controlled the men's actions. Use the same words for "Spirit of God" as you have used in previous passages. Even though God's Spirit is not called the Holy Spirit here, you may refer to God and to the Holy Spirit in the Master Glossary for more information about the Spirit of God.

Stop here and discuss how you will describe King Saul's act of stripping his clothes off as Saul is prophesying. How will you say that King Saul is naked in an appropriate way?

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
