title: 1 Samuel 20:1–17
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 20:1–17 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 20:1–17 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 20:1–17 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous story, Saul tried to kill David, but David's wife, Michal, helped David escape. David went to live with Samuel. When Saul sent messengers to Samuel to capture David, the men instead began to prophesy or speak a message from God before Samuel. Twice more, Saul sent messengers to Samuel, but these men also prophesied instead of capturing David. Finally, Saul himself went to Samuel, but God's Spirit made Saul prophesy as well.

In this story, David now runs away from where Samuel is in Naioth near the town of Ramah and goes to see Jonathan, Saul's son. We are not sure what Naioth is, but it may have been a small village where prophets lived inside or just outside the town of Ramah. The story also does not tell us where Jonathan is staying, but Jonathan is probably in Gibeah, the town where Saul was living before Saul went to look for David in Ramah.

Stop here as a group and find Ramah and Gibeah on the map of Israel. Pause this audio here.

David asks Jonathan what crime or wrong thing David did that Saul is now trying to kill David. But Jonathan does not believe what David says. Jonathan says that surely Saul is not trying to kill David. Jonathan tells David that David is not going to die. Jonathan says Saul does nothing without telling Jonathan, so if Saul wanted to kill David, Saul would have told Jonathan. Jonathan is so sure of this that again, Jonathan tells David it cannot be true.

David promises Jonathan that David is telling the truth. David says Saul knows how much Jonathan likes David, so Saul must have decided not to tell Jonathan so that Jonathan would not be upset. But David makes a strong oath, or promise, again that David is telling Jonathan the truth. David says that just as surely as Yahweh lives and Jonathan lives, David is in great danger.

This time, Jonathan says he will do whatever David wants Jonathan to do. So David gives Jonathan instructions. First, David reminds Jonathan that tomorrow is the New Moon festival. In Old Testament times, the people of Israel celebrated this festival at the beginning of each month, when the people could see the new moon rise in the sky. During this festival, the Israelites stopped their work, offered special sacrifices, and blew trumpets to celebrate. David knows David is supposed to come eat a meal with the king during this festival, but David asks Jonathan's permission not to come. Instead, David says he will go to a field outside of the town and hide until the evening of the day after tomorrow. At that time, the festival will be finished.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What special festivals or celebrations does your community celebrate? Who attends these festivals, and what are some traditions or things you always do during these celebrations? Pause this audio here.

David tells Jonathan what to say if Saul notices that David is not at the festival. We know that this thing David tells Jonathan to say is a lie, and Jonathan knows it too. Jonathan will say that David strongly asked Jonathan for permission to quickly travel to David's hometown of Bethlehem and then quickly travel back again. Jonathan will say this is because David wanted to attend the annual sacrifice for David's clan, or all of David's relatives. This was a special sacrifice that David's clan made together each year before Yahweh, so it would be important for David to be there. David says that if Saul says "Very well," or "Good," to Jonathan, this means that David will be safe from harm. But if Saul becomes very angry, then Jonathan will know that Saul wants to kill David.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when you were uncertain if a person was angry or not. What did you do or ask that person to find out if the person was angry? What did that person do or say that helped you to know if they were angry? Pause this audio here.

David now reminds Jonathan of the covenant that Jonathan made earlier with David before Yahweh. You will remember that a covenant is a solemn agreement. Jonathan made this covenant with David that Jonathan and David would always be loyal friends. So David now asks Jonathan to do David a favor as his friend. David says that if Jonathan thinks David is guilty of being disloyal to Saul, Jonathan must kill David himself. David does not want Jonathan to take David to Saul if Jonathan thinks David is guilty. David would rather that Jonathan kill David than for Saul to kill David. But Jonathan strongly says that Jonathan would never harm David. Then Jonathan asks David a question that Jonathan does not expect David to answer. Jonathan says, "If I really knew that my father wanted to kill you, would I not tell you?" By asking this question, Jonathan tells David that Jonathan would certainly warn David if he knew David was in danger.

David now asks Jonathan who will come to tell David if Saul does become angry when Jonathan speaks with Saul. Before Jonathan answers David's question directly, Jonathan tells David to come with Jonathan out into a field or an open piece of land outside the city. Although the passage does not say why Jonathan does this, Jonathan probably wants to make sure no one can hear what Jonathan and David say to each other. Then Jonathan answers David's question. First, Jonathan promises David with an oath before Yahweh that Jonathan will find out what Saul is thinking and planning about David. Jonathan says that if Saul has a friendly attitude toward David, Jonathan will tell David this. But if Jonathan discovers that Saul truly is planning to kill David, Jonathan says Yahweh must punish Jonathan severely if Jonathan does not tell David this and help David escape to safety.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when you made a very strong promise to someone else. What happens in your culture if someone breaks a strong promise to someone else? Pause this audio here.

Jonathan speaks a blessing over David and asks Yahweh to be good to David just as Yahweh has been with Jonathan's father, King Saul. Then Jonathan asks David to keep showing kindness toward Jonathan in the same way that Yahweh shows kindness. Jonathan asks David to do this for as long as Jonathan lives, so that Jonathan will not be killed. Jonathan would normally become the next king as Saul's heir, or the oldest son. So Jonathan is probably thinking that if David becomes the next king after Saul, people may think that Jonathan is a threat to David. Jonathan asks David to show this kindness not only to Jonathan himself, but also to Jonathan's whole family. Jonathan asks David to keep showing kindness to Jonathan's family even when Yahweh cuts off, or kills, every one of David's enemies from the face of the earth. This is special language that means Yahweh will completely destroy all of David's enemies so that there will be none left in the whole world.

Stop here and discuss as a group: In your culture, when a new person becomes a leader, what happens to the family or officials of the old leader? Pause this audio here.

So Jonathan makes a covenant, or solemn promise, with the house of David, or between David's descendants and Jonathan's descendants. Then Jonathan calls on Yahweh to bring punishment. However, the original language is not clear about who Jonathan wants Yahweh to punish. Jonathan may ask Yahweh to destroy David's enemies, or Jonathan may ask Yahweh to punish David's descendants if those descendants ever break this covenant with Jonathan's descendants.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Jonathan blesses David and promises to be loyal to David even though Jonathan's own father, Saul, wants to kill David. In your culture, when might it be okay to be loyal to someone even more than to your own family? Pause this audio here.

Finally, Jonathan asks David to repeat David's promise to Jonathan once more because of their strong friendship and Jonathan's love for David.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 20:1–17 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has four scenes.

In the first scene: David runs from Ramah to the place where Jonathan is staying. David asks Jonathan why Saul is trying to kill David. Jonathan says David must be mistaken about Saul, but David swears that what David says is true.

In the second scene: Jonathan promises to help David, and David gives Jonathan a lie to tell Saul. David says this lie will help Jonathan know if Saul wants to kill David or not. But David says that if Jonathan thinks David is guilty, Jonathan should kill David himself. Jonathan says he would never kill David, and that if Jonathan knew Saul wanted to harm David, Jonathan would surely tell David. So David asks how Jonathan will get this information about Saul back to David.

In the third scene: Jonathan takes David to a field outside the city. Here, Jonathan promises to carry out the plan to find out what Saul is thinking. If Saul is feeling peace toward David, Jonathan promises to tell David. But if Saul does want to kill David, Jonathan will not only tell David but also help David escape.

In the fourth scene: Jonathan asks that Yahweh be with David just as Yahweh has been with Saul. Jonathan also asks David to be kind to Jonathan so that Jonathan will not be killed. And Jonathan asks David's descendants to show kindness to Jonathan's descendants when Yahweh destroys all of David's enemies. Finally, Jonathan asks David to swear this again because of their friendship and Jonathan's love for David.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • Jonathan

  • Saul

  • Yahweh

  • David's clan, or all of the people David is related to

  • David's descendants

  • And Jonathan's descendants

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In the first scene, David flees, or runs away from, Naioth in Ramah to the place where Jonathan is staying. David comes to Jonathan and asks Jonathan three questions: "What have I done? What is my guilt? What have I done wrong to your father? Your father is trying to take my life!" All three of David's questions are different ways of asking the same thing. David is asking Jonathan what David did to make Saul so angry that Saul would try to kill David. However, David already knows that David has done nothing wrong to Saul, so David does not expect Jonathan to answer these questions. Instead, David uses these questions as a way to tell Jonathan in a strong way that David is not guilty.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, if someone accuses you of something that you know is not true, how do you strongly deny that you are guilty of that thing? Pause this audio here.

Jonathan says very strongly to David, "Surely not! You are not going to die!" Jonathan seems very confident that David is not in any danger. Jonathan explains why he thinks this when Jonathan says, "Listen, my father does not do anything without telling me, whether it is important or not." Jonathan means that Saul tells Jonathan even about small, unimportant things, so surely Saul would tell Jonathan if Saul was planning to kill David.

Then Jonathan asks David a question that Jonathan does not expect David to answer. Jonathan asks why Jonathan's father would hide or keep this secret from Jonathan. Jonathan asks this question as a way to say that if Jonathan does not know about Saul's plan, then that plan must not be true. Jonathan is so confident about this that Jonathan says again that this thing cannot be true.

We cannot be sure, but some people believe this story happened before the last story because of how David and Jonathan still have different ideas of what Saul is thinking and feeling.

David swears an oath again, or makes a strong promise, before Yahweh that what David says is true. We are not sure why the story says that David swore again, because the passage does not say clearly when David swore the first time. However, David's three questions to Jonathan at the beginning of the passage could be like a kind of oath.

David reminds Jonathan that Saul knows very well how much David has found favor in Jonathan's eyes. This is special language that means Jonathan likes David very much. David says that Saul knew Jonathan would be very grieved or upset if Jonathan knew Saul wanted to kill David, so Saul did not tell Jonathan. But David swears another oath that what David says is true. David says, "As sure as Yahweh lives and you live, there is only a step between me and death." This is special language that means David is in great and immediate danger.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when you were in great danger. Pay attention to the words you use to describe this danger. Then discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use where David says there is only "a step between me and death." Pause this audio here.

Jonathan asks David what David wants Jonathan to do, so David gives Jonathan instructions. David says that people will celebrate the festival of the new moon tomorrow night, and the king expects David to come eat a meal with the king. But David asks Jonathan's permission not to come. Instead, David will go and hide in a field, or an open place outside, until the third evening. You will remember that for the Israelites, each new day began at sunset, so when David says tomorrow, David means after the sun sets on the same day he talks with Jonathan. The New Moon festival sometimes lasted for two nights, because people could not yet see the new moon in the evening of the first day of the festival in certain months. So in the months when that happened, the phrase "until the third evening" would mean when the festival day is over.

David says that if Saul misses David, or notices that David is not at the meal, Jonathan must tell Saul that David asked Jonathan's permission to run to Bethlehem, David's hometown, because David wanted to attend the annual sacrifice there. Although the original language uses the word "run," it probably does not mean that David literally ran, but only that David wanted to quickly travel to Bethlehem and then quickly travel back. You will remember that David and Jonathan both know that this is a lie. David wants Jonathan to say this to deceive Saul. David says that if Saul says "Very well," or "Good," then David is not in immediate danger. But David says that if Saul loses his temper or becomes very angry, then Jonathan will know for sure that Saul is determined to harm David.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you know if someone feels anger about something? For example, maybe the person communicates these feelings directly with their words or actions, or maybe the person shows their feelings more indirectly, such as by not talking anymore or by how they move their body. If needed, remember the story you told in step two about a person who you thought was angry. Pause this audio here.

David asks Jonathan to show kindness to David because of the covenant, or solemn agreement, that Jonathan and David made with each other. In the original language, the word David uses means "steadfast love," or a special type of kindness that does not end, no matter what happens. Throughout this story, both David and Jonathan ask for this kindness from each other and promise it to each other because of their covenant.

David says that if Jonathan thinks David is guilty of harming Saul, David wants Jonathan to kill David himself. But Jonathan says, "Far be it from you!" or "Never!" Then Jonathan asks David a question that Jonathan does not expect David to answer. Jonathan asks, "If I knew that my father was determined to harm you, would I not tell you?" Jonathan says this to show that Jonathan would certainly tell David. So David asks Jonathan who will tell David if Saul gets angry when Saul learns that David will not come. Jonathan responds, "Come, let us go out into the field." We do not know for sure what kind of field this is. It may be land where people grow crops for food, or it may refer more generally to open land.

When Jonathan and David get to the field, Jonathan makes an oath using Yahweh's name that Jonathan will "sound out," or find out, what Saul is thinking and planning by this time, the day after tomorrow. Jonathan says that if Saul is favorably disposed or has a friendly attitude toward David, will Jonathan not tell it to David? This is a question that Jonathan does not expect David to answer. Jonathan uses this question to make a statement. But Jonathan says that if Jonathan's father is inclined, or wants, to hurt David, Yahweh should severely punish Jonathan if he does not tell David and send David away to a safe place. Jonathan says this to show that Jonathan's promise to protect David is very serious.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you make a strong promise in your culture? What special things do you say or do to show that you very much mean what you say? How will you talk about Jonathan making this strong promise to David? Pause this audio here.

Jonathan asks that Yahweh be with David just as Yahweh has been with Saul. Then Jonathan asks David to be kind and faithful to Jonathan just as Yahweh is kind and faithful, so that no one will kill Jonathan. Jonathan also asks David not to cut off or stop his kindness to Jonathan's family when Yahweh cuts off every one of David's enemies from the face of the earth. This is special language that means that Jonathan wants David and David's descendants to always be friendly with Jonathan and Jonathan's descendants, and never to fight against them as enemies.

So Jonathan makes a covenant or solemn agreement with David's house, or with David and David's descendants. Jonathan uses the words, "May Yahweh call David's enemies to account." This is special language that means Jonathan is calling on Yahweh to punish David's descendants if David's descendants ever break this covenant by harming Jonathan's descendants. It is as if Jonathan is saying, "If anyone breaks this covenant, Yahweh will punish that person."

Finally, Jonathan makes David swear this oath again because of their loyal friendship and Jonathan's love for David—the strong kind of love where a friend is willing to die for his friend.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 20:1–17 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has four scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • Jonathan

  • Saul

  • Yahweh

  • David's clan, or all of the people David is related to

  • David's descendants

  • And Jonathan's descendants

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

David runs from Ramah to the place where Jonathan is staying. David asks Jonathan, "What have I done wrong to your father? Your father is trying to kill me!"

But Jonathan says, "You must be mistaken! My father does not do anything without telling me about it. Surely I would know if my father wanted to kill you. This cannot be true!"

But David says, "I promise this is true. Your father knows how much you like me, so your father must have hidden this from you because he knew you would be upset. But just as true as Yahweh lives and you live, I am in danger of being killed!"

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel shocked that Saul would want to kill me! I have always served Saul faithfully; or

  • I feel afraid and unsure who I can trust, but Jonathan has always been a loyal friend.

Ask the person playing Jonathan, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel very confused. Why would my father want to kill David? That does not make any sense; or

  • My father always tells me about the decisions he makes as king. I am sure if my father were angry with David, my father would tell me about it; or

  • There is no way my father could want to kill David. David has always loved our family and faithfully served my father, the king. David must have misunderstood.

Jonathan says, "I will do whatever you want me to do."

So David gives Jonathan some instructions. David says, "You know that the New Moon festival begins tomorrow. I am supposed to be there to eat the meal with your father. But give me your permission not to come to the meal. Instead, I will hide in the field until the evening of the day after tomorrow, when the festival is finished. But if your father notices that I am not there and asks where I am, tell your father I asked your permission not to come, and instead I ran home to Bethlehem to be there for the annual sacrifice with all of my family. If your father says 'Good,' that means I am not in danger, but if he becomes angry, you will know he wants to harm me. But if you think I am guilty, be kind to me and kill me yourself."

But Jonathan says, "I would never kill you!"

So David asks, "Who will come to tell me if your father becomes angry?"

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am sure Saul still wants to kill me, but I know that Jonathan does not believe it; or

  • I do not like to deceive Saul, but there is no other way to help Jonathan know the truth; or

  • If I am hiding out in the field, how will Jonathan let me know if Saul is angry and still wants to kill me?

Ask the person playing Jonathan, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I still cannot believe that my father would want to kill David. But I trust David, so I will follow David's plan; or

  • I do not like to lie to my father, but I will do anything to help my friend David.

Jonathan takes David to a field outside the city. Then Jonathan says, "Yahweh, the God of Israel, be my witness! I will surely find out what my father is thinking about you by this time, the day after tomorrow. If my father is feeling friendly toward you, I will let you know. But if my father wants to harm you, may Yahweh punish me if I do not tell you and help you escape to safety.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Jonathan, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I love my father, but I would never let my father do anything bad to David; or

  • I know David is afraid, and I want David to know that he can trust me to do what I promise.

Jonathan says to David, "May Yahweh be with you as he has been with my father Saul. But be kind and faithful to me just as Yahweh is kind and faithful. Keep on showing kindness to my family when Yahweh kills every one of David's enemies in the world."

So Jonathan makes a covenant with David and David's descendants. Jonathan says, "If anyone breaks this covenant, Yahweh will punish them." Finally, Jonathan asks David to repeat the promise David has just made.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Jonathan, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I love David; or

  • I do not want David or David's descendants to ever become my family's enemies; or

  • I know Yahweh's power is with David.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel like Jonathan is afraid of me, but I am not sure why; or

  • I already promised Jonathan these things, so why is he asking me to promise them again? or

  • I am starting to feel annoyed because Jonathan has asked this again!

Ask the person playing Yahweh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am very happy with Jonathan. Although Jonathan could expect to become the next king, instead, Jonathan has asked me to be with David just as I have been with Saul; or

  • Jonathan can see that I have given David my power and protection. Although Jonathan does not know for sure, he seems to understand that I will make David the next king.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 20:1–17 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

David asks Jonathan what David's guilt is. Guilt is a person's responsibility for the wrong thing they have done. A person who is guilty deserves to be punished for doing that wrong thing. Use the same word or phrase for guilt that you have used in previous passages.

David also asks Jonathan what David's sin is that makes Saul want to kill David. Sin is an act of rebellion against God. Anytime that a person disobeys God's laws, that person sins. Use the same word or phrase for sin that you have used in previous passages. For more information, look up sin in the Master Glossary.

Jonathan says that Jonathan's father, Saul, never does anything, either great or small, without disclosing it to Jonathan. Saul would always tell Jonathan what Saul was going to do.

Stop here and discuss as a group how you will talk about Saul telling Jonathan everything Saul was about to do. Pause this audio here.

David vowed, or swore an oath, to Jonathan. An oath is a special sort of promise. When someone swears an oath, that person says, "I will absolutely keep my promise. If I do not, God may punish me." If someone did not keep his promise after swearing an oath, we say that the person broke his oath. It was an utterly disgraceful and dangerous thing to break an oath. Use the same word or phrase for "swore an oath" that you have used in previous passages. For more information, look up oath in the Master Glossary.

David says that Saul knows that David has found favor in Jonathan's eyes. To "find favor in someone's eyes" means to make that person happy with you or pleased by what you do so that they like or approve of you. Use the same word or phrase "finding favor in someone's eyes" that you have used in previous passages.

David calls himself Jonathan's servant. A servant is a person who does work for someone else. To call himself Jonathan's servant showed David's respect for Jonathan as the king's son. Use the same word or phrase for servant that you have used in previous passages. For more information, look up servant in the Master Glossary.

David says that if Saul is angry, they will know that Saul intends to harm or do evil to David. Use the same word or phrase for harm or evil that you have used in previous passages. For more information, look up evil in the Master Glossary.

David asks Jonathan to show David kindness. This is the kind of kindness or love that people promise to show to each other forever.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for kindness or steadfast love. Look up steadfast love in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

David says that just as Yahweh lives and Jonathan's soul lives, there is but a step between David and death. The name Yahweh is God's personal name that shows the close relationship that God had with the people of Israel. Use the same word or phrase for Yahweh that you have used in previous passages. For more information, look up Yahweh in the Master Glossary.

The soul is the invisible part of a person where that person's thoughts, feelings, and emotions are. But the Bible often uses the word soul to mean a person's life, because without the inner part of the person, the person is not complete. Use the same word or phrase for soul that you have used in previous passages. For more information, look up soul in the Master Glossary.

Although the next day was the festival of the New Moon, David tells Jonathan to tell Saul that David went to Bethlehem for the yearly sacrifice for all of David's clan. The festival of the New Moon celebrates the time of the month when the new moon rises in the sky.

Stop here and discuss as a group what you will call the festival of the New Moon in this story. See the Master Glossary for more information about the festival of the New Moon, but also use the same title for this festival that you used in Numbers 10:10, if you have already translated it there. Pause this audio here.

A sacrifice is a gift to God. People often placed the gift on a platform that people made of earth or large stones, which people called an altar. The purpose of a sacrifice could be that people wanted to thank God for something, worship God, confirm their relationship with God, or ask forgiveness for something they had done wrong. A sacrifice could involve the killing of an animal, which people would then burn on the altar. But the gift could also be food items, oil, or sweet-smelling spices. Use the same word or phrase for sacrifice that you have used in previous passages. For more information, look up sacrifice in the Master Glossary.

David's clan means a group of families who were descended from the same ancestor. This would be a very large group of people. Use the same word or phrase for clan that you have used in previous passages.

Jonathan swears by Yahweh, the God of Israel, that Jonathan will find out what Saul intends to do. Use the same words for God and Israel as you did in previous passages, and remember that God and Israel are in the Master Glossary.

Jonathan promises to send David away with peace. In this case, two people live in peace when they live in a good relationship with each other. Translate peace in the same way you have previously, and see the Master Glossary for more information about peace.

Jonathan made a covenant with the house of David. When people make a covenant, they make a solemn promise to each other that they cannot break. Individual people or whole families could make a covenant with each other. By making a covenant with each other, the people were saying that they wanted to have a good relationship with each other. For instance, people might promise that they would not fight with each other and that they would help the other group if that group had a problem. Use the same word or phrase for covenant that you have used in previous passages. For more information, look up covenant in the Master Glossary.

The house of David means not only David himself, but also all of David's family and David's descendants.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for house of David. If you have already translated this phrase in another book of the Bible, use the same phrase that you have used there. For more information, look up descendants in the Master Glossary.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 20:18–34
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 20:18–34 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 20:18–34 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 20:18–34 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the last story, David told Jonathan how Saul tried to kill David. Jonathan promised to help David, and David came up with a plan for how Jonathan could trick Saul to find out what Saul is thinking about David. Finally, Jonathan asked Yahweh to be with David, and David renewed his promise to show kindness, or steadfast love, to Jonathan and Jonathan's descendants forever.

In this story, Jonathan now gives David instructions. Jonathan says that tomorrow is the New Moon festival and that people will notice when David is not at the feast. You will remember from the last story that the people of Israel celebrated this festival at the beginning of each month, when people could see the new moon rise in the sky. During this festival, the Israelites stopped their work, offered special sacrifices, and blew trumpets to celebrate. As David said in the last passage, David would normally eat at Saul's table during this festival, so Jonathan is concerned that Saul will notice when David does not come to the feast.

Jonathan tells David that toward evening on the third day, or the day after tomorrow, David must go down quickly to the place where David hid when the trouble with Saul began and wait there by the stone, or pile of stones. Jonathan tells David that at that time, Jonathan will come and use Jonathan's bow to shoot three arrows to the side of the rock, or pile of rocks, where David is hiding. Jonathan will do this as if Jonathan were shooting at a target.

Stop here and look at a picture of a bow and arrow. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, what kinds of weapons do people use to hunt or fight from a distance? How do people practice with these weapons so that people can use the weapons well? Pause this audio here.

Jonathan says that Jonathan will then send a young male servant to go find the arrows Jonathan has shot. Jonathan says that if Jonathan tells the servant that the arrows are between the servant and Jonathan, which means that the servant has gone too far, then David is to come to Jonathan because this means that David will be safe. Here, Jonathan swears an oath that David will be safe, which means Jonathan promises that David can trust Jonathan. But Jonathan also says that if Jonathan tells the servant that the arrows are beyond the servant, or farther away from Jonathan, then David must go away, because this means David is in danger and Yahweh wants David to leave.

Jonathan ends by reminding David that this thing Jonathan and David have discussed is a secret between Jonathan and David, and that Yahweh will watch Jonathan and David to make sure they keep their promise to each other.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are some things that people in your community keep secret between two people? When is it right to keep a secret to protect someone from harm? When does it harm other people to keep a secret? Pause this audio here.

So David goes and hides in the field just as Jonathan said to do. And on the day of the New Moon feast, King Saul comes and sits down at the table to eat. The king sits in his usual place at the table, with his back to the wall, and Jonathan sits opposite, or on the other side of the table. Abner, Saul's army commander, sits beside Saul, but David does not come to sit in David's seat.

Although David does not come to the feast, Saul does not say anything about David. Saul thinks to himself, "David must have done something that accidentally made David unclean." You will remember that the law of Moses said that certain things, like touching a dead body, would make a person unclean, and that while a person was unclean, that person could not participate in a religious celebration such as the New Moon festival. So Saul thinks this is why David did not come.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are some celebrations in your community where people expect to come together? What are some reasons you might not allow someone to come who you would normally allow to come? Pause this audio here.

But the next day, which is the second day of the new month, David is still not at his place at the table. So Saul now asks Jonathan why David has not come, and Jonathan tells Saul what David told Jonathan to say. Jonathan says, "David earnestly asked me if he could go to Bethlehem. David said, 'Our family is having a sacrifice in the town, and my brother has demanded that I come. If you are my friend, please give me permission to go see my relatives.' That is why David has not come to the king's table."

Saul becomes very angry with Jonathan. Saul says, "You are as perverse and rebellious as your mother!" Then Saul asks a question he does not expect Jonathan to answer. Saul says, "Don't I know that you have sided with the son of Jesse to your own shame and the shame of the mother who gave you birth?" Saul means that Jonathan's friendship with David, whom Saul refers to as the son of Jesse, will bring shame upon Jonathan and upon Jonathan's mother.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, what are some wrong actions that a person might do that would bring shame to their family? Now tell a story about a person who did something that was right and good, but that thing still caused their family to feel shame. Pause this audio here.

Saul continues, "As long as the son of Jesse is alive, you will never be king. Now send someone to bring David to me, because David deserves to die, and I am going to kill David!"

Jonathan responds, "David should not be killed! David has done nothing wrong!"

Saul throws his spear at Jonathan to try to kill Jonathan. So Jonathan now knows that Saul plans to kill David, just as David said.

Jonathan feels very angry as Jonathan leaves the festival. Jonathan does not eat anything because Jonathan feels grieved or sad by the way Saul had disgraced and dishonored David.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 20:18–34 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has four scenes.

In the first scene: Jonathan gives David instructions on where to hide in the field and how Jonathan will communicate with David to let David know if Saul wants to kill David or not. Then David goes and hides in the field.

In the second scene: When the New Moon festival begins, Saul sees that David does not come to Saul's table. However, Saul does not say anything, because Saul thinks David accidentally became unclean and cannot come.

In the third scene: When David does not come to the table to eat the next day either, Saul asks Jonathan where David is. Jonathan says David went to David's hometown for the annual sacrifice. Saul becomes very angry with Jonathan. Saul says that Jonathan has brought shame upon Jonathan and upon Jonathan's mother. Saul says that Jonathan will not become king as long as David is alive. Finally, Saul tells Jonathan to bring David to Saul so that Saul can kill David. Jonathan says that Saul should not kill David, because David has done nothing wrong. So Saul throws Saul's spear at Jonathan to try to kill Jonathan.

In the fourth scene: Jonathan leaves the festival without eating anything because Jonathan feels grieved by the shameful way Saul has treated David.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Jonathan

  • David

  • Yahweh

  • King Saul

  • The young male servant

  • And Abner

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In the first scene, Jonathan continues to talk with David. Jonathan says, "Tomorrow is the New Moon festival, and my father will miss you, because your seat will be empty." You will remember that the Israelites celebrated the New Moon festival each month, and King Saul expected David to eat this meal with Saul. We are not sure how many people ate with Saul, but we later learn that both Abner, the commander of Saul's army, and Jonathan were there. And since Abner, Jonathan, and David are all important warriors who fight for Saul, this may be why the king invites David to eat with Saul.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, what are some reasons why a king or important leader might invite certain people to eat a meal with the king or leader? Pause this audio here.

Jonathan now tells David that David must wait until dark on the third day and then go down quickly to the place in the field where David hid when David first experienced this trouble with Saul. You will remember that for the Israelites, the new day began in the evening, so Jonathan means that David must go there on the day after tomorrow.

Jonathan says David must hide there by the stone, or stones. We are not sure what the original language says here. Some translations say "stone Ezel," which means "the Departure Stone," while others say stone heap or pile of stones.

Next, Jonathan says that Jonathan will shoot three arrows toward this pile of stones as if Jonathan were shooting at a target. Although Jonathan does not use the word "bow" here, we know that Jonathan will shoot these arrows using Jonathan's bow. You will remember that a bow is a long, narrow piece of wood. People tie a strong string tightly to either end of this piece of wood so that the wood bends into a curved shape. Arrows are long, thin sticks with a pointed tip on one end. People often tie bird feathers onto the other end to help the arrow fly straight through the air. A person can shoot an arrow from the bow by pulling back the string and then letting go of the string quickly so that it pushes the arrow forward and makes it fly into the air.

Stop here and look at a picture of a bow and arrow as a group. Pause this audio here.

Jonathan says that Jonathan will shoot the three arrows to the side of the pile of stones as if Jonathan were shooting at a target. We are not sure if this means that Jonathan will shoot the arrows so that the arrows hit the side of the rock itself, or if Jonathan means that Jonathan will shoot the arrows so that the arrows fall to a point beside the rock. Jonathan says that Jonathan will then send a young male servant to go get the arrows. If Jonathan says to the servant, "The arrows are on my side," that means the servant has gone farther away from Jonathan than the arrows. This will mean Jonathan is telling David that Saul does not want to kill David. Jonathan says, "Then as surely as Yahweh lives, you are safe." The phrase "as surely as Yahweh lives" is the normal way to say an oath, which means that Jonathan is promising to David before Yahweh that David can trust that Jonathan is telling the truth.

But Jonathan also says that if Jonathan says to the servant, "The arrows are beyond you," that means that the servant has not gone far enough away from Jonathan to reach the arrows. In that case, Jonathan is telling David that Saul still wants to kill David. Jonathan says that if Jonathan says this to the servant, then David must go away, because David will know that David is in danger and Yahweh wants David to leave.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about someone who created a special way of communicating a secret message to someone else. How did that person decide what to use to communicate this message? How did the person keep it a secret from other people? Pause this audio here.

Jonathan ends the conversation with David by reminding David that the thing that Jonathan and David have discussed is a secret between Jonathan and David. Jonathan is talking about the covenant, or strong promise, that Jonathan and David made with each other. Yahweh will act as a witness between Jonathan and David to make sure they keep this promise to each other. After Jonathan and David finish talking, David goes and hides in the field. In the original language, the word for field here means farmland that people use for growing crops or for grazing animals.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, when two people make an important promise to each other, how do those people talk about that promise? Who is responsible to make sure each person keeps that promise? Pause this audio here.

In the second scene, when the New Moon feast begins, the king comes and sits down at the king's table to eat. The king sits down at his usual place at the table, with the king's back to the wall. In the original language, the storyteller says that Jonathan "stood in his place," which some translations translate as "arose." However, what this probably means is that Jonathan stood in attendance, ready to serve his father, the king. So after Saul sits down first, then Jonathan sits opposite the king, or on the other side of the table. And Abner, the commander of the king's army, sits next to Saul. But David is not there to sit in David's seat.

Saul notices that David is not at the table, but Saul does not say anything. Saul thinks to himself, "Something must have caused David to become unclean." You will remember that the law of Moses talks about many things that might cause a person to become ceremonially unclean. Some of these things a person might do intentionally, such as bury a family member who has died. Other things might be accidental or unplanned. Here, Saul thinks David must have accidentally become unclean, and so David cannot come to the feast.

In the third scene, when David still does not come to the feast the next day, Saul asks Jonathan, "Why has the son of Jesse not come to the meal either yesterday or today?" You will remember that David's father is Jesse, so when Saul says "the son of Jesse," Saul means David.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How will you make it clear in your translation that Saul is talking about David? Pause this audio here.

Now Jonathan says the words David told Jonathan to say. Jonathan says, "David earnestly asked me if he could go to Bethlehem. David said, 'Our family is having a sacrifice in the town, and my brother has demanded that I come. If you are my friend, please give me permission to go see my relatives.' That is why David has not come to the king's table." You will remember that Jonathan is lying. David did not go to Bethlehem, but is actually hiding nearby. Jonathan tells Saul this lie to see how Saul will respond. If Saul responds that this is okay, Jonathan will know that Saul does not mean to kill David. But if Saul becomes angry, then Jonathan will know that Saul wants to kill David.

When Jonathan says these words, Saul becomes very angry. Saul says, "You are as perverse and rebellious as your mother!" Calling someone a perverse and rebellious son is a strong insult. Saul is saying Jonathan is a lowly traitor or a shameful person who is not loyal. Where Saul calls Jonathan's mother rebellious, some translations say prostitute. We are not sure if this is correct, but we do know that Saul is speaking in an insulting way about both Jonathan and Jonathan's mother.

Saul continues, "Do I not know that you are choosing the son of Jesse to your own shame and the shame of your mother's nakedness?" Here, Saul is asking a question that Saul does not expect David to answer. What Saul means is that Saul knows Jonathan is very loyal to David. And Saul is saying that because of this, Jonathan's own mother should be ashamed that she gave birth to Jonathan.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: If someone in your community acts very shamefully toward their family, what are some insulting things people might say about that person? Also, if a person causes shame to your community, what insults might people say about that person's parents? Pause this audio here.

Saul says, "As long as the son of Jesse lives on the earth, your kingdom will never be established. Now send someone to bring Jesse's son to me, because Jesse's son deserves to die, and I am going to kill him!" As Saul's oldest son, Jonathan would expect to become the next king when Saul dies. But Saul is saying that as long as David is alive, David will keep Jonathan from being able to become the next king. So Saul wants Jonathan to help Saul kill David by bringing David to Saul.

Jonathan responds by asking two questions that Jonathan does not expect Saul to answer. Jonathan says, "But why should David be killed? What has David done?" Jonathan is strongly disagreeing with Saul. Jonathan is saying that David must not die. This makes Saul very angry, and Saul throws Saul's spear at Jonathan to try to kill Jonathan.

In the last scene, Jonathan gets up from the table very angry. Jonathan leaves the festival without eating anything, because Jonathan feels very sad about the shameful way Saul has treated David.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 20:18–34 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has four scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Jonathan

  • David

  • Yahweh

  • King Saul

  • The young male servant

  • And Abner

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

In the first scene, Jonathan continues to talk with David. Jonathan says, "Tomorrow is the New Moon festival, and my father will miss you, because your seat will be empty. On the day after tomorrow, at evening time, go to the place where you hid when this trouble with my father began and wait by the pile of stones there. I will shoot three arrows to the side of the stones like I am shooting at a target. Then I will send a young male servant to get the arrows. If I call to the young man, 'The arrows are on my side,' then come, because as surely as Yahweh lives, you will be safe. But if I call out, 'The arrows are farther away,' then you must go, because Yahweh wants you to leave. And may Yahweh make us keep our promises to each other, because Yahweh has heard what we said." Then, when Jonathan and David finish talking, David goes and hides in the field.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Jonathan, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel hopeful that David misunderstood my father's actions and that David will be able to come out of hiding; or

  • I do not think that my father, King Saul, wants to kill David, but this is a good plan to keep David safe, just in case David is right; or

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Jonathan is a good man. Although Jonathan is loyal to me, I know it is important for Jonathan to trust and honor his father, King Saul; or

  • This is a good plan. I know that Saul wants to kill me, but this will help Jonathan see the truth, too.

In scene two, as the New Moon feast begins, the king comes and sits down at the king's table to eat. The king sits down at his usual place at the table, with the king's back to the wall. Jonathan sits opposite the king, or on the other side of the table. And Abner, the commander of the king's army, sits next to Saul. But David is not there to sit in David's seat. Saul thinks in his mind, "Something must have caused David to become unclean." But Saul does not say anything to Jonathan or anyone else about David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Some things that make people unclean accidentally are shameful to talk about, so I will not ask what happened; or

  • I am sure David will be ceremonially clean again tomorrow and can come to the feast then.

In scene three, when David again does not come to the feast, Saul asks Jonathan, "Why has the son of Jesse not come to the meal either yesterday or today?" Jonathan says, "David earnestly asked me if he could go to Bethlehem. David said, 'Our family is having a sacrifice in the town, and my brother has demanded that I come. If you are my friend, please give me permission to go see my relatives.' That is why David has not come to the king's table."

When Saul hears this, Saul is very angry! "You are as bad and rebellious as your mother! Do I not know that you are choosing the son of Jesse to your own shame and the shame of your mother's nakedness? As long as the son of Jesse lives on the earth, you will never be king! Now send someone to bring Jesse's son to me, because Jesse's son deserves to die, and I am going to kill him!"

But Jonathan responds, "But why should you kill David? What has he done?" And in Saul's great anger, Saul throws his spear at Jonathan to try to kill Jonathan.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am furious that Jonathan is more loyal to his friend David than Jonathan is to me. Not only am I Jonathan's own father, but I am the king of Israel and must be obeyed! or

  • I am shocked that Jonathan would dishonor me like this. This is shameful! or

  • I want Jonathan to honor me and our family by becoming the next king. But if Jonathan refuses to obey me and chooses to honor David instead, then I must kill both of them.

Jonathan feels very angry. Jonathan gets up from the table and leaves the festival without eating anything, because Jonathan feels very sad about the shameful way Saul has treated David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Jonathan, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel shocked that my father would want to kill David. David has always been loyal and trustworthy toward my father; or

  • I am grieved that my father would be so jealous of David's success that my father would try to kill David. Does my father not see that Yahweh is blessing David? or

  • I know that it is right to show loyalty to my family, and especially to the king. But I must be even more loyal to David, because Yahweh has blessed David.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 20:18–34 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Jonathan tells David that tomorrow will be the festival of the New Moon. "New moon" means the time each month when people can see the new moon rise in the sky. The Israelites celebrated this time each month during the festival of the New Moon. Use the same word or phrase for "festival of the new moon" that you have used in previous passages. See the Master Glossary for more information about the festival of the New Moon.

Jonathan says that Jonathan will shoot three arrows as though Jonathan is shooting at a mark or target. A target is an object or particular place that a person tries to hit with their arrows when they practice shooting with their bow. By aiming at a target, a person can improve how they shoot to become more skilled and accurate with their bow.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for target. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Jonathan tells David that as surely as Yahweh lives, David will be safe if Jonathan tells David that everything is safe. Use the same word for Yahweh as you have used in previous passages, and see the Master Glossary for Yahweh for more information.

The king, or Saul, comes to eat at the feast. Use the same word for king as you have used in previous passages, and see the Master Glossary for king for more information.

When David does not come to the feast, Saul thinks that something must have made David unclean. This does not mean dirty from the outside. In the Bible, a clean person means a person who is fit for service to God, while a person who is unclean is unfit for service to God. A person would become unclean either because of sin or by touching an unclean thing.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for unclean. Look up clean and unclean in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Jonathan says that David asked for Jonathan's permission to go to Bethlehem, where David's clan is making a sacrifice. The word clan means a group of families who are descended from the same ancestor. This would be a very large group of people. Use the same word or phrase for clan that you have used in previous passages.

A sacrifice is a gift to God. People often placed the gift on a platform made of earth or large stones, which people called an altar. The purpose of a sacrifice could be that people wanted to thank God for something, worship God, confirm their relationship with God, or ask forgiveness for something they had done wrong. Use the same word or phrase for sacrifice that you have used in previous passages. For more information, look up sacrifice in the Master Glossary.

Jonathan says that David had said to Jonathan, "If I have found favor in your eyes, let me go." The phrase "favor in your eyes" means that the person likes and approves of you and therefore treats you with kindness. Use the same word or phrase for "favor in your eyes" that you have used in previous passages.

When Jonathan finishes telling these things to Saul about David, Saul's anger is kindled. The word kindled means to create a fire, or to arouse and stir up, like someone who stirs up a fire to make it burn hot. Use the same word or phrase for kindled that you have used in previous passages.

Saul calls Jonathan perverse and rebellious. The word perverse means bent, twisted, bad, or distorted, and rebellious means to resist or to refuse to obey orders.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for perverse and rebellious. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Saul says that Jonathan's kingdom will never be established. In other words, Jonathan will never rule as king. Use the same word or phrase for kingdom that you have used in previous passages. For more information, look up kingdom in the Master Glossary.

Jonathan is grieved by the way Saul has treated David. To be grieved means to be sad or very upset and unhappy. Use the same word or phrase for grieved that you have used in previous passages.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
