title: 1 Samuel 20:35–42
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 20:35–42 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 20:35–42 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 20:35–42 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the last passage, after Jonathan gave David instructions about how Jonathan would communicate secretly with David by shooting arrows, David hid in the field. When the festival of the New Moon began, and David did not come to eat with King Saul, Saul thought David had become unclean, so Saul did not say anything. But when David did not come on the second day of the festival either, Saul asked Jonathan where David was. Jonathan told Saul a lie that David had gone to David's hometown of Bethlehem. Saul became very angry. Saul used some insulting words to call Jonathan disloyal and a traitor. Saul said that Jonathan would never become king as long as David was alive. Saul told Jonathan to bring David to Saul so Saul could kill David. Jonathan responded that David had done nothing wrong. So Saul threw Saul's spear to try to kill Jonathan. Finally, Jonathan left the festival very angry and very sad because of how Saul had treated David.

Now, the very next morning, Jonathan goes out into the field to the place where Jonathan told David to meet Jonathan. Jonathan takes a young servant boy with him, and Jonathan tells the servant in a kind way to run and find the arrows Jonathan will shoot from Jonathan's bow.

Stop here and look at a picture of a bow and arrow as a group, if needed. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about someone who gives a command to a servant or a less powerful person who has to obey the command. Tell how that person gives the command in a kind way, even though the other person must obey the command. Pause this audio here.

As the servant boy runs ahead, Jonathan shoots an arrow beyond the boy so that the arrow flies through the air above the boy's head. When the servant gets to the place where the arrow has fallen to the ground, Jonathan shouts to the boy, "Isn't the arrow beyond you?" Jonathan does not expect the boy to answer this question. Jonathan uses the question to say that the arrow is indeed farther away. Jonathan says this to communicate the secret message to David that Jonathan had planned in the previous passage. This message means that David must leave because Saul wants to kill David.

Then Jonathan shouts again to the servant boy, "Hurry! Go quickly! Do not stop!" Jonathan says this to secretly communicate to David how quickly David must leave because of the danger.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Think of a time in your community when someone warned other people that something dangerous was going to happen. Maybe this danger was a wild animal, a storm, enemy soldiers, or something else. Now, act this story out. Pay attention to what the person does to get other people's attention, and what words the person uses to warn the other people. Pause this audio here.

The servant boy picks up the arrow and brings it back to Jonathan. The servant does not know about Jonathan's plan. Only Jonathan and David understand what Jonathan's words mean.

Jonathan gives Jonathan's weapons to the servant boy and tells the boy to take the weapons back to the city. Then, as soon as the boy leaves the field, David stands up where he has been hiding on the south side of the stone. David bows low in front of Jonathan. In this culture, people would bow to show great respect. David touches David's forehead all the way to the ground three times. Since this was the lowest David could kneel, it showed the greatest possible honor David could show toward Jonathan.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your culture, how do people show respect to other people? If two people are friends, but one of those people is more powerful or respected in the community than the other, how do those people act or speak to each other to show this? Pause this audio here.

Now David stands up, and Jonathan and David kiss each other. In ancient Israel, Jewish men often greeted each other with a kiss to show friendship and honor each other. Jonathan and David also weep together, but David weeps the loudest. We are not sure why David and Jonathan took this risk that someone might see David with Jonathan. This seems surprising after all that Jonathan did to communicate secretly with David. It is possible that David and Jonathan did not plan to meet, but changed their minds at the last minute because the two men felt such strong emotion.

Jonathan blesses David and says to go in peace, because Jonathan and David have sworn to be loyal to each other. Jonathan repeats part of the oath that Jonathan and David swore earlier when Jonathan says, "Yahweh is witness between you and me, and between your descendants and my descendants forever."

Finally, David goes away, and Jonathan goes back to the city.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 20:35–42 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has three scenes.

In the first scene: Jonathan takes a servant boy with Jonathan and goes to the field where David has hidden. Jonathan shoots an arrow into the field and tells the servant to find it. Jonathan shouts to the servant that the arrow is farther out and to go quickly. Then, when the servant returns with the arrow, Jonathan sends the boy back to the city.

In the second scene: David comes out from where David hid by the pile of stones and bows before Jonathan. Then David and Jonathan kiss and weep together. Jonathan tells David to go in peace because of the oath the men both swore to be loyal to each other.

In the third scene: David goes away and Jonathan returns to the city.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Jonathan

  • David

  • Young servant boy

  • And Yahweh

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In the first scene, Jonathan goes to the field where Jonathan and David planned to meet and where David is now hiding. The original language says that Jonathan goes to the field for the "appointment," or that Jonathan goes to the "appointed place." However, it may be more natural to say that Jonathan goes to the place where Jonathan and David agreed to meet.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What is the most natural way to say that Jonathan went to the appointed field so that everyone will understand which field Jonathan goes to? Pause this audio here.

Jonathan takes a young servant boy to the field with Jonathan. The storyteller uses the same word here to describe the servant as in the last story, except that here the storyteller adds one more word to show that the servant is "small." This probably means that the servant is a very young boy who is younger than 13 years old.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: In your language, how do you talk about a male child who is not yet a teenager? How will you translate this so that people will understand how young the servant is? Pause this audio here.

When Jonathan and the servant arrive at the field, Jonathan tells the servant, "Run ahead and get the arrows that I am about to shoot." Although this is a command that the servant knows he must obey, Jonathan says it in a way that sounds kind and not harsh.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How will you translate what Jonathan says so that it sounds like a command and not a request, but also so that it sounds kind? If needed, refer back to the previous step to see how you talked about this there. Pause this audio here.

As the servant runs ahead, Jonathan shoots an arrow so that it flies over the boy's head and out into the field beyond the boy. When the boy arrives at the place where the arrow has fallen to the ground, Jonathan shouts a question that Jonathan does not expect the boy to answer. Jonathan yells, "Isn't the arrow beyond you?" Since Jonathan is actually using this question to make a statement, it may be more natural to say, "But the arrow is in front of you!"

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How will you translate where Jonathan tells the boy to find the arrow? Pause this audio here.

You will remember that Jonathan told David that Jonathan would shoot three arrows. However, here the passage only mentions that Jonathan shoots one arrow. We are not sure why this is. Some translations change this part of the passage to say that Jonathan shot "arrows," or more than one arrow. But it is very possible that Jonathan changed his plan and shot only one arrow. So it is best to follow the original language and only mention that Jonathan shoots one arrow.

Now Jonathan shouts again to the servant, "Hurry! Be quick! Do not stay!" You will remember that Jonathan yells this so that David will hear and understand how quickly David must go away. Jonathan gives the command three times, in three different ways, to show how urgent it is. So it is important to do this in your translation too.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What words or phrases in your language will work best for these commands in your translation? Pause this audio here.

After the servant boy gets the arrow, the servant returns with the arrow to Jonathan. Here, the passage says that the servant "knew nothing." This means that the servant does not know about the plan that Jonathan and David made or the secret meaning of Jonathan's words. Only Jonathan and David know these things.

Now the passage says that Jonathan gives Jonathan's "weapons" to the servant. This probably means Jonathan's bow and arrows, but it could include other weapons as well. Then Jonathan tells the servant to carry the weapons back to the city. The passage does not say which city this is. This may be Saul's hometown, Gibeah, but we are not sure.

As soon as the servant leaves, David stands up from David's hiding place on the south side of the stone. Then David bows down before Jonathan three times "with his face to the ground." This means that David bowed so low to the ground that David touched his forehead to the ground each time.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How will you talk about the way that David gets on his knees and bows so that David's head touches the ground? Pause this audio here.

David and Jonathan kiss each other. David and Jonathan also weep or cry loudly together. But David cries the most, or the loudest. Then Jonathan says, "Go in peace, because we swore to be friends with each other when we said, 'Yahweh will be a witness between us and between our descendants forever.'" The phrase "go in peace" is something that a person with more authority or power would say to someone who has less authority. Since Jonathan is the king's son, Jonathan has more authority than David does. But Jonathan also shows with his words that Jonathan and David are friends.

Finally, David goes away, and Jonathan goes back to the city.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 20:35–42 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has three scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Jonathan

  • David

  • Young servant boy

  • And Yahweh

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

In the first scene, Jonathan takes a young servant boy with Jonathan and goes to the field where Jonathan told David to hide. Jonathan tells the boy, "Run and find the arrows I shoot with my bow." So as the boy starts to run, Jonathan shoots an arrow into the air so that the arrow flies above the boy, far out into the field. Then, when the boy reaches the place where the arrow has fallen on the ground, Jonathan shouts to the boy, "Isn't the arrow beyond you? Hurry! Go quickly! Do not stop!" So the servant boy picks up the arrow and takes it back to Jonathan. Then Jonathan gives the servant boy Jonathan's weapons and sends the boy back to the city with the weapons.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Jonathan, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I hope David is here like I told David to be. David has hidden so well that I cannot see him! or

  • I know my servant may wonder why I only shot one arrow, but I do not want to use up any more time. It is important for my servant to leave quickly so that David can get away without anyone seeing David.

Ask the person playing the servant boy, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am surprised that my master Jonathan came all the way out to this field to only shoot one arrow. Usually, when my master comes to practice shooting arrows, he shoots many more arrows. But my master must have just changed his mind.

In the second scene, David stands up from David's hiding place on the south side of the stone. First, David bows before Jonathan. Then David and Jonathan kiss and weep together. David weeps louder than Jonathan does. Then Jonathan says, "Go in peace, because we swore to be friends with each other when we said, 'Yahweh will be a witness between us and between our descendants forever.'"

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Jonathan, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am very sad that my good friend David has to go away, but there is no other way to protect David from my father; or

  • I will always be loyal to David, not only because David is my friend, but also because of the oath I swore in the presence of Yahweh.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I know it may be dangerous to come out of hiding, but I want to see my friend Jonathan one more time before I go; or

  • I do not understand why Saul wants to kill me after everything I have done to show my loyalty to Saul and Saul's family; or

  • I love my friend Jonathan, and I do not want to leave Jonathan. But I know that it would be too dangerous to stay here.

Finally, David goes away, and Jonathan goes back to the city.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 20:35–42 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

In the morning, Jonathan took a young servant boy and went to the appointed place in the field. You will remember that an appointed place is a location that people agree on together beforehand. Use the same word or phrase for "appointed place" that you have used in previous passages.

You will remember from the previous passage that this field might be a piece of land where people grow crops for food, or it might just be an open plot of land where there are no buildings or people living. Use the same word or phrase for field that you used in previous passages.

Jonathan told the servant to run and get the arrows that Jonathan would shoot. Then, as the boy ran, Jonathan shot an arrow beyond the servant. Here, the word beyond means to pass over, so this means that Jonathan shot the arrow so that the arrow flew above the servant's head, far out into the field. Use the same word or phrase for beyond that you have used in previous passages.

The storyteller in this passage talks about both arrows and weapons. Arrows are long, thin sticks with a pointed tip on one end. People can make arrows fly very quickly through the air by shooting the arrows from a bow. Although the storyteller does not mention the bow, we know that Jonathan used a bow to shoot Jonathan's arrow. Look up bow in the Master Glossary for more information. Use the same word or phrase for arrows that you have used in previous passages.

Stop here as a group and look again at a picture of a bow and arrows, if needed. Pause this audio here.

Weapons can mean any kind of tool people use to fight in battle. A bow and arrows are one kind of weapon. Jonathan may have had other weapons with Jonathan, but the passage does not say what these weapons were. Use the same word or phrase for weapons that you have used in previous passages.

After Jonathan sent the servant back to the city, David rose, or got up, from where David was hiding on the south side of the stone. "Rose" means to stand up tall, so David may have been sitting, crouching, or even lying down flat on the ground so that the servant could not see David. Use the same word or phrase for rose or got up that you have used in previous passages.

David "fell on his face to the ground" in front of Jonathan. This does not mean that David fell down accidentally or hurt himself. This means that David kneeled down and then leaned forward to touch David's forehead to the ground out of great respect for Jonathan.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for fell on his face to the ground. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

After telling David to go in peace, Jonathan repeats some of the words from the oath Jonathan and David made to each other in a previous passage. In that oath, Jonathan and David promised not only to be loyal to each other, but also that their descendants would be loyal to each other in the name or power of Yahweh. Use the same words or phrases for peace and Yahweh that you have used in previous passages, and see the Master Glossary for more information about peace and Yahweh, if needed.

Originally, Jonathan and David used the word "house" to refer to their descendants, or the people in their families who would come after them, like children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. But here in this story, Jonathan uses a slightly different word in the original language that means seed or offspring to describe these descendants. This is special language that shows how Jonathan and David's families will grow large and cover the land of Israel, just like the seeds that a farmer spreads across his land grow to become a field of crops.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for seed or offspring. Look up seed in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 21:1–9
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 21:1–9 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 21:1–9 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 21:1–9 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous story, Jonathan went to meet David in the field where David was hiding from Saul. Jonathan shot arrows and sent his servant boy to collect the arrows. Jonathan gave the boy commands that were a secret, urgent warning to David that Saul wanted to kill David, and that David should run away immediately. When the servant boy left, Jonathan sent David away with a blessing and reminded David of the covenant of friendship that David and Jonathan had made earlier in Yahweh's presence.

Then David traveled from the city where King Saul was, most likely Gibeah, to the city of Nob. Nob was the city where the priests lived. It is likely that the ark of the covenant was in Nob at that time. Nob was eight kilometres southwest of Gibeah and a very short distance north of Jebus, later known as Jerusalem. David went to see Ahimelech the priest, who was the great-grandson of Eli the high priest. The title "priest" here means the chief priest or the high priest. The high priest was the most important priest who, once a year, offered a sacrifice on behalf of all the people of Israel to ask Yahweh's forgiveness for all the sins the people had committed the previous year. Ahimelech was most likely the brother of Ahijah, Saul's priest. Ahimelech trembled in fear when he saw David. Ahimelech asked David why David came alone. Probably other servants of Saul normally came with David, and Ahimelech sensed that something was wrong. Ahimelech did not want to become involved in any trouble.

Stop here and look as a group at a map showing David's journey from Gibeah to Nob. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and tell a story about someone who showed that they were afraid. What kinds of things did that person do? Pause this audio here.

David answered Ahimelech and told Ahimelech a lie. David said that the king had sent David to do something special for the king. David said that the king told David not to tell anyone anything about David's task and the king's instructions. David said that David told David's men where to meet David. David was probably not sure whether he could trust Ahimelech because Ahimelech was the brother of Saul's priest Ahijah. Or David may have wanted to protect Ahimelech from King Saul. Saul might have thought that Ahimelech was involved in David's escape. So David made up a story to explain why David was by himself.

David asked Ahimelech what Ahimelech "had on hand." If Ahimelech had five loaves of bread, David wanted the five loaves, or David wanted whatever there was. David asked if Ahimelech had any food available that David could take with him on David's mission. David asked for five loaves because David had spoken of several men going with David, and probably wanted to gather provisions for two or three days. David was prepared to accept any food if the five loaves of bread were not available.

Ahimelech said that Ahimelech did not have any common bread available, but there was holy bread. "Common" or ordinary bread is bread that has not been set apart for Yahweh as holy. Common bread was ordinary bread that anyone could eat. Holy bread, also called the "bread of the Presence," was the bread that Yahweh commanded to be always in Yahweh's presence in the tabernacle. The holy bread consisted of 12 large round loaves, which likely symbolized the 12 tribes of Israel. The bread also symbolized God's constant provision for his people. Yahweh only allowed priests and the priests' families to eat this bread. Ahimelech the priest was happy to give David some of the holy bread, as David had said that David was traveling on an important mission from the king. Ahimelech said that Ahimelech would give David the holy bread only if David and David's men had not had sexual relations with women recently. To have sexual relations with women made men ceremonially unclean for a time.

Stop here and look as a group at a picture of the holy bread. Pause this audio here.

Stop here as a group and discuss this question: Who in your culture can handle holy things? What makes someone ritually clean in order to do that? Pause this audio here.

David answered Ahimelech and said that David and David's men had not had sexual relations recently. It was a common practice for men not to have sexual relations with women during military missions because people regarded war as sacred. David then said that the "vessels of the young men" were holy even when they went on common, ordinary missions. David's expression "the vessels of the young men" referred to the body and particularly to the parts of the body involved in sexual relations. David assured Ahimelech, the high priest, that the body parts of the young men remained holy during ordinary or common missions, so the men would certainly stay holy on this special mission for the king. By saying this, David suggested that this mission was holy.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What do soldiers in your people group do to make their bodies fit or ready for battle or war? Pause this audio here.

Therefore, since there was no other bread available, Ahimelech gave David the bread of the Presence or the holy bread. The bread of the Presence was 12 large loaves of bread that the priests set in two rows on a table before Yahweh in the tabernacle. The priests put freshly-baked bread on the table each Sabbath, and only the priests were allowed to eat the old bread. Ahimelech gave David and his men the old bread, even though the men were not priests. However, Ahimelech ensured that David and David's men would not treat the bread as ordinary bread by checking that David and David's men were ceremonially clean.

Now, Doeg the Edomite, or a native from the land of Edom, was there that day. Doeg was working for King Saul, probably as Saul's chief shepherd, overseeing the king's herdsmen. Doeg was there because some religious duty he needed to perform kept Doeg before Yahweh at the tabernacle. The storyteller is not clear what that duty was. Doeg may have been there for purification because of a particular sin Doeg committed. Or, perhaps because Doeg was a non-Jew, Doeg wanted to become part of the religious community of Israel.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What kinds of people besides priests remain around your places of worship, and why? Pause this audio here.

Then David asked Ahimelech if Ahimelech had a sword or a spear available. David gave a false explanation of why David asked for the weapons. David said that David had not brought with him David's sword or any other weapons because the king had told David to leave immediately, so quickly that David had not had time to get his weapons.

Ahimelech replied that there was only the sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom David killed in the Valley of Elah or the Terebinth Valley. This sword was wrapped up in a cloth and was hanging behind the ephod—the high priest's shoulder-dress. You will remember that David first took Goliath's sword as part of his plunder after David had killed Goliath. David probably later brought this sword to the tent of meeting, where the Israelites sacrificed to Yahweh. The fact that the sword was in the tent of meeting behind the ephod meant that the sword was very important. The high priest's ephod was a highly decorated piece of clothing that the high priest wore in the tent of meeting when the priest served Yahweh. On top of the ephod, the high priest wore a breastpiece which held the Urim and Thummim, two objects the high priest used to determine Yahweh's will. Ahimelech said that if David wanted the sword, David could take it, as it was the only sword there. David accepted the sword. David said, "There is no other sword as good." David believed that this sword had greater value to David than any other sword. The sword was so valuable to David because David had cut off Goliath's head with it after David had killed Goliath.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a spear and a sword.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 21:1–9 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has five scenes.

In the first scene: David travels from Gibeah to Nob and meets Ahimelech the priest. Ahimelech is afraid and asks David why David travelled totally alone. David lies to Ahimelech. David says that he is alone because the king sent David to do a special task for the king, and David's men will meet David later at a certain place.

In the second scene: David asks if Ahimelech has any food available that David can take with David on his mission. David asks for five loaves of bread, or whatever else Ahimelech has. Ahimelech says that he does not have any common bread available, but that there is holy bread. Ahimelech says Ahimelech will give David the holy bread on the condition that David's men have not had sexual relations with women recently.

In the third scene: David says that David and his men do not have sexual relations with women whenever they go on any common mission. Because this mission is special, the men will keep "the vessels of the young men" holy and not have sexual relations before this mission. Ahimelech gives David and his men old bread of the Presence or holy bread, which the priests had taken away from the table in the tent of meeting, or tabernacle.

In the fourth scene: The storyteller gives the audience additional information. The storyteller tells us that Saul's servant, a man called Doeg from Edom who was Saul's chief shepherd, is also there at Nob. Doeg is there because some religious duty Doeg needs to perform keeps him serving Yahweh at the tabernacle.

In the fifth scene: David asks Ahimelech if Ahimelech has a spear or a sword that David can have. Ahimelech says that he only has Goliath's sword, which David can have if David wants it. David accepts the sword as a weapon of greater value to David than any other.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • Ahimelech the high priest

  • And Saul's servant Doeg the Edomite

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

Then David travelled from the city where King Saul was, most likely Gibeah, to the city of Nob. Nob was about eight kilometers southwest of Gibeah and a very short distance north of the city of Jebus, later called Jerusalem. David went to see Ahimelech the high priest. Ahimelech trembled in fear when he saw David. Ahimelech asked David why David was alone and why there was no one with David. Ahimelech asked David two questions that meant the same thing to show Ahimelech's surprise that David came totally alone.

Stop here and look as a group at a map that shows David's journey from Gibeah to Nob, if necessary. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What words or phrases do you use in your language to say that someone is trembling? Do you use different words or phrases to show different causes of trembling, for example, fear, cold or shock? Pause this audio here.

David answered Ahimelech and said that David was alone because the king had sent David to do a special task for the king. David also said that David's men were not with David because David would meet the men later at a certain place. Note that David told Ahimelech a lie, but we only know it from following the events in the story. The storyteller does not use the word "lie" to explain what David said. David said that David would meet his men "at a certain place." People said this when they either did not know the name of a person or place, or when they deliberately tried to hide the name.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What are the ways, if any, to make it clear in your language that a character in a story is telling a lie? How will you show that David lied to Ahimelech? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What phrases or words do you use in your language to mention a specific place without saying where that place is? Pause this audio here.

Now David introduces a new topic to the conversation. David uses a phrase that makes it clear David is talking about a new thing. David says to Ahimelech, "And now, what do you have on hand? If you have five loaves of bread, give them to me, or whatever there is." "What do you have on hand?" is an expression that means "what food do you have with you at present?" David was probably making a polite request rather than giving Ahimelech a command.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What words or phrases do you use in your language to introduce a new topic into a conversation like David does here? Pause this audio here.

Ahimelech answered David and said that Ahimelech did not have any common bread available, but there was holy bread. Ahimelech said he would give David the holy bread on the condition that David's men had not had sexual relations with women recently, as this would make the men ceremonially unclean. Remember that "common" bread means bread that is not holy or set apart for the worship of Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How will you talk about common bread as opposed to holy bread? Pause this audio here.

David answered Ahimelech and said that David and his men did not have sexual relations with women whenever the men went on any common mission. Therefore, much more now, they would keep "the vessels of the young men" holy and not have sexual relations before this mission for the king. David's expression "the vessels of the young men" referred to the body, and probably particularly to the parts of the body involved in sexual relations. David implied that this mission was holy.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Talk about phrases or nicknames in your language that people use to describe body parts that are not proper to talk about politely, and that people might be embarrassed to talk about. Talk about phrases or words you will use to translate the phrase "the vessels of the young men," which refers to the male body parts involved in sexual relations. Pause this audio here.

Therefore, since there was no other bread available, Ahimelech gave David the bread of the Presence or the holy bread. The priests put freshly baked bread on the table before Yahweh in the tabernacle each Sabbath. Ahimelech gave David and his men the old bread, which the priests had taken away from the table in the tent of meeting, or tabernacle. The storyteller does not actually mention the tent of meeting, or tabernacle, but it talks about bread that is "before Yahweh," or "in Yahweh's presence." This implies that the bread was in the tabernacle, near the ark of the covenant.

Now the passage introduces some background information to the story. The passage uses a phrase that makes it clear that this is background information. Doeg the Edomite, or a native from the land of Edom, was there that day. Doeg was working for King Saul, probably as Saul's chief shepherd. Doeg was there because some religious duty Doeg needed to do kept him before Yahweh at the tabernacle. Although we do not hear any more about Doeg in this passage, we hear more about Doeg later. The storyteller introduces Doeg here to set up the later story.

Stop here and discuss as a group: In your language, how do you show that you are introducing additional or background information to the story? Pause this audio here.

Then David asked Ahimelech, "Don't you have a spear or a sword here?" The way David asked the question implied that David expected that Ahimelech would have a spear or a sword. David gave a false explanation of why David asked for the weapons. David said that he had not brought with him David's sword or any other weapons because the king had told David to leave immediately, so quickly that David had not had time to get his weapons.

Ahimelech replied that there was only the sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom David killed in the Valley of Elah or the Terebinth Valley. This sword was wrapped up in a cloth and was hanging behind the ephod—the high priest's shoulder-dress. Ahimelech said that if David wanted the sword, David could take it, as it was the only sword there. David accepted it because David said this weapon had more value or was more important than any other weapon.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a spear and a sword.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 21:1–9 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has five scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • Ahimelech the high priest

  • And Saul's servant Doeg the Edomite

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

David travels from Gibeah to Nob and meets Ahimelech the priest. Ahimelech is trembling and asks David why David travelled alone. David lies to Ahimelech. David says that David is alone because the king sent David to perform a special task for the king. David also says that David's men are not with him because David will meet the men later at a certain place.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Ahimelech looks scared. I will have to lie to Ahimelech because I do not want to get Ahimelech into trouble with the king; or

  • But Ahimelech knows me and trusts me, so it will be easy to say something that Ahimelech will believe; or

  • I am desperate. I need to get some food and some weapons from Ahimelech.

David asks if Ahimelech has any food available that David can take with him on David's mission. David asks for five loaves, or whatever else Ahimelech has. Ahimelech answers David and says that Ahimelech does not have any common bread available, but that there is holy bread. Ahimelech says he will give David the holy bread on the condition that David's men have not had sexual relations with women recently.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Ahimelech, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am not sure what to do. David wants me to give him food, but we only have the holy bread. Only the priests can eat the holy bread; or

  • But David and his men serve the king of Israel. I am sure Yahweh will be happy if I give David the old holy bread that was in the tent of meeting last week; or

  • I just need to make sure that David and his men are pure before Yahweh and have not had sexual relations with women recently.

David answers Ahimelech and says that David and his men do not have sexual relations with women whenever they go on any common mission. Therefore, much more now, the men would keep "the vessels of the young men" holy and not have sexual relations before this mission. Ahimelech gives David old bread of the Presence or holy bread, which the priests had taken away from the table in the tabernacle.

Saul's servant, a man called Doeg from Edom who was Saul's chief herdsman, is also there at Nob. Doeg is there because some religious duty he needed to perform keeps Doeg before Yahweh at the tabernacle.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Doeg, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel curious and suspicious. What is David doing here without his men? or

  • Did King Saul send David on a mission by himself? Why is Ahimelech giving David the holy bread? or

  • I will remember what I have seen and perhaps tell the king when I see him.

David asks Ahimelech if Ahimelech has a spear or a sword David can have. Ahimelech says that he only has Goliath's sword, which David can have if David wants it. David accepts this sword as a weapon of greater value to David than any other.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so happy! I get to use the precious sword again! I cut Goliath's head off with this sword; or

  • This sword reminds me of Yahweh's faithfulness when Yahweh caused me to defeat the giant; or

  • I am feeling hopeful that Yahweh is with me now and will keep me safe from Saul.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 21:1–9 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Then David came to Nob, to Ahimelech the priest. The title priest here means the chief priest or the high priest. Use the same word or phrase for priest as you used in previous passages. For more information on priest, refer to the Master Glossary.

David said to Ahimelech that the king had sent David to perform a special mission.

David is talking about King Saul, who is the ruler of an entire nation. Use the same word or phrase for king as you used in previous passages. For more information on king, refer to the Master Glossary.

David said to Ahimelech, "And now, what do you have on hand?" What do you have on hand means, "What food do you have with you right now?"

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for "What do you have on hand?" If you have already translated this phrase in another book of the Bible, use the same phrase that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Ahimelech answered that Ahimelech had no common bread, but there was holy, or consecrated bread. Ahimelech checked that David and David's men had not had sexual relationships with women recently. Then Ahimelech gave David some of the bread of the presence, which people removed from before Yahweh and which they replaced with hot bread.

Common bread was ordinary bread that anyone could eat. Holy, or consecrated bread, also called the bread of the presence, refers to the bread which Yahweh commanded to be always in his presence in the tabernacle. The priests consecrated this bread, which means that the priests had made the bread holy. The bread of the presence was 12 large loaves of bread that the priests set in two rows on a table before Yahweh in the tabernacle. The 12 loaves likely symbolized the 12 tribes of Israel and how God always provided for his people, the Israelites. The Israelites brought the bread to the table as an act of thanksgiving for God's provision for the people. The priests put freshly baked bread on the table each Sabbath, and only the priests were allowed to eat the old bread.

Stop here and look as a group at a picture of the holy, or consecrated, bread. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for common bread, holy or consecrated bread, and the bread of the presence. Look up holy or consecrated in the Master Glossary. If you have already translated these phrases in another book of the Bible, use the same phrases that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Yahweh is God's personal name that appears throughout this passage. Use the same name for Yahweh that you have used in previous passages. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary.

Now, Doeg the Edomite was there that day. Doeg was working for King Saul as Saul's chief shepherd, overseeing the king's herdsmen. Use the same word or phrase for shepherd as you used in previous passages. For more information on shepherd, refer to the Master Glossary.

Then David asked Ahimelech if Ahimelech had a spear or a sword at hand. Use the same word or phrase for spear and sword as you used in previous passages.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a spear and a sword. Pause this audio here.

Ahimelech said to David that Ahimelech had the sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom David had killed in the Valley of Elah. This sword was wrapped in a cloth behind the ephod. Use the same word or phrase for ephod as you used before. For more information on ephod, refer to the Master Glossary.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 21:10–15
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 21:10–15 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 21:10–15 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 21:10–15 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous story, David ran away from King Saul to Nob, where Ahimelech the high priest was. David lied to Ahimelech and told him that David was on a special mission for the king. David asked Ahimelech for food and weapons. Ahimelech gave David holy bread from the tent of meeting and Goliath's sword.

Then David quickly left Nob that day as he continued to run away from Saul. David went to Achish, the king or ruler of the Philistine city of Gath, which was 37 kilometres southwest of Nob and far away from Saul. Perhaps David went there because the Philistines in Gath were also enemies of Saul, and maybe the people there would accept another of Saul's enemies. Achish was not the king of the land of the Philistines, but as a ruler of a main city, Achish was called the king of that city. Gath was one of five main Philistine cities, and the birthplace of Goliath. David wanted to hide from Saul in Gath and possibly work for Achish as a hired soldier. David was probably hoping that people in Gath would not recognise David because some years had passed since David had killed Goliath.

Stop here and look as a group at a map that shows David's journey from Nob to Gath. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What is the official title for leaders of cities in your people group? Pause this audio here.

But the servants or officials of King Achish recognised David as "the king of the land" and the one whom the Israelite people honoured with dances, singing, "Saul has killed his thousands, and David his ten thousands." The officials called David "king of the land" not because they knew that Yahweh had chosen David to be the next king of Israel, but because the officials remembered David's success when he killed Goliath. The officials also quoted the song that women sang about David's war victories to show Achish how strong David was. David's strength could be a danger to Achish.

And David took these words to heart, or paid attention to what the officials of Achish said about David. David became afraid of Achish because the song about David implied that David was a threat to Achish. Since David was alone, David was afraid that Achish might kill him because Achish would be afraid of David.

So, because of David's fear, David changed his behaviour while Achish and Achish's servants were watching. David pretended to be insane and acted differently than usual when he was in their hands, or when the Philistines tried to restrain David. To make the people of Gath think that David was insane, David made marks on the gates to the city or the gates of Achish's palace by either scratching or clawing. David also let his saliva, or water from his mouth, run down into David's beard.

Stop here and discuss as a group how insane people act in your culture. Tell a story of someone who pretended to be insane but who was not really insane. Pause this audio here.

When Achish saw how David was behaving, Achish spoke to his officials, who had first recognised David. Achish said that David was acting insanely and asked why the officials had brought David to Achish. Achish felt there were many crazy or insane people in Gath, and therefore, Achish did not need David there as well. Achish was speaking angrily and in a mocking way. Achish was saying that his officials were fools for being afraid of a crazy man. Achish certainly was not interested and did not care what David the crazy man did, because Achish thought David was crazy. Achish definitely did not want David in his house.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 21:10–15 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has four scenes.

In the first scene: David quickly leaves Nob that day as he continues to flee from Saul. David goes to Achish, the king or ruler of Gath.

In the second scene: The servants or officials of Achish recognise David as the "king of the land." The officials even remember the song people sang about David's war victories.

In the third scene: David pays attention to what Achish's officials say about David. David is afraid that King Achish may kill David. David changes his behaviour and pretends to be insane when the men try to restrain David. David makes scratch marks on the city or palace gates and David lets his saliva run down his beard.

In the fourth scene: Achish mocks his officials and asks the officials why they brought David to Achish. Achish feels there are many crazy people in Gath, and therefore, David is unimportant and just another crazy person. Achish does not need David there as well.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • Achish, the king or ruler of Gath

  • And officials of King Achish

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

Then David "rose" and fled Nob that day as David continued to run away from Saul. The word "rose" does not mean that David was sitting, but it shows that David acted quickly and decisively. David went to Achish, the king or ruler of the city of Gath. Gath was 37 kilometers southwest of Nob, and it would have taken David a whole day to walk to Gath.

Stop here and look as a group at a map showing David's journey from Nob to Gath. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How are you going to describe Achish's official title as the ruler of the city of Gath? Pause this audio here.

But the servants or officials of King Achish recognised David. The officials asked, "Is not this David the king of the land? Did they not sing to one another of him in dances, 'Saul has killed thousands of people, and David has killed tens of thousands'?" The officials did not expect anyone to answer these questions. The officials asked these questions to strongly say that they believed the man who came to their city, Gath, was in fact David. The words of the song show that Saul has killed thousands of people in battles. However, David has killed tens of thousands of people.

Stop here and remember how you translated this song in previous stories in 1 Samuel. Pause this audio here.

David took these words to heart, or paid attention to what the officials of Achish said about David. David became afraid that Achish might kill him because David was a danger to Achish. So, because of his fear, David changed his behaviour while Achish and Achish's servants were watching. David pretended to be insane and acted abnormally when David was in their hands. The phrase "in their hands" has a number of possible meanings. One interpretation is that David acted like a madman when the officials tried to restrain David. The other interpretation is that David acted insane when he was nearby, or in the presence of the officials. David made marks on the gates to the city or the gates of Achish's palace by either scratching or clawing. David also let his saliva run down into David's beard.

When Achish saw how David was behaving, Achish spoke to his officials, who had first recognized David. Achish said that David was acting insanely and asked why the officials had brought David to Achish. Achish said, "Do I lack madmen, that you have brought this fellow to behave as a madman in my presence? Shall this fellow come into my house?" Achish asked questions he did not expect anyone to answer to stress that Achish had madmen, or crazy people, already in his city. Achish said he would not need David there as well since David was unimportant and not dangerous. Achish asked, "Must this man come into my house?" Achish did not want his officials to let David into Achish's house. Achish spoke in an angry and mocking manner.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 21:10–15 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has four scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • Achish, the king or ruler of Gath

  • And officials of King Achish

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

David quickly leaves Nob that day as he continues to run away from Saul. David goes to Achish, the king or ruler of Gath.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel relieved! I have food and weapons. I can continue on my way; or

  • Where can I go? I am desperate. I will go to the Philistine city of Gath. Surely Saul will not look for me there; or

  • I will ask the king of Gath if I can work for him as a soldier. So many years have passed since I killed Goliath. Surely the Philistines will not recognise me.

The officials of Achish recognise David as the "king of the land," the man about whom people sing songs and dance to celebrate his war victories.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the officials of Achish, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are scared. This is David, who killed Goliath the giant! Women sang a song about David's victories over our people; or

  • What is David doing in our city? David is a dangerous man of war! or

  • We must warn King Achish.

David pays attention to what the officials of Achish said about him. David is afraid that King Achish may kill David. David changes his behaviour and pretends to be insane when the men try to restrain him. David makes scratch marks on the city or palace gates, and David lets his saliva run down his beard.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am really worried! The officials recognised me! What do I do now? Achish will want to kill me! or

  • Perhaps I should pretend to be insane? Maybe they will not kill me then; or

  • I will dribble and act crazy. This is my only hope in this situation.

Achish mocks his officials and asks the men why they brought David to Achish. Achish feels there are too many crazy people in Gath who are unimportant and not dangerous. Achish thinks David is unimportant and not dangerous. Achish certainly does not want David in Achish's house.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 21:10–15 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Then David quickly left Nob that day as he continued to run away from Saul. David went to Achish, the king or ruler of a Philistine city, Gath. Use the same word or phrase for king as you used in previous passages when you talked about the king of a city. For more information on king, refer to the Master Glossary.

Someone who is insane, or crazy, is someone who does not act like a normal person. An insane person may not have control over that person's own actions.

Stop here and discuss as a group the best way to describe David as insane. Remember that David was not really insane, but David acted like he was. Pause this audio here.

But the servants or officials of King Achish recognised David as "the king of the land" and the one that people honoured with dances, singing, "Saul has killed his thousands, and David his ten thousands." In this case, the servants are really officials who serve the king. Use the same word or phrase for servant as you used in previous passages, when the servants are officials of a king. For more information on servant, refer to the Master Glossary.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
