title: 1 Samuel 22:1–10
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 22:1–10 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 22:1–10 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 22:1–10 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous story, David continued to run away from Saul. After David left the high priest Ahimelech in the city of Nob, David went to Achish, the king of the Philistine city of Gath. However, the officials of Achish recognised David. David pretended to be insane so that the king would not kill David.

David ran away from the Philistine city of Gath because David was afraid of Achish, the king of Gath. David found refuge in a cave near the city of Adullam in the territory that belonged to the tribe of Judah. Adullam was 16 kilometres southeast of Gath and 16 kilometres southwest of Bethlehem, David's birth town. When David's seven brothers and the rest of his father's household heard where David went, they came from Bethlehem to join David in Adullam, because now they were in danger from Saul. David's father's household included all the living descendants of David's father, plus David's mother and the family slaves. Female descendants who were married were not part of the household anymore.

Stop here and look at the map as a group. Identify David's journey from Gath to the cave of Adullam and David's family's journey from Bethlehem to the cave of Adullam. Pause this audio here.

When people heard that David was in the cave of Adullam hiding from Saul, many people went to David. They were people in any kind of trouble. They were people who owed money to other people. They were people who were bitter in their souls, or discontent, because they had suffered some kind of loss or because they were without something that they wanted or needed. There were about 400 of these men, and David became their military leader. These men wanted a change in their lives, and they were willing to follow David and do anything for David.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Who or what kind of people usually join a person who rebels against the government to fight alongside that person? Pause this audio here.

David took his elderly parents from the cave to the city of Mizpeh in the country of Moab, east of the Dead Sea. The name Mizpeh means watchtower or mountain height. We do not know where in Moab the city of Mizpeh was, but its name suggests it was probably on top of a mountain. David asked the king of Moab to allow David's parents to stay in Mizpeh with the king. David was afraid that Saul would harm his parents if David's parents remained in Israel. In seeking protection for his parents and looking after them, David was following common ancient custom and obeying the fifth commandment that Yahweh gave to Moses. David's ancestor Ruth was from the land of Moab, so Moab was a good place for David's parents to find refuge. David's parents would not necessarily live in the same house as the king, but they would live in the same city, close enough for the king to protect David's parents. David told the king of Moab that David wanted his parents to stay there until David knew what God would do for David. This way, David showed the Moabite king David's belief that God controlled David's future. David was sure that David's cause was just and that Saul was attacking David unfairly. David confidently hoped that God would give David safety again.

Stop here and look at the map as a group. Identify David's journey from the cave of Adullam to the city of Mizpeh in Moab. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and tell a story of a time when you or someone you know did something to protect their parents. Pause this audio here.

The king of Moab agreed to David's request, and David left his parents with the king. David's parents stayed there all the time David was in the stronghold, but it is not clear how long that was. We are not sure where the stronghold was. A "stronghold" is any place that is difficult to attack or capture. The stronghold may have been the city of Mizpeh or a different place in Moab. We can see from what the prophet Gad says to David next that the "stronghold" was probably not the cave near Adullam in the territory of the tribe of Judah.

There was a prophet named Gad in Israel at that time. The prophet warned David not to remain in the stronghold but to leave the stronghold and go to the land of the tribe of Judah. From then on, Gad would tell David Yahweh's word and advise David, just like Samuel told Yahweh's word to Saul. So David left and went to the forest of Hereth in the land of the tribe of Judah. We do not know exactly where the forest was.

Stop here and look at the map as a group. Identify David's journey from Moab to the forest of Hereth in the land of the tribe of Judah. Pause this audio here.

One day, Saul was in the city of Gibeah, which was where Saul lived. Saul was sitting under a tamarisk tree on a hilltop, with his spear in his hand, and all Saul's officers were standing around Saul. A tamarisk tree is a tree that grows up to eighteen metres in height and has delicate, needle-like leaves and small, pink or white flowers. It is a good shade tree because it rarely loses its leaves. The storyteller says that Saul was sitting under a specific tamarisk tree. Saul held his important meeting with his officers at a well-known place where Saul usually held council. The spear in Saul's hand showed that Saul was the king.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a tamarisk tree. Pause this audio here.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a king's spear. Pause the audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: In your culture, what special clothes or items would a king wear or hold during special occasions to show that he is the king of the country? If your country does not have a king, talk about special clothes or items that a leader of your country would have to show their high position. Pause this audio here.

Someone told Saul that some of Saul's men had seen David and David's men. Possibly someone saw David and David's men going to the forest or living in the forest. Saul thought that David was trying to kill Saul and become king himself. Saul also thought that Saul's officials were secretly supporting David. Saul reacted to the news by speaking to Saul's men. Saul called his men the "men of Benjamin." Saul was one of the members of the tribe of Benjamin, and Saul had chosen men from the tribe of Benjamin to serve Saul as his government and military officials. David, however, was from the tribe of Judah. Saul asked his men if the son of Jesse, or David, would give all of his men fields and vineyards. Saul did not expect anyone to answer this question. Saul was being sarcastic. Saul used a question to strongly say that David would not give the men of Benjamin fields and vineyards. Saul had chosen men from his own tribe of Benjamin to be Saul's officials, and Saul rewarded the men with land. Saul was assuming that David would also choose men from David's own tribe, Judah, to be David's officials and that David would reward those men with gifts of land. Saul called David "the son of Jesse" instead of using his name to show that Saul despised David.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do government leaders in your people group choose their officials? What makes government leaders either favour or not favour people from your tribe or area? Pause this audio here.

Saul also asked if the son of Jesse would make all the men commanders of thousands of soldiers and commanders of hundreds of soldiers. Saul was not expecting anyone to answer this question either. Saul was saying that David would not choose men from the tribe of Benjamin to be his military commanders. If Saul's officials thought David would choose them, the officials were quite wrong.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Talk about what levels of military commanders your people group's army has. Pause this audio here.

Saul asked his men if this was why Saul's men plotted against Saul. Saul did not expect anyone to answer. Saul was being sarcastic again. Saul did not believe that David would give the Benjamite men land and important positions, and Saul thought his Benjamite officials were therefore being foolish to support David.

Saul was not happy that no one told Saul when his son made a covenant with the son of Jesse. Saul was talking about his oldest son, Jonathan, and the agreement that Jonathan had made with David regarding their friendship and the friendship of their families. Someone must have told Saul about the covenant, but apparently, it was not one of Saul's officials who told Saul. Saul accused his men of not feeling sorry for Saul, because the men did not inform Saul that his son Jonathan had stirred up Saul's servant David to wait secretly for an opportunity to kill Saul. Saul thought that David was hiding in the forest at that very moment to make a surprise attack on Saul, but it was not the truth.

Then Doeg the Edomite, one of Saul's servants, spoke. Doeg was a foreigner from the country of Edom, and Doeg was Saul's chief shepherd. Doeg said that he saw the son of Jesse coming to the city of Nob, to Ahimelech the priest, son of Ahitub. Doeg was retelling the events he probably would have witnessed when Doeg was in Nob. Doeg said that Ahimelech asked Yahweh what David should do. Probably Ahimelech would have consulted Yahweh through the ephod, which contains the Urim and Thummim. The Urim and Thummim were two objects the high priest used to determine Yahweh's will. Doeg also told Saul that Ahimelech gave David food provisions and the sword of Goliath the Philistine. Everything that Doeg told Saul sounded to Saul like Ahimelech was helping David in military preparations against Saul.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 22:1–10 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has six scenes.

In the first scene: David flees Gath and finds refuge in a cave near the city of Adullam. When David's seven brothers and the rest of David's father's household hear where David went, they come from Bethlehem to join David in Adullam.

In the second scene: About 400 men join David in the cave near Adullam, and David becomes these men's military leader. These men are rebels who are unhappy, have suffered losses, or whom others mistreated.

In the third scene: David takes his elderly parents from the cave of Adullam to the city of Mizpeh in the country of Moab. David asks the king of Moab to allow David's parents to stay in Mizpeh with the king until God works out his plans for David. David leaves his parents with the king of Moab, and David's parents stay there all the time David is in the stronghold.

In the fourth scene: A prophet named Gad warns David not to remain in the stronghold but to leave and go to the land of the tribe of Judah. David leaves and goes to the forest of Hereth in the land of the tribe of Judah.

In the fifth scene: Saul and his officials are on a hilltop where Saul usually holds council. Someone tells Saul that some of Saul's men had seen David and David's men. Saul thinks that David is trying to kill Saul and become king himself, and that Saul's officials are secretly supporting David. Saul mocks his officials and tells the men that they should not expect that the son of Jesse will give them privileges of land and important positions. Saul accuses his officials of not telling Saul about a covenant that his son Jonathan made with David. Saul also accuses his officials of not feeling sorry for Saul and not informing him that, apparently, Jonathan stirred up David to wait for an opportunity to kill Saul.

In the sixth scene: Doeg the Edomite tells Saul that Doeg saw the son of Jessie coming to Nob, to Ahimelech the priest. Doeg says that Ahimelech asked Yahweh what David should do and gave David food provisions and the sword of Goliath the Philistine.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • David's brothers

  • The rest of David's father's house, including David's mother, all of David's father's descendants except David's married sisters, plus all the slaves or servants

  • About 400 men who joined David to be in his army

  • The king of Moab

  • The prophet Gad

  • King Saul

  • Saul's officials who were with Saul

  • And Doeg the Edomite

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

David fled the Philistine city of Gath and found refuge in a cave near the city of Adullam in the territory that belonged to the tribe of Judah. Adullam was 16 kilometers southeast of Gath and 16 kilometers southwest of Bethlehem, David's birth town. When David's seven brothers and the rest of David's father's household heard where David went, they came from Bethlehem to join David in the cave of Adullam.

Stop here and look at the map as a group. Identify David's journey from Gath to the cave of Adullam and David's family's journey from Bethlehem to the cave of Adullam. Pause this audio here.

When people heard that David was in the cave of Adullam hiding from Saul, about four hundred men joined David, and David became their military leader. These men were rebels in any kind of trouble, people who owed money to other people, and people who were bitter in their souls because they had suffered some kind of loss or because they were without something that they wanted or needed. These are examples of the problems these men had, but we do not know exactly what problems they actually had. However, these men were bitter of soul, or very discontent and unhappy with their lives.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do you describe people like that, who are always bitter and not content? Pause this audio here.

David took his elderly parents from the cave to the city of Mizpeh in the country of Moab, east of the Dead Sea. David made a polite request to the king of Moab to allow David's parents to stay in Mizpeh with the king. David told the king of Moab that David wanted his parents to stay there until David knew what God would do for David. David used the general word for God rather than God's personal name, "Yahweh," because David was talking to a non-Israelite king.

Stop here and look at the map as a group. Identify David's journey from the cave of Adullam to the city of Mizpeh in Moab. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What words do you use in your language when you talk about God to a believer and to a non-believer? Pause this audio here.

David left his parents with the king of Moab. David's parents stayed in Moab all the time David was in the stronghold, but it is not clear how long that was. We are not sure where the stronghold was. We can see from what the prophet Gad says to David next that the stronghold was probably not in the territory of the tribe of Judah. If the stronghold was not in the territory of the tribe of Judah, at some point, David's men would have probably left the cave of Adullam and joined David at the stronghold.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What does a stronghold look like in your area? What do you call these places that have strong defenses, like a surrounding wall or barrier, and soldiers guarding it? Pause this audio here.

A prophet named Gad warned David not to remain in the stronghold but to leave and go to the land of the tribe of Judah. We are not sure if Gad was staying with David or if Gad came from somewhere else. So David left and went to the forest of Hereth in the land of the tribe of Judah. We do not know exactly where the forest was. If David's men had joined David at the stronghold, then the men probably would have gone with David.

Stop here and look at the map as a group. Identify David's journey from Moab to the forest of Hereth in the land of the tribe of Judah. Pause this audio here.

As the storyteller tells the story, he uses language that shows the listener that the storyteller is changing scenes. Now the storyteller is talking about Saul in Gibeah. One day, Saul was in Saul's city, Gibeah. Saul was sitting under a tamarisk tree on a hilltop where Saul usually held council. Saul had a spear in his hand, and all Saul's servants or officials were standing around Saul. Although the original language uses the word servants for Saul's officials, these are not servants in the normal way. These are officials, or advisors and leaders, in Saul's government. As leaders, these men serve their king, Saul. Saul was holding an important meeting. Someone told Saul that some of Saul's men had seen David and David's men. Saul thought that David was trying to kill Saul and become king himself. Saul also thought that Saul's officials were secretly supporting David. Saul spoke to Saul's men. Saul addressed his men as "men of Benjamin" and asked them if the son of Jesse would give all of the men fields and vineyards. Saul also asked if the son of Jesse would make all the men commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds. Saul was not expecting anyone to answer Saul's questions. Saul spoke sarcastically to his men and made a strong point that David, who was from the tribe of Judah, would not give Benjamite men privileges of land and important positions. Saul asked his men if this was why the men plotted against Saul. Saul did not expect anyone to answer. Saul was speaking sarcastically and accusing the men again. Saul did not believe that David would give the Benjamites land and important positions, and Saul thought his Benjamite officials were therefore being foolish to support David.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Saul mocked his men by asking questions that did not require an answer but that acted as pointed statements. Saul mocked David by not referring to David by name but by calling David "the son of Jesse." Discuss different ways people mock or insult others in your language. Pause this audio here.

Saul was not happy that no one told Saul when Saul's son made a covenant with the son of Jesse. Someone must have told Saul about the covenant, but apparently it was not one of Saul's officials. Saul accused his men of not feeling sorry for Saul, because they did not inform Saul that, apparently, Saul's son Jonathan stirred up his servant David to wait secretly for an opportunity to kill Saul. Saul thought that David was hiding in the forest at that very moment to make a surprise attack on Saul.

Then Doeg the Edomite, who oversaw Saul's shepherds, said that Doeg saw the son of Jessie coming to Nob, to Ahimelech the priest, son of Ahitub. Doeg said that Ahimelech inquired of Yahweh for David and gave David food provisions and the sword of Goliath the Philistine. However, everything that Doeg told Saul sounded like Ahimelech was helping David in military preparations against Saul.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 22:1–10 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has six scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • David's brothers

  • The rest of David's father's house, including David's mother, all of David's father's descendants except David's married sisters, plus all the slaves or servants

  • About 400 men who joined David to be his army

  • The king of Moab

  • The prophet Gad

  • King Saul

  • Saul's officials who were with Saul

  • And Doeg the Edomite

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

David fled the city of Gath and found refuge in a cave near the city of Adullam. When David's brothers and the rest of David's father's household heard where David went, they came to join David in the cave of Adullam.

When other people heard that David was in the cave of Adullam, about 400 men joined David, and David became their military leader. These men were rebels in any kind of trouble. They were people who owed money to other people. The men were people who were bitter in their souls because they had suffered some kind of loss or because they were without something that they wanted or needed.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am not safe near Saul, and I am not safe near King Achish of Gath. The cave of Adullam will be a good hiding place! or

  • I am so glad my family has joined me, as Saul will probably try to kill them too! Perhaps I should take my parents to stay with the king of Moab, as their ancestors came from Moab. I need to look after my parents; or

  • Look at all the rebels joining me! Maybe Yahweh brought these men to me to be my army, and I will be their leader!

David took his elderly parents from the cave to the city of Mizpeh in the country of Moab. David asked the king of Moab to allow David's parents to stay in Mizpeh with the king. David told the king of Moab that David wanted his parents to stay there until David knew what God would do for David. David left his parents with the king of Moab, and David's parents stayed there all the time David was in the stronghold.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David's parents, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are happy that David is a good son and that David is looking after us; or

  • We are relieved that we will be safe from Saul in Moab. The king of Moab will take care of us; or

  • We are worried about David. Saul wants to kill David.

A prophet named Gad warned David not to remain in the stronghold but to leave and go to the land of the tribe of Judah. So David left and went to the forest of Hereth in the land of the tribe of Judah.

One day, Saul was in Saul's city, Gibeah. Saul was sitting under a tamarisk tree on a hilltop where Saul usually held council. Saul had a spear in his hand, and all Saul's officers were standing around Saul. Saul was holding an important meeting. Someone told Saul that some of Saul's men had seen David and David's men. Saul thought that David was trying to kill Saul and become king himself. Saul also thought that Saul's officials were secretly supporting David. Saul spoke sarcastically to his men. Saul asked the men if the son of Jesse would give all of the men fields and vineyards. Saul also asked if the son of Jesse would make all the men commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds. Saul asked his men if this was why they plotted against Saul. Saul did not believe that David would give the Benjamites land and important positions, and Saul thought his Benjamite officials were therefore being stupid to support David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I knew that the son of Jesse wanted to kill me, so he could become king! or

  • And even my own officers are helping David! Nobody tells me anything! Even my own son Jonathan made a covenant with David, and none of my officials warned me about it! I feel betrayed by everyone; or

  • I am worried now. I must find a way to keep my men from betraying me. Don't these foolish Benjamites realise that they will be unimportant in David's army? David will reward his own men with land and rank, because those men come from the tribe of Judah, like David does.

Saul was not happy that no one told Saul when Saul's son made a covenant with the son of Jesse. Saul accused his men of not feeling sorry for Saul, because the men did not inform Saul that, apparently, Saul's son Jonathan had stirred up his servant David to wait secretly for an opportunity to kill Saul. Saul thought that David was hiding in the forest at that very moment to make a surprise attack on Saul.

Then Doeg the Edomite said that he saw the son of Jessie coming to Nob, to Ahimelech the priest, son of Ahitub. Doeg said that Ahimelech talked with Yahweh for David and gave David food provisions and the sword of Goliath the Philistine.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Doeg the Edomite, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I have some information about David that Saul will like. I was clearly at the right place at the right time when I saw Ahimelech help David; or

  • Saul will think highly of me when I tell him what I saw in Nob; or

  • I will tell Saul that Ahimelech the priest advised David what to do and gave him food and Goliath's sword. It truly looks like Ahimelech is supporting David.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 22:1–10 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

David went from the cave of Adullam to Mizpeh in Moab and asked the king of Moab if David's parents could stay with the king until David knew what God would do for David.

Use the same word or phrase for God as you used in previous passages. For more information on God, refer to the Master Glossary.

The king in this story is the king of a whole area called Moab. Use the same word or phrase for king as you used in previous passages. For more information on king, refer to the Master Glossary.

After David left his parents with the king of Moab, David stayed in a stronghold. Then the prophet Gad told David not to remain in the stronghold but to go to the land of the tribe of Judah.

A stronghold is a place that is well-protected and difficult to attack or take over. A stronghold can be a building that people make like a fortress or castle, or it can refer to a cave in the wilderness that offers safety and security. Here, stronghold means a man-made fortified building.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for stronghold, meaning a man-made fortified building. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. For more information on stronghold, refer to the Master Glossary. Pause this audio here.

Use the same word or phrase for prophet as you used in previous passages. For more information on prophet, refer to the Master Glossary.

One day, Saul was sitting on a hilltop in Gibeah under a tamarisk tree. Saul had Saul's spear in his hand, and all Saul's servants were standing near Saul. A tamarisk tree is a tree that grows up to 18 metres in height and has delicate needle-like leaves and small, pink or white flowers. A tamarisk is a good shade tree because it rarely loses its leaves.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a tamarisk tree. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for tamarisk tree. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Here, the word servants refers to the officials in Saul's government, not to slaves. However, these officials do serve Saul. You may use the word officials in your translation if you would like. Use the same word for servants or officials of the king as you have used in previous passages. If you use the word for servant, see the Master Glossary for more information.

Here, the word spear refers to the king's spear. Saul's spear would likely be larger, more ornate, and better crafted than those of ordinary soldiers. People would make Saul's spear from higher-quality materials. The spear might include symbols or markings that represent the tribe of Benjamin, Saul's family, or Saul's authority as the anointed king of Israel. Since this spear belonged to Saul, the makers of the spear could have made it unique in some way, such as having a unique shape, balance, or other features that set it apart from standard spears. Use the same word or phrase for spear that you have used in previous passages.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a king's spear. Pause the audio here.

And Saul said to his servants who stood around Saul, "Hear now, people of Benjamin; will the son of Jesse give every one of you fields and vineyards, will he make you all commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds? Is that why you all conspired against me?"

Use the same word or phrase for vineyards as you used in previous passages. For more information on vineyards, refer to the Master Glossary.

Use the same word or phrase for army commanders as you have used before.

Stop here and discuss as a group if you have special words or phrases in your language for commanders of hundreds of soldiers and commanders of thousands of soldiers. If you do, then you can use them here. If you do not have them in your language, decide what words or phrases you will use. Pause this audio here.

Doeg the Edomite told Saul that Doeg saw David at Nob coming to see Ahimelech the priest and that Ahimelech talked with Yahweh for David and gave David food provisions and Goliath's sword. Yahweh is God's personal name, and Yahweh is used throughout this passage. Use the same name for Yahweh that you have used in previous passages. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 22:11–23
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 22:11–23 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 22:11–23 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 22:11–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous passage, David continued to flee from Saul and went to a cave near the city of Adullam in the territory of the tribe of Judah. David's family joined David at the cave, as well as 400 rebels. David took his parents to Mizpeh in Moab so that David's parents could stay in safety with the king of Moab. David stayed in a stronghold until the prophet Gad advised David to go to the land of the tribe of Judah. So David went to the forest of Hereth. In the meantime, King Saul accused his officials of plotting with David and not keeping Saul informed of what David was doing. Doeg the Edomite, Saul's chief shepherd, told Saul that Doeg had seen Ahimelech the high priest in the city of Nob talk with Yahweh for David and give David food provisions and Goliath's sword.

After hearing Doeg the Edomite's story of David's time with Ahimelech, King Saul sent a message to Ahimelech, the priest, the son of Ahitub. The title "priest" here means the chief priest or the high priest. Saul told Ahimelech that Saul wanted to see Ahimelech and all his father's house. Ahimelech's "father's house" referred to all the adult male descendants of Ahimelech's father. All of these men were priests in the city of Nob. All the priests in the city of Nob were Ahimelech's brothers or sons. So all the priests obeyed Saul and went to see Saul in Gibeah. Gibeah was eight kilometers northwest of the city of Nob.

Stop here as a group and look at a map that shows the priests' journey from Nob to Gibeah. Pause this audio here.

Then Saul spoke to Ahimelech in an angry and mocking way and said, "Listen now, son of Ahitub." Ahimelech replied and said, "Here I am, my lord." "My lord" was a general term of respect that people used for any ruler or master. Then Saul asked Ahimelech a long question that Saul did not expect anyone to answer. The question was really a series of statements accusing Ahimelech of plotting with David against Saul. Saul said that Ahimelech and the son of Jesse were plotting against Saul. Saul referred to David by David's father's name to show that Saul did not respect David at all. Saul accused Ahimelech of helping David to rebel against Saul because Ahimelech gave David bread and a sword and talked with God for David. Saul was convinced that even as he was speaking to Ahimelech, David was waiting for an opportunity to kill Saul.

Ahimelech answered Saul and asked Saul a long question that was really a few small questions that Ahimelech did not expect Saul to answer. Ahimelech used this question to make several statements to prove that Ahimelech had been loyal to Saul. Ahimelech implied that the king's accusations could not be true. Ahimelech asked Saul, "And who among all your servants is so faithful as David?" Ahimelech considered David to be better than any of the other servants of Saul. Ahimelech could not understand why Saul would think that David was not loyal to Saul. Ahimelech asked Saul if this had been the first time that Ahimelech had talked to God for David. This was another question that did not require an answer. Ahimelech was saying that Ahimelech often talked with God for David, and Saul had not been concerned before. It was normal for Ahimelech to ask questions of Yahweh for David, because David had a high position in Saul's court. Ahimelech told Saul that Saul should not consider Ahimelech the king's servant and Ahimelech's family to be guilty of any wrongdoing. Ahimelech truthfully denied that he knew anything about David's plot against Saul.

But Saul refused to listen to Ahimelech. Saul said that Ahimelech and all Ahimelech's father's family, all the priests at Nob, were certainly going to die. Saul was going to have someone kill these men.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Think about the history of your people group. Discuss situations from the past when a ruler killed or put innocent people in prison because the ruler feared that other people would overthrow the ruler. Pause this audio here.

The king told his guards, who stood near the king, to surround and kill the priests who served Yahweh. Saul told the guards that the priests had also, like everybody else, supported or helped David. Saul said that although the priests knew that David had run away, the priests had not told Saul. But the king's guardsmen refused to obey Saul's order to kill the priests of Yahweh. As the king of Israel, Saul's responsibility was to encourage people to follow God's laws and respect the priests, as the priests were responsible for offering sacrifices, teaching the people, and praying to God to help the people of Israel. The guardsmen probably thought that the sentence was unjust, and the guards feared Yahweh more than they feared the king.

Then Saul commanded Doeg the Edomite to go and kill the priests. So Doeg went and attacked the priests. That day, Doeg killed 85 people who wore the linen ephod. The linen ephod was a plain, probably white, linen robe, which only priests wore. The priest's ephod was very different from the high priest's ephod, which was a highly decorated piece of clothing. The high priest wore the ephod in the tent of meeting when he served Yahweh. Since the people who Doeg the Edomite killed wore linen ephods, this means that Doeg killed 85 priests. Doeg was a foreigner from a country that people called Edom, which may be why Doeg did not have as much respect for priests and was willing to kill the priests.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a priest wearing an ephod. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Talk about tasks or responsibilities that the authorities in your people group have given to foreigners because people from your people group did not want to do those tasks. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Here, the passage identifies priests as "people who wore the linen ephod." What kinds of professions in your culture can you clearly identify and name by what the people in that profession wear? Pause this audio here.

And Doeg the Edomite also killed everyone else who lived in the city of Nob, the city of priests. Nob was a central religious centre in Saul's kingdom. Nob was where the ark of the covenant probably was, at least for a while. Yet Saul treated Nob like some enemy city against which Saul started a holy war. Saul wanted to destroy the city and everything in it. Doeg killed both men and women, children, babies, and the livestock, including oxen, donkeys, and sheep. Doeg did not necessarily slaughter all the townspeople himself. Doeg could have had Doeg's own followers and relatives with Doeg.

Doeg killed everyone in Nob except Abiathar, one of Ahimelech's sons. Abiathar escaped and ran to David to join David's group of supporters. After Abiathar had caught up with David, Abiathar told David that Saul had killed Yahweh's priests. Abiathar would have given David a detailed account of what happened.

David told Abiathar that from the moment David had seen Doeg the Edomite in Nob, David had known that Doeg would tell Saul that David had been to see Ahimelech. David confessed to Abiathar that David himself was ultimately responsible for Saul killing Abiathar's family. Although it was Doeg the Edomite who killed the priests, David felt that, through David's earlier presence at Nob, David was guilty of causing the priests' death.

David told Abiathar not to be afraid and to stay with David. Abiathar and David now had the same enemy, Saul, who wanted to kill them both. David said that David would protect Abiathar, so before Saul could kill Abiathar, Saul would first have to kill David.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 22:11–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has seven scenes.

In the first scene: King Saul summons Ahimelech, the high priest, and Ahimelech's father's house to come and see Saul. So, Ahimelech and all his father's descendants, who are the priests in the city of Nob, travel to Gibeah to see the king.

In the second scene: Saul speaks to Ahimelech and accuses Ahimelech of conspiring with David against Saul.

In the third scene: Ahimelech tells the king that the king should not consider Ahimelech and Ahimelech's family to be guilty of any wrongdoing. Ahimelech truthfully denies that he knew anything about David's plot against Saul.

In the fourth scene: Saul refuses to listen to Ahimelech's defense. Saul says that Ahimelech and all Ahimelech's father's family, all the priests at Nob, were certainly going to die.

In the fifth scene: The king tells the king's guards to surround and kill the priests who served Yahweh. The king's guardsmen refuse to carry out the king's order to kill the priests. Saul commands Doeg the Edomite to go and kill the priests, and Doeg kills 85 priests that day. Doeg also kills all the men, women, children, babies, and livestock in the city of Nob.

In the sixth scene: Abiathar, one of Ahimelech's sons, escapes from Nob and flees to David to join David's group of supporters. Abiathar tells David that Saul killed Yahweh's priests. David says that David himself is ultimately responsible for the murder of Abiathar's family.

In the seventh scene: David tells Abiathar not to be afraid and to stay with David. Abiathar and David now have the same enemy, Saul, who wants to kill them both. David says that David will protect Abiathar.

The characters in this passage are:

  • King Saul

  • Ahimelech the high priest

  • Ahimelech's father's household, which consisted of all Ahimelech's father's male descendants, who were all the priests in the city of Nob

  • Saul's guardsmen

  • Doeg the Edomite

  • Everyone in the city of Nob, including the men, women, children, and babies

  • All the livestock in the city of Nob

  • Abiathar, one of Ahimelech's sons

  • And David

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

After hearing Doeg the Edomite's story of David's time with Ahimelech, King Saul sent a message to Ahimelech, the high priest, in the city of Nob. Saul told Ahimelech that Saul wanted to see Ahimelech and all of Ahimelech's father's house, which means all Ahimelech's relatives who descended from Ahimelech's father, whether or not they lived together. These men were Ahimelech's brothers and their sons, who were all priests from Nob. So all the priests obeyed and went to see Saul in Gibeah. Gibeah was eight kilometers northwest of the city of Nob.

Stop here as a group and look at a map that shows the priests' journey from Nob to Gibeah. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What words or phrases do people use in your language to describe family members as a group? What words do you use to describe immediate family and extended family? What words do you use to describe family members who live in the same house? Pause this audio here.

Then Saul spoke to Ahimelech, "Listen now, son of Ahitub." The phrase "Listen now" would normally mean, "listen please." However, since Saul was very angry, Saul was probably speaking in a mocking way. Saul was angry when he called Ahimelech "son of Ahitub" rather than by Ahimelech's name. This phrase was an insulting rather than polite way to address someone. Ahimelech replied, "Here I am, my lord." "My lord" was a general term of respect that people used for any ruler or master.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What are the polite ways of referring to a king or an important leader in your people group? How do people in authority talk to their subjects when they are angry with those subjects? Pause this audio here.

Then Saul asked Ahimelech a long question that Saul did not expect anyone to answer. The question was really a series of statements accusing Ahimelech of plotting with David against Saul. Saul said that Ahimelech and the son of Jesse were plotting against Saul. Saul referred to David by David's father's name to show that Saul did not respect David at all. Saul accused Ahimelech of helping David to rebel against Saul because Ahimelech gave David bread and a sword and inquired of God for David. Saul was convinced that even as Saul was speaking to Ahimelech, David was waiting for an opportunity to kill Saul.

Ahimelech asked Saul a long question that was really a few short questions that did not require an answer. Ahimelech used this question to make several statements to affirm that Ahimelech had been loyal to Saul. Ahimelech implied that the king's accusations could not be true. Ahimelech asked Saul, "And who among all your servants is so faithful as David?" Ahimelech considered David to be better than any of the other servants of Saul. Ahimelech referred to David respectfully by David's name, in contrast to Saul, who called David "the son of Jesse." Ahimelech asked the king, "Who is the king's son-in-law?" Ahimelech was stressing that the king had given the king's own daughter to David in marriage. Ahimelech asked Saul, "Who is the captain over the king's bodyguard?" Ahimelech was saying that Saul had put David in charge of the officials who were guarding Saul's life. Ahimelech asked the king, "Who do people highly honour in your house?" Ahimelech was saying that all the members of the king's household highly respected David. Ahimelech asked Saul if this was the first time that Ahimelech had talked with God for David. This was another question that did not require an answer. Ahimelech was saying that it was normal for Ahimelech to talk with God for David, because David had a high position in Saul's court. Ahimelech told Saul that Saul should not consider Ahimelech the king's servant and Ahimelech's family to be guilty of any wrongdoing. By referring to himself as "the king's servant," Ahimelech spoke to the king in a humble and polite way. Ahimelech truthfully denied that Ahimelech knew anything about David's plot against Saul.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Both Saul and Ahimelech used questions that did not require an answer to make important or strong statements. How do you make important or strong statements in your language? Pause this audio here.

But Saul refused to listen to Ahimelech. Saul said that Ahimelech and all Ahimelech's father's family, all the priests at Nob, were certainly going to die.

The king told the guards who stood near the king to surround and kill the priests who served Yahweh. Saul told the guards that the priests had also, like everybody else, supported or helped David. Saul said that although the priests knew that David had run away, the priests had not told Saul. But the king's guardsmen refused to obey Saul's order to kill Yahweh's priests. The storyteller says that the servants of the king "would not raise a hand" to strike Yahweh's priests. The storyteller means that the servants would not attack the priests.

Then Saul commanded Doeg the Edomite to go and strike down, or attack and kill, the priests. This way of talking about killing people is very violent. So Doeg went and attacked the priests. That day, Doeg killed 85 people who wore the linen ephod. Only priests wore a linen ephod, so this means that Doeg killed 85 priests.

And Doeg the Edomite also killed everyone else who lived in Nob, the city of priests. Doeg killed both men and women, children, babies, and the livestock, including oxen, donkeys, and sheep. Doeg did not necessarily slaughter all the townspeople alone. Doeg could have had his own followers and relatives with Doeg.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do you describe violent scenes in stories in your language? Remember that Doeg probably did not kill everyone himself, but Doeg led the group of people who killed everyone in Nob. Pause this audio here.

Now the storyteller changes the direction of the story and introduces a contrast in the story. One of the high priest's sons escaped and went to see David. Doeg killed everyone in Nob except Abiathar, one of Ahimelech's sons. The word "one" in the original language can mean either "one son" or "the first son." Abiathar escaped and ran to David to join David's group of supporters. After Abiathar had caught up with David, Abiathar told David that Saul had killed the priests of Yahweh. Saul had not personally killed the priests but was responsible for their deaths. Saul was the one who authorized the killing that Doeg the Edomite carried out. Abiathar would have given David a detailed description of what happened.

David told Abiathar that as soon as David saw Doeg the Edomite in Nob, David knew Doeg would tell Saul that David had visited Ahimelech. David confessed to Abiathar that David himself was ultimately responsible for the killing of Abiathar's family.

David told Abiathar not to be afraid and to stay with David. Abiathar and David now had the same enemy, Saul, who wanted to kill them both. David said that David would protect Abiathar, so before Saul could kill Abiathar, Saul would first have to kill David.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 22:11–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has seven scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • King Saul

  • Ahimelech the high priest

  • Ahimelech's father's household, which consisted of all Ahimelech's father's male descendants, who were all the priests in the city of Nob

  • Saul's guardsmen

  • Doeg the Edomite

  • Everyone in the city of Nob, including the men, women, children, and babies

  • All the livestock in the city of Nob

  • Abiathar, one of Ahimelech's sons

  • And David

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

After hearing Doeg the Edomite's account of David's time with Ahimelech, King Saul sent a message to Ahimelech the priest in the city of Nob. Saul told Ahimelech that Saul wanted to see Ahimelech and all Ahimelech's father's house, the priests from Nob. So all the priests obeyed Saul and went to see Saul in Gibeah. Gibeah was eight kilometers northwest of the city of Nob.

Saul said, "Listen now, son of Ahitub." Then Saul accused Ahimelech of plotting with David against Saul. Saul said that Ahimelech and the son of Jesse were plotting against Saul. Saul accused Ahimelech of helping David to rebel against Saul because Ahimelech gave David bread and a sword and inquired of God for David. Saul was convinced that even as Saul was speaking to Ahimelech, David was waiting for an opportunity to kill Saul.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so angry with Ahimelech! Ahimelech is helping David to become a king! I feel panic that I am losing my throne! Who does Ahimelech think he is? or

  • Ahimelech is supposed to be my priest, yet he is plotting against me with the son of Jesse! or

  • Let's see what Ahimelech has to say for himself. Doeg the Edomite told me how Ahimelech helped the son of Jesse!

Ahimelech answered Saul and assured Saul that Ahimelech had been loyal to Saul. Ahimelech asked Saul, "And who among all your servants is so faithful as David? Who is the king's son-in-law? Who is the captain over the king's bodyguard? Who do people highly honour in your house?" Ahimelech asked Saul if it was the first time that Ahimelech had inquired of God for David. Ahimelech was saying that it was normal for Ahimelech to talk to God for David, because of David's high position in Saul's court. Ahimelech told Saul that Saul should not consider Ahimelech the king's servant and Ahimelech's family to be guilty of any wrongdoing. Ahimelech truthfully denied that Ahimelech knew anything about David's plot against Saul.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Ahimelech, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • This must be a misunderstanding. How can Saul accuse me of conspiring against Saul with David? or

  • David is a man of very high standing, and the king usually trusts David! David's wife is the king's daughter. Everyone at the king's court trusts David; or

  • I cannot believe this! How could I not have helped David? How could I not have talked to Yahweh for David? I have talked with Yahweh for David in the past. The king's accusations against me and my father's house are untrue.

But Saul refused to listen to Ahimelech. Saul said that Ahimelech and all Ahimelech's father's family, all the priests at Nob, were certainly going to die.

The king told the guards who stood near the king to surround and kill the priests who served Yahweh. Saul told the guards that the priests had also, like everybody else, supported or helped David. Saul said that although the priests knew that David had run away, the priests had not told Saul. But the king's guardsmen refused to carry out the king's order to kill Yahweh's priests.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the king's guardsmen, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • It is the king's duty to obey Yahweh's laws. Yahweh wants the king to look after the priests of Yahweh; or

  • Why does the king want us to kill the priests? It is against Yahweh's law! or

  • We feel afraid of Yahweh. We would rather obey Yahweh than King Saul. We are not going to kill the priests!

Then Saul commanded Doeg the Edomite to go and kill the priests. So, Doeg went and attacked the priests. That day, Doeg killed 85 priests.

And Doeg the Edomite also killed everyone else who lived in Nob, the city of priests. Doeg killed both men and women, children, babies, and the livestock, including oxen, donkeys, and sheep.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Doeg the Edomite, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • The king wants me to kill the priests. I will do it. I am the king's hired soldier, so I must do what the king tells me to do; or

  • The king could kill me if I do not obey the king. I have proof that David and Ahimelech were conspiring against King Saul. I saw Ahimelech help David at Nob; or

  • Part of my job is to kill people and livestock in the city of the priests. I will kill them and take all their possessions; or

  • If I kill the priests when no one else wants to do it, perhaps King Saul will give me something extra or show me more favour.

Doeg killed everyone in Nob except Abiathar, one of Ahimelech's sons. Abiathar escaped and ran to David to join David's group of supporters. After Abiathar had found David, Abiathar told David that Saul had killed Yahweh's priests.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Abiathar, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I lost all my family! Doeg killed my father and all my brothers, the priests; or

  • The king wants to kill me, too. I was able to escape! or

  • I will run away to be with David. David is running away from Saul, too. We will ask Yahweh to save us.

David told Abiathar that as soon as David saw Doeg the Edomite in Nob, David knew Doeg would tell Saul that David had visited Ahimelech. David confessed to Abiathar that David felt that David himself was ultimately responsible for the killing of Abiathar's family.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel so sad. I am responsible for the death of all these innocent priests! I regret going to see Ahimelech! The minute I saw Doeg, the hired soldier from Edom, I knew Doeg would tell Saul about me; or

  • I feel ashamed that because of me, Abiathar lost all his family; or

  • Now the two of us, Abiathar and I, are fleeing from the king. Abiathar will be safe with me.

David told Abiathar not to be afraid and to stay with David. Abiathar and David now had the same enemy, Saul, who wanted to kill them both. David said that David would protect Abiathar.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 22:11–23 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Then King Saul sent a message to summon Ahimelech the priest, and all Ahimelech's father's house or household, who were the priests at the city of Nob. The title priest here means the chief priest or the high priest. Use the same word or phrase for priest as you used in previous passages. For more information on priest, refer to the Master Glossary.

In this case, Ahimelech's father's house or household refers to all the adult male descendants of Ahimelech's father, even if those descendants did not live in the same house with Ahimelech. Use the same word or phrase for father's house or household as you used in previous passages.

Ahimelech respectfully calls Saul his "lord," or master. Use the same word or phrase for lord or master as you have used in previous passages, and see the Master Glossary for more information about lord.

Saul asked Ahimelech why Ahimelech had conspired against Saul and had given David bread and a sword and had inquired or talked to God for David. Use the same words or phrases for bread and sword as you used in previous passages. In this case, when a priest inquires of God for someone, the priest talks to God for that person and asks God what God wants that person to do.

Stop here as a group and discuss how you will say that Ahimelech inquired of God, or talked to God, for David. If you have already translated this word or phrase in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Use the same word or phrase for God as you used in previous passages. For more information on God, refer to the Master Glossary.

Ahimelech could not understand why Saul would think that David was not loyal to Saul. Ahimelech told the king that there was no one more loyal among all Saul's servants than David and that David was the king's son-in-law. Ahimelech told the king that David was the captain of the king's bodyguard and that everyone in the king's house honoured David.

Here, the word servants refers to the officials in Saul's government, not to slaves. However, these officials do serve Saul. Use the same word for servants or officials as you have used in previous passages, and see the Master Glossary for more information about servants.

A person's son-in-law is the husband of that person's daughter. David was Saul's son-in-law because he was the husband of Saul's daughter, Michal. Use the same word or phrase for son-in-law as you used in previous passages.

The king's bodyguards were soldiers whose job was to protect the king. A captain of the king's bodyguard was a high-ranking officer responsible for leading and commanding the group of soldiers who protected the king. This person oversaw the king's safety and security and made sure no one harmed the king.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for bodyguard or captain of the king's bodyguard. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

And the king commanded his guardsmen to surround and kill Yahweh's priests. Yahweh is God's personal name, and the storyteller uses it three times in this passage when the passage mentions the priests of Yahweh. In other places, the storyteller uses the general word for God. Use the same general term for God and the same name for Yahweh that you have used in previous passages. For more information on God and Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary.

Then the king commanded Doeg the Edomite to kill the priests. And Doeg went and killed the priests. Doeg killed 85 persons who wore the linen ephod. Use the same word or phrase for ephod as you used before. For more information on ephod, refer to the Master Glossary.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a priest wearing a linen ephod. Pause this audio here.

And Doeg the Edomite killed both men and women, children and babies, as well as cattle, donkeys, and sheep. Use the same words or phrases for cattle, donkeys, and sheep as you used before. For more information on donkey, refer to the Master Glossary.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 23:1–14
content:

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 23:1–14 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous passage, King Saul accused Ahimelech of plotting against Saul with David. Ahimelech assured Saul of Ahimelech's loyalty, but Saul ordered Saul's guards to kill Ahimelech and all of Ahimelech's father's household. When the guards refused to obey Saul, Saul told Doeg the Edomite to kill Ahimelech and Ahimelech's household. Doeg murdered Ahimelech and all the priests of Yahweh, as well as all the other people and livestock in the city of Nob. However, Abiathar, Ahimelech's son, escaped and ran away to David. David said David would protect Abiathar.

One day, someone told David that the Philistines were attacking the city of Keilah and stealing grain from the people's threshing floors. Keilah was a strong city in the territory of the tribe of Judah, near the Philistine border, about eight kilometers south of Adullam. David was likely traveling between the forest of Hereth and Keilah when David heard the news. Threshing floors were outside the city walls, where people separated grain from husks. It was harvest time, and the Philistines attacked because the Philistines could use the grain right away and knew the people would be too busy to defend the city. Losing the crop would cause great hardship for the people of Keilah.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a threshing floor. Pause the audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about a time when other people attacked cities or areas in your land. Why did those people attack? Pause this audio here.

So, David asked Yahweh whether David should go and attack the Philistines. We do not know how David asked Yahweh. If Abiathar the priest was with David at this point, Abiathar would have asked Yahweh for David to use the Urim and Thummim from the high priest's ephod. Otherwise, David could have asked Yahweh through the prophet Gad. David could have also asked Yahweh directly by praying to Yahweh. David wanted to know if Yahweh wanted David to try to defend Keilah against the Philistines. In the ancient Near East, people asked their gods before going out to war. However, it would have been the king's job to fight his enemies. Yahweh told David that David should attack the Philistines in order to save the city of Keilah and its people from the Philistines.

Stop here and discuss the question as a group: How do the military leaders in your country decide whether they should go to war? Pause this audio here.

But David's men responded with fear when they heard about David's plans to attack the Philistines in Keilah. David's men said that they were already afraid of the enemies around them. The men did not want to go into another battle while they were also in the centre of their enemies in the territory of the tribe of Judah. The men were even more afraid of facing the Philistine army in Keilah, so close to the Philistine territory.

Then David asked Yahweh the second time. David probably wanted Yahweh to reassure David because David's men were fearful. Yahweh answered David and told him to go to Keilah. Yahweh said that Yahweh would cause David and David's men to defeat the Philistines. Again, we do not know how David asked Yahweh.

So David obeyed Yahweh's command and trusted Yahweh's promise. David and David's men went to Keilah and attacked the Philistines and led away the Philistines' cattle. The Philistines may have brought their cattle to Keilah to eat what people left on the threshing floor or to transport the grain the Philistines were stealing. David and his men killed many Philistines. In this way, David rescued the people who lived in Keilah from the Philistines.

Stop here as a group and look at the map to see David's journey from the forest of Hereth to Keilah. Pause this audio here.

Now we hear background information about Abiathar the priest, Ahimelech's son. Abiathar had already escaped from Saul. We do not know where exactly Abiathar joined David, but most likely it was somewhere before Keilah. When Abiathar came to Keilah, Abiathar brought with him the ephod. This was the high priest's ephod, which was a highly decorated piece of clothing. The high priest wore this ephod in the tent of meeting when he served Yahweh. On top of the ephod, the high priest wore a breastpiece. This breastpiece held the Urim and Thummim, two objects the high priest used to learn Yahweh's will.

Then someone informed Saul that David had gone to Keilah. Instead of being happy that Yahweh freed the people of Keilah from the Philistines, Saul mistakenly believed that God had delivered David into Saul's hands, or into Saul's power. Saul spoke as though it were God's will that Saul capture David. Saul believed that God had made it possible for Saul to catch David because David had put himself in a trap. Saul had not set a trap that David had entered, and David had not deliberately trapped or imprisoned himself. Rather, by entering Keilah, David had put himself in a dangerous position. Keilah was a fortified city. Keilah had a wall around it. David would have no way out of Keilah except through the gates, which people could bar from the inside and watch from the outside.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Talk about cities in your area. In the past, how did people make those cities safe from attack? How do people make those cities safe now? Pause this audio here.

Then Saul called all the people to war. Israel did not have a professional army, so Saul would gather men to come fight as soldiers whenever Saul needed. We do not know how many men responded, but in a previous battle with the Amalekites, 200,000 men and 10,000 from Judah had joined Saul. Since Saul called up everyone, Saul likely planned to use a large army against David's 600 men. Saul wanted to besiege Keilah by surrounding the city to cut off supplies of arms, food, and water, to force the people inside to either fight their way out or surrender.

Someone told David that Saul was plotting evil against David and not against the Philistines. David asked Abiathar the priest to bring the ephod to David. It was the high priest's ephod which Abiathar brought with him from the city of Nob. David wanted to find out Yahweh's will.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do people in your people group find out God's will? Pause this audio here.

Then David prayed to Yahweh. David addressed Yahweh as, "Yahweh, the God of Israel." Yahweh was God's name by which the people of Israel knew God. "The God of Israel" means the God whom the people of Israel worship. David told Yahweh that David had heard for certain that Saul was seeking to come to Keilah to destroy the city because of David.

David asked Yahweh to tell David something that might happen in the future. David asked if the men or the citizens of Keilah would hand David over to Saul in order to try and save their city. The citizens were those men who lived in Keilah and owned property there. The citizens were the city's rich people and were probably the city leaders or authorities. David also wanted Yahweh to tell David if Saul would come and attack Keilah. And Yahweh confirmed that Saul would come to Keilah.

David asked Yahweh again if the men of Keilah would hand David and David's men over to Saul, as David feared might happen. The leaders of Keilah likely knew that Saul had destroyed Nob and could do the same to their city. From the leaders' perspective, David had brought more trouble than help. While the Philistines only stole grain, Saul intended to destroy Keilah. Yahweh told David that the men of Keilah would surrender David to Saul.

David accepted Yahweh's answer and immediately left Keilah with David's 600 men. David had started with 400 men at the cave of Adullam, and more men had joined since then. The men moved from place to place, never staying anywhere permanently, always seeking safety from Saul. When someone told Saul that David had escaped Keilah, Saul chose not to chase David further at that time.

When David left Keilah, David went into the wilderness of the territory of the tribe of Judah. The wilderness was between the mountains of Judah and the Dead Sea. Different parts of this wilderness had different names. The desert or wilderness of Ziph was part of the wilderness of Judah, which was near the city of Ziph. Ziph was about 8 kilometres south-southeast of Hebron, about 19 kilometres southeast of Keilah. David may have lived only in the wilderness strongholds in the hill country of the wilderness of Ziph. Wilderness strongholds were places where people could hide and find refuge or protection in the wilderness. These were probably natural structures like caves, not man-made forts. It is possible that David lived in the wilderness and then went to the mountains in the wilderness of Ziph. And Saul searched for David every day, but God did not permit Saul to catch David. God was keeping David safe from Saul.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 23:1–14 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has seven scenes.

In the first scene: David finds out that the Philistines have attacked the city of Keilah and are stealing the grain from the threshing floors. David asks Yahweh if David should go and attack the Philistines at Keilah. Yahweh says that David should go and attack the Philistines to save the people of Keilah.

In the second scene: David's men are afraid when they hear about David's plans to attack the Philistines in Keilah. David's men say that they are already afraid of the enemies around them in Judah. So David asks Yahweh again if the men are to go to Keilah, and Yahweh says the men are to go right away because Yahweh will cause David and David's men to defeat the Philistines.

In the third scene: David trusts Yahweh's promise, and David and David's men go to Keilah. The men attack the Philistines and take the cattle that the Philistines brought to Keilah. David and David's men kill the Philistines and save the inhabitants of Keilah.

In the fourth scene: The storyteller gives background information about Abiathar the priest, Ahimelech's son. We find out that when Abiathar came to David at Keilah, Abiathar brought with him the high priest's ephod.

In the fifth scene: Someone tells Saul that David has gone to Keilah. Saul mistakenly believes that God has delivered David into Saul's hands. Saul calls up all the people for war, so Saul and Saul's army can go to Keilah and besiege or surround David and David's men.

In the sixth scene: David finds out that Saul is planning to capture David. David asks Abiathar to bring David the ephod so he can find out Yahweh's will. Yahweh confirms that Saul will come to Keilah. Yahweh tells David that the men from Keilah will surrender David to Saul.

In the seventh scene: David and David's men leave Keilah and go from place to place, wherever the men will be safe from Saul. When Saul hears that David has escaped from Keilah, Saul decides not to go after David at that time. David and David's men now live in the strongholds in the wilderness in the territory of the tribe of Judah and reach the hill country in the wilderness of Ziph. Saul searches for David every day, but God does not permit Saul to catch David.

The characters in this passage are:

  • People who told David about the Philistine attack on Keilah, probably David's men

  • David

  • The Philistines

  • Yahweh

  • People of Keilah

  • David's men, or soldiers

  • Abiathar the priest

  • The person who told David that Saul was coming to Keilah

  • King Saul

  • And Saul's army

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

One day, someone said to David, "Look! The Philistines are fighting against Keilah and are robbing the threshing floors." Here, the messenger was calling David's attention to a serious problem. The messenger was not telling David to physically see the Philistines. The messenger was alerting David that the Philistines were stealing the grain from the threshing floors. Keilah was a city in the area of the tribe of Judah and was located near the Philistine border, eight kilometres south of the city of Adullam. David was probably traveling between the forest of Hereth and Keilah when David heard the news.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about a time when someone brought serious news that needed immediate action. What words or phrases did that person use to call people's attention to the problem? Pause this audio here.

So David asked Yahweh, "Shall I go and attack these Philistines?" David referred to the Philistines in a way that showed how much David did not respect the Philistines. Yahweh told David that David should attack the Philistines in order to save the city of Keilah and its people from the Philistines.

The story is clear that the way David's men react is not how Yahweh and David expected the men to react. When the men heard the news, David's men said, "Look, even here in the heart, or middle, of Judah, we are afraid." David's men feared enemies all around them and the thought of battle. The men said, "We will be terrified if we try to fight the Philistines' armies at Keilah!" David's men feared the Philistines. That is why the men refer to the Philistine raiding party as "armies," although the Philistines did not really send an army to Keilah. The Philistines would have sent a raiding party of a smaller group of men.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What do you say in your language to show that somebody's response was not how we would expect that person to respond? Pause this audio here.

Then David asked Yahweh again. It is important to note that this was the second time David asked Yahweh. And Yahweh said to David, "Arise, go down to Keilah." "Arise" did not mean David was to stand up, but that David was to go quickly. The phrase "go down" here probably means that where David and David's men were staying was perhaps on a hill, and the men would have to travel downhill. Yahweh said that Yahweh would "give the Philistines over into David's hand." This means that Yahweh was going to give David and David's men power over the Philistines. As before, the story does not say what David did to ask Yahweh and by what means Yahweh spoke to David.

Stop here and discuss as a group the best way to translate Yahweh's instructions to David. Pause this audio here.

The storyteller makes it clear that David immediately obeyed what Yahweh had commanded. So, David and David's men went to Keilah and attacked the Philistines. David and his men led away the Philistines' cattle. David and David's men killed many Philistines. In this way, David rescued the people who lived in Keilah from the Philistines. Although the storyteller seems to say that David did these actions by himself, we know that David's men were fighting with David. By using this type of language, the storyteller makes David important and presents David as a brave and successful leader.
