Stop here as a group and discuss: How will you talk about a character in a story to show that the person is brave and courageous? How will you show that this person is the most important character among other characters? Pause this audio here.

Now we hear background information about Abiathar, Ahimelech's son. Abiathar the priest had already escaped from Saul. We do not know where exactly Abiathar joined David. It is very likely that Abiathar joined David before the battle in Keilah, and David and Abiathar traveled together to Keilah. Here, the story repeats information about Abiathar joining David and tells us new information about Abiathar bringing the ephod with Abiathar.

Then someone informed Saul that David had gone to Keilah. Saul believed that God had delivered David into Saul's hands, or into Saul's power. Saul believed that God had made it possible for Saul to catch David. Saul was probably speaking to Saul's officials and gave a reason why Saul thought that God wanted Saul to catch David. Saul said, "Because David has shut himself in by entering a city that has gates and bars."

Stop here and discuss as a group: How will you translate the phrase "to deliver someone into someone's hands" so it means giving someone into another person's power? Talk about whether there is a similar phrase in your language, or whether you will need to use another phrase and what that phrase will be. Pause this audio here.

Because Saul knew that David was in a city with gates and bars, Saul decided that Saul should go capture David. Then Saul called up all the people for war. Saul wanted his army to go to Keilah to besiege or surround David and David's men.

Someone told David that Saul was plotting evil against David instead of against the Philistines. David told Abiathar the priest to bring the high priest's ephod to David. David wanted to use the Urim and the Thummim from the ephod to ask Yahweh what to do.

David prayed to Yahweh and called Yahweh by his personal name, which the people of Israel knew. David called Yahweh "Yahweh, God of Israel." David humbly approached God by using the phrase "your servant" when referring to himself. David said, "Your servant has surely heard that Saul seeks to come to Keilah, to destroy the city because of me." David used language that stressed that David had definitely heard beyond any doubt that Saul was coming to Keilah to destroy the city because of David.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Talk about a situation in your life when someone trustworthy told you about something scary that was going to happen. Pause this audio here.

David asked Yahweh to tell David something that might happen in the future. David asked Yahweh, "Will the citizens of Keilah surrender me into Saul's hand?" The phrase "surrender into Saul's hand" means to let Saul capture David. David also asked Yahweh, "Will Saul come down, as your servant has heard?" The phrase "come down" means simply to come to a place, not to physically go down. David again called Yahweh "Yahweh, God of Israel." David was humbly asking Yahweh when David referred to himself as "your servant." Yahweh answered David's second question and confirmed that Saul would come to Keilah.

Then David asked Yahweh again if the men of Keilah would hand David and David's men over to Saul. Yahweh answered David and said that the men from Keilah would surrender David to Saul.

Now the storyteller introduces what David did as a result of what Yahweh had told David in the previous passage. The storyteller uses language that makes it clear there is a link between what happened before and what David is doing now. So David and his men left Keilah at once. There were about 600 men with David at that time. The men went wherever they might be safe to avoid Saul capturing the men. When somebody told Saul that David had escaped from Keilah, Saul decided not to go after David at Keilah.

Now we hear about the area that David went to when David left Keilah and was hiding from Saul. When David left Keilah, David went into the wilderness of the territory of the tribe of Judah. The wilderness was between the mountains of Judah and the Dead Sea. Different parts of this wilderness had different names. The desert or wilderness of Ziph was part of the wilderness of Judah, which was near the city of Ziph. Ziph was about 8 kilometres south-southeast of Hebron, about 19 kilometres southeast of Keilah. David may have only lived in the wilderness strongholds in the hill country of the wilderness of Ziph. Wilderness strongholds were places where people could hide and find refuge or protection. These were probably natural structures like caves, not man-made forts. It is possible that David lived in the wilderness and then went to the mountains in the wilderness of Ziph. And Saul searched for David every day, but God did not permit Saul to catch David. God was keeping David safe from Saul.

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 23:1–14 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Someone told David that the Philistines were attacking the town of Keilah and were robbing the grain from the threshing floors. Threshing floors were hard, level surfaces in the open air, located outside of towns, where the blowing winds could separate the seeds from the husks. People either walked on the grain or dragged a heavy board over it, and then tossed both grain and husks into the air. The wind blew away the lighter husks, but the heavier grain fell to the ground.

Use the same name for Yahweh that you have used in previous passages. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary.

David and his men went to Keilah and attacked the Philistines. David led away the cattle and killed many Philistines. This term "cattle" is a general term that could include any animals that people use, such as cows, sheep, or goats.

Use the same word or phrase for ephod as you used before. For more information on ephod, refer to the Master Glossary.

Talk about delivering people into the hands of others in the same way here as you have done in previous passages. Use the same word or phrase for God as you used before. For more information on God, refer to the Master Glossary.

Someone told David that Saul was plotting evil against David and not against the Philistines. David asked Abiathar the priest to bring the ephod to David. Use the same word or phrase for priest as you used before. For more information on priest, refer to the Master Glossary.

Then David said, "O Yahweh, the God of Israel, your servant has surely heard that Saul seeks to come to Keilah, to destroy the city because of me." Use the same word or phrase for servant as you used before. For more information on servant, refer to the Master Glossary.

And David remained in the strongholds in the wilderness, in the hill country of the wilderness of Ziph. Wilderness strongholds were places where people could hide and find refuge or protection in the wilderness. The strongholds in this story were probably natural structures like caves, not man-made forts like the storyteller mentioned in previous passages.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for wilderness stronghold. Look up stronghold in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of a stronghold in the wilderness in the territory of the tribe of Judah. Pause this audio here.

Use the same word or phrase for wilderness as you used before. For more information on wilderness, refer to the Master Glossary.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 23:15–29
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 23:15–29 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 23:15–29 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 23:15–29 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous story, David found out that the Philistines attacked the people in the strong city of Keilah. Yahweh told David that Yahweh wanted David to go and fight the Philistines to free the people of Keilah. Yahweh caused David to defeat the Philistines. David and David's men killed the Philistines, but David soon found out that Saul was planning to catch David in Keilah. Yahweh confirmed that Saul was coming to Keilah and that the men of Keilah would surrender David to Saul. David and David's men ran away from Keilah at once and wandered from place to place until the men reached the wilderness of Ziph. Saul searched for David every day, but Yahweh prevented Saul from finding David.

While David was at Horesh in the wilderness of Ziph, David realised that Saul had come out to kill David. The word Horesh means "in the Wood," so we are not certain whether Horesh was a town, a village, or a forested area. Somebody told David that Saul was leading a military raid to kill David.

Stop here as a group and look at the map. Find Horesh in the desert of Ziph. Pause this audio here.

Then Jonathan, Saul's son, came to see David at Horesh. Jonathan probably traveled from Gibeah, the city where Jonathan's father, King Saul, ruled from and where Jonathan lived. Gibeah was about 50 kilometres away from Horesh. Jonathan came to "strengthen David's hand in God," which meant that Jonathan came to encourage David to trust God and believe that God would protect David. It was most likely very dangerous for Jonathan to visit David at this time, when Jonathan's father was searching for David. At the same time, it must have been very encouraging for David to see Jonathan at this dangerous time.

Stop here as a group and look at the map to see Jonathan's journey from Gibeah to Horesh in the desert of Ziph. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and tell a story about a time when one friend travelled far in order to encourage another friend. Pause this audio here.

Jonathan reassured David and told David not to be afraid because Saul, Jonathan's father, would not be able to find David to do any harm. Jonathan told David that David would be the future king of Israel and that Jonathan would be the second man in the kingdom, or David's second in command. Jonathan was convinced that Yahweh, whom both Jonathan and David trusted, would protect David from Saul's hand or power. Jonathan spoke about David's future even though Jonathan did not know that the prophet Samuel had anointed or selected David to be king, as Yahweh had instructed Samuel. Even though Jonathan knew nothing about David's anointing, Jonathan could tell from David's actions and Jonathan's father's behaviour that David would become king after Saul's death. Jonathan told David that Saul, Jonathan's father, also knew that David would be king over Israel. Saul must have realized that David would become king because the prophet Samuel had predicted that Yahweh would reject Saul, and David was successful in everything David did. Jonathan realized that Saul, Jonathan's own father, was the enemy of Jonathan's best friend, David.

Then Jonathan and David made a covenant, or an agreement. In the presence of Yahweh, Jonathan and David renewed the strong promise of friendship they had made earlier in Yahweh's name. Jonathan and David promised each other that they would always act as faithful friends to one another. After that, Jonathan returned home, but David stayed in Horesh.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What types of relationship covenants or agreements do people in your culture make? How do people renew and remember these covenants? Pause this audio here.

The Ziphites, or the people who lived in the town of Ziph, went up to Saul in the city of Gibeah, which was in the territory of the tribe of Benjamin. The Ziphites brought Saul the news that David was hiding in their land in the strongholds of Horesh on the hill named Hakilah, south of Jeshimon. Jeshimon was the name of a desert region in the territory of the tribe of Judah. Jeshimon meant wasteland or desert.

Stop here as a group and look at the map to see the Ziphites' journey from Ziph to Gibeah. Pause this audio here.

The Ziphites invited King Saul to come down to their land, the territory of the tribe of Judah, at once, or at any time Saul wanted. The Ziphites said they would make it possible for the king to capture David.

Saul was very pleased that the Ziphites wanted to give David to Saul. Saul said, "May Yahweh bless you because you had compassion on me." Saul wanted Yahweh to be kind to the Ziphites because the Ziphites helped Saul. By asking Yahweh to bless the Ziphites for helping him, Saul showed that Saul did not understand Yahweh's will and did not respect Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about a ruler who mistakenly thought they had authority from God to do something. What happened when the ruler used his authority wrongly? Pause this audio here.

Saul told the Ziphites to go back to their hometown, or to their own territory, and find out exactly where David was. Saul wanted the Ziphites to do that because Saul had heard from someone that David was very cunning or clever. Saul thought that David was smart and careful and planned things out wisely, but Saul also thought that David used tricks and deception when necessary to escape Saul.

Saul urged the Ziphites to look around and carefully discover the different places where David was likely to hide. Then Saul wanted the Ziphites to return to Saul and tell Saul when they were certain exactly where David was. Then Saul would go with the Ziphites to their land, the territory of the tribe of Judah. If David were in the land of the tribe of Judah, Saul would search for or hunt for David among thousands of people from all the clans or families of the tribe of Judah until Saul found David.

So, the men from Ziph set out for home ahead of Saul. In the meantime, David had gone further with his men and was in the wilderness, or desert, near the town of Maon. This town was in the dry valley of the Arabah. Maon was eight kilometres south of Ziph, which was located in the Jeshimon wilderness.

Saul and Saul's soldiers went to Ziph and started to search for David. When someone told David that Saul was looking for him, David went to "the rock" and lived in the wilderness of Maon. The meaning of "the rock" is not clear here. It perhaps refers to a large rough and uneven cliff or rockface, which are common in mountain regions, or it could refer to a valley at the bottom of the mountain that runs through the Maon wilderness. When Saul heard where David had gone, Saul chased David and David's men in the wilderness of Maon.

Stop here as a group and look at a photo of a rock face from a mountain region in the territory of the tribe of Judah. Pause this audio here.

Saul reached the rock or mountain where David was. Saul and Saul's men went on one side of the mountain, and David and David's men were on the other side. David and David's men were in great hurry to get away from Saul. As Saul and Saul's army were getting close to David and David's men, suddenly a messenger, another Israelite, came to Saul with a message. The messenger told Saul to hurry back home, because the Philistines had attacked the land of Israel.

Then Saul stopped chasing David and returned to Gibeah to fight the Philistines. Therefore, people began to call the place where Saul stopped pursuing David the rock of escape or the rock of separation.

Then David left the wilderness of Maon and went to stay in the strongholds in the wilderness surrounding En Gedi. En Gedi was an oasis, a fertile area with water that allowed plants to grow. En Gedi was located between 19 and 32 kilometres northeast of the wilderness of Maon, on the western shore of the Dead Sea. Caves in that area acted as strongholds or safe places. En Gedi was an ideal hiding place for David and David's men.

Stop here as a group and look at the map to see [David's journey from the wilderness of Maon to En Gedi][#c400]. Pause this audio here.

Stop here as a group and look at a photo of the En Gedi oasis.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 23:15–29 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has seven scenes.

In the first scene: While David and David's men are at Horesh in the wilderness of Ziph, someone tells David that Saul is leading a military raid to kill David.

In the second scene: Jonathan, Saul's son, comes to see David at Horesh to encourage David to trust God. Jonathan reassures David and tells David that Saul will not be able to find David to do any harm. Jonathan tells David that David will be the future king of Israel and that Jonathan will be David's second in command. Jonathan tells David that Saul also knows that David will be king over Israel. Jonathan and David renew their covenant of friendship before Yahweh. Jonathan goes home, and David remains in Horesh.

In the third scene: The people from the town of Ziph go up to Saul at Gibeah and tell Saul that David is hiding in the strongholds of Horesh, on the hill of Hakilah, south of the wilderness of Jeshimon. The Ziphites invite King Saul to come down to their territory. The Ziphites say they will make it possible for the king to capture David. Saul asks Yahweh to bless the Ziphites because the Ziphites are kind to Saul.

In the fourth scene: Saul tells the Ziphites to go back to their hometown and find out exactly where David is. Saul urges the Ziphites to go and look around and learn about the different places where David is likely to hide. The Ziphites are to return to Saul and tell Saul David's hiding place when they are certain where David is. Then Saul will go with the Ziphites to their land, the territory of the tribe of Judah. Saul says that if David is in the land of the tribe of Judah, Saul will search for or hunt for David among all the clans of Judah until Saul finds David.

In the fifth scene: So, the men of Ziph set out for their town. David and David's men are in the wilderness of Maon, in the valley of Arabah, to the south of the wilderness of Jeshimon. Saul and Saul's soldiers go to Ziph and start to search for David. When someone tells David that Saul is looking for David, David and his men go to a rocky mountain and live in the wilderness of Maon. When Saul hears where David had gone, Saul chases David with his men in the wilderness of Maon.

In the sixth scene: Saul reaches the rocky mountain where David is. Saul and Saul's men go on one side of the mountain, and David and David's men are on the other side. David and his men are in great hurry to get away from Saul. As Saul and Saul's army are getting close to David and his men, suddenly a messenger comes to Saul with a message to hurry back home, because the Philistines have attacked the land of Israel.

In the seventh scene: Saul stops pursuing David and returns to Gibeah to fight the Philistines. People begin to call the place where Saul stopped pursuing David the rock of escape or the rock of separation. Then David leaves the wilderness of Maon and goes to stay in the strongholds of the wilderness surrounding the oasis of En Gedi.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • Saul

  • Jonathan

  • Yahweh

  • The Ziphites, or people from the town of Ziph

  • Saul's men

  • David's men

  • Someone who told David that Saul was searching for David

  • And Saul's messenger

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

While David was at Horesh in the wilderness of Ziph, somebody told David that Saul was leading a military raid to kill David.

Stop here as a group and look at the map. Find Horesh in the desert of Ziph. Pause this audio here.

Now we learn what happened while David was in Horesh. Jonathan, Saul's son, came to see David at Horesh. Jonathan probably traveled from Gibeah, where Jonathan was staying at his father's, Saul's, court. Gibeah was about 50 kilometres away from Horesh. It probably would have taken Jonathan about one or two days to walk from Gibeah to Horesh. Jonathan came to encourage David to trust God and believe that God would protect David.

Stop here as a group and look at the map to see Jonathan's journey from Gibeah to Horesh in the desert of Ziph. Pause this audio here.

Jonathan reassured David and told David not to be afraid because Saul, Jonathan's father, would not be able to find David to do any harm. Jonathan told David that David would be the future king of Israel, and that Jonathan would be the second man in the kingdom, or David's second in command. Jonathan told David that Saul, Jonathan's father, also knew that David would be king over Israel. Jonathan says, "Saul, my father," both at the beginning and the end of Jonathan's statement. This repetition shows Jonathan is genuinely prepared to accept his relationship with Jonathan's father, Saul.

Then Jonathan and David made a covenant or agreement. Jonathan and David renewed in the presence of Yahweh the strong promise of friendship they had made earlier in Yahweh's name. Jonathan and David promised each other that they would always act as faithful friends to one another. After that, Jonathan returned home, but David stayed in Horesh.

Then the Ziphites, or the people who lived in the town of Ziph, went up to Saul at Gibeah. The phrase "went up" here means that Gibeah was located on higher ground than Ziph. The Ziphites asked Saul, "Is not David hiding among us in the strongholds at Horesh, on the hill of Hakilah, which is south of Jeshimon?" The Ziphites were not asking for information about David. Instead, the Ziphites used the question to make a statement to tell Saul where David was.

Stop here as a group and look at the map to see the Ziphites' journey from Ziph to Gibeah. Pause this audio here.

The Ziphites invited King Saul to come down to their territory at once, or at any time Saul wanted. The Ziphites said to Saul, "Now come down, O king, according to all your heart's desire to come down." The Ziphites said, "Come down," because the king would be coming down from his hill country to the Ziphites' area, which was on lower ground. "O king" was the polite way to address the king directly. The Ziphites continued and said they would make it possible for the king to capture David.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do you address a king or a very high-ranking official in your language? Pause this audio here.

Saul responded to the Ziphites and said, "May Yahweh bless you, because you have had compassion on me." Saul makes it clear that the kindness that the people of Ziph showed Saul is what caused Saul to ask Yahweh to bless the Ziphites.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do you talk when you express reasons for actions? What do you say to make it clear that something made you act in a certain way? Pause this audio here.

Saul told the Ziphites to go back to their hometown, or their own territory, and find out exactly where David was. Saul wanted the Ziphites to do that because Saul had heard from someone that David was very cunning or clever. The word cunning means that David was smart and careful, and planned things out wisely. But David also lied when necessary to get his way and escape Saul.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What word or phrase will you use to say that David was cunning? How will you show that David was both careful and wise, but also used tricks and deception? Pause this audio here.

Saul asked the Ziphites to "know about all the hiding places where David hides." In other words, Saul wanted to persuade the Ziphites to look all around and learn about all the different places where David was likely to hide. Saul told the Ziphites to return to Saul and tell Saul where David's hiding place was when the Ziphites were certain where David was. Then Saul would go with the Ziphites to their land, in the territory of the tribe of Judah. If David were in the land of the tribe of Judah, Saul would search for or hunt for David among all the clans of Judah until Saul found David.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What do you say when you try hard to persuade someone to do something? Pause this audio here.

So, the men of Ziph "arose and went" to their town ahead of Saul. The word "arose" does not mean that the men stood up, but it shows that the men went quickly.

Now the storyteller introduces what is happening to the other characters in the story while Saul is persuading the Ziphites to search for David. The storyteller uses language that makes it clear he is talking about a new thing. Now David and David's men were in the wilderness of Maon, in the valley of Arabah, to the south of the wilderness of Jeshimon, where the men were trying to escape Saul.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What do you say to make it clear that you are introducing new information to the story? Pause this audio here.

Saul and Saul's soldiers went to Ziph and started to search for David. When someone told David that Saul was looking for David, David went to a rocky mountain and continued to live in the wilderness of Maon. When Saul heard where David was, Saul chased David with his men in the wilderness of Maon.

Stop here as a group and look at a photo of a rock face from the mountain region in the territory of the tribe of Judah. Pause this audio here.

Saul reached the rocky mountain where David was. Saul and Saul's men went on one side of the mountain, and David and David's men were on the other side. Now we learn how David and David's men were in a great hurry to get away from Saul. As Saul and Saul's army were getting close to David and David's men, suddenly a messenger, another Israelite, came to Saul with a message. The messenger told Saul to hurry back home, because the Philistines had attacked the land of Israel. Note that all the action in this part of this story is taking place really fast, and there is a lot of stress.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How will you describe the events of this part of the story to show the fast speed of things taking place and the stress? What word or phrase will you use to show that Saul needed to both go back to his land and hurry? Pause this audio here.

Then Saul stopped chasing David and returned to Gibeah to fight the Philistines. Therefore, people began to call the place where Saul stopped chasing David the rock of escape or the rock of separation.

When David found out that Saul had stopped chasing David, David left the wilderness of Maon and went to stay in the strongholds of the wilderness surrounding the oasis of En Gedi. En Gedi was located between 19 and 32 kilometres northeast of the wilderness of Maon, on the western shore of the Dead Sea. It would take David and his men between 8 and 10 hours to walk to En Gedi.

Stop here as a group and look at the map to see David's journey from the wilderness of Maon to En Gedi.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 23:15–29 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has seven scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • Saul

  • Jonathan

  • Yahweh

  • The Ziphites, or people from the town of Ziph

  • Saul's men

  • David's men

  • Someone who told David that Saul was searching for David

  • And Saul's messenger

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

While David and David's men were at Horesh in the wilderness of Ziph, someone told David that Saul was leading a military raid to kill David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am scared. Saul truly wants to kill me! or

  • Saul is even searching for me in the wilderness! or

  • Will Yahweh save me this time?

Jonathan, Saul's son, came to see David at Horesh to encourage David to trust God. Jonathan reassured David and told David that Saul would not be able to find David to do any harm. Jonathan told David that David would be the future king of Israel and that Jonathan would be David's second in command. Jonathan said that Saul also knew that David would be king over Israel. Jonathan and David renewed their covenant of friendship before Yahweh. Jonathan went home, and David remained in Horesh.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Jonathan, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • My friend David is in need. I feel worried for David because my father, Saul, is trying to kill David; or

  • I feel scared, but I need to go to the wilderness and encourage David to trust God. David needs to know that God will make David king of Israel and that my father knows it; or

  • I feel so happy that we can renew our covenant of friendship before Yahweh. David and I will be friends forever!

The people from the town of Ziph went up to Saul at Gibeah and told Saul that David was hiding in the strongholds of Horesh, on the hill of Hakilah, south of the wilderness of Jeshimon. The Ziphites invited King Saul to come down to their territory and said they would make it possible for the king to capture David. Saul asks Yahweh to bless the Ziphites because the Ziphites had shown Saul mercy.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Ziphites, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are pleased we can tell King Saul where David and David's men are; or

  • Perhaps Saul will give us special privileges for helping Saul find his enemy; or

  • It is surprising that Saul felt we were merciful towards Saul. Saul did not sound like a king. We are doing our duty.

Saul told the Ziphites to go back to their hometown and find out exactly where David was, because people had told Saul that David was very cunning. Saul urged the Ziphites to go and look around and learn about the different places where David was likely to hide. The Ziphites were to return to Saul and tell Saul David's hiding place when they were certain where David was. Then Saul would go with the Ziphites to their land, the territory of the tribe of Judah. Saul said that if David were in the land of the tribe of Judah, Saul would search for David among all the clans of Judah until Saul found David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel hopeful of killing David this time; or

  • I need to make sure that the Ziphites know exactly where David is, because David is very clever and can outsmart me. If I know for sure that David is in the land of the tribe of Judah, I will search through all their clans! or

  • At last, I have someone who is taking pity on me instead of supporting David.

So, the men of Ziph set out for their town. David and David's men were in the wilderness of Maon, in the valley of Arabah, to the south of the wilderness of Jeshimon. Saul and his soldiers went to Ziph and started to search for David. When someone told David that Saul was looking for David, David and his men went to a rocky mountain and lived in the wilderness of Maon. When Saul heard where David had gone, Saul chased David with his men in the wilderness of Maon.

Saul reached the rocky mountain where David was. Saul and Saul's men went on one side of the mountain, and David and David's men were on the other side. David and his men were in a great hurry to get away from Saul. As Saul and Saul's army were getting close to David and David's men, suddenly a messenger came to Saul with a message to hurry back home because the Philistines had attacked the land of Israel.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel so disappointed! We nearly caught up with David and David's men. What a shame we must abandon the chase; or

  • But there is no other way. I have to defend our land from the Philistines; or

  • I have to wait for another chance to catch David.

Saul stopped pursuing David and returned to Gibeah to fight the Philistines. People began to call the place where Saul stopped pursuing David the rock of escape or the rock of separation. Then David left the wilderness of Maon and went to stay in the strongholds in the wilderness surrounding the oasis of En Gedi.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I praise Yahweh for saving me again! or

  • Hopefully, we can have a rest now that Saul will be fighting the Philistines; or

  • I am grateful that we can hide near the oasis of En Gedi, where there is fresh water and plenty of food.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 23:15–29 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

David was in the wilderness of Ziph at Horesh. Use the same word or phrase for wilderness as you used in previous passages. For more information on wilderness, refer to the Master Glossary.

And Jonathan, Saul's son, rose and went to David at Horesh, and strengthened David's hand in God. Use the same word or phrase for God as you used in previous passages. For more information on God, refer to the Master Glossary.

Jonathan told David that David would be king over Israel, and Jonathan would be David's second in command. Use the same word or phrase for king as you used in previous passages. For more information on king, refer to the Master Glossary.

Jonathan and David made a covenant of friendship before Yahweh. Use the same word or phrase for covenant as you used in previous passages. For more information on covenant, refer to the Master Glossary.

Yahweh is God's personal name, and the storyteller uses this name throughout most of this passage. Use the same name for Yahweh that you have used in previous passages. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary.

Saul says that Saul will find David among all the clans of Judah. Clans are groups of families within a larger tribe. Use the same word or phrase for clan, or family group, as you have used in previous passages.

The Ziphites told Saul that David was hiding in their territory in the strongholds at Horesh, on the Hill of Hakilah, south of Jeshimon. Here, "strongholds" means wilderness strongholds, which were caves. Use the same word or phrase for wilderness strongholds as you used in previous passages. For more information on stronghold, refer to the Master Glossary.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 24:1–7
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 24:1–7 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 24:1–7 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 24:1–7 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous story, while David was at Horesh in the wilderness of Ziph, David found out that Saul was pursuing David to kill him. Jonathan, Saul's son, came to encourage David to trust God. Jonathan and David renewed their covenant of friendship in Yahweh's presence. The Ziphites told Saul that David was hiding in their territory and said they would lead Saul to David. Saul and Saul's men went to Ziph and chased David and David's men in the wilderness of Maon. When Saul found out that the Philistines were attacking Israel, Saul stopped searching for David and went home to Gibeah. David and David's men went to the oasis of En Gedi and stayed there.

Saul and Saul's army were fighting the Philistines and chasing the Philistines away from the land of Israel. When Saul and his army returned home, someone told Saul that David was in the wilderness surrounding the oasis of En Gedi.

Stop here as a group and look at the map. Locate the wilderness of En Gedi. Pause this audio here.

On hearing the news about David's location, Saul selected 3,000 of the best soldiers in Israel. Then Saul and his army went to look for David and David's men in a place called the rocks of the wild goats at En Gedi. Gibeah, where Saul lived, was about 65 to 80 kilometres from En Gedi. It would take Saul and Saul's army between 1.5 and 2 days to walk from Gibeah to En Gedi. The name "rocks of the wild goats" probably is not a name for particular rocks, but a general description of a place. People probably called this place "rocks of wild goats" because there were many wild goats in the area.

Stop here as a group and look at the map. Locate the journey Saul and Saul's men traveled from Gibeah to En Gedi. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Talk about where the names for different places in your village, town, or region come from. Talk about the reasons why people gave places certain names. Pause this audio here.

When Saul's army arrived at En Gedi, Saul came to some sheepfolds, or sheep pens, which were along the route where people walked. People built sheepfolds to fence in their sheep. People built the fences out of stones. Some sheepfolds were permanent, with stone walls and a roof. Others were temporary buildings that people made from loose stones with thorn bushes on top. There was a cave by the sheepfolds, and David and David's men were sitting in the innermost part of the cave, which was the area farthest away from the entrance. And Saul went into the cave to relieve himself, which means to empty his bowels.

Stop here and look at a picture of a sheepfold. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of a large cave, like the one where David and his men were hiding. Pause this audio here.

When David's men saw Saul, the men told David that this was the day Yahweh had spoken about, the day Yahweh said he would deliver David's enemy into David's hands and allow David to do to the enemy whatever seemed right. By saying this, the men implied that Yahweh brought Saul there so David could kill Saul. However, David's men mistakenly believed that Yahweh had spoken to David about this day. We do not have a record of it anywhere, so we cannot be sure that Yahweh ever told David he would deliver Saul to David. The men saw Saul coming into the cave as a sign from Yahweh that now was the time for David to kill Saul.

Then David quietly moved close enough to touch Saul's robe, which was a long, sleeveless outer garment. Then David secretly cut off the corner of Saul's robe. A corner refers to an edge or border of the robe. It was not necessarily a corner piece. The robe may have been round, without corners. The word "secretly" refers both to the way David moved over to Saul and to the way David cut off the corner of the robe. Saul did not know what David had done.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a robe that Saul was likely to wear. Pause this audio here.

After David cut the corner of Saul's robe, David felt sorry and regretted what he had done because he believed it was wrong. In those days, people viewed cutting off a corner of the hem as a symbol of disloyalty and rebellion. Saul's robe also showed Saul's authority as king. David was disrespecting Saul as king by cutting off part of Saul's robe.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Talk about a situation when somebody made a wrong decision because they followed wrong advice. Talk about a time when something seemed like a message from God, but you later realized that it was not from God. What made you think the message was from God in the first place? What made you realize the message was not from God? Pause this audio here.

David said to David's men, "Yahweh forbid that I should do such a thing to my master, Yahweh's anointed." David regretted what David had done and said he would not harm Saul. David would not do "such a thing," to kill Saul as David's men had suggested. David would not kill Saul because Saul was Yahweh's anointed one, which meant that Yahweh had chosen Saul to be king over Israel. David respected Saul because Yahweh had anointed, or appointed, Saul to be king over Israel, and Saul was still king. Saul was still king even though, as you will remember, the Spirit of Yahweh had already left Saul. Because Saul was the person Yahweh had anointed, David would not attack or harm Saul.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Talk about a situation when somebody wronged you, but you stopped yourself from paying that person back. Talk about the reasons that made you not pay that person back. Pause this audio here.

David stopped or restrained his men by what David said, and David did not allow his men to kill Saul. Saul finished relieving himself, stood, went out of the cave, and started out on his way.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 24:1–7 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has five scenes.

In the first scene: Saul returns home from fighting the Philistines, and someone tells Saul that David is in the wilderness surrounding the oasis of En Gedi. Saul selects 3,000 of the best soldiers in Israel, and Saul and his army go to look for David and David's men in a place called the rocks of the wild goats at En Gedi.

In the second scene: Saul comes to some sheepfolds along the route where people walked. There is a cave by the sheepfolds, and David and his men are sitting in the innermost part of the cave. Saul goes into the cave to relieve himself.

In the third scene: David's men mistakenly believe that Saul's coming into the cave is a sign from Yahweh that now is the time for David to kill Saul. David moves over to within reach of Saul's robe and secretly cuts off the corner of the robe.

In the fourth scene: After David cuts the corner of Saul's robe, David feels sorry and regrets what he had done because he believes that it was wrong. David speaks to his men and strongly rejects the idea of attacking Saul. David says that David would not attack Saul, because Yahweh had anointed or chosen Saul to be king of Israel.

In the fifth scene: David stops or restrains his men by what David says, and David does not allow the men to kill Saul. Saul gets up, leaves the cave, and starts out on his way.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Saul

  • The Philistines

  • Someone who told Saul where David was

  • Three thousand soldiers that Saul selected

  • David

  • And David's men

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

Saul and his army were fighting the Philistines and chasing them away from the land of Israel. When Saul and Saul's army returned home, someone told Saul, "Look! David is in the wilderness of En Gedi." The man started talking to Saul in a way that shows that the information the man gave to Saul was important.

Stop here as a group and look at the map. Locate the wilderness of En Gedi. Pause this audio here.

Stop here as a group and discuss: What do you say in your language to show that the information you are giving is important? Pause this audio here.

As a result of the news Saul received, Saul selected 3,000 of the best soldiers in Israel. Then Saul and his army went to look for David and David's men in a place people called the rocks of the wild goats at En Gedi. Gibeah, where Saul lived, was about 65 to 80 kilometres from En Gedi. It would take Saul and Saul's army between 1.5 and 2 days to walk from Gibeah to En Gedi.

Stop here as a group and look at the map. Locate the journey Saul and his men did from Gibeah to En Gedi. Pause this audio here.

Saul came to some sheepfolds that were along the route where people walked. There was a cave by the sheepfolds, and David and his men were sitting in the innermost part of the cave, which was the area farthest away from the entrance. The cave must have been big enough that Saul was not aware that there were other men in the cave. Saul went into the cave to relieve himself. The original language says that Saul went into the cave to "cover his feet," because when a man squatted to relieve himself, his robe covered his feet.

Stop here as a group and discuss: What do you say in your language when someone has gone to relieve themselves? How do you say it in an appropriate way that all people, men and women and children together, can listen to? What do you say specifically when a person has gone to empty their bowels? Pause this audio here.

Then David's men spoke to David and said, "Here is the day of which Yahweh said to you, 'Behold, I will give your enemy into your hand, and you shall do to him as it shall seem good to you.'" The men did not speak to David altogether. Most likely, one of the men spoke to David in a whisper, and the others agreed. The men were calling David's attention to the fact that this was a good time or opportunity to kill Saul.

Stop here as a group and discuss: How do you speak in your language to say that someone is whispering? Pause this audio here.

Then David quietly moved close enough to touch Saul's robe. Then David secretly cut off the robe's edge or border. The word "secretly" refers both to the way David moved over to Saul and to the way David cut off the corner of the robe. Saul did not know what David had done.

As soon as David cut the corner of Saul's robe, "his heart struck him," because he believed that what he had done was wrong. The expression "his heart struck him" means that David suddenly felt sorry and regretted what David had done. You can also say that David felt sad in his heart. It is important to note that David realized that what he did was wrong very soon after David had cut the corner of Saul's robe.

David spoke to his men and strongly rejected the idea of attacking Saul. David said to his men, "Yahweh forbid that I should do such a thing to my master, Yahweh's anointed." "Yahweh forbid" means "Never!" David said that he would never do such a thing to David's master, Yahweh's anointed. David would not attack Saul, because Yahweh had anointed or chosen Saul to be king of Israel. That is why David would not put out his hand against Saul or harm Saul. David was likely very quietly whispering to his men, as Saul was still in the cave.

David stopped or restrained his men by what David said, and David did not allow the men to kill Saul. Then Saul got up, left the cave, and started out on his way or in the direction Saul intended to go.

Stop here as a group and discuss: How will you translate "Yahweh forbid" to mean "Never!"? How will you show that David and his men are speaking so quietly that Saul does not hear the men? Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 24:1–7 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has five scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Saul

  • The Philistines

  • Someone who told Saul where David was

  • Three thousand soldiers that Saul selected

  • David

  • David's men

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Saul returned home from fighting the Philistines, and someone told Saul that David was in the wilderness surrounding the oasis of En Gedi. Saul selected 3,000 of the best soldiers in Israel, and Saul and his army went to look for David and David's men in a place called the rocks of the wild goats at En Gedi.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so happy that at last we will catch David; or

  • I will not let David get away again! David must die! or

  • God is delivering David into my hand again! No one will interrupt my mission this time!

Saul came to some sheepfolds along the route where people walked. There was a cave by the sheepfolds, and David and his men were sitting in the innermost part of the cave. Saul went into the cave to relieve himself.

David's men spoke to David and told him that this was the day Yahweh had spoken about, the day Yahweh said Yahweh would deliver David's enemy, King Saul, into David's hands and allow David to do to the enemy whatever seemed right. Then David moved over to within reach of Saul's robe and secretly cut off the corner of the robe.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David's men, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • At long last, the day has come to kill Saul! or

  • Saul walked into the cave we are in! Yahweh has delivered Saul into our hands! or

  • We need to tell David that this is the day Yahweh has given him to do with Saul as David pleases. Surely David will allow us to kill King Saul!

After David cut the corner of Saul's robe, David felt sorry and regretted what he had done because David believed that it was wrong. David spoke to his men and strongly rejected the idea of attacking Saul. David said that he would not attack Saul because Yahweh had chosen Saul to be king of Israel.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • What have I done by cutting off the corner of King Saul's robe? I feel so ashamed! I behaved like a traitor; or

  • Saul is still King of Israel. Yahweh anointed Saul to be king. I will not kill Yahweh's anointed! or

  • I must speak to my men and stop them from killing Saul. My men spoke like they heard from Yahweh, but Yahweh does not want us to kill Saul.

David stopped or restrained his men by what David said, and David did not allow the men to kill Saul. Saul stood, left the cave, and started out on his way.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 24:1–7 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

When Saul and his army returned home, someone told Saul that David was in the wilderness surrounding the oasis of En Gedi. Use the same word or phrase for wilderness as you used in previous passages. For more information on wilderness, refer to the Master Glossary.

On hearing the news about David's location, Saul selected 3,000 of the best soldiers in Israel, and Saul and his army went to look for David and his men in a place called the rocks of the wild goats at En Gedi. Use the same word or phrase for Israel as you used in previous passages. For more information on Israel, refer to the Master Glossary.

Saul came to some sheepfolds, or sheep pens, along the route people walked. A sheepfold refers to a fence-like enclosure that people made of stones. Some sheepfolds were permanent, consisting of stone walls and a roof. Others were temporary constructions of loose stones with thorn bushes on top.

Stop here and look at a picture of a sheepfold. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for sheepfolds. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

David's men spoke to David. The men told David that this was the day Yahweh had spoken about, the day Yahweh said he would deliver David's enemy, King Saul, into David's hands and allow David to do to the enemy whatever seemed right. Yahweh is God's personal name, and the storyteller uses this name throughout this passage. Use the same name for Yahweh that you have used in previous passages. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary.

David reached out and cut off a corner of Saul's robe. Use the same word for robe as you have used in previous passages, and remember that robe is in the Master Glossary.

David spoke to his men and strongly rejected the idea of attacking Saul. David says that David would not attack his lord Saul, because Saul was Yahweh's anointed, or chosen person to be king of Israel. Here, the word lord means master, someone who has full authority. Saul was David's lord because Saul was the king of Israel.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for lord. Look up lord in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Use the same word or phrase for anointed as you used in previous passages. For more information on anointed, refer to the Master Glossary.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
