title: 1 Samuel 24:8–22
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 24:8–22 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 24:8–22 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 24:8–22 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous passage, after hearing that David was in the wilderness of En Gedi, Saul took 3,000 of his best soldiers to find David. Saul went into a cave to relieve himself, not knowing David and David's men were hiding inside. David's men said this was the day Yahweh promised to give David's enemy into David's hands. David quietly cut off a corner of Saul's robe but immediately felt guilty. David stopped his men from attacking Saul because Saul was the king whom Yahweh chose. Then Saul got up and left the cave.

As soon as Saul had left the cave, David quickly goes out of the cave and shouts after Saul, "My lord the king!" to show David's great respect. When Saul looks behind to see who is calling him, David bows down with his face to the ground to honour Saul.

David asks why Saul is listening to people who tell Saul that David wants to harm Saul. David is not really asking a question, but is telling Saul that Saul should not listen when people tell Saul that David is seeking Saul's harm.

David tells Saul that Saul was in the cave and saw what happened with his own eyes. Saul witnessed how Yahweh put Saul into David's hands, or into David's power, and David had a chance to kill Saul in the cave. Some of David's men told David to kill Saul, but David felt sorry for Saul and spared him. David refused to lay a hand on Saul, or harm Saul, because Saul is David's master and Saul is the person Yahweh anointed, or chose to be king.

David tries to convince King Saul that David is innocent. David says, "Look, my father, see the corner of your robe in my hand." David calls Saul his "father" to show respect. David shows Saul the piece of Saul's robe he secretly cut off, which proves that David could have easily killed Saul but chose not to. David tells Saul that this shows David has not sinned against Saul or done anything wrong. David has not rebelled against Saul or encouraged others to disobey Saul. Even though David has not wronged Saul, Saul is still chasing David to kill him.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Talk about a situation when someone has accused you wrongly of having done something you did not do. How did you convince that person that you were innocent? Pause this audio here.

David keeps talking to Saul and calls on Yahweh to decide who is right. David believes Saul is wrong, so David calls on Yahweh to avenge David against Saul, or punish Saul for the bad things he has done. However, David promises that David himself will never hurt Saul. David says, "But my hand shall not be against you." These words make it clear that David does not want to use any violence against Saul.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Talk about a time when someone treated you unfairly, and you chose not to take revenge. How did you feel, and why did you decide not to take revenge? Pause this audio here.

David now quotes an old proverb, or wise saying, which David, Saul, and the people of that time knew well. The saying says, "Wicked actions come from wicked men!" The meaning of the wise saying is that only evil people do evil deeds. David implies that since David is not an evil person, David would not do evil to Saul. David is likely also implying that since Saul was trying to do evil to David, Saul must be an evil person. David says that he will not hurt Saul because David is not a bad person. David promises that his hand will not be against Saul.

David continues to speak to Saul and asks Saul a question that does not require an answer. David tells Saul that Saul, the king of Israel, should not have come out with an army to chase David in the wilderness. David asks why Saul is wasting time chasing someone who will not hurt Saul. It is like chasing a dead dog or a tiny flea. But a dead dog is harmless. A flea is a tiny insect that jumps and feeds on the blood of animals or people. A flea is so small that it is hard to see. David speaks humbly, saying that David is not dangerous, not important, and not worth Saul's trouble.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a dog. Pause this audio here.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a flea. Pause this audio here.

David knows he will not get justice from Saul, so while speaking to Saul, David calls on Yahweh to judge between David and Saul and to decide who is right and who is wrong. David also calls on Yahweh to see, or pay attention to, David's situation and defend David. David wants Yahweh to support David and prove he is right. David is also asking Yahweh to save David from Saul's hand, or power, and stop Saul from trying to harm David.

After David finishes speaking, Saul asks David, "Is this your voice, my son David?" Saul knows who was speaking, because Saul saw David when David called after Saul. When Saul says this, Saul shows that he is surprised that David is there. Saul means, "Am I really hearing you, David, my son?" Saul calls David Saul's son because it was a polite and affectionate way to refer to a younger man. There was no family relationship between Saul and David. Then Saul weeps, or cries loudly, probably because he realises that he wronged David.

Saul says to David, "You are more righteous than I am." Saul admits that David is more righteous, which means that David acted morally and correctly. Saul explains that David treated him well by showing Saul kindness and faithfulness. David was loyal to Saul and did not try to harm Saul. But Saul treated David badly, and Saul admits he acted the opposite of how David acted.

Saul tells David that what David just said shows Saul that David was good to him. Even though Yahweh gave David the chance to kill Saul, David chose not to.

Saul makes a strong point by asking a question that does not need an answer. Saul says people do not let their enemies go free when people can hurt their enemies. Saul admits that David was good to Saul by not killing him when David had the chance. Saul then asks Yahweh to reward David for this kind action.

Then Saul admits that he has no doubt that David will become king, and the kingship of Israel will always remain in David's hands.

Saul now asks David to swear, or make a serious promise in Yahweh's name, that David will not kill Saul's descendants and make Saul's family disappear. Saul wants David to promise that when David becomes king, David will not harm Saul's children or grandchildren. Back then, it was common for new kings to kill the former king's family to stop rebellions. If David killed Saul's descendants, people would forget Saul's name, and Saul's sons would not be there to pass on Saul's name and land. Other members of Saul's clan would take over Saul's land.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Why do you think it was important for Saul that his name and land carry on to Saul's descendants? How do you feel about descendants inheriting the family name or title and land in your culture? Pause this audio here.

So David agrees to Saul's request and swears, or makes a serious promise in Yahweh's name, not to kill Saul's family. Then Saul returns home to Gibeah, but David and his men go up to the stronghold, their hiding place in the mountains in the wilderness in the territory of the tribe of Judah.

Stop here as a group and look at the map. Locate the journey of Saul from En Gedi to Gibeah and the journey of David from En Gedi to the wilderness in the mountains in the territory of the tribe of Judah.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 24:8–22 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has five scenes.

In the first scene: Shortly after Saul left the cave, David quickly goes out from the cave and shouts after Saul. When Saul looks behind him, David tells Saul that Saul should not listen when people tell Saul that David is seeking to harm Saul.

In the second scene: David speaks to Saul. David tells Saul that Saul saw how Yahweh gave David a chance to kill Saul in the cave, but David chose not to. David says he has not done anything wrong to Saul, even though Saul is chasing David to kill him. David calls on Yahweh to judge between David and Saul and to punish Saul if Saul has done wrong. But David promises he will never hurt Saul. Finally, David asks Yahweh to defend David, protect him, and save him from Saul's power.

In the third scene: After David finishes speaking, Saul admits that David is more righteous than Saul is because David stayed loyal and did not harm Saul, even though Saul treated David badly. Saul asks Yahweh to reward David for David's kindness. Saul also admits that he is sure David will become king and that Israel will do well under David's leadership.

In the fourth scene: Saul asks David to promise in Yahweh's name not to kill Saul's descendants or destroy Saul's family. David agrees and makes the promise.

In the fifth scene: Then Saul returns home to Gibeah, but David and his men go up to the stronghold, their hiding place in the mountains in the wilderness in the territory of the tribe of Judah.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • King Saul

  • Saul's men—the storyteller does not mention the men, but we know they are somewhere near, and they travel back with Saul to Gibeah

  • And David's men—the storyteller does not mention the men, but we know they are in the cave and then travel back with David to the stronghold

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

Right after Saul left the cave where David and his men were hiding, David quickly goes out from the cave and shouts after Saul respectfully, "My lord the king!" Even though Saul is close by, enough time passed for Saul to be some distance away, so David shouts or speaks loudly to Saul. When Saul looks behind to see who called him, David bows down with his face to the ground to give respect to Saul.

David asks why Saul is listening to people who tell Saul that David wants to harm Saul. David is not really asking a question, but telling Saul that Saul should not listen when people tell Saul that David is seeking to harm Saul.

David tells Saul that Saul was there and saw what happened with his own eyes. Saul witnessed how Yahweh put Saul into David's hands, or into David's power, and David had a chance to kill Saul in the cave. Some of David's men told David to kill Saul, but David felt sorry for Saul and spared him. David refused to lay a hand on Saul or harm Saul, because Saul is David's master and the one Yahweh anointed or chose to be king.

David wants Saul to look closely at the piece of Saul's robe that David cut off. David says, "Look, my father, see the corner of your robe in my hand." David refers to Saul as "my father" to show respect. David tells Saul that this shows David has not sinned against Saul. David says that "there is no evil in David's hands," which means that David has not done anything wrong. Still, even though David has not hurt Saul, Saul is chasing David to kill him.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What do you say in your language if you want someone to look closely at something? Pause this audio here.

David keeps talking to Saul and calls on God to judge between David and Saul, which means to decide who is right. David believes Saul is wrong, so David asks God to avenge David against Saul, or punish Saul for the wrong things Saul has done. However, David promises that David himself will never hurt Saul. David says, "But my hand shall not be against you." This means that David does not want to use any violence against Saul.

David now quotes an old proverb, or wise saying that everyone knew: "Wicked actions come from wicked men." David suggests that because he is not evil, he will not harm Saul. David also hints that since Saul is trying to harm David, Saul might be acting like an evil person. However, David speaks very humbly and politely to Saul and does not say this directly. David finishes by saying that David's hand will not be against Saul, which means that David will not hurt Saul because David is not a wicked man.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Talk about wise old sayings in your culture. Talk about what areas of life people mostly use these sayings for, and how people have changed the sayings over time. Is there a special way you use words when you quote wise sayings? Or is there a way you show that you are using a wise saying in a story? Pause this audio here.

David keeps speaking to Saul, and David refers to Saul in a way that shows respect for Saul's high position. David says, "After whom has the king of Israel come out?" By asking a question that does not require an answer, David makes a strong point that the king of Israel should not have come out against David. When David says Saul has "come out," David means that Saul has come to chase David. David asks why Saul is wasting time chasing someone who will not hurt David. It is like chasing a dead dog or a tiny flea. David is speaking humbly, saying that David is not important, not dangerous, and not worth Saul's trouble.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What kinds of animals might you compare an unimportant person to? How will you talk about what David says in a way that shows that David is humble? Pause this audio here.

David continues to speak to Saul and calls on Yahweh to judge between David and Saul and decide who is right and who is wrong. David also asks Yahweh to see, or pay attention to, David's situation and to defend David. David wants Yahweh to support David and prove he is right. David also calls on Yahweh to deliver David from Saul's hand, or Saul's power, and to stop Saul from trying to harm David.

After David finishes speaking, Saul asks David, "Is this your voice, my son David?" Saul knows who was speaking, but Saul's question shows surprise at what David has said. Saul calls David his son because it was a polite and affectionate way to refer to a younger man. Saul weeps or cries aloud, probably because Saul thinks he has wronged David.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What are the usual ways people refer to each other in your language, depending on their age and position in the community? Pause this audio here.

Saul says to David, "You are more righteous than I am." Here, "righteous" means being in the right. Saul admits that David acted morally and correctly. Saul explains why he believes that David is in the right by comparing David's good behaviour to Saul's own bad actions.

Saul tells David that what David just said shows him that David was good to Saul. Even though Yahweh put Saul into David's hands, or gave David the chance to kill Saul, David chose not to.

Saul asks a question that does not need an answer. Saul says, "For if a man finds his enemy, will he let him go away safe?" Saul makes a strong point that most people do not let their enemies go free when they can harm their enemies. Then, Saul asks Yahweh to reward David for David's kind action.

Then Saul admits that Saul believes that David will become king and the kingship of Israel will remain in David's family.

Saul now asks David to swear, or make a serious promise in Yahweh's name, that David will not kill Saul's descendants and make Saul's family disappear. Saul wants David to promise that when David becomes king, David will not harm Saul's children or grandchildren. In making such a promise, an Israelite probably said something like, "As surely as Yahweh lives."

Stop here and discuss as a group: What do people say in your language when they make solemn promises or vows? Remember how you translated what people say to make serious promises in previous passages in 1 Samuel. Pause this audio here.

So David agrees to Saul's request and swears, or makes an oath, not to kill Saul's family. Then Saul and his men return home to Gibeah, but David and his men go up to the stronghold, their hiding place in the mountains of the wilderness in the territory of the tribe of Judah. Gibeah was about 65 to 80 kilometres northwest of En Gedi, and it would take Saul and his men about 1.5 to 2 days or more to walk across a mountain area. The stronghold in the mountains in the wilderness in the territory of the tribe of Judah was about 20 to 30 kilometres west of En Gedi, and it would take David and his men about 2 to 3 days to walk across the steep mountains.

Stop here as a group and look at the map. Locate the journey of Saul from En Gedi to Gibeah and the journey of David from En Gedi to the wilderness in the mountains in the territory of the tribe of Judah. Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 24:8–22 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has five scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • King Saul

  • Saul's men—the storyteller does not mention the men, but we know they are somewhere near, and they travel back with Saul to Gibeah

  • And David's men—the storyteller does not mention the men, but we know they are in the cave and then travel back with David to the stronghold

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Shortly after Saul left the cave, David quickly goes out from the cave and shouts after Saul, "My lord the king!" When Saul looks behind to see who is calling him, David bows down with his face to the ground to honor Saul. David tells Saul that Saul should not listen when people tell Saul that David is seeking Saul's harm.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel hopeful. King Saul has seen for himself that Yahweh gave Saul into my hands, but I have not hurt Saul; or

  • I feel desperate. This is my only chance to convince Saul that I do not want to harm him and have done good to him; or

  • I feel a bit scared. What if Saul now sends his men to attack me and my men?

David tells Saul that Saul saw with his own eyes how Yahweh put Saul into David's hands, or into his power, and David had a chance to kill Saul in the cave. Some of David's men told David to kill Saul, but David spared Saul. David says he refused to lay a hand on Saul, or harm Saul, because Saul is David's master and the one Yahweh anointed, or chose to be king.

David tries to convince King Saul that David is innocent. David shows Saul the piece of Saul's robe he secretly cut off, which proves that David could have easily killed Saul but chose not to. David tells Saul that this shows David has not sinned against Saul or done anything wrong. Even though David has not wronged Saul, Saul is still chasing David to kill him.

David keeps talking to Saul and calls on Yahweh to decide who is right. David also calls on Yahweh to avenge David against Saul, or punish Saul for the bad things Saul has done. However, David promises that David will never hurt Saul.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel desperate for King Saul to see that I am innocent, and I am in the right; or

  • I am losing hope that Saul will be just. I need to ask Yahweh to show Saul that I am in the right. Yahweh needs to protect me; or

  • Only Yahweh can punish Saul for the bad things Saul has done, because Yahweh chose Saul to be king.

David now quotes an old wise saying, "Wicked actions come from wicked men!" David says that he is not going to harm Saul because David is not a wicked man. David tells Saul that Saul, the king of Israel, should not have come out with an army to chase David in the wilderness. It is like chasing a dead dog or a tiny flea because David is not important, not dangerous, and not worth Saul's trouble.

While David speaks to Saul, David calls on Yahweh to judge between David and Saul and to decide who is right and who is wrong. David also calls on Yahweh to pay attention to David's situation and defend David. David wants Yahweh to support David and prove he is right. David is also calling on Yahweh to deliver David from Saul's hand, or power, and stop Saul from trying to harm David.

After David finishes speaking, Saul asks David whether he was really hearing David's voice. Then Saul weeps, or cries loudly. Saul admits that David was more righteous than Saul was. David was loyal to Saul and did not harm him, but Saul treated David badly.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am shocked. Is that really David speaking to me right now? Has David really spared my life even though he could kill me in the cave? or

  • I am ashamed. I wrongly accused David and chased David to kill him; or

  • I feel deep sadness. David is more righteous than I am. I hope Yahweh forgives me for what I have done.

Saul tells David that what David just said shows Saul that David was good to Saul. Even though Yahweh gave David the chance to kill Saul, David chose not to. Saul makes a strong point that people do not let their enemies go free when people can hurt their enemies. Saul admits that David was good to Saul by not killing Saul when David had the chance. Saul then asks Yahweh to reward David for this kind action.

Saul admits that he has no doubt that David will become king, and the kingship of Israel will prosper and remain in David's family. Saul now asks David to swear, or make a serious promise in Yahweh's name, that Saul will not kill Saul's descendants and make his family disappear. So David agrees to Saul's request and swears, or makes an oath, not to kill Saul's family. Then Saul returns home to Gibeah, but David and his men go up to the stronghold, their hiding place in the mountains in the wilderness in the territory of the tribe of Judah.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel relieved that I did not kill Saul, even when my men told me to; or

  • I praise Yahweh, for Yahweh is just! Yahweh showed Saul my innocence; or

  • I feel grateful that evil people cannot stop Yahweh's plans. Now even Saul says that I will be king over Israel!

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 24:8–22 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Shortly after Saul left the cave, David gets up and goes out from the cave and shouts after Saul, "My lord the king!" David bows down to Saul. Use the same words or phrases for cave, lord, king, and bow down as you used in previous passages. For more information on lord, king, and bow, refer to the Master Glossary.

David tells Saul that Saul saw with his own eyes how Yahweh put Saul into David's hands, or into David's power, and David had a chance to kill Saul in the cave. Use similar phrases for the idea of Yahweh putting people into someone's hands, or power, that you have used previously. Yahweh is God's personal name, and the storyteller uses this name throughout this passage. Use the same name for Yahweh that you have used in previous passages. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary.

David tries to convince King Saul that David is innocent. David shows Saul the piece of Saul's robe that David secretly cut off, which proves that David could have easily killed Saul but chose not to because Yahweh anointed Saul. David tells Saul that this shows David has not sinned against Saul or done anything wrong. Use the same words or phrases for anointed, robe, and sin as you used in previous passages. For more information on anointed, robe, and sin, refer to the Master Glossary.

David asks Yahweh to judge between David and Saul to see who has done the right thing. Use the same words or phrases for "judging between people" that you have used previously. Judge is in the Master Glossary.

David now quotes an old proverb, or wise saying that David, Saul, and the people of that time knew well. The saying says, "Wicked, or evil, actions come from wicked men!" Wicked actions are evil or bad. Use the same words or phrases for wicked and proverb as you used in previous passages. For more information on wicked and proverb, refer to the Master Glossary.

David tells Saul that Saul, the king of Israel, should not have come out with an army to chase David in the wilderness. It is like chasing a dead dog or a tiny flea because David is not important and not worth Saul's trouble. Use the same word or phrase for Israel as you used in previous passages. For more information on Israel, refer to the Master Glossary.

A dog is a furry animal that people often keep as a pet. Dogs are loyal and friendly, and people often train dogs to do things like fetch or protect their owners. But a dead dog is harmless. Use the word for dog that you used before.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a dog. Pause this audio here.

A flea is a tiny insect that jumps and feeds on the blood of animals or people. A flea is so small that it is hard to see.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a flea. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for flea. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

After David finishes speaking, Saul calls David his son and asks David whether he was really hearing David's voice. Then Saul weeps, or cries loudly. Saul admits that David was more righteous than Saul was. Here, the word righteous means being in the right. Saul admits that David did what was right, and Saul did not. Use the same words or phrases for son and righteous as you used in previous passages. For more information on son and righteous, refer to the Master Glossary.

Saul says that Saul knows Yahweh will give David the kingdom of Israel. Use the same word or phrase for kingdom that you have used previously. Kingdom is in the Master Glossary.

After David gives an oath not to kill Saul's family, Saul returns home to Gibeah, but David and his men go up to the stronghold, their hiding place in the mountains in the wilderness in the territory of the tribe of Judah. Here, stronghold means a cave, not a strong fort that people built. Use the same words or phrases for oath and wilderness stronghold as you used in previous passages. For more information on oath and stronghold, refer to the Master Glossary.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 25:1–13
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 25:1–13 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:1–13 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:1–13 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

This true story happened sometime after David spared Saul's life. In this story, the old prophet, Samuel, dies. The Israelites gather to grieve, or mourn, for Samuel. In Israelite custom, mourning often included loud crying or wailing. Public mourning for someone important like Samuel often lasted for weeks. The Israelites hold Samuel's funeral in Ramah, Samuel's hometown.

Stop here and look at a map that includes Ramah as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do people in your culture mourn for an important person or religious leader? Pause this audio here.

The storyteller mentions that David then goes down to the wilderness of Paran. David may have moved to the wilderness to get further away from Saul. Samuel's presence had helped keep Saul from hurting David. Now that Samuel has died, Saul might come to hurt David. A wilderness does not have many resources, so people have a hard time finding food, water, and shelter in the wilderness. People usually do not choose to live in a wilderness. Though the storyteller does not say it, we know from later in the story that David's army of men also travels with David. The wilderness of Paran lay in the northeastern part of the Sinai Peninsula. The area spanned from northwest of the Gulf of Aqaba into the mountains of Judah.

Stop here and look at a picture of a wilderness as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a map that includes the wilderness of Paran as a group. Pause this audio here.

The storyteller starts talking about a very rich man whom people called Nabal. Nabal lived in Maon, a town in the territory of the tribe of Judah, near Hebron. Nabal had property in Carmel, about a 30-minute walk north of Maon. The fertile land in Carmel provided a good place for Nabal's servants to take care of Nabal's animals. Nabal had many grazing animals. Nabal had 3,000 sheep and 1,000 goats.

Stop here and look at a map that includes Maon and Carmel as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at pictures of goats and sheep as a group. Pause this audio here.

Nabal's wife, Abigail, was good, wise, and beautiful. Nabal, however, was a bad man. People knew Nabal as a mean man with selfish habits and who treated people badly. Nabal descended from Caleb. This means that Nabal came from a well-known family in the tribe of Judah.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about someone important who was also a bad person. Pause this audio here.

In the wilderness, someone tells David that Nabal's servants have started to shear Nabal's sheep and goats. To shear means to pull or cut off the long hair or "wool" from the animals. Since the Israelites did not have iron tools in those days, people may have pulled off loose wool by hand or with a bronze comb. This typically does not hurt the animals. In fact, it helps to keep the sheep healthy. In those days, people usually sheared sheep once a year. The animals then grew more wool until the next year. Then the owner would either sell the wool or use the wool to make cloth. At that time, the owner of the animals used profits from selling the wool to pay the workers.

Stop here and look at an image of workers shearing sheep as a group. Pause this audio here.

In the story, David sends 10 young men from David's army as messengers to talk with Nabal in Carmel. We know from previous stories and from later in this story that David's army had hundreds of men. David sends the 10 young men to Nabal as representatives of David and David's army.

David's message includes a respectful greeting and an extremely polite request. David asks Nabal for help to send food for David's army to eat. David knew that during the animal shearing time, Nabal would have prepared a party with lots of food for Nabal's workers. David tells Nabal that David's army had stayed in Carmel near Nabal's workers, or shepherds, who took care of the sheep and goats. The whole time David's army stayed near Nabal's shepherds, the shepherds did not lose anything. In other words, David's army never attacked or stole from the shepherds. In fact, David's army likely even helped to protect Nabal's shepherds and animals from dangerous thieves. David even told Nabal that Nabal could ask Nabal's workers about what David had said. David knew that Nabal's workers would confirm that David told the truth.

Stop here and look at a picture of a shepherd as a group. Pause this audio here.

David was trying to arrange with Nabal to help each other. David and David's men had already protected Nabal's business. So, David was asking Nabal to help give some food to David's army. David does not ask for enough food to feed the whole army. David simply asks for the amount of food Nabal is willing to give.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about when one person politely negotiated with someone else. What did the first person say to start the negotiation? Pause this audio here.

After David told the message to the 10 men, these men went to tell the message to Nabal. David's 10 men then waited to hear Nabal's answer. This likely means that David's young men told David's message to Nabal's servants. Then Nabal's servants would have told Nabal. Nabal then gave a formal, very harsh response. Nabal not only rejected David's request but also insulted David. Nabal then asked who David was. Nabal was implying that David was not important. Nabal even compared David to a slave who has run away from the slave owner. Nabal made it clear that Nabal would not give any help at all to David. Nabal did not want to share the food Nabal had prepared for his shearers.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when you made a polite request to another person. How would you feel if that person responded like Nabal did? Pause this audio here.

David's young men went back to David to report everything Nabal said to David. David immediately told David's army to attack Nabal. David and 400 men put on their swords and started to go to Nabal. Two hundred of David's men stayed to protect the army's supplies.

Stop here and look at a picture of a sword as a group.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:1–13 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has six scenes.

In the first scene: Samuel dies, and the Israelites mourn for Samuel. David and David's men move to the Desert of Paran.

In the second scene: The storyteller describes Nabal and Nabal's wife, Abigail.

In the third scene: David learns that Nabal is shearing sheep. So, David asks 10 messengers from David's army to give Nabal a message. David tells the messengers the message to give to Nabal. David wants to ask Nabal for food and drink since David's army already protected Nabal's shepherds and sheep.

In the fourth scene: The messengers travel to Nabal and tell David's message to Nabal. David's messengers then wait for Nabal's response.

In the fifth scene: Nabal strongly insults David and rudely refuses to help David.

In the sixth scene: David's messengers return to tell David what Nabal said. David prepares 400 men from David's army to go attack Nabal.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel

  • Israelites who mourn for Samuel

  • David

  • David's army

  • Nabal

  • Abigail

  • Nabal's servants, who include the shepherds and shearers

  • And 10 young men from David's army who tell Nabal about David's message

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In scene one, we learn that the prophet Samuel has died. Israelites traveled from many places to Ramah to mourn for Samuel. The Israelites buried Samuel in Ramah, Samuel's hometown. The original language says that "all Israel" came together to mourn. Many of the Israelite people likely came to Ramah at different times over several weeks. After this, David and David's army of men went to stay in the wilderness of Paran.

Stop here and review the map that includes Ramah as a group, if needed. Pause this audio here.

In scene two, the storyteller describes a rich man from Maon but does not give the man's name. Then the storyteller describes this man's business in Carmel. The man owned 3,000 sheep and 1,000 goats. Each year, this man's servants, called shearers, would pull off or cut off the wool or hair of these sheep and goats. The original language says that this man "was shearing the sheep and goats." Actually, this man's servants did the shearing.

Stop here as a group and look at a photo of workers shearing sheep. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Act out pulling out and cutting off the extra hair on sheep and goats. Then act out gathering this hair to sell or so that others can make cloth to sell. After acting this out, describe the actions you did in your language. Pause this audio here.

The storyteller finally tells us the rich man's name, Nabal. Some translations tell Nabal's name first and then describe Nabal.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Describe someone you know. Pay attention to the order of when you tell details about the person and when you tell the person's name. Pause this audio here.

The storyteller also briefly tells us that Nabal had a wise and beautiful wife named Abigail. Then the storyteller continues to describe Nabal as a cruel man who was selfish and treated people badly. Nabal came from the clan of Caleb, part of the Israelite tribe of Judah.

In scene three, the storyteller mentions David's name three times. This shifts the focus from Nabal back to David. David learns that Nabal's servants were shearing sheep. David knew that owners celebrated during the shearing time. This means that Nabal would have prepared a lot of food. David's large army had little access to food in the wilderness. We learn later in the story that David already knew about Nabal since David's army had stayed near Nabal's shepherds before the shearing time. David had protected Nabal's business. So, David prepares 10 messengers from David's army to give a polite request for help from Nabal. David tells these messengers to peacefully ask in David's "name." This means that the messengers had David's authority to deliver the message to Nabal for David.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about one person. Then, in the same story, change the focus to another person. How does the listener know that you have shifted the focus to the second person? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a true story of when someone with authority sent messengers to deliver a message on behalf of the person in authority. Pay attention to the words you use that show that the messengers had the authority to give the message. Pause this audio here.

Then, David tells the messengers the message to give to Nabal. David wants to ask Nabal for food and drink since David's army already protected Nabal's shepherds and sheep. David gave a very polite request and used the word for "peace" three times. David wished Nabal, everyone in Nabal's home, and Nabal's belongings a good upcoming year and good health. Then David said that David had heard about the animal shearing time. David then informed Nabal that Nabal's servants who cared for Nabal's animals stayed in Carmel, near David's army. David's army never mistreated or stole from these servants. In other words, David's army had the strength and opportunity to mistreat and steal from Nabal, but did not do so. David said that Nabal could ask these servants, and the servants would confirm that David spoke the truth.

David then respectfully asked Nabal to treat David's men with kindness during the shearing celebration. David asked that David's men would "find favor" in Nabal's eyes. Finally, David asked Nabal to give whatever food Nabal could give to the messengers and to David for David's army. David refers to the messengers as "your servants" and to David as "your son David." David is showing respect to Nabal by showing that David knows Nabal has more wealth and power than David does.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Act out a situation with two people. The first person should have more wealth and power than the second. The second person should respectfully and humbly ask for help from the first person. What words did the second person use to show respect? Pause this audio here.

David spoke to the messengers. David's words to the messengers included the message that the messengers would soon say to Nabal. Some translations use David's words as though David spoke all of this directly. The messengers would then quote this to Nabal later. For example, "I have heard that your shearers are shearing the animals." Other translations use David's words as the messengers would tell the words for David. For example, "David heard that your shearers are shearing the animals."

Stop here and try different ways to say this. Discuss as a group which ways sound more natural. Pause this audio here.

In scene four, David's messengers travel to Nabal. With David's authority, the messengers tell David's message to Nabal. David's messengers then wait for Nabal's response.

In scene five, the story briefly shifts to focus on Nabal. Nabal asks, "Who is this David? Who is this son of Jesse?" "Son of Jesse" refers to David, whose father is named Jesse. Nabal then said that many slaves run away from their owners. Nabal is insulting David and implying that David is no better than a lowly slave. Nabal then says to David's messengers, "I do not even know you or where you come from. Why should I give you bread and water? Why should I let you eat the animals I have killed for my servants who sheared my sheep?" Nabal is not expecting anyone to answer these questions. These questions emphasize that Nabal did not think David had any importance or worth to Nabal. Nabal had no intention of giving up Nabal's food to help feed David and David's men.

Scene six starts with David's men's response. The men "turn around and go back" to David and tell David everything. The storyteller emphasizes this by repeating David's name three times. David's men tell David "all these words." This means the men said everything Nabal said when Nabal arrogantly rejected David's request.

Then the storyteller shows that David immediately responds after David hears that Nabal has rudely rejected David's request. As we see in the next story, David is very upset and acts immediately. David instructs all of David's men to put on their swords. David also puts on his own sword. Then David leads 400 of the men in the army, and they start to go to Nabal in Carmel. Two hundred of David's men stay behind at the camp to protect all the gear.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:1–13 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has six scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel

  • Israelites who mourn for Samuel

  • David

  • David's army

  • Nabal

  • Abigail

  • Nabal's servants, who include the shepherds and shearers

  • And 10 young men from David's army who tell Nabal about David's message

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

In the first scene, Samuel dies, and the Israelites mourn for Samuel in Ramah. Then David and David's army go to the wilderness of Paran.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Israelites, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We loved and respected Samuel. This is a hard time for us Israelites; or

  • God used Samuel to bless and direct our people. We want to honor Samuel at Samuel's funeral.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Saul knows that God has chosen me as the next king. Now that Samuel has died, Saul will probably act more harshly toward me; or

  • Now that Samuel is not here to stop Saul, Saul may come to hunt me down. My men and I will need to go into hiding.

In scene two, the storyteller describes Nabal and Nabal's wife, Abigail. Nabal lives in Maon and has a business raising sheep and goats in the nearby town, Carmel. Nabal has a lot of wealth, but people know Nabal's mean and unethical character. Abigail is very different from Nabal. Abigail is intelligent and beautiful.

In scene three, David learns that Nabal's servants are cutting the wool from Nabal's animals. David then prepares 10 young men from David's army to give a message to Nabal.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • My army lives in the wilderness. We do not have enough food for all 600 men. We need help from others to give us food; or

  • My army has helped Nabal's shepherds. I can ask Nabal to help us in return; or

  • I have shown kindness to Nabal, so perhaps Nabal will show kindness to me.

Then David tells the messengers the message to give to Nabal. David wants to ask Nabal for food and drink since David's army already protected Nabal's shepherds and sheep.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Nabal has a higher position and more wealth than I do. I want to show respect to Nabal; or

  • I will only ask Nabal for the amount Nabal wants to give. I do not want to ask for too much. I will feel content with whatever Nabal willingly gives; or

  • We treated Nabal's men very well, so I feel like I have a right to ask for food in return. But I do not want to be demanding or disrespectful. I'll just ask nicely for Nabal's leftovers.

In scene four, the messengers travel to Nabal and tell David's message to Nabal. David's messengers then wait for Nabal's response.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David's messengers, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • David has given a very polite, respectful, and humble message to Nabal. Since our army has helped Nabal, we believe Nabal will help us; or

  • David is making a wise arrangement with Nabal. Our army can help Nabal, and we will gladly continue to help Nabal.

In scene five, Nabal strongly insults David and rudely refuses to help David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Nabal, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel very angry at this stranger, David; or

  • Carmel has a monument of big stones that celebrates Saul's battle victory. Everyone who sees these stones knows King Saul's power. David, Jesse's son, does not have any power; or

  • I worked hard to gain my wealth, and this nobody, David, shows disrespect to ask anything from me; or

  • I do not care that David helped my servants. I do not owe David anything. I am better than David.

In scene six, David's messengers return to tell David what Nabal said. David prepares 400 men from David's army to go attack Nabal.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I asked Nabal politely for help in return for helping Nabal. Nabal is acting selfishly; or

  • I humbly and respectfully gave a message to Nabal, but Nabal very rudely insulted me; or

  • I am very angry at Nabal.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:1–13 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Israel came together to mourn for Samuel. Here, "Israel" refers to the Israelites. Israelites refer to the people who are descendants of Abraham. The Israelites lived in the country called Israel. Use the same word or phrase for Israelites as you used in previous passages. For more information on Israelites, refer to the Master Glossary.

David and David's army went to the wilderness. A wilderness has almost no plants or animals. People do not usually live in the wilderness.

Look up wilderness in the Master Glossary for more information, and translate wilderness in the same way as you have in previous passages. Pause this audio here.

The story talks about Nabal's 3,000 sheep and 1,000 goats. Rich people in those days often had many sheep and goats. Sheep and goats are both grazing animals. This means that sheep and goats eat grass and other small plants in fields. People use the milk and meat from sheep and goats to make food to eat. People also use the skin and hair from sheep and goats to make clothes. Sheep and goats depend on shepherds, people who guide the animals to find food. The shepherds also protect sheep and goats. Shepherds stop thieves from stealing the sheep and goats. Shepherds also stop wild animals from attacking and killing the sheep and goats. Use the same words for shepherds, sheep, and goats that you used in previous passages. See shepherd in the Master Glossary for more information.

Nabal's servants sheared the sheep and goats. This means that the servants cut off or pulled off the hair or wool of the animals in order to make cloth. In Nabal's time, servants sometimes used a metal comb to help pull off the animals' hair. This usually does not hurt the animal.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for shear and wool. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Nabal had servants who sheared the sheep. A servant is a man or woman who works for another person, the master. Servants have low status in the community and must obey the master. Look up servant in the Master Glossary for more information, and use the same word for servants as you have used in previous passages.

People knew Nabal as a harsh or mean man. A harsh person usually acts angrily toward other people. Harsh people often are very selfish. Harsh people often feel happy when other people suffer.

Stop here and discuss as a group how you will describe Nabal as a harsh and mean man. Remember how you described the bad person in step two. Pause this audio here.

The storyteller tells us that Nabal comes from the Calebite family. Calebite refers to a descendant of Caleb. Calebites came from the Israelite tribe of Judah.

In this story, David wishes peace to Nabal and Nabal's household, or the people who live in Nabal's house. This word for peace shows that David wishes for Nabal to have well-being in life. This also shows that David does not intend to harm Nabal. Instead, David is giving a friendly greeting. Look up peace in the Master Glossary for more information, and use the same word for peace that you have used in previous passages.

Sometimes the storyteller calls both David's and Nabal's men "young men" or servants. These are probably men who are not married but are old enough to fight or work hard for their master.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for young men.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
