title: 1 Samuel 25:14–22
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 25:14–22 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:14–22 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:14–22 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the last story, Nabal rudely rejected David's polite request for help. David responded by telling 400 men in David's army to join David to attack Nabal. This story happens at the same time that David's army was coming toward Nabal's land.

In this story, one of Nabal's servants told Nabal's wife, Abigail, how David had sent messengers to Nabal. Nabal's servant explained to Abigail how the messengers came from where David had been staying in the wilderness. Nabal's servant also explained how Nabal shouted at David's messengers when Nabal heard the message from David.

The servant then tells Abigail about how, for many days, David's army had stayed nearby to Nabal's servants. The servant talking to Abigail had personally stayed near David's army. The servant tells Abigail that David's army acted very kindly to Nabal's servants. David's army never stole from Nabal's servants who worked to care for Nabal's animals in the fields. In fact, David's army even protected Nabal's servants and animals all day and all night for a long time.

After telling Abigail how Nabal rudely responded to David's kindness, the servant urgently asked Abigail to carefully think about how to respond. Otherwise, the servant knew that things would end badly for Nabal and everyone in Nabal's household, including the servants. Because of Nabal's bad character, Nabal would not listen to anyone. So, the servant knew that talking to Nabal would not change the situation.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story about a person who would not listen to anyone. Pause this audio here.

Abigail quickly told the servants to prepare a generous gift of food and drink for David's army. The combination of all the food Abigail brought likely provided enough food for a good meal for at least 400 men, perhaps more. The food included 200 loaves of bread, 2 containers holding wine, the meat from 5 sheep, 5 large bags of dry, roasted grain, 100 handfuls of raisins, and 200 handfuls of ripe figs.

Abigail's servants prepared 200 loaves of bread. Sometimes, the Israelites made flat, round pieces of bread without yeast, which only took a short time. The Israelites called the bread with yeast "leavened" and the bread without yeast "unleavened." Unleavened bread tends to stay fresh longer than leavened bread. The storyteller does not explain the size or shape of each bread that Abigail asked the servants to prepare for David. Abigail either brought larger chunks of bread with yeast, called loaves or smaller, flat, round pieces of bread without yeast. Either way, more than one person could likely share each "bread." Two hundred loaves of bread, along with other food, would likely feed more than 200 men, perhaps even 400 men.

Stop here and look at a picture of loaves of bread and flat, round bread as a group. Discuss what word you might use in your language. Pause this audio here.

Abigail's servants also prepared two containers that held wine. Some translations call these containers "skins," meaning dried animal leather that people made into a container. But the containers could also refer to bottles or jars. In those days, the Israelites often drank a little bit of wine with each meal. The storyteller does not mention the size of these containers. The size depends on the size of the animal that the servants had killed to make the container of skin. However, one typical wineskin could hold enough wine for 126 to 169 people to each have a full drink. So, two wineskins could hold enough wine for 252 to 338 people to each have a full drink.

Stop here and look at a picture of a wineskin as a group. Describe in your own words what the wineskin looks like. Pause this audio here.

Abigail's servants prepared the meat from five sheep by removing the skin and the inside parts of the animal. The storyteller does not say whether the servants had already cooked the meat or not. Most likely, the servants had already cooked the meat. Each sheep could probably feed up to 60 men. So, the meat from all five sheep would likely feed almost 300 men.

Stop here and look at a picture of sheep as a group. Pause this audio here.

Abigail's servants prepared five large bags of dry, roasted grain, probably either wheat or barley. This amount of grain could feed about 18 people for one meal. People would need to eat most of the other food soon so that it did not spoil, but people could keep the grain longer without spoiling since someone had already roasted it.

Stop here and look at a picture of dry, roasted grain as a group. Pause this audio here.

Abigail's servants prepared 100 handfuls of raisins, or sun-dried ripe grapes, that people pressed together into one big lump. This kind of dried food lasted longer than fresh fruit.

Stop here and look at a picture of raisins as a group. Pause this audio here.

Abigail's servants prepared 200 handfuls of ripe, dried figs, a small, sweet fruit pressed together into one big lump. This kind of dried food lasted longer than fresh fruit.

Stop here and look at a picture of dried figs as a group. Pause this audio here.

Abigail told her servants to load all the food supplies onto donkeys. Then Abigail told the servants to start taking all the supplies to meet David's army. Abigail rode her donkey behind these servants to go greet David. Abigail did not tell her husband, Nabal, about what Abigail was doing. Suddenly, while Abigail rode her donkey down into a valley, David's army came down into the valley from the other direction.

Stop here and look at a picture of a donkey carrying a lot of supplies as a group. Pause this audio here.

Just before Abigail and David met in the valley, David had been talking about Nabal. Most likely, David said this out loud to the men in David's army. David said, "I did not receive any benefit by protecting this man's property in the desert. Because of me, no one stole any of this man's possessions there. I did good things for this man. In return, this man is acting badly towards me."

David then continued to say a very serious promise, or oath. David promises to kill every male in Nabal's household before the next morning. David also says that if David does not complete this oath, God should bring punishment to someone. Some translations say that God should bring punishment to David's enemies. But it is more likely that David means God should punish David if David does not kill every male in Nabal's household before the next morning.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:14–22 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has three scenes.

In the first scene: One of Nabal's servants tells Abigail about David's kindness to Nabal and Nabal's meanness to David.

In the second scene: Abigail quickly prepares food for David's army. Then Abigail and her servants go to meet David and David's army.

In the third scene: On the way to meet Nabal, David regrets ever helping Nabal. David makes an oath that God should kill David if David does not kill Nabal and all Nabal's male servants on that day.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Nabal's servant who talks with Abigail

  • Abigail, Nabal's wife

  • Nabal and Abigail's servants

  • David

  • And David's army

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In scene one, the storyteller starts the story with language that shows that what happens next happened at the same time as the end of the previous story. In other words, this story happens while David and 400 men from David's army are coming with swords to meet Nabal. At this time, back at Nabal's land, one of Nabal's young male servants speaks directly with Nabal's wife, Abigail. The servant uses a word to let Abigail know that the servant is about to say something important.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story of a time when someone wanted to tell an important person an important message. Pay attention to the words the person said to get the attention of the important person. Pause this audio here.

Scene one continues as Nabal's servant explains to Abigail that David had sent messengers to kindly greet Nabal. However, Nabal shouted harshly at David's messengers. Then the servant tells Abigail about something that happened before David sent the messengers to Nabal. In the recent past, Nabal's servants took care of Nabal's animals in the fields. At that same time, David and the men in David's army stayed near Nabal's servants. The servant says that David's army was "a wall" to Nabal's servants. Walls provide protection from bad things. So, the servant was saying that David's army protected the servants. The storyteller does not say how long David's army stayed near Nabal's servants. However, we know that animals eat in fields for weeks or months before shearers cut off the animal's hair. So, David's army likely stayed near Nabal's servants for weeks, possibly months. The servant even says that David's army showed kindness and gave protection to Nabal's servants all day and all night. Also, no one from David's army hurt or stole from Nabal's servants. Then David sent messengers to Nabal. Nabal shouted at the messengers.

Nabal's servant tells Abigail about all these events. Finally, the servant asks Abigail to carefully think about how to respond.

Stop here and discuss as a group: The events of scene one happened in a different order than how the servant told Abigail about the events. First, the servant told Abigail about how Nabal had insulted David's messengers, and then the servant told Abigail what had happened before Nabal insulted David's messengers. Practice telling this part of the story. What order sounds natural in your language? Pause this audio here.

Nabal's servant then says a word to bring Abigail's attention back to the current situation. The servant then tells Abigail to think carefully about how Abigail can respond to this situation. The words the servant uses almost sound like a command. Normally, especially in those days, a servant would not tell a superior what to do. The servant here is still acting respectfully to Abigail. However, the strong words show that the servant is making an urgent request. The servant continues to explain the reason for this request. The servant knows that something bad or "evil" will happen. The servant says the bad thing will happen to "our master," meaning Nabal, and all of the people in Nabal's household. The servant also says that speaking to Nabal will not work. In other words, the servant knows that the foolish and stubborn Nabal will not change or solve the bad situation. The servant actually calls Nabal a "son of worthlessness," which means a useless man. Here, "a son of worthlessness" means more than just useless. It also tells us that Nabal regularly chose to act badly.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Tell a story of a time that someone gave a respectful but urgent request to a superior. Pay attention to the words the person uses to show both respect and urgency. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Retell the story you told in step two about a person who would not listen to other people's advice. Now, think about what words you used in the story to describe this "son of worthlessness," or foolish person, who would not listen to anyone. Pause this audio here.

Scene two starts when Abigail responds to what Nabal's servant said. Abigail hurries and asks her young male servants to prepare food and drink to load on donkeys to take to David. This includes 200 breads, 2 large containers of wine, meat from 5 whole sheep, 5 bags of dry, roasted grain, 100 handfuls of pressed raisins, and 200 handfuls of pressed dried figs. We do not know for sure if the servants had already cooked the meat or if the servants had just cut the meat so that people could cook it right away. After the servants finish putting all the food and drink on the backs of the donkeys, Abigail sends the servants with these supplies to meet David. Abigail then rides on a donkey behind the servants to also meet David. The storyteller says that Abigail did not tell what Abigail was doing to her husband, Nabal.

Stop here and look at a picture of a donkey carrying a lot of supplies as a group. Pause this audio here.

At the end of scene two, the storyteller uses words to show that Abigail suddenly met David. This happened suddenly because Abigail rode her donkey down into the valley on the mountain path from Nabal's land. This mountain path was hidden and hard to see from the other side of the valley. At the same time, David and David's army walked down the mountain path on the other side of a valley, going towards Nabal's land. In other words, Abigail and Abigail's servants arrived in the valley at the same time that David and David's men arrived in the valley from the other direction.

In scene three, the storyteller tells us that David had just been talking while on the way to attack Nabal. In other words, what David said happened before David met Abigail. David makes an oath, or a serious promise to God, to kill every male in Nabal's household before the next morning. David actually says that David will kill everyone who belongs to Nabal who pees against a wall. This refers to how males pee differently from women. It means that David plans to kill every male of every age in Nabal's household.

David also says that if David does not complete this oath that God should punish David. Some translations say, "May God punish David." Since David is speaking, some other translations say, "May God punish me."

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:14–22 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has three scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Nabal's servant who talks with Abigail

  • Abigail, Nabal's wife

  • Nabal and Abigail's servants

  • David

  • And David's army

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

In the first scene, one of Nabal's servants tells Abigail about David's kindness to Nabal and Nabal's harshness to David. The servant tells Abigail that Nabal shouted at David's messengers when David asked Nabal for help. Then the servant tells Abigail how David had protected Nabal's servants and animals. Nabal's servant expects that David will react negatively to everyone in Nabal's household because of Nabal's harshness. Nabal's servant knows that Nabal will not change his mind even if someone reasons with Nabal about the dangerous situation. So, Nabal's servant asks Abigail to consider how to respond to fix the situation.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the servant, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • David acted respectfully and peacefully toward Nabal, but Nabal acted harshly toward David. David did not deserve this injustice; or

  • I am afraid David will respond in anger to Nabal's harshness toward David; or

  • David is a strong military leader. David can easily come and kill all of us because of our foolish master, Nabal; or

  • I am afraid that all of us will die; or

  • Nabal does not listen to other people's good advice. We should not even bother talking with Nabal; or

  • Abigail is our last and only hope to fix this bad situation.

In the second scene, Abigail quickly prepares food for David's army. Then Abigail and her servants take all the food and go to meet David and David's army. Abigail chooses not to tell Nabal that Abigail is preparing food to take to David. Then, suddenly, Abigail and all her servants meet David and 400 men from David's army in the mountain valley.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Abigail, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I need to hurry to respond so that David will not harm us after what my foolish husband has done; or

  • Nabal refused to give David even a little bread, wine, and meat. I will take all those things plus more food as well. Nabal is very wealthy, and we have a lot of food ready from the animal shearing feast time. We can give a large amount of food to David; or

  • If I tell Nabal what I am doing, Nabal will stop me. I will not tell Nabal about this, or Nabal might make even more foolish decisions to make the situation worse; or

  • Oh! Here comes David and David's army. I do not know what will happen; or

  • I hope that David will accept the gifts I prepared for David. I hope that David will not kill us because of my foolish husband's harshness.

In the third scene, the storyteller tells us what David said on the way to meet Nabal. David knew that David did not benefit from helping Nabal. David made an oath that God should kill David if David did not kill Nabal and all Nabal's male servants on that day.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • My army did not have much food in the wilderness. We helped Nabal's servants and did not steal from the servants. When we needed help, Nabal responded very rudely; or

  • Nabal has plenty of food, but Nabal refused to help us. I regret ever helping a very greedy man like Nabal; or

  • I wasted my time and energy helping this mean man; or

  • I am very angry! Nothing will stop me from killing Nabal and all of the males in Nabal's household; or

  • I deserve revenge; or

  • God has already chosen me as the next king, and Nabal compared me to a slave. I am important and powerful. I will use my power against Nabal.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:14–22 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Nabal's servant tells Abigail about what happened between Nabal and David. Also, later in the story, Abigail asked her young men, or servants, to prepare food to take to David and David's men. A servant is a man or woman who works for another person, the master. Servants have low status in the community and must obey the master. If needed, look up servant in the Master Glossary for more information, and use the same word for servant as you have used in previous passages.

Nabal's servant tells Abigail how David had sent messengers from David's army from the wilderness to meet Nabal. A wilderness has almost no plants or animals. People do not usually live in the wilderness. Look up wilderness in the Master Glossary for more information, and translate wilderness in the same way as you have in previous passages.

Nabal's servant referred to Nabal as "our lord." This means "our master." A lord is a man who is a master over other people, who has full authority, and whom people have to show respect. When you call someone "lord," you are saying that this person has authority over you. Use the same word for lord here that you have used previously when lord means master. The word lord is in the Master Glossary.

Nabal's servant tells Abigail about how David's men protected Nabal's servants while Nabal's servants took care of the flock. Here, flock means a group of sheep and goats. Use the same word for flock that you used in previous passages.

Abigail asks her servants to prepare 200 breads. In those days, the Israelites usually shared bread with each other at each meal. The Israelites ground up and roasted grain to make flour. Then the Israelites made bread by combining flour with oil to make a dough. Then the Israelites would bake this dough. People baked dough by slowly heating food at a high temperature to make it ready to eat. The Israelites made some kinds of bread with yeast, which made the bread grow bigger while baking. Israelites would make this kind of bread as loaves, or bigger chunks of bread to cut or tear apart for smaller pieces later. The process to make bread dough with yeast took a few days. Use the same word for bread that you used in previous passages.

If necessary, stop here and look at a picture of bread as a group. Pause this audio here.

Abigail also told her servants to prepare two large bags of wine. People called these kinds of containers "wineskins" since people typically made these out of the dried skin of animals.

If necessary, stop here and look at a picture of wineskins as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for wineskins. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Abigail also told her servants to prepare the meat from five sheep. Use the same word for sheep that you used in previous passages.

If necessary, stop here and look at a picture of sheep as a group. Pause this audio here.

Abigail also told her servants to prepare two big containers of dry, roasted grain. People in those days often prepared the very top part of a type of grain, probably wheat or barley, by roasting this in an iron pan or on a rock over a fire. The top part of each piece of grain contains seeds that people could eat. When people roasted the top part of the grain, they could save the food since it stayed good to eat for a long time without having to cook it more. People in those days often used roasted grain as travel food. Armies of men also used roasted grain for food during fighting times. Use the same word or phrase for roasted grain that you used in previous passages.

If necessary, stop here and look at a picture of grain as a group. Pause this audio here.

Abigail also told her servants to prepare 100 handfuls of raisins. People in those days would take grapes, a fruit that makes wine, and dry the grapes in the sun. We call dried grapes "raisins." The Israelites often used this food for travel or for soldiers to eat during battle since it lasts for a while without the need to cook it more. Sometimes the people would soak the raisins in water and mix the raisins with grain to eat.

If necessary, stop here and look at a picture of raisins as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for raisins. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Abigail also told her servants to prepare 200 handfuls of ripe, dried figs. Figs are similar to raisins. The Israelites often used this food for travel or for soldiers to eat during battle since it lasts for a while without the need to cook it more.

If necessary, stop here and look at a picture of figs as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for figs. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Abigail told the servants to put all the food on the backs of donkeys. For more information on donkey, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word for donkeys that you used in previous passages.

If necessary, stop here and look at a picture of donkeys carrying lots of supplies as a group. Pause this audio here.

David says that David did good things for Nabal, but Nabal did evil to David. Use the same word or phrase for evil as you used in previous passages. If needed, look up evil in the Master Glossary for more information, and use the same word for evil as you have used in previous passages.

David says that he hopes God will kill David if David does not kill every man in Nabal's household before morning. David uses the general word for God. Use the same words for God and household as you used in previous passages. If needed, look up God and household in the Master Glossary for more information.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 25:23–38
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 25:23–38 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:23–38 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:23–38 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

This true story happens after the last story when Nabal's wife, Abigail, sent her servants ahead of Abigail to meet David and David's men with a gift of food supplies. At the end of the last story, David had planned to kill Nabal and all the men in Nabal's household. Abigail rode a donkey behind her servants to go meet David. Suddenly, Abigail sees David.

Stop here and look at a picture of someone riding on the back of a donkey as a group. Pause this audio here.

In this story, as soon as Abigail sees David, Abigail quickly gets down from riding on the donkey's back. Abigail drops her body to the ground with her face towards the ground, in front of David. In those days, people bowed face down like this in front of someone to show respect and honor to the other person.

Abigail is still bowing to David when Abigail begins her long and respectful speech to David. Abigail says, "On me alone be the blame." In other words, Abigail says that Abigail will take the guilt or responsibility. Abigail is probably requesting that David place the blame on Abigail for Nabal's bad behavior. Abigail speaks very politely to David as if David is someone who has authority over Abigail. Abigail even calls herself David's servant.

Stop here and act out a situation as a group when one person asks a more powerful person to listen to something important. How does the person listening act? How does the person asking act? Pause this audio here.

Abigail calls David "my lord" again. Abigail asks David to please not pay attention to the worthless Nabal. Abigail calls Nabal worthless because Nabal has acted foolishly. Abigail also says that Nabal's name means a foolish person and that Nabal regularly acts foolishly.

Abigail then says that she did not meet "my lord's" young men directly. Abigail is calling David master again. Abigail is telling David that Abigail did not meet the messengers or young men whom David had sent to meet Nabal.

Abigail continues to very politely call David "my lord," or "master," again. Then Abigail starts to make a very strong promise to Yahweh and to David. Abigail says that Yahweh has prevented David from two things. Yahweh has stopped David from killing innocent people and taking revenge for David's own self. But David has not said that David will not harm Nabal. Abigail is suggesting that Yahweh has caused Abigail to meet David to stop David from killing Nabal and all the men in Nabal's household. Nabal has done something bad to David, but Yahweh is stopping David from doing something bad back to Nabal.

Abigail once again refers to David as "my lord." Abigail says she hopes that anyone who purposefully tries to do bad things to David will "be like Nabal." This means that Abigail hopes that anyone who does bad things to David will, at some point in time, experience bad consequences or punishment. Yahweh has not punished Nabal yet, but Abigail expects that Yahweh will punish Nabal because Nabal acted foolishly or treated David badly.

Abigail then asked David to allow Abigail to give the "blessing," meaning the gift of food supplies, to the young men in David's army.

Abigail asks David to forgive her "rebellion." Another way to say this might be, "Please forgive me if I have done anything wrong." But Abigail had not done anything wrong. Perhaps Abigail is accepting Nabal's guilt for doing something bad to David. However, most likely, Abigail is speaking politely and asks David to forgive Abigail for continuing to speak. In other words, Abigail is humbly asking David's permission for Abigail to continue speaking.

Stop here and tell a story about a time when someone who was not important in the community begged a respected leader to do something. Pause this audio here.

Abigail says that Yahweh will make a house that lasts forever for "my lord." Abigail means that she believes Yahweh will make David's house, or David's descendants, the leaders of Israel for many generations, or for a long time. Abigail thinks that Yahweh will do this because David, whom Abigail again calls "my lord," is fighting Yahweh's battles, and Abigail hopes that David will not do evil things during David's lifetime.

Abigail then talks about her hope that Yahweh will punish anyone who might start to chase David to kill David. Then Abigail talks about Yahweh keeping David in the "bundle" or "pouch" of the living. In those days, people often kept small, valuable items in a pouch or a small bag that someone could carry with them. Abigail hopes Yahweh keeps David alive, just like a person guards a valuable treasure. But, Abigail hopes Yahweh will quickly kill David's enemies just as fast as a person throws a rock very quickly and very far from out of the pouch of a sling.

Stop here and look at a picture of a rock in a sling as a group. Pause this audio here.

If available: Stop here and look at a video of someone throwing a stone from a sling as a group. Pause this audio here.

Abigail tells David that she knows that Yahweh will complete all the good things that Yahweh has planned for "my lord," or David. Abigail also says that Yahweh will definitely make David the future leader of Israel. Abigail tells David that she knows David will not have grief or a guilty conscience because David chose not to needlessly kill innocent people or to take revenge for David's own self. Abigail requests that David remember Abigail, "your female servant," when David officially starts to lead Israel. Abigail is asking David to remember what Abigail had done to stop David from killing innocent people for revenge. Abigail is also asking David to show Abigail kindness when David begins to lead Israel.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group. What makes an honest and good leader in your culture? Why do you think it is important that David did not kill innocent people for revenge? Pause this audio here.

Abigail finishes speaking, and David responds to Abigail. David praises Yahweh, God of Israel. David says that Yahweh sent Abigail on that day to meet David. Then David blesses Abigail and thanks her for her wise actions. David says that Abigail's actions stopped David from killing innocent people that day because David no longer plans to take revenge for himself.

David continues to tell Abigail that Yahweh, God of Israel, stopped David from doing evil to Abigail. This means that Yahweh stopped David from killing all the men in Nabal's house, including Abigail's husband, Nabal. David tells Abigail that, if Abigail had not quickly come to meet David, David would have killed Nabal and all the men in Nabal's household before sunrise the next morning.

David accepts the food gifts that Abigail brought for David's men. Abigail has her servants give all the food to the men in David's army. Then David tells Abigail to go back up the hill to Abigail's house in peace. David means that David will not do anything to hurt Abigail or the people in Abigail's household. David tells Abigail, "I have listened to you and I will do what you asked."

Then Abigail returns to her household to go talk to Nabal. Abigail sees that Nabal is hosting a big feast, like a king might host. Abigail sees that Nabal acts very cheerfully because Nabal has been drinking too much wine at the feast. So, Abigail decides not to tell Nabal about what happened with David until the next morning.

In the morning, Nabal has recovered from being drunk. So, Abigail explains to Nabal about what happened with David. Right away, Nabal becomes so sick that Nabal becomes as still as a rock. Ten days later, Yahweh takes away Nabal's life.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:23–38 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has three scenes.

In the first scene: Abigail pleads with David on behalf of the people in Abigail's household. Abigail gives a gift of food to David and the men in David's army.

In the second scene: David answers Abigail and agrees not to harm Abigail's household.

In the second scene: Abigail returns to find Nabal drunk at Nabal's own feast. Abigail waits until the morning to tell Nabal what happened with David. When Nabal hears about this, Nabal gets so sick that Nabal is as still as a rock. Then, ten days later, Yahweh takes Nabal's life.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Abigail, along with Abigail's servants who helped Abigail deliver the food gifts to David

  • David

  • David's men

  • Yahweh, God of Israel

  • Nabal

  • And the people who celebrated with Nabal during Nabal's feast

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In the first scene, Abigail gave a very long and respectful speech to David. Abigail used very humble and polite words throughout her speech. When Abigail saw David, Abigail quickly got down from riding on the back of her donkey. Abigail purposefully and humbly fell down with her face to the ground in front of David to show respect to David. Abigail "fell at David's feet." Abigail did not trip and fall. This means that Abigail bowed close, in front of David. Abigail put her head close to David's feet as David looked at Abigail. The storyteller tells us twice, with different words, that Abigail bowed before David. We do not know if Abigail bowed once or twice. Abigail may have bowed down to David a first time and then moved closer to David to bow again. Or, possibly, Abigail may have bowed only once, but the storyteller just said the information twice. We do know that Abigail is still bowing to David the whole time Abigail gives her speech to David. Abigail calls David, "my lord," meaning "master." Abigail is using a title for David that shows Abigail knows David has authority over Abigail and that Abigail is showing respect for David. Abigail even calls herself David's "servant." Then Abigail asks David to please listen to what Abigail has to say. Abigail says that she would take the responsibility or the blame for the evil that Nabal had done to David. Abigail will call David "my lord" and will call herself David's "female servant" many times in this story. Abigail does not say "I" but, instead, calls herself David's female servant.

Abigail politely asks David for permission to speak to David. Abigail asks David if she can speak to David's "ears;" in other words, Abigail asks David to listen to what Abigail will say. This does not mean Abigail is talking directly to David's ear, like a whisper. It just means that Abigail wants David to listen.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Think about how an unimportant person begs an important person to do something in your culture. Talk about how you will translate Abigail's speech to David as she uses titles like "my lord" to address David and "your servant" to talk about herself. Pause this audio here.

Abigail asks David not to pay attention to, or to ignore, this "worthless man," Nabal. Here, the phrase "worthless man" shows that Abigail knows that Nabal does not tend to make decisions that honor Yahweh. Abigail says that the name Nabal means fool. So, Nabal's name fits Nabal well because Nabal certainly acts like a fool. People who act foolishly do not follow God. When people continue to act foolishly, bad consequences come, and Yahweh punishes those people.

Abigail calls David "my lord" again. Abigail does this when she tells David that Abigail did not see the messengers David had sent to Nabal.

Abigail again calls David "my lord" and changes her speech to show that Abigail is going to say her main point. Abigail says that Yahweh has stopped David from killing innocent people by taking revenge. Abigail then says that she hopes that any of David's enemies who want to do something evil to "my lord," meaning David, will have a fate like Nabal's fate. Abigail knows that Yahweh will somehow punish Nabal for Nabal's foolish actions. Abigail stresses this point by saying an oath, or a strong promise, to Yahweh and to David. Abigail does this by saying, "As Yahweh lives and your soul lives." Abigail is saying, "I will absolutely keep my promise. If I do not, Yahweh may punish me."

Stop here and discuss as a group some ways that someone can make a strong promise in your language. Pause this audio here.

Abigail continues to talk to David. Abigail says that Yahweh has stopped David from killing innocent people by taking revenge. Abigail then says that she hopes that any of David's enemies who want to do something evil to "my lord," meaning David, will have a fate like Nabal's fate. Abigail knows that Yahweh will somehow punish Nabal for Nabal's foolish actions.

Abigail continues to speak politely to David. Abigail asks David to forgive her for continuing to speak. Probably this means that Abigail is asking David for permission to keep speaking to David. Abigail says that she knows Yahweh will make "my lord," meaning David, to have a household or family that continues for many generations as leaders. Abigail talks about David having a sure or enduring house. This means that Yahweh will allow David's descendants to rule Israel. Here, "house" or "household" refers to David and David's future descendants.

Stop here as a group and talk about people you know who have ruled as leaders for many generations. How is this the same or different from David and David's descendants leading for generations? Pause this audio here.

Abigail says the reason why she believes Yahweh will make David and David's descendants leaders. Abigail says this is because "my lord," meaning David, is fighting the battles of Yahweh. In other words, Abigail is saying that David has fought battles as an Israelite against people in other nations who oppose Yahweh. Also, Abigail says that David will not do evil things during David's lifetime.

Abigail continues talking and shares her hope that, if anyone tries to kill David, Yahweh, David's God, will keep David alive. Abigail says this by saying that she hopes Yahweh will tie up the life of "my lord," meaning David, with the "pouch of the living." In those days, people often kept a valuable item in a special pouch in order to keep the item safe. So, Abigail is saying that she hopes Yahweh will keep David alive and safe because Yahweh protects David like a valuable treasure.

Stop here and look at a drawing of a pouch for keeping valuable items. Abigail means that Yahweh will watch over or protect David. Discuss as a group how you will describe in your language that Yahweh will watch over or protect David. Pause this audio here.

Abigail also says that she hopes that Yahweh will throw out the lives of David's enemies like a person throws stones far and fast from the middle of a sling. A sling is a simple weapon that people made of a piece of cloth with two long cord strings on each side of the cloth. In those days, people used a sling as a weapon to throw stones at a person or animal who threatened them when that person or animal was too far to fight by hand.

Stop here and look at a picture of a rock in a sling. Then discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for sling. If you have already translated this word or phrase in another book of the Bible, use the same word or phrase that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Abigail says that Yahweh will do all the good things that Yahweh had said Yahweh would do for "my lord," meaning David. Abigail says this includes Yahweh appointing David as the official ruler of Israel. Abigail says that David will not be sad or have a bad conscience as Israel's leader because David will choose not to kill out of revenge.

Finally, Abigail finishes her speech to David. Abigail asks David to remember Abigail when Yahweh does these good things to "my lord," meaning David. Abigail is asking David to show "your female servant," meaning Abigail, kindness when David becomes the ruler of Israel.

In the second scene, David responds to Abigail. First of all, David praises Yahweh, God of Israel, for sending Abigail at that time to meet David. Then David says a blessing about how Abigail's wisdom stopped David from killing just for revenge. In other words, David is showing thanks to Yahweh and to Abigail.

David starts his next sentence saying, "But, as Yahweh God of Israel lives." David is saying that what David is about to say is just as true as the fact that Yahweh lives. David continues to say that Yahweh stopped David from causing harm to Abigail. David explains to Abigail that, if Abigail had not quickly come to meet David, David and David's men would have followed David's plan to kill every one of the males in Nabal's household before the next morning.

Then David accepts the food gifts from Abigail's hand, meaning that David accepts these things from Abigail. David tells Abigail to "Go back up to your house in peace. I have listened to you and I will do what you ask." David is telling Abigail that David and David's men would not harm anyone in Abigail's household.

So, Abigail goes to find Nabal. The storyteller now uses language to show that something important is about to happen as Abigail goes to find Nabal. Nabal is hosting a huge feast, like what a king would host, and Nabal has a "happy heart" from drinking too much wine.

Stop here and act out a scene when someone is very happy and very drunk. Then take turns describing this person in your language. Pause this audio here.

Abigail decides to wait until the morning to talk with Nabal about what happened with David, since Nabal would recover from being drunk by morning.

In the morning, Nabal has recovered from being drunk, so Abigail, Nabal's wife, tells Nabal what happened with David. Right away, Nabal's "heart died," and Nabal's body became as hard as a rock. This does not mean that Nabal dies. It means that Nabal somehow instantly became so ill that Nabal could not even move.

Then, about ten days later, Yahweh "strikes" Nabal dead. This means that Yahweh quickly takes away Nabal's life at that time, and Nabal dies. Often, the word "strike" means to hit someone. Here, the word struck does not mean that Yahweh hit Nabal. In this story, struck means that Yahweh caused Nabal to die. Yahweh did this as a consequence for Nabal's foolish actions.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for this meaning of strike. If you have already translated this word or phrase with the same meaning in another book of the Bible, use the same word or phrase that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:23–38 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has three scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Abigail, along with Abigail's servants who helped Abigail deliver the food gifts to David

  • David

  • David's men

  • Yahweh, God of Israel

  • Nabal

  • And the people who celebrated with Nabal during Nabal's feast

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

As soon as Nabal's wife, Abigail, sees David, Abigail hurries to get down off her donkey so that Abigail can bow face down on the ground in front of David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Abigail, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am terrified to approach David's army of 400 men with swords when I have no way to defend myself. I might even die; or

  • I know my husband Nabal acted foolishly and rudely to David. I am sure that David is planning to do something bad back to Nabal. But I think David might listen to me and change his mind; or

  • I see David coming with David's army of men. I am afraid that the people I love will die because of what my husband did; or

  • I will gladly accept my husband's guilt so that David will not take revenge on our household; or

  • I hope that David will accept the gifts I have prepared for David and David's men. Perhaps David will stop being so angry.

Abigail stays down in a bowing position and pleads with David to listen to what Abigail has to say. Abigail asks David not to pay attention to Nabal because Nabal acted foolishly. Abigail also tells David that Abigail did not see the messengers that David had sent to Nabal.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so angry with Nabal for acting so rudely to me, and I want to kill Nabal and all the men in Nabal's household. I do not plan to kill the women. I will listen to what this woman has to say; or

  • This woman is showing a lot of bravery, respect, and humility. Also, the woman told me that she did not participate in acting rudely to my messengers. I want to hear what she will say.

Abigail tells David that Yahweh is stopping David from killing innocent people through revenge.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Wow, I was not thinking about what Yahweh wanted me to do! I should pay attention to think about what Yahweh wants and not just what I want; or

  • This woman is right. I am thinking only about revenge. Revenge is an evil reason to kill people; or

  • When I wanted to kill Nabal for revenge, I did not think about the future consequences I would have when I became the ruler of Israel. Leaders should not act in revenge.

Abigail shares her hope that anyone who tries to do evil to David will have a bad consequence, as Abigail knows Nabal will soon have. Then Abigail asks David to accept the food gifts that Abigail brought for David's army of men.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Abigail, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I know that Yahweh punishes foolish people who do evil things. I need to remind David that Yahweh will make sure Nabal will have a bad consequence. David should not take revenge for himself; or

  • I want to show honor to David as a future leader by giving these gifts; or

  • I hope that David will see that I am paying David back something good in return for the good that David had done before by protecting our shepherds and flocks.

Abigail says that Yahweh will definitely make David's household rulers for a long time. Abigail says that Yahweh will do this because David is fighting Yahweh's battles and that David will not do evil things during David's life. Abigail also talks about how Yahweh, David's God, will protect David's life and kill David's enemies. Abigail says that, when Yahweh makes David the ruler of Israel, David will not be sad or have a bad conscience because David will not kill innocent people in an act of revenge. Abigail also asks David to remember to show her kindness when Yahweh makes David the king of Israel.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Yahweh, through Samuel, already chose me as the future king of Israel. I have fought many battles for Yahweh and for Israel. But I have faced so many difficulties, including King Saul trying to kill me many times. Also, the men in my army have had little food to eat in the wilderness. I do not see much evidence that I will start to be king soon. I am so tired, and I struggle to have hope. This woman has reminded me that Yahweh will keep Yahweh's promise; or

  • I was planning to do something evil to Nabal and the men in Nabal's household. But, if I want to follow Yahweh, I have to fight Yahweh's battles, not my own battles for revenge; or

  • I have to trust that Yahweh will punish the people who do evil things to me. I should not try to do Yahweh's job. I am not Yahweh; or

  • This woman is right, as the future leader, I cannot do something evil like killing all the men in Nabal's household for revenge. I would always have a guilty conscience if I did that evil thing; or

  • This woman is so wise. Yahweh sent this woman to stop me from doing something very evil.

David answers Abigail by praising Yahweh for sending Abigail to meet David. David thanks Abigail for her wise actions that kept David from David's plan of murder and revenge. David tells Abigail that David had planned to kill all the men in Nabal's household before the morning. Instead, David chooses not to kill these men. David accepts the food gift from Abigail. David tells Abigail to return home in peace. David had listened to Abigail and so no longer plans to kill anyone in Nabal's household.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Abigail, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so grateful to Yahweh! I had guessed that David would do something evil back to Nabal. Now I know for sure that David planned to do that. Thank you, Yahweh, that David has changed his mind! or

  • I need to tell Nabal that Yahweh spared Nabal's life.

Abigail goes to find Nabal. Abigail sees Nabal very happily drunk at Nabal's big feast. So, Abigail decides to wait to tell Nabal about what happened with David in the morning. Nabal recovers from drunkenness in the morning. So, Abigail tells Nabal what happened. Nabal instantly gets so sick that Nabal's body is as still as a rock. Around ten days later, Yahweh takes Nabal's life, so that Nabal dies.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Nabal, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am so happy to have this big feast. Look at all I have. I am a very wealthy businessman. I have a great life, and I can do whatever I want to do; or

  • I am so angry that my wife gave so much of my food to David! or

  • I am scared because David almost came to kill us; or

  • I am very sick. I know I will die.

Ask the person playing Abigail, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Nabal has eaten too much and drunk too much wine. David and David's men had little access to food, and they were hungry. Nabal had plenty of food to give to David, but Nabal selfishly kept the food. David is the true, future king, but Nabal acts like Nabal is a king; or

  • Nabal already does not listen well. I have to wait until Nabal recovers from drunkenness to talk with Nabal; or

  • Yahweh is punishing Nabal for Nabal's foolishness; or

  • Now Nabal has the consequences for acting foolishly. Yahweh has taken Nabal's life.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:23–38 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Abigail had been riding her donkey. When Abigail sees David, she gets off the back of the donkey. Translate donkey the same as you have in previous passages. For more information on donkey, refer to the Master Glossary.

If necessary, stop here and look at a picture of a donkey as a group. Pause this audio here.

Abigail bows low with her face to the ground in front of David. Abigail bowing down like this shows respect to David and humility from Abigail. Refer to the Master Glossary for more information about bow, and use the same word for bow that you have used in previous passages.

Abigail calls David "my lord." This means "my master." A lord is a man who is a master over other people, who has full authority, and who deserves for people to give him respect. When you call someone "lord," you are saying that this person has authority over you. When Abigail uses the word lord, Abigail is showing humility for herself and is giving respect to David. Some translations may also say "sir" instead of "you" to show the same meaning as "lord." Use the same word for lord here that you have used previously when lord means master. The word lord is in the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for lord that you used in previous passages.

Abigail calls herself David's maidservant or female servant. Usually, a servant is a man or woman who works for another person, the master. Servants have low status in the community and must obey the master. Abigail was not David's servant. Abigail had married a rich farmer, so Abigail had high status in the community. Abigail humbly calls herself David's servant to show respect to David. Look up servant in the Master Glossary for more information, and use the same word for servant as you have used in previous passages.

Abigail says that Nabal's name means foolishness or folly. Then Abigail hopes that David's enemies will experience folly, like Nabal. A fool, or a person who acts foolishly, eventually experiences folly, meaning bad results or consequences because of bad behavior. A foolish person usually acts selfishly by treating other people badly and not following God. Abigail hoped that anyone who tried to hurt David would experience bad consequences for their folly.

Abigail and David both talk about Yahweh. Yahweh is God's proper name, the Israelites' personal name for God. Use the same general word for God and the same name for Yahweh as you used in previous passages. For more information on God and Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary.

Abigail talks about the people who may plan to act evilly toward David. Abigail also says that David will not do evil if David fights for Yahweh instead of fighting for David. Evil means that people decide for themselves what they can and cannot do instead of obeying God. Evil is always bad, the opposite of good. People who act evilly think that they know better than God. Use the same word for evil as you used in previous passages. For more information on evil, refer to the Master Glossary.

Abigail says that Yahweh kept David from unnecessary killing, or bloodshed, and from avenging, or taking revenge for, himself. David also talks about this. From previous stories, we know that Yahweh does not want the Israelites to allow bloodshed because Yahweh is holy. Yahweh is set apart from all evil, and Yahweh lives with the Israelites. Someone who takes revenge for themselves imposes a punishment on another person or group of people as a type of payment for the suffering or loss that this other person caused the first person. Taking revenge for yourself means that you do not trust God to provide justice for you. People who take revenge have not shown grace or forgiveness to others. With forgiveness, the people can restore the relationship between the two groups and remove guilt. With revenge, the person who takes revenge for himself causes more harm and wrongdoing.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for revenge and bloodshed. If you have already translated this phrase in another book of the Bible, use the same phrase that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Abigail gives a blessing or gift to David. Here, Abigail means the food and wine that Abigail had prepared for the men in David's army. Note that Abigail did not try to bribe David with this gift. Abigail was honoring David through the gift.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for blessing or gift. Here, blessing is another way to talk about a gift, because Abigail means for the gift to bless, or do good to, David and David's men. You may either use the same word for blessing that you have used in previous passages, or you may use a word for gift. If needed, refer to the Master Glossary for more information about bless. Pause this audio here.

Abigail asks David to forgive her rebellion or transgression. Rebellion is when someone does something against someone in authority. Similarly, transgression is when someone does something that goes against the rules of someone in authority. Here, Abigail is showing respect by talking with David.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for rebellion. Pause this audio here.

Later in this story, David tells Abigail to go in peace back to her house. Here, David means that David will not attack the people in Abigail's household. Look up household and peace in the Master Glossary for more information, and use the same words for peace and household that you have used in previous passages.

Abigail says that Yahweh will appoint David as ruler over Israel in the future. David talks about Yahweh God of Israel. Here, to appoint means God will assign a job or role to David and give David authority through that role as the leader of Israel. Use the same word or phrase for appoint as you used in previous passages. Use the same word for Israel that you have used in previous passages, and remember that Israel is in the Master Glossary.

Abigail prays that David will not have a troubled heart because he commits bloodshed and takes revenge on Nabal. Later in the story, the storyteller describes Nabal as having a happy heart because Nabal felt happy when Nabal drank too much wine. Then, after Abigail tells Nabal what happened with David, Nabal's heart died. In these examples, the heart refers to the person's thoughts, feelings, and will. Use the same word for heart as you used in previous passages. For more information on heart, refer to the Master Glossary.

David blesses Yahweh, God of Israel. Here, David is thanking and giving praise to Yahweh for stopping David from doing an evil thing. David also blesses Abigail for her wise discernment. Here, David is thanking Abigail and praying that God will do good things for Abigail. Use the same word for bless that you have used in previous passages. Refer to the Master Glossary for a full definition of bless.

Nabal hosted a banquet or a feast to celebrate with other people during the animal shearing time for Nabal's business. When someone hosts a feast, the host usually provides a very large meal as a way to celebrate something. Nabal also drinks so much wine at the feast that the word the storyteller used for feast actually refers to drinking lots and lots of wine.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for feast. If you have already translated this word or phrase in another book of the Bible, use the same word or phrase that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
