title: 1 Samuel 25:39–44
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 25:39–44 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:39–44 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:39–44 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

This true story happens after Yahweh caused Nabal, Abigail's husband, to die. So Abigail became a widow, or a woman whose husband had died. We know from a previous story that Nabal had a business in the town of Carmel. So, in this story, Abigail was still in Carmel after her husband Nabal died. David and David's men probably had returned to their army camp somewhere in the wilderness nearby.

Stop here and look at the map that includes Carmel as a group. Pause this audio here.

In this story, someone had told David that Nabal had died. So, David praises Yahweh. David says that Yahweh has avenged David for Nabal's insult against David. To avenge is to punish someone for something that person did wrong to someone else. Then David says that Yahweh had stopped David from doing something evil. David says that Yahweh justly punished Nabal for the evil Nabal had done. David understood that it was Yahweh's job to avenge people. Therefore, Yahweh had acted mercifully to David by keeping David from doing something wrong by trying to avenge himself.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Tell a story about a time when someone did something bad and then received a punishment for the wrong thing they did. Pause this audio here.

Then David sends messengers to Carmel to talk to Abigail. The messengers tell Abigail that David sent the messengers to ask Abigail to marry David. Abigail quickly bows her face down to the ground in front of David's messengers. Abigail is showing respect for David by showing respect to David's messengers. Abigail speaks to David's messengers as though Abigail were talking to David. Abigail says that Abigail will serve David by washing David's messengers' feet. In those days, people typically wore shoes on their feet that had openings where dirt and dust could easily enter. The person wearing the shoes had very dusty and dirty feet. In those days, a person hosting guests would provide a bowl-like container of water for the guests to wash their own feet. The host would have also provided some kind of cloth to dry the guests' feet. Abigail could have simply offered water for David's messengers to wash their own feet. Or, Abigail could have asked one of Abigail's servants to wash David's messengers' feet. Abigail chose to wash the very dirty feet of these men by herself to show that Abigail wanted to serve David. So, Abigail is showing her willingness to marry David through humbly serving David's messengers.

Stop here as a group and act out someone important doing a job that normally someone with low status would do. Discuss as a group: What would you think if you saw a leader from your community doing this? How is this the same or different from what Abigail did? Pause this audio here.

Then Abigail quickly gets on the back of Abigail's donkey to ride to the place where Abigail will marry David. Five young women, Abigail's female servants, walk behind Abigail to go with Abigail to meet David. In those days, other women often went with a bride to the groom's house, where the bride and groom would get married. Abigail and these young women follow David's messengers back to David. Then Abigail marries David.

Stop here and look at a picture of someone riding on the back of a donkey as a group. Pause this audio here.

The storyteller tells us that David also married Ahinoam from the town of Jezreel in Judah's territory. Though we do not know the exact location of Jezreel, we do know that it was in the hill country near the towns of Maon and Carmel.

Stop here and look at the map that includes Jezreel as a group. Pause this audio here.

We do not know for sure when David married Ahinoam, but possibly, David married Ahinoam before marrying Abigail. So, both Ahinoam and Abigail became David's wives. Although David now had more than one wife, David probably treated Ahinoam and Abigail equally, or as having the same rights. In those days, people accepted when men married more than one woman. Leaders, especially, might marry more than one wife to gain support from the people who lived in the areas where each wife lived. Both Ahinoam and Abigail came from the area of Judah, so David likely gained support from people in Judah by marrying these women. Also, sometimes a man would marry a widow to take care of the widow. In that culture, women did not have the same rights as a man. A new husband would protect and provide for the widow.

Stop here and discuss as a group: In your culture, do men have more than one wife? How would you describe wives who have the same rights as other women who are married to the same man? In some cultures, men cannot have more than one wife at a time. If your culture is like this, discuss how you will translate that David had more than one wife. Pause this audio here.

The storyteller also tells us what happened with David's first wife, Michal. We know from previous stories that David had married King Saul's daughter, Michal. We also know that Saul hated David. Saul felt jealous of David because Saul knew Yahweh wanted David to become king.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How would a man in your culture feel if someone forced the man's current wife to marry someone else against the first man's will? Pause this audio here.

Michal's second husband, Palti or "Paltiel," whose father was Laish, comes from the town of Gallim. We do not know Gallim's exact location, but Gallim was most likely less than one hour north of Jerusalem and less than one hour south of Gibeah, where Saul lives.

Stop here and look at the map that includes Gallim as a group.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:39–44 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has three scenes.

In the first scene: David praises Yahweh for avenging David and punishing Nabal for the evil Nabal did.

In the second scene: David sends messengers to Abigail to ask Abigail to marry David.

In the third scene: David marries Abigail. We also learn information about two of David's other wives, Ahinoam and Michal.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • Yahweh

  • Nabal

  • David's messengers

  • Abigail

  • The five young women who went with Abigail as Abigail went to marry David

  • David's wife, Ahinoam

  • Saul, who was David's father-in-law and Michal's father

  • David's wife, Michal

  • And Palti or Paltiel, the man who married Michal

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

In the first scene, someone had told David that Nabal had died. So, David blesses Yahweh. This means that David thanks or praises Yahweh. David says that Yahweh had "pleaded David's case" or spoken in David's favor. The words David uses are like Yahweh acted as a judge in a courtroom who both protects an innocent person's rights and punishes the guilty person. David says that David received disgrace or shame from Nabal's hand, meaning Nabal acted towards David in a very rude, shameful way. David then says that Yahweh had stopped Yahweh's servant, meaning David, before David did an evil thing to Nabal. In those days, sometimes people talked about themselves as Yahweh's servant instead of saying, "I am the servant." David then talks about the fact that Yahweh punished Nabal. David says that Yahweh made the evil that Nabal did to David return on Nabal's own "head." This is special language that just means that Nabal now has the consequences of that evil instead of David. In other words, Yahweh had punished Nabal for the wrong that Nabal had done to David.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Who in your culture acts like a judge to decide when people are innocent or guilty? Tell a true story about a judge who punished a guilty person in a right, or just, way. What happened? How did the person whom the guilty person harmed respond to the guilty person's punishment? Pay attention to the words you use to describe this. Pause this audio here.

In the second scene, David sends messengers to ask Abigail to marry David. David's messengers, or servants, arrive at Carmel, where Abigail is staying. David's messengers tell Abigail, "David sent us to you to take you to him as his wife." This does not mean that David is forcing or kidnapping Abigail to marry David. This is David's way of asking Abigail to marry David.

Stop here and discuss as a group: In your culture, how do people decide marriages? What words or phrases do people use when they want to ask someone else to agree to a marriage? Act out this scene using each of those different words and phrases. Which words or phrases do you think that David or David's messengers may have said? Pause this audio here.

Abigail quickly bows down with her face to the ground in the same way Abigail did in the previous story. Then Abigail uses language that shows she is about to say something important. Abigail talks to the messengers as though Abigail were talking directly to David. Abigail calls herself David's female servant. Abigail says that Abigail will act as a servant by washing the feet of "my lord's servants," meaning David's messengers. When Abigail calls David "my lord," Abigail is calling David her master. Abigail does all these things to show that Abigail is very willing to marry David.

In the third scene, Abigail quickly goes to meet David. Abigail rides on the back of a donkey to go to David. Five young women, likely Abigail's closest servants, walk along with Abigail while Abigail rides on the donkey. Abigail and the five young women follow David's messengers back to the place where David is staying. Then Abigail marries David.

The storyteller tells us that David also married a woman named Ahinoam from the town of Jezreel. So, David had two new wives, Ahinoam and Abigail.

The storyteller uses language that shows that what the storyteller is about to say happened before David married Abigail. Saul had made Saul's daughter, Michal, marry another man named Palti. The storyteller does not say that David is still married to Michal, but we know this is true. The storyteller tells us the name of Palti's father, Laish. Palti comes from the town of Gallim.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:39–44 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has three scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • Yahweh

  • Nabal

  • David's messengers

  • Abigail

  • The five young women who went with Abigail as Abigail went to marry David

  • David's wife, Ahinoam

  • Saul, who was David's father-in-law and Michal's father

  • David's wife, Michal

  • And Palti or Paltiel, the man who married Michal

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

In the first scene, David learns from someone that Nabal died. David praises Yahweh for avenging David, stopping David from doing something evil and for punishing Nabal.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Wow, Yahweh, thank you for doing good things for me! or

  • I must praise Yahweh! Yahweh both kept me from doing something evil by taking revenge on Nabal and punished Nabal for the evil Nabal did; or

  • Yes, Nabal deserved to die! or

  • Yahweh not only saved me from the guilt of doing evil for my own purposes but also did good things for me because I obeyed Yahweh.

Then, in the second scene, David sends messengers to Carmel to ask Abigail to marry David. The messengers say David's message to Abigail. Abigail responds by bowing and washing the messengers' feet.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Abigail, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Wow! Yahweh is taking care of me by providing a new husband; or

  • I cannot wait to marry David. My husband Nabal was a worthless fool, but David has shown wisdom by obeying Yahweh; or

  • Before Nabal died, I asked David to show kindness to me when David becomes the ruler of Israel. David is already showing kindness to me. I am so grateful! or

  • I will do anything for David!

Ask the person or group playing David's messengers, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Abigail has shown a lot of humility. Abigail is a wealthy woman, but Abigail has even chosen to wash our dirty feet like a servant. This beautiful and wise woman will make a great wife for David.

In the third scene, Abigail marries David. Abigail rides a donkey, and five young women, likely Abigail's female servants, walk behind Abigail to go with David's messengers to meet David. Abigail marries David. The storyteller tells us that David also married Ahinoam from Jezreel, another part of the territory of Judah.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I have a wise wife, Abigail; or

  • Perhaps the family and friends of Ahinoam and Abigail here in Judah will also support me.

The storyteller tells us something that happened with David's wife, Michal, sometime before David married Abigail and Ahinoam. Saul, Michal's father, made Michal marry another man while Michal was still married to David. Michal's new husband's name is Palti or Paltiel. Palti, Laish's son, comes from the town of Gallim.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I hate David and am afraid that David will take my kingdom from me. As my son-in-law, David might try to say that David has the right to take over my kingdom. So, if I make Michal marry someone else, David will not have any claim to try to become king; or

  • This will weaken David's power.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am very angry and hurt that Saul would treat me like this! or

  • I had the opportunity in the past to kill Saul and take the kingdom, but I did not do it because I obeyed Yahweh; or

  • I miss my wife, Michal, and I do not want Michal to marry someone else; or

  • I want my wife, Michal, back. Michal and I are still married. Saul cannot legally do this.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Michal, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I have to obey my father, King Saul; or

  • I am sad that I am still married to David, but my king and father is making me marry another man; or

  • Women here do not marry more than one man at a time. This is a very strange thing for me to do. I feel like my father forced me into this second marriage; or

  • What will happen between me and David now? or

  • What will people think about me for doing this strange thing?

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 25:39–44 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

David learns that Nabal died. David blesses Yahweh, the God of Israel. Yahweh is the personal name for God. David is thanking or giving praise to Yahweh for justly punishing Nabal and for stopping David from doing an evil thing. Use the same word for Yahweh and bless that you have used in previous passages. Refer to the Master Glossary for a full definition of Yahweh and bless. Evil means that people decide for themselves what they can and cannot do instead of obeying God. Evil is always bad, the opposite of good. People who act in an evil way think that they know better than God. Nabal had done something evil to David. A person who does evil willingly does bad things to hurt other people. Use the same word for evil as you used in previous passages. For more information on evil, refer to the Master Glossary.

David's messengers tell Abigail that David wants to marry Abigail. Abigail responds and calls herself David's maidservant or female servant. A servant is someone who works for another person. Here, Abigail is humbly calling herself David's female servant to show respect to David. Abigail offers to wash the feet of David's servants. The word "servants" here is different than the word Abigail uses, which means "female servant." Here, servants refer to David's messengers, men who worked for David whom David trusted to deliver David's message. In fact, at the end of this passage, the storyteller just calls these men David's messengers. Look up servant in the Master Glossary for more information, and if you use the word "servant," use the same word for servant as you have used in previous passages.

Abigail also calls David, "my lord." This means "my master." A lord is a man who is a master over other people, who has full authority, and who deserves for people to give that man respect. When you call someone "lord," you are saying that this person has authority over you. When Abigail uses the word lord, Abigail is showing respect to David. Use the same word for lord here that you have used previously when lord means master. The word lord is in the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for lord that you used in previous passages.

Abigail quickly goes with David's messengers so that Abigail can marry David. Abigail rides on the back of a donkey to go to David. Translate donkey the same as you have in previous passages. For more information on donkey, refer to the Master Glossary.

If necessary, stop here and look at a picture of a donkey as a group.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 26:1–12
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 26:1–12 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 26:1–12 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 26:1–12 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous passage, Nabal wronged David and David's men. David went with his men to kill Nabal. But Abigail, Nabal's wife, met David on the road and begged David not to kill Nabal. David agreed not to kill Nabal. But Nabal later died. David married Abigail. David also married Ahinoam of Jezreel. Saul gave Saul's daughter, Michal, to another man to be that man's wife, even though Michal was married to David.

In this passage, Saul decides to chase David again. You will remember that David and David's band of followers have been hiding from Saul because Saul was trying to kill David. When David spared Saul's life in an earlier story, Saul showed that Saul was sad about chasing David. Some time has passed, and now Saul again chases David to try to kill David.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Share about a time when someone wronged you and apologized, but then did the same hurtful thing later. How did you feel? Pause this audio here.

The Ziphites go to Saul's hometown of Gibeah to tell Saul where David is hiding. You will remember that the Ziphites had previously come to Saul and told Saul about David's hiding place. The Ziphites are Israelites from the tribe of Judah from the nearby area of Ziph. Probably only some of the Ziphites went to Gibeah to share this information with Saul. The Ziphites told Saul that David was hiding on the hill of Hakilah, which overlooks Jeshimon. Jeshimon means wasteland. Many translations translate the hill of Hakilah as "east of Jeshimon," but it could also mean "facing Jeshimon." Others translate the hill of Hakilah more vaguely as "near Jeshimon."

Stop here as a group and look at a map of Gibeah in relation to Ziph, the hill of Hakilah, and Jeshimon. Pause this audio here.

After hearing what the Ziphites say, Saul takes 3,000 special soldiers to pursue David in the wilderness. Saul chooses these men because they are elite or the most fit. Saul leaves the comforts of his home to go into the wilderness after David. Saul feels that David's presence threatens Saul, so Saul is willing to go into such a harsh location to chase David, and to take 3,000 elite men to fight just a few hundred of David's men. Saul and the 3,000 soldiers camp at the hill of Hakilah, where the Ziphites told Saul that David would be. David is in the wilderness with the group of soldiers who are loyal to David.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a wilderness. Pause this audio here.

David discovers or sees that Saul is chasing David, and David sends scouts or spies to find Saul's camp. David goes to Saul's camp. David is probably hiding with some of David's men in a place where they can see Saul's camp. David sees that Saul and Abner, son of Ner, the commander of Saul's army, are sleeping. Saul is lying in the middle of the camp with Saul's men around Saul. The men are also sleeping. David asks for one volunteer to go with David into Saul's camp, either Ahimelek or Abishai. Ahimelek is silent, but Abishai volunteers to go with David.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are some dangerous jobs or tasks that people in your culture might have to do? How do you choose people to do these dangerous tasks? Pause this audio here.

This is the only place that Scripture mentions Ahimelek the Hittite. You will remember that the Hittites were one of the Canaanite groups that Yahweh commanded Israel to destroy. Ahimelek is probably a descendant of those Hittites that the Israelites did not destroy.

Abishai is the brother of Joab and the son of Zeruiah. Zeruiah is Abishai's mother. In that time, people in that culture usually identified someone by who the person's father was. But here, the storyteller identifies Abishai by who Abishai's mother was.

David and Abishai sneak past the encampment of soldiers at night to where Saul sleeps, along with Saul's commander, Abner. Saul's spear is stuck in the ground by Saul's head. Saul's spear would have been a royal spear that identified Saul as the king.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a royal spearhead in David's time. Pause this audio here.

An encampment is a place where an army would stop to rest and set up their sleeping places in a circle for protection.

Abishai, who likely whispers, tells David, "Today God has delivered your enemy into your hands." Abishai is encouraging David that God has given David the opportunity to kill David's enemy, even this very night. Abishai wants to use a spear, probably Saul's spear, to kill Saul. Abishai tells David that Abishai will not have to strike Saul twice with Saul's spear, meaning that Abishai's first thrust of the spear would be enough to kill Saul.

David will not let Abishai kill Saul. David asks Abishai who could be innocent if they killed Yahweh's anointed king. David did not mean for Abishai to answer this question. Rather, this question emphasizes that David believes he would be guilty before Yahweh if David or Abishai killed Saul. You will remember from an earlier story that Yahweh directed the prophet Samuel to anoint Saul as king of Israel by pouring oil on Saul's head. The Israelites called their kings "Yahweh's anointed" to show that the Israelites recognized that it is Yahweh himself who chooses kings.

Stop here and discuss these questions as a group: What are some rituals in your culture that you have to appoint someone as a leader? In what ways do people show respect to their leaders in your culture? Pause this audio here.

David insists that Yahweh will cause Saul to die in some other way than David killing Saul. Then David uses the oath "as Yahweh lives" to make David's statement even more certain. David says, "Yahweh forbid that I should put out my hand against Yahweh's anointed." Here, David again strongly insists that David will not reject Saul.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What kind of oaths or strong words do people use in your language to show they will keep their promises? Pause this audio here.

Instead of killing Saul, David takes Saul's spear and water jug, then leaves the encampment with Abishai. David does this to prove to Saul later that David spared Saul's life again.

Stop here and look at a picture of an ancient water jug as a group. Pause this audio here.

Neither Saul nor any of Saul's 3,000 soldiers awake as David and Abishai come and go from the camp because Yahweh causes the soldiers all to fall into a deep sleep.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 26:1–12 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has four scenes.

In the first scene: The Ziphites come to Saul at Gibeah and tell Saul where David is hiding. Saul takes 3,000 chosen soldiers to the location where the Ziphites said David would be.

In the second scene: David discovers or sees that Saul has come after David in the wilderness. David sends scouts to determine if Saul really has come.

In the third scene: David and some of David's men go to see Saul's camp. David asks for a volunteer to go into the camp with David. Abishai says Abishai will go.

In the fourth scene: David and Abishai sneak into Saul's camp, where everyone is sleeping. David and Abishai find Saul also sleeping. Abishai wants to kill Saul, but David will not let Abishai kill Saul. Instead, David takes Saul's spear and water jug. Then David and Abishai leave Saul's camp without anyone waking up.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The Ziphites

  • Saul

  • Saul's army of 3,000 special men that Saul chose for this task

  • Abner

  • David

  • David's scouts

  • Abishai

  • And Ahimelek

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

The story starts with Saul in Saul's home city of Gibeah. Saul would be living comfortably as king of Israel in Gibeah. A group of Ziphites travels to Gibeah to tell Saul what these men know about where David is. The Ziphites are Israelites from the tribe of Judah who live near the area where David is hiding. The Ziphites probably tell David's location because the Ziphites want Saul to be kind to the Ziphites since Saul is king.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel that shows Gibeah, Ziph, Jeshimon, and the hill of Hakilah. Pause this audio here.

The Ziphites say to Saul, "Isn't David hiding on the hill of Hakilah near Jeshimon?" Even though the Ziphites ask a question, the Ziphites are telling Saul where David is rather than asking Saul where David is.

Stop here and discuss how you might translate a question like this that is meant to provide information rather than request information. Pause audio here.

Jeshimon is a wilderness. The wilderness is a lonely place with very little water or food. David and David's men know the wilderness well and can survive in it.

Stop here and look at a photo of a wilderness in Israel as a group. Notice places people could hide if they wanted to. Pause audio here.

David sees that Saul is coming and sends spies to confirm Saul's approach. David does not actually "see" Saul coming, but this is a way to say that David knows or discovers that Saul is coming because someone tells David. Then David and some of David's men sneak to a place where they can observe Saul's camp without anyone seeing David's men.

David asks if either Ahimelek or Abishai will go with David into Saul's camp. Abishai is the brother of Joab and the son of Zeruiah. Zeruiah is Abishai's mother. Most of the time, Scripture identifies someone as the son of that person's father. The storyteller probably mentions Zeruiah instead of Abishai's father because Zeruiah is David's sister. Abishai is David's nephew. The storyteller probably mentions Joab as Abishai's brother because Joab becomes important later in David's story.

Stop and discuss as a group: How will you translate that Abishai is the son of Zeruiah? Is it important for your people to know that Zeruiah is Abishai's mother and not Abishai's father? If so, then how will you translate this so people understand? Pause this audio here.

David is asking whoever volunteers to do a very dangerous thing because Saul's men could capture or kill whoever goes into Saul's camp.

Stop here as a group and look at a picture of a camp formation. Use rocks or other items to form a circular camp. At the center, place a different item to represent King Saul. Pause the audio here.

Abishai volunteers to go. At night, David and Abishai sneak to the center of the encampment where Saul and Saul's commander, Abner, are sleeping. Saul's men had probably set up the camp with their sleeping places in a circle around the most important people, like Saul and Saul's commander, Abner, to protect those people. Later, the storyteller tells us that all of Saul's men are sleeping at this point, too.

Stop here and discuss as a group how you will talk about the camp where Saul was sleeping with Saul's 3,000 special men who were helping Saul chase David to kill David. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss how to show that everyone was asleep even though the storyteller does not tell us that until later. Pause this audio here.

Abishai, who likely whispers, says to David that today God has given David's enemy to David. Abishai is telling David that tonight David can kill Saul. Abishai says that Abishai will kill Saul with Saul's own spear. David asks Abishai who could be innocent if they killed Yahweh's anointed. David did not mean for Abishai to answer this question. Rather, this question emphasizes that David believes David would be guilty before Yahweh if David or Abishai killed Saul.

David uses two oaths to Yahweh to emphasize that David would never harm Saul. In the first oath, David says, "as surely as Yahweh lives," which means David is as sure that Yahweh himself will kill Saul as David is sure that Yahweh exists.

Stop and discuss other options for translating the phrase "as surely as Yahweh lives." You could translate this phrase with the words "by Yahweh who lives." You could also translate the phrase "I promise you." Pause this audio here.

David says, "Yahweh forbid that I should put out my hand against Yahweh's anointed." Here, David strongly insists with an oath that David will not harm Saul.

David shows mercy to Saul. But David also wants Saul to know that David could have killed Saul. So, David takes Saul's spear and water jug. The water jug has been next to Saul from the beginning, but this is the first time we hear about it. David and Abishai leave the camp without waking Saul, Abner, or any of the 3,000 soldiers because Yahweh put Saul and Saul's army in a deep sleep.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 26:1–12 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has four scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The Ziphites

  • Saul

  • Saul's army of 3,000 special men that Saul chose for this task

  • Abner

  • David

  • David's scouts

  • Abishai

  • And Ahimelek

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

The Ziphites come to Saul at Gibeah and tell Saul that David is hiding in the wilderness.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person or people playing the Ziphites, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am hoping that Saul will be happy with us for telling Saul where his enemy is; or

  • I do not like doing this, but we will be in trouble if we do not tell Saul that David is in our wilderness; or

  • We need to kill David and David's band of rebels. These men will only bring trouble.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • These Ziphites are good people. This is the second time the Ziphites told me where to find my enemy, David; or

  • Finally, I can eliminate the only threat to my throne; or

  • I know it is wrong to keep going after David. But I must capture David because David is a threat to my throne; or

  • God has blessed me with the knowledge of my enemy's whereabouts.

Saul takes 3,000 soldiers and goes to the place where the Ziphites told Saul David would be. David learns that Saul is coming and sends spies to confirm it. When David knows for sure that Saul has come, David takes some of David's men to a place near Saul's camp. David asks if Ahimelek or Abishai will go with David into Saul's camp. Abishai volunteers to go with David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Ahimelek, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • This is a very foolish thing to do. I am not going down there; or

  • I do not know what to say. I do not want to do this, but I do not want to look like a coward either; or

  • I feel disappointed. I wanted to go with David, but Abishai spoke up first.

David and Abishai sneak into Saul's camp while Saul and all of Saul's men are sleeping. When David and Abishai find Saul and Abner, Saul's commander, asleep, Abishai urges David to let Abishai kill Saul. But David will not let Abishai kill Saul and says that David will never kill the one whom Yahweh anointed as king. David and Abishai take Saul's spear and Saul's water jug. Then David and Abishai leave the camp without waking any of Saul's men because God put all of the men in a deep sleep.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Abishai, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel frustrated. Why did I risk my life to come into this camp? or

  • We have lived as exiles for years because of Saul. What is David thinking? or

  • David is weak. If David will not act when it is clearly time to act, David will put us all in danger; or

  • Maybe David is right, and we should not kill Saul. Maybe we should let Yahweh punish Saul.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 26:1–12 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

The Ziphites tell Saul where David is hiding by asking, "Is not David hiding on the hill of Hakilah east of Jeshimon?" Then Saul takes 3,000 chosen soldiers to pursue David in the wilderness of Ziph. A wilderness is a lonely, barren place without much water where people do not live. David is staying in such an isolated place because David is hiding from Saul. Use the same word for wilderness that you have previously used. Look up wilderness in the Master Glossary for more information.

By sending spies, David discovers where Saul's army camped. These spies were like scouts but moved around secretly.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for spies. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

David and Abishai find Saul asleep with Saul's spear stuck in the ground beside Saul's head. This was probably a special spear for Saul since Saul was king. Translate spear in the same way you have translated spear in previous passages. Later, we find out that Saul also has Saul's water jug next to Saul as he sleeps.

Stop here and look at a picture of a royal spear and a water jug as a group. Pause this audio here.

Abishai says, "God has given your enemy into your hand this day." Abishai uses the general word for God rather than Yahweh. Use the same word for God as you previously used. For more information on God, refer to the Master Glossary. Use similar language for giving enemies into David's hands as you have used in previous stories.

David tells Abishai not to destroy Saul. David asks Abishai who could be innocent if they killed Yahweh's anointed. David uses Yahweh, God's personal name. You will remember that Samuel anointed Saul as king to show that Yahweh had chosen Saul. Use the same words for Yahweh and anoint that you have previously used. For more information on Yahweh and anoint, refer to the Master Glossary.

David tells Abishai that Saul will die some other way besides David killing Saul. Use the same language that you have used in earlier stories to talk about Yahweh "striking," or killing, Saul. David makes David's words even more insistent by using the oath, "as Yahweh lives." Although the storyteller does not use the word oath here, David is swearing an oath. When someone swears an oath, that person says, "I will absolutely keep my promise. If I do not, God may punish me." For more information about what an oath is, you can refer to the Master Glossary.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 26:13–25
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 26:13–25 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 26:13–25 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 26:13–25 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

This story follows immediately from the previous story. In that story, David and Abishai went into Saul's camp. All the people in Saul's camp were asleep. Yahweh made all the people in the camp stay asleep while David and Abishai were in the camp. David and Abishai took Saul's spear and water jar from beside Saul. David and Abishai did not hurt or kill anybody in Saul's camp. David and Abishai left Saul's camp. This passage tells us what David does next.

David goes to stand on a hill near Saul's camp. There is a deep space, or valley, between the hill where David stands and Saul's camp. The space between David and Saul's camp makes David feel safe.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Where in your country is there a valley between two hills that you could shout across the valley? If there is no valley like this, talk about what the valley in the passage might have looked like. Pause this audio here.

David shouts across the valley to Saul's army. David calls out and shouts to Abner, Ner's male descendant. You will remember from previous passages that Abner is the commander of Saul's army and is part of Saul's army. Abner leads Saul's soldiers and keeps Saul safe. David calls Abner by Abner's name. David wants Abner to know that David has visited Saul's camp. We do not know if the people in the camp wake up before David calls out to the camp or if David wakes the people in the camp by shouting. David calls out to get Abner's attention. David wants Abner to answer David's call.

Abner replies to David. Abner does not know who is shouting at the camp and at Abner. Abner asks who is shouting. Abner wants to know who dares to disturb Israel's king. Abner speaks angrily to David because David woke the king. David uses questions to show that Abner is doing a bad job of guarding the king.

Stop here and do this activity as a group: Have someone in the group tell a story about a time when someone scolded a leader for doing a bad job. Pause this audio here.

David knows and tells Abner that Abner did not guard Saul properly that night when David and Abishai went into Saul's camp. David does not say who went into Saul's camp. David did not go to Saul's camp to kill Saul, but Abishai did want to kill Saul. David then talks to all the soldiers in Saul's camp. David uses a common phrase as a promise that what David says afterwards will happen. David knows that Yahweh is alive. With the same confidence, David knows that Abner and the soldiers must die. David tells all the soldiers that the soldiers must die because the soldiers did not guard Saul, the person Yahweh anointed or chose to be king. Saul is the soldier's master.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Talk about situations when people swore or promised that something was going to happen. Pause this audio here.

David asks the soldiers and Abner to look around for the king's spear and water jug. David knows the spear and water jug are gone. David wants Abner to see the evidence that Abner and the soldiers failed to protect the king. David knows where the spear and jug are.

Stop here and look at a picture of a royal spear from the time of David. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of a water jug from the time of David. Pause this audio here.

Saul is awake. Saul has heard David and Abner calling to each other across the valley. Saul recognises David's voice and wants David to confirm that David is the one who calls to the soldiers and Abner. Saul calls David Saul's son to show Saul's affection for the younger man.

David shows respect to Saul by calling Saul David's lord and king. David shows Saul that Saul is still David's master and king. David continues to show respect by calling Saul lord and naming himself, David, the servant. David uses the questions to Saul to ask Saul what David has done wrong. David knows that David has not done anything wrong. David wants Saul to hear what David wants to say to Saul. David talks about why Saul may be hunting David. David knows that Saul has no reason to hunt David. First, David suggests that Yahweh caused Saul to hunt David as a judgment for David's sinning against Yahweh. If David did sin against Yahweh, David would give an offering. David offers this in order to please Yahweh and to ask Yahweh not to punish David.

David suggests a second reason for Saul hunting David. David suggests that men, people of Israel, persuaded Saul to hunt David. If people did this, David wants Yahweh to punish the people. The people who hunt David are making David leave the land of Canaan. Yahweh gave the land to the Israelites as an inheritance from one generation to the next generation for all time. The people who hunt David are making David go into lands where the people serve and worship different gods. It is wrong to stop an Israelite from living in the land Yahweh gave to the Israelites. This is why David calls for Yahweh to curse and punish those people.

David asks Saul not to kill David. David does not want to die and have David's blood go into the ground away from where the Israelites meet with Yahweh. It is important to remember that Yahweh is everywhere and works in all lands. However, Canaan is where the Israelites worshiped Yahweh and where Yahweh appeared to the Israelites. It was important to the Israelites to die in the land where the Israelites met with Yahweh.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What traditional and important things can you only do when you are in your own land? What does somebody do if they need to live outside of your country or the land that you live in? Pause this audio here.

David tells Saul that David is not important. The king, the most important person in Israel, hunts a flea. A flea is a very small animal that lives on other animals. A flea is the size of a small seed. David says that David is like a flea, an insignificant creature, compared to the king. David then compares Saul hunting David to someone who hunts a partridge in the mountains. A partridge is a wild bird that people hunt, cook, and eat. We do not know the exact type of bird that David is talking about.

At David's time, there were many partridges on the fields and lowlands of Israel. Nobody needed to go to the mountains to find a partridge. David means that there is no need to hunt David. Also, a bird calls out just like David is calling out to Saul. David is saying that David is like the partridge.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What animals do you say people are like in your community or language because of similarities between the people and the animals? Pause this audio here.

Saul responds to David. Saul admits that Saul has sinned against Yahweh. Saul sinned by hunting David. Saul calls to David and tells David to return to Saul. Saul knows that David decided not to kill Saul that night, at that time. Because David did not kill Saul, Saul says that Saul will not hurt David again. Saul has been foolish. Saul was not wise or sensible. Saul made wrong choices.

David decides to give back to Saul the spear that David took from Saul. David does not go over to Saul's camp. We do not know why David does not give back the water jug. David wants one of the soldiers in Saul's camp to come to get the spear. David knows that Yahweh blesses people who are faithful, follow Yahweh, and do what Yahweh asks. David tells Saul that, at that time, Yahweh put Saul into David's power. David chose not to harm Saul because Saul was Yahweh's chosen and anointed king for Israel. In the same way as David respected Saul and kept Saul safe, David wants Yahweh to look after David and keep David safe. David puts his trust in Yahweh.

Saul wants Yahweh to bless David so that David receives good things from Yahweh. Saul knows that David will do lots of good things and be successful. We do not know what Saul expects David to succeed in doing. David and Saul stop talking and go away from the hill and the camp in different directions. Even though Saul asks David to come back, David does not go with Saul. Saul goes back to Saul's home, probably to Gibeah.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 26:13–25 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has three scenes.

In the first scene: David calls out to Saul's army and speaks to Abner. David tells Abner and the other soldiers that Abner and the soldiers have not kept the king safe.

In the second scene: David speaks to Saul. David asks why Saul hunts David. Saul says Saul has done the wrong thing. David decides to give back the king's spear. David tells Saul that David kept Saul safe. Saul blesses David.

In the third scene: David and Saul leave in different directions.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • Abishai

  • Saul's army

  • Abner, son of Ner, commander of Saul's army

  • Saul

  • And the young man who collects the spear from David.

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

This passage describes what happens immediately after the previous one. David and Abishai leave Saul's camp and cross a valley to reach a hill. David and Abishai go to Saul's camp at night. When David leaves the camp, it is still night, and David crosses to the other side of the valley. David stands far from Saul's camp but close enough to shout across the valley to the camp. David is at the top of a hill. We do not know if it is still night at the beginning of this passage or how long David traveled from the camp to the hill. However, we know that David wakes some people when David shouts to the camp, so it was probably still night.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What do you shout to get someone's attention? Is there a particular phrase that you use? Pause this audio here.

First, David calls out to talk to Abner. Abner leads Saul's army. The soldiers can also hear David. We do not know if David calls out something else before Abner answers. Abner answers David after David calls out to Abner by name. David responds to Abner with three questions that David does not expect Abner to answer. David uses the questions to tell Abner that Abner failed to guard Saul properly. The first question is an insult. David knows Abner is a fully grown man and one of the best soldiers in Israel. Saul trusts Abner to protect Saul, the king. David refers to Abner's lord. Saul is Abner's lord, the person Abner obeys and serves.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What respectful title do you call a person who is a leader and tells other people what to do? Pause this audio here.

David tells Abner and the soldiers that Abner and the soldiers failed to keep Saul safe. Because Abner and the soldiers failed, David judges Abner and the soldiers. David uses a common phrase as a promise that what David says afterwards will happen.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What words or phrases do people use in your community to show they are really confident that something is true or will happen? Pause this audio here.

The punishment for Abner and the soldiers is death, but these men do not die in this story. David shows Abner and the soldiers the king's spear and water jug. The spear and water jug are not beside Saul. David has the spear and the water jug on the top of the hill.

Saul is awake. We do not know when Saul woke up. Saul talks to David after David talks to Abner. Saul checks that the voice Saul hears belongs to David. Saul calls David Saul's son. David is not one of Saul's sons. Saul calls David Saul's son to show Saul's affection for the younger man.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What affectionate words or names do you use in your community for people you care about? Do you call people son or daughter even if those people are not your own children? Pause this audio here.

David tells Saul that Saul is right. David asks in three different ways why Saul is hunting David. David shows respect to Saul by calling Saul lord and himself Saul's servant. Firstly, David asks why Saul is hunting David. Then David asks what David has done. Lastly, David asks what evil or guilt is on David's hands. David does not have anything actually on David's hands. If a person has guilt or evil on their hands, it means that the person is responsible for doing something wrong.

David wants Saul to hear that David knows that Saul is doing the wrong thing by chasing and hunting David. David knows that only Saul is responsible for chasing David. David uses two possible reasons for Saul to chase David to show Saul that Saul is responsible for chasing David. First, David suggests to Saul that Yahweh made Saul chase after David. Second, David suggests that people have made Saul chase after David. David says that the people chased David from Israel today. Today means at this time, not the exact 24-hour time period that David is experiencing.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What words or phrases do you use to describe something that happens to you or affects you now? Pause this audio here.

Then David asks Saul not to kill David in foreign lands. David tells Saul that David is not important and that Saul does not need to hunt David.

After David questions Saul, Saul admits to David that Saul has disobeyed God by chasing after David.

Stop here and do this activity as a group: Talk about a time when you showed a person what they did wrong, and then the person admitted that they made a mistake. Pause this audio here.

Saul wants David to go back to Saul and to Saul's camp. Saul recognises that David kept Saul safe and showed respect to Saul at that time, on that night. Saul says that Saul will keep David safe because David kept Saul safe. Saul admits to David that Saul was not wise and made wrong choices.

Stop here and do this activity as a group: Talk about a time when a leader admitted they had done something wrong. Talk about the leader's tone of voice and manner of speaking. How might Saul have been speaking here? Pause this audio here.

David answers Saul. David wants to give back the king's spear to Saul. David does not go over to Saul's camp. David suggests that a soldier or young man from Saul's camp should come to get the spear from David. Notice that David does not go to Saul himself.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How might you describe the soldier in your translation? Pause this audio here.

David says that Yahweh blesses people who follow Yahweh and do what Yahweh wants. Yahweh let David be in control of Saul's life at that time, on that night. David did what was right and did not hurt the person Yahweh chose to be king. On that day, at that time, David valued and saved Saul's life. David calls on Yahweh to do the same for David as David did for Saul.

Saul replies to David. Saul wants Yahweh to give David good things. Saul shows affection to David by calling David Saul's son. Saul recognises that David will succeed and do great things in life after this meeting.

David then leaves the hill and goes away from that place. Saul goes away as well, but Saul goes in a different direction, back to Saul's home, probably at Gibeah.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 26:13–25 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has three scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • Abishai

  • Saul's army

  • Abner, son of Ner, commander of Saul's army

  • Saul

  • And the young man who collects the spear from David.

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

David calls out to Saul's army and speaks to Abner. David tells Abner and the other soldiers that Abner and the soldiers have not kept the king safe.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Come on, wake up and see what we did while you were sleeping! or

  • These soldiers have failed; or

  • Look what we managed to do while you slept!

Ask the person playing Saul's army, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • What is going on? Who is shouting at us? or

  • What has happened while we were asleep? or

  • I am afraid! We have failed our lord the king!

Ask the person playing Abner, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • This man has woken us up! or

  • It is David! What has David done? or

  • David has my king's spear and jug!" or

  • I have failed my lord the king. Yahweh will punish me. I am ashamed and frightened.

David speaks to Saul. David asks why Saul hunts David. Saul says Saul has done the wrong thing.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I want to speak to Saul; or

  • It is time for Saul to understand that Saul is sinning against Yahweh; or

  • I am tired and sad. I do not want Saul to hunt me anymore. I want to live in my family's land.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • David knows that I am responsible for hunting David; or

  • I am sorry that I have hunted David. I love David like a son; or

  • I want David to come back to be with me.

David decides to give back the king's spear. David tells Saul that David kept Saul safe. Saul blesses David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I will give you back your spear; or

  • Yahweh guides me; or

  • I respect the king that Yahweh gave to us; or

  • I will continue to trust Yahweh.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Please Yahweh, bless David; or

  • I am sad. I have done bad things as king, and I know that David will be great.

David and Saul leave in different directions.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I will not go to Saul. I do not trust Saul; or

  • It is time to go and find somewhere to rest.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I want David to come home with me; or

  • David will be great. I do not like that. Maybe I can kill David if he comes back with me; or

  • It is time to go back to Gibeah.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 26:13–25 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

David crossed over to the other side of the valley and stood on top of the hill. David called out to the army and to Abner. David asked Abner why Abner did not guard his lord, or master, the king. Use the same words or phrases for lord and king as you used in previous passages. For more information on lord and king, refer to the Master Glossary.

David makes a promise to Abner and the army. David says that as sure as Yahweh lives, Abner and the army will die. Yahweh is God's personal name. In this passage, the storyteller calls God "Yahweh." Be sure to translate Yahweh in the same way as you have in previous passages, and remember that Yahweh is in the Master Glossary.

Yahweh has anointed Saul as king. Anointed means that God chooses someone for a special task. Use the same word or phrase for anointed that you have used in previous passages. Anoint is in the Master Glossary.

David told the soldiers to look for the king's spear and water jug. Use the same words or phrases for king's spear and water jug as you used in previous passages.

Saul spoke to David. Saul called David Saul's son. Use the same word or phrase for son when the person uses it as an affectionate title as you used in previous passages. For more information on son, refer to the Master Glossary.

David asked Saul why Saul is chasing David. David suggests to Saul reasons why Saul is chasing David. David will make an offering to Yahweh if Yahweh sent Saul. Use the same word or phrase for offering as you used in previous passages. For more information on offering, refer to the Master Glossary.

If people have told Saul to chase David, David wants Yahweh to curse those people, or punish them. Use the same word or phrase for curse as you used in previous passages. For more information on curse, refer to the Master Glossary.

David cannot live in Yahweh's inheritance, which is the land Yahweh gave to the Israelites. Use the same word or phrase for inheritance as you used in previous passages.

Saul and Saul's army are chasing David to lands where the people serve other, false gods. Use the same word or phrase for false gods as you used in previous passages. For more information on gods, refer to the Master Glossary.

David says that David is like a flea. Use the same word or phrase for flea as you used in previous passages.

David says that Saul is hunting David like a person hunts a partridge in the mountains. A partridge is a wild bird that people hunt, cook, and eat.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for partridge. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Saul admits to David that Saul has sinned. Use the same word or phrase for sinned as you used in previous passages. Sin is in the Master Glossary.

David says that Yahweh rewards everyone for their righteousness and faithfulness. In other words, Yahweh rewards people when people behave rightly, according to Yahweh's will. Yahweh also rewards people who are faithful or who obey Yahweh's laws. Use the same words for righteousness and faithfulness that you have used in previous passages. Both righteousness and faith are in the Master Glossary.

Saul asks David to come back to Saul and tells David that Saul will not harm David again. David decides to give Saul the spear. David prays that Yahweh will take care of David as David took care of Saul. Saul hopes that Yahweh will bless David. Use the same word or phrase for bless as you used in previous passages. For more information on bless, refer to the Master Glossary.

David leaves the hill, and Saul goes home.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
