title: 1 Samuel 27:1–28:2
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 27:1–28:2 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 27:1–28:2 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 27:1–28:2 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

This story tells us about the time after Saul was hunting David in Israel. In Israel, David and Saul spoke to each other across a valley. Saul said that Saul would not try to hurt David again. David heard Saul but did not trust Saul. David did not believe that Saul would stop hunting David.

This story happens some time after the conversation between David and Saul. We do not know how much time has passed between the events in this story and the conversation between David and Saul across the valley.

David thinks to himself that one day, Saul will kill David. David knows that the best thing for David to do is to leave Israel and go to where the Philistines live. David hopes Saul will give up looking for David in Israel.

Stop here and do this activity as a group: Tell a story about a time someone escaped a leader who was trying to kill that person. Where did the person go and what happened? Pause this audio here.

David leaves where David and his followers have been staying in the wilderness of Israel. David goes from the land of the Israelites to the land of the Philistines. David goes over the boundary or the border between the two lands.

David's 600 men go with David. David and his followers go to King Achish in the city of Gath in Philistia. King Achish was the son of Maok. We do not know if this is the same Achish that David stayed with before. All the kings of the Philistines might have used the name Achish, or Achish might be this king's personal name.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Talk about examples of people in your community who use the same name from one generation to the next. Why do these people have the same name? Is the name ceremonial, or does the name have a different meaning? Pause this audio here.

David lives with Achish in the city of Gath. David probably does not share a home with Achish. David lives in Gath, and Achish protects and supports David. David lives in Gath with lots of people. David's men live with their households, which are the men's close family and possibly servants. David's two wives, Ahinoam and Abigail, are with David in Gath. The story reminds us that Ahinoam came from Jezreel. Abigail is the widow of Nabal and lived in Carmel before she married David.

Stop here and do this activity as a group: Tell stories of times when large groups of people had to run away from their homeland and live in a different place for a while. Pause this audio here.

Saul hears that David is in Gath. We do not know who tells Saul that David has left Israel. Saul stops looking for David because David has left Israel, the land over which Saul has power.

David hopes that Achish is happy with what David is doing. David asks Achish for a gift, or somewhere for David and all David's men to live. At that time, kings gave land to servants whom they trusted. David calls himself a servant of Achish. David is saying politely that Achish has power over David, and David will do what Achish wants David to do. David does not serve Achish by doing household jobs or looking after Achish. David asks Achish why David, Achish's servant, should stay in Gath. David is saying that David is not important enough to stay in the royal city. David does not want or need to live in the city where King Achish lives, the royal city. David wants to live away from Gath in the countryside, in a smaller town.

When David asks Achish for a place to live, Achish gives David the town of Ziklag. The storyteller reminds us that Ziklag still belongs to the kings of Judah at the time when the storyteller tells this story. You will remember that Judah became a separate kingdom later in Israel's history. The city of Ziklag belonged to David's family from generation to generation as an inheritance from Achish.

Stop here and look at a map of Philistia showing the city of Gath, the town of Ziklag, and the border with Israel. Pause this audio here.

David stays in Philistia at Gath and then Ziklag for a year and four months.

Next, the storyteller tells us what David did while David was in Philistia. David and his men raided, attacked, and stole from groups of people south and west of Ziklag and Philistia. These groups of people were enemies of Israel who had attacked Israel and now lived on the land Yahweh had given to Israel. The Geshurites, Girzites, and Amalekites lived in the settlements all the way towards Shur and Egypt. Some translations say that the settlements reached from Telam, a town in Judah, but most translations say that people lived in the lands from ancient times. Telam in the original language means a long time or forever. The Geshurites in this story are a different group of people from the Geshurites who lived near Gilead, northeast of Israel.

Stop here and look at a map of Ziklag in Philistia, the lands of the Geshurites and Girzites and Amalekites, Shur, the eastern border of Egypt, and the lands of Judah and Edom. Pause this audio here.

When David and David's men attacked a settlement, the men killed everybody but took sheep, cattle, donkeys, camels, and clothing.

Stop here and look at a picture of sheep as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of cattle as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of a donkey as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of a camel as a group. Pause this audio here.

David and David's men took back anything that was valuable. David and his men kept some of the animals and clothing to support David and his men in Ziklag. David probably gave some of the animals and clothing to Achish. David went out many times to attack the Geshurites, Girzites, and Amalekites. After each raid, Achish asked David what David was doing and who David attacked. David did not tell the truth to Achish. David told Achish that David and his men were raiding in the area of the Israelites and the people who lived with the Israelites in the Negev wilderness. The Negev wilderness is an area of dry land in the south of Israel, in the tribal lands of Judah. The Jerahmeelites were a group of people in the tribe of Judah. The Kenites were friends of Israel and lived between Judah and Edom.

Stop here and look again at a map of Ziklag in Philistia, the lands of the Geshurites and Girzites and Amalekites, Shur, the eastern border of Egypt, and the lands of Judah and Edom, if needed. Pause this audio here.

David and his men killed everyone on a raid so that nobody from a raided town came to Gath and told the truth to Achish. David did this all the time that David lived in Philistia on this occasion. Achish did not learn the truth. Achish trusted David and thought that David had become someone that the Israelites hated and rejected. Achish believed that David would be Achish's servant. Achish believed that David would provide military service to Achish and live under Achish's protection. Achish believed that David would always be Achish's servant, that David would live out the rest of David's life serving Achish.

Stop here and do this activity as a group: Talk about a time someone lied to people in order to continue obeying God or in order to help a group of people. Pause this audio here.

At the time that David was living in Philistia, the people in Philistia came together to fight Israel. The leaders of the Philistines called the fighting people together to be ready to attack Israel. Achish wanted David to fight with the Philistines against Israel. Achish says that David and David's men have to join the Philistine army. David does not say that David and his men will attack Israel. David is careful when David replies to Achish. Achish thinks that David is going to help the Philistines attack Israel. Achish honours David by making David Achish's bodyguard. A bodyguard is someone who provides personal protection to somebody special. A bodyguard may give their life to keep the special person safe. Achish makes David Achish's permanent bodyguard, for all the time from that time onwards.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you protect the leaders in your community in dangerous situations?

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 27:1–28:2 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has seven scenes.

In the first scene: David decides to go to Philistia.

In the second scene: David, David's men, and the men's wives go to Gath in Philistia. Saul stops looking for David.

In the third scene: David asks Achish, the king of Gath, for somewhere for David and David's men to live. Achish gives Ziklag to David.

In the fourth scene: David and David's men raid the Geshurites, Girzites, and Amalekites.

In the fifth scene: Achish asks David where David raided. David tells Achish that David and David's men raided people in Judah.

In the sixth scene: Achish thinks about David and thinks that David will serve Achish from now on and always.

In the seventh scene: The Philistines get ready to fight Israel, and Achish tells David that David and David's men will have to fight with the Philistines against Israel. David replies, and Achish thinks that David will be faithful and protect Achish.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • David's men and their households

  • Achish, king of Gath

  • David's wives, Ahinoam and Abigail

  • Saul

  • Geshurites, Girzites, and Amalekites

  • And Philistine leaders

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

This story starts with David in Israel. David is thinking about what to do. In the previous story, David talked with Saul across the valley, and Saul was friendly. This storyteller tells us that David does not trust Saul. David decides to leave Israel and go to Philistia. The storyteller tells us that David thinks to himself, or says in David's heart, that Saul will one day kill David. David talks to himself without speaking out loud. David thinks about slipping out of Saul's hand. This is a way to say that David would move away from Saul's power and that Saul would not be able to capture David. David is not actually in Saul's hand. David is under Saul's power in Israel, and Saul might capture David. When David leaves, Saul will not be able to catch David, and David will be away from Saul's power.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you say that someone is under the control or in the power of another person? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and do this activity as a group: Talk about someone who left your community without telling people they left. Pay attention to any particular phrases you use to describe this. Pause this audio here.

David and David's men leave Israel and go over the border into Philistia.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How would you describe the change between the land of your people and the land of the people next to you? Is there a well-understood borderline between you, or is there a wider boundary of change? How do you know when you have moved from your land to other people's land? Pause this audio here.

David and David's men went to Achish, the king of Gath. Gath was a city in Philistia. Each man had his family with that man, and David had his wives with David. The storyteller gives us information about each of David's wives. Ahinoam is from Jezreel, and Abigail is from Carmel. Abigail is the widow of Nabal.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you talk about people and help other people identify who those people are? What features or information about a person do you add to that person's name? Pause this audio here.

After David leaves Israel, someone tells Saul that David is in Gath. Then Saul stops looking for David.

After some time in Gath, David asks Achish if David has found favour in Achish's eyes. David wants to know if David pleases Achish. David wants Achish to give David and David's men somewhere to stay away from Gath and the king. David is very polite when David talks to Achish and tells Achish that David is Achish's servant.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you say that a leader now likes someone, particularly if the person has done something to change the leader's feelings? Pause this audio here.

At that time, after David asks Achish for somewhere to stay, Achish gives David the town of Ziklag. David becomes the leader of the town of Ziklag, and the land belongs to David. The town is David's property, and it passes on to each Israelite king as an inheritance from one generation to the next until the time of the kings of Judah, when the storyteller writes this story. The kings of Judah come to power and rule many years after the time of this story.

David lives in Philistia, in Gath and then Ziklag, for one year and four months. During this time of one year and four months, David and David's men raided people to the southwest of Philistia many times. In a raid, people suddenly attack someone else with weapons that can cause damage. Then, rather than keeping the enemy's land, the raiders usually take the possessions of the people in the land.

Stop here and do this activity as a group: Talk about the difference between an attack on people to gain land and an attack on people to hurt the people and take their possessions. Pause this audio here.

David raided the Geshurites, the Girzites, and the Amalekites. These people had lived on their land a long time. These people's lands went all the way to Shur and Egypt, and the people were enemies of Israel. David killed all the people in a settlement but took away anything valuable. David took sheep, cattle, donkeys, camels, and clothing.

After a raid, when David went back to Gath and met with Achish, Achish would ask David where David had raided that time. David did not tell Achish the truth. David told Achish that David and David's men raided people in Israel, in the dry lands of Judah and the Kenites.

Stop here and look again at a map of Ziklag in Philistia, the lands of the Geshurites and Girzites and Amalekites, Shur, the eastern border of Egypt, and the lands of Judah and Edom, if needed. Pause this audio here.

David and David's men killed everybody in the settlement during a raid. David was worried that if David left someone alive, that person would go to Gath and tell Achish the truth. David wanted Achish to believe that David and David's men were raiding their fellow Israelites. All the time that David was in Philistia, living in Gath and Ziklag, David was careful not to let anybody survive a raid who might tell Achish the truth.

Achish trusted David and thought that David had made himself offensive to the Israelite people. If David did kill people in Judah, the people in Judah and their fellow Israelites would hate David and find David unacceptable. David would never be able to go back to Israel. Achish believed that David would always serve Achish.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How would you describe a person who did something terrible to his people and whom the people hated? Pause this audio here.

David raided the Geshurites, Girzites, and Amalekites during the year and four months in Philistia. Towards the end of that time, the Philistine leaders started to gather their fighting men together to fight Israel. Achish gathered his fighting men and talked to David. Achish told David that David and David's men must be part of Achish's army. David replied to Achish politely and said that Achish would see what his servant, David, could do. However, David did not promise to fight against Israel. Achish believed David would fight against Israel, and Achish made David Achish's bodyguard from that time onwards.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 27:1–28:2 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has seven scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • David

  • David's men and their households

  • Achish, king of Gath

  • David's wives, Ahinoam and Abigail

  • Saul

  • Geshurites, Girzites, and Amalekites

  • And Philistine leaders

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

David decides to go to Philistia.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I do not trust Saul; or

  • I do not feel safe in Israel; or

  • I think that Philistia might be a good place for me, my men, and my wives.

David, David's men, and the men's wives go to Gath in Philistia. Saul stops looking for David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I hope that we will be safe here; or

  • I need my wives to have somewhere to live; or

  • I hope we have a better time in Philistia this time compared to the last time I came.

Ask the person playing David's men, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We have left our homeland, our inheritance from Yahweh; or

  • Maybe we can make a life here; or

  • I hope David knows what David is doing.

Ask the person playing David's wives, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Maybe here we can make a home together and be safe from Saul; or

  • Will our children be born in a foreign land?

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • David is gone! Now I can be king without David making me look bad; or

  • The Philistines can maybe harm David, so I do not have to! or

  • Now I can concentrate on Israel and stop trying to find David.

David asks Achish, king of Gath, for somewhere for David and David's men to live. Achish gives Ziklag to David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We need to be away from Achish; or

  • My people need a place to live; or

  • We need to live in Philistia, so I will pretend to serve Achish.

Ask the person playing Achish, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am pleased with David. David is strong, and maybe David will help me; or

  • David can have Ziklag to live in.

David and David's men raid the Geshurites, Girzites, and Amalekites.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am going to stop these people from hurting Israel; or

  • We must keep this a secret from Achish. Do not let anybody live; or

  • Take the animals and clothes so that we can give some to Achish and keep some for ourselves.

Ask the person playing the Geshurites, Girzites, and Amalekites, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • David and David's men are killing entire villages in their raids; or

  • We are all going to die.

Achish asks David where David raided. David tells Achish that David and David's men raided people in Judah.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Achish, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I love hearing where David has been raiding; or

  • This man, David, is hurting my enemies in Israel. I am pleased with David; or

  • David brings me plenty of animals and valuable items. David is a good servant.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Achish thinks I am hurting my own people; or

  • So far, Achish does not know that I am actually raiding Israel's enemies; or

  • I must be careful to make sure nobody survives a raid.

Achish thinks about David and thinks that David will serve Achish from now on and always.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Achish, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • David is making the Israelites hate David; or

  • David is my servant now.

Philistia gets ready to fight Israel, and Achish tells David that David and David's men will have to fight with the Philistines. David replies, and Achish thinks that David will be faithful and protect Achish.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Achish, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I must have David and David's men in my army; or

  • David will be my bodyguard now and always. David is a faithful servant to me.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I must be careful now. Achish must believe that we will fight with Achish against Israel; or

  • I cannot fight my brothers in Israel; or

  • Achish trusts me completely. My plan is working!

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 27:1–28:2 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

David decided to leave Israel and escape from Saul's hand, or power. Use the same word or phrase for when hand means power as you used in previous passages.

David knew that Saul would not look for David inside the borders of Israel. For more information on Israel, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word for Israel that you have used in previous passages.

David hopes that David has found favor in the eyes of Achish. In other words, David hopes that Achish likes David. Use the same word or phrase for "found favor in someone's eyes" as you used in previous passages.

David wants to leave the royal city, the city of Gath where the king lives. David asks Achish for a country town or small city for David and David's men to live in. Cities usually have walls around them.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for royal city. Use the same word for city as you have used in previous passages. If you have already translated this phrase in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

David wants to live in a country town. A town is smaller than a city but usually still has walls around it. Use the same word or phrase for town as you used in previous passages.

David and David's men raided the Geshurites, Girzites, and Amalekites. David kills all the people and takes the valuable items from their houses. Use the same word or phrase for raided as you used in previous passages.

David told Achish that he was raiding the Negev wilderness of Judah. The Negev wilderness is dry land in the south of Israel and part of the land that Yahweh gave to the tribe of Judah.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for Negev. You may say that the Negev is a wilderness, and you can look up wilderness in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Achish believed that David would be Achish's servant always. Use the same word or phrase for servant as you used in previous passages. For more information on servant, refer to the Master Glossary.

Achish believed that David would be Achish's servant for life, for all the time from that time onwards.

Stop here and talk about how you will say that David will be Achish's servant for life. Pause this audio here.

Achish told David to bring David's men to join Achish's army. Achish thought David would do everything Achish wanted and that David and David's men would protect Achish from Achish's enemies. Achish decided to make David a bodyguard of Achish.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for bodyguard.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 28:3–14
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 28:3–14 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 28:3–14 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 28:3–14 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

This story describes King Saul's visit to a medium, or witch, in a place called Endor. This story interrupts the story about Achish, the Philistine ruler of Gath, who wanted David to help Achish go to war against the Israelites. The story about David and Achish continues after this story about Saul. Some scholars believe that this story about Saul actually took place after the stories about David and the Philistines. Those scholars think the author probably placed this story between the stories about David and the Philistines to make some comparisons about David and Saul's lives.

The author begins by reminding us that the prophet Samuel had died and that all the people of Israel had mourned or were very sad because Samuel had died. The people of Israel buried Samuel's body in Samuel's hometown, Ramah.

Some of the people who lived in Canaan before the Israelites inherited the land used to try to talk to spirits of the dead. A medium is a person who, people believed, could talk to the spirit of a dead person. People sometimes call mediums "witches." A necromancer is very similar to a medium. People thought a necromancer could talk to the spirit of a dead person to reveal or influence future events, a bit like a "fortune teller." People sometimes call necromancers "spiritists." The spirit, or soul, is the invisible, inner part of a person that continues to exist after a person dies. The law that Yahweh gave to Moses banned the Israelites from consulting the spirits of dead people, as the other nations practised. In a previous story, Yahweh said that to consult the spirits of dead people was a disgusting, terrible thing to do, and that anyone who consults the spirits of dead people must die. So Saul, the king of Israel, had banned or expelled all the mediums and necromancers from the land of Israel.

The events of this story begin when the armies of the Philistine people gather and set up camp in the city of Shunem. The Philistines were enemies of Israel. The Philistines camp at Shunem to prepare for battle against Israel. Shunem was on the southwest side of Mount Moreh, in the Jezreel Valley, within the land that belonged to the Israelite tribe of Issachar.

Then King Saul gathers the army of Israel and sets up camp at Gilboa, a hilly area about eight miles southeast of Shunem. Saul can probably see the Philistine army from Gilboa because Gilboa is a hilly place. The Philistine army is very big. When Saul sees the Philistine army, Saul becomes very afraid.

Because Saul is very afraid, Saul asks Yahweh what to do, but Yahweh does not answer Saul. In those days, Yahweh did not usually speak directly to people. Yahweh would usually speak through a special person, like a prophet, or through a priest who cast lots with the Urim, or sometimes through dreams. A prophet is a person who gives messages from Yahweh to the people. The Urim was an object that Yahweh allowed the priests to use to "throw lots" to discover Yahweh's will on a matter. It is not clear how the priests would use the Urim to throw lots, but the Urim would show the priest what Yahweh wanted Yahweh's people to do. The priest would then give that information to the people. Yahweh does not answer Saul through any of these methods in this story.

Saul then asks Saul's advisors to find a woman who is a medium so that Saul can ask the woman to talk to the spirits of dead people for Saul. Saul probably asks Saul's advisors to find a woman who is a medium because Yahweh is not responding to Saul through dreams, Urim, or prophets. Saul has no other way to find out what Yahweh thinks about the battle with the Philistines. Even though Saul had previously banned mediums from the land of Israel, Saul's advisors know of a woman who is a medium who lives in Endor. Endor is a town a short distance northeast of where the Philistine army is camped, about a 2-hour walk from the Israelite army's camp.

Stop here, and as a group, look at a map of the land of Israel. See the locations of Shunem, Mount Moreh, the Jezreel Valley, Gilboa, and Endor marked on the map. Pause this audio here.

Saul probably does not want anyone to recognise Saul because Saul knows that Yahweh will not be pleased, and because Saul is breaking Saul's own law. Saul disguises himself by wearing normal clothes instead of royal robes. Saul and two of Saul's men wait until night, when it is dark, to go to Endor and find the medium. Mediums and necromancers often performed their rituals at night.

Stop here and, as a group, talk about the different reasons a person might not want other people to recognise that person. If you can, tell a story about a time when someone disguised themself. Did that person disguise themself for a good reason or a bad reason? Pause the audio here.

Now discuss as a group, or tell a story about, some of the ways kings or leaders might try to get good advice that will help them govern wisely. Pause the audio here.

Saul tells the woman to bring up the spirit of a dead man that Saul wants to talk to. When Saul asks the woman to call up or bring up the dead man's spirit, Saul is asking the medium to bring a spirit up from the place where dead people are.

It is not clear if this medium could actually speak to the spirit of a dead person or if she only deceived people into thinking that she could. It is not clear if, or how, a medium could call a dead man's spirit from the underworld, or Sheol. People believed that the spirits of dead people all stayed together in one place after a person died. Some scholars think that the Bible does not explain the practice of calling up the spirits of dead people in more detail because Yahweh hated this practice.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What do people in your culture think about trying to call up the spirits of dead people? Why do you think Yahweh hated this practice? Pause this audio here.

The woman does not seem to recognise Saul. The woman seems surprised that Saul asked her to help him, because Saul, in his disguise, speaks as if he did not know that Saul had "cut off" or killed the mediums in the land of Israel. The woman suspects that Saul is trying to set a trap for the woman's life. This is special language to say that the woman thinks this stranger, who is really King Saul, is trying to get her in trouble with the authorities for disobeying Saul's command not to use mediums. The woman's response suggests that people in the land of Israel knew that Saul often killed mediums and necromancers.

Saul makes an oath, or a very solemn promise, in Yahweh's name. By this oath, Saul assures the woman that just as it is completely true that Yahweh is alive, the woman can be equally certain that no one will punish her for helping Saul at this moment. Saul's behaviour does not seem to make sense. At the same time that Saul is making a promise in Yahweh's name, Saul is also rebelling against Yahweh. Saul is insulting Yahweh when Saul makes a promise in Yahweh's name that Yahweh will not punish the woman if she breaks Yahweh's law.

Because Saul promised that no one would punish the woman, the woman agrees to help Saul. The woman asks Saul who he would like her to bring up for him. Saul asks the woman to bring up the prophet Samuel. We do not know what kinds of rituals the woman performs first, or if Samuel just appears unexpectedly.

When the woman sees the spirit of Samuel, the woman is so frightened that she screams in a loud voice! We do not know what caused the woman to become afraid and cry out. It is important to note that the woman actually saw Samuel. It was not a vision or a dream.

The woman then recognises who Saul is, and asks Saul why he deceived or tricked the woman by disguising himself. King Saul tells the woman not to be afraid. Saul asks the woman what she can see. The woman says she can see a god, or ghost-like figure, "coming up" out of the earth, meaning that she could see a spiritual being rising up from the earth. Then Saul asks the woman what the spiritual being looks like.

The woman says she sees an old man coming up, wearing a robe. A robe is a piece of clothing that people wear over other clothing for protection or warmth. In the Bible, outer garments, such as cloaks or robes, often showed a person's status or role. From the woman's description, Saul knew the woman was talking about Samuel, the prophet. Samuel the prophet was an old man who used to wear a robe when Samuel was alive. You will remember a previous story when Saul held on to the bottom of Samuel's robe, and it tore.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What do people in your culture wear or decorate themselves with to show they have a position of authority or a particular role in the community? Pause the audio here.

This story ends when Saul understands that the woman can see Samuel, and Saul bows down to the ground to show deep respect to Samuel.

Stop here and, as a group, talk about different ways in your culture people might show deep respect to a person in authority.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 28:3–14 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has five scenes.

In the first scene: The storyteller describes what was happening in the history and culture of Israel at that time. Samuel had died, and the people had buried Samuel's body. Saul had expelled all the mediums and necromancers from Israel.

In the second scene: The Philistine and Israelite armies assemble and set up camp close to each other in the Jezreel Valley. Saul becomes terrified when Saul sees the Philistine army.

In the third scene: Saul asks for guidance from Yahweh, but Yahweh does not respond. So Saul asks Saul's advisors where Saul can find a medium.

In the fourth scene: Saul disguises himself and visits the medium at night. Saul asks the medium to call up the dead prophet Samuel.

In the fifth scene: The medium sees Samuel and is afraid. The medium describes what she sees to Saul. Saul recognises that the medium can see Samuel, and Saul bows down with his face to the ground as a sign of respect to Samuel.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The prophet Samuel

  • Saul, Israel's king

  • The Philistine army

  • The Israelite army

  • Saul's advisors, or servants

  • And the medium of Endor

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

The first scene of this story introduces us to the details of what was happening around the time this story took place. Samuel the prophet had died, and the Israelites buried Samuel's body in Ramah. King Saul had expelled all the mediums and necromancers from the land of Israel, as Yahweh had commanded the Israelites through the law Yahweh gave Moses. Yahweh's law did not permit anyone to talk to the spirits of dead people. It is important to make clear in your translation that these things have already happened. These things do not happen in this story, but these things do help us to understand this story better.

The events of this story begin in the second scene when the Philistine soldiers come together and camp at Shunem, and the Israelite soldiers camp nearby at Gilboa. There are so many Philistine soldiers that when Saul sees the soldiers, Saul becomes afraid and his heart trembles. This is special language to show that Saul feels terrified or that fear is overwhelming Saul.

Stop here and try to imagine a very large enemy army ready to attack a much smaller army. What word or phrase in your language might best describe how you would feel if you were the leader of the smaller army? Pause the audio here.

In the third scene, Saul asks Yahweh what he should do, but Yahweh does not answer Saul. Yahweh did not usually speak directly to people. Yahweh would usually speak through someone Yahweh chose. Yahweh might speak through a prophet, a priest who would cast lots with the Urim, or even through dreams. However, this time, Yahweh does not answer Saul through any of these methods.

Saul then speaks to his servants. The Bible says these men were servants who served Saul, but they were not like household servants. These men were more like officers or advisors. Saul previously banned all the mediums from Israel, but now, Saul asks Saul's advisors to look for a woman who is a medium. It is not clear why Saul asks specifically for a woman. What is clear is that Saul wants to ask the woman to talk to the spirits of dead people for Saul.

Saul probably asks Saul's advisors to find a woman medium because Yahweh is not responding to Saul in the ways that Yahweh approved of to speak to Yahweh's people.

Saul's advisors know of a woman medium who lives in a small town called Endor. Endor is a short distance northeast of the Philistine camp in Shunem, about a two-hour walk from the Israelite camp at Gilboa.

The fourth scene happens at night. Saul puts on different clothes so that people do not recognise Saul as the king. When it is dark, Saul and two of Saul's men go to Endor to find the woman medium. It is likely that Saul and Saul's advisors do this in the evening of the same day that Saul's advisors tell Saul about the medium in Endor.

When Saul and Saul's men find the woman in Endor, Saul tells the woman that Saul needs to talk to a man who has died. Saul asks the woman to "divine by," or talk to a spirit, meaning that Saul wanted to find out Yahweh's will through the spirit of a dead man. Saul asks the woman to call, or bring up, the dead man's spirit for Saul. This means Saul wanted the medium to bring up the dead man's spirit from the place where people believed the spirits of dead people would remain after a person died.

Stop here and, as a group, discuss what word or phrase you will use to say that Saul wanted the woman to "divine by" or consult the spirit of a dead man. If you have translated this phrase in a different book of the Bible, use the same word or phrase that you used previously. Pause the audio here.

The woman does not seem to recognise Saul. The woman responds to Saul by calling Saul's attention to the fact that King Saul has removed or killed all the mediums in the land of Israel. The woman suspects that Saul is trying to set a trap for the woman's life. This is special language to say that the woman thinks Saul is putting the woman's life in danger, like a man sets a trap to catch an animal when he is hunting. The woman knows that if the authorities find out that she talked to a spirit, the woman's life will be at risk.

Saul makes an oath, or a very solemn promise, in Yahweh's name. By this oath, Saul is saying that in the same way it is completely true that Yahweh is alive, the woman can also be completely sure that no one will punish her for helping Saul in this moment.

The woman does not protest against Saul's request anymore. The woman asks Saul who he wants to bring up. Saul asks the woman to bring up the prophet Samuel.

In the fifth scene, the woman sees Samuel and cries out or screams loudly. The Bible passage does not tell us how the woman was able to see Samuel, but it is important to note that the woman actually saw Samuel. It was not a vision or a dream.

Then the woman asks Saul why he deceived her by not telling her that he was King Saul. The storyteller does not tell us what causes the woman to suddenly recognise Saul as King Saul of Israel.

Saul, who is the king, responds to the woman by telling her not to be afraid. The king asks the woman to tell Saul what she can see. The storyteller specifically uses the title "king" for Saul instead of saying Saul's name. This is important. Make sure you use the word "king" in your translation of this part of the story to show the contrast that the king of Israel, who is supposed to follow Yahweh, has broken Yahweh's commands.

The woman tells Saul that she can see a spiritual being coming up from the earth. Your version of the Bible might say the woman saw a god, or a ghost-like, divine figure. In your translation, it is important to make sure that the words you use to describe what the woman saw show that the woman saw something spiritual. The woman did not see something physical, like a living person.

Stop here and discuss as a group the way the spirit-being that the woman saw came up from the earth. If anyone in the group has seen a spirit-being or the spirit of a dead person, have that person describe what it looked like. Then discuss what words or phrases you will use to describe the spiritual being that the woman saw and how it "came up from the earth." Pause the audio here.

Then Saul asks the woman to describe what the spiritual being looks like. The woman says that she sees an old man wearing a robe coming up. From the woman's description, Saul immediately knows that the woman can see Samuel the prophet.

The story ends when Saul recognizes that Samuel has appeared to the woman. Saul bows himself down to the ground as a sign of deep respect for Samuel.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 28:3–14 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has five scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The prophet Samuel

  • Saul, Israel's king

  • The Philistine army

  • The Israelite army

  • Saul's advisors, or servants

  • And the medium of Endor

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

The Philistine and Israelite armies camp close to each other. King Saul becomes very afraid when Saul sees how big the Philistine army is.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am terrified by the sight of this great and powerful army! I do not know what to do or how to lead my army against them!

Saul inquires of, or asks, Yahweh what Saul should do. But Yahweh does not answer Saul. Yahweh does not answer Saul by dreams, or by the Urim, or by prophets.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I do not know what to do to beat the Philistine army! I am seeking divine guidance from Yahweh, but Yahweh's prophet Samuel is dead and cannot help me! Yahweh sometimes speaks to people through dreams, but Yahweh is not speaking to me through dreams! Yahweh also speaks to his people through the Urim, but Yahweh is not speaking to me through the Urim either! or

  • I urgently need an answer from Yahweh, but Yahweh is not responding to me. Why is Yahweh not responding to me? I am the king Yahweh placed over Yahweh's people, the Israelites. I am afraid we will all die!

Then Saul asks Saul's advisors to find a woman who is a medium so that Saul can ask the woman what to do about the coming battle with the Philistines. Saul's advisors say there is a woman medium in the town of Endor, about a two-hour walk away.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I know Yahweh does not permit people to talk to the spirit of a dead person, but Yahweh is not answering me. I am desperate to know what I should do in this battle against the Philistines! or

  • I feel like I have no choice but to look for a medium to help me. It seems that Yahweh has abandoned me!

Now ask the people playing Saul's advisors, or servants, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The people might answer things like:

  • We do not understand why Saul wants to talk to a medium. Our job is just to do what Saul tells us to do; or

  • Saul is behaving very strangely. We wonder why Yahweh is not answering Saul.

Saul puts on different clothes so that people will not recognise Saul. Then Saul goes with his advisors to Endor at night to find the woman. Saul and Saul's advisors find the medium, and Saul asks the woman to call up the spirit of a dead person whom Saul wants to speak with.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I do not want this woman, who is a medium, to recognise me. If the woman recognizes me, she will become afraid for her life and may not want to help me; or

  • I really hope this woman can help me find out what I should know about the Philistine army. Otherwise, I do not know what I will do.

The woman responds cautiously to Saul's request. The woman fears that Saul is trying to trap her. The woman says that Saul has already cut off, or killed, all the mediums and necromancers from the land of Israel, and she fears for her own life.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the woman who is a medium, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel afraid. I do not know these men. These men might be trying to deceive me into helping them so that King Saul will force me to leave the land of Israel, or worse still, have King Saul kill me!

Saul makes an oath in Yahweh's name and promises the woman that she will not receive any punishment for helping Saul speak to the spirit of a dead man. After Saul makes this promise, the woman asks who Saul wants to bring up. Saul asks the woman to bring up the prophet Samuel.

The woman sees Samuel and cries out with a loud voice. Then the woman asks Saul why he deceived her about who Saul really is. Saul, the king, tells the woman not to be afraid. Then Saul asks the woman to describe what she sees. The woman says to Saul that she can see a spirit-figure coming up out of the earth.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the woman who is a medium, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I did not expect to suddenly see this spirit-figure coming up out of the earth. It frightened me! Now I can see that King Saul has deceived me, and I am even more afraid for my life!

The woman describes to Saul what the spirit-figure looks like. The woman says it is an old man wearing a robe. After hearing this description, Saul knows the woman is seeing Samuel. Saul bows himself down to the ground to show reverence or respect to Samuel.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel relieved! I felt afraid to go to the woman who is a medium because I know it is dangerous to try to communicate with the spirit-world, and I know that Yahweh does not allow any contact with the dead! But I feel happier now because Samuel has appeared. Samuel is Yahweh's prophet, and now that Samuel has appeared, I will finally hear what Yahweh will say to me. I feel honoured that Yahweh would allow me to have this encounter with Samuel.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 28:3–14 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

The storyteller clearly calls Saul the king in this story to show the contrast between how Saul was supposed to behave as king and how Saul actually behaved. Use the same word or phrase for king as you have used in previous passages. King is in the Master Glossary.

Samuel the prophet had died, and the Israelites mourned or felt great sorrow because Samuel had died. The Israelites had buried Samuel's dead body in Samuel's hometown, Ramah. In addition, Saul had banned or removed all the mediums and necromancers from the land of Israel. A medium is a person who, people believed, could call up the spirit of a dead person. People sometimes call mediums "witches." A necromancer is very similar to a medium. People thought a necromancer could communicate with the spirit of a dead person to reveal or influence future events, a bit like a "fortune teller." People sometimes call necromancers "spiritists."

Stop here and discuss as a group what words or phrases you will use for mediums and necromancers. Look up medium in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Saul asked Yahweh what to do about the Philistine army, but Yahweh refused to answer. Yahweh is God's personal name. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Yahweh as you used in previous passages.

Yahweh did not respond to Saul with dreams, or Urim, or by the prophets. The Urim was an object which Yahweh authorized the priests to use as a way to "cast lots" and discover Yahweh's guidance about a matter. While using the Urim and Thummim was a form of divination, it showed the priest what Yahweh wanted Yahweh's people to do. The priest could then give that information to the people.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for Urim. The word Urim also appears in the books of Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, Deuteronomy, as well as chapter 14 of 1 Samuel. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

A prophet is a person who gives messages from Yahweh to the people. For more information, refer to prophet in the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for prophet as you used in previous passages.

Saul disguises himself and goes to Endor with two of Saul's advisors. Saul asks the woman to consult the spirit of Samuel the prophet. The spirit, or soul, is the invisible, inner part of a person that continues to exist after a person dies. Refer to spirit in the Master Glossary for more information. Use the same word or phrase for spirit as you used in previous passages.

Saul vows, or makes an oath in Yahweh's name, that no one will punish the woman for doing what Saul asks. An oath is a very serious promise. Refer to oath in the Master Glossary for more information. Use the same word for oath as you used in previous passages.

Saul tells the woman not to be afraid and asks what the woman sees. The woman says that she sees a spirit-like being coming up out of the earth. The woman tells Saul that the spirit looks like an old man wearing a robe. Saul recognizes that this is Samuel and bows down to the ground. Use the same words or phrases for "bow down" and robe as you have used in previous passages, and see bow and robe in the Master Glossary for more information.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
