title: 1 Samuel 28:15–25
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 28:15–25 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 28:15–25 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 28:15–25 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

This story continues the previous story when Saul, Israel's king, visited a woman who was a medium at Endor. You will remember that a medium is a person who, people believed, could call up the spirit of a dead person. The previous story ended when the medium described the spiritual being that she could see. Saul recognised the description as Samuel the prophet, and Saul bowed to the ground as a sign of deep respect to Samuel. Now, Samuel is about to speak to Saul.

This story shows that Yahweh will sometimes abandon a person who continues to abandon Yahweh. This story reminds us that Yahweh is a just and holy God whom people ought to fear and obey. When people continually disobey or sin, there are serious consequences.

Samuel now speaks directly to Saul without the help of the woman. Samuel asks Saul why Saul disturbed or troubled Samuel. In bringing Samuel's spirit up from the dead, Saul has interfered with the natural process of death. Some Bible scholars believe Samuel's question shows that Samuel was happily resting and did not like it when Saul interrupted Samuel's rest.

Stop here and, as a group, talk about what people in your culture believe happens to a person's soul once a person dies. Pause the audio here.

Saul tells Samuel why Saul called for Samuel to speak with Saul. Saul says Saul feels great distress or worry because the enemies of Israel, the Philistines, are at war with Saul and because God does not answer Saul. Saul says that God has turned away from or abandoned Saul and that God no longer answers Saul by prophets or by dreams. Notice that Saul says God, and not Yahweh, here. Yahweh is God's personal name that the Israelites use and which Saul has been using until now. You will remember a previous story where Yahweh's spirit "departed from" or left Saul. Now, it seems Saul is recognising that Yahweh has indeed abandoned Saul. This may be why Saul refers to Yahweh as "God."

Samuel responds to Saul with another question. Samuel asks why Saul wants advice from Samuel about what Saul should do if Saul already knows that Yahweh has left Saul. Samuel says that Yahweh has become Saul's enemy. You will remember a previous story when Saul tore the fabric of the robe that Samuel wore. In that story, Samuel prophesied that Yahweh had rejected Saul and taken away Saul's rule as king over the kingdom of Israel, to give the rule to another Israelite man named David. Now, Samuel tells Saul that Yahweh has fulfilled the promise Yahweh made in that previous story.

Samuel reminds Saul of the reasons why Yahweh has given the kingdom to David. Samuel says it is because Saul did not obey Yahweh's voice or do what Yahweh told Saul to do about the Amalekite people. You will remember a previous story where Yahweh instructed Saul to completely destroy the Amalekites and everything the Amalekites owned, but Saul did not obey. Samuel says that Saul did not show Yahweh's fierce wrath or intense anger against the Amalekites. The Amalekites were enemies of Israel.

Then Samuel prophesies, or tells Saul what will soon happen. Samuel says that the very next day, Yahweh will give or deliver the Israelite army into the hand of the Philistines. This is special language to say that Yahweh will cause the Israelites to lose the battle against the Philistines. Samuel also says that the next day, Saul and Saul's sons will be where Samuel is, showing that Saul and Saul's sons will die the next day. Samuel ends his speech by repeating the prophecy or predicting that Yahweh will cause the Israelites to lose the battle against the Philistines.

Saul immediately falls, stretched out on the ground, when Saul hears Samuel's words. Saul probably falls in this way because Samuel said that Saul and Saul's sons would die a tragic death the next day. By now, Saul has probably learnt that Yahweh always does what Yahweh says he will do, so Saul knows with certainty that Saul will die the next day. This bad news fills Saul with fear. Sometimes, when a person hears bad news like this, it can cause the person to suddenly become weak and collapse to the ground. Also, Saul had eaten nothing that whole day and night, so Saul was already feeling weak in his body. Some Bible scholars think Saul probably fasted as a purification ritual to prepare himself to meet Samuel.

Stop here, and if you can, talk about a time when you received very bad news. Talk about how your body reacted at that moment. Pause the audio here.

Then the woman comes over to Saul. Seeing that Saul is terrified, the woman tries to help him. The woman addresses Saul respectfully and calls herself Saul's servant. The woman reminds Saul that she took her life into her own hands to obey Saul. This means that the woman risked Saul severely punishing her or even killing her because she broke the law. The woman now wants Saul to do as she asks. The woman offers to bring Saul a morsel of bread or something to eat so that Saul may regain his strength for the journey back to the Israelite camp.

Saul refuses to eat until Saul's advisors and the woman insist again. Then Saul listens to their words, meaning that Saul does what the advisors and the woman ask Saul to do. Some Bible scholars think this shows that Saul has accepted that this food may be the last thing Saul eats because he will die the next day. Saul gets up from the floor and sits on the bed, or couch, which may have been a mat or a solid piece of furniture for people to sit or sleep on.

The woman owns a fattened calf, so she quickly kills the calf and prepares it for Saul and Saul's advisors to eat. A fattened calf is a young cow whose owners have fed the calf well enough for it to become fat. Fat adds flavour and nutrients to the meat. The meat of cows was an acceptable food to eat amongst the Israelite community.

Then the woman takes some flour and kneads or presses it together to make unleavened bread. Flour is a grain that people grind into a powder and then mix with water to make bread. Unleavened bread is a type of flatbread that does not ferment or rise before people bake it. It was normal in that culture to show hospitality to visitors by providing food for the visitors to eat. The woman probably only had one fattened calf, so this meal would have been very costly for her. The woman honors Saul by giving Saul the best meal she can offer him.

Stop here and look at a picture of a fattened cow, some flour, and unleavened bread as a group. Then, as a group, talk about the kinds of food people might like to give in your culture when they want to honour a visitor. Pause the audio here.

The woman brings the food to Saul and Saul's advisors, and they all eat. That same night, Saul and Saul's advisors get up and leave the woman's house.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 28:15–25 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has three scenes.

In the first scene: The prophet Samuel and King Saul speak to each other. Samuel confirms that Yahweh has abandoned, or departed from, Saul. Samuel prophesies that Saul and Saul's sons will die the very next day, and Israel will be defeated by the Philistines.

In the second scene: Saul reacts to Samuel's words by falling to the ground. The woman and Saul's advisors encourage Saul to eat some food.

In the third scene: The woman feeds Saul and Saul's advisors. Then Saul and his advisors get up and leave.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel the prophet

  • Saul, Israel's king

  • The woman who is a medium

  • And two men who are Saul's advisors, or servants

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

This story is a continuation of the previous story when Saul and two of Saul's advisors went to visit a woman who was a medium in Endor. In that story, Samuel, who was a dead prophet, appeared to the woman.

This whole story takes place at night. In the first scene, Samuel speaks directly to Saul without the help of the medium. Samuel asks why Saul has disturbed Samuel by calling Samuel back up. The word for disturbed makes someone think about someone stirring up a pile of leaves that a gust of wind blows around. The idea of Saul calling Samuel back up suggests that Samuel's spirit was resting somewhere below the earth, in the "underworld." Remember that in the previous story, the woman said she saw a spiritual being "coming up" out of the earth.

Saul says he called or summoned Samuel because Saul is worried about the threat of war with the Philistines. Saul also says he wants to speak to Samuel because God has "turned away" from Saul. This is special language that means that Yahweh has left, or abandoned, Saul. It is significant that Saul, in contrast to Samuel, now refers to Yahweh as God instead of as Yahweh. Make sure you include this detail in your translation.

Samuel asks Saul another question. Samuel asks why Saul expects Samuel to give Saul an answer from Yahweh if Yahweh has already abandoned or left Saul. Samuel's question shows that Samuel thinks Saul should not have asked Samuel what to do. Samuel says that Yahweh is now Saul's enemy.

Then Samuel says that Yahweh has torn the kingdom out of Saul's hands. This is special language to say that Yahweh has removed Saul from being the king over the kingdom or nation of Israel. Samuel says that Yahweh has given the kingship of Israel to a fellow Israelite named David. You will remember when Samuel prophesied or predicted all these things in a previous story.

Samuel says Yahweh took the kingdom away from Saul because Saul did not obey Yahweh's voice, which is special language that means Saul did not do what Yahweh told Saul to do. In a previous story, Yahweh told Saul to completely destroy the Amalekite people and everything the Amalekites owned, but Saul did not obey. Now, Samuel says that Saul did not show Yahweh's fierce wrath or intense anger against the Amalekites.

Then Samuel tells Saul what will soon happen to Saul and the Israelites. Samuel says that the very next day, Yahweh will give or deliver the Israelite army into the hand of the Philistines. This is special language that means that Yahweh will cause the Israelites to lose the battle against the Philistines. Samuel also says that Saul and Saul's sons will "be where Samuel is." This indicates that Saul and his sons will die the next day. The words Samuel uses to say that Saul will die show us that Saul will die a tragic death. Samuel ends his speech by repeating the prophecy that Yahweh will cause the Israelites to lose the battle against the Philistines. This makes it completely clear to Saul that Yahweh will cause the Israelites to lose the battle against the Philistines.

Stop here and discuss as a group how you will say that Saul and Saul's sons will soon "be where Samuel is." Is there a special word or phrase in your language that you can use to describe the place where people believe the spirit of a person goes once a person dies? Pause the audio here.

Notice that Samuel's spirit appears to leave now, because the storyteller no longer mentions Samuel in this story. In scene two, we hear that Saul immediately falls to the floor after hearing the death sentence that Samuel speaks over Saul's life. The passage says that Saul falls full-length to the ground, meaning Saul is fully stretched out, not that Saul collapses in a heap. It is not clear if Saul falls face down or face up on the ground. What is important to note is that Samuel's words fill Saul with fear or terror.

Then the woman comes to Saul. It is not clear if the woman is in the same place as Saul and just came closer to Saul, or if maybe the woman had previously left the place where Saul was and now comes back to Saul. The woman sees that Saul is terrified and in great distress on the floor, and the woman tries to help Saul. The woman says that because she listened to Saul and risked her own life by bringing up Samuel's spirit, the woman now wants Saul to listen to her and to do what the woman says.

Stop here and, as a group, discuss which words or phrases in your language will show how afraid and distressed Saul was in that moment. Pause the audio here.

The woman asks Saul to allow her to bring Saul a morsel of bread or some food to eat. The woman wants Saul to eat food to regain his strength for the journey back to the camp of the Israelite army, but Saul refuses to eat. Saul's advisors and the woman continue to urge Saul to eat. Finally, Saul agrees to eat. Then Saul gets up from the ground and sits on the bed or couch.

It is important to note how this story shows a contrast in Saul's behaviour. This passage highlights how Saul did not listen to Yahweh's voice or obey Yahweh's instructions, yet now, Saul listens to the voices of the woman and Saul's advisors and obeys them.

In the third scene, the woman quickly kills her fattened calf, or young cow, to prepare a meal for Saul and Saul's advisors. Then the woman mixes and kneads flour and bakes unleavened bread, or flatbread. Shortly after, the woman brings the meal to Saul and Saul's advisors, and they eat. Then Saul and Saul's advisors get up and leave. It is important to note that Saul and Saul's advisors leave that very same night.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 28:15–25 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has three scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Samuel the prophet

  • Saul, Israel's king

  • The woman who is a medium

  • And two men who are Saul's advisors, or servants

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Samuel asks why Saul has disturbed Samuel. Saul says he brought Samuel up because Saul feels great concern about the Philistine army, and because Yahweh does not answer Saul through prophets or dreams. Saul wants Samuel to tell Saul what to do.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel so relieved! Finally, Samuel will tell me what I must do to overcome the Philistine army; or

  • Yahweh has left me, just as Yahweh said he would. I feel like I can no longer use God's personal name, but I am thankful that God has allowed Samuel to come back up to speak to me!

Samuel asks why Saul expects to receive an answer from Yahweh if Yahweh has already left Saul and become Saul's enemy.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Samuel, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel so frustrated by this man, Saul. Saul's behaviour is becoming irrational. I can hardly believe that Saul has failed to follow Yahweh's instructions against contacting the spirits of dead people, when Saul himself even banned the mediums from the land of Israel! or

  • I previously told Saul that Yahweh had rejected Saul from being king over Israel. How can Saul be so foolish as to think that Yahweh will bless him because Saul called me back up from the place of the dead?

Samuel tells Saul that Yahweh's words in a previous story have been fulfilled: Yahweh has taken the kingdom of Israel away from Saul and given it to David, because Saul did not obey Yahweh's instructions about the Amalekites.

Then Samuel tells Saul that the very next day, Saul and Saul's sons will die, and Israel will lose the battle against the Philistines.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel shocked and I am in panic! I did not expect Samuel to say these things! What can I do to stop this from happening?

Samuel's words fill Saul with fear, and Saul falls to the ground. Saul loses all his strength because Saul has eaten nothing all day and night.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • Surely Yahweh will fulfil the word he spoke through Yahweh's prophet Samuel! I feel terrified! What will happen to me? I was foolish not to obey Yahweh's instructions to destroy the Amalekites! I listened to the people and did what they wanted, but I did not listen to Yahweh and obey him. I wish I could go back and change what I did, but it is too late!

The woman comes to Saul and sees that Saul is terrified. The woman offers to bring Saul some food, but Saul refuses to eat at first. Saul's advisors and the woman continue to urge Saul to eat, and finally, Saul agrees. Then Saul gets up from the floor and sits on the bed.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I think it is useless for me to eat this meal if I am to die tomorrow, but I will do as these people say. I still have a long journey ahead of me, and I need my strength. I will eat, even if it is probably going to be my last meal!

The woman quickly kills her fattened calf, bakes unleavened bread, and serves Saul and Saul's advisors a meal. That same night, after they have eaten, Saul and Saul's advisors leave the woman's house.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the woman, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • The visit from Saul and the things that have happened tonight are very unusual. I do not know what will happen in the future, but I do know that the king of Israel came to my house tonight. I want to honour the king with the best meal I can give; or

  • Saul needs to eat. Saul is in no condition to make the journey back to the Israelites' army camp; or

  • I do not want Saul to change his mind again and decide to punish me for bringing up Samuel's spirit, so I will try to keep Saul happy by giving Saul a tasty meal before he leaves.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 28:15–25 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

Samuel asks why Saul has disturbed Samuel by bringing Samuel, or calling Samuel up. Saul says that Saul is very worried because the Philistines are at war with Saul and because God has turned away from Saul. In the Bible, "God" refers to God who created everything and is the most powerful spiritual being. Use the same word or phrase for God as you used in previous passages. For more information on God, refer to the Master Glossary.

Saul says that God does not answer Saul through the prophets or dreams. A prophet is a person who gives messages from God to the people. Use the same word for prophet as you used in previous passages. For more information on prophet and dreams, refer to the Master Glossary.

Samuel says Saul cannot expect an answer from Yahweh because Yahweh has already left Saul and become Saul's enemy. Yahweh is God's personal name. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same word or phrase for Yahweh as you used in previous passages.

Samuel says Yahweh has taken the kingdom away out of Saul's hands, or power, and given it to Saul's neighbour, or fellow Israelite, David. A kingdom is the territory or the people that a king rules. Use the same word or phrase for kingdom as you used in previous passages. A neighbour can mean a person from your community or area. Use the same word for neighbour as you used in previous passages. For more information on kingdom and neighbour, refer to the Master Glossary. Use the same words or phrases for taking something out of someone else's hands, or power, that you used in previous passages.

Samuel says Yahweh has left Saul because Saul did not obey Yahweh's instructions to destroy the Amalekite people. Then Samuel tells Saul that Yahweh will cause the Israelite army to lose the battle against the Philistine army the following day. Samuel also says that Saul and Saul's sons will all die the following day.

Saul falls to the ground, full of fear, because of Samuel's words and because Saul is weak since he has not eaten for many hours. Then the woman comes to Saul and respectfully tells Saul to eat. The woman calls herself Saul's servant as a sign of respect for Saul. At first, Saul refuses to eat, but after Saul's advisors and the woman insist, Saul gets up from the ground and sits on the bed or couch.

The woman kills and prepares a fattened calf for Saul and Saul's advisors to eat. A calf is a young cow. The woman also kneads flour and bakes unleavened bread for Saul and Saul's advisors to eat. After Saul and Saul's advisors eat, the men get up and leave. Use the same word for bread as you used in previous stories.

Stop here and, as a group, talk about what word or phrase you will use to say a fattened calf. If needed, look again at the picture of a fattened cow.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 29:1–11
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 29:1–11 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 29:1–11 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 29:1–11 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

When the Philistines gathered at Shunem to attack Israel, Saul became afraid and asked Yahweh what to do, but Yahweh did not answer. So, Saul asked a woman who speaks to the dead to bring up the spirit of the dead prophet Samuel, as Saul wanted to ask Samuel what Saul should do. In the previous story, Samuel's spirit told Saul that God took the kingdom of Israel from Saul and gave it to David, and that Saul and Saul's sons would die in battle the next day, with the Philistines winning. Saul became scared and weak, so the woman gave Saul a meal to strengthen him, and then Saul and Saul's men left.

This story returns to the story of David and the Philistines, which the narrator interrupted to tell us about Saul speaking to Samuel's spirit. You will remember that all the Philistines were preparing to fight against the Israelites. The Philistine king, Achish, had told David that David and David's men would have to fight with the Philistine army against the men's own people, the Israelites. And Achish made David Achish's bodyguard forever.

At the start of the story, we learn that the Philistines gather all their forces at the town of Aphek. The last time we heard about the Philistines, they were in Shunem in the Jezreel Valley in Israel, about to fight the Israelites. But before the Philistines march to Shunem to fight Israel, the soldiers of the different Philistine lords or kings gather at Aphek in Philistine territory, 60 to 70 kilometres southwest of Shunem. The Israelite army had already camped by a spring of water in the Jezreel Valley. This spring, probably the En Harod spring, comes out from a rock at the foot of Mount Gilboa, making a pool and then a brook through the valley. The spring is about 10 to 15 kilometers southeast of Shunem.

Stop here and, as a group, look at the map. Locate the Philistine town of Aphek and the Israelite camp by Mount Gilboa. Pause this audio here.

The five Philistine lords, or kings, gather their troops and march out for battle against the Israelites in traditional military units—in groups of a hundred and a thousand soldiers. Each king from the five main Philistine cities has his own army. The fact that the kings are going to battle shows that the kings think it is an important battle. Achish, the king of Gath, is at the back with his soldiers. David and David's men march with Achish and Achish's troops at the rear.

The Philistine commanders ask King Achish, "What are these Hebrews doing here?" The commanders are probably the army leaders of units of thousands and hundreds, not the city lords or kings. The commanders want to know why there are Hebrew soldiers with the Philistine army. The Philistines used the word "Hebrews" in a negative way to describe the Israelites as weak or unimportant. Only non-Israelites, like the Philistines, called the Israelites Hebrews.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Talk about the organisation of the army in your people group. How big are the army units, and what are the positions of those who oversee the units? What is the most senior position in the whole army in your people group? Pause this audio here.

Achish replies to the commanders by asking a question that does not need an answer but makes a strong point. Achish explains who David is and why the commanders can trust David. Achish says he trusts David, the servant of Saul, the king of Israel, because David and David's men have been with Achish for over a year. Since David left Saul and joined Achish's army, Achish has not seen David do anything disloyal.

The Philistine commanders are angry with King Achish because they fear that David and David's men will turn against the Philistines during the battle. The commanders tell Achish to send David back to the place Achish gave David instead of letting David fight. The commanders are talking about Ziklag, a city on the border between the Philistines' land and the territory of the tribe of Judah, which Achish gave to David. The commanders do not want David to join the battle, because the commanders worry that David might switch sides and become their enemy. The commanders may remember how some Hebrew soldiers who had previously joined the Philistines turned against the commanders during a battle.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What are the terms under which foreigners can join the army of your people group? What do the foreigners need to do to prove that they will be loyal during a military campaign? Pause this audio here.

The Philistine commanders point out to Achish that a good way for David to get Saul to like David again would be to kill some Philistine soldiers. Victorious soldiers sometimes cut off the heads of defeated enemies and their commanders. The commanders ask Achish, "How could this fellow make peace with his lord? Would it not be with the heads of the men here?"

The Philistine commanders remind Achish that David is the same person people celebrated with songs and dances, singing, "Saul has killed his thousands, and David his ten thousands." The commanders quote the song that women sang about David's victories over the Philistines to show how strong David is. The commanders point out that David's strength could be a danger to the Philistines.

Stop here and, as a group, tell a story of how foreigners came to help your people group in battle. Pause this audio here.

Achish does not want to go against the other leaders, so Achish calls David and tells David about the commanders' concerns. But Achish does not share all the details. To show David Achish is telling the truth, Achish swears solemnly in the name of David's God, saying, "As Yahweh lives, you have been upright." Achish believes David has been trustworthy. Achish says to David that Achish would be pleased to have David serve in the army. Achish says he has not seen David do anything disloyal since joining, but the other kings do not trust David. This is probably because the military commanders warned the kings that David might not stay loyal during the battle. So, Achish asks David to go back to Ziklag peacefully and avoid upsetting the Philistine kings. "Go in peace" could be a kind way of saying goodbye, but here it probably also means that Achish wants David and David's men to leave without causing trouble. Achish mentions this so that David will not do anything to anger the kings.

David asks King Achish what David has done wrong. David probably wants to prove David has not done anything bad and see if Achish is being honest. Achish replies to David and assures David even more strongly that Achish believes David is completely loyal and upright. Achish says David is like an angel of God, or a messenger from heaven to Achish. Achish means David is completely good or faultless, like an angel. But the Philistine army commanders do not want David to fight in the battle against Israel.

Achish tells David to go back to Ziklag right away. Achish tells David to get up early the next morning and leave with the servants of David's lord who came with David. Achish calls David's men servants of King Saul because the men served Saul before they came to serve Achish in Gath. David and David's men are supposed to leave as soon as it is light enough to see.

David and David's men do what Achish tells them. Early the next morning, the men get up, leave the camp, and start their journey back to Philistine territory. Meanwhile, the Philistine army marches from Aphek toward Jezreel.

Stop here and, as a group, look at the map. Find the journey David and David's men took from Aphek to Ziklag and the journey the Philistine army took from Aphek to Jezreel.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 29:1–11 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has six scenes.

In the first scene: The Philistine army gathers at Aphek, and the Israelites camp near Mount Gilboa by a spring in the Jezreel Valley. The Philistines march out for battle in groups of hundreds and thousands, while David and David's men march at the back with King Achish.

In the second scene: The Philistine commanders ask Achish why Hebrew soldiers are in their army. Achish defends David, saying David has been loyal for over a year since leaving Saul, Israel's king. Achish explains that Achish has never seen David do anything untrustworthy.

In the third scene: The Philistine commanders become angry and demand that Achish send David back to Ziklag. The commanders worry David might switch sides during the battle to win back Saul's favor. The commanders remind Achish about the songs people sang about David defeating the Philistines.

In the fourth scene: Achish tells David that Achish believes David has been trustworthy and that he would gladly have David fight in his army. However, the other kings do not trust David, so Achish asks David to return peacefully to Ziklag and avoid causing trouble.

In the fifth scene: David respectfully asks Achish what David has done wrong and why Achish does not allow David to fight the king's enemies.

In the sixth scene: Achish tells David to leave early the next morning with David's men. The men leave the camp at dawn and head back to Philistine territory, while the Philistine army marches from Aphek toward Jezreel.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The Philistine army

  • The Israelite army

  • The lords or kings of the Philistine cities

  • David

  • David's men

  • King Achish

  • And Philistine army commanders

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

This story starts from before Saul talked to the woman who speaks to the dead and shifts focus back to the Philistines. In this story, the Philistines have gathered all their forces at the town of Aphek. The Philistines are preparing to fight against the Israelites. Remember, this takes place before the Philistines marched to Shunem in the valley of Jezreel. At the same time, the Israelite army camped by a spring in the Jezreel valley, which was most likely the En Harod spring at the foot of Mount Gilboa.

Stop here and, as a group, look at the map. Locate the Philistine town of Aphek and the Israelite camp by Mount Gilboa. Pause this audio here.

The five Philistine lords, or kings, gather their troops and march out for battle in groups of a hundred and a thousand men. King Achish and his soldiers are at the back. David and David's men march with Achish and Achish's troops at the rear.

The Philistine commanders ask King Achish why there are Hebrew soldiers with their army. The Philistines used the word "Hebrews" in a negative way to describe the Israelites as weak or unimportant. Only non-Israelites like the Philistines use this word to talk about the Israelites.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Talk about negative words that people use in your language to refer to other people groups in a negative way. Pause this audio here.

Achish replies to the commanders by asking a question that does not need an answer, but makes a strong statement. Achish asks, "Is this not David, the servant of Saul, the king of Israel? David has been with me for a long time, and since he came to me, I have not found anything wrong with him until now." Achish explains who David is and why the commanders can trust David. Achish says he trusts David, the servant of Saul, Israel's king, because David and David's men have been with Achish "for days and years," which means for over a year. Since David left Saul and joined Achish's army, Achish has not seen David do anything disloyal.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Achish says "for days and years" to show that David has been with Achish for more than a year. What words or phrases do you use in your language to talk about different amounts of time, like a year or longer? Pause this audio here.

The Philistine commanders are angry with King Achish. The commanders tell Achish to send David back to Ziklag, the city Achish gave David, instead of letting David fight. The commanders do not want David to join the battle, because the commanders worry that David might switch sides and become their enemy. The commanders say to Achish, "David shall not go down with us to the battle." The commanders probably say "go down to the battle" because armies fought battles in valleys and not on hillsides, and the armies would be going down into the valley of Jezreel.

The Philistine commanders point out to Achish that a good way for David to get Saul to like David again would be to kill some Philistine soldiers. The commanders ask Achish, "How could this fellow make peace with his lord? Would it not be with the heads of the men here?" The commanders call David "this fellow" to insult David because the commanders are angry.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What do people call someone in your language to insult that person because they are angry with the person? Pause this audio here.

The Philistine commanders ask Achish a question that does not need an answer. The commanders make a strong point that David is the same person whom people celebrated with songs and dances. People were singing, "Saul has killed his thousands, and David his ten thousands." The commanders quote the song that women sang about David's victories over the Philistines to point out how strong David is and that David could be a danger to the Philistines. Please note that you translated this song before in 1 Samuel 18:7 and 1 Samuel 21:11.

So Achish calls David and tells Achish about the commanders' concerns. But Achish does not share all the details. To show David that Achish is telling the truth, Achish swears an oath in the name of David's God and says, "As Yahweh lives, you have been upright." Achish says to David that Achish would be pleased to have David serve or "go forth and come back" in the army. Achish says Achish has not seen David do anything disloyal since joining, but the other kings do not trust David. So, Achish asks David to go back to Ziklag peacefully, without causing trouble and to avoid upsetting the Philistine kings.

David asks King Achish what David has done wrong. Then David asks Achish again what David has done during David's time serving Achish that would make Achish not allow David to fight against the king's enemies. David speaks to Achish very respectfully. First, David refers to himself as Achish's servant, and then David politely calls Achish "my lord the king."

Stop here and discuss as a group: What do you say in your language to show respect when you speak to someone older or in authority? Pause this audio here.

Achish replies to David and assures David even more strongly that Achish believes David is completely loyal and upright. Achish says David is like an angel of God to Achish, meaning David is completely good or faultless, like an angel. Achish tells David that, despite that, the Philistine army commanders do not want David to fight in the battle against Israel.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Achish compares David to God's angel to show that Achish thinks of David as faultless. What do you say in your language when you want to say someone is perfect or faultless? Pause this audio here.

Achish tells David to go back to Ziklag right away. Achish uses language that shows Achish wants David and David's men to be urgent about leaving the camp. Achish starts by saying, "Now then, rise early in the morning," and Achish tells David to leave with David's men as soon as it is light enough to see.

David and David's men follow Achish's orders. Early the next morning, the men get up, leave the camp, and head back to Philistine territory. At the same time, the Philistine army marches to Jezreel from Aphek.

Stop here and, as a group, look at the map. Find the journey David and his men took from Aphek to Ziklag and the journey the Philistine army took from Aphek to Jezreel.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 29:1–11 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has six scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The Philistine army

  • The Israelite army

  • The lords or kings of the Philistine cities

  • David

  • David's men

  • King Achish

  • And Philistine army commanders

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

The Philistine army gathers at a town called Aphek, and the Israelite army is camped by a spring in the Jezreel valley near Mount Gilboa. The Philistine kings and their army march out from Aphek for battle against the Israelites in groups of a hundred and a thousand men. David and David's men march with Achish and Achish's troops at the rear.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel awful. I will have to attack my own people, the Israelites! or

  • I feel scared about what will happen to me and my men when we refuse to fight the men of Israel, or if Achish makes us fight the men of Israel!

  • I feel hopeful that Yahweh will help us in this situation. Yahweh is faithful.

The army commanders ask Achish why there are Hebrew soldiers with Achish's army. Achish replies to the commanders and explains who David is and why they can trust David. Achish says he trusts David, the servant of the king of Israel, because David and David's men have been with Achish for over a year. Since David left Saul and joined Achish's army, Achish has not seen David do anything disloyal.

The Philistine commanders are angry with King Achish. The commanders tell Achish to send David back to the place Achish gave David instead of letting David fight. The commanders do not want David to join the battle, and worry that David might switch sides and become their enemy. The commanders point out to Achish that a good way for David to get Saul to like David again would be to kill some Philistine soldiers. The Philistine commanders remind Achish that David is the same person people celebrated with songs and dances, and the commanders quote a song women sang about David after David won a battle against the Philistines: "Saul has killed his thousands, and David his ten thousands."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing a Philistine army commander, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel angry! How are we to go to battle alongside the Hebrews? These men could betray us to King Saul! or

  • I am surprised that King Achish does not realise that David is so strong. Has Achish not heard the song women sang about David killing thousands of our men? or

  • I strongly feel that Achish must send David and David's men back to Ziklag.

Achish calls David and swears solemnly in the name of David's God, Yahweh, and Achish tells David he believes David has been trustworthy. Achish says that Achish would be pleased to have David serve in the army, because Achish has not seen David do anything disloyal since joining, but the other kings do not trust David. So, Achish asks David to go back to Ziklag peacefully without causing trouble and to avoid upsetting the Philistine kings.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing King Achish, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel so sad that the army commanders and the other kings do not trust David; or

  • I feel I have to be loyal to the other kings and tell David to go back to Ziklag, even though David is an honest soldier, and I cannot fault David; or

  • I feel embarrassed that I have to tell David he cannot come to battle with my army. I will make sure David knows I have found nothing wrong with David.

David replies and asks King Achish what David has done wrong. Then David respectfully asks Achish again what David has done during his time serving Achish that would make Achish not allow David to fight against the king's enemies.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel relieved that I will not have to fight against Israel's army; or

  • I feel suspicious. Why does King Achish want me to go back to Ziklag? Achish said he was happy with my service and even made me his bodyguard forever; or

  • I feel grateful to Yahweh for taking me and my men out of this difficult situation. I do not want to betray King Saul.

Achish tells David to get up early the next morning and leave with David's men as soon as it is light enough to see. So early the next morning, the men get up, leave the camp, and start their journey back to Philistine territory. Meanwhile, the Philistine army marches from Aphek toward Jezreel.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 29:1–11 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

The Philistine army gathers at a town called Aphek, and the Israelite army is camped by a spring in the Jezreel valley near Mount Gilboa. The Philistine lords, or kings, and their army march out for battle against the Israelites in groups of a hundred and a thousand men. Use the same word or phrase for lords as you used in previous passages. For more information on lord, refer to the Master Glossary.

The Philistine army commanders ask King Achish why there are Hebrews, or Hebrew soldiers, with their army. Achish says he trusts David, the servant of Saul, the king of Israel, because David and David's men have been with Achish for over a year. Since David left Saul and joined Achish's army, Achish has not seen David do anything disloyal. Use the same words or phrases for commanders, Hebrews, servant, king, and Israel as you used in previous passages. For more information on Hebrews, servant, king, and Israel, refer to the Master Glossary.

Then Achish calls David and says to David, "As Yahweh lives, you have been honest." Achish says to David that he would be pleased to have David serve in the army because Achish has not seen David do anything disloyal since joining, but the other kings do not trust David. Remember previous times when you have translated people giving a strong promise that includes the words "as Yahweh lives," and translate this in a similar way.

Yahweh is God's personal name, and this story uses this name throughout this passage. Use the same name for Yahweh that you have used in previous passages. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary.

Achish asks David to go back "in peace," or without fighting or causing trouble. This was either a normal way to say goodbye, or Achish was asking David specifically not to cause trouble. Use the same word for peace that you have used before. For more information on peace, refer to the Master Glossary.

Achish answers David and says that David is as blameless in Achish's sight as an angel of God.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for angel. Look up angel in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Use the same word or phrase for God as you used in previous passages. For more information on God, refer to the Master Glossary.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
