title: 1 Samuel 30:1–15
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 30:1–15 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 30:1–15 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 30:1–15 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the last story, the Philistine army gathered at Aphek to attack the Israelites near Mount Gilboa. The Philistine commanders did not want David and his men to fight with the Philistines, because the commanders were afraid David might betray them and help Saul. Though King Achish trusted David, Achish sent David and his men back to Ziklag to please the Philistine commanders.

While David and David's men are away, the Amalekites attack the city of Ziklag and the Negev wilderness in the southern part of the territory of the tribe of Judah. The Amalekites had fought the Israelites many times before. Ziklag is a city God promised to give to the tribes of Judah and Simeon, but now Ziklag is part of Philistine territory. King Achish gave Ziklag to David and David's men. The Amalekites conquer and burn down Ziklag, probably without a fight, since the men are away with David. The Amalekites likely do this to get revenge because David had raided the Amalekites' towns before.

Stop here and, as a group, look at the map. Identify Ziklag and the Negev wilderness in the territory of the tribe of Judah. Identify the area south of Beersheba where the Amalekites lived. Pause this audio here.

The Amalekites take the women and everyone in the city, whether young or old, important or not, but they do not kill anyone. Instead, they force the people from Ziklag to go with them, probably to the countryside where no one lives.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Talk about the last time an enemy attacked your territory. What happened? Talk about the last time your army attacked another people group. What happened? Pause this audio here.

After leaving King Achish near Aphek, David and his men reach Ziklag on the third day. When David and his men arrive, they find that the Amalekites had destroyed their city by fire and taken their wives, sons, and daughters captive. Among those the Amalekites captured are David's two wives, Ahinoam from Jezreel and Abigail, who was once married to Nabal from the village of Carmel in the territory of Judah's tribe. In that culture, it was common for men to have more than one wife.

Stop here and look at the map. Identify the journey that David and David's men took from Aphek to Ziklag. Pause this audio here.

David and his men saw that the Amalekites took their entire families. The men mourn and cry loudly until they are too weak to cry anymore.

Stop here and, as a group, tell a story about a time when you saw people weep like this. Pause this audio here.

Now David is in big trouble because the men in David's army talk about stoning David. Yahweh sometimes commanded stoning to punish people who broke certain laws. An angry crowd could also use stoning to kill someone. David's men do not just want to hurt David—they want to kill David. The men feel bitter in their souls, or in the inner part of themselves. Usually, "bitter" describes something that tastes bad, but here it means the men feel deeply upset. David's men's souls are filled with anger and sadness because the Amalekites have taken their sons and daughters. The men blame David for losing their families. But David makes himself strong by trusting Yahweh, David's God. In this dangerous and confusing time, David turns to Yahweh, who gives David strength. This kind of strength means peace, confidence, and courage, not physical strength.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do the people in your people group talk about the part of a person that has emotions, thoughts, and feelings? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do people in your people group show their unhappiness to the leaders when they blame the leaders when something bad or tragic happens? Could you tell a story of when this happened? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do you become strong again by trusting Yahweh when something hard or difficult happens in your life? What do you do to turn to Yahweh, and how does Yahweh give you peace? What do people who follow other gods do to receive peace and encouragement from these gods? Pause this audio here.

David asks Abiathar the priest, Ahimelech's son, to bring David the ephod so Abiathar can ask Yahweh what to do. Abiathar has been with David since he fled from Nob. Abiathar is now the rightful high priest, and Abiathar brings the ephod. The ephod is a piece of priestly clothing that contains the Urim and Thummim, two objects the high priest uses to ask Yahweh for guidance. David asks Yahweh through the ephod, "Should I chase the group of raiders? Will I catch them?" David wants to know if David can catch the raiders if David goes after the raiders. Yahweh answers and tells David to chase the raiders. Yahweh promises that David will catch the raiders and rescue the women and children.

David leads his 600 men to Besor Brook, a large stream in the wilderness of western Negev. In the rainy season, the brook is 100 to 150 meters wide and carries water to the Mediterranean Sea. But in the dry season, the brook has no water and its sides are steep, so people sometimes call the brook Besor Valley or Besor Gorge. Two hundred of David's men are too tired to cross the valley, so the men stay behind on the other side. David and the other 400 men cross Besor Valley and keep chasing the Amalekites.

Stop here and, as a group, look at the map. Locate Brook Besor. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: We do not know if there was water in this valley at this time. In any case, it would have been difficult to cross. How do you cross a steep valley, a brook, or a river in your area? Pause this audio here.

David's men find an Egyptian man in a field while they are traveling through the wilderness. David's men bring the Egyptian man to David and give the man some bread to eat and water to drink. Here, "bread" may just mean food in general. The men also give the Egyptian man a piece of fig cake and two cakes of raisins. Figs and raisins are common for travellers to carry because they are filling and nutritious. A fig cake is dried figs that people press into a round shape, and cakes of raisins are chunks of dried grapes. The Egyptian man eats the food, and it makes the man feel better. The man had not eaten or drunk anything for three days.

Stop here and, as a group, look at pictures of figs and raisins, fig cakes and raisin cakes. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What kind of food do people in your people group carry with them when travelling? What food do people consider to be nutritious and long-lasting? Talk about a time when you ate food like that and felt better. Pause this audio here.

David asks the Egyptian man who his master is and where the man comes from. David likely guesses from the man's clothes that the man is a slave. The man says he is a young Egyptian and a servant, or slave, to an Amalekite master. Most servants had no choice and were like slaves, unable to leave or get paid. Instead, the servants' masters gave them food, clothes, and shelter. It is unclear if the Egyptian became a slave through war, if someone bought the Egyptian, or if the Egyptian was born a slave. The Egyptian tells David that three days ago, the Egyptian got sick, and his Amalekite master left the Egyptian to die in the countryside because the Egyptian was too weak to travel. That is why the Egyptian had not eaten or drunk anything for three days.

The young Egyptian tells David that before his Amalekite master abandoned the Egyptian, the Amalekites raided four places: the Negev of the Kerethites, the territory of Judah, the Negev of Caleb, and the city of Ziklag, which they burned down. All four places were in the Negev wilderness, a big dry wilderness that mostly belonged to the tribe of Judah. Yahweh promised the Negev Wilderness to Israel, but other people groups still lived there. The Negev of the Kerethites was where the Kerethites lived. The territory of Judah refers to the part of the Negev Wilderness where people from the tribe of Judah lived, close to the Negev of the Kerethites. The Amalekites probably raided the Negev of the Kerethites and then went into the land where people from the tribe of Judah lived. This does not mean the Amalekites took over all of Judah's land or raided every town, just certain areas. The Negev of Caleb was where Caleb's family lived. Caleb was one of the 12 spies Moses sent to explore Canaan. Yahweh gave Caleb Hebron in southern Judah. Caleb's family stayed near Hebron after Caleb died. The Amalekites raided both Israelite and non-Israelite lands. Ziklag was probably the farthest west the Amalekites went, and the Amalekites set Ziklag on fire.

Stop here and, as a group, look at the map. Identify the areas the Amalekites raided. Pause this audio here.

David asks the Egyptian if the Egyptian can guide David to the raiders. David says, "Will you take me down to this band of raiders?" Since the wilderness is mountainous, David likely wants the Egyptian to lead David from the hills down to the valley where the Amalekites are staying. David calls the Amalekites "a band of raiders," meaning the Amalekites are thieves, not an army. The Egyptian agrees to help but only if David promises not to kill the Egyptian or send the Egyptian back to his Amalekite master. The Egyptian asks David to swear before God to keep David's promise. Swearing before God means to make a serious promise, an oath, with God as a witness. People swear like this to convince others that they are not lying.

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 30:1–15 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has eight scenes.

In the first scene: While David and his men are away, the Amalekites attack the city of Ziklag and other parts of the Negev wilderness. The Amalekites conquer and burn down the city of Ziklag. The Amalekites take the women and children from the city of Ziklag and make the people go with the Amalekites.

In the second scene: David and his men leave King Achish near Aphek, and the men reach Ziklag on the third day. David and David's men find that the Amalekites destroyed the men's city by fire and took their wives, sons, and daughters captive.

In the third scene: When David and David's men see that the Amalekites took their families, the men mourn and cry loudly until they are too weak to cry anymore.

In the fourth scene: David is in big trouble because the men in David's army talk about stoning David to kill him. David's men feel deeply upset, and they blame David for losing their families. But David makes himself strong by trusting Yahweh, David's God.

In the fifth scene: David asks Abiathar the priest to bring David the ephod so he can ask Yahweh what to do. Abiathar brings the ephod, and David asks Yahweh if he can catch the raiders if David goes after the raiders. Yahweh answers and tells David to chase the raiders and promises that David will catch the raiders and rescue the women and children.

In the sixth scene: David leads his 600 men to Besor Brook, a large stream in the wilderness of western Negev. Two hundred of David's men are too tired to cross, so they stay behind by the brook. David and the other 400 men cross Besor Brook and keep chasing the Amalekites.

In the seventh scene: David's men find an Egyptian man in a field. The men bring the Egyptian to David and give the man some food, which strengthens the man. The man had not eaten or drunk anything for three days. David finds out that the young Egyptian is a servant or slave to an Amalekite master. Three days before, the Egyptian had gotten sick, and the Egyptian's Amalekite master left him alone in the countryside to die.

In the eighth scene: The young Egyptian tells David that before his Amalekite master abandoned him, the Amalekites raided four places: the Negev of the Kerethites, the Negev of Judah, the Negev of Caleb, and the city of Ziklag, which the Amalekites burned down. David asks the Egyptian if he can guide David to the raiders. The Egyptian agrees to take David to the raiders but only if David promises not to kill the Egyptian or send him back to his Amalekite master. The Egyptian asks David to swear before God that David will keep David's promise.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The Amalekite raiders

  • Women and children from Ziklag who are the wives and children of David and David's men

  • David

  • David's men

  • David's wife, Ahinoam, of Jezreel

  • David's wife, Abigail, the widow of Nabal

  • And the young Egyptian

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

This passage begins when David and his men come back to Ziklag and find that the Amalekites have raided Ziklag. Here we are retelling the story chronologically as it happened.

While David and his men are away, the Amalekites attack the city of Ziklag and the Negev wilderness in the southern part of the territory of the tribe of Judah. The Amalekites conquer and burn down the city of Ziklag, probably without a fight, since David and David's men are away.

The Amalekites take the women and everyone in the city, "both small and great," as prisoners. "Both small and great" probably means people of all ages and importance. The Amalekites capture everyone, whether young or old, important or not, but they do not kill anyone. Instead, they force the people from Ziklag to go with them, probably to the countryside where no one lives.

After David and David's men leave King Achish near Aphek, they reach Ziklag on the third day. The storyteller counted the day they left as the first day. The men arrived two full days later, on the third day. The men would have walked between 125 and 145 kilometres. When David and his men arrive, the men find that the Amalekites destroyed their city by fire and took their wives, sons, and daughters captive. Among those the Amalekites captured are David's two wives, Ahinoam from Jezreel and Abigail, who was once married to Nabal from the village of Carmel in the territory of the tribe of Judah.

Stop here and look at the map. Identify the journey that David and his men took from Aphek to Ziklag. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: How do you count days in your culture? Pause this audio here.

When David and his men see that the Amalekites took their families, the men mourn and cry loudly until they are too weak to cry anymore.

Now David is in big trouble because the men in David's army talk about stoning David to kill David. The men feel bitter in their souls, which means that the men feel deeply upset. The men blame David for losing their families. But David makes himself strong by trusting Yahweh, David's God. In this dangerous and confusing time, David turns to Yahweh, who gives David strength, which here means peace, confidence, and courage, not physical strength.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do you talk in your language about crying so much? What do you say when someone is deeply upset or feels bitter in their spirit? Pause this audio here.

David asks Abiathar the priest, the son of Ahimelech, to bring David the ephod so David can ask Yahweh what to do. Abiathar brings the ephod. The ephod was a piece of the high priest's clothing. The storyteller may not mean that Abiathar brought the piece of clothing. Instead, the ephod symbolises the Urim and the Thummim, the two objects the priest used to discover Yahweh's will, which were inside the ephod. David asks Yahweh if David can catch the raiders if David goes after them. Yahweh tells David to chase the raiders and promises that David will catch the raiders and rescue the women and children.

David leads his 600 men to Besor Brook or valley, a large stream in the wilderness of western Negev. Besor Brook is about 19 to 21 kilometers from Ziklag, and in the rainy season, the brook is 100 to 150 meters wide. In the dry season, this brook has no water, but the sides are very steep. Two hundred of David's men are too tired to cross the brook, so these men stay behind by the valley. It is likely that the brook had at least some water in it and was a good place to rest and recover. David and the other 400 men cross Besor Brook and keep chasing the Amalekites.

Stop here and, as a group, look at the map. Locate Besor Brook. Pause this audio here.

David's men find an Egyptian man in a field while they are traveling through the wilderness. The men bring the Egyptian to David and give the man some bread to eat and water to drink. The word bread may mean food in general. The men also give the Egyptian a piece of fig cake and two cakes of raisins. The Egyptian man eats the food, and the food makes the man feel better. The story says the man's spirit returns to him, which means the Egyptian feels stronger, not that he died and came back to life. The Egyptian man had not eaten or drunk anything for three days.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What words do you have in your language that mean food in general? Decide which word will work best here. Will you use a word for bread or a word for food in general? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What do you say to show that someone who was very weak has regained their strength? Pause this audio here.

David asks the Egyptian man who the man's master is and where the Egyptian comes from. The man says that he is a young Egyptian and a servant, or slave, to an Amalekite master. The Egyptian tells David that three days ago, the Egyptian got sick, and his Amalekite master left him alone in the countryside to die because the Egyptian was not strong enough to travel. That is why the man had not eaten or drunk anything for three days.

The young Egyptian tells David that before his Amalekite master abandoned him, the Amalekites raided four places: the Negev of the Kerethites, the Negev of Judah, the Negev of Caleb, and the city of Ziklag, which the Amalekites burned down. All four places were in the Negev, a big dry wilderness that mostly belonged to the tribe of Judah.

Stop here and, as a group, look at the map. Identify the areas that the Amalekites raided. Pause this audio here.

David asks the Egyptian if the man can guide David to the raiders. David calls the Amalekites "a band of raiders," meaning they are people who steal, not an army. The Egyptian agrees to take David to the raiders but only if David promises not to kill the Egyptian or send him back to his Amalekite master. The Egyptian asks David to swear before God that David will keep his promise.

Stop here and, as a group, talk about what word or phrase you will use to describe the band or raiders to show that they are not an army but people who steal.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 30:1–15 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has eight scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The Amalekite raiders

  • Women and children from Ziklag who are the wives and children of David and David's men

  • David

  • David's men

  • David's wife, Ahinoam, of Jezreel

  • David's wife, Abigail, the widow of Nabal

  • And the young Egyptian

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

While David and his men are away, the Amalekites attack the city of Ziklag and other parts of the Negev wilderness. The Amalekites conquer and burn down the city of Ziklag. The Amalekites take the women and children from the city of Ziklag and make the people go with the Amalekites.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the women, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We feel very scared! The raiders burned our city and are taking us and our children away; or

  • We feel angry and disappointed that our husbands are not here to protect us; or

  • We are hoping and trusting that Yahweh will save us and keep us safe.

After leaving King Achish near Aphek, David and his men reach Ziklag on the third day. The men find that the Amalekites destroyed their city by fire and took their wives, sons, and daughters captive.

Having seen that the Amalekites took their families, David and his men mourn and cry loudly until they are too weak to cry anymore.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David's men, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We feel heartbroken that the Amalekites have kidnapped our wives and our children; or

  • We feel hopeless. What can we now do? Our wives and children are probably very far away now; or

  • We feel so scared. Will the Amalekite raiders keep our wives and children alive? or

  • We regret following David! It is because of David that the Amalekites stole our wives and children.

David is in big trouble because the men in his army talk about stoning David to kill him. David's men feel deeply upset, and they blame David for losing their families. But David makes himself strong by trusting Yahweh, David's God.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am scared. The men blame me for the loss of their families, and the men want to stone me! or

  • I feel so sad that I let my men down. What can we do? I do not know where the women and children are; or

  • I feel hopeful. I can and I will trust Yahweh. That is the only solution I have. I will ask Yahweh what to do.

David asks Abiathar the priest to bring David the ephod so David can ask Yahweh what to do. Abiathar brings the ephod and David asks Yahweh if David can catch the raiders if David goes after them. Yahweh answers and tells David to chase the raiders and promises that David will catch them and rescue the women and children.

David leads his 600 men to Besor Brook, a large stream in the wilderness of western Negev. Two hundred of David's men are too tired to cross, so they stay behind by the brook. David and the other 400 men cross Besor Brook and keep chasing the Amalekites.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David's men, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We trust David again. Yahweh told David that we will catch up with the raiding party! or

  • We are desperate to free our wives and children. We must leave behind two hundred of our men who are too tired to cross the brook; or

  • We have renewed hope in seeing our families again.

David's men find an Egyptian man in a field while they are traveling through the wilderness. The men bring the Egyptian to David and give the man some bread to eat and water to drink. The men also give the Egyptian a piece of fig cake and two cakes of raisins. The Egyptian man eats the food, and it makes him feel better. The Egyptian had not eaten or drunk anything for three days. David finds out that the young Egyptian is a slave to an Amalekite master. Three days before, the Egyptian had gotten sick, and the Egyptian's Amalekite master had left the Egyptian alone in the countryside to die.

The young Egyptian tells David that before his Amalekite master abandoned him, the Amalekites raided four places: the Negev of the Kerethites, the Negev of Judah, the Negev of Caleb, and the city of Ziklag, which the Amalekites burned down. David asks the Egyptian if he can guide David to the raiders. The Egyptian agrees to take David to the raiders but only if David promises not to kill the Egyptian or send him back to his Amalekite master. The Egyptian asks David to swear before God that David will keep his promise.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the young Egyptian, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am grateful that David and his men saved me from dying in the wilderness; or

  • I am interested to know why David has saved me and did not leave me to die; or

  • I am happy to take these men to the Amalekite band or raiders, but I am worried that they will kill me or return me to my master; or

  • I will only help these men if David swears by his God that he will not return me to my master or kill me.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 30:1–15 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

David is in big trouble because the men in David's army talk about stoning David to kill him. David's men feel bitter in their souls, or very upset. The men blame David for losing their families. But David makes himself strong by trusting Yahweh, David's God.

God created people with bodies, and we can touch and see each other's bodies. But God also created people with thoughts and feelings and desires. We cannot see this part of a person, but we know it is there. This invisible part of a person is in the Bible usually called a soul. Even when our body dies, our soul may live on. David's men were bitter in their soul, which means that they were deeply upset.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for soul. Look up soul in the Master Glossary for more information. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Yahweh is God's personal name, and the story uses this name throughout this passage. David found strength in Yahweh, David's God. Use the same name for Yahweh and God that you have used in previous passages. For more information on Yahweh and God, refer to the Master Glossary.

David asks Abiathar the priest to bring David the ephod. Abiathar brings the ephod, and David asks Yahweh if David can catch the raiders if David goes after the raiders. The ephod is a piece of priestly clothing that contains the Urim and Thummim, two objects the high priest uses to ask Yahweh for guidance. In this story, the ephod probably symbolizes the way that the priest asks Yahweh for guidance. Use the same words or phrases for priest and ephod as you used in previous passages. For more information on priest and ephod, refer to the Master Glossary.

David and 400 of David's men cross the Besor Brook, valley, or gorge. This valley is full of water in the rainy season but dry at other times of the year. In any case, the brook is difficult to cross.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What will you call a steep valley like this that is full of water in the rainy season and dry at other times of the year? If you have already translated this kind of valley or gorge in another book of the Bible, use the same word here that you used there. Pause this audio here.

David's men find an Egyptian man in a field. The men bring this man to David and give the man a piece of fig cake and two cakes of raisins. This strengthens the man, as the man had not eaten or drunk anything for three days.

Stop here and, as a group, look at pictures of figs and raisins, fig cakes and raisin cakes. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for fig cake and raisin cake. If you have already translated these words in another book of the Bible, use the same words that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

David finds out that the young Egyptian is a servant, or slave, to an Amalekite master.

Use the same word or phrase for servant and master as you used in previous passages. For more information on servant and master, refer to the Master Glossary.

The Egyptian slave asks David to swear, or promise with an oath, that David will not kill the slave or give him back to his master. Although the storyteller does not use the word oath, you should talk about this strong promise in a similar way to how you have talked about people giving oaths before. See the Master Glossary for more information about oaths.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.

title: 1 Samuel 30:16–31
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 30:16–31 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 30:16–31 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 30:16–31 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous passage, David and his men return to Ziklag and find the Amalekites have burned their city and taken the men's families. David and his men are very sad, but the men blame David. After Yahweh promises that David will catch the raiders, David and his men chase the Amalekites. David and his men meet a young Egyptian slave whose Amalekite master left the Egyptian behind. The Egyptian agrees to lead David to the raiders.

The young Egyptian leads David and David's men to the Amalekites. David sees that the Amalekites are not a strong, organized army. The Amalekites are spread out all over the land in a disorganised way. The Amalekites cannot protect themselves and are unable to move or escape quickly. The Amalekites have likely been there for days, and celebrated with food, strong drinks, and dancing. The Amalekites are having a big festival because they stole a large amount from the Philistines and from the descendants of Judah. The Amalekites may even be holding a ceremony to thank their god for their success during the raid.

David and his men attack the Amalekites. The men fight from twilight until the evening of the next day. "Twilight" is either the dim light before sunrise or after sunset, but most scholars believe that here twilight refers to the time just before sunrise. For the Israelites, a new day began at sunset, so "evening of the next day" refers to the evening after the battle. This means the Israelites likely fight throughout the daylight hours of that day and finish in the evening after sunset. David's army defeats the Amalekites, and no man escapes except 400 young men. These men manage to escape on camels, which are large desert animals with a hump on their backs. David and his men either kill or capture the rest of the Amalekite raiders.

Stop here and look at a picture of a camel as a group. Pause this audio here

David gets back everyone and everything the Amalekites took, including David's two wives. Nothing is missing. The Amalekites did not kill or take anyone away. David and his men save everyone, both small and great, as well as the sons and daughters of David's men. David also gets back all the things the Amalekites stole. David brings everything back. David's mission is a complete success.

David also takes back all the flocks and herds from the Amalekites. The Amalekites likely stole these animals from the Kerethites and Philistines. Flocks include groups of smaller animals like sheep and goats, while herds include groups of larger animals like oxen and cattle. These animals are different from the ones David's men already owned and recovered. David's men drive the flocks and herds in front of their own cattle and declare that these animals now belong to David. David's men want to thank and reward David for leading the men to victory.

Stop here and look at a picture of a flock of sheep as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of a flock of goats as a group. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a picture of a herd of oxen and cattle as a group. Pause this audio here.

On the way back to Ziklag, David stops at Besor Brook. David is traveling with his men, the men's families, their cattle, and the plunder. At Besor Brook, David meets the 200 men David had left behind because those men were too weak and tired to march to the battle. The men go out to welcome David and the people with David. As David gets closer to the 200 men, David greets the men warmly. David speaks to the men in a friendly way and shows David is not angry with the men.

Stop here and discuss as a group: How do people in your culture say hello to each other? Share some formal and informal ways to greet someone. Also, explain how you would greet someone if you were happy with that person and how you would greet someone if you were not happy with them. Pause this audio here.

Some of the 400 men who fought the Amalekites with David are selfish troublemakers. These men complain to David and the others who went to battle. The men say the 200 men who stayed behind at Besor Brook did not help fight, so the troublemakers do not want to share the valuable plunder with those men. The plunder includes animals, and probably items like clothing, jewels, and precious metals. The troublemakers say the men at Besor Brook should only get their wives and children back and leave. The troublemakers want the 200 men to go away while the fighters divide the plunder and celebrate the victory.

But David answers the troublemakers, "No, you will not do that, my brothers, with what Yahweh has given us." David says it would be wrong to act selfishly when Yahweh has been so generous to the men. David calls the troublemakers "brothers" to show that even though David disagrees, David is still their friend and on their side. David insists the men must include the 200 men when they divide the plunder. David reminds the troublemakers that it was Yahweh who gave David and the men the victory over the Amalekites, and gave the plunder and the men's families back. David wants his men to be compassionate and generous, just as Yahweh has been compassionate and generous to the men.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Make up a story about someone who wants to behave in a way that is selfish and not honourable to others. What will you say to that person if you are someone in authority? What will you say to that person if you are just that person's friend? Pause this audio here.

David asks the troublemakers a question that does not require an answer: "Who would listen to you in this matter?" David makes a strong point that no one would agree with the men's idea because the idea is wrong. David tells the men that no good person would support the men's idea and to stop talking this way. Then, David makes a new rule for dividing plunder. David compares the men who fought with those who stayed behind to guard supplies. Since the 200 men at Besor Brook helped with the victory because they guarded the supplies, David says everyone will get the same share. The fighters will not get more, and the guards of supplies will not get less. This rule will apply in the future, so guards of supplies will always get a share. Each man's portion will be equal, even if the items are different, like cattle, valuables, clothing, and metals.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Talk about times in life when someone shares things, like goods or rewards, equally among people who do different jobs. Can you think of examples where people work as a team, but not everyone does the same task? Should everyone get the same amount, or should some people get more? Why? Pause this audio here.

The writer of 1 Samuel now shares some background information. David made what he had just told his men into a general law or rule for everyone. This rule began after David's victory over the Amalekites and continued until the time the storyteller told this story.

Then David, his men, and their families return to Ziklag, the city the Philistines gave to David. David takes some of the plunder and sends it as gifts to the elders of the tribe of Judah. These elders were friendly with David, and David wants to show the elders kindness and strengthen their friendship. David probably visited these elders in the past and wants to thank them. David possibly knows that one day, David will need these elders as allies. David only sends the gifts to a specific group of people, who are important elders who are also David's friends. David likely gives the gifts to David's men to deliver, along with a message that says, "Look! Here is a gift for you from the plunder we took from the enemies of Yahweh." David calls the Amalekites the enemies of Yahweh because the Amalekites were enemies of the Israelites, who were God's people. David believes that anyone who fights against Yahweh's people is also an enemy of Yahweh.

Now David distributes the plunder among a number of large and small cities near Hebron. David sends some of the plunder to the elders or leaders who live in the cities of Bethel, Ramoth in the Negev, and Jattir. The Bethel here is a different Bethel from the one in the territory of the tribe of Benjamin. This Bethel is near the cities of Hormah and Ziklag. The city Ramoth was in the Negev, which was a wilderness in the south. Both Bethel and Ramoth of the Negev are in the territory of the tribe of Simeon, whose land originally belonged to the tribe of Judah. Jattir was a city for the priests of Israel, and the tribe of Levi lived here.

David sends some of the plunder to the elders or leaders who live in the cities of Aroer, Siphmoth, and Eshtemoa. Eshtemoa was a city for the priests of Israel, and the tribe of Levi lived here.

David sends some of the plunder to the elders or leaders who live in the city of Rakal, and cities belonging to the Jerahmeelite clan and the cities belonging to the Kenite clan. The elders of Racal and the Jerahmeelites were Israelites, but the Kenite elders were not. However, since some Kenites lived among the Israelites, the Kenites may have been allies of the Israelites.

David sends some of the plunder to the elders or leaders who live in the cities of Hormah, Bor Ashan, and Athak. Bor Ashan means "Well of Ashan." Hormah and Bor Ashan were in the territory of the tribe of Simeon, whose land originally belonged to the tribe of Judah.

David sends some of the plunder to the elders or leaders who live in the city of Hebron, and to the elders in all the other places David and David's men visited. Hebron was a very important city. Abraham built an altar to Yahweh in Hebron. Hebron was a city of refuge and a city for the priests of Israel, and the tribe of Levi lived there. Hebron was 30 kilometres southeast of Jerusalem.

Stop here and, as a group, look at the map and locate the cities near Hebron where David sent gifts of the plunder. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: Talk about situations when the leaders of your people group sent gifts to the neighbouring countries. Why did your leaders send gifts? What kind of gifts were there?

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 30:16–31 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has ten scenes.

In the first scene: The young Egyptian takes David and his men down to where the Amalekites are. The Amalekites are celebrating because the Amalekites stole a large amount of goods from the Philistines' land and from the descendants of Judah.

In the second scene: David and his men attack the Amalekites. David's army defeats the Amalekites, with no man escaping except 400 young men who rode on camels to escape.

In the third scene: David gets back everyone and everything the Amalekites took, including David's two wives. David also gets back all the things the Amalekites stole and takes as plunder all the flocks and herds that the Amalekites likely stole from others earlier.

In the fourth scene: On the way back to Ziklag, David stops at Besor Brook and meets the 200 men he had left behind. The men go out to welcome David and the people with David, and David greets the men warmly.

In the fifth scene: Some fighters who went to battle with David are selfish troublemakers. These men complain to David and say that the men who stayed behind should not get any plunder because they did not help fight the Amalekites. The troublemakers say those men should only get their wives and children back and then leave.

In the sixth scene: David says it would be wrong to act selfishly when Yahweh has been so generous to all the men, and David insists they must share plunder with the 200 men at Besor Brook.

In the seventh scene: David makes a strong point that what the troublemakers are suggesting is wrong. David makes a new general rule about dividing the plunder. Those who stay with the supplies will get the same share of the plunder as those who fight in the battle.

In the eighth scene: The writer of 1 Samuel now shares some background information. David made what David had just told his men into a general law or rule for everyone. This rule began after David's victory over the Amalekites and stayed in place until the time of the writing of this story.

In the ninth scene: David, David's men, and their families all return to Ziklag. David takes some of the plunder and sends it as gifts to the elders of the tribe of Judah, but only to those who were also David's friends.

In the tenth scene: The passage lists the large and small cities near Hebron to which David sends the plunder as gifts.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The young Egyptian

  • David

  • The Amalekites

  • David's men—the story does not mention the men at this point, but we know they are with David

  • Families of David and David's men, including David's two wives

  • Two hundred of David's men who stayed at Besor Brook

  • The troublemakers—some of David's men who went to battle against the Amalekites

  • The rest of David's men who went to battle against the Amalekites

  • And the elders of cities in Judah who were also David's friends

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

After David talks with the young Egyptian, the Egyptian leads David and David's men down to where the Amalekites are. The storyteller now uses a phrase that shows that David and his men finally see the men they have been searching for. The storyteller says, "Look! There they are." The men are spread out all over the land in a disorganized way. The Amalekites have probably been there for a few days and have set up camp. The Amalekites are celebrating, eating good food, drinking strong drinks, and dancing together. The Amalekites are having a big festival because they stole a large amount of goods from the Philistines' land and from the people of Judah.

David and his men attack the Amalekites. We do not know if David and his men attack right away or if the men wait in hiding to attack later. When David and his men do attack, the men rush in and defeat the Amalekites. The men fight from twilight until the evening of the next day. "Twilight" in the original language can mean either the dim light before sunrise or after sunset, but most scholars believe that here twilight refers to the time just before sunrise. Therefore, the men likely fight throughout the daylight hours of that day and finish the battle after sunset, since for the Israelites a new day began at sunset. David's army defeats the Amalekites, and no man escapes except 400 young men who manage to get away on camels. David and his men either kill or capture the rest of the Amalekite raiders.

Stop here and discuss as a group: Some words can mean more than one thing, like the word "twilight" in this story. Talk about words in your language that have more than one meaning. How do you make sure people understand what you mean when you use those words? Pause this audio here.

David, with the help of David's men, recovers everything the Amalekites have taken, including David's two wives. The word "everything" refers to both people and things. Nothing is missing. David and his men save everyone, both small and great, as well as the sons and daughters of the men. "Small and great" likely means people of all ages and importance. David also gets back all the things the Amalekites stole. David brings everything back. David's mission is a complete success.

Now the storyteller introduces a different group of things that David and his men take back from the Amalekites. The passage mentions David alone to focus on what David achieves as a leader, but we know David's men are with David. David also takes back all the flocks and herds that the Amalekites had stolen earlier from the Kerethites and Philistines. David now keeps those flocks and herds for David's own people. David's men drive the flocks and herds that David takes as plunder in front of the other livestock or cattle that belonged to David and his men. David's men place the flocks and herds at the front, leading their cattle behind them. The men say that the flocks and herds now belong to David. The men want to thank and reward David for leading the men to victory.

On the way back to Ziklag, David returns the way he came and stops at Besor Brook.

David is traveling with his men, their families, their cattle, and the plunder. At Besor Brook, David meets the 200 men he had left behind because they were too weak and tired to march to the battle. The 200 men see David, his men, and the women and children coming, and they go out to welcome David and the people with David. As David gets closer to the 200 men, David greets the men warmly.

This next part is very different from what just happened. David greets the 200 men at Besor Brook in a friendly way, but some evil men, or selfish troublemakers from among those who went to battle, now act unkindly toward these men. The word "evil" here does not mean these men are dangerous criminals or always bad, but that these men are acting selfishly and without kindness. These men are causing problems. These men insist that the 200 men do not deserve any of the plunder because they did not join the raid. The troublemakers say the 200 men can only take their wives and children and then leave.

But David answers the troublemakers, "No, you will not do that, my brothers, with what Yahweh has given us." David says it would be wrong to act selfishly when Yahweh has been so generous to all the men. David calls the troublemakers "brothers" to show that even though David disagrees, David is still their friend and on their side. David insists they must include the 200 men and not divide the plunder only among the 400 fighters. David reminds the troublemakers that it was Yahweh who gave David and the men the plunder and their families back. It was Yahweh who delivered into the fighters' hand, or handed over to them, the band of Amalekite raiders.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What do you say in your language when you want to show you are supporting someone, or want to show kindness? What words do you use when you are upset with someone or want to show you do not agree with them? Talk about how the words you choose can show how you feel about a person. How do you decide which words to use?

Pause this audio here.

David asks the troublemakers a question that does not need an answer: "Who would listen to you in this matter?" David makes a strong point that no one would agree to do what the troublemakers are suggesting because it is wrong. The word "listen" here means both hearing what the troublemakers are saying and agreeing to do it. Now David makes a new rule about dividing the plunder. David says, "The share of the man who stayed with the supplies is to be the same as that of him who went down to the battle." This is a general rule or principle that will apply to all similar situations. It does not refer to one man. All the soldiers will get fair and equal portions of the plunder.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What do you say when you want everyone to know that a rule is not just for one time but for every time something similar happens? Can you think of examples of when someone made a general rule, like at school, at home, or in your community? How did the person explain that the rule was for more than just one time? Pause this audio here.

David is not speaking anymore. The storyteller of 1 Samuel now shares some background information. David made what David had just told his men into a general law or rule for everyone. This rule began after David's victory over the Amalekites and stayed in place until the storyteller wrote this story.

The story now shows that this part happens later. David, David's men, and their families all return to Ziklag. David is not the only one to return, but since David is the leader, the story mentions David by name. When they arrive, David takes some of the plunder and sends it as gifts to the elders of the tribe of Judah, but only to those who are also David's friends. David likely gives the gifts to his men to deliver, along with a message, saying, "Look! Here is a gift for you from the plunder we took from the enemies of Yahweh." The message draws attention to the gifts David is sending to each elder. The word that many people translate as "gift" in the original language means blessing. David distributes the plunder among a number of large and small cities near Hebron. David sends some of the plunder to the elders or leaders who live in the cities of Bethel, Ramoth in the Negev, and Jattir.

David sends some of the plunder to the elders or leaders who live in the cities of Aroer, Siphmoth, and Eshtemoa.

David sends some of the plunder to the elders or leaders who live in the city of Rakal, and cities belonging to the Jerahmeelite clan and cities belonging to the Kenite clan.

David sends some of the plunder to the elders or leaders who live in the cities of Hormah, Bor Ashan, and Athak.

David sends some of the plunder to the elders or leaders who live in the city of Hebron, and elders in all the other places David and David's men visited.

Stop here and, as a group, look at the map and locate the cities near Hebron where David sent gifts of the plunder. Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 30:16–31 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has ten scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • The young Egyptian

  • David

  • The Amalekites

  • David's men—the story does not mention the men at this point, but we know they are with David

  • Families of David and David's men, including David's two wives

  • Two hundred of David's men who stayed at Besor Brook

  • The troublemakers—some of David's men who went to battle against the Amalekites

  • The rest of David's men who went to battle against the Amalekites

  • And the elders of cities in Judah who were also David's friends

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

The young Egyptian takes David and David's men down to where the Amalekites are. David sees that the Amalekites are spread out all over the land and are celebrating—eating good food, drinking strong drinks, and dancing together. The Amalekites are having a big festival because they stole a huge amount of goods from the Philistines' land and from the descendants of Judah.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel grateful that Yahweh helped us to find the Amalekites; or

  • We will now be able to rescue our wives and children! or

  • I expect to conquer the Amalekites because Yahweh told us we will succeed.

David and his men attack the Amalekites. The men fight from twilight throughout the daylight hours of that day. David's army defeats the Amalekites, with no man escaping except 400 young men who ride away on camels to escape.

David gets back everyone and everything the Amalekites took, including David's two wives. David also gets back all the things the Amalekites stole. David also takes as plunder all the flocks and herds that the Amalekites stole from others earlier. David's men drive the flocks and herds in front of the other livestock that belonged to David and his men. The men say that the flocks and herds now belong to David.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David's men, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are so happy! We have our wives and children back! or

  • We recovered everything! or

  • David is a good and brave leader.

On the way back to Ziklag, David stops at Besor Brook and meets the 200 men he had left behind because they were too weak and tired to march to the battle. The men go out to welcome David and the people with David. As David gets closer to the 200 men, David greets the men warmly.

Some of the men who went to battle with David are selfish troublemakers. These men complain to David and say that the 200 men who stayed behind at Besor Brook should not get any plunder because they did not help fight the Amalekites. The troublemakers say the men at Besor should only get their wives and children back and then leave.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the troublemakers, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are bitter. We have worked hard and stayed loyal to David. We feel like we should get more than the weak men who stayed behind; or

  • We will not be happy if the lazy men who did not go to battle share in our spoils; or

  • Surely David and the other fighters will agree with us. The men from Besor Brook should just take their wives and children and go.

David replies to the troublemakers and says it would be wrong to act selfishly when Yahweh has been so generous to the men. David insists they must include the 200 men and not divide the loot only among the 400 fighters. David reminds the troublemakers that it was Yahweh who gave David and the men the plunder and their families back, and the victory over the Amalekites. David makes a strong point that no one would agree to do what the troublemakers are suggesting because it is wrong. Now David makes a new rule about dividing the plunder. The share of those who stay with the supplies is to be the same as those who go down to the battle. This is a general rule or principle that will apply to all similar situations. All the soldiers will get fair and equal portions of the plunder.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the 200 men who stayed at Besor Brook, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are relieved. David decided that we will share in the plunder the fighters brought from the Amalekites; or

  • We are happy the troublemakers did not get their way.

The storyteller of 1 Samuel now shares some background information. David made what he had just told his men into a general law or rule for everyone. This rule began after David's victory over the Amalekites and stayed in place until the time the storyteller told this story.

David, David's men, and their families all return to Ziklag. David takes some of the plunder and sends it as gifts to the elders of the tribe of Judah, but only to those who were also David's friends. David sends the gifts with a message, saying, "Look! Here is a blessing for you from the plunder we took from the enemies of Yahweh."

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing David, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I feel glad that we have all this plunder. I will send it as gifts to the elders who are my friends in some of the cities of the tribe of Judah; or

  • The Amalekites robbed those people, too; or

  • I will need the elders to be my allies when I am king of Israel. The gifts will help the elders remember me.

David distributes the plunder among a number of large and small cities near Hebron. David sends some of the plunder to the elders or leaders who live in the cities of Bethel, Ramoth in the Negev, and Jattir; the cities of Aroer, Siphmoth, and Eshtemoam; the city of Rakal, and cities belonging to the Jerahmeelite clan and the cities belonging to the Kenite clan; and the cities of Hormah, Bor Ashan, and Athak. David sends some of the plunder to the elders who live in the city of Hebron and elders in all the other places David and his men visited.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 30:16–31 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

David's army defeats the Amalekites. No man escapes except 400 young men who ride away on camels to escape. Use the same word or phrase for camel that you have used in previous passages.

After defeating the Amalekites, David also takes back all the flocks and herds from the Amalekites. Flocks include groups of smaller animals like sheep and goats, while herds include groups of larger animals like oxen and cattle. Use the same word or phrase for flocks that you have used in previous passages.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for herds. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

David's men drive the flocks and herds that David takes as plunder in front of the other livestock or cattle that belonged to David and his men. Use the same word or phrase for livestock that you have used in previous passages.

The evil men, or selfish troublemakers, complain to David and the others who went to battle. The troublemakers say the 200 men who stayed behind at Besor Brook did not help fight, so the troublemakers do not want to share the valuable plunder with those men. Use the same words or phrases for evil and plunder that you have used in previous passages. For more information on evil, refer to the Master Glossary.

David replies to the troublemakers and says it would be wrong to act selfishly when Yahweh has been so generous to them. Yahweh is God's personal name, and the storyteller uses this name throughout this passage. Use the same name for Yahweh that you have used in previous passages. For more information on Yahweh, refer to the Master Glossary.

David reminds the troublemakers that it was Yahweh who gave David and the men the plunder and their families back. It was Yahweh who delivered into their hand, or handed over to them, the band of Amalekite raiders. Use the same word or phrase for band of raiders, band, or raiding party that you have used in previous passages. Use the same word or phrase for "delivered into their hand" that you have used in previous passages.

David makes a rule that will continue for a long time in Israel. Use the same word for Israel that you have used previously, and remember that Israel is in the Master Glossary.

The storyteller calls this rule a statute and an ordinance. Both of these terms refer to special rules about how to live well together in the Israelite community. These words have similar meanings to each other, and you may choose to use just one term if you only have one term that would refer to a rule like this.

Stop here and discuss as a group what you will call this statute and ordinance. See the Master Glossary for statute and ordinance. Pause this audio here.

David likely gives the gifts to his men to deliver to several small and large cities, along with a message that says, "Look! Here is a gift for you from the plunder we took from the enemies of Yahweh." Use the same word for city that you have used in previous passages. Cities were usually larger settlements that people built a wall around for protection.

The word that many people translate as gift or present in the original language means blessing. You may call this a gift if you have a word or phrase for a good gift in your language. Or you may use the term for blessing, which also can mean a good gift. For more information on blessing, refer to the Master Glossary.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
