title: 1 Samuel 31:1–13
content:
Hear and Heart

Hear and Heart

In this step, hear 1 Samuel 31:1–13 and put it in your hearts.

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 31:1–13 three times, in three different translations, if possible.

Pause this audio here.

Now, as a group, discuss the following questions:

  1. What do you like in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  2. What do you not like or not understand in this passage? Pause this audio here.

  3. What does this passage tell us about God? Pause this audio here.

  4. What does this passage tell us about people? Pause this audio here.

  5. How does this passage affect our daily lives? Pause this audio here.

  6. Who do you know who needs to hear this passage?

Setting the Stage

Setting the Stage

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 31:1–13 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In the previous passage, David and David's men defeated the Amalekites and recovered everything the Amalekites stole from Ziklag. On the way back, some selfish men refused to share the plunder with those who stayed at brook Besor. David created a rule that everyone would receive an equal share, whether they fought or guarded the supplies. When David and his men returned to Ziklag, David sent plunder gifts to those elders of Judah near Hebron who were David's friends.

The story now goes back to when the Philistine army set up camp in Shunem and Saul gathered the Israelite army at Mount Gilboa, about 10 to 15 kilometres south of Shunem in the valley of Jezreel. This part of the story talks about the war between the Philistines and Israel, which the storyteller mentioned earlier. The storyteller had paused that battle story to tell us about David and David's men leaving the Philistine army, returning to Ziklag, and chasing the Amalekites to get back everything the Amalekites had stolen from them. The events in this story happen at the same time that David and his men are chasing the Amalekites.

Back in Jezreel, the Philistines fight against the Israelites on Mount Gilboa. The Philistines kill many Israelite soldiers, and the Israelite army starts to lose the battle. The Israelites must retreat. The Israelites, including King Saul and Saul's sons, run away quickly to save their lives. But the Philistines catch up to Saul and his sons and kill three of Saul's sons: Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malki-Shua. We know that Saul has another son, Ish-Bosheth, who survives, but we do not know if Ish-Bosheth was in the battle. The word "kill" here means to use a weapon, like a sword or spear, to strike someone and cause that person to die.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel. Locate Mount Gilboa, the place where the Israelites and the Philistines fought the battle. Pause this audio here.

The Philistines fight fiercely against Saul. After killing Saul's sons, the Philistines get close to where Saul is. The Philistines attack hard, fighting the men who are still with Saul, including Saul's bodyguard. Then the arrows from the archers hit Saul. The arrows wound Saul very badly. Saul is in severe pain from the arrows, and Saul cannot move easily. Saul's wounds are so bad that Saul's life is in danger, and Saul has no chance of escape.

Stop here and look as a group at a picture of an archer shooting arrows with a bow. Pause this audio here.

Then Saul asks Saul's armor-bearer to pull out the armor-bearer's sword and kill Saul by stabbing him. An armor-bearer is a young man who helps an older soldier or leader by carrying extra weapons and equipment. Saul wants his armor-bearer to kill Saul because Saul is afraid the Philistines will kill Saul slowly and painfully. Saul thinks it would be more shameful and painful if the Philistines killed Saul. Saul also worries the Philistines will mock Saul and hurt him for their own entertainment. Saul calls the Philistines "uncircumcised fellows," a negative term the Israelites used. The Israelites circumcised their sons as a sign of the Israelites' special agreement with God, and the Israelites looked down on uncircumcised men. The armor-bearer refuses to kill Saul because the armor-bearer is afraid to harm the king of Israel, whom God appointed. Since Saul's armor-bearer will not kill Saul, Saul pulls out his own sword and kills himself by falling on its point.

When the man who carried Saul's armour sees that Saul is dead—either by watching Saul kill himself or seeing Saul's dead body—the armor-bearer throws himself on the point of his own sword and kills himself. The armour-bearer dies with Saul. This means the armor-bearer dies at about the same time, in the same place, and in the same way as Saul.

In that way, Saul, three of Saul's sons, the young man who carried Saul's armour, and all of Saul's men die on that same day. "All of Saul's men" may refer to the men closest to Saul who surround Saul. It may also refer to Saul's household or to Saul's most loyal leaders who were protecting Saul. Saul and these people all died in the same battle on the same day.

The storyteller pauses the story about the battle between Israel and the Philistines to explain what happened after the Philistines won. The Israelite people who lived on the other side of the Jezreel Valley, and those who lived beyond the Jordan River, realised that the Israelite army had run away and that Saul and three of Saul's sons had died. The other side of the Jezreel Valley means the north side, which is also called the Plain of Jezreel. The "area beyond the Jordan" could mean either the east side of the Jordan River or the cities near the river on the west side.

When the Israelites in these areas saw or became aware of what had happened, they ran away from their cities quickly to live somewhere else. The Israelites did not destroy their homes or buildings, but just abandoned them. Then the Philistine soldiers and their families moved into the empty cities and lived there, and took control of the area.

Stop here and, as a group, look at a map of Israel and locate the area from where the Israelites ran away and which the Philistines took over. Pause this audio here.

The storyteller now goes back to the story of the battle. The day after the people fought, the Philistine soldiers go back to Mount Gilboa to take valuable things from the dead Israelite soldiers. The Philistines "strip the slain," which means the Philistines take weapons and armour from the Israelite soldiers they killed with swords. While doing this, the Philistines find Saul and Saul's three sons lying dead.

The Philistine soldiers cut off Saul's head and take off Saul's armour, including Saul's weapons. So the Philistines remove Saul's military clothes and the weapons Saul carried, like Saul's sword, shield, and spear. After this, the Philistines send men all over the land of Philistia to share the good news that Saul is dead and that the Philistines won the battle. These men possibly carry Saul's weapons and armour as proof of victory. The Philistine messengers announce the good news in the temples, which are houses where Philistines worship their idols. An idol is an object that people make in order to worship a god. The Philistine men also share the news with the Philistine people, possibly in public places like markets or smaller worship areas. The news spreads quickly from person to person and from town to town throughout the land of Philistia.

Stop here and look as a group at pictures of the kinds of armour and weapons that Saul may have had. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group how people in your community in the past shared news that affected the whole nation, whether good or bad news. Then, discuss how people share important news now. Pause this audio here.

The Philistines put Saul's armour and weapons in the temple of their goddess that people called Ashtoreth. The temple of the Ashtoreths was a building where people worshipped the Ashtoreth idols, or representations of the goddess Ashtoreth. Ashtoreth was the Philistines' most important goddess, and Ashtoreth was the goddess of love and war. The Philistines place Saul's armor and weapons in the temple to try to show their goddess' power. The Philistines also hang Saul's dead body on the outer wall of one of their cities called Beth Shan, but we do not know how the Philistines hang the body. The Philistines hang Saul's body to insult both Saul and the Israelites. In those times, it was very important to bury a person's body with respect. When someone did not have a proper burial, people saw it as very shameful. Beth Shan was about 11 miles from Mount Gilboa, where people fought the battle. Beth Shan was an important city where roads from the Jordan Valley and the Jezreel Valley came together. The city had a large stone wall for protection.

Stop here and, as a group, talk about burial customs in your people group. What would people consider to be a respectful burial? What practices would people consider as shameful? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and, as a group, look at a map of Israel and locate the city of Beth Shan. Pause this audio here.

But when the people in the city of Jabesh Gilead hear the news about how the Philistines insulted Saul's dead body, all the brave warriors from Jabesh Gilead decide to leave their city and travel all night to the city of Beth Shan. Jabesh is in the region of Gilead, on the east side of the Jordan River, about 32 kilometers from Beth Shan. The people of Jabesh are Israelites. The people feel thankful to Saul because Saul saved them from the Ammonites in the past. The brave warriors take Saul's dead body and the bodies of Saul's sons down from the wall of Beth Shan. The warriors carry the bodies back to Jabesh and burn the bodies. Burning bodies was not something the Israelites usually did, and no one knows why the people burned the bodies this time.

Afterwards, the warriors gather the burned bones and bury them under a tamarisk tree in Jabesh. A tamarisk tree is tall, growing up to 18 meters, with needle-like leaves and small pink or white flowers. This tree was likely famous in Jabesh. The people bury the bones there to honour Saul and Saul's sons. Then the people of Jabesh fast, or stop eating, for seven days. Fasting was a traditional way to mourn someone's death. The people fast to honour Saul and show their sadness because Saul had died.

Stop here and, as a group, look at a map of Israel and locate the city of Jabesh in Gilead. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and, as a group, look at a picture of a tamarisk tree. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are the burial customs in your people group? What do people do to honour the dead person? Talk about the burial of a special person in your people group who people honoured after their death. What did the person do to earn the honour? How did people honour that person?

Defining the Scenes

Defining the Scenes

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 31:1–13 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will define the scenes, characters, and setting of this passage. Then the group will visualize this passage.

This passage has six scenes.

In the first scene: Back in Jezreel, the Philistines fight the Israelites on Mount Gilboa and kill many Israelite soldiers. The Israelites, including King Saul and three of Saul's sons, run away, but the Philistines catch up to the men and kill them.

In the second scene: The Philistines fight fiercely against Saul and get close to where Saul is. Then the archers' arrows hit Saul and wound Saul very badly. Saul asks his armor-bearer to kill Saul, but the armor-bearer refuses because the armor-bearer is scared. Saul kills himself by falling on the point of Saul's sword. When the armor-bearer sees this, Saul's armor-bearer throws himself on his own sword and kills himself.

In the third scene: Now, the storyteller summarises what happened that day. Saul, three of Saul's sons, and Saul's armor-bearer all die on the same day, along with all of Saul's soldiers who do not run away or the men closest to Saul who are surrounding Saul.

In the fourth scene: The storyteller pauses the story about the battle between Israel and the Philistines to tell what happens after the Philistines won. The Israelite people who lived on the other side of the Jezreel Valley, and those who lived beyond the Jordan River, realised that the Israelite army had run away and that Saul and three of Saul's sons died. The Israelites flee or run away from their cities to live somewhere else. Then the Philistine soldiers and their families come into the empty cities and live there.

In the fifth scene: The storyteller now returns to the story of the battle. The day after people fought, the Philistine soldiers go back to Mount Gilboa to take valuable things like weapons and armour from the dead Israelite soldiers. The Philistines find Saul and Saul's three sons lying dead, and they cut off Saul's head and remove Saul's military clothes and the weapons he carried. The Philistines send men all over the land of Philistia to share the good news that Saul is dead and that the Philistines won the battle.

In the sixth scene: The Philistines put Saul's armour and weapons in the temple of their goddess, Ashtoreth, and the Philistines hang Saul's dead body on the outside wall of one of their cities called Beth Shan. The Israelites from the city of Jabesh Gilead hear how the Philistines insult Saul's dead body, so the Israelites come and take the dead bodies of Saul and Saul's sons down from the wall of Beth Shan, carry the bodies back to Jabesh Gilead, and burn the bodies. The Israelites bury the burned bones under a tamarisk tree in Jabesh. Then the people of Jabesh fast, or stop eating, for seven days.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Philistine army

  • Israelite army

  • King Saul

  • Three of Saul's sons: Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchi Shua

  • Philistine archers

  • Saul's armor-bearer

  • Saul's men who died with Saul

  • Israelites, or Israelite people who lived on the other side of the Jezreel Valley and beyond the Jordan River, who ran away from their homes

  • Israelite soldiers who ran away from the Philistines

  • Philistine soldiers who moved into the homes that the Israelites had run away from

  • Philistines, or Philistine people

  • Israelite people who lived in the city of Jabesh in the region of Gilead

  • And brave Israelite warriors from the city of Jabesh

As a group, pay attention to these parts of the passage's setting:

The storyteller starts with language that introduces a new event, but shows that this story continues from where the storyteller paused it before. The story goes back to when the Philistine army set up camp in Shunem and Saul gathered the Israelite army at Mount Gilboa, about 10 to 15 kilometres south of Shunem in the valley of Jezreel. The events take place at the same time that David and David's men are chasing the Amalekites.

Stop here and discuss as a group how you will start this passage to show that this is a new event, but at the same time, that this story continues from where the storyteller paused before. Pause this audio here.

Back in Jezreel, the Philistines fight the Israelites on Mount Gilboa. The Philistines kill many Israelite soldiers. The Israelites, including King Saul and Saul's sons, run away quickly to save their lives. But the Philistines catch up to Saul and his sons and kill three of Saul's sons: Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malki Shua. Here, the storyteller repeats the word "Philistines" several times to stress that it is the Philistines who kill the Israelites.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel. Locate Mount Gilboa, where the Israelites and the Philistines fought the battle. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: What are the natural ways in your language to stress that it was the Philistines who killed the Israelites? Pause this audio here.

The Philistines fight fiercely against Saul and Saul's men. The Philistines get close to where Saul is. The Philistines attack hard, fighting the men who are still with Saul, including Saul's bodyguard. Then the archers find Saul. In the original language, "archers" means men with bows. The word "find" here means that the archers' arrows find their target, Saul, and hit Saul. The arrows wound Saul very badly. Saul is in severe pain from the arrows, and Saul cannot move easily.

Then Saul asks his armor-bearer to pull out the armor-bearer's sword and kill Saul by stabbing Saul. Saul wants his armor-bearer to kill him because Saul is afraid the Philistines will kill Saul slowly and painfully. Saul also worries the Philistines will mock Saul and hurt him for their own entertainment. Saul calls the Philistines "uncircumcised fellows," a negative term the Israelites used for the Philistines. The armor-bearer is very scared and refuses to kill Saul. Since Saul's armor-bearer will not kill him, Saul pulls out his own sword and kills himself by falling on the sword's point.

Stop here and talk as a group about the negative words or nicknames that people in your community use to describe people from enemy nations or people groups. Pause this audio here.

When the man who carried Saul's armour sees that Saul is dead, the man throws himself on the point of his own sword and kills himself. The armour-bearer dies at about the same time, in the same place, and in the same way as Saul.

Now the storyteller summarises what happened that day. Saul, three of Saul's sons, and the young man who carried Saul's armour all die. These people die on the same day, along with all of Saul's men. Please note that the phrase "all of Saul's men" does not mean the Philistines kill every single Israelite soldier, but all of Saul's soldiers who do not run away or the men closest to Saul who are surrounding Saul. Saul and these people all die in the same battle on the same day.

The storyteller pauses the story about the battle between Israel and the Philistines to tell what happens after the Philistines won. The Israelite people who lived on the other side of the Jezreel Valley, and those who lived beyond the Jordan River, saw and realised that the Israelite army ran away and that Saul and three of Saul's sons died. In this case, "men of Israel" refers both to the Israelite people and the Israelite army. The other side of the Jezreel Valley means the north side, which is also called the Plain of Jezreel. The "area beyond the Jordan" could mean either the east side of the Jordan River or the cities near the river on the west side. When the Israelites in these areas realised that the Philistines had defeated Saul's army and Saul's army ran away, these Israelites ran away from their cities to live somewhere else. The idea of running away appears twice in the story because the storyteller wants to show that the Israelite army ran away quickly, and the Israelite people also ran away in a similar way. Then the Philistine soldiers and their families come into the empty cities, live there and take control of the area.

Stop here and, as a group, look at a map of Israel and locate the area from where the Israelites ran away and which the Philistines took over. Pause this audio here.

The storyteller now goes back to the story of the battle. The day after the people fought, the Philistine soldiers go back to Mount Gilboa to take valuable things like weapons and armour from the dead Israelite soldiers. While doing this, the Philistines find Saul and Saul's three sons lying dead.

The Philistine soldiers cut off Saul's head and take off Saul's armour. Saul's "armour" also refers to Saul's weapons. So the Philistines remove Saul's military clothes and the weapons Saul carried, like his sword, shield, and spear. After this, the Philistines send men all over the land of Philistia to share the good news that Saul is dead and that the Philistines won the battle. These men announce the good news in the temples of their idols and to the Philistine people, possibly in public places like markets or smaller worship areas.

Stop here and look as a group at pictures of the kinds of armour and weapons that Saul may have had. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what words you have in your language for armour and weapons. What do soldiers in your people group wear for battle? Pause this audio here.

The Philistines put Saul's armour and weapons in the temple of their goddess, Ashtoreth, to show Ashtoreth's power. Please note that the word "armour" means "armour and weapons" as in the previous passage. The Philistines called the goddess "Astarte" in their language. The name Ashtoreth was the Hebrew version and had a negative meaning of shame. Because people had many idols of the goddess in the temple, the storyteller talks about the temple of the Ashtoreths—the many idols of Ashtoreth. The Philistines hang Saul's dead body on the outside wall of Beth Shan, one of their cities, to insult Saul and the Israelites.

Stop here and discuss as a group: What are the ways you can make a name sound shameful in your language? How are you going to translate the name Ashtoreth or Astarte into your language? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look at a map of Israel and locate the city of Beth Shan. Pause this audio here.

But when the people in the city of Jabesh Gilead hear the news about how the Philistines have insulted Saul's dead body, all the brave warriors from Jabesh Gilead leave their city and travel all night to the city of Beth Shan. Jabesh is in the region of Gilead, on the east side of the Jordan River, about 32 kilometers from Beth Shan. The brave warriors take Saul's dead body and the bodies of Saul's sons down from the wall of Beth Shan. The men carry the bodies back to Jabesh and burn the bodies. Afterward, the warriors gather the burned bones and bury the bones under a tamarisk tree in Jabesh. Then the people of Jabesh fast, or stop eating, for seven days to honour Saul and show their sadness because Saul had died.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: "Brave warriors" means "the most courageous warriors." How would you describe someone like that in your language? Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss this question as a group: The city of Jabesh is called Jabesh Gilead in this story to show that it was Jabesh in the region of Gilead. If your country has cities or towns with the same name but in different regions, how do you tell them apart? Pause this audio here.

Now, the group should storyboard, draw, or use objects to visualize the passage and the action in it.

Embodying the Text

Embodying the Text

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 31:1–13 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will dramatize the passage.

This passage has six scenes.

The characters in this passage are:

  • Philistine army

  • Israelite army

  • King Saul

  • Three of Saul's sons: Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchi Shua

  • Philistine archers

  • Saul's armor-bearer

  • Saul's men who died with Saul

  • Israelites, or Israelite people who lived on the other side of the Jezreel Valley and beyond the Jordan River, who ran away from their homes

  • Israelite soldiers who ran away from the Philistines

  • Philistine soldiers who moved into the homes that the Israelites had run away from

  • Philistines, or Philistine people

  • Israelite people who lived in the city of Jabesh in the region of Gilead

  • And brave Israelite warriors from the city of Jabesh

As a group, act out the passage twice. You should act out the passage in your own language.

First, act out the passage without stopping. Pay attention to the dialogue, flow, plotline, and chronology of the passage. Make sure you do not skip acting out the difficult or important parts of the passage. Help each other remember every part of the passage.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage.

The group should act out this passage a second time. At certain points in the drama, pause the drama and ask the person playing the character, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person playing the character should answer what they would be feeling or thinking if they were that character. Then continue the drama.

Pause this audio here and act out the passage a second time.

The following is an example of the drama and possible responses.

Back in Jezreel, the Philistines fight the Israelites on Mount Gilboa. The Philistines kill many Israelite soldiers. The Israelites, including King Saul and Saul's sons, run away quickly. The Philistines catch up to Saul and Saul's sons and kill three of Saul's sons: Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malki Shua.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Philistines, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are so happy that we are winning against the Israelites at last; or

  • We are grateful to our goddess Astarte, who is helping us; or

  • We are so happy that we killed Saul's three sons. Now we need to kill Saul.

The Philistines fight fiercely against Saul, and the Philistines get close to where Saul is. Then the archers' arrows find their target, Saul, and hit Saul. The arrows wound Saul very badly. Saul asks Saul's armor-bearer to kill Saul by stabbing him. The armor-bearer is very scared and refuses to kill Saul. Saul pulls out his own sword and kills himself by falling on the sword's point. When Saul's armor-bearer sees that Saul is dead, the armor-bearer throws himself on the point of his own sword and kills himself.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing Saul, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am desperate. My sons are dead, and now I am badly wounded; or

  • I am afraid that the Philistines will treat me badly; or

  • My only hope is in death.

Ask the person playing Saul's armor-bearer, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • I am scared. King Saul asked me to kill him, but I am here to save Saul's life; or

  • I failed at my job—King Saul killed himself; or

  • My only hope is in death.

Now the storyteller summarises what happened that day. Saul, three of Saul's sons, and the young man who carried Saul's armour all die. The men die on the same day, along with all of Saul's soldiers who do not run away, or the men closest to Saul who are surrounding Saul.

The narrator pauses the story about the battle between Israel and the Philistines to tell what happens after the Philistines won. The Israelite people living on the other side of the Jezreel Valley, and those living beyond the Jordan River, saw and realised that the Israelite army fled or ran away and that Saul and three of Saul's sons died. When this happened, the Israelites fled or ran away from their cities to live somewhere else. Then the Philistine soldiers and their families came into the empty cities and lived there.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the Israelites on the other side of the Jezreel Valley and those living beyond the Jordan River, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are scared because Saul's army has fled, and King Saul is dead; or

  • We are in a state of panic! Who is going to protect us from the Philistines now? The Philistines will kill us," or

  • We must run away as soon as we can. Yahweh will provide another place for us to live.

The narrator now goes back to the story of the battle. The day after the fighting, the Philistine soldiers go back to Mount Gilboa to take valuable things like weapons and armour from the dead Israelite soldiers. The Philistines find Saul and Saul's three sons lying dead. The Philistines cut off Saul's head and remove Saul's military clothes and the weapons Saul carried. After this, the Philistines send men all over the land of Philistia to share the good news that Saul is dead and that the Philistines won the battle. These men announce the good news in the temples of their idols and to the Philistine people, possibly in public places like markets or smaller worship areas.

The Philistines put Saul's armour and weapons in the temple of the Philistines' goddess, Ashtoreth. The Philistines hang Saul's dead body on the outside wall of one of their cities called Beth Shan. When the Israelites from the city of Jabesh in the region of Gilead hear the news about how the Philistines have insulted Saul's dead body, all the brave warriors leave the city and travel all night to the city of Beth Shan. The warriors take Saul's dead body and the bodies of Saul's sons down from the wall of Beth Shan, carry the bodies back to Jabesh, and burn the bodies. The warriors gather the burned bones and bury the bones under a tamarisk tree in Jabesh. Then the people of Jabesh fast, or stop eating, for seven days.

Pause the drama.

Ask the person playing the people of the city of Jabesh, "What are you feeling or thinking?" The person might answer things like:

  • We are so sad and angry that the Philistines killed Saul and treated Saul's dead body so disrespectfully; or

  • Saul was kind to us and saved us from the Ammonites. We are now going to get Saul's body and bring it back to our city and bury it in an honourable way; or

  • We are so happy that we went to Beth Shan and were able to rescue the bodies of Saul and his sons. We will honour Saul and Saul's sons by burying their bones under the tamarisk tree, and we will fast for seven days.

Filling the Gaps

Filling the Gaps

Listen to an audio version of 1 Samuel 31:1–13 in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this step, the group will discuss key terms and words in this passage.

The Philistines fight against Israel on Mount Gilboa, and the men of Israel run away from the Philistines. Use the same word or phrase for Israel as you used in previous passages. For more information on Israel, refer to the Master Glossary.

The Philistines fight fiercely against Saul. Then the archers find Saul, or their arrows find their target, Saul, and hit Saul.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for archer. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and look as a group at a picture of an archer shooting arrows with a bow. Pause this audio here.

Then Saul asks his armor-bearer to pull out the armor-bearer's sword and kill Saul by stabbing Saul, so that the uncircumcised fellows do not kill Saul slowly and painfully. The Israelites circumcised their sons as a sign of the Israelites' special agreement with God, and the Israelites looked down on uncircumcised men. Use the same words or phrases for sword, armour-bearer, and uncircumcised as you used in previous passages. For more information on circumcision, refer to the Master Glossary.

The Israelites on the other side of the Jezreel Valley and beyond the Jordan River also ran away. Use the same word or phrase for Jordan River as you have used previously. Jordan River is in the Master Glossary.

The Philistines send men all over the land of Philistia to share the good news that Saul is dead and that the Philistines won the battle. These men announce the good news in the houses, or temples, of their idols and to the Philistine people. Use the same word or phrase for temple as you used in previous passages. For more information on temple, refer to the Master Glossary.

An idol is an object that people make in order to worship a god. The object reminds the people about some characteristics of this god. People make an object or an image of a god and worship that object as if it were that god. God forbade the Israelites in God's commandments to ever make such an idol, or image, or to worship anything else besides God himself.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for idol. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there. For more information on idol, refer to the Master Glossary. Pause this audio here.

Afterward, the warriors gather the burned bones and bury the bones under a tamarisk tree in Jabesh.

Stop here and, as a group, look at a picture of a tamarisk tree. Pause this audio here.

Stop here and discuss as a group what word or phrase you will use for tamarisk tree. If you have already translated this word in another book of the Bible, use the same word that you have used there.

Speaking the Word

Speaking the Word

Listen to an audio version of the passage in the easiest-to-understand translation.

Pause this audio here.

In this session, retell the passage, as a group, in your own language.

First, the whole group should practice telling the passage in your own language. Remember to include the things you decided in previous steps, like chronology, words, phrases, emotions, or anything else you discussed.

One group member should tell a few sentences of the passage and pause. Another group member should tell the next part of the passage and pause. Do this until the group has retold the whole passage. The group members can correct each other in this step.

Pause this audio here.

Next, each member of the group should tell the whole passage without interruption at least one time. A group member can use random objects, motions, or their storyboard to help them remember the passage.

Pause this audio here.

Next, the group can decide whose version of the passage you like the most. You may decide that you liked the way one group member told one scene but you liked the way a different group member told another scene.

Pause this audio here.

Finally, the group can put together a final version of the passage that everyone agrees on. Each group member should practice telling this final version of the passage.
